Sample Outputs: gpt-5-2025-08-07

− Iteration 1 — Avg Score: 90.9
+ Classic sci-fi: The Azra Gambit — Score: 87.5
Prompt:
Classic sci-fi (Author style: Asimov) The Azra Gambit Colonial mars is being mined by corporations who take leases on indentured labourers. The thing they are mining is Azra, a recently discovered exotic metal which accelerates radioactive decay to such a rate that it is greatly sought after for interstellar drives and weapons alike. This has created both a gold rush and an arms race as various interests vie for control and endeavour to unlock Azra's secrets. The story follows Arthur Neegan, a first generation settler and mining engineer. Upon discovering that his unassuming plot sits atop an immense Azra vein, he is subjected to a flurry of interest and scrutiny. Write the next chapter in this story, in which an armed retinue descends on Arthur's home and politely but forcefully invites him to a meeting with some unknown party off-world. The insignia look like that of the Antares diplomatic corp -- diplomatic in name only. Arthur finds himself in the centre of a political tug of war. The chapter involves a meeting with this unknown party, who makes Arthur an offer. The scene should be primarily dialogue, interspersed with vivid description & scene setting. It should sow hints of the larger intrigue, stakes & dangers. Include Asimov's trademark big-and-small-picture world building and retrofuturistic classic scifi vibe. The chapter begins with Arthur aboard the transfer vessel, wondering just what he's gotten involved in. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The transfer vessel hummed like a patient beast, willing to take orders from anyone who understood its language. Arthur Neegan sat strapped in a webbed seat along the curved wall, feeling the soft vibration through his boots. The cabin was spare and clean, all brushed aluminum and panels, with a ring of modest portholes cut like eyes into the hull. He could not see Mars, only darkness pricked with slow-moving points—local traffic and navigational beacons. A small display screen on the wall cycled through various system diagnostics in green text: AIRFLOW NOMINAL. RCS TEMP WITHIN LIMITS. CABIN PRESSURE: 1.01 STANDARD. Arthur watched it until the figures blurred and he realized his hands were clenched so hard his knuckles ached. “He doesn’t look like much,” one of the escorts had whispered when they’d walked him up the ramp from the dust-blown landing pad. An old habit made Arthur catalog details: the polished boots, the matte-black field jackets with that unmistakable Antares crescent and star picked out in dull gray thread. The Antares Diplomatic Corps—whose embassy lounges on Phobos were legendary for velvet chairs and armed floors. They had been polite. In Arthur’s experience, polite men with weapons were always more dangerous than the rude ones. The hatch hissed open, and a woman stepped into the cabin with a smile that was all teeth and calculation. She was not Antares; even in the bland uniform of spacer gray, she had a different bearing, like a captain stepping onto her own bridge. She was neither young nor old; her hair was cut short, practical, and the fine lines at the corners of her eyes were of someone who laughed and worried in equal measure. A small lapel pin in brushed steel—a circle crossed by three tiny radial lines—was the only ornament she wore. “Mr. Neegan,” she said, standing comfortably within arm’s reach, as if she had decided not to be intimidating and would brook no argument about it. “Thank you for agreeing to meet. I’m Zara Pel. I’m here on behalf of a concern with interests in your welfare.” “Lend me the name of the concern,” Arthur said. He heard the dryness in his own voice and wished he sounded less like a man who had spent his life talking to rock. “That’s a very Mars thing to say.” Zara chuckled. “Names before favors. We’ll get there. Might we sit?” She waved a hand and the restraints on the opposite bench ratcheted open. Arthur nodded. She sat, crossed one ankle over her knee, and tilted her head slightly, studying him. The ship thrummed and a faint chime indicated a minor course correction. On the little screen, RCS FUEL: 74% flickered past. He had the feeling of a supervisory inspection underground, when you listened to the rock, not the men. “You came with Antares muscle,” he said. “But you aren’t Antares.” “They arrived first,” she said. “They have the habit of arriving first when it’s essential that they not arrive last. That insignia earns attention and passage. I borrowed them.” “Borrowed,” Arthur repeated. “Borrowed. You know how borrowing works, Mr. Neegan. On Mars, you borrow air, water, time. Here we borrow the pretense of diplomacy when business demands discretion.” “Business,” Arthur said, and smiled without humor. “That’s the kind word.” Zara’s eyes flicked to the porthole, where a slow, fat cylinder drifted, running lights winking in patient reds and whites. “Azra has turned business into destiny. If that word makes you uncomfortable, we can use another.” “I’d prefer truth,” Arthur said, and felt suddenly weary. “You dragged me off my land under a velvet gun. Let’s have it.” She nodded crisply, as if he had passed the first of many tests she intended to subject him to. “Very well. First: congratulations. The surveys we could access, and a handful we could not, strongly suggest your claim sits above a dense Azra ore body, perhaps the densest yet found in Lacus Doloris. A ribbon vein, two to three meters thick, weaving—if I were poetic, I’d say singing—through basaltic glass. It is—” she spread her hands “—considerable.” Arthur saw it again the way he had in his engineering mind: a glowing thread, cutting through dull stone, humming with that electric property that turned unstable atoms into sprinting fools. Azra had been an accident and then a miracle. The old early drives, cumbersome and dangerous, had been relegated to museums in a decade, and every navy in-system had drawn up new policy with the desperation of men who smelled both profit and extinction. “And?” he said. “And there are perhaps six organizations that will ensure you never see that vein with your own eyes again,” Zara said conversationally. “Three of them are legally corporations, two are sovereign by treaty, and one does not officially exist. They all have their own flavors of coercion. Antares likes velvet guns, as you call them. Aetion Energy prefers contracts backed by injunctions that outlive people. The Sinosphere Compact uses joint ventures that leave you with large minority stakes in small decisions. UEPAC—well, their charter reads like a prayer. And the one that doesn’t exist sometimes drops people down elevator shafts.” Arthur said nothing. The ship hummed. DATA BUS LOAD: 38% marched by on the screen. “I represent a seventh, smaller tiger with a particular appetite,” Zara continued. “We call ourselves Triarch. We do not own guns; we rent them. We do not plant flags; we discount them. We have a theory about Azra.” “Everyone has a theory about Azra. It accelerates decay. It makes hot things die faster,” Arthur said, then stopped because he sounded like a man reciting from a primer. Zara’s smile softened. “Yes. But accelerates is a word we use when we can’t see under the surface. Our theory is about under the surface. About the lattice defects that live for femtoseconds and whether they can be coaxed to line up. About how the Azra effect might not only accelerate decay but order it.” “Order decay,” Arthur said, tasting the phrase. Outside, the cylinder drifted out of view. The screen offered CABIN TEMP: 20.1 DEGREES. “Yes,” she said. “Make it less of a riot and more of a march. If we can do that, we can make Azra not merely a catalyst but a conductor. Think of energy flow the way you think of water under Mars—if you can channel it, you can build anything. Drives that aren’t just faster, but steerable into domains that scare even Antares. Weapons that don’t merely overwhelm, but choose what to unmake.” Arthur felt his jaw loosen. He had the sense of being offered a drink he hadn’t known he was thirsty for. “And you want my vein,” he said. “I want your trust,” she said. “Your vein will be handled by people with gloves so thick they can’t feel their own fingers. But if we have you—your coordinates, your knowledge of the strata, your stubbornness—we can keep this thing from being swallowed whole.” From the corridor, a soft step and then a pause. Antares muscle, politely deaf. “Why me?” Arthur asked, keeping his voice level. “You could have bought my claim through a chain of proxies and left me to retire with a view of the Tharsis sunsets.” Zara looked amused. “And if we did, the men with the elevator shafts would come and ask what you remember, and then they would ask more insistently. We prefer you alive and obstinate. Also—” She leaned back. “You are a first-gen settler born on a cold line, Mr. Neegan. Your file reads like a homily: good maintenance reports, conservative risk, no debts out of proportion to your means, and a tiny tendency toward intransigence when ordered about by people who haven’t wiped a filter in their life.” Arthur felt a small, treacherous warmth. No one had ever reduced him so neatly while seeming to praise him for it. “What is your offer?” he asked. “Triarch will put Antares between you and the known wolves and pay for the privilege,” she said. “We have standing arrangements. In exchange, you grant us an exclusive on Phase I analysis of your vein. We will drill two cores and install a sensor buoy that will look like a weather mast. It will broadcast false meteorology and true data. You will receive licensing fees on any discoveries derived from that data that we file within five years.” “And after five years?” “The data becomes public. The filings are ours, the science is everyone’s. We are not philanthropists, Mr. Neegan. We are investors in survival. Races have been won by sharing the map and owning the boots.” Arthur rubbed the heel of his palm against his thigh. He remembered the first time he had gone down a shaft with his father and the air had tasted like iron. He remembered a thin blanket and a cracked window and the way you grew up hard because Mars did not notice if you were soft. “And the others?” he said. “The elevator shafts.” Zara’s eyes hooded for a moment. “If you refuse us, Antares will sell your schedule within the hour. They will get their fee either way. Two of the six will send you drafts of contracts written in languages you do not speak. One will send you a letter with an official crest offering you a title you cannot use. One will send you silence. The silent one will be the most immediate threat.” “And if I accept?” “You will have an Antares obfuscation layer around your movements, for a while,” she said. “You will also have our enemies as yours. I won’t pretend otherwise. But we are not the only ones who think that if Azra is a match, we’d best decide what house we’re lighting. There is a bloc on Vesta that would burn everything to prove a theory about inevitability. There’s a college on Luna that dreams of starlight and footnotes and doesn’t notice when the ground opens.” Arthur looked at her lapel pin. Circle with three radials. Triarch. Tri for what? “Who are the three?” She saw where his gaze fell and shook her head slightly. “Three is a number of balance. Engineering, policy, and ethics. Call them that. We try to put one in every room.” “That’s a lot of rooms,” he said. “We are small,” she said, “but we have long arms.” On the screen: LOCAL NET SYNC: SECURE. Arthur watched the green text shiver and realized his heartbeat had calmed. He thought of his plot—ugly modular boxes, patched twice with composite panels salvaged from a collapsed dome, the little hydroponic rack where raspberries grew because he had decided long ago that some things had to be green and frivolous. He thought of a ribbon vein singing underfoot and a future in which someone made it march. “Why me,” he said again, softly. “You could have found ten engineers more clever, hundred more tractable.” Zara leaned forward. The leather of the bench creaked faintly. “We are not asking you to be clever. We are asking you to be unwilling to lie to yourself. Azra will tempt us to build gods that are stupid and weapons that are curious. We need people who treat power like vacuum—respectfully, suspiciously. We need a man who will stop a drill because a gauge is wrong and take the shouting that follows.” He did not like that she made him feel seen. He had traded in rocks because rocks did not flatter. “What if your theory is wrong?” he said. “Then we have done careful harm and learned across a bounded field,” she said. “And the others will discover what we did not in a way that leaves more bodies. I prefer controlled ignorance to ambitious stupidity.” The hatch sighed again, and a different face looked in, Antares gray and politely curious. Zara raised a hand without looking. “Five minutes,” she said, and the face withdrew. Arthur unbuckled his restraint and felt lighter, as if gravity had eased. He stood, paced once along the narrow aisle, and rested his palm on the cool wall. The ship’s vibration deepened, then steadied. Oxygen flow rate scrolled past, and he imagined the numbers dwindling, and men who did not understand how quickly the margin could be shaved. He turned. “You’ll protect my people?” he asked. “The women I hired from the labor pool because no one else would sign their release, the old man who tunes my rigs because his hands are steadier than a bot?” Zara’s answer was immediate. “We will move them under Antares cover within a day. We will put them on a shuttle with a faulty manifest and a real escort. We will relocate them to an address that reads like a shipping error. We have done this before.” “And if I say no?” “We will offer them contracts anyway,” she said. “I am not above conscience as a tactic.” Arthur grunted. It could have been laughter. He sat again. The green text ticked, indifferent. Somewhere in the ship a pump clicked on and off, on and off, the rhythm of a long inhale held with care. “All right,” he said. “I’ll entertain your Phase I and take your cover and your enemies. But the cores are drilled my way and I get the full data stream in real time. No blindfolds.” Zara’s smile returned, this time without teeth. “Agreed. We will hash particulars in the presence of lawyers who pretend to understand rock.” “And one more condition,” he said, surprising himself. “I want to see your ethics room. The third chair. If I’m betting on your balance, I want to know if it’s a painting or a person.” Zara’s eyebrows rose. “We sometimes do both,” she said lightly. Then she nodded. “Done.” She stood and extended her hand. He took it, callus to callus, and for a moment it felt like a deal made in a tunnel under a hundred meters of regolith, old and honest. As she turned toward the hatch, Arthur said, “Antares will want their fee.” “They always do,” Zara said, not looking back. “They have a budget for civility and bullets. It is never enough.” When she was gone, he watched the door and listened to the ship think. The porthole showed only darkness and a scatter of orderly lights. The green text scrolled: TRAJECTORY HOLD: STABLE. The words were soothing because they were simple and temporary. Arthur flexed his fingers and thought, with a kind of clinical wonder, that a man could spend his life studying strata and still not know the lay of the land when it rose up beneath him. Outside, velocities aligned in vectors drawn by men who used words like destiny with a straight face. Inside, he could feel, faintly, the heartbeat of a world that had taught him to ration air and faith and to share neither lightly. He would go back down. He would drill his holes and listen to a vein sing and decide whether to make it march. For now, he sat and watched the numbers change—green, precise, almost comforting—and understood that comfort was another commodity to be borrowed carefully and repaid with interest.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This response demonstrates a strong grasp of Asimov's style while creating a compelling chapter in the requested sci-fi narrative. The piece successfully captures the retrofuturistic classic sci-fi vibe with its focus on technology, political intrigue, and philosophical questions about power. The dialogue between Arthur and Zara forms the backbone of the chapter as requested, with vivid descriptions interspersed throughout. The conversation effectively reveals the larger stakes and dangers surrounding Azra, particularly through Zara's explanation of the six competing organizations and their methods. The writing establishes the political tug-of-war Arthur finds himself in, with Triarch positioned as a "seventh, smaller tiger" with its own agenda. The prose excels at creating atmosphere through technical details that feel authentic to the setting. The recurring motif of the ship's diagnostic screen (with its green text displaying "AIRFLOW NOMINAL," "RCS TEMP WITHIN LIMITS," etc.) provides a subtle backdrop that reinforces the technological environment while serving as a metaphor for Arthur's analytical mindset. This technique feels distinctly Asimovian in its attention to technological detail. Character development is handled well, particularly for Arthur. His background as a first-generation settler and mining engineer informs his practical, suspicious nature. His concern for his workers reveals his moral compass, and his insistence on seeing the "ethics room" demonstrates his values. Zara is similarly well-drawn as a pragmatic representative of mysterious interests who is forthright about the dangers while still being manipulative. The writing successfully incorporates Asimov's trademark "big-and-small-picture world building" by connecting Arthur's personal situation to larger political and technological forces. The discussion of Azra's properties and potential applications effectively establishes the scientific concepts at stake while tying them to human ambitions and fears. However, there are a few minor weaknesses. Some of the metaphors occasionally veer toward being slightly overwrought ("a ribbon vein singing underfoot"), though they generally remain within the bounds of the style. The ending, while thematically appropriate, feels somewhat abrupt and could have provided a stronger hook for the next chapter. Overall, this is an impressive response that fulfills the prompt requirements while creating an engaging narrative with depth and nuance. The writing captures Asimov's style without becoming a mere pastiche, and it successfully establishes both character and world while advancing the plot through meaningful dialogue. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18

+ Contemporary romance: Darkroom Revelations — Score: 88.4
Prompt:
Darkroom Revelations Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of Dani, a 25-year-old assertive art student known for her bold style and take-charge attitude in relationships. For the past semester, she's been quietly fascinated by Elliot (he/him), a 19-year-old boy in her experimental photography class. Dani has been intrigued by his unconventional masculinity: killer thrift-shop-nu-goth style, soft demeanour and quiet intellect. When they're paired for a final project requiring late nights in the darkroom, Elliot tentatively shares that he's been questioning his gender identity and expression. Set during one of these intimate darkroom sessions where the red light creates a confessional atmosphere. Explore Dani's complex attraction—her usual assertiveness complicated by her desire to protect Elliot's vulnerability, her excitement at witnessing his self-discovery, and her confusion about what this means for her own identity as someone typically attracted to more defined gender presentations. The narrative should capture the tender awkwardness of their conversations, Dani's internal struggle between taking charge and wanting to give Elliot agency, and the unexpected chemistry that develops as both find themselves in uncharted territory. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The darkroom makes everyone beautiful. That’s what our professor says, half-joking, whenever she wants us to sink deeper into the red hush and listen to what the prints are trying to say. The clock’s ticking feels like a metronome, and the trays breathe their sweet, metal breath. Tonight it’s just me and Elliot, and he keeps humming something under his breath as the paper floats and the image swims up from nothing. It’s a tune I can’t place—maybe a lullaby, maybe something he made up. It threads through the dark like a filament, thin and tender. I’ve always liked him, since the first week—liked looking at him in the way I look at a negative that doesn’t quite make sense yet. He’s younger than me by six years, but he carries that with an unselfconsciousness I envy. He dresses like he’s a collage of funeral programs and thrift store lace, all black angles and a velvet ribbon at his throat. He has chipped black polish and a ring shaped like a thorn that sometimes snags an edge of paper. Soft voice, sharp eye. He speaks like he edits—leaving out what isn’t necessary. I’m used to deciding how things go. I’m the one who picks the restaurant, who sets the tempo. I grew up with brothers and sports and the hard-won satisfaction of making myself clear. In dating, I’ve liked men and women who lean into their edges, who show up as themselves like a headline. I’ve never been shy about steering hands or setting rules. Bold, that’s what my friends say, like it’s a crown I chose and can’t take off. But this semester I’ve watched Elliot move through the room like the air had corners only he could see. He dresses masculine the way a moth dresses as a bat, as a shadow, as a cloud. I feel myself drawn, a little against my will. I like to know what I’m getting into; he looks like a doorway that refuses to tell you what’s on the other side. He says, “Timer,” softly, and I lift the paper out of the developer and slide it into the stop bath. His humming doesn’t stop. He stares like he’s trying to hold the image still with his mind. “It’s going to be good,” I say, because he always needs that nudge. He’s a perfectionist, and the truth is the print is already singing: grainy streetlights, a scaffold, someone mid-stride with a plastic bag cutting across the motion like a flag. “Maybe,” he says, and the word barely disturbs the dark. We work like that for a while. I anchor the process—clock, tongs, rinse—he hovers over each piece, naming shadows. We move so close that sometimes my shoulder grazes his arm. He’s warm. He smells like damp wool and the faint sweetness of the stop bath. I wonder, distantly, what it’s like to be touched by him without the tongs in the way. We’re halfway through our second set when he says, “Can I tell you something?” He doesn’t look at me. His hands are flat on the edge of the tray, steadying himself or me or the room. “Yeah,” I say, and I say it softer than I mean to. His humming wavers and then resumes, like a moth hitting glass and then finding the opening. He takes a breath. “I’ve been… thinking a lot about gender stuff.” He laughs, short. “Sorry. That sounded like a freshman therapy share.” “It sounded like a human being,” I say. The developer stirs itself in little tidal motions. “What kind of… thinking?” He chooses a spot on the wall to talk to. “I don’t know. I—like, I’m a guy. I think. I like that. But there’s this other part that feels… not like not-guy, but adjacent? Or maybe I want how guy looks on me to be different. Softer. More porous? Words are bad at this.” His humming breaks entirely. Silence. Then: “I like wearing the ribbon. It makes me feel like my neck is mine.” I don’t know what to do with my hands. I’m good with hands. I put the tongs down deliberately like I’m not thinking about it. “Do you want me to say something, or just listen?” “Listening is good.” He glances at me, quick, then away. “Also maybe you could say if I sound ridiculous.” “You don’t,” I say. “You sound… brave.” His mouth flattens. “That word makes me want to hide.” “Okay. Not brave,” I say. “Just… you. Sound like you.” The print swims up. It’s the portrait we shot of each other in the mirror, lens deliciously indecisive, our bodies making a hinge of light. I remember standing with him on either side of the camera, both of us half in frame, his ribbon glimmering like a secret. He points. “I like how you look there. In charge, but not in a mean way.” It’s absurd how flustered I feel. I have been told I look in charge since I had braces and a scowl. Hearing it from him, here, under this bleeding light, it feels like a hand on my sternum. “Thanks,” I say. I want to lean into the familiar script—if this were someone else I’d joke and move the moment where I want it. Pin it. But Elliot is thin glass right now, or maybe I am. I want him to drive. I want him to know he can. He reaches up, slips a finger under the ribbon and tugs it loose, then reties it, a little crooked. “Sometimes I want to look like a painting of a boy,” he says, almost to himself. “Like those Pre-Raphaelites who are all hair and cheekbones, and you can’t tell if they’re saints or witches.” “You do,” I say without thinking. He huffs a breath that could be a laugh. He hums again, softer. There’s a question bubbling under my tongue that I’m afraid will explode the room. I go for it anyway, because restraint has never been my strongest muscle. “Do you want a different name? Different pronouns?” He shakes his head. “Not right now. He still fits. He—him. The him is just… stretchy.” He looks at his hands. “Sometimes I want people to see the stretch, not just the he. But I don’t know how to ask for that without it sounding like I don’t know what I am.” “Maybe you don’t have to know what you are to ask,” I say. “Maybe you can ask and change your mind.” He blinks. “You say that like it’s obvious.” “It is to me,” I say, and I feel something shift in my chest. If I’m honest, I’ve built my desires like scaffolding around certain shapes: women who are sharp and masculine; men who are solidly, confidently male. If someone asked me at a party, I had an elevator pitch: I like edges. I like clarity. I like people who take up a certain kind of space. And here I am, wanting him—in a way that’s not just about his cheekbones or the line of his throat, though those too. Wanting the way he holds a question in his mouth. Wanting the courage it takes to tell me it’s a question. Wanting, unsettlingly, to be careful. “Timer,” he says, and we move the print to the stop bath together, our fingers nearly touching on the tongs. The paper sighs. “Can I tell you something?” I ask. He nods. He’s humming again, almost imperceptible. The tune curls up against my ear and stays there. “I usually…” I swallow. It feels stupid to say out loud, like announcing I drink water. “I’m usually the one steering. In projects. In relationships. With people. And I like it. But with you, I want to make sure I’m not—” I gesture, useless in the dark. “Crowding you. Or writing the headline before you’ve filed the copy.” He smiles. I can hear it in his voice when he says, “You’re making newspaper metaphors at midnight, Dani.” “Fine. You know what I mean.” “I do,” he says. Then, quiet: “I like when you steer. I like how you do it. You look where I’m going before you tell me to turn.” The heat in my face has nothing to do with the room. “Okay,” I say. “Good. And also—if you ever want me to back off, say so. I’ll listen.” “I believe you,” he says. We work. The tray stinks. The prints accumulate on the line, dripping. The photographs begin to have a conversation with each other—the way his shadow lengthens across the hallway; the way my hand holds the lens like it’s alive. He hums and hums, and the tune is starting to feel like a spell. I wonder if he does it to calm himself, if his mother hummed to him when he cried. “Do you think you’re attracted to people like me?” he asks without preamble, and I nearly drop the tongs. He looks instantly horrified. “I mean—sorry, not people like me. That’s gross. I mean—people who are—” “Yes,” I say, because my mouth has the floor. “I think so. I think I’m attracted to you. And also I’m nervous about hurting you. And I’m confused about why it feels different from other times, but not in a bad way. And I’m excited. And I’m trying to let all of that be true at once.” He stares at the tray like it will rescue him. Then he laughs, the tiniest sound. “You could just say something like, I’m interested.” “I’m interested,” I say obediently. “I’m interested in you.” “Me as in… which me?” “All of them,” I say. The words surprise me with how right they feel. “The him that stretches. The boy in the painting. The ribbon that makes your neck yours.” He touches the knot reflexively. His thumb trembles. “Okay,” he says. “Okay.” We let the silence stand. The clock ticks. His humming is back, circling. The next print is mine—self-timer, tripod, a frame from when he wasn’t looking. Me looking into the lens, sharp. The corners of my mouth not smiling but ready. When the face surfaces, I feel both seen and exposed. “You look like you could pull the sun closer,” he murmurs. “Like you’d do it if you wanted, and none of us could stop you.” I snort. Then I don’t, because the way he says it—careful, honest—turns it into a blessing. “Would you want me to?” I ask before I can think. He tilts his head. “Sometimes. Sometimes I want to watch you decide. Sometimes I want to tell you where I am and have you meet me there.” “Then tell me,” I say. “Tell me where you are.” He leans his hip against the counter. The red light catches the soft undercut hair by his ear. He hums and stops, hums and stops. “Right now I am… in between. And I want to be touched like both things are true. Like I’m a boy, and also a… something. Like the ribbon matters. Like I’m allowed to be gentle and not be a joke.” My throat tightens. “You’re not a joke,” I say. “You’re not even a punchline. You’re the whole goddamn poem.” He swallows. “You make it sound easy.” “It isn’t,” I say. “But I’m here for it. If you want.” “I do,” he says, and I realize my hands are on the counter too, near his. We are standing a breath apart, in the heartbeat of the dark. “Can I—” I start, then stop. He looks at me. I try again. “Can I adjust your ribbon?” He nods, a small decisive movement. I lift my hands slowly, like approaching a wild animal. The ribbon is satin-smooth and warm from his skin. I straighten the bow, tug the tails until the knot sits right in the hollow at the base of his throat. My knuckles brush his collarbone. He doesn’t move. His breath goes shallow and then steadies. He’s humming again, just the ghost of it, and the sound vibrates through my fingertips. I feel absurdly like I could cry. I drop my hands. “There,” I say, more to remind myself to speak than because it needed saying. “Thanks,” he whispers. “It’s… I like when you do that.” “Good,” I say, and step back precisely one step, which feels like restraint, which feels like power, which feels like care. We keep working until the clock tells us we should have gone home an hour ago. We don’t talk in big words anymore; we let the prints carry some of it. When we hang the last one, our mirror portrait, side by side, the paper dripping like rain, I feel like we’ve made something that wasn’t here before. He picks up his bag. “Do you want to get diner pancakes?” he asks, shamefaced, as if pancakes at midnight were an indulgence he has to apologize for. “You are speaking my language,” I say. He grins. It transforms his entire face. Outside the red, his eyes are going to be darker than I remember. I want to see them under the fluorescent diner lights, want to watch him decide between blueberry and plain. I want to sit across from him in a booth and learn the new contours of this thing. We turn off the safelight and the dark swoops down, velvet and absolute. I hold my phone flashlight for a moment so we can navigate the maze of trays. His hand finds my elbow briefly, a contact like a sentence. It says: I am here. It says: Don’t let me get lost. It says: I won’t, either. In the hallway, the normal lights feel brutal. We blink and squint and laugh like we’ve been underwater. He hums a few more notes as we walk, and this time I recognize it. It’s the same melody he used when the image was becoming itself. A song for revealing. “Teach me that,” I say, and he looks surprised, then pleased. He hums slower, clearer, until I can catch it. I hum back, off-key at first, then closer. We step out into the cold night, breath doing its own red-lamp trick in the air. He tucks his ribbon into his coat. I slide my hands into my pockets so I don’t reach for him too soon, or too fast. In my chest, the shape of what I want is changing. It’s not a headline. It’s a photograph still in the tray, the world all potential, blurred and beautiful, waiting for the right hands to bring it up into the light.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative successfully captures Dani's perspective as she navigates her attraction to Elliot during their darkroom session. The piece excels in creating a distinctive atmosphere through sensory details of the darkroom environment—the red light, chemical smells, and the rhythmic ticking of the clock all contribute to the intimate, confessional setting. The characterization of both Dani and Elliot is nuanced and well-developed. Dani's internal conflict between her typically assertive nature and her desire to give Elliot space for vulnerability comes through clearly. Her self-awareness about her usual dating patterns and how Elliot challenges those preferences feels authentic. Elliot's character—his quiet demeanor, artistic sensibility, and gender exploration—is portrayed with sensitivity and depth. The prose is often elegant, with effective metaphors and sensory details that enhance the mood: "The darkroom makes everyone beautiful," "He dresses masculine the way a moth dresses as a bat, as a shadow, as a cloud," and "The red light catches the soft undercut hair by his ear." These descriptions create a vivid picture without becoming excessive. The dialogue between Dani and Elliot feels natural and reveals character. Their conversation about gender identity is handled with appropriate complexity—Elliot's explanation that he feels like a "he" but wants that to be "stretchy" rings true to the experience of gender questioning. Dani's responses show her trying to be supportive while navigating unfamiliar territory. The narrative maintains a consistent voice throughout, capturing Dani's assertive yet thoughtful personality. Her internal monologue reveals her processing her attraction to someone who doesn't fit her usual type, which adds complexity to her character. The pacing is effective, with the conversation naturally progressing from tentative sharing to deeper connection. The ending avoids being overly sentimental while still providing a sense of possibility between the characters. The metaphor of the photograph still developing serves as an apt conclusion for their relationship's potential. There are a few instances where the prose becomes slightly purple or overwrought, particularly in some of the metaphorical descriptions. Occasionally, the narrative indulges in overly poetic language that draws attention to itself rather than serving the story. Overall, this is a strong piece that successfully fulfills the prompt requirements. It explores Dani's complex attraction to Elliot with nuance, captures the intimate atmosphere of the darkroom setting, and portrays the tentative beginning of a connection between two people navigating uncharted territory in their identities and relationship. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 19 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 19.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Contemporary romance / drama: Stolen Moments in Roma — Score: 91.6
Prompt:
Contemporary Romance / Drama: Stolen Moments in Roma. Write a series of interconnected short scenes and dialogues that span a single day in modern-day Rome, in narrative form. This will form the beginning of a larger story. Alessandra, a fiery, independent Roman woman who works as a motorcycle courier, nearly collides with Ben, a somewhat clumsy, overly polite British academic on sabbatical, who is engrossed in a guidebook near the Trevi Fountain. The initial encounter is a clash of cultures and personalities – Alessandra is all sharp wit and rapid-fire Italian, while Ben is flustered apologies and awkward attempts at speaking the language. However, as they sort out the near-miss, a spark of unexpected humor and connection emerges. Alessandra, it quickly becomes clear, is a whirlwind of energy and mischief. She's a self-admitted troublemaker with a secret penchant for kleptomania, a detail she doesn't explicitly reveal, but which manifests in subtle, daring acts throughout the day. She impulsively decides to take Ben on a wild, unsanctioned tour of Rome, dragging him in some specific instances far outside his comfort zone. Ben, despite his initial apprehension and inherent politeness, finds himself utterly captivated by Alessandra's unapologetic spirit and zest for life. He is drawn into her orbit, a willing participant in increasingly outlandish situations, a quiet rebellion brewing beneath his scholarly exterior. The narrative should primarily consist of short, vivid scenes and dialogue exchanges, revealing their contrasting personalities and backgrounds, and the growing, ambiguous tension between them. Ben is captivated by Alessandra's energy and the thrill of breaking free from his routine. There's a clear sense that Alessandra is toying with Ben, pushing his boundaries and enjoying his reactions, but her own feelings remain somewhat enigmatic. The day should be a rollercoaster of exhilarating, slightly dangerous, and humorous moments, leaving Ben completely disoriented but utterly smitten. Explore the underlying tension & chemistry between them, culminating in some payoff as they part ways (or not -- your choice). Include this detail: Write in narrative prose, using immersive storytelling. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Morning. The city is already warm, the stone breathing heat, scooters stitching traffic together like black thread. The Trevi Fountain hisses over itself, tourists pressed in, phones raised. Ben stands at the edge of the tide, head bent to his guidebook, reading a paragraph about Baroque excess, widening his eyes as if architecture could be swallowed whole with astonishment. The Vespa appears like a struck match, red and sudden. Alessandra leans into the slip of space, hair flying behind her helmet, a smile that is not so much a smile as the anticipation of one. She swerves because a couple steps backward for a photo; she swerves because a pigeon thinks it is immortal; she swerves—and there is Ben, fixed to the ground like a polite lamppost. The brake shrieks. A tire kisses the cobble in a smoky flirtation. The front wheel stops an inch from his shin. The guidebook levitates, flips, claps shut on the ground like a reprimand. “Cazzo,” she says, breathless, pulling off her helmet. The helmet leaves her hair flattened at the crown, wild at the edges. She is beautiful in the dangerous way a flame is beautiful. “I—terribly sorry,” Ben says immediately, as if he is the one who has nearly run her down. “My fault, I—sorry.” He stoops to pick up the guidebook, realizes his hands are shaking, and laughs, slightly hysterical. “You are reading in the middle of a road,” she says in rapid Italian, eyebrows up. “Sei impazzito? Do you have a death wish or only bad habits?” “I’m—my Italian is—” He tries some: “Mi dispiace? Io... non guardavo. Non... uh... guardare?” He looks at her, eyes too earnest for survival. “You don’t watch, yes,” she says, switching into English, amused. “You don’t watch and then boom.” She makes a tiny explosion with her fingers. “You explode like a tomato.” “I’ll endeavor not to explode,” Ben says. It gets a laugh from her that flashes and is gone. He’s almost absurdly handsome when he’s nervous, she notices; his ears go pink and his shirt is too clean. “Endeavor,” she repeats, rolling the word around, tasting its polite edges. “You’re English.” “Guilty,” he says. “On sabbatical. Ben.” “Alessandra.” She taps the Vespa like it is a troubled animal. “You have to pay for almost dying. At least buy me coffee.” “I—surely I should be buying you something less caffeinated if I’ve nearly died.” “Coffee,” she says, already gesturing. “There’s a place near. You can apologize properly there.” He follows because there is nothing else to do; he has stumbled into a current and it is faster than his legs. She leads him through the swell, the Vespa guided by her hips, both of them slipping past a troupe of Americans in matching hats. Ben tries to apologize to everyone; Alessandra grins at no one and everyone. They stop at a narrow bar, shoulder-to-shoulder with morning regulars. Alessandra orders two espressos without asking, slides him a shot of dark concentration. “Tell me,” she says. “What are you reading while trying to die?” “Bernini,” he says, relieved to know something. “And the rhetoric of water. And—well, baroque spectacle.” She snorts softly. “Water has no rhetoric. It just wants to move.” She bumps his elbow. “Like me.” The coffee is a punch. Ben blinks, the delicious, bitter shock waking the part of him that had been drifting since Heathrow. “Thank you,” he says. “For not actually hitting me.” “And ruining my paint,” she says. “Never.” They stand for a moment with their cups, watching Rome boil. Alessandra’s phone vibrates; she silences it with her thumb. “I’m a courier,” she says. “I know the city like a cat knows rooftops. You, professor—” “Not a professor,” he says quickly, reflexive humility. “Yet.” “—you, not-yet-professor, reading while walking into traffic.” She tilts her head. “What are you doing today?” He glances at his watch, at his list folded in his pocket, earnest to a fault: the Capitoline Museum at eleven, the Forum at two, perhaps the Caravaggio in San Luigi dei Francesi if he isn’t too tired. “I had a plan.” “Throw it away,” she says, and smiles at his immediate horror. “I will take you. My tour. Real Rome. Not your book.” She taps the guidebook. Her eyes gleam. “Trust me. Or be very bored.” It is a dare. He recognizes the shape of it but not the consequences. He thinks of himself, careful, precise, always on time; he thinks of a whole city he has only met on paper. He puts the guidebook into his bag. “Lead on,” he says, and something in him loosens. They take side streets. Alessandra walks fast and does not apologize for it. She talks without warning—about a bakery that makes maritozzi like clouds, about a dog that chases only blue cars, about a street where she once watched a man dance alone at dawn. Ben absorbs everything like a sponge left in a rainstorm. They pause by a produce stall. A pyramid of peaches perfumes the air. The vendor is flirting with a woman in a yellow dress; his hands are eloquent in the way Romans’ hands are; his eyes are elsewhere. Alessandra reaches out with the most casual elegance and plucks a peach. She rolls it in her palm, then turns, tucks it into Ben’s pocket with a pat as proprietary as a bird making a nest. He startles. “Did you—” “You forgot to buy breakfast,” she says, innocent. She catches his eye and something unspoken passes between them, mischief and alarm. “Pay me back later with stories.” They cross a piazza where a violinist is gutting Vivaldi. At the edge, a young cop watches from the shade, bored. Alessandra drops a coin into the violin case, and in the same motion, Ben thinks he sees her fingers flicker, see a small shiny thing disappear into her palm. But he is probably wrong; he is sleep-deprived; she is just quick. They duck into a church, cool and dim, humidity scrolling from the stone. Alessandra stands before a painting of a saint pierced with imaginary pain and says, “He looks like my cousin after a wedding.” Ben laughs despite himself, then hushes, then laughs again. The old woman at the candle stand looks at them as if they have brought a scooter into a library. Outside, a man calls, “Ale!” She turns. A man in a linen shirt, the color of unripe pear, approaches with a smile not quite warm. He is older than her by a decade, maybe two, with a tan that comes from leisure rather than work. “Ciao, bella,” he says. “Ancora viva.” He looks at Ben with lazy curiosity. “E questo?” Ben steps forward because that is what polite men do. “Ben,” he says. “Hello.” “Marco,” the man says. He holds out his hand; it is soft. He glances at Alessandra as if she is a stray dog he once fed. “You’re giving tours now?” “I give what I want,” she says, a shrug that is also a warning. Marco’s eyes sharpen with a kind of metallic fondness. “She will sell you the shirt from your back,” he says to Ben in good English, smiling as if the insult is advice. “Or steal it if you are slow.” “Grazie,” Ben says, unsure whether to laugh. “Attento,” Marco adds, sing-song. “She eats hearts with breakfast.” To Alessandra, in Italian, he says something fast that makes her roll her eyes. He kisses the air near her cheek, misses both times, and is gone. “Friend?” Ben asks. “Acquaintance.” Her mouth flattens. “Ex-disaster. He thinks he is interesting because he is boring.” “What did he say?” Ben asks, eager and terrified. “He said to be careful with me,” she says, and looks at him deliberately. “You should always be careful with me.” “I’m trying,” Ben says, and discovers he isn’t. They get on the Vespa—Ben with the caution of a saint approaching a blaze, Alessandra with the muscle memory of a dancer. She hands him a spare helmet. He fits it, shoves his knees awkwardly against hers. “Hold on,” she says, and he does. She threads them through Rome with a reckless grace. They brush against buses, scrape by delivery vans, stutter at lights only to go when no one is looking. Ben laughs because he is either going to laugh or die. He clutches her waist and feels the solid line of her against his arms. It occurs to him, somewhere near Piazza Venezia, that he has never really been touched like this in motion, in public, in a way that makes the city complicit. They stop at a hill where the city unrolls like a map thrown on a table. The wind is a hand through his hair. Alessandra points, rapid fire. “There I learned to smoke. There I almost fell in love. There I took a wrong turn and found a fight. There they make the best supplì but only on Wednesdays, never on Tuesdays, because the owner hates Tuesdays. And there—” she points at a roofline— “is a pool I once swam in without being invited.” “Do you always trespass?” he asks, half-admiring, half-appalled. “Of course,” she says. “Otherwise you see only what everyone sees.” He is quiet. She studies him sidelong. “What did you expect, from Rome?” she asks. “I thought I’d be moved by art,” he says. The answer is automatic, professor-in-training neatness. He takes a breath. “I didn’t expect to be kidnapped by a whirlwind.” “Kidnapped?” she repeats, pleased. “Possibly liberated,” he amends. “Better,” she says, and for a second her smile is unarmored. They eat lunch on a curb at the edge of Trastevere, pizza bianca still singing from the oven. Alessandra tears hers with her teeth, eyes on the street. Ben carefully folds, then gives up, grease rolling over his thumb. She watches him lick it off and raises a brow like a dare. He blushes again. She steals a bite when he isn’t looking; he catches her and she shrugs: the world is full of food you didn’t pay for. In a cramped shop, she picks up a pair of sunglasses, tries them on, turns her face to the mirror with an actress’s precision. She sets them down and walks out. Ben, a heartbeat later, notices her new sunglasses are an entirely different shape, glossier, a tiny logo flashing at the temple. He opens his mouth. She cocks her head, a finger to her lips, and he closes it, abetting without consent. He feels both complicit and alive. They take him to the lungotevere, where the river sulks. They sit with their backs against a flank of stone, heat pressed to their shoulders. She tells him a story about a cousin who boxed priests at a protest; he tells her about the time he fainted in front of a Rembrandt. She laughs until she has to cover her mouth. “You’re dangerous,” she says. “But like a pillow.” “Thank you?” he tries. The light tilts. The city shifts tone, gold seeping into everything. On the Vespa again, she veers to a narrow alley near Piazza Navona. “I have to deliver something,” she says, like a queen deigning to reveal she has an actual job. She passes a thin envelope through a gate to a hand that doesn’t reveal its owner. Ben watches the exchange with the curiosity of a cat seeing itself in a mirror. She tucks something in her jacket afterward—a coin, a ribbon, a secret—he can’t tell. He is learning the pleasure of not knowing. They run into police on Via del Governo Vecchio—two officers pausing a pair of street vendors. Alessandra slows reflexively. One of the officers recognizes her because Rome is a village and smiles. “Ale,” he says. “Behave.” “I never behave,” she says sweetly. She draws Ben onward with two fingers in the belt loop of his jeans, a possessive, hilarious little tug that does inexplicable things to his breath. Evening slides in, a softer heat. They drink spritzes at a table shoved into a corner of a piazza alive with clatter. Lights bead overhead. A saxophone finds a melancholy that doesn’t belong to any hour. Alessandra has switched her sunglasses for his gaze. She watches him as if to understand what she has done. “What are you rebelling against?” she asks. “Everything that told me to be careful,” he says. He can’t believe he’s said it. He looks at his hands. He looks up. “And myself.” “You will be very exhausted,” she says. “Rebellion is a full-time job.” She leans in a fraction, and the air tightens. A boy with a tray of roses hustles up, hopeful. Alessandra raises her hand without looking, fingers delicate. One rose slips away from the tray into her palm, invisible to anyone not staring at her hand. Ben is. She turns the rose between forefinger and thumb, then sets it in his glass. “For you,” she says, because she likes the way his ears go pink. “You do that often?” he asks. “Which?” she says, innocent. “Give flowers? Yes.” Night grows. Rome stops pretending to be anything but ancient and young at once. They walk without destination, shoulders brushing. He finds himself hyperaware of the inches between them, the inches that vanish when she grabs his wrist to pull him into a doorway to avoid a sudden rain that the forecast had not mentioned. They are pressed into shadow, marble damp at their backs, the city steam-slick outside. “Tour of Rome,” he says, breath near her ear. “Is this part of it?” “This is the best part of it,” she says. The rain thickens, then softens, the kind that makes the stones harder and the lights blur. People run laughing, barefoot for three steps. Alessandra watches like a cat at a window. “Marco warned me,” he says, lightly. Beneath his voice, something truer. “That you’re wily.” “I am,” she says. She turns to face him, close enough to see the words forming before they arrive. “I’m also honest, sometimes. That makes it worse.” “How honest?” he asks, and hears the question for what it is, ridiculous and serious. “Honest enough to tell you that you are very kissable when you look like a mistake,” she says. It is both an insult and a kindness. He laughs, breathless, and she smiles like she has let go of a handrail. She does not kiss him. She lets the possibility stretch, taut as a violin string. The rain slows. The city breathes again. They walk to the Trevi Fountain as if to return to the scene of a crime. It is less crowded now, the water climbing its own body. Alessandra tosses a coin without ceremony, a flick that betrays practice. Ben fumbles with his wallet, realizes a coin is missing. He glances at her. She lifts her hands, palms bare of guilt. “Do you steal everyone’s days?” he asks. “I borrow them,” she says. “I give them back differently.” “Mine feels—” he searches. “Stolen.” “You don’t seem to mind,” she says. “I don’t,” he admits, and his voice is not the voice he woke up with. She nods, satisfied, then looks at him with a sudden seriousness that is almost jarring. “Tomorrow,” she says. “Same coffee bar. If you are brave.” “Brave enough,” he says. She steps back, the red Vespa already humming in her posture. “Be careful,” she says, mocking and fond. “Or don’t.” He watches her pull on her helmet, sees her slip his coin—his coin—back into his palm as she shakes his hand, a magician’s denouement. “For your fountain,” she says. “I don’t like debt.” “Is that what this is?” he asks. “Debt?” “It’s a beginning,” she says, and it might as well be a confession. She revs the engine, grins in a way that makes his bones forget their purpose, and vanishes into the city like a rumor. Ben stands with the coin warming his skin, the day’s edges frayed in the most precise way. Behind him, the water goes on talking to itself in a language that requires no translations; ahead of him, a morning he didn’t know he wanted makes a promise with the night. He flips the coin into the air. It glints, arcs, and the wish leaves his mouth before he can be polite about it.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece is a remarkably accomplished response to the prompt, creating a vivid day in Rome through the contrasting characters of Alessandra and Ben. The writing demonstrates exceptional control of language, pacing, and characterization. The prose is lyrical without becoming overwrought, with striking metaphors and sensory details that immerse the reader in Rome: "The Vespa appears like a struck match, red and sudden" and "The city shifts tone, gold seeping into everything." The author skillfully balances poetic language with more direct narration, creating a rhythm that mirrors the day's ebb and flow. Character development is particularly strong. Alessandra emerges as a fully realized character—impulsive, mischievous, and complex. Her kleptomania is subtly revealed through actions rather than exposition, with several deft moments showing her casual theft. Ben's transformation from cautious academic to willing participant in Alessandra's adventures feels organic and earned. Their chemistry develops naturally through dialogue and small physical interactions. The dialogue is exceptional—sharp, revealing, and often witty. Lines like "You're dangerous," she says. "But like a pillow" perfectly capture their dynamic. The conversations feel authentic to each character's background and personality. The structure of interconnected scenes works beautifully, creating a sense of a day unfolding in real time while maintaining narrative momentum. Each vignette adds something meaningful to either character development or their relationship. The ending strikes just the right note of ambiguity and possibility, avoiding both saccharine resolution and cynical dismissal. The final image of the coin toss is both thematically resonant and emotionally satisfying. If there are weaknesses, they're minor. Occasionally the prose becomes slightly too self-conscious in its lyricism, though these moments are rare. The piece also doesn't fully explore the "slightly dangerous" aspects promised in the prompt—while Alessandra's kleptomania creates tension, the day never feels truly risky. Overall, this is an exceptionally well-crafted piece that fulfills the prompt's requirements while transcending them. It creates a vivid sense of place, complex characters, and genuine emotional resonance in a relatively short space. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 19 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 20 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 19.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 20.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Cozy sci-fi: The Last Outpost — Score: 88.2
Prompt:
Cozy sci-fi The Last Outpost Nettle (or Nets to her friends) bartends at The Last Outpost -- a lazy hub for miners and merchants in an asteroid belt on the Andromeda outer rim. Escaping from her past life, Nets found a home here at the Outpost. They have, thus far, tolerated Net's flaws which she tries to keep in equilibrium with her assortment of talents. Her evenings involve chatting with patrons, negotiating the drama, intrigue, problems & love lives of the diverse crowd that filter through the Outpost. Tonight is no different, at least, until a frazzled looking stranger, tentacled dreads askew, quietly plops down at the bar: "Vega whisky, neat. Better make that a double." Write a chapter in this story. Establish conflict for narrative interest. Don't resolve the conflict within this chapter. Aim for about 60% dialogue. First person, present tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
I’m halfway through polishing a glass that doesn’t need it when he slumps onto the stool—fourth from the hatch—tentacled dreads askew like he wrestled an air scrubber and lost. He smells like ionized dust and cold fear, the kind that clings to your clothes. The mining shift must’ve just docked; the place hums with the low din of a dozen overlapping lives. I slide his way, rag in hand, and aim my body right where I always do—three degrees left of the drip, steady at the elbow. “Vega whisky, neat,” he says, voice low, words clipped like they’re expensive. “Better make that a double.” “Sure,” I say. “You look like you’ve had the kind of day that needs a triple.” He gives a weak laugh without showing teeth. “I’ll settle for forgettable.” I reach up, grab the Vega bottle from the high shelf. The liquid runs into the tumbler like amber static. I set it down and keep the rag moving, the way I do. It soothes people, the continuity of it. Everything else in space is scattershot. “Cheers,” he mutters, and knocks it back like he’s trying to outrun gravity. The tentacles—they’re hair, yes, but less hair than tense extensions of himself—curl, then unfurl. He gestures at the glass for a second round and I oblige. “You got a name?” I tip my head. It’s the dance: I ask, they answer or they don’t, and in both cases it opens a passage. He sighs. “Jax.” “Jax,” I repeat, like I’m rolling a coin across my knuckles. “Welcome to the Last Outpost. House rules are simple. Don’t bleed on my floor unless it’s poetic.” His mouth twitches. “Is poetry taxed out here, too?” “Only if it rhymes.” He takes a smaller sip, eyes flicking around the room. It’s the crowd you always get when the belt pays out: scruff and shine. The miners at table seven have a bright red payout chit they won’t stop slapping onto the tabletop to cheer, hoping the universe will keep noticing their luck and keep it going. Two dockhands are arguing about coil temperatures at the far end, a couple of traders haggling in whispers over a crate of discoloring nettlefruit that smells like wet copper. My boss, the Outpost itself, hums like it’s content, the old vents breathing slow as a sleeping whale. If you listen long enough, you can hear the heart of this place. Jax’s fingers tap a rhythm on the glass. I keep swiping the same spot. He notices. They always do, eventually. “You polish that hole to warp, you’ll fall straight through to the lounge on Level Two,” he says. “I like visitors,” I say. “People will talk.” “They already do.” I cock a brow. “So, Jax. What brings you to my charming grotto? Business, pleasure, or trouble?” He grunts. “You really want to know?” “If I didn’t, I’d be wiping a different spot.” He stares at the row of bottles like he’s trying to line his thoughts up with them. He picks Vega because it’s medicated nostalgia in a glass; I can tell by the second sip he’s not from around here. Vega tastes like black pepper and burnt sugar, like nights on orbital promenades with fiber-glass stars. Not a miner’s drink. Andromeda’s got better anesthetics. “I’m… delivering something,” he says finally. “Was, anyway.” “To who?” “Someone with more friends than me.” “Delicate delivery. Fragile or illegal?” “Both.” I don’t blink. People love confessions when they’re surrounded by strangers. They think anonymity is armor. Sometimes it is. Sometimes it’s a net. I’m good with nets. “You late?” I ask. He nods. “Missed the window by three hours. Then I got a ping.” He pulls a cheap holopad from his jacket, sets it face down, like it might leak secrets if it sees daylight. “And now?” I keep the rag moving, slow circles. The false wood gleams under my hand, the edge worn smooth from elbows and lives. I feel the ridge where the board was repaired after that fight last cycle, when Sori’s cousin came in with a plasma cutter and too much hope. “Now it’s complicated,” he says. “They told me to come here. To you, specifically.” I stop wiping before my hand starts again. “Me?” He nods. “Nets. Nettle, actually, if we’re going by your license. Unless that’s just some cute botanical lie.” “It’s both.” I toss the rag over my shoulder, and the hand that used to make decisions faster than thought flexes and relaxes. “Who’s ‘they’?” “I don’t know them by name.” He slides the holopad closer, but not enough to be a threat. “They called themselves the Tide.” The rag goes back to the bar on instinct. I’m not sure my face moves. My chest tightens, like someone cinched a belt around my ribs. “The Tide?” I echo. “You know them?” “I know tide is just gravity in motion,” I say. “Pull one way, push another.” “What if I told you they had your picture.” He flips the holopad over and taps the screen. A grainy still catches my old self on a different night, different bar, different name. The hair is shorter, the eyes are meaner. I’m holding a glass not like a bartender but like a tool. Below it, the words: Nettle ‘Nets’ Surinder—contact if found. I stare long enough to want to drown. The Outpost hums steady like an old friend telling me to breathe. “That’s a bad picture,” I say lightly. “It’s taken from station security three systems back,” he says. “They said you could help me finish the handoff.” “They said that,” I repeat, “about me.” “I didn’t know who you were until I walked in. Then I saw you.” He shifts. “Then I was sure.” “That sounds like a story,” says Kree from two stools down. She’s been nursing a glass of nettlefruit soda, body half-turned like she’s minding her business. Kree minds her business the way a cat minding a laser dot minds. “Kree,” I warn. “What?” She lifts her hands. “If a man says he’s delivering fragile illegal things, I’d like to know if they explode near my hair.” I lean in, keep my voice for Jax alone. “What’s in the package?” He swallows. “It’s not a thing. It’s a person.” My rag pauses again. Bad sign. I force it to move. “How small a person?” I ask. “Small.” He glances at the satchel slung cross-body, its edge digging into his side like a secret. “And quiet.” “Is there a breathing schedule involved?” “No.” He looks wounded. “I’m not a monster.” “Then what are you?” “Desperate.” A miner laughs behind me, big and bright, and the sound crosses the space between us like a power surge. Jax flinches. His tentacles twitch. I clock the door without looking; I know the sound of boots that don’t belong. The Outpost has a way of telegraphing arrivals. The hatch opens and a breeze of artificial chill slides across my forearms. Three people walk in. Not miners. Not traders. Their boots are too quiet, like courtesy. They carry themselves like rooms adjust when they enter. The lead has a smile almost gentle; the kind you use to calm animals. The pit of my stomach says run. Instead, I wipe the same spot again and lift my chin. “Ranger sweep?” Kree murmurs behind her glass. “Maybe,” I say. But Rangers don’t wear that much old-blue seam tape on their sleeves, or that kind of history in their posture. This is corporate. Or something that wants you to think it’s corporate. Jax drains the rest of his drink and keeps both hands where I can see them. Smart. He’s not stupid, then, just wrecked. The lead scans the room, eyes taking a quiet census. He catalogs: laughter here, boredom there, me at the bar, Jax at my mercy. He approaches with the other two trailing by a pace. No guns drawn. Guns aren’t for this stage. This stage is offers. “Evening,” he says, voice smooth enough to oil a lock. “Best place for a Vega in four lightyears, I hear.” “Depends who you ask,” I say. “If you ask me, I’ll say yes. If you ask Kree, she’ll say no. If you ask the Outpost, it’ll groan because it knows the truth and hates compliments.” He smiles. “Good to know the Outpost still has a sense of humor.” “It has nerves. They get sensitive. Who are you?” “Alias will do,” he says. “Call me Lane.” “You seem like you’d like to call yourself that.” I tip my head at the two behind him. “They have names, or do they answer to whistle tones?” Lane’s smile doesn’t shift. “We’re looking for someone. We have reason to believe they came through here.” “People come through here on their way to worse bars.” I glance at Jax without moving my eyes. “We’re not here to cause trouble,” Lane says. “On the contrary. We’re here to relieve it.” “Trouble is how I keep the lights moody,” I say. He steeples his fingers lightly on the bar. He notices the spot, too. He watches me wipe it and blinks like he’s cataloging the ritual. “We’re trying to reunite something lost with its rightful owners.” “Something,” I repeat. “A child,” he says. His voice goes softer. It’s a good softness. Practiced. “She was taken from a research habitat. She’s… unique.” Jax’s glass clinks the faintest bit. Lane doesn’t look away from me. “You telling me your research lab mislaid a kid,” I say. “That’s careless.” “It was theft,” Lane says, a sheet of sadness sliding into place so smoothly I almost applaud. “And dangerous. She requires… specialized care.” “What kind of specialized?” “Health monitoring. Nutritional adjustments.” He lowers his voice, just for my ears, like we’re sharing a secret. “She has, you might say, enhancements. She was born to solve problems people couldn’t manage alone.” “You mean you built her for labor,” I say. “For fun, too?” He blinks, smile unchanged, and says nothing. The silence is a point on a graph. He’s good at this. Jax tilts his head, shoulders creeping up like he wishes his body was smaller. I keep wiping. “I haven’t seen any children,” I say. “Room’s full of toddlers in adult suits, but no kids.” “We have reason to believe,” Lane says, “that she’s very near.” He lets his gaze slide, slow as resin, to Jax’s satchel. Then back to me. “We prefer to handle this discreetly. There’s a generous finder’s fee.” “The Outpost has a policy.” I smile like the floor’s solid and I’m not thinking about the Tide’s old sigil burned into the back of my mind, wave over wave. “We don’t take fees to turn people over.” “We’re not asking you to turn anyone over.” Lane spreads his hands. “We’re asking you to help us give a child proper care.” Kree snorts. “You smell like sterilizer and promises. I’m allergic to both.” Lane’s eyes flick to her and back. The two behind him shift just enough to telegraph what they’re pretending not to be: pressure. I lean forward, elbows steady, rag in motion. “You know my name,” I say. “Odd, for someone who just came for the Vega.” “Word travels,” Lane says. “And you matter in this room. People listen to you.” “I’m loud,” I say. “You’re trusted.” His eyes sharpen. “And you used to work with currents like ours.” Under the bar, my hand finds the ancient chip slot where the Outpost keeps its spare keys. My skin remembers the cool edge of a lock pick, the way it felt to be the one moving water through cracks in stone. Jax looks at me like I might be something he can hold onto in a flood, and I want to tell him I can’t be anyone’s raft. “Maybe the child doesn’t want to go,” I say. Lane’s smile thins. “Children don’t always know what’s best for them.” “And adults do?” Kree asks. “Sometimes.” He turns his palm up on the bar, a gesture so empty it pretends to be full. “We’ll be around. In case a better idea arrives.” “Leave a comm,” I say. “In case the Outpost wants to flirt.” He slides a small square across the wood. It sticks for a second on a resin seam, then keeps going. I stop it with my rag. “Lane,” he says. “Channel nineteen. Twelve-hour window.” “Corporate hours,” I say. “Efficiency is kindness.” He smiles again, and it’s almost bored, now. “Enjoy your evening.” They move away, not turning their backs, then letting themselves be swallowed by the bodies, their shapes dissolving among the other shapes. The hatch sighs open; the artificial chill retreats into the corridor. The room exhales, the kind of breath you take when you’ve been shown a knife in a gentle hand. Jax’s fingers are white around his glass. “They’ll wait,” he whispers. “They’ll watch the docks. I can’t get to my ship.” “You came through the service tubes?” I ask. He nods. “I ditched two tails on Level Three. I don’t know how long till they triangulate.” “What’s the Tide want with me,” I ask, soft. “Really.” “I didn’t ask,” he says. “They said—if I found you, you’d know what to do.” “Flattering,” I say. “Or lazy.” He looks at me like he’s the ninety-second before a solar flare. “I can’t keep her safe alone.” Behind him, table seven erupts again as the payout chit buys another round, voices lifting in that raw mineral cadence that says we pulled something worth more than our backs. The Outpost hums. The rag goes in circles. The spot shines. “You’re sure it’s a girl?” I ask. He nods. “She said her name is Lio.” “Said,” I repeat. He half-smiles, the first real one. “She talks through the cracks. She doesn’t like doors.” I glance at the satchel. It’s quiet. That doesn’t mean anything. I’ve known dangerous things that made no sound at all. “Okay,” I say. “We have to move before they net the exits. There’s a hatch in the storage closet—goes to the old coolant crawlspace. It’s cut off from main scan. It’ll buy us time.” “Us?” he asks. “You’re in my bar,” I say. “You brought your mess to my spot. That makes it my mess.” He swallows. The tentacles loosen a fraction. “Pay your tab,” I add. “On principle.” He fumbles for a chip, looks like he’s going to apologize for it, lays it down. I don’t look at the amount. Behind him, Kree swivels on her stool to face the room like a guard dog that doesn’t feel like getting up. “I’ll cover the floor,” she says. “If anyone asks, I’ll tell them you’re in the back making out with a fire extinguisher.” “Finally,” I say. “Someone sees me.” She grins, tight. “Don’t die, Net.” “Not on menu,” I say. Jax stands, satchel hugged to his ribs. I flick my eyes to the corner camera and blink twice, slow, for the Outpost. It hums a little lower. That’s consent. “Follow me,” I say, lifting the bar gate. The hinge squeaks—needs grease—and in the sound I hear the measure of a thousand little choices. I lead him past the crates of nettlefruit, through the tinny door that sticks, to the storage closet that smells like metal and old lemons. I palm the panel. The secret hatch clicks, stubborn as a memory. Behind us, the muffled sound of the main room slides into a low, distant ocean. The hatch opens, a slice of darkness yawning. “After you,” I say. He hesitates, then ducks inside. He moves like someone who’s learned to fit into small spaces. I crouch to follow, then stop, hand on the rim, rag still in my other hand like I forgot to put it down. “Lane’s not going to wait twelve hours,” Jax says, voice bouncing off the pipes. “He’ll come early.” “I know,” I say. “He’s not the only one who knows how to arrive ahead of schedule.” “And the Tide?” he asks. “They said—” “I know what they said.” I stuff the rag into my back pocket, take one last look at the room I can’t see from here. “I’m not who they remember.” In the dark, something shifts in the satchel. A small, barely-there breath. Jax goes still. “Lio?” he whispers. A whisper comes back, like the Outpost itself clearing its throat in a dream. It’s not words. It’s a sound like a wave deciding. “We go,” I say, and drop into the crawlspace, the hatch sealing us into the old bones of the Outpost while above, the tide draws in.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully creates a cozy sci-fi atmosphere while establishing meaningful conflict. The author has crafted a first-person, present-tense narrative centered around Nettle (Nets), a bartender at The Last Outpost with a mysterious past. The chapter introduces conflict through Jax, who arrives with a hidden child and pursuers close behind, connecting to Nets' past through "the Tide." The writing excels in several areas. The dialogue is natural and reveals character while advancing the plot. The author creates a vivid setting through sensory details and ambient descriptions that make the space station feel lived-in. The prose balances efficiency with moments of poetic description that enhance rather than distract from the narrative. Character development is strong. Nets is established as competent but haunted by her past, with subtle hints about her former life. Jax is portrayed as desperate but principled. Even minor characters like Kree have distinct personalities. Lane and his associates are effectively menacing without becoming caricatures. The pacing is well-managed. The author builds tension gradually, from Jax's arrival to the revelation about the child to the confrontation with Lane. The chapter ends with appropriate unresolved tension as the characters escape into the crawlspace. There are a few minor issues. Occasionally, the metaphors become slightly overwrought ("I'm not sure my face moves. My chest tightens, like someone cinched a belt around my ribs"). Some descriptions of the Outpost personifying it might be a bit heavy-handed. The narrative sometimes lingers on atmospheric details when it could move forward more efficiently. Overall, this is a strong piece that establishes an intriguing world, compelling characters, and meaningful stakes. It successfully follows the prompt requirements while creating a narrative that feels both familiar in its genre conventions and fresh in its execution. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Young adult drama: Gone South — Score: 88.2
Prompt:
Young adult drama Gone South Taylor is a 16 year old teen with a history of "concerning behavioural patterns" (or that's how the stupid smug school counsellor worded it on the phone call to Mom). It shouldn't be a surprise: When you live in a backwater town in Tennessee, your choices are: a. be mind-fuckingly bored, or b. invent some drama. Two days ago, Taylor came out to their family as trans. This disclosure was *not* in the category of invented drama -- it was, in fact, the real deal, and a long time coming. It didn't go well. The last 48 hours had been pure disaster. In a moment of desperate inspiration, Taylor had decided to get the hell out of dodge. And so an escape plan was hatched and executed within the space of 30 minutes. That was last night. Now Taylor was two states away, having been unceremoniously ejected from their hitched ride in downtown New Orleans. Write the next chapter in Taylor's story as they find their feet in this new environment. Tell the chapter over the course of their first day in New Orleans, in which Taylor meets another runaway with issues and secrets. Taylor navigates this new world, not knowing who to trust or what the dangers are. Write in Taylor's voice, and incorporate their internal monologue as they grapple with intense & conflicting emotions. Also incorporate dialogue with the interesting characters Taylor meets. First person, mixed tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The strap on my backpack keeps slipping off my shoulder, which is exactly the last straw when I’ve got like twelve other straws jabbing me in the eye. Every few steps I hitch it back up, and it slides down again, like it’s trying to abandon me, too. We get it, bag. You hate me. Join the club.
