The bar smells like old beer and new violence. Neon hums behind a wire cage, painting the bottles in tropical bruises. A fan on the ceiling turns slow as a planet tired of spinning. Somewhere in the wall, a compressor coughs like a cat with a cigarette habit. Spike Spiegel leans against the bar, elbow crooked, posture loose enough to fall off the stool and graceful enough to look like he meant it. A ring of rust circles his lighter’s emblem—someone’s cheap Pegasus—pocked and scarred like it’s been to the bottom of the sea and back. Maybe it has. He flips the lid, the hinge complaining, flame briefly blue, then gold. He lights one and lets the smoke leak out of his lip like a bored promise. “Whatever happens, happens,” he murmurs to the flame, snaps it shut, puts it away. The bartender gives him an angled look that says drink or move. Spike slides a few bills he can barely afford—his chips always fall wrong when they’re his—and gets a whiskey that could strip paint. He tastes it, grimaces without moving his face, and watches the room in the mirror. His prosthetic eye catches glints, smears neon into a soft smear. Depth is always a little off; the world is farther and closer than it ought to be, like a laugh heard through a door. The door opens. Roanapur drifts in on a woman’s hips. She’s nothing like the place and exactly like it—Revy, Two Hands, shorts that are an act of war, crop top, boots that look like they’ll kick you into a better life if you deserve it. Cigarette already lit. Dragon ink climbing her right arm to the shoulder like a pet that learned to bite. She walks as if the floor owes her money. The crowd parts out of respect or good instinct. Spike’s gaze ticks over without moving his head. He’s seen photos, read a line or two. Bounty hunters hear about other hunters. They say she drinks gun oil for breakfast. They say she can put two bullets into the same eyelash from across the room without blinking. They say a lot of things. Right now she orders a bottle, drinks from it like it’s her last and first friend. “Nice artwork,” Spike says, the mirror carrying his voice to her like a secret. “Nice hair, scarecrow,” she says without looking. His lips press to a smile. He flicks ash into a glass tray shaped like a skull. “You know this place serves food? Or at least a chemical that pretends.” She drags her eyes over to him like she’s choosing whether to shoot. They’re amber with broken glass in them. “Food’s for when you plan on living long enough for it to matter.” “Guess I ordered wrong.” “Guess you did a lot of things wrong.” She picks up the bottle, shoulders her way closer, sets it down so it thunks and sloshes over. “You Spike? The space cowboy.” “Just Spike.” He taps his cigarette. “And you’re the girl who makes bullet casings cry.” “I’m not a good person, not a bad person. I’m just here.” She leans in, vapor and whiskey on her breath, the filter of her cigarette stained the color of old news. “So are you.” He angles his face, studying her from beneath lashes. “Looks like we’re both here for the same reason.” Her mouth crooks into a grin that has no joy in it. “Guy with a price tag on his head and a taste for disappearing acts. Green jacket. Bad mustache. Thinks Roanapur is a rabbit hole.” “Thinks a lot of things,” Spike says. His stomach reminds him he’s hungry by punching him in the spine. He ignores it. “Our mutual friend sent you?” “Mutual friend didn’t mention you.” She cracks her neck. “Which means I get there first. Which means this conversation’s over unless you wanna make it interesting.” “I like interesting. It never likes me back.” He sips his whiskey, winces, then smiles again. “I’ve got a ship needs fuel. Crew needs noodles. I need cigarettes. You need another bottle.” “What I need is half your bounty. Or your ass out of my way.” She smiles bigger. “Or both.” The bar’s sound dips. Men play cards in molasses. Out on the street, a moped backfires like a bad decision. Spike turns his lighter in his fingers, the rust ring catching the light, and sets it down between them. The Pegasus looks tired. “Flip you for it,” he says. She barks a laugh. “You think I’m gonna leave money to chance?” “Not chance. Gravity.” He nudges the lighter. “Rust on the hinge. Falls heads three out of five.” She thinks he’s lying because he is. She puts her cigarette down, the ash trembling but not falling. She catches his eyes. “No. We do this my way.” Gunmetal whispers as she draws, the twins sliding into her hands like they were born there. The barrels point at his chest. The click of hammers might as well be chords in her favorite song. Spike sighs. “I was hoping you’d say that.” He doesn’t move, then moves, the stool scraping out as he drops into a slouch that’s almost a dance. Her first shot goes where his sternum was. Bottle glass explodes. The bar erupts—shouts, chairs, the bartender diving like he’s trained for hurricanes. Spike’s hand is already on the Jericho, drawing, tilting, his prosthetic eye pushing time into that stretched place where a bullet becomes a bead of rain. He fires left of her right shoulder. The mirror cracks. She’s already adjusting, already smiling, already putting two shots into the neon sign to kill the light. “Cute,” she says, as both of them go and the room goes with them. They move without thinking and think without moving. She twin-taps his shadow. He sends a long low shot that bites chips out of the bar behind her thigh but doesn’t bite her. He’s reading the angle off her boot and she’s reading the twitch in his mouth and neither of them is trying to kill the other as hard as they could. Men who try to be heroes try to break it up, and she breaks one’s bottle over his head, he trips another into safety with a foot, all while the air stinks of cordite and burned neon. A ceiling fan dies mid-swing, a slow decapitation. Revy’s laughter gutters and flares. “You’re not bad, cowboy,” she says, sliding behind a table that used to be new. “You’re expensive,” he says, from somewhere behind the jukebox that’s still playing a soft old tune about regret. “You want to split, we split it now and argue later.” “I don’t do later.” “Then now.” He puts his cigarette between his teeth, shoots again, close enough to shave a hair off her arm without threading it. He could have put it in her. He doesn’t. She notices. Silence folds fast. The bar recalculates its damage. Revy snorts, holstering one pistol, keeping the other out. She gestures with it toward the back. “Our guy’s got a room two blocks away. Motel with a sign that flickers ‘OT L’ like it’s stuttering. You got wheels?” “I’ve got legs,” Spike says. “They come with me.” “Walk, then.” She swipes the bottle on instinct and finds it’s dead. She tosses it; it clatters. They move together like two cats trying not to walk in step and failing. Outside, Roanapur’s heat presses against the skin like a hand. The motel sign blinks its can’t-quite word. They stand under it for a second, smoke curling from both, the night loud with distant engines and too close insects. Revy pauses at the curb, flicks ash. “You’ve got a death wish,” she says, almost curious. “Had one.” He glances up at the broken sign, the way the light makes a halo out of cheap plastic. “Used it already.” She grins. “Same.” They go up the stairs. The hallway carpet smells like stale things that had hopes once. Room 208. Revy’s heel nudges the door. It’s locked. She looks at Spike. He rolls his neck, listens at the jamb with the ear that still believes in beats, then takes out the lighter. He worries the rust ring with his thumb and uses the base to pry a cheap latch. It pops. He looks at her. She looks at him. They count to three with their eyes. The door swings in. Their guy is inside, wrong mustache, wrong pants, wrong everything, wrong place to hide. He squawks, goes for something that might be a gun, but in this story the hero doesn’t get to be him. Revy shoots the table near his hand and splinters it into a reason to stop moving. Spike steps in sideways and puts a bullet through the air an inch from his ear. The man sits. His courage leaves out the window. “Hands where we can see them, mustache,” Revy says. She’s almost gentle. She ties him with a phone cord she rips out of the wall. “Split,” Spike says. “Even.” “Even?” She cocks an eye. “I did the pretty work.” “You did the loud work.” He gestures at the screaming wallpaper. “We both did work.” She thinks about not agreeing and then agrees. “Fine. Even.” They gag the man. Spike calls it in with a number that recognizes him and hates him. Pickup in twenty. Revy kicks the door shut, the two of them suddenly alone with the bounty as furniture. The silence grows a skin. He lights another cigarette. The lighter’s rust ring glows in the dim. He offers one to her. She takes it, mouth softening around the paper for a microsecond before clamping down into the woman who’d bite a god. “You dance?” she asks. “I fall with style,” he says. She snorts, smoke out her nose. “You didn’t shoot to hit.” “Neither did you.” “I always shoot to hit.” She’s close enough that he can see the tiny nick on her lower lip, healed pale. Close enough that he can see the fine lines in the dragon. Close enough that his eye makes her a step farther than she is, and he almost leans. Her guns are holstered but not more than a thought away. He can feel his Jericho like a heartbeat at his hip. Outside, someone laughs with a mean mouth. Inside, they don’t move. “Attachments are trouble,” he says. Sounds like something he’s memorized to keep himself alive. “Yeah,” she says. Sounds like something she learned by being set on fire. “I don’t do them.” “Me neither.” He smiles sideways. “Except when I do.” Her mouth curves. “We’re not doing anything.” “Right.” His cigarette burns down. His fingers smell like oil and ocean. He wants to feed her ramen and watch her get mad at chopsticks. He wants to put a bullet through the past and miss on purpose. The bounty groans through the gag. Revy rolls her eyes and plants a boot in his shoulder as a reminder to be quiet. “You from space, cowboy?” she asks, eyes never leaving his. “For now.” “How’s the view?” “Same as here.” He exhales. “Dead stars. Cheap bars.” She laughs then, something real and jagged. “You ever come back to this toilet, look me up.” “You ever leave it, look me up.” They are ten feet apart and one inch closer than either of them has been to anyone in a long time. The room holds its breath. He reaches into his pocket. Her hand lands on a pistol like a reflex made of older reflexes. “Easy,” he says, lifting the lighter. “Thought your bottle deserved a proper goodbye.” He flicks it. The flame lifts. The rust ring flashes like an old wound smiling. For a second, in the gold, they’re both softer versions of themselves. For a second, she looks scared of nothing in particular. For a second, he looks alive. She stubs out her cigarette on the cracked windowsill. “We split,” she says, and it’s not about the money anymore. “Even,” he says, putting out the flame. A knock at the door. Two men with a van-sized appetite for trouble. Papers to sign. Money to count. Revy tucks half into a place no one will survive reaching for. Spike tucks his into a coat that needs a tailor and a future. They stand in the threshold as the bounty gets dragged away, fluorescent hall light making them ghosts. “Whatever happens, happens,” he says. She rolls her shoulder, the dragon rippling. “And whatever doesn’t, didn’t.” They look at each other until looking becomes the same as touching and they both stop before it’s too late or too early. He turns first because he always does when it counts. She lets him because she doesn’t want to see him go. He walks into the humid dark with a lighter that’s seen oceans and a hunger that noodles won’t fix. She lights another cigarette and tries not to think about the hand she didn’t put on his chest. Somewhere, a sign flickers: OT L. The night says the rest. The motel door shuts with a soft click that sounds like a gun cooling down. They will tell the story different ways. He’ll say she almost shot him. She’ll say she should have. Both will know better. Both will sleep badly. Both will wake wanting the same thing and pretending they don’t. Whatever happens, happens. And sometimes, it doesn’t. But it almost does. And almost is enough to make a man keep the rust on his lighter like a promise.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece is a remarkably well-crafted character study that brings together two iconic anime characters with similar yet distinct personalities. The author demonstrates exceptional skill in capturing the essence of both Spike and Revy while creating a believable scenario for their interaction. The prose style is distinctive and confident, employing a noir-influenced, staccato rhythm that perfectly suits the seedy setting and the characters' hardened personalities. The author uses metaphor and simile with precision: "A fan on the ceiling turns slow as a planet tired of spinning" and "She walks as if the floor owes her money" are particularly effective examples that establish atmosphere and character in economical fashion. The characterization is outstanding. Spike's laid-back fatalism and Revy's aggressive volatility are rendered faithfully to their source material. Their dialogue is sparse but loaded with subtext, capturing their respective voices perfectly. The author understands that these characters communicate as much through action as through words, and the gunfight sequence brilliantly demonstrates their mutual professional respect—they shoot near but not at each other, testing boundaries rather than seeking to kill. The unresolved sexual tension is handled with remarkable subtlety. Rather than resorting to clichéd descriptions of physical attraction, the author conveys their connection through small details: the shared cigarettes, the way they notice each other's scars and habits, the careful maintenance of physical distance that feels more intimate than touch. The line "They are ten feet apart and one inch closer than either of them has been to anyone in a long time" perfectly encapsulates this dynamic. The structure is tight and purposeful. The narrative builds tension effectively through the bar encounter, the gunfight, and the motel room standoff, with each scene revealing more about the characters' similarities and differences. The resolution—or deliberate lack thereof—feels true to both characters, who recognize their mutual attraction but are too damaged and distrustful to act on it. If there are weaknesses, they are minor. Occasionally the prose veers slightly toward the purple, with metaphors that call attention to themselves. The actual bounty capture feels somewhat secondary to the character study, though this is clearly by design. Some readers might find the ending too ambiguous, though it perfectly suits these characters who are defined by their inability to form lasting connections. Overall, this is an exceptional piece of character-driven fiction that demonstrates a deep understanding of both source materials while creating something fresh and compelling in their intersection. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 20 Nuanced Characters: 20 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 19 Emotionally Complex: 20 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 20.0, Nuanced Characters: 20.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 19.0, Emotionally Complex: 20.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Folk horror: Útiseta — Score: 88.8
Prompt:
Folk Horror: Útiseta Write a chapter set in rural northern Sweden in the mid-1990s. Linnea, a teenage girl from Stockholm, has reluctantly moved to a small village with her parents after her father's job transfer. She's befriended Astrid, a local girl who claims her grandmother taught her ancient practices passed down through generations. Astrid has been introducing Linnea to "midnight games" that involve old rituals, convincing her they can use them to learn classmates' secrets or influence their behavior. Tonight, Astrid has convinced Linnea to participate in Útiseta—sitting out on an ancient burial mound at midnight to "receive knowledge from beyond." The chapter focuses on this single midnight excursion, the ritualistic preparations, Astrid's matter-of-fact instructions that mix teenage rebellion with eerily specific traditional elements, and the mounting tension as Linnea becomes increasingly uncertain whether they're simply scaring themselves or if something is actually responding to their presence. The narrative should maintain ambiguity about whether the strange occurrences are supernatural or psychological, while establishing the dangerous line they're crossing by treating ancient practices as entertainment. First person, past tense, told as Linnea's recollection of events in the present day (though this device should be largely transparent). 1000 words. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
Astrid had said it would be easy because it was old. “Older than church,” she’d told me in that careless way she had, like a shoulder-shrug could make anything ordinary. “You just sit. That’s all. You keep still and you listen. People here did it when they needed to know things. They went out and sat.” She called it Útiseta like it was a word she used every day. I repeated it under my breath on the bike ride out of the village, feeling the shape of the vowels in my mouth like something borrowed: oo-tee-seh-tah. It was July, a late pale summer evening that would never quite become full night. The sky was the color of skimmed milk with a bruise in it, and the mosquitoes hovered even in the wind that came off the lake. We passed wooden fences patched with rusty wire and fields of thin barley that leaned as if trying to hear something in the dirt. Back in Stockholm I had counted my years by train lines and cinema release dates. Here, people measured distance by the time it took to walk on a snowmobile track when the marsh froze. I’d learned names of places that weren’t on maps: Lillskogen, the Witch’s Finger, the Ravine. The burial mound was called simply Högen, which made me think of cartoons until Astrid took me there the first time and I saw the hill for what it was: a swell in the earth, a gentle hump with stones showing through like knuckles. There was a ring of black spruce around it, and wild strawberries grew on the sides, tiny and sweet and close to the ground. We left our bikes by the ditch and moved quiet, which was ridiculous because we were fifteen and sixteen and being quiet should have been an act we’d long forgotten how to pull off. But there was something in the trees that made both of us lower our voices without talking about it. The wind tugged at the tops of the pines and made a noise that wasn’t quite a hiss, not quite a whisper, and I felt it crawl along my scalp like a hand. “Okay,” Astrid said when we reached the clearing. “First you spit.” I laughed. “Sorry?” She tilted her head, her pale braids sliding forward. In daylight she had freckles and chipped pink nail polish and the kind of mouth that made boys want to tell jokes. Here, her face looked flat and serious, and her eyes were dark as tree knots. “Not at it. In your hand.” She cupped her palm and spat into it, then rubbed the spit over the inside of her wrists like perfume. “Sweat and spit and smoke. Otherwise your smell is wrong.” “Wrong for what?” I asked, but I did it, because that was how it worked with Astrid; you said you didn’t believe and did it anyway. “For listening,” she said. “For who’s listening. Hold out your hands.” She drew a match from the pocket of her black denim jacket and struck it. The sulfur popped. She passed the flame under my fingers, quickly enough not to burn, just so the smoke licked the spit-damp skin and turned it to something else. She did her own wrists, then held the match under her hair, which snapped and curled at the ends where it got too close. She shook it out and ground the match head into the dirt with her boot. “I thought we were just sitting,” I said. “Why the drama?” “It isn’t drama.” She looked offended. “It’s manners.” We had a blanket rolled up in her backpack, but she didn’t spread it on top of the mound. She walked around it once, counterclockwise, tapping her fingers against her thigh and counting under her breath. She stopped at three steps from where we’d started. “There,” she said. “Never on top. You sit where the head is, not on the chest.” “I feel like there are a lot of rules you haven’t told me.” I tried to make it sound like a joke. “There are a lot of rules.” She had the blanket in her hands and didn’t unfold it. “But you can just remember to sit and keep quiet. You can do that, right?” “Sure.” I was about to add something sarcastic, something about being from Stockholm and knowing how to sit, but it fell flat in my mouth. The long dusk had thickened. In the trees the wind ran a hand through the needles and they shivered, and I had the sense of being watched, which I told myself came from stories and mosquitoes and nothing else. Traffic was a memory out here. The sound carried farther and everything in it was distinct: the snap of a twig, the slap of a mosquito against your ear, the gust that made the small cones clatter. “What do we do with the blanket?” I asked. “We put it over our knees if it gets cold.” She said it with a tone so practical that I believed, for a second, that I was the one being melodramatic. The whole point was to strip everything away: no candles, no chanting, no necklaces with teeth on them. She had rolled her eyes at me when I asked early on if we needed salt circles. “It’s not a movie,” she had said. “It’s sitting.” The first time she told me she knew things about our classmates that she couldn’t know, I’d laughed and then pressed her the way I pressed the test questions that somehow didn’t have answers at the back of the book. She’d said that Mia’s dad had a blue Jägermeister blanket folded in his car trunk, underneath the winter shovel, and that he cried in the garage when he thought nobody could hear him. She’d said that Hanna, who flirted with the older boys at the rink, kept a little jar of Vaseline in her pocket because she was terrified her lips would crack. Those were easy, I told her. You could guess. But then she told me about the picture Mr. Lindgren kept behind the tax tables in his desk drawer, a way he could look at his son and pretend it was a reason to drink coffee at ten at night. “The corner is bent,” she said. “He keeps playing with it.” She said it like she wasn’t bragging, like she was sharing something mildly interesting, and the next day when we stayed late to copy notes the door to his office was open and there was the desk and the drawer and the sharp smell of paper and coffee and nothing else, and I didn’t look, and that was the same as looking. Now, on the edge of the mound, she sat with her back straight and her hands on her knees. “Okay,” she said. “Ask.” “What do we ask?” She made a face. “What do you think? You want to know if Sebastian is going to dump you or if he cheated on the English test. Things like that.” “Sebastian hasn’t spoken to me in three weeks,” I said, and the words were out before I could stop them, which was not how I wanted to be with her. “And I don’t care.” I did. I cared in that hollow-stomach way that made you count days by the times you didn’t walk past someone’s locker. “Then ask something else.” She sat. I sat three feet away, feeling the damp creep into my jeans through the moss. The mound under me was warm, holding the day’s heat. I put my hands on my knees and tried to slow my breathing. “Do I say it out loud?” “If you whisper, you’ll scare birds,” she said. “Just think it like you think your own name.” I thought my own name: Linnea. It sounded wrong in this place, like plastic in a wooden room. I thought of my mother hanging curtains in the kitchen, my father learning the names of the men at the paper mill, the way he practiced them out loud so he wouldn’t get it wrong. I thought about leaving, which was a kind of asking. But what came out without my permission was: How do I make them like me? It was so ugly I wanted to cover my face with my hands. I stared hard at the tree line. The wind took a long breath and let it go. The pines made their sound—almost-whispers, not words exactly but the shape of words in someone else’s mouth. A mosquito touched my cheek and I slapped it and my palm came away smeared with a dot of my own blood. Somewhere at my back a bird snapped its wings and settled. Astrid’s voice came low. “You can’t flinch,” she said. “If you flinch, they see you.” “Who?” She didn’t answer. She sat very still. Her stillness made my skin itch. After a while my eyes adjusted to the milky dark. The sky kept its human glow like a curtain lifted but not tied back. The mound had its own geometry; nothing on it was straight. Stones pushed up in a pattern you could only see if you unfocused your eyes, like the Magic Eye pictures that had been everywhere the year before. I let my gaze slide, and the stones became a line, and the line became a shape, and the shape was a man bending, burying. I blinked, and it was stones again. A crack came from the edge of the trees, loud as a breaking plate. My head turned before I could stop it. “Linnea.” Astrid didn’t look at me. Her voice pressed my name flat. “I just told you.” “I didn’t,” I started, and stopped. My heart was in my mouth. “There’s something there.” “Maybe,” she said. “Ask properly.” How do I make them like me? I thought again, and then, because I hated myself, I added: How do I make Sebastian see me? The question felt like dropping a coin down a well and hearing no splash. The wind ran through the pines, stopped, ran again. I tried to slow my breathing. I thought about not moving, about not scratching the itch that had started at the crook of my elbow. The itch moved; it became a little line of heat across my skin like a very small finger. I didn’t look. I imagined the mosquitoes forming letters. A moped buzzed faintly somewhere far away and then cut out. The village was a storybook across the field. Houses like painted boxes. Dogs sleeping curled under the stairs. The burial ground was a place that existed before those things and would exist after. I felt the thought as if it wasn’t mine. Astrid inhaled. “You feel that?” she asked, very softly. “What?” “Don’t talk.” The scold carried no heat. It was almost tender. It was temperature I felt. A cooling on the skin above my knees, a faint movement in the air that wasn’t wind. The pine whispers dimmed. There was a silence that wasn’t the absence of sound but a weight put on top of it. I hadn’t noticed how many small noises the world made until they all leaned back like surprised people in a crowd. Something touched my shoe. It could have been a falling cone. It could have been a beetle. It could have been nothing. I kept my eyes on the dark line of trees and said nothing and did not move. The touches came again, a series along the rubber toe of my sneaker, light as the tips of grass. If I let my mind name it, it was a hand. If I didn’t, it was the wind. “What do I give?” Astrid asked into the air, and I thought she hadn’t told me about giving. She reached into the pocket of her jacket and pulled out something small. I could smell smoke and meat; she had brought a piece of dried reindeer. She didn’t get up. She stretched out an arm and set the meat on the moss and pulled her hand back, slow, slow, like a person working a splinter out of a child’s foot. “We’re not supposed to bring things,” I whispered. “No,” she said. “We’re not supposed to take things. We’re supposed to leave them.” “Leave what?” “Pieces,” she said. “So they have a reason to come.” The matter-of-factness in her tone wrapped around something hard. I thought of the rules I didn’t know and how they weren’t written anywhere, and how in this place the difference between a dare and a promise was just whether you meant it when you said it. The weight of silence eased. The wind moved through the pines again and their not-quite-words came back. The pressure lifted, or I convinced myself it had. My foot felt nothing but my sock. I realized I had been holding my breath and let it go. “Okay,” Astrid said, like she’d just finished tying her shoe. “That’s good.” She stood, and the movement startled me so much I jerked to my feet, my knees stiff and damp. The blanket lay untouched, forgotten. There was a damp patch on my jeans where the moss had given back what it had taken from the air. “What did you—” I started. “What did you feel?” She shrugged. “They’re listening. They’re always listening. Sometimes they answer.” “What did they say?” She smiled, and it wasn’t kind or cruel; it was the smile she wore when she lied to grown-ups and they never noticed. “You’ll know. When you go to school and people treat you different, you’ll know.” “I don’t want to—” I began, hot in the face with something like shame, and stopped. The trees shifted and the whispers ran through them and made the hairs on my arms stand up. We walked back to the bikes with our lights off, pushing them until we hit the gravel road. My fingers were cold around the handlebars. Astrid hummed under her breath, a tune I didn’t recognize, and every now and then she flicked the bell with her thumb, so it made a bright, small sound, like a metal frog. At home I washed my hands longer than I needed to. My mother called from the living room to ask if I’d had fun, and I said yes, which was the wrong word, and she nodded without looking at me, her attention on a game show where everyone was cheerful. In my room I lay on my back and listened to the wind through the open window. It ran through the pines and gave them voices. It sounded like someone in the next room, talking about me. In the morning I found a brown streak across the toe of my sneaker where something had dragged. It could have been dirt. At school, Mia said my hair looked nice and asked if I wanted to sit with her in history. Sebastian passed me in the corridor and said hey like a normal person, and later I would tell myself he would have done that anyway, that things are always shifting under us and we only think it’s because we asked. Later, I would learn another of Astrid’s rules and see how late it had come. You can sit out and not bring anything, her grandmother had told her. But you must leave something. You must always leave something. If you don’t, it might be you. And even now, even remembering, I can’t tell you if we left meat or if we left something else on Högen that night. Only that the wind spoke in almost-words, and we were reckless enough to pretend we understood.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This folk horror piece successfully captures the essence of the Útiseta ritual while maintaining the requested ambiguity between psychological and supernatural elements. The author has crafted a compelling narrative that follows Linnea's experience with the ancient ritual, skillfully balancing teenage dynamics with eerie folkloric elements. The writing excels in establishing atmosphere through sensory details. Descriptions like "The sky was the color of skimmed milk with a bruise in it" and the way the wind makes "a noise that wasn't quite a hiss, not quite a whisper" create a palpable sense of unease. The author effectively uses the Swedish setting, incorporating local terminology and geographical features that ground the story in its specific cultural context. Character dynamics are well-developed. Astrid is portrayed as knowledgeable yet casual about dangerous ancient practices, while Linnea's skepticism mixed with curiosity feels authentic for a city girl transplanted to rural Sweden. Their relationship has complexity—Linnea both admires and resents Astrid's confidence and knowledge. The ritual itself is presented with just the right balance of mundane details and unsettling elements. The preparations—spitting into hands, passing matches under fingers—feel both improvised by teenagers and eerily specific. The author maintains ambiguity about whether anything supernatural occurs, allowing readers to interpret the events either way. The narrative effectively uses first-person past tense as requested, with Linnea recounting the experience. The present-day framing is subtle, primarily appearing in the final paragraph with "even now, even remembering," which provides the requested transparent device. Where the piece could be stronger is in its pacing during the middle section. Some descriptions become slightly repetitive, particularly regarding the wind and trees. Additionally, while the ending effectively maintains ambiguity, it feels slightly rushed compared to the careful buildup of the ritual. The dialogue is generally strong, though occasionally Astrid's explanations feel a bit too expository. However, this serves the narrative purpose of establishing her as the knowledgeable guide to these practices. Overall, this is an accomplished piece of folk horror that successfully creates an atmosphere of unease while exploring the dangerous territory of treating ancient practices as entertainment. It adheres closely to the prompt requirements while delivering a compelling narrative with authentic characters and setting. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Physical-spatial: Therapeutic Boundaries — Score: 94.5
Prompt:
**"Therapeutic Boundaries"** Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of a former professional athlete undergoing mandatory physical therapy after a career-destroying injury, harboring resentment toward recovery itself. Their physiotherapist is not only unnervingly attractive but also a former training partner from their competitive days who has successfully transitioned to a new career while the protagonist's identity remains shattered. We'll lean into the sexual tension of the scene by having her be attracted to him, but both of them attempting to maintain mental distance while being in physical contact as he shows her stretches & movements & manipulates her body, navigating the thresholds of pain. This scene MUST maintain complete physical coherence—every movement, stretch, and manipulation must be anatomically precise and spatially consistent. Paint an exceptionally vivid sensory picture through detailed attention to pain thresholds, involuntary responses to touch. Capture the suppressed, flaring tension of physical proximity, touch, and the controlled infliction of uncomfortable movements. Physical clarity is essential — readers must understand exactly what is happening with the body during each therapeutic technique. 1000 words.
Model Output:
He’s already set the table for me when I limp in—vinyl plinth at mid-thigh height, foam wedge at one end, a clipboard balanced on the stool where I used to sit between heats. He wears those absurd compression sleeves—teal and orange chevrons sliding from wrist to bicep—that he wore the year he beat me by three tenths. They make my skin pull tight across the scar along my lateral thigh like the memory is underneath it, shivering. “Hey,” he says, as if the word doesn’t have ten years of weight. He looks at me just long enough to register changes—meat gone from my right glute, a hitch in the stride, the way my left shoulder hikes to guard against the pain. His eyes flick to the scar and back. He doesn’t say I’m sorry. Good. “On the couch, right sidelying to start,” he says. “We’ll do tissue prep and joint assessment, then load if you’re calm.” I’m never calm. Still, I turn, hitch myself onto the table. Right sidelying means my right hip stacked over my left, knees bent to ninety, ankles together. The foam wedge props under my waist to keep my spine neutral; he nudges it with two fingers until my iliac crest feels level. The vinyl is cold through the thin shorts, and the smell of disinfectant doesn’t cover the rubber’s animal tang. His hands are warmer than mine. He uses the flat of his right palm to smooth over the band of scar tissue that corrugates my right tensor fasciae latae like a badly repaired zipper. “Just contact,” he says. “Breath in the back of your ribs.” He means expand posteriorly, not lift the chest. I let my ribs widen against his hand where he’s slid it under me, palm broad on my lower thoracic paraspinals. When I exhale, he drags the heel of his other hand distally along the iliotibial band, not directly on it but just anterior, along the vastus lateralis. It’s not pain yet—more like an ache waking up under a heavy blanket. “Pain?” he asks. “Not pain,” I say, which is true, and a lie. It isn’t the knife-to-socket lightning that tore me off the track six months ago. It’s the controlled, curated almost-pain of someone who knows exactly how far to push and who knows I know it too. He has a tell when he’s concentrating: he presses his tongue to the inside of his cheek. He’s doing it now, the muscle in his jaw fluttering under the beard stubble he never used to have. He pins the skin and fascia over the TFL with his thumb and asks me to flex the hip, just ten degrees. My pelvis wants to roll back; he’s already there, his left forearm across my iliac crest, holding me stacked. I bring my right knee forward a fraction, feel the tissue under his thumb slide—and then catch, like velcro. He holds through my micro-tremor, not chasing, just corraling the movement. “Again,” he says. “Slow.” The second pass hurts. Not sharp, not hot. Granular, like chewing ice with a cracked tooth. My breath flares up into my throat. He says, “Drop your ribs,” which is an old cue, one I associate with summer heat and lane three and believing my body was a machine that would obey me. I drop them. The pain changes shape, slides somewhere I can file it. He strokes proximally along the lateral quad and into the thickened junction where muscle becomes tendon near the greater trochanter. “You feel this?” he asks, and presses with two fingers, perpendicular pressure, until a line of sensation lights up along the outside of my thigh. It’s exactly the line that sings when I try to accelerate. “Longitudinal gliding,” he says to the clipboard. “Lats/ITB adjacent. Hypersensitive.” “Don’t narrate me,” I say. He smiles without showing teeth. “Old habit.” “So is losing to you,” I mutter. “We can load,” he says, as if I haven’t spoken. “Turn supine.” The change in position is a choreography we once did without thought. Now each pivot is an arithmetic problem: roll shoulders, keep pelvis still, bring knees together, place feet flat on the table at hip-width. He helps me minimally: a hand under my right heel to guide it, a restraint on my left ASIS to keep me from rolling. His contact is precise. It also makes heat unfurl from my abdomen in a way that has nothing to do with tissue temperature. “Neutral pelvis,” he says. His right hand is on my lower abdomen, fingers on the left and thumb on the right, feeling the ASIS under the skin; his other hand is under my lumbar spine, palpating the lordosis. “Exhale. Think pubic bone to sternum.” I posteriorly tilt until his bottom hand loses contact with the little arch of my lower back. My hamstrings try to clench. He taps the inside of my knees. “Let the hamstrings go. Think lower abs. Again.” The cue is infuriating because it’s correct. I soften my ankles, let the knees be heavy, stop trying so hard. The contraction migrates up from the pelvic floor to deep in the lower abdomen. My right adductor flickers; he notices, of course. His thumb slides to the inside of my right thigh, just above the knee, and presses down. “Not here,” he says. “Here.” He moves his other hand to the inside of my lower belly, only it’s not inside, it just feels like it, slow pulsing contact on the transversus. Heat spikes under my skin. I clench my jaw. The ceiling’s fluorescent panel hums. He moves to my right side and lifts my leg with one arm cradling under my calf and the other stabilizing the knee. “Passive hip flexion,” he says. He brings my hip to ninety degrees, knee bent, foot relaxed. I feel the head of my femur glide in the acetabulum like a weight rolling in a bowl. At ninety-five I wince; at a hundred the ache blooms. He stops at ninety-eight. “Where are you?” “Ninety-eight,” I say, because his brain and mine used to calibrate to the same ruler. He cradles my thigh against his torso to keep the hip flexed, then abducts slightly—knee out to the side just a few degrees. He is very close. His sleeves brush my skin, the compression fabric rasping lightly. He externally rotates my hip—foot moves inward, knee out—and I feel the posterior capsule wake up, a stretch like a yawn in the back of the joint. “Breathe into it,” he says quietly. I hate that his voice still has the rhythm of a starter’s pistol. I do as told. The stretch spreads, diffuse. He holds for two breaths. On the third, I feel the guard drop a millimeter. He catches it. “There,” he says. “Let me take it.” He slides me another few degrees into rotation. Pain sharpens and then flickers out to the lateral thigh. He pin-and-moves again: thumb at the front of the hip over the TFL, the other hand guiding my tibia to change the vector. The precise lines of what is being asked and what is being allowed draw themselves in the map of my body. “I hate this,” I say, because the words are safer than the silence. “I know,” he says, and I believe him, which makes me hate it more. He sets my leg down carefully, heel to table, knee bent, foot neutral. Then he steps to my left and lifts my right leg into a straight-leg raise, ankle dorsiflexed, foot pointing to the ceiling. “Tell me when you feel posterior thigh.” “At forty.” I feel the hamstring bite. He does a sciatic nerve glide, tipping my ankle into plantarflexion while flexing my hip five degrees more, then dorsiflexing the ankle while lowering the leg. The nerve tension shifts without compressing into a corner. It’s maddeningly efficient, like watching someone you used to beat walk through your old times. “Good,” he says. “Bridge.” I bend both knees, bring heels closer to sit bones. He places his fingertips on the spines of my pelvis, tracking symmetry. “Exhale. Posterior tilt. Lift tailbone, then sacrum, then L5 through T12.” He cues the sequence while his hands follow the vertebral segments lifting. My right glute refuses to fire at the same time as the left: it lags, the force traveling up the chain feels like a crooked zipper. At the top, he taps the right glute med with two fingers just posterior to the iliac crest. “Think wide,” he says. It’s a cue from our old coach. It makes my right hip stop trying to pull into extension with back muscles and instead widen into abduction, the pelvis level, the inner line in my thigh quiets. He makes me hold. The burn accu mulates in the deep lateral hip, an ache under the iliac crest that would make me bail if I were alone. He counts: “Three, two, slow down. Segmental.” I lower vertebra by vertebra. On L4 I falter; he puts his palm under and gives me a target: resist the hand, then melt. I do it. When my sacrum touches the table, my hamstrings seize. He presses his palm into them and rolls them like dough until the spasm lets go. It feels intimate and humiliating and necessary. “Side plank,” he says, cheerful. He helps me onto my left side again, stacks my legs, lines my elbow under my shoulder. He cups my right waist, fingers along the obliques. “Lift from here,” he says. His sleeves brush my bare flank as he stabilizes my pelvis. I push into my forearm and the outer edge of my left foot, lifting my pelvis. The right lateral line shouts. He holds me steady with the lightest touch imaginable. My breath is shallow and fast. His hand moves to my top hip, pressing down to stop me from hitching. “Long,” he says. I lengthen out of my waist instead of curling. The trembling starts around the five-second mark. He waits until eight. “Lower slow,” he says, and I do, even though every cell screams to drop. By the time we stand, my legs are shaky and my skin thrums. He has me place my right foot on a low step, hip-width apart, hip hinge: pelvis back, spine long. “Reach,” he says, and he touches my ribs to prevent rotation as I reach my left hand forward and feel my right glute engage without the hamstrings stealing. “Five reps,” he says. “No compensation.” His eyes are on my pelvis, not my face. Mine are everywhere, not his face either, unless they are, sliding and away. The sleeves flash in my peripheral vision; I remember them windmilling in victory. He puts both hands on my pelvis, thumbs on my PSIS, and guides me into a small single-leg squat. My knee tracks over my second toe; he steers with micro corrections at my hip, not the knee, applying pressure just enough to nudge the femur into internal rotation at the right moment. When I drop past the safe zone, the pain flares along the lateral hip, sharp and clean. I stop, hold. My breath wants to lock. “Exhale like fogging glass,” he says, and when I do, the pain reclassifies to sensation and then to signal. “Again.” We do one more. And one more. The room is small and bright and smells like mint. The mirror is merciless. My body is an unfamiliar instrument being re-tuned by hands that know all its bad habits and good tricks. He is so close when he adjusts my ribcage that I can see the scar in his eyebrow I gave him with my spikes in a warm-up collision once. He caught me that day by the wrist to keep me from face-planting. He doesn’t touch my wrist now, because that would be the wrong thing. He touches my bones. We finish with a prone hip extension test. I lie face down, pillow under pelvis to erase lumbar extension. He slides his hands under my ASIS again to feel cheating. “Lift right leg, knee straight.” I float the leg two inches. He says “no back,” and I correct: downshift from paraspinals into glute. The movement becomes smaller and heavier, more honest. My hamstrings sigh. He’s quiet, watching in the mirror, eyes distant, professional, not. When it’s over, I sit up and swing my legs off the table. The room tilts. He stands close enough that I could lean into the chevrons if I wanted. I don’t. My hands are shaky. He hands me water. Our fingers brush. The contact is an electric slice I swallow like a pill. “Homework,” he says, already writing. “Supine TA activation with breath, two sets of eight. Side plank holds, three by ten seconds on the right. Step downs, five each, mirror. And—” He pauses like there’s one more thing he could say, something that isn’t an exercise. He doesn’t say it. “Log the pain. Discern between stretch and joint. You know the difference.” “I used to,” I say. “You still do,” he says, and it lands somewhere under my ribs. On the way out, I catch the edge of the table with my hip, graceless. He steps forward without thinking, one hand out, stopping short of my waist. We both feel the ghost of what would have been contact. The moment holds, compresses, releases. He drops his hand. I keep walking. The sleeves flash as he turns back to the clipboard, and the pain in my hip is louder than desire, and quieter too. I hate recovery, but I come back Thursday.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative brilliantly captures the complex dynamics between a former professional athlete and their physiotherapist. The piece excels in its anatomical precision, creating a technically accurate portrayal of physical therapy that simultaneously serves as a vehicle for exploring the psychological and emotional tension between the characters. The writing demonstrates exceptional technical knowledge of physical therapy procedures. Terms like "posterior tilt," "transversus," "iliotibial band," and "tensor fasciae latae" are used with confidence and accuracy. Each movement is described with spatial clarity that allows readers to visualize exactly what is happening. The author maintains physical coherence throughout, never losing track of body positioning or anatomical relationships. What elevates this piece beyond mere technical exercise is how it weaves the physical therapy into the emotional narrative. The protagonist's resentment toward recovery is palpable, expressed through lines like "I hate this" and the way they compare their current struggles to past athletic performance. The history between the characters emerges organically through details like "the sleeves flash in my peripheral vision; I remember them windmilling in victory" and "the scar in his eyebrow I gave him with my spikes in a warm-up collision once." The sexual tension is handled with remarkable subtlety and restraint. Rather than resorting to obvious descriptions, the author conveys it through physiological responses ("Heat spikes under my skin"), fleeting moments of almost-contact ("We both feel the ghost of what would have been contact"), and the protagonist's hyperawareness of the therapist's proximity. This approach creates a simmering undercurrent that never overwhelms the primary narrative. The prose style is controlled and precise, mirroring the controlled nature of physical therapy itself. Sentences vary effectively between clinical descriptions and emotional revelations. The author employs sensory details masterfully, from the "vinyl plinth" and its "animal tang" to the "mint" smell of the room and the "electric slice" of finger contact. Character development is nuanced despite the brevity of the piece. The protagonist's complex emotions—resentment, attraction, determination, and vulnerability—are conveyed through their physical responses and sparse dialogue. The therapist is equally well-drawn through his professional demeanor that occasionally slips to reveal their shared history. The ending strikes a perfect balance, avoiding both saccharine resolution and complete despair. The line "I hate recovery, but I come back Thursday" encapsulates the protagonist's conflicted state—still resentful but committed to the process, perhaps partly due to the connection with the therapist. If there are any weaknesses, they might be in occasional moments where the technical language could overwhelm readers unfamiliar with anatomy. However, even these passages remain comprehensible through context, and they contribute to the authenticity of the narrative. Overall, this is an exceptionally well-crafted piece that fulfills all the requirements of the prompt while transcending them to create a genuinely moving and psychologically complex narrative. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20 Elegant Prose: 19 Emotionally Engaging: 19 Emotionally Complex: 19 Coherent: 20 Meandering: 2 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 1 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20.0, Elegant Prose: 19.0, Emotionally Engaging: 19.0, Emotionally Complex: 19.0, Coherent: 20.0, Meandering: 2.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 1.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Historical fiction: High Seas and Low Vices — Score: 88.0
Prompt:
High Seas and Low Vices: British Naval Officer in the Opium Trade Character: Lieutenant James Merrick, a high-ranking officer in the British Royal Navy stationed in Canton, China in the 1830s. Once promising and decorated, now struggling with a severe opium addiction he hides from his superiors. Synopsis: Write a chapter following Lieutenant Merrick during a single day as he shirks his official naval duties in what has become a daily need to satiate the dragon. Told primarily in dialogue with the characters he interacts with. Focus on brief slices of his journey through the shadowy underworld of Canton: interactions with acquaintances, negotiations with local dealers, schemes and unsavoury jobs taken to fund his habit. Writing Task: Use rich sensory details to describe a day in the life of James Merrick. Write for a real sense of time & place while avoiding cliche. First person, past tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The bell at Hog Lane tolled twice before I realised the dust on my boots belonged to yesterday. “Lieutenant Merrick, where are you bound?” cried Wilkes from the gangway, his voice bright as a biscuit tin. “To the quartermaster,” I lied, tapping my cap with a hand that could not stay still. “That inventory of salt pork still wants checking.” “You look ill, sir.” “Sea air,” I said. “Too many nights in it.” The cough came on the end of that, a dry rattle I swallowed, that copper taste like a coin pressed under my tongue. He let me go. The Pearl River lay flat as hammered tin. Sampans drifted like black beetles against the paler water. A breeze brought the stink of tallow, fish, the sour sweetness of the city. Cannon Street’s whitewashed fronts blinked at the light, and beyond, Canton began to speak in clatters and hawks and the soft slap of wooden sandals. I set my pace to the clamor of the morning, to the opening of shutters and the thump of sacks against thresholds, to drown the ache in my bones that beat time from inside my ribs. A boy no taller than my waist called, “Flowery water, cold water!” and his buckets swung, tinkling. He looked at me with the open stare of children and dogs. I gave him a coin and drank, the water tasting of clay and river, as if it remembered every fish that had ever died in it. “You go factory today, Lieutenant?” said Mr. Thomson, a trading clerk I’d lost at cards last week. “Later,” I said, water running down my chin. “I’m sent for a message from Pidgin Alley.” “Hah! Tell them we have no more tin teapots until the tide changes.” He gave me his sly grin. “I heard you were due to examine Capt. Harding’s charts.” “Sea air,” I said when he reached to clap my shoulder and then drew back at the pallor of my skin. He laughed without humour. “Aye, it does wreck a man.” A junk’s hull rasped the quay as men heaved. Canton’s mouth opened wider. I turned from the river and into Hog Lane, into the steam of soy and hot oil, into the murmur that lowers itself when a uniform enters and then rises to cover it. There was a little shaving of shade in the lane where the wall had been blackened with oil smoke, and in it sat Ginger Harris, his back against a cracked stucco pillar. “You walk like your boots don’t fit,” he said, his voice muffled by his hat brim. “Fine coat for the Company’s dogs.” “Royal Navy,” I said, though the coat felt too heavy. “I need to talk to Weng.” “Weng won’t see you with those shoulders,” Ginger said. “He sees men who walk like they don’t know how thin they are.” “I’ve money.” “Then you’ll see anyone you like.” He pushed himself up slowly, bones creaking like a ship’s. “But he won’t take your queen’s face. He wants silver that bites.” “I have Spanish,” I said. He glanced at the bulge in my pocket, then at my hands again. “And there’s the matter of the fee. You’ve been a ghost these last days, Jamie.” “I’ve kept to the river.” “The river keeps you, more like.” He kicked his heel at a stray dog; the thing slunk aside and then came back with an eye fixed on us, hopeful. The sun found my neck and made me aware of every drop of sweat there. “We had an understanding,” I said. “I’m good for the rest.” “Hah.” He grinned and showed his bad teeth. “They all say that, and then the mandarins thump their drums and the hawks come out, and it’s a new tune then. Come. He’ll be in the back, behind the blue jars.” We threaded through a tangle of mats, baskets, and women sitting with their legs tucked like birds. The smells stacked atop one another: star anise, brine, charred sugar, stale rice. I coughed and it tasted like the iron hoop of a barrel, and Ginger said, “Get that looked at.” “Sea air,” I said. He did not laugh. He led me under a lintel with a painted carp leaping through waves. The shop beyond was narrow as a coffin and twice as dark. Latticed light fell on rows of porcelain glazes like resting moons. And through those, down a step, in a room that smelled of ashes and orange peel, sat Weng. He wore his robe like a man wears patience. Two boys flanked him, their hair braided, their eyes unreadable. “Merrick,” Weng said in the flattest English. He had learned the name as a shape he could pick up with tips of fingers. “You come empty.” “I’ve silver.” I put the coins on the table. They seemed loud, like bells. “Empty,” he repeated, and raised one hand a fraction. The boys did not move, but I felt them as the room’s corners. “And late.” “Look,” I said. “Any other day, I’d be early and carrying oranges for your mother. Today—” He set a small pipe upon the table as if it were a bird he was training. “English officers always have excuses. Their ships always late when they must be early. Their mouths always busy.” “I’ve done work for you,” I said, forcing my voice to the same calm. “I steered the cutter past the watch at the Salamander quay. I carried letters to the godowns at night. I kept Peters’ stupid mouth shut when he wanted to brag that he’d a pipe under his mattress.” Weng’s face made a movement that might have been amusement or an itch. “This why you live, Lieutenant. Your ship has guns. Your words have small guns.” He nudged my coins with a fingernail. “And your money has little teeth. Spanish is good.” “It is,” Ginger said. “And his need is honest.” Weng shifted the pipe aside. “Honest need is biggest thief. Today, you make errand, then you can smoke. There is a parcel in Pidgin Alley. You take it to the red door by the temple of the Five Genii. No soldier eyes. No knocking twice. You make mistake, you come back with the mistake.” “What is it?” I asked. His eyebrow ticked. “A parcel.” “I’m not carrying a poppy ship down my throat sight unseen,” I said. “Not without—” “All you do, you do without seeing,” he said. “You steer blind; you sleep blind; you swallow blind.” He stood, smoothing his robe, and in those motions I saw how very little I mattered. “The red door. You will be there before the shadow of the joss-house roof reaches the third stone.” “I can’t stay away so long,” I said. “They’ll miss me aboard.” Ginger chuckled. “They miss your hat, not you.” He clapped my shoulder. “Come, Jamie.” In the alley, sweat made the dust tacky to my skin. The pipe had seemed to breathe on me from the table, though I hadn’t touched it. Pidgin Alley was a bright slit of hats and faces, sailors haggling in words that had no grammar but every intention, dogs trotting with tails like plumes. I found the stall with the painted crane, as Weng had described on some night past, when he spoke to me as if I were an instrument he had tuned. The parcel was wrapped in blue paper tied with twine, light as a fistful of feathers. The woman who handed it to me didn’t look at my face. “You,” someone said behind me, and I turned to Henry Bell, a marine with cheeks like apples. He took in the parcel, the alley, my uniform. “Should you be in here, sir?” “God damn it, Bell,” I said, the words easy, slipping. “Do I need to ask your leave?” He flushed. “Lieutenant, sir—Captain’s been looking. He asked me to find you.” “I’m doing a kindness for the purser,” I said. “A letter needs sealing and I have the seal.” I waved the parcel. “Ink’s messy. You don’t know these things.” “Sea air,” he muttered, as if that explained whatever written on my face. He looked relieved to name it. “Very good, sir.” “Tell Captain Harding I’ll be back before noon,” I said. “Or tell him I’m dead. Choose whichever gives you less trouble.” He laughed because I did. When he left, I stood a moment, the alley slipping around me like water. The parcel pulled my hands forward. The temple was where Weng said, the gods jostling for attention, each with painted eyes that did not blink. Joss sticks leaked sweet smoke. The red door was not the first I found but the second, darker under the lintel. I knocked once. The scrape of a bolt; a woman’s eye in a crack; then the door gave. “You late,” she said. “I’m always told that,” I said, passing the parcel. She sniffed as if I were meat and turned away. The room inside smelled of must, hay, something bruised. I reached into my pocket, feeling for the remaining coins. Her hand appeared, palm out. “Weng say you wait,” she said, and the door closed almost all the way, leaving me with a sliver of her profile, a single glint of an earring. “How long?” She tucked a strand of hair and looked past me, measuring the shadow of the joss-house roof. “So shadow eat stone,” she said. “Then you smoke.” My cough crept up again, and I swallowed it down. A child ran past with a kite that looked like a bat. A man hawked and spat, the sound sticky. I stood on the edge of myself, feeling how thin that edge was. A foreigner in a city that had learned to live around us like a river around a rock. The shadow licked the second stone and moved toward the third. In the crack of the door, I saw smoke drift, blue as the paper on the parcel. “Lieutenant Merrick,” said a voice at my elbow, and I knew before I turned it was Harding’s Chinese comprador, Mr. Lin, in his spotless robe. “The Captain wishes to dine aboard. He asks after his chart-room key.” “It’s with the purser,” I said, and watched his eyes track mine, then the door, then the joss sticks grinning their smoke. “Sea air,” he said softly, as if marking a ledger. “You cough.” “It is nothing,” I said. “It is always nothing until it is not,” he said. “The Captain is angry this morning. The tea men say a gunboat frightened a junk in the night. He thinks it was you.” “It was the Salamander,” I said. “Ask their men. They drink with both hands.” My chest ached with the words. Mr. Lin inclined his head. “I think you are making many trades with your breath.” “Is that a proverb?” I asked. “It is a bill.” He stepped aside and let me pass to the wall if I wished it. He would tell Harding what he thought, and Harding would chew on it, the way he chewed on everything – including the ends of his moustache when he believed himself unseen. The shadow ate the third stone. The door opened enough to admit a hand, open, waiting. I laid silver upon it and the hand withdrew. A boy came out with a pipe and a small lamp, his bare feet silent. He looked at me without malice, as a carpenter looks at a plank. “Here,” he said. I sat on a stool that had three legs and wobbled, and set the stem between my teeth. The smoke pulled, filling my mouth with bitterness that rounded into something else, softer, as if a woolen blanket had been soaked in heat and wrapped about my lungs. I coughed, hard. The copper ran. “Sea air,” I said to the boy because he waited to see if I would break. “Sea has many airs,” he said. The sounds of the alley turned down like a lantern wick. Ginger’s voice filtered from somewhere—“Don’t be long,”—as if he cared. Mr. Lin’s footsteps clicked away along the stone. Fragrant powder and dust and ash. I closed my eyes on the blades in my shoulders. The ache receded to some shore I could not quite see. The river’s skin reflected only sky. “You have another,” I said, when the pipe was empty in that way that feels sudden. “I can carry more.” “You carry enough,” the boy said. “Weng say.” “Weng isn’t inside my bones,” I said. The boy smiled. “Weng is everywhere.” I paid for the little blind islands one at a time. When I could stand, the sun had shifted, and the alley had eaten a different part of itself in shade. My legs walked me without complaint. Ginger came and we made a second errand for a man who wanted news of a Dutch ship. “Tell him she broke her back on a sandbank,” Ginger instructed, and I did, and took his finger-warm coins that smelled like fish. On Old China Street, a teacher corrected a boy’s brushstroke, and their voices were water. A clerk in a blue gown told me the Devizes had shipped under a false name. A girl selling pears let me touch one and feel the weight of it, the give at its blossom end, without buying. “You look better,” she said, though she did not mean it. “Sea air,” I said. It had begun to rain—just a lace of it, not enough to wet me, but enough to change the smell of the street to something green. My throat burned with the clean of it. Harding would be cutting his pheasant and swearing at his key. Wilkes would be marking the names at roll, his pencil judging in its coughs. At dusk, when the lanterns came alight like fruit on strings, I climbed the gangway with light feet. The deck boards gave their familiar, tired grunt. “You had the purser’s seal, then?” Wilkes said. His eyes searched my face and then looked aside. He held words between his teeth, and I felt a perverse affection for him for not letting them out. “Sea air,” I said again, and thumped my chest as if it were a barrel that needed sounding. The copper taste lingered. I wiped my mouth with the back of my glove and saw the thin rust there and curled my fist to hide it. In the wardroom, Harding stared at me as a cat watches a loose thread. “Your charts.” “I sent them with Mr. Lin,” I said. The lie had started somewhere behind my tongue and came out wearing my voice. “I’ve been with the quartermaster and then the purser. The pens aboard are all bristles; we need proper quills.” “Everything aboard needs something,” he said, and drank. “Including you. Scratch that cough, Merrick. You sound like a damned dhow.” “Sea air, sir,” I said, with a smile as neat as I could make it. The room smelled of tallow, wine, and the old leather of men who had stained chairs with themselves. “Sea air,” he repeated, and his mouth quirked. “Well, it’s made worse men than you. Be in the chart-room at eight.” “Aye, sir,” I said. I went to my hammock and lay with my hands folded over my stomach like a gentleman in a painting. The ship breathed around me. Somewhere a rat scrabbled. The harbor bells marked a wind that had shifted. My chest ticked and ticked, and the taste of copper would not leave. I shut my eyes and counted back from a number that had no beginning. The city turned its shoulder toward the river and slept, or pretended to. The dragon was quiet for now, and my bones, poor sailors, came off watch. I told myself I would go to the quartermaster at dawn. I told myself I would not listen for the first bell. I told myself the sea air would sweeten overnight. It did not. But I slept, which was something like truth.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully creates a vivid portrayal of Lieutenant James Merrick's day as he navigates his opium addiction in 1830s Canton. The writing excels in establishing a strong sense of place through sensory details that bring the setting to life: "The Pearl River lay flat as hammered tin. Sampans drifted like black beetles against the paler water. A breeze brought the stink of tallow, fish, the sour sweetness of the city." The character of Merrick is well-developed through his interactions, internal thoughts, and physical symptoms. His addiction is shown through subtle details rather than explicit statements - the copper taste in his mouth, the trembling hands, the constant "sea air" excuse, and the way others perceive his deteriorating condition. The narrative effectively conveys his desperation and the compromises he makes to feed his habit. The dialogue is particularly strong, with distinct voices for each character. Weng's broken but precise English ("English officers always have excuses. Their ships always late when they must be early. Their mouths always busy") contrasts with Ginger Harris's rougher speech patterns. The dialogue efficiently reveals character relationships and power dynamics without exposition. The prose style maintains a consistent first-person past tense voice throughout, with a lyrical quality that never becomes overwrought. Metaphors and similes are fresh and appropriate to the setting: "Canton began to speak in clatters and hawks and the soft slap of wooden sandals." The author avoids clichés about opium addiction and colonial China, instead creating specific, textured experiences. The narrative structure effectively follows Merrick through his day, showing his interactions with various characters as he pursues his addiction. The pacing is well-managed, with a natural flow between scenes that maintains tension while allowing for moments of sensory immersion. Where the piece could improve is in its relatively limited emotional range. While Merrick's physical discomfort and desperation are well-portrayed, we get less insight into deeper feelings like shame, fear of discovery, or conflicted loyalty. The ending, while avoiding incongruent positivity, feels somewhat abrupt and could benefit from a stronger concluding note that ties together the themes of self-deception and deterioration. Overall, this is an accomplished piece that creates a compelling character study while vividly evoking a specific historical setting. It successfully fulfills the prompt requirements while avoiding common pitfalls of writing about addiction or colonial settings. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 15.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Humour: Sisyphus Gives Advice — Score: 92.0
Prompt:
Sisyphus Gives Advice Write a comedic scene in the style of Terry Pratchett featuring Sisyphus, who has started an advice column while continuing his eternal boulder-pushing. Rather than being bitter about his punishment, Sisyphus has developed a comfortably zen emotional intelligence and wisdom from his centuries of repetitive labor. Not in the cliche ways you might expect -- he's actually very grounded, warm & connected with the everyday human plight. He dictates responses to "Crow," his feathered familiar who serves as both scribe and mail carrier. The piece should include Sisyphus thoughtfully answering several advice-seekers' letters about everyday problems (relationship troubles, work-life balance, dealing with difficult people, life purpose doubts) while periodically returning to his boulder-pushing duties. His advice should be surprisingly insightful and practical. The humor should emerge naturally from the messages he receives, from mundane to risque. Sisyphus should genuinely enjoy helping others, finding meaning in this new pursuit while maintaining his boulder routine. The humour should be *understated and not forced*. Contrary to expectation, almost none of his advice involves boulder rolling metaphors (though he does sneak *one* subtle in there), nor a treatise on stoicism. We are also going against the obvious fish-out-of-water trope; in fact, he's surprisingly a natural at this. In all of this , it's important to *show, don't tell*. The format should be largely epistolary, with the occasional interjection for scene setting. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The wind at the top of the hill had long ago given up trying to impress Sisyphus. It riffled his hair and fussed at his tunic, then resigned itself to being noticed only when it blew someone else’s parchment away. “Crow,” Sisyphus said, bracing one shoulder against the boulder, “who’s next?” Crow shuffled on the rock with a certain professional dignity, ink-potted claws leaving the lightest of scratches. He shook his glossy head and produced a letter from somewhere on his person, which was mostly feather. “Dear Sisyphus,” he read, in a voice that had a flint edge but a surprisingly gentle echo, “I’m twenty-eight and my partner never replaces the lid on the jam. I know this sounds small, but the jam develops a skin. It sends me into a spiral. How do I address something so petty without becoming the sort of person who writes to a centuries-dead Greek king about preserves? Signed, Sticky Situation.” Sisyphus leaned into the boulder, felt it begin to move, and let the push become a stroll. He had once been robustly muscular; now he was muscular in a way that made people think of bridges: built for the long load, with scenery all around. “Write this down,” he said, and Crow dipped his beak into ink, which tasted like old arguments and iron. “Dear Sticky, It is never just about the jam. It is about you walking into your morning and feeling you don’t have a say in it, and the jam skin becoming the flag of that small empire. Here’s what you do: don’t call it petty when you speak to them. You’re already telling yourself you don’t deserve the courtesy you’re asking for. Say, ‘When the lid isn’t on, I feel ignored at the start of my day. I’d like us to make a different habit. What would make it easier for you to remember?’ If they say, ‘I just forget,’ put a spoon rest in the lid. Move the jam. Put a little ridiculous sticker of something you both find stupid on the jar. People remember the things that make them smile and the things that make them bleed. Choose the first. Also, wipe the jar before asking anything. It’s good to start with what you can control. Warmly, Sisyphus.” “Not even a pun about preserves?” Crow said, as the boulder came to a dignified stop. “The day is young,” Sisyphus said, and turned around with the unhurried care of someone who had all the time in the world and had decided to spend it. A small deity, the sort that got assigned things like “dew on a particular species of iris” and “how bread smells three streets away,” shimmered into sparkly being beside the path. They were composed entirely of pale light and self-satisfaction. They had bothering to do. “Sisyphus,” they said, “feedback. Your letters lack a strong call to worship.” “Hello,” Sisyphus said, because nothing in his punishment explicitly forbade manners. “I mean, where’s the divine awe? Where’s the ‘and also, have you considered sacrificing a goat’?” The minor deity gestured, and a handful of goat-shaped sparkles drifted away, bleating in a tinkly manner. “I’ll put in a note about worship if someone asks about it,” Sisyphus said pleasantly. “If you’ve got mail, I can answer those, too.” The deity sniffed. It was the sort of sniff that, if translated into words, would have required footnotes. “I am personally handling all supplicants on my docket. Do not get in the way.” “That’s good,” Sisyphus said. “I was worried you were bored.” He nodded at Crow. “Next?” Crow tugged another envelope open with delicate savagery. “Dear Sisyphus, my boss schedules meetings at 4:55 p.m. on Fridays. My team is exhausted. We can’t push back without seeming uncommitted. How do I set boundaries without losing ground? Sincerely, Calendar Prisoner.” The boulder rolled, uncomplaining, gathering a certain philosophical dust. “Dear Calendar, Some people put meetings there to see who will stay. It isn’t about the meeting. It is about the theater. Don’t play the role they’ve written for you. Start three steps small. First, propose a standing rule for the team: Fridays after three are for ‘deep work’—which is a modern phrase meaning ‘you can’t get me unless there’s fire.’ Put it on the shared calendar. Most people obey calendars even when they do not obey decency. Second, when the 4:55 meeting appears, reply-all with a brief, ‘I have a hard stop at five, can we move this to Monday morning so I can give it focused attention?’ Do not apologize. Apologies are for harm, not logistics. Third, if the meeting remains, attend and at 4:59 say, ‘I’m leaving in one minute. What decision is needed today?’ You will teach them what time costs by spending yours in front of them. If your boss raises an eyebrow, lower yours slightly. Eyebrow contests settle more office politics than memos. If all else fails, ask to be measured by outcomes, not attendance. Then make the outcomes happen where you can reach them—early. Yours, Sisyphus.” “Very managerial,” Crow observed. “I once managed a rebellion,” Sisyphus said. “The minutes were hopeless.” The small deity huffed the way a kettle thinks about boiling. “You’re normalizing mortal autonomy,” they said. “It leads to dancing.” “Good,” Sisyphus said, and set his shoulder again. Between pushes, he drank a little water from a goatskin and poured a little more onto the ground. The dust made a noise like gratitude. Crow cleared his throat, which sounded like two stones trying to remember how to be birds. “Dear Sisyphus, my mother-in-law corrects my cooking while eating it. She brings salt in her handbag.
