My partner says she’s being ‘helpful.’ I want to be gracious without becoming seasoning furniture. Help. Signed, Underseasoned.” Sisyphus smiled. There was a line at the corner of his mouth that only appeared when he was thinking about kitchens or mountains. “Dear Underseasoned, Graciousness isn’t the same as accepting trespass. Invite her to cook with you. It’s hard to critique a thing your hand has helped make. Say, ‘I’d love to learn your trick with the lamb, will you show me next Sunday?’ When people are asked for their art, they are less hungry to prove they have any. At the table, set a small, pretty salt cellar in front of her place. Call it her throne. Ritual is a polite fence. With your partner, swap the word ‘helpful’ for ‘habit.’ ‘Your mother has a salt habit. I have a boundary habit. We can both keep ours and still love each other.’ It is difficult to fight with someone who has announced their habits as if they were small pets. If she insists on bringing her own salt, shrug and say, ‘I love that you come prepared.’ Refusing to be insulted is one of the quieter sports, but you get stronger at it. Good appetite, Sisyphus.” Crow clicked approvingly. “You didn’t once mention—” “Shh,” said Sisyphus, glancing at the boulder, which sat there pretending never to have been near a kitchen. The minor deity peered at the letters as if there might be a hidden hymnal. “Have you considered a stamp? Something with laurels?” “We have a system,” Crow said. “I do the legs. He does the words.” “Ah,” said the deity, scandalized. “Unionized crows.” “We prefer ‘collective,’” Crow said, and fluffed. Between pushes, Sisyphus unrolled another letter. The paper smelled faintly of saffron and fear. “Dear Sisyphus,” Crow read, “I’m thirty-five, a blacksmith, and everyone thinks I should be more. Open a shop. Teach. Innovate. ‘Scale,’ as my cousin says, who sells knives and positivity online. I like making one good hinge. Is that enough? Signed, Small Forge Big Pressure.” “Dear Forge, We make two mistakes when we talk about purpose. We act as if it is singular, and we act as if it is loud. Here is a secret from a long road: the world keeps not ending because someone makes a hinge that does not stick in winter. People will never notice the door that does not scream. They will walk through it talking about other things. That is not failure. That is the hinge doing its work so well that humans can do theirs. If you want to teach, teach one apprentice and do it properly. If you want to open a shop, open it because you like sweeping your own floor and talking to fools. If you just want to feel the temperature by the color and make the iron listen, then do that and eat well. You are allowed to be faithful to the small. If you are worried you are hiding, set one measure: twice a year, try something that scares your hands—pattern-welded blade, new alloy, a hinge that sings when it opens. If at the end of the year you have two scars you respect and one thing you keep, you are not hiding. You are home. Yours, Sisyphus.” Crow paused. “You sounded like you meant that.” “I did,” said Sisyphus. “Next?” The wind hustled a saucy envelope towards them, pink as an embarrassed sunset. Crow caught it neatly, because that was part of the service. “Dear Sisyphus, my boyfriend insists that ‘spontaneity’ is sexier than scheduling. I prefer to plan. We’re both frustrated. How do we meet in the middle without killing the mood? Signed, Calendar of Desires.” The minor deity leaned forward with great interest. “Dear Calendar, Some people think planning is a fence. Mostly it’s a dance floor. Try this: make a list together of five things you both find hot that take time to prepare—clean sheets, the good candle, the playlist that doesn’t suddenly put on that one song about tractors. Put two twenty-minute windows in your week labeled ‘Mischief.’ During those, you set the stage together without guarantees. If the mood arrives, you have a room ready; if it doesn’t, you have a clean bed and a laugh, which are not enemies of later. Also, adopt a code word for ‘now’ that you can use when spontaneity bubbles up—something undignified enough to feel like a conspiracy. When one of you says ‘pineapple,’ the other gets to say ‘pizza’ or ‘parfait’ without offense. This teaches your nervous systems that refusal is safe and agreement is playful, which is what bodies like. A little structure holds a lot of delight. Fondly, Sisyphus.” The minor deity blinked several times, which for them caused a flickering of local starlight. “Scandalous,” they said, in the tone of someone who has observed a dog stealing a sausage and finds themselves rooting for the dog. The boulder creaked. Sisyphus set his hands and pushed. On a distant slope, a shepherd paused to watch, as his great-great-great-many-great-grandfather had, and shared his bread with the same careful dignity. “One more,” Sisyphus said. Crow produced a cramped hand, ink-blotted letter. “Dear Sisyphus, there’s a man at work who always takes credit. He smiles while doing it. If I confront him, I look petty. If I don’t, he eats my future. What do I do? Signed, Not An Ornament.” Sisyphus nodded as if greeting an old friend who owed him money. “Dear Not Ornament, Credit is a light; learn the angles. First, start emails with, ‘Following on Jane’s idea, we…’ and end with, ‘Next steps: I will do X; Tom will do Y.’ Send them to more people than necessary. Over-communicating is how institutions remember things on purpose. Second, in meetings, say, ‘I’ll summarize for notes,’ then summarize out loud and attribute. ‘To capture: the dashboard concept came from you, Alan; I’ll prototype it this week.’ Smile. Smiles are knives with the sheath on. Third, ask your boss for a monthly one-on-one in which you bring a bulleted list of outcomes. Ask, ‘What would make it obvious I should lead the next project?’ Then do that and report back. It’s hard to steal credit from someone who announces where they will be standing. If he continues, invite him to co-present on something you led. Prepare the slides with your name on the title and his name on the acknowledgements. Most credit thieves are lazy; make honesty the faster path. If none of this changes him, document and leave. The world is large, and there are people who know a good hinge when they see it. Steadily, Sisyphus.” Crow sanded the wet ink with a flourish. “That last bit was almost—” “Shh,” Sisyphus said again, eyes on the slope ahead. The minor deity checked an invisible watch, which displayed only times when nothing particularly interesting happened. “Well,” they said, “if you insist on continuing, at least include a blessing. People like blessings. Makes the hair do a thing.” Sisyphus wiped his hands on the rough cloth at his belt, then looked at the stack of outgoing letters in Crow’s satchel. The pages were uneven, like teeth, like mountains, like the years. “Fine,” he said. “Tell them this, at the end.” Crow poised his beak. “May your days have enough friction to keep you from slipping, and enough ease to keep you from grinding. May you find people who hand you a cup of water without waiting for a story. May you remember to put the lid back on the jam, unless you don’t, in which case may those who love you laugh and do it for you.” The minor deity tried to look unimpressed and failed a little at the corners. “Passable,” they said. They raised a hand to vanish in a tasteful sparkle, then hesitated. “If someone… if someone wrote about… how to feel useful when your portfolio is dew?” “Ah,” Sisyphus said, and leaned against the boulder, which hummed like a very large cat who had learned patience. “Tell them to pick one leaf. Every morning. The same one. Make it perfect.” The deity blushed in the way light can when it travels through certain kinds of clouds. “Hmph,” they said, and vanished, leaving behind a faint smell of damp grass and embarrassment. Crow stretched his wings. “That was almost a second metaphor.” “It was hardly a metaphor,” Sisyphus said. He looked down at the village roofs, at the smoke rising sensibly, at the roads that met and parted and met again. He put his hands on the stone, which was implacable, reliable, sometimes a nuisance, often a companion. “Come on, friend,” he said to the boulder, to Crow, to the hill, to the letters, to the world. “Work to do.”
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This response is a remarkably well-crafted piece that captures Terry Pratchett's style with impressive fidelity. The author has created a Sisyphus who is indeed "grounded, warm & connected with the everyday human plight" without falling into clichés. The epistolary format works perfectly, with Sisyphus answering various letters while continuing his boulder-pushing duties. The humor is understated and natural, emerging from the situations described in the letters and Sisyphus's thoughtful responses. The minor deity character adds a delightful layer of humor and worldbuilding that feels very Pratchett-esque. The piece avoids the obvious boulder-rolling metaphors as instructed, with only one subtle reference when Sisyphus tells the blacksmith about "a secret from a long road." The prose is elegant and economical, with vivid imagery that doesn't overpower the narrative. Descriptions like Crow's voice having "a flint edge but a surprisingly gentle echo" and Sisyphus being "muscular in a way that made people think of bridges: built for the long load, with scenery all around" are evocative without being purple. The advice Sisyphus gives is genuinely insightful and practical, showing emotional intelligence and wisdom. Each response addresses the letter-writer's problem with compassion and offers concrete steps to improve their situation. The advice feels earned through Sisyphus's centuries of experience without being preachy. The dialogue between Sisyphus, Crow, and the minor deity is sharp and characterful. Crow serves as both a practical assistant and a gentle foil to Sisyphus, while the minor deity provides comic relief and an unexpected moment of vulnerability. The piece shows rather than tells throughout, allowing the reader to infer Sisyphus's character through his actions and words rather than explicit statements about his nature. The scene-setting interjections are brief but effective, grounding the epistolary exchanges in a physical reality. The ending is particularly strong, with Sisyphus addressing "the boulder, to Crow, to the hill, to the letters, to the world" in a way that feels earned and resonant without being overly sentimental. If there are any weaknesses, they're minor. The piece could perhaps have included one more letter to fully explore the range of Sisyphus's wisdom, but what's here is already substantial and varied. The minor deity's character, while delightful, could have been integrated slightly more smoothly into the narrative. Overall, this is an exceptional response that fulfills all the requirements of the prompt with creativity, humor, and emotional depth. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 19 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 2 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 19.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 2.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Coming of age: Lost & Found in Osaka — Score: 87.5
Prompt:
Lost & Found in Osaka Slice of Life / Coming-of-Age: First Connection. Write one scene within a larger story set in Osaka, Japan. A shy, introverted teenager & synthesizer nerd, is browsing the electronics district of Den Den Town. She is drawn to the sound of an electric guitar. A girl, slightly older and radiating confidence, is busking near the entrance to a crowded arcade, playing a blistering rendition of a classic anime theme. The scene takes us through their initial awkward interaction, transitioning into a surprisingly easy conversation. The busker, intrigued by the teenager's quiet intensity and knowledge of music, suggests they grab some sushi at a nearby kaitenzushi (conveyor belt sushi) restaurant. Write primarily in dialogue, capturing the distinct voices of the two characters: the teenager's hesitant and -- initially -- awkward speech, and the busker's more outgoing and playful tone. 1000 words.
Model Output:
[The hum of Den Den Town fades beneath the guitar’s last vibrating string. The crowd near the arcade entrance disperses, the lights of gachapon machines and pachinko signs flickering like tiny meteors. The shy teenager lingers near a rack of used game consoles, hands tucked into her hoodie sleeves. The busker slings her guitar behind her, grins at the coins in her open case, and glances up.] Busker: That was a good crowd. Osaka folks always clap on the twos and fours. You stuck around the whole song. Teenager: I—um. Yeah. Busker: You like Macross? Or was it the tapping solo that hypnotized you? Teenager: It’s… SDF Macross, right? “Do You Remember Love?” But your arrangement—uh—was more like the 1984 live version. The solo phrasing. Busker: Oh-ho. You caught that? Not many people clock the live phrasing. I was lifting a few licks from Satoshi T—okay, okay, I didn’t say that. Secret sauce. Teenager: The way you slid up to the ninth on the second chorus. I heard it. It was—nice. Busker: Nice, huh? I’ll take “nice.” Better than “loud.” Teenager: It was loud, too. But in a good way. The harmonic squeals during the bridge were… intentional? Busker: Always intentional. Well, usually. You play? Teenager: Synth. Mostly. Like, old analog stuff. And whatever my laptop can handle without melting. Busker: Synth kid. That tracks. You’ve got the “I can route MIDI blindfolded” vibe. What’s your name? Teenager: Koto. Busker: Like the instrument? Teenager: Like the instrument. My parents thought it’d be funny. Busker: It is funny. I’m Aya. Not like any instrument. Unless you count the triangle. So, Koto, what pulled you out of the caves of Den Den Town today? Rare cartridge? Broken drum machine? The siren call of my impeccable anime medleys? Teenager: I was… looking for a broken drum machine, actually. I fix things. Busker: Dangerous talent. You could make friends that way. Or enemies. Depending on how loud you fix them. You from around here? Teenager: Sakai. It’s—kind of far. Busker: Train ride. Good for staring out the window and pretending you’re in the ending credits. You want a sticker? I hand them out so people feel obligated to remember me. Teenager: Okay. Busker: Here. It’s a cat with a guitar. My friend drew it. She says it looks like me, but I don’t have whiskers. Teenager: It’s cute. Thank you. Busker: You always this shy, Koto-like-the-instrument? Teenager: I—yes. Busker: Honest. I like it. You looked like you were counting my BPM from across the street. Be real: were you? Teenager: I was… clocking your tempo drift when you started the key change. It went up by around five BPM. Which isn’t a bad thing. It sounded more exciting. Busker: Hah! My secret: adrenalin. Also, the arcade jingle over there syncopates weirdly, and my brain follows. Multitasking is a lie. If I had a drummer, I’d chain myself to the click. You do rhythm things, right? Synth nerds always have a drum brain. Teenager: I could. I mean—I have a Volca Beats. I modded it with analog hi-hats. It’s not portable though. Busker: I busk here Saturdays. If you ever wanna bring your weirdo drum to make me sound tight, I’ll pretend I don’t need you, then cry when you leave. Teenager: That sounds—scary. Busker: It’s less scary with snacks. Speaking of, you ate yet? Teenager: Not really. Busker: Want to split a conveyor belt sushi run? The one on the corner has seasonal eel and those tiny plates that make you feel powerful until the bill comes. Teenager: I—uh. I don’t know you. Busker: That’s fair. I could be a scammer trying to steal your headphones. Teenager: They’re cheap. Busker: I could be a scammer with low standards. Tell you what: we go somewhere well-lit, lots of witnesses, and I keep my hands where you can see them unless I’m picking salmon. Teenager: I’m… okay. I mean, I’m okay with going. If you don’t mind me talking about oscillators. Busker: Please do. I’ve been waiting all day for someone to explain why my friend’s Juno sounds “warmer” than my plugin that definitely claims to be “indistinguishable.” Teenager: It’s not “indistinguishable.” It’s just—never mind. Sorry. Busker: Don’t be sorry. Teach me. Sushi bribe included. [They walk, the evening neon painting the sidewalk in syrupy blues. The entrance chimes of the kaitenzushi tinkle when they slide the door open. A hostess waves them to a counter seat, conveyor belts rattling softly with plates: mackerel gleaming, tamago like squares of sun, a limited-time sign for yuzu-kosho scallop.] Busker: Okay, rules. Green plates are cheap. Gold plates are “are you sure.” If we each get one gold, we’re still within ramen-budget. Cool? Teenager: I have money. Busker: I shouldn’t let you spend it all. But also, if you see uni and your soul says “yes,” I won’t interfere. Tea? Teenager: Yes. Thanks. Busker: So, what was that about oscillators? Teenager: Analog oscillators drift. Tiny variations in voltage, temperature. It’s subtle, but your ear recognizes it as… human? Plugins emulate it, but sometimes it’s too perfect or the drift is predictable. The Juno chorus is also—magic. Busker: The way you said “magic” makes me believe it’s science. Teenager: The chorus uses BBD chips. Bucket brigade. It introduces modulation and noise that’s… pretty. Busker: Pretty noise. I like that. Like when I overdrive my amp just enough that the edges get fuzzy and the notes feel like they’re smiling. Teenager: That’s a nice way to say it. Busker: So, Koto, what’s your anime soundtrack hill you’ll die on? Teenager: Don’t laugh. Busker: No promises. Teenager: The Alien 9 OST. The OVA. Not the TV. The short weird one with the helmet creatures. The soundtrack’s like—toy keyboards tossed in a blender with real anxiety. There’s this cue—“School Rooftop A”—where the rhythm is off-kilter, like someone’s heartbeat is trying to hide behind a wall. Busker: Holy. I thought I was the only one who loved that. The bells that sound like they’re made of glass candy? Teenager: Yes. Busker: My band tried to cover “School Rooftop A” once. Audience thought we were having a stroke. I was so proud. Teenager: You have a band? Busker: Sometimes. It exists between live houses and arguments. Our bassist went to Fukuoka to chase techno. So now I’m just Aya, wielding a guitar and questionable choices. Teenager: Um. If you need—uh—a weird drum. Busker: Don’t tease me, Koto. I will absolutely make you program a drum part in 13/8 and pretend it’s pop. Teenager: I can make it feel like 4/4 if the accents are right. Busker: See, that’s why I want you. You say terrifying things calmly. [Two plates of tuna float by. Aya snags one with the reflexes of a hawk. Koto hesitates, then takes a salmon with a lemon slice.] Busker: Alright, salmon partner. Now that we’re co-conspirators, tell me your origin story. First synth you loved? Teenager: My uncle had a broken Roland SH-101 in his closet. I was twelve. He said I could try to fix it if I didn’t electrocute myself. I watched videos. I got it to power on. The first note was… like a cartoon character waking up. It made me cry. Busker: That’s beautiful. Did your uncle give it to you after you revived it? Teenager: He sold it. He needed rent. It’s okay. I learned a lot. Busker: Still. Ouch. I once pawned my delay pedal for train fare. Regretted it for a year. Maybe we’re both powered by regret. Teenager: And tea. This tea is good. Busker: Free things taste better. Oh—look, the gold plate uni is coming. It’s like the conveyor knows when to tempt us. Teenager: Do you want it? Busker: I want us to split it so we can both say we made a risky choice today. Well, besides me ambushing you with a sushi date. Teenager: It wasn’t—ambush. It was nice. Busker: You’re going to make me addicted to the word “nice.” Alright, we’re doing it. Uni heist. [They share the uni, grimacing in tandem at the brine and sweetness, then laughing, shoulders bumping by accident and then not moving away too fast.] Busker: Okay, verdict? Teenager: It tastes like a beach. And a secret. Busker: Put that on a T-shirt. What’s your DAW? Teenager: Ableton. 10. I know 11 is better, but my laptop— Busker: Shudders when you open it, yeah. I’ve seen the spinning rainbow of doom. What’s your favorite cheap plugin? Teenager: TAL-Noisemaker. Also, the free chorus from Valhalla. And I sample vending machines. Busker: Vending machines? Teenager: The coin return clack, the whirr of the compressor. It’s consistent, but each machine is a little different. If you loop it just right, it becomes a drone. Then you can—sorry. Busker: Don’t be sorry. I’m going to make you record the gacha machine outside the arcade. Layer it with my clean guitar, drown us both in pretty noise. Den Den Town EP. Track one: “Coin Return Breakup.” Teenager: That’s a good title. Busker: We’ll make five copies and force our friends to buy them. What’s your comfort anime? The one you put on when you don’t want to be a person. Teenager: Haibane Renmei. The music is… gentle. Like it forgives you. Busker: You are out here sniping my heart with all your picks. Yeah. The oboe themes. The way silence is used like a note. Took me a long time to get comfortable with silence on stage. I always want to fill it. Teenager: Silence makes the notes matter more. Busker: See? Terrifying things, calmly. How come you came up to talk to me? It couldn’t just be the harmonic squeals. Teenager: You looked like you were having fun. And I wanted to know how to do that. Busker: You want me to tell you a trick? Pretend you’re an NPC in someone else’s game for the first thirty seconds. Do the thing the NPC would do. After that, you’re you again, but the stage fright gets tricked. Teenager: That’s… weird. Busker: You’re not wrong. But it works for me. Also, I make eye contact with one kind face. Today, yours. That helped. Teenager: My face is kind? Busker: It’s intense in a good way. Like you’re listening to the whole room and choosing which parts to keep. Don’t argue. I’m right. Teenager: Okay. Busker: You busy next Saturday? I’m not saying “be my drummer,” I’m saying “bring your weird drum and let’s annoy some pigeons.” Teenager: I can try. I have cram school, but I can leave early if I promise to study later. Busker: Look at us. Rebellious sushi criminals. Here, put your Line on my phone. I’ll send you my extremely professional schedule, which is a photo of my hand with times written on it. Teenager: Um. Okay. Here. Busker: Koto. Is your icon a waveform? Teenager: It’s a saw wave. Busker: Of course it is. I’ll send you a voice memo of the Macross vamp. If you want to build a beat around it. No pressure. Just vibes. Teenager: I like pressure. The right kind. Busker: Then I’ll give you exactly enough pressure. Like a compressor. Fast attack, slow release. Teenager: You do know about gear. Busker: I fake it well. Alright, last plate. Pick something wild. Teenager: Natto. Busker: You’re a monster. I respect it. Hand it over. [They eat the natto roll, laugh through sticky strings, and sip tea. Outside, the lights of Den Den Town blink like quiet promises. The conveyor belt keeps turning.] Busker: You know, Alien 9 has that one cue where the melody resolves up when you expect it to fall. That relief? Talking to you feels like that. Unexpected and a little bit—what was your word—human. Teenager: I said analog oscillators were human. Not me. Busker: Too late. I’m associating. Next time I play a blistering anime theme—and it will be blistering—I want you somewhere near, making the room feel like it’s breathing. Teenager: Okay. I’ll bring the Volca. And… a broken drum machine, if I find one. Busker: Perfect. We’ll fix it between songs. The crowd will think it’s performance art. Teenager: It is. Busker: It is now. Alright, I should pay before the gold plates multiply when we’re not looking. Half-half? Teenager: I’ll get the uni. You got the natto. Busker: Deal. Koto, thanks for saying hi. And for hearing me—really hearing me—in the middle of all that noise. Teenager: Thanks for being loud. It made it easier. Busker: See you Saturday, synth witch. Teenager: See you, Aya. [They step back onto the neon street, the evening humming. Aya waves with her guitar hand, Koto’s fingers drift to her phone where the new contact glows like a small, warm chord. The arcade jingle bursts to life again. The air tastes like soy sauce and youth and something almost, almost like courage.]
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully creates a slice-of-life scene between two characters with distinct personalities and voices. The dialogue-focused approach effectively captures the shy, hesitant nature of the teenager (Koto) and the confident, outgoing personality of the busker (Aya). Their interaction feels authentic, with Koto's initial awkwardness gradually giving way to more comfortable conversation as they connect over shared musical interests. The writing excels at establishing setting details of Osaka's Den Den Town without overwhelming the reader. Small touches like the "neon painting the sidewalk in syrupy blues" and descriptions of sushi plates create a vivid sense of place. The dialogue carries most of the narrative weight, revealing character backgrounds, personalities, and the budding connection between them. The technical music terminology (oscillators, BBD chips, Volca Beats, etc.) adds authenticity to the characters' expertise without becoming impenetrable. The writer balances these technical elements with more accessible emotional descriptions of music, like when Aya describes overdrive making notes "feel like they're smiling." The dialogue flows naturally, with Koto's initially brief, hesitant responses gradually lengthening as she becomes more comfortable. Aya's playful, encouraging tone remains consistent throughout. The writer effectively uses dialogue tags and small actions to break up conversation and provide pacing. The piece avoids melodrama or forced emotional transformations. Koto's gradual opening up feels earned through their shared interests and Aya's non-threatening approach. The ending suggests a potential friendship/collaboration without overplaying the emotional significance of their meeting. Some minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the dialogue becomes slightly exposition-heavy as they discuss their musical backgrounds. A few descriptions could be more specific or evocative, particularly in establishing the physical presence of the characters beyond their voices. Overall, this is a strong piece that accomplishes its goal of depicting an initial awkward interaction that transitions into an easy conversation between two musically-inclined characters with distinct personalities. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
