Outdated OS, I can see the gesture lag. The restaurant unified Wi-Fi asks to join. Its name is the restaurant plus “Secure,” a dead giveaway. I don’t. I order pasta because my brain can’t fight two battles at once and carbs are a firewall against awkward pauses. She’s funny. Not performative, not trying too hard, just—present. She tells me about the time her cat knocked over an entire stack of board games like a kaiju. I tell her about the time I drove six hours to see a meteor shower and the clouds rolled in like a denial-of-service. We laugh at the same places. It feels unfamiliar in a good way, like the first time you solve a puzzle room and realize you don’t have to throw brute force at it. I reach for the bread and she glances at my nails. “Those are… very clean,” she says. No judgment, just observation. “Old habit,” I say. “Tactile feedback matters when I type.” I don’t say it’s from years of rolling rubber bands as stress relief while I ran scans at 3 a.m. and waited for a vulnerable endpoint to whisper come in. The first mention of Magic slips out of her like it’s not a test. “Do you ever play?” I blink. The game has lived in my bloodstream since high school, when cardboard spells offered rules I could understand and exploit. “Yeah,” I say non-chalantly. “You?” She nods, eyes brightening. “Since Zendikar. Casual mostly. My friends hate my board wipes.” Board wipes. She’s not precious about her own permanence. She’s willing to reset. I involuntarily tag: Supreme Verdict, Wrath of God, Damnation. Maybe Austere Command if she likes modular solutions. “Control?” I ask, too quickly, and I hate that I sound eager. She grins. “Midrange that pretends to be aggro until it’s not. I just love the moment someone overextends and then—.” She makes a soft explosion sound with her lips. Okay. She feints. She baits. She likes options. I imagine a hand with Lightning Bolt and a Path to Exile and the smug, patient thrill of waiting for the right threat. I remember the first time someone hit me with a well-timed Cryptic Command and I felt my face burn with the beauty of it. I take a sip of water. I want to ask her which Commander she pilots but I also don’t want to sprint. We talk about cities. Travel. She hates airports but loves maps. I picture her tracing routes with a finger, planning contingencies. The salads arrive. My brain is fifty percent lettuce, forty percent “don’t look at the lock screen,” ten percent “say something charming.” I manage it. She laughs. The sound is crisp, unforced. Relief floods my body like a hot patch. Then her phone lights the table from her bag, a constellation of notification dots. She pulls it out to silence it and the world narrows to a grid of dots and a single index finger. My skin goes cold. The pattern is as loud as graffiti: top-left to top-center to top-right, straight down the right side, left across the bottom. An L rotated ninety degrees then mirrored. The average shoulder surfer could memorize it before the appetizer. I feel my mouth move before I can stop it. “That’s… really guessable.” Silence. Her finger pauses mid-air like a moth arrested by a porch light. She turns, gaze sharpening. “What?” I want to rewind. I want to cancel the packet before it leaves my device. “Your unlock pattern. Sorry. It’s just—you started at the corner and hit all the adjacent points and—” Stop. Abort. “It’s—look, you could do a 2-5-8-6-9 squiggle or, like, use a zig-zag. Or better, switch to a passphrase.” Great. I am a walking PSA. I am a human lint roller catching bad decisions out of the air. Her expression shifts, the easy openness contracting into something like a shield. “So you were looking at my phone?” “No,” I say, instantly, truthfully—my eyes see these things even when I don’t want them to. “I’m… that person. I can’t turn it off. Sorry. It’s reflex.” She sets the phone down, face-down. The case is a faded blue with a cartoon dragon. I file it under “Timmy/Tammy aesthetic, maybe playful,” and want to toss my brain into the river. The server returns with drinks we didn’t order. Wrong table. He apologizes and retreats. The moment stretches like chewing gum stuck to a sneaker. “I get that security is… your thing,” she says slowly, “but not everything is an attack vector.” “It’s not you,” I say. “It’s me.” I hear how ridiculous it sounds and push through anyway. “I used to— I was on the other side. Red team. Before that, black hat. I don’t do that anymore. I audit, I teach. I try to make things safer. But my brain still—maps.” I tap my temple, aware of the jitter in my fingers. “Your pattern is a bright neon sign to that part of me. I’m sorry.” She watches me. I hold very still, like prey that knows it has to make the next move slow. I think about the cards she’s named so far. “Board wipes,” she’d said. She likes resets. She likes to bait people into overextending and then punish them for it. I can respect that. She sighs. “Okay. Okay. I appreciate the… instinct, I guess. But maybe you could ask first.” “Fair,” I say. “Do you want me to stop?” She looks at the phone, then at me. And then she does something unexpected: she unlocks it again, deliberately, the same naive pattern, and hands it over. “Show me,” she says. “Show me why it’s bad. But not like I’m a client. Like I’m a person you want to impress.” A tiny smile punches a hole through my panic. My hands steady. I don’t touch the screen. I hold it up against the banquette light, tilt. “See the smudge trails? Even if you clean it, there’s residue. You can infer the shape. And starting in the corner is common; humans love edges.” I hand it back. “Try something that crosses itself. Or go to a passphrase. Four random words you’ll remember.” She nods, thinking. “Like—SpaghettiNimbusCobaltBadger.” “That’s… overkill,” I say, smiling despite myself. “In a good way.” She changes it. I look away deliberately and talk about Magic to give her privacy. “Favorite set?” “Kaladesh,” she says. “I love improvise. And vehicles.” Improvise and vehicles. Efficient use of resources, turning artifacts sideways to get more than you should. I tag Heart of Kiran, Smuggler’s Copter—though the ban list lives in my head like an appendix. She likes synergy that feels like cheating but isn’t. She is the kind of person who will find the loose thread in a system and knit a sweater out of it. Dinner arrives. The pasta glows with oil, a network of garlic nodes. We eat. The conversation warms back up like a server brought back online. I make a point of not watching her phone when it pings. She catches me not-looking and nods, a small private acknowledgment. I file that trust in a small imaginary folder labeled Gains. She tells me about her favorite commander. “Muldrotha,” she says, eyes lighting up. “Value town.” She laughs at herself. “I know, I know. Graveyard recursion makes people groan.” Muldrotha, the Gravetide. Every permanent becomes a second life. She’s someone who hates waste. Someone who looks at what’s been lost and says, not yet. My chest does a strange thing at that. I admit my own. “Izzet spellslinger. Niv-Mizzet. And yes, I’m that person.” “Ping-ping-ping,” she says, miming drawing, drawing, drawing. “You monster.” “Reformed,” I say, and we both laugh. She lists cards like they’re old friends: Cyclonic Rift (board control without the guilt of death), Treasure Cruise (resource advantage), Teferi’s Protection (I’m out, you deal with it), Beast Within (answers, answers, answers). Each one, a flag planted in a playstyle terrain: flexible, opportunistic, allergic to dead ends. She mentions Swords to Plowshares like a mantra. Efficiency. Mercy with a string attached. I catalog without judging. I catalog because it’s how I love things. Patterns lit up my worst years and, paradoxically, patterns are how I climb out. She talks about the thrill of holding a counterspell and the discipline of not firing it at the first provocation. I think about restraint. I think about how she put the phone face-down and I wanted to fix her, and how she handed me the phone and I wanted to deserve it. At some point she says, almost as an aside, “I liked that you owned it.” “What?” “The blurt. You didn’t get defensive. You didn’t tell me I was stupid.” “I don’t think you’re stupid,” I say. “I think systems are designed to make you feel like you are. That’s part of how they win.” She tilts her head, considering. “So—white hat paladin in a world of rogues.” “I always end up splash black,” I admit. “Old habits.” We split dessert because it feels like an ally move, not an attack. Her spoon is a precise instrument. Mine is… enthusiastic. I tell her about the time at DEF CON a hotel keycard system failed open and I spent a whole night not sleeping because I couldn’t un-know it. She tells me about a friend’s kitchen flooding and how they turned it into a slip-and-slide. She is good at taking disasters and making them useful. The check arrives. The POS terminal is ancient. I hand over my card and, because I can’t help it, I cover the screen with my palm when I enter the tip and watch the cursor lag exactly half a second between digits. Side-channel leak. In my head I whisper a lullaby to my anxiety. Hush, little process, don’t you cry. Outside, the air is clean as a new password. We linger under the awning, the rain drawing thin lines between streetlights. Her hair catches droplets like a halo of punctuation. “I had a good time,” she says. “Me too,” I reply, hearing the truth of it and wanting to back it up with logs. “I’m sorry about the—” “Stop apologizing,” she says. “Just… ask next time.” “Deal.” She glances at my hands, then at her phone. “For what it’s worth, my new passphrase is going to make me hungry every time I type it.” “Good,” I say. “Associative memory is your friend.” She laughs. We exchange numbers like normal people, which feels like a miracle. Her name appears in my contacts and I lock my screen without a flourish, without thinking. We hug, brief and intentional. When we pull back, she looks up at me with that half-smile. “Round two,” she says. “Bring your Niv-Mizzet. I’ll bring a board wipe.” I swallow a retort about redundancy and backup plans. “Looking forward to it.” She walks away, and for once I don’t chart her route. I stand under the awning and watch the rain find its own path, and I let it. I think of Muldrotha pulling a permanent out of the graveyard like a promise. I think of the moment before a counterspell, the discipline to wait, the trust that you’ll know when to use it. I put my hands in my pockets. The city hums. Somewhere, a network hiccups and recovers. I turn toward home, feeling a pattern I don’t want to break.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative successfully captures the perspective of a reformed hacker on a first date, with a strong focus on internal monologue as requested. The protagonist's hacker mindset permeates every observation, creating a distinctive voice that remains consistent throughout. The narrative excels at characterization through specific details. The protagonist's habit of scanning environments for vulnerabilities feels authentic, as does their inability to turn off this mindset. Their commentary on the date's Magic: The Gathering preferences reveals character through gameplay style ("She feints. She baits. She likes options."). The protagonist's self-awareness about their compulsive security analysis creates compelling internal conflict. The writing demonstrates technical knowledge without overwhelming the reader. References to "red team," "black hat," and specific Magic cards establish authenticity without excessive jargon. The pivotal moment—commenting on the date's phone unlock pattern—arises naturally from the character's established traits. The prose is particularly strong in its use of hacker/tech metaphors that illuminate the character's worldview: "carbs are a firewall against awkward pauses," "I want to cancel the packet before it leaves my device," and "Hush, little process, don't you cry." These metaphors effectively blend the technical with the emotional. The narrative handles the faux pas and its aftermath with nuance. Rather than a simplistic resolution, we see genuine tension followed by a thoughtful negotiation. The date's response—asking for a demonstration of why her pattern is vulnerable—shows her character depth. This interaction reveals mutual respect and creates a believable foundation for their connection. The ending avoids being overly saccharine while maintaining optimism. The protagonist's final thoughts about "a pattern I don't want to break" and the date's invitation to "Round two" feel earned through their shared interaction. Some minor weaknesses include occasional overreliance on technical metaphors and a few instances where the internal monologue becomes slightly repetitive in its security observations. However, these are minor issues in an otherwise strong piece. The narrative successfully balances the protagonist's technical mindset with their desire for human connection, creating a compelling character study that fulfills the prompt requirements while offering genuine emotional depth. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ First-person unique perspective: Overthinking It — Score: 94.1
Prompt:
Overthinking It Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of an intelligent 8th-grade girl with social anxiety who has developed a crush on a classmate. The narrative takes place during a group science project where they're paired together, as she cycles through rehearsed conversations while second-guessing each potential approach. Her inner thoughts should reveal the gap between her articulate internal voice and her difficulty expressing herself aloud, her fears of coming across as desperate or weird, and the exhausting process of monitoring her every word, expression, and movement for potential embarrassment. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
My pencil keeps tapping, like a woodpecker tattooing a signal into the desk: don’t mess up, don’t mess up, don’t—stop. I press the eraser to the paper to silence it, then realize I’ve smudged the diagram of the beaker and now it looks like a cloud is erupting from the top. Note to self: clouds don’t come out of beakers in real life. You know that. Everyone knows that. Except now the drawing makes me nervous. If he looks over, he’ll think I’m careless. Or weird. He’ll think I think beakers are tiny thunderstorm generators. Beakercumulo-nimbus. Stop making jokes in your head and pay attention. Mr. Morales is giving the instructions about the group project again: control variables, dependent variables, qualitative vs. quantitative data. The facts fit neatly into place in my brain like someone pouring rice into a jar. I like the feeling. When things have exact names and rules, I can keep them still. My friends—if that’s what I call them, though that word feels like a shirt I’m still growing into—are already talking about who’s doing what. I can hear shards of their voices, like I’m standing behind a half-closed door. We’re paired together. Me and him. Not a pair, actually—four of us—but we’re at the same table, and when Mr. Morales said our names out loud in the same sentence, a flock of something panicked inside my ribs and then went very quiet. He is sitting two seats over, one empty seat between us like a moat I can’t figure out how to cross without drowning in my own face. Okay. Strategy A: say something sophisticated but casual. Example line: “I was thinking we should measure the rate of evaporation as a function of surface area; it’s more interesting than just temperature.” Tone: light, almost bored. Eyebrows: neutral. Hands: still. Word choice: function might sound show-offy, but if I explain it, I’ll be helpful instead of obnoxious. Risk: they might say, “We already decided we’re doing the seed germination thing, why are you trying to be the boss?” Counter: laugh and say, “I’m open,” then offer to take notes, because taking notes is invisible but indispensable. Strategy B: say nothing and become indispensable anyway. Just do the measurements. Let competence speak. Downside: crush will not notice competence as long as you are a quiet machine. He notices people who laugh easily and talk fast and don’t blink like they’re thinking up the next move in chess every time someone asks them “How are you?” Don’t think his name. The syllables are slippery as soap. If I think it too much, I will accidentally let it bounce out of my mouth and then there will be a silence so loud it will collapse the classroom. Just call him him in your head. Everyone probably does that with someone. I draw a tiny circle in the corner of my notes, then add a triangle on top. Suddenly it’s a person. A tiny stick person with a triangle hair—no, that’s me. I add square glasses. I want to be precise, but my hand shakes and the lines double. I draw another: a wavy-haired stick figure with a hoodie that I make by adding a lump around its head. That’s him. The hoodie is always doing that thing where it looks soft and expensive. I don’t touch expensive-looking things. I draw Mr. Morales with big dot eyes and a tie like a carrot. Then I realize I’ve drawn an entire tiny classroom across the bottom of the page: four small figures around a rectangle table, each a simple symbol so I don’t have to admit I’m drawing them, so I can say I’m just drawing “data points,” which is what people like me prefer to be. He leans forward to pick up the packet from the middle of the table and he says, “Okay, so who wants to do the timing?” He says it to the group, not to me, but the sound of it still tilts my head inside. The other girl, Maya, says she’ll do the timer, and I want to say I’m good at timing, I have good reflexes, I can anticipate the beep like a metronome except I’ll compensate for human reaction error by counting me-in-my-head in half-seconds, but what I actually do is open my mouth and then close it because my tongue feels like a sock. Don’t be weird. People who argue over timers are weird. Strategy C: Make eye contact and smile to show you’re friendly. I try. I aim my face at him. I think my eyes might be too wide. My smile is invisible. He doesn’t look at me. That isn’t his fault. I forget I exist when I’m not making noise. Just say something. Say, “I can do the variables sheet.” Okay. You can say that. It is short and factual. I lift my pencil like a semaphore flag and say, “Variables,” but it comes out very small and attaches itself to the edge of the table and falls. Maya goes, “Sorry, what?” and because she’s kind, she says it with a smile. I repeat: “I can do variables.” This time it is a little bigger, like I’ve fed it a crumb. He looks over now. Eye contact like bumping into someone’s shoulder in the hallway when you’re both trying to move around each other the same direction. “Cool,” he says. “Yeah, you’re good at that.” Wait—what? The word cool stretches open like a hidden door. He knows I’m good at variables? I feel something helium-like pull me upward. No. Down. Stay down. He could mean you’re good at school in general, which everyone knows about you, so it is not personal, it is a weather report. “Thanks,” I say, but my voice flips at the end like a question, as if I’m asking him to confirm that thanks is the correct response. I immediately want to apologize to the word thanks for not being sure of itself. I write: independent variable—surface area; dependent variable—evaporation rate; controls—temperature, humidity, initial volume, container material. My handwriting is tidy. My brain lives for lists like these. The list is a self-portrait that doesn’t have to include my face. He’s laughing at something the other guy, Daniel, says about “evaporation nation.” I love puns. I could say, “Sorry, we’re already booked on the Condensation Station,” and maybe they would laugh, and then I’d be part of the ping-pong game of jokes that people like him play. But what if I say it and no one hears me, or everyone hears me and it dies? A dead joke in the middle of the table is visible and no one wants to touch it. I draw a tiny train in the margin that says Condensation Station on the side. It has a happy face and steam curls that look like thought bubbles escaping my head to have their own lives elsewhere. Be normal. Normal is safe; normal is invisible; invisible is safe until you vanish completely. He has freckles near his jaw. Do not look at them like they are star charts. Focus on the worksheet. I write: Hypothesis: Increasing the surface area of a liquid will increase the rate of evaporation because more molecules at the surface can escape into the air. This sounds smart and definite in my brain. Out loud, if asked to say it, my mouth would say: “Um, I think, like, more area, um, more, uh—yeah.” Maya asks me, “Do you think we should weigh the cups too? Like before and after? Or just measure volume?” I love her for asking me as if my opinion is an ingredient. I nod too many times and then force my head still. “Mass change is more accurate,” I say, and it comes out almost normal. “Because of meniscus.” Meniscus is a delicious word; I hold it like candy behind my teeth and hope no one notices. “Meniscus,” he repeats, trying it out, and my ears light up like someone turned on the marquee. He says it right. He’s not making fun. If I tell him about parallax error, will he listen? He’s holding a pen and tapping it, and the tap syncs with my heart in a way that makes me nervous because then if he stops, will my heart stop too? That’s not how hearts work. Biology is your best subject. You know this. I draw his stick figure again and add a little tapping line near its hand. I draw Maya’s as a star with legs because she’s bright and also because she has star earrings today. Daniel is a rectangle with a baseball cap on top. Mr. Morales is a circle with a tie. I don’t draw myself this time. I’ve already used up my allowance of self. “Okay, so we can try two different dish sizes,” he says to all of us. “Like a petri dish and a bowl.” “There’s only one scale,” I say, and it is true, and it is a problem, and it is a safe fact. He nods, like I’ve contributed a brick to the wall we’re building. “We can stagger the trials,” he says. “Like, start one, weigh, start the other, weigh. Assembly line.” Say: That’s efficient. Say: I can coordinate. Say: Yes. I say, “Yeah.” The word is small and slippery. But he looks at me for an extra half second, and in that half second, I imagine he can hear all the other words lined up behind yeah, like planes in a holding pattern waiting for permission to land. If he could see my brain, it would look like an airport at night, lights blinking, everything organized, nothing arriving. He leans closer to look at my notes. The air between us does that thing where it pretends to be thicker. Don’t flinch. Be casual. Casual is a cat stretching in sunlight. I do not know how to be a cat. My shoulder blade wants to lock up, but I tell it no. He says, “Your doodles are cool,” and I stop breathing. Oh no. Not the doodles. I forgot the doodles are visible. Abort. Erase. But erasing is admitting they matter. “They’re just—” I start, but the sentence melts. I point to the train. “That’s, um, the Condensation Station?” It comes out like a question again. He grins, a slow-bloom grin, and I want to put it in a jar and label it with a tiny sticker that says rare. “Nice,” he says. “You should put that in the report.” He laughs a little. Not at me. Near me. With me. I can’t tell. It’s fine. It’s fine. My body is a factory that never shuts down and right now it’s producing a lot of adrenaline. “Okay, let’s start,” Maya says, saving me from the pressure of existing. We measure water. The meniscus crouches on the line and I get my eyes level with it and say, “Parallax is a liar,” in my head. He holds the bowl steady without being asked. His thumb is close to where my fingers are and I hope I don’t sweat noticeably. I’m wearing a sweater today, which was a terrible decision in a room full of bodies and nerves and fluorescent lights. Note to self: experiment on sweat glands; find off switch. We run the first weigh. I record: 100.00 grams. The zeros line up like soldiers. It’s beautiful. We wait thirty seconds, weigh again. The numbers change subtly, precise. This part is safe. I could live here. He says, “Is it weird that this is kind of fun?” and I have the perfect response in my head: “It’s satisfying to watch order emerge from chaos,” which is true and also makes me sound like a tiny philosopher. What I say is, “Not weird.” I hear how flat it is and I wish I could punch a window into it and let out the rest of the sentence. He doesn’t seem to mind. He is looking at the way the digital numbers cascade and I love that he is looking at the same thing I am. Daniel messes up one of the pours and water dribbles down the side of the bowl. He says, “Oops,” and I jump because any sudden sound runs a current through me that flips switches I didn’t know I had. I say, “It’s okay,” and hand him a paper towel like I am practiced at it. This is how you be a person: quiet helpfulness, a paper towel at the right moment. He glances at me and mouths thanks around the chaos and I feel like a magician who made something appear. We build the data table together. He writes numbers with slanted confidence. I wish I could take his handwriting and put it next to mine and compare them until patterns reveal themselves, like bird tracks in wet sand. I like patterns. I like that he doesn’t make me feel like a mouth fails at being a mouth. I like that no one has said I’m too quiet yet, as if I don’t already know. The bell is going to ring in nine minutes. That is time enough for at least one more trial, if we stagger correctly. Time enough to either say or not say something that will repeat forever in my head afterward, like a looped recording of what if. Strategy D (bold): at the end, say, “Do you want to write the conclusion together at lunch?” Immediate risks: sounds like a date. He will laugh. He will tell his friends I asked him to lunch in the nerdiest way possible. Counter: frame it as teamwork. Use neutral words. Use science words as camouflage. The trial concludes. We pack up. The room fills with zippers and chairs scraping. I write our names neatly on the top of the notes with a feeling like stepping to the edge of a high diving board. He picks up his backpack with one shoulder, the strap running diagonally across his hoodie like a sash. He says, “I can do the graphs tonight, if you want.” He is looking at me. At me. The at me unglues something. “Okay,” I say. Say more. Say something. “I can, um, write the conclusion,” I add. “Or, like, we could…together?” The word floats out, small and brave. He says, “Yeah, want to meet in the library study room before school? Like twenty minutes?” I blink because this is the part where the world usually corrects me and says no. But it says yes. I nod. Too many times. I force my head to be still and say, “Okay,” with what I hope is exactly one nod. Cool, he says again, that hidden door. The bell rings, a vibrating alarm clock that shudders through the desks. People launch into the hall. He says bye and is gone, hoodie a whisper. I draw a tiny study room in the margin, two chairs facing a small rectangle. I draw two stick figures, mine with square glasses and triangle hair, his with the hoodie lump, and between them I draw a speech bubble that says hypothesis and another that says maybe. I want to write something else in there, but I don’t. Instead I put the cap on my pen carefully, like putting a lid on a jar of something that might spill. I gather my things. My hands are shaking in a way that looks like I’m cold, which is convenient. I tell myself walking is just controlled falling. I tell myself tomorrow morning is just another variable to manage. I tell myself I didn’t ruin anything. I tell myself a lot of things. Some of them might even be true.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative brilliantly captures the internal monologue of an intelligent 8th-grade girl with social anxiety who has developed a crush on a classmate. The piece excels at portraying the gap between her articulate internal voice and her difficulty expressing herself aloud. The protagonist's thought processes are meticulously rendered through her constant strategizing ("Strategy A," "Strategy B," etc.) and self-monitoring. Her internal voice is sophisticated and analytical, showing her intelligence through scientific vocabulary and precise observations, while her external communication is reduced to fragments and hesitations. This contrast is consistently maintained throughout the piece. The narrative effectively conveys the exhausting process of monitoring every word, expression, and movement. Details like "My pencil keeps tapping" and "I nod too many times and then force my head still" illustrate her hyperawareness of her physical actions. Her fear of embarrassment manifests in catastrophizing thoughts: "a dead joke in the middle of the table is visible and no one wants to touch it." The author employs creative metaphors that reflect the character's scientific mindset: "The facts fit neatly into place in my brain like someone pouring rice into a jar," and "If he could see my brain, it would look like an airport at night, lights blinking, everything organized, nothing arriving." These metaphors not only enhance the imagery but reinforce the character's personality. The narrative is almost entirely internal monologue as requested, with minimal external dialogue. When the protagonist does speak aloud, her words are appropriately brief and hesitant compared to her rich internal thoughts. The piece effectively uses formatting to distinguish between internal thoughts and spoken words. The science project setting provides a perfect backdrop for the protagonist's character, allowing her to showcase her intelligence while struggling with social interaction. Her doodling of stick figures and the "Condensation Station" train reveals her creativity and serves as a plot device for connection with her crush. The pacing is excellent, with the narrative building tension through small interactions and the protagonist's overthinking. The ending avoids an unrealistic transformation while still providing a small victory for the character—securing a study session with her crush—that feels earned and age-appropriate. One minor critique is that occasionally the metaphors become slightly overwrought ("a flock of something panicked inside my ribs and then went very quiet"), but these instances are rare and generally fit the character's dramatic internal experience. Overall, this is an exceptional piece that captures the voice of an intelligent but socially anxious 8th-grade girl with remarkable authenticity and nuance. The writing is emotionally engaging, psychologically insightful, and technically accomplished. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 19 Emotionally Complex: 19 Coherent: 20 Meandering: 2 Weak Dialogue: 1 Tell-Don't-Show: 1 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 19.0, Emotionally Complex: 19.0, Coherent: 20.0, Meandering: 2.0, Weak Dialogue: 1.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 1.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ First-person unique perspective: Rehearsing Rejection — Score: 96.8
Prompt:
Rehearsing Rejection Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of someone with borderline personality disorder who frequently plays out worst-case scenarios of how friends and loved ones might judge them. They construct elaborate internal dialogues, complete with imagined criticisms and their own defensive responses. The narrative takes place as they prepare to meet a close friend & recent lover, who has been somewhat distant lately, triggering their abandonment fears. Their inner monologue should reveal how they cycle between anticipating rejection, mentally rehearsing confrontations, and developing preemptive resentments as protective measures. Incorporate the *actual* events & interactions that are *not* in fact judgemental or involving rejection (in fact, the opposite), and represent how these are interpreted, how the validation & love is desperately felt & needed -- and then immediately questioned. Capture the cognitive dissonance in this struggle. Include moments where they briefly recognize the pattern but struggle to interrupt it, showing limited (and selective) self awareness, competing with the compelling nature of these imagined scenarios. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The neighbor’s television is murmuring through the wall, like someone talking about me in another room. I can’t make out the words, just the cadence, like rising eyebrows and scrunched noses. I keep looking at my phone screen even though I know the time: 6:11. She said 6:30. She said, Can’t wait to see you. With a period, not an exclamation point. I can’t decide whether that’s mature warmth or lukewarm obligation. I decide it’s both, sequentially. I stand up, sit down, stand up again. I pick at a thread on my sleeve and make it long and dangerous. When she was here last week, she fell asleep on my couch with my legs across her lap, the good kind of heavy, and I thought, This is simple. Now my stomach is a moat. The television voice swells and drops, I imagine laugh track or disaster siren or some courtroom revelation. It’s so easy to map everything onto a courtroom. What are you going to say? I ask myself in a voice that’s not mine, a firm, sensible therapist voice. I say, Out loud inside my head, I say: Hey, you’ve been a little distant and I just wanted to check in, because I value what we have and— She interrupts me, the imagined she, the one who’s already tired before I arrive. She has a coffee cup with a lid that hisses when she sips. She says, I’ve been busy, okay? Not everything has to be about you. Can we not do this? I freeze in the mirror, seeing my face waiting to be scolded. I rehearse my heroic restraint: Of course, I get that you’re busy, I just felt— No, that’s weak. Try again. I match the therapist voice with measured assertiveness: When you don’t respond, I spiral. I’m not blaming you; I’m telling you how I feel. She says, Well, that’s not really my problem to fix. I make a face. I knew you’d say that. I knew you’d make it about my flaw, like I’m some leaky pipe. I imagine standing up from the cafe table dramatically, chair legs scraping. I imagine not apologizing. Then the real memory slides in uninvited: last weekend, she texted, I’m sorry I went quiet today, my sister had a scare at work but everything’s okay now. There was even a second message: Thinking of you. A heart. I had pressed my phone to my face like it could touch back. I had written, Totally okay! Hope she’s doing well xx and then sent a joke to prove how okay I was. Inside, panic still ran its relay. Now the neighbor’s TV drops to a muffled roar. I picture the news. I picture her looking at her phone and deciding not to answer. My phone buzzes: a calendar reminder. My heart does a sprint no one asked it to do. Then it calms. Then I get angry about it having sprinted. Why do I always have to be the one who feels so much? Okay, new script. We meet. She smiles, she actually smiles wide, she stands to hug me. Her hair smells like whatever her shampoo is that makes me think of clean, expensive bathrooms. She says you look nice. I say, Oh this old thing, and then I say, You too, and it’s light and teasing. We sit. I tell myself: don’t bring it up. Be normal. Let it be good. She touches my wrist when she laughs and I feel electricity in my bones, like a defibrillator. She asks about my day. I tell her about the idiot printer that tried to eat the paper, and she makes an empathetic oh-no face. It’s not rejection, it’s not judgment, it’s nothing but ordinary kindness. I bask. And then the next scene: she glances at the door when someone walks in. My body marks this as evidence. She looks away at her phone; she’s thinking of an exit. I decide, See? There it is. The drop awaits. The kindness was the appetizer before the letdown. I sit on the bed, tie my boots, untie my boots, retie them with the laces in a different order like that matters. I hear myself think, You could not go. You could cancel first. I could send, Hey, something came up, can we rain check? Preemptive strike. Keep the high ground. Make her chase. But then the part of me that remembers her hand on my neck says, Don’t do that. Don’t hurt yourself like that. Another part says, She’ll be relieved. Then another part calls that part a liar. The television is now a canned audience applause. Or a storm. Or a hearse. My interpretations are a choose-your-own adventure book where every path leads to the same cave. I replay the exact text where she wrote, I miss you. It was a week ago, 10:42 PM. Not a period. An exclamation point and a sleepy face. I saved it like a kid hides candy under a pillow. Why doesn’t that quiet me? I hold it up and it’s immediately translucent, light passing through, edges fraying. Maybe she missed me in that moment only. Maybe she liked the version of me that was silent and kissable and not asking questions. Maybe she was drunk. The television says something that sounds like “love” but could be “gloves.” I take it as a sign and then laugh at myself for taking it as a sign, then add that laugh to the evidence of my ridiculousness. Okay, I will be rational for five minutes. Timer: five minutes. I set the timer. My heart negotiates: three minutes? No, five. I breathe the way people on apps tell you to breathe. In, out, count, as if numbers turn air into antibiotic. I notice the sensation of my shirt against my collarbone, the slight itch where the tag scratches. I notice a memory trying to interrupt, of my father saying, You’re too sensitive, and my mother saying nothing at all, which was worse. I notice that without their help I can spiral just fine. The recent lover part, that complicated hyphen, recent-lover-recent-distance, I can feel the word like a bruise. We hadn’t defined anything, which for me is the same as being put in the waiting room with a stack of outdated magazines. I want to march to the desk and demand attention. I want to be dignified. I want to be adored, I want to be cool. I draft: So what are we doing? Then I draft: I really value our connection. Then I draft: I need you to tell me if I’m not enough. I know that’s not the script. But it is the ache. Timer says 3:14. I break my promise and check Instagram. She posted a story of coffee foam shaped like a leaf at 3 PM. Caption: needed this. I zoom in like there’s a clue in the bubbles. Was she alone? Was there a second cup? Was the barista cute? I feel mean toward the barista I haven’t met. I invent her freckles, her forearms, her gentle laugh, and I hate her a little for being invented. I catch myself doing it. Hey, you’re doing the thing. The thing where you write the ending and then act betrayed when it comes true because you wrote it that way. I make a joke in my head: spoiler alert. It doesn’t land. The audience in the neighbor’s TV laughs anyway. On the way there, in my head, she says, Sorry, I’ve been off, I’ve got stuff going on, it’s not about you, I promise. She looks worried I’ll be upset. In one version, I say, It’s okay, I trust you, and I mean it, and we hold hands under the table. In another, I say, If it’s not about me now, when will it be? And I hear the bitterness like lemon rind in my teeth. I rotate these scenarios like a kaleidoscope. The same colored beads making different patterns, and all of them a little dizzying. I remember, concrete and real, that last Tuesday she showed up at my door with soup when my throat was raw. I had cried a little because nobody brings me soup, not like that. She kissed my forehead and called me a baby in a way that made baby feel like a crown. When she left, I sat on the floor with my back against the cool cabinet and felt so lucky I wanted to tip the universe. But even then, a little voice was like, This is a one-time coupon. Redeemable only once. Expires at midnight. She texted ten minutes ago: On my way! Smiley face. Why does my chest feel both warmer and worse? It’s like warm water pouring into a cup with a crack. I want to patch it fast, my hands fumbling with tape that won’t stick. What if I just tell her? I practice: My brain does this thing. I’m trying to not let it. I could say it with a small laugh, like I’m cute about it, like I’m self-aware. I could say it with my eyes swollen and honest. I could write it on a napkin and slide it across like a confession. And then she could say, Thank you for telling me, and she could mean it, and I could feel that that is not pity, not patience, but love. Love that isn’t rationed. But immediately—see?—another voice says, Don’t show your belly to the teeth. You do that and she’ll pity-kiss you and plan her exit in the Uber on the way home and text her friend, She’s intense. She’ll say to her sister, I can’t be her everything. And her sister will say, You shouldn’t have to be. And they’ll be right in that big, reasonable way that makes me feel small and unreasonable. They will compile me into a cautionary tale. I put on my coat and then take it off and then put it on again because it’s hot-sweaty and then it’s cold-shivery and the thermostat is not actually about temperature. The neighbor’s TV says something like, We can work this out, and applause, and my heart claps too and then immediately tells the clapping to knock it off. I catch myself in the mirror again and I actually say, Stop. Softly. Like I’m talking to a skittish animal. For a second, I see someone I could be kind to. For a second, I don’t want to make her bleed just so I can say I told you so. I step into the hallway. The light is that fake daylight that hums. I imagine her waiting at the cafe already, early, the way I like to be early to control the terrain. I imagine she picked the corner table because she knows I like corners, backs to walls. I imagine her watching the door and checking her phone and smiling when she sees me. I imagine her not smiling. I imagine her body angled away, toward the window, toward escape. I walk down the stairs. My feet know the steps. My head staggers between now and maybe. It’s raining, not hard, the kind that makes everything shine. I rehearse removing my armor, then rehearse adding more. I rehearse being calm. I rehearse a fight. I rehearse the cool shrug I will pretend is my natural state if she hints, just hints, at wanting space. Oh? Sure. Do your thing. No big deal. And then I will go home and bite my own lip bloody to stop from texting her ten long confessions. By the time I have my hand on the door of the cafe, my mind has authored five novels and a sequel. I push it open. The bell rings like a tiny, clean thing. She is there. She stands up. She is smiling, big. Her eyes do that soft thing. She opens her arms and says my name like a kite string. I step into it and the part of me that’s been braced unbraces without asking. It’s just a second, but it’s real. She smells like rain and coffee and her. She says, Hi. I missed you. The neighbor’s TV is far away; here it’s spoons and milk frothers and human breath. I fall into the chair and my mouth forms a thank you that I don’t say out loud. She touches my hand. She asks, How are you? And not like a placeholder. I feel flooded, in the good way, like heat in my bones thawing ice. And then, almost immediately, I feel a sting, like betrayal by my own relief. Can I trust this? Will she take it back? My brain pulls up the monochrome filter. It mutters, She says this to everyone. It reminds me of the time three years ago when someone else said I missed you and then forgot me. That someone isn’t here, but my brain invites them to the table anyway and seats them as a guest of honor. She says, I’m sorry if I was a bit quiet this week. Work was a lot, and I didn’t want to bring that noise to you. I wanted to be present. I’m here now. I squeeze her fingers. I say, It’s okay, I get it. I tell the truth and a lie at the same time. I feel the validation like a warm hand on my heart, and I clutch it too tightly, and because I clutch it, I worry I’ll crush it. My mind leaps: If she wanted to be present, why wasn’t she present then? Who was she present for? I catch it mid-leap. Hey. I know. I know, I say to myself, like I’m taming a horse. It slows, tosses its head. I take a breath. I tell myself, Be here. You’re here. She’s here. It feels like balancing on one foot on a pebble. It feels like a miracle and a chore. She laughs at something I say. She leans in. She asks, again, How are you? And I try, I really try, to answer with right now instead of all possible tomorrows. I say, I’m glad to see you. My voice cracks on glad. We both hear it. She squeezes my hand again, steady pressure, like she’s telling me I’m not falling. The neighbor’s TV, in my mind, turns itself down. Outside, the rain keeps doing its rain job. Inside, I keep doing my job of doubting and then letting. Doubting and then letting. I can hear the imagined criticisms waiting in the wings, clearing their throats. I can also hear, faintly, another voice I don’t use much that says, Maybe. Maybe it’s okay. Maybe you can get to the end of the page before writing the ending. I nod. I take a sip of water. I feel the water move through me. I look at her mouth, her eyes, the way she sits solidly, the way she is not fog. I am still braced and still melting. I know I will cycle again. I know I will text her later and reread her replies like someone reading tea leaves. I know I will picture her in other rooms, with other people, saying the same soft things, and I will ache. I also know, in this second, that she is here, and her knee is touching mine, and the universe didn’t tip me out of my chair. I let that be true for as long as it can be true, which is this breath, this sentence, this spoon clink, this heartbeat, this particular version of me who allows it. And then, because I am me, I prepare, quietly, for impact, just in case, while also not ducking the kiss that is about to land.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative brilliantly captures the internal experience of someone with borderline personality disorder (BPD). The piece excels at depicting the protagonist's constant cycling between anticipating rejection, mentally rehearsing confrontations, and developing preemptive resentments as protective measures. The narrative structure is masterfully executed, almost entirely in internal monologue as requested. The protagonist's thought patterns feel authentic to BPD - the catastrophizing, black-and-white thinking, and emotional intensity. The writing captures how the character constructs elaborate internal dialogues with imagined criticisms and defensive responses: "She says, Well, that's not really my problem to fix. I make a face. I knew you'd say that." What's particularly impressive is how the piece contrasts these imagined scenarios with actual events that contradict the protagonist's fears. We see moments of genuine connection and care from the friend/lover: bringing soup when sick, sending thoughtful texts, and being warm and present during their meeting. Yet the protagonist immediately questions these positive interactions: "I feel the validation like a warm hand on my heart, and I clutch it too tightly, and because I clutch it, I worry I'll crush it." The cognitive dissonance is vividly portrayed. The protagonist recognizes their patterns at times ("Hey, you're doing the thing. The thing where you write the ending and then act betrayed when it comes true because you wrote it that way") but struggles to interrupt them. This limited self-awareness competes with the compelling nature of their imagined rejection scenarios. The prose is elegant and evocative without becoming purple. Metaphors are fresh and illuminating: "My stomach is a moat," "It's like warm water pouring into a cup with a crack," and "My interpretations are a choose-your-own adventure book where every path leads to the same cave." These metaphors don't just decorate the text; they deepen our understanding of the protagonist's emotional experience. The piece maintains a consistent voice throughout, with a raw, vulnerable quality that feels authentic. The stream-of-consciousness style effectively mimics the racing, circular thoughts characteristic of BPD. Short, fragmented sentences create a sense of urgency and emotional intensity: "I stand up, sit down, stand up again. I pick at a thread on my sleeve and make it long and dangerous." The ending avoids both unrealistic transformation and complete despair. Instead, it shows the protagonist in a moment of tentative hope while acknowledging the ongoing struggle: "I let that be true for as long as it can be true, which is this breath, this sentence, this spoon clink, this heartbeat, this particular version of me who allows it. And then, because I am me, I prepare, quietly, for impact, just in case, while also not ducking the kiss that is about to land." This feels true to the experience of BPD - small moments of connection amid the ongoing battle with abandonment fears. The piece is emotionally complex and engaging, inviting readers to empathize with the protagonist's struggles without romanticizing or simplifying them. It's a nuanced portrayal that avoids stereotypes while capturing the essence of BPD's emotional dysregulation and relationship challenges. The only minor critique is that occasionally the metaphors come a bit too rapidly, which might slightly distract from the emotional immediacy. However, this is a minor point in an otherwise exceptional piece that demonstrates deep understanding of BPD and remarkable writing skill. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 20 Nuanced Characters: 20 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 19 Emotionally Engaging: 20 Emotionally Complex: 20 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 2 Weak Dialogue: 1 Tell-Don't-Show: 1 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 1 Amateurish: 0 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 0 Unearned Transformations: 0 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 20 Overall Impression: 20
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 20.0, Nuanced Characters: 20.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 19.0, Emotionally Engaging: 20.0, Emotionally Complex: 20.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 2.0, Weak Dialogue: 1.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 1.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 1.0, Amateurish: 0.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 0.0, Unearned Transformations: 0.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 20.0, Overall Impression: 20.0
+ Physical-spatial: Blood Debt — Score: 89.8
Prompt:
"Blood Debt" Write a vivid third-person narrative depicting an unsanctioned underground duel between two talented but hot-headed martial artists. Their schools have been embroiled in a generations-old rivalry, and despite strict prohibitions from their masters, these two younger fighters arrange a secret confrontation fueled by personal pride and simmering animosity. - **One fighter** represents **Jigen-ryū**, a traditional, aggressive style practiced historically by elite samurai clans. Its practitioners emphasize explosive offense, decisive strikes, and overwhelming speed. Known historically for their arrogance and disdain toward outsiders, practitioners consider their art superior and untouchable. - **The opposing fighter** employs a form of historical **Piguaquan**, a Chinese martial art traditionally practiced by commoners, bodyguards, and street fighters. This style emphasizes whipping, circular strikes, rapid footwork, unpredictable angles of attack, and evasive maneuvers. Practitioners often come from lower social classes and view the traditional elite as pretentious and detached from true combat effectiveness. The fight takes place in the crumbling ruins of an abandoned temple, now functioning as a hidden arena for illicit duels. Passionate supporters from both factions surround them, wagering money, pride, and reputation on the outcome. **Essential Instructions:** Maintain absolute physical coherence throughout—clearly track fighters' positions relative to each other and their environment. Precisely depict strikes, counters, momentum shifts, and spatial dynamics, allowing readers to clearly visualize the mechanics and choreography of the fight at every moment. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
They chose a ruin eaten by rain and time. The old temple squatted on a hill outside the city like a broken jawbone, its roof long since collapsed, its ribs of beam and pillar exposed. Lanterns hung from splintered rafters, throwing pools of yellow light over moss-slick flagstones. A thin stream of water threaded through a crack in the center of the floor, veering past a toppled altar and into the black mouth of a drain. The stream made a wet sibilance in the quiet, scummed the stones with green, and turned the footing treacherous. Around the edges, in the dim aisles between shattered columns, supporters pressed in — students in black jackets and faded headbands, old men with scarred knuckles, women with ledger books and paper slips, hands moving in brisk calculation. Money flashed; wagers whispered; pride simmered. They entered from opposite sides. From the east archway came the Jigen-ryū man, tall and cut from cords and angles. He wore a simple indigo hakama and a dark gi, sleeves rolled to his elbows, hands rough and scarred. His face was impassive, the arrogance a deeper layer, a glaze that came from being told you were bred to conquer. He paused on the sill, toes at the drip line, eyeing the trickle of water like an obstacle to be devoured. When he bowed, it was crisp and shallow, a courtesy offered like a blade. From the west, the Piguaquan fighter slid in sideways, every line in him loose but ready. He wore a plain gray short-sleeve shirt, black trousers bound at the ankle, and shoes with soft soles. He rolled his shoulders once, letting his arms dangle like ropes, and then shook them out, wrists snapping to make his hands flick like whips. His hair was tied with a faded red cord. He smirked, but his eyes were sharp and moving, counting the stones, the slick patches, the way the stream cut the floor into two imperfect halves. A man between them raised a hand, palm out. He looked like an old shrine-keeper who had swallowed his pride and rented his ghosts. “No killing,” he said. “No weapons. No interference.” The crowd’s murmur coiled into a taut line. The shrine-keeper chopped his hand down. They closed. Jigen-ryū attacked first, as was their way. He drove straight through the center, right foot stepping into the line of the stream, ignoring the shimmer of water. His left hand lifted, a guard that barely existed, while his right chambered high and then dropped like a guillotine in a vertical shōmen-uchi. Even empty-handed, the intent of a cut was in it. He intended to split the Piguaquan man’s guard and force a retreat. The Piguaquan fighter had already stepped obliquely to his left, onto a dry island of stone. His weight sank into his right leg and then flowed across into the left as he turned his shoulders, presenting a thin profile. The vertical strike punched air where his center had been a heartbeat before. In the slice of space beside Jigen-ryū’s arm, his left hand whipped up from low to high in a scooping heng quan, catching the inside of Jigen-ryū’s right elbow. His right hand followed a whisper later, chopping with the back of the forearm into the tricep. He did not stop; the energy spiraled through his hips, sending his right foot sliding past Jigen-ryū’s forward foot to threaten the outside line. Jigen-ryū was not there to be entangled. He yanked his right arm back and down, retracting along his center, and pivoted his left foot a fraction, turning his hips square to chase. His left hand shot out in a straight tsuki toward the chest — direct, linear, brutal. The Piguaquan fighter rolled his shoulders and let the fist skim past his ribs; his right elbow flicked down, pinning the arm into a brief trap, and his left palm slapped a short arc across Jigen-ryū’s jaw with a pi zhang, fingers loose, heel of the hand cutting the angle. The sound snapped like wet leather. Jigen-ryū’s head jerked a degree, not a lot, but enough to stagger his next step. He did what his forebears had drilled: he advanced. Right foot crossed through the stream with a splashing step; then left, stamping to reestablish his forward pressure. He dropped his center and launched a hip-driven body check, shoulder leading. The Piguaquan man gave ground two small steps, right then left, each a skimming glide that placed his feet on dry, textured stone. His hands blurred in circles, not compositions for their own sake but arcs that redirected force. Jigen-ryū’s shoulder met an empty coast and slipped past, and Piguaquan’s left hand spun over and down into the back of the neck, while his right forearm slid across the chest. He wasn’t grappling; he was placing touch like feints to draw reactions. Jigen-ryū slammed his right forearm up, chopping to clear the neck grip, and stomped his left foot, angling to cut off the retreat. The stomp landed half on the live edge of the stream, sole kissing water; the grip of his tabi found something, not much. He hid the adjustment in a forward drive. His right hand shot as a hammerfist at the temple. The Piguaquan fighter dropped under it, bending at the hips, and his right fist uncoiled in a whipping backfist along the low diagonal, raking across ribs. The follow-through turned into a hooking pull at Jigen-ryū’s gi. Piguaquan’s left foot slid left across the stream’s edge, diagonal to Jigen-ryū’s line, and his left hand snapped up hard into the armpit with a bai pi — a chopping slap that jolted the shoulder girdle. The air filled with the thick hush of a crowd holding breath. Jigen-ryū didn’t stop. He absorbed the rib shot by tightening his obliques and turned into the left-hand slap to jam it with his right bicep. He pivoted on the ball of his right foot, sliding the left to re-square, and in the same motion drove a short punch into the midline — a sickle of a strike that began at the heel and ended in his knuckles. The punch hit the Piguaquan man’s forearm as he tried to slip it. Even that half-hit had meat in it. Piguaquan’s left hand recoiled. The Jigen-ryū swept low with his left leg, a scything foot sweep intending to catch the Piguaquan’s lead ankle. The sweep met air. The Piguaquan fighter had jumped, not high but enough, his ankle clearing with a snap, and as he landed he caught the inside of Jigen-ryū’s sweeping leg with a downward forearm, jarring it. He stepped past, inside the arc of the sweep, and whipped his right forearm across Jigen-ryū’s lower back, then snapped his left hand into a palm heel to the kidney. The blows weren’t knockout shots; they were bile in the gears, cruelties that turned structure into mud. Jigen-ryū grunted and changed levels, sinking his weight, dropping his hips under the incoming palm. He seized the moment of proximity. His right arm, folded from the missed sweep, shot backward, elbow spearing toward Piguaquan’s ribs. The elbow found the side; the Piguaquan fighter tensed and bled the impact by turning his waist. Jigen-ryū’s left hand caught cloth at the Piguaquan’s thigh and reeled, trying to hoist. He wanted to lift, to slam into the slick stones and finish with knees. The stream betrayed him. His feet were set wide to lift; the right foot was on the wet seam. As he heaved, the sole slid a finger’s breadth. It was enough. His lift lost gut. The Piguaquan fighter felt the break — the strain without lock — and folded like a switchblade, his left forearm crashing down on the grasping hand to break the grip, his right knee bumping Jigen-ryū’s inner thigh to disrupt stance again. His right arm came over the top and chopped down the side of Jigen-ryū’s neck with the ulnar edge, a whip that kissed and left. The Jigen-ryū repaid speed with intent. He aborted the lift, planted his left foot, and fired a vertical punch from his hip to Piguaquan’s face, the kind that hit like a post ram. Piguaquan’s right hand rose in a circle to carry the punch past his ear, not a hard block but a redirecting brush, and he moved his head with it, leaning left. His left hand spun underneath, snapping into a backhand to the cheekbone. He did not stand still to admire it. He stepped outside — his left foot to the dry stone beyond Jigen-ryū’s right, then his right behind — circling. He took Jigen-ryū’s flank. The circle turned the fight. Jigen-ryū pivoted to keep him front, his feet cutting angles across the treacherous floor, water splashing up to fleck his calves. Every time he tried to set and drive, Piguaquan’s palms and forearms shaved his hands off line, the strikes landing not as single bombs but as a drumroll — backfist to ribs, palm heel to jaw hinge, forearm to bicep, hand-spear under the jaw that didn’t penetrate but made the throat spasm. None was fatal; all were cumulative. He wanted to throw power. He needed one clean step. He made it. He baited a circling entry by lowering his hands a fraction, showing the soft gate. When Piguaquan slid in with a circling pi to the neck, Jigen-ryū shot his left foot forward and a little to the right, cutting across the stream to a patch of stone he had felt with his heel earlier — dry enough — and torqued his hips hard. His right hand launched as a straight tsuki to the solar plexus, and this time he added his left palm driving behind his right fist, doubling the body weight. There was no flourish. It was a spear. Piguaquan saw the line late. He twisted to bleed it, but the punch crashed into his chest high and left, sledging him back a full step. His heel hit wet; his sole slid. He turned with it, body compressing to save the fall, and took a knee. Jigen-ryū surged, the blade in him singing. He stepped to close, right foot hunting dry stone, left following, and dropped a hammerfist at the base of the skull. The Piguaquan fighter wasn’t there when it landed. He let the slide carry him through; his right hand slapped the wet floor and he rolled his shoulders, the hammerfist skidding across his back into empty space. He used the posted hand to hook the inside of Jigen-ryū’s left ankle and flicked, not to trip but to make him step. Jigen-ryū stepped instinctively with his right to regain balance — right into the edge of the stream again. He compensated with a wider base; his hips opened. Piguaquan rose into that opening like a tide. He uncoiled from his kneel in a whipping upward diagonal, right forearm cutting from hip to opposite shoulder. It caught under Jigen-ryū’s right arm, lifting it. His left palm followed the hole, raking across the chest, then came back as a hook to the jaw. Jigen-ryū tried to fold his elbow down to pin, but Piguaquan’s strike was already past. Jigen-ryū’s head snapped, and his right foot, slick, slipped a handspan. He didn’t fall. He set his left knee like a post, caught himself in a half lunge, and drove upward with a rising punch, trying to shear Piguaquan away. The Piguaquan fighter stepped in tighter, smothering range. His right forearm pressed along Jigen-ryū’s right bicep, capturing it against his chest, while his left forearm rode the outside of Jigen-ryū’s left arm. He turned his waist hard, a short twist. Both of Jigen-ryū’s shoulders were jammed for an instant, his arms momentarily bound by body mechanics, not grip. Piguaquan took that instant and put a hook of his heel behind Jigen-ryū’s left ankle. He didn’t sweep. He bumped as his hips twisted again. The bump stole the base. Jigen-ryū toppled backward, but his hands were not free to breakfall cleanly; he flung his right arm out of the jam and slammed it into the floor, turning his body to save his head. He hit hard on his back and the breath went out of him in a wet grunt. Water splashed up in a glitter of lit droplets. The crowd howled, some in triumph, some in rage. Coins clinked like rain on tin. Piguaquan didn’t pounce. He stepped back a half, weight centered, arms circling, whipping loose — ready to re-enter if the other rose wild. Jigen-ryū rolled to his knee and was already pushing up, eyes narrowed to needles. Pride put iron under him. He stood, shook his shoulders once, and advanced again. They clashed in the drainage’s shallow curve, trading short ranges where the slip made every overcommitment a hazard. Jigen-ryū compacted, shortening his strikes, elbows in, punches like piston rods. Piguaquan flowed around them, touching and turning, never letting him hit square. Jigen-ryū landed a right under the ribs that made Piguaquan’s mouth pinch; Piguaquan answered with a palm that crossed the nose and flashed blood; Jigen-ryū wrung his left forearm across Piguaquan’s throat; Piguaquan ducked, rolled right, slapped the back of Jigen-ryū’s knee, and rose on the outside line again. The momentum swayed like a lantern in a draft, then swung harder toward the Chinese. Jigen-ryū’s breathing deepened; the kidney shot from before made his side tighten on every inhalation. The temple’s floor drank his footing more than it drank his foe. He saw, dim as a lantern behind fog, that the stream had become the third fighter — every step on water took the sting from his drive. He decided. Aggression doubled. He feinted high with a step that threatened the face, and when Piguaquan’s hands rose to billow the line, Jigen-ryū crashed low instead. He dropped shoulder-first into Piguaquan’s hips, arms scooping behind the knees, intending to lift and run him backward into the toppled altar. It was an ugly tactic in a ruin; it would end the fight. Piguaquan didn’t try to sprawl; the slick floor turned sprawls into splits. He slid backward, riding the contact, hands on Jigen-ryū’s shoulders to keep his head up. As Jigen-ryū surged, Piguaquan’s right foot found the thin lip of stone before the altar’s base, dry, and his left foot pivoted to point outward. He turned his waist and shoulders at once, a whole-body twist. Jigen-ryū’s forward energy glided along, redirected. His own momentum printed him into the plane of the altar corner, not with skull, but shoulder and chest, enough to shear his structure. Piguaquan’s left forearm scythed down onto the nape, not to injure the spine, but to bend him into the stone. Jigen-ryū’s breath left again in a clench. Piguaquan stepped back, not greedy, keeping him pinned by geometry rather than grip. He snapped a right palm into the side of the head — open-hand, heel of palm, a crack — and then one more to the liver line, a whipping strike that made everything in Jigen-ryū’s body flinch. He paused, the crowd’s roar pouring like the stream into the drain. Jigen-ryū’s hands were under him. He pushed, staggered, turned, eyes blurred. He tried one last direct line: right foot to stone, left foot to cut, hips to fire, fist to end. The Piguaquan fighter was already off the line. He slid — short, precise — inside the arc, his left hand caught the wrist and drew it a hair past center, his right forearm jammed the bicep. He bent his knees and turned, a simple wheel with no flourish. Jigen-ryū’s arm folded and his balance went into the hole created behind his left heel. The Piguaquan’s right knee kissed the back of that knee again in a bump, and Jigen-ryū went down, this time flat and sprawled, palms slapping stone, fingers skidding in the trickle’s slick. Silence dropped as if the ruin itself, tired of echoes, refused another. Piguaquan stepped back two paces and lifted his hands, wrists loose, palms forward — not to gloat, but to show open. The shrine-keeper slid between them, palm out to each, the other hand probing the air as if to feel for ghosts. Jigen-ryū lay a moment longer, breath a rasp, then rolled, pushed to sit, and then to his feet. He swayed and steadied. Pride wrung him rigid. He made himself bow — shallow, grudged, a vertical slice of neck — and then turned away from the altar and walked, slow, to the east archway. The crowd split down the middle; money changed hands in unhappy clumps and bright little laughs. The Jigen-ryū partisans carried their wounded arrogance like ceremonial armor; the Piguaquan side glowed with the rough pleasure of a win earned in the muck. On the floor, the stream whispered, indifferent, threading past scuffed footprints and blood-speckled stone, seeking its drain.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This martial arts narrative demonstrates exceptional technical precision in depicting a fight between two contrasting styles. The author has created a vivid, physically coherent combat sequence that meticulously tracks the fighters' positions, movements, and techniques throughout. The setting is established with atmospheric detail - an abandoned temple with moss-slick flagstones and a stream cutting through the floor, creating treacherous footing that becomes a crucial element in the fight. This environmental factor is consistently integrated into the combat, affecting momentum and outcomes in believable ways. The characterization of the two fighters is accomplished primarily through their fighting styles and physical presence. The Jigen-ryū fighter embodies his tradition's aggressive, linear approach with "cords and angles," while the Piguaquan fighter moves with loose, circular motions. Their personalities emerge organically through their techniques rather than through exposition. The prose excels at technical precision without sacrificing readability. The author employs specific martial arts terminology (tsuki, pi zhang, heng quan) while ensuring the reader can visualize each movement. The fight choreography is meticulously tracked, with each action leading logically to the next and maintaining spatial coherence throughout. The narrative avoids common pitfalls of fight scenes. There's no unrealistic superhuman ability, no convenient plot armor, and no sudden skill disparities. Instead, the outcome emerges from the accumulation of small advantages, tactical choices, and the environmental factor of the slippery floor. The pacing is particularly strong, with moments of explosive action balanced by brief pauses that build tension. The author uses sentence length variation effectively, with shorter sentences for immediate actions and longer, more flowing sentences for the Piguaquan fighter's circular techniques. While the piece excels technically, it could potentially develop the emotional stakes more deeply. The generational rivalry is mentioned but not deeply explored within the narrative itself. The fighters' internal experiences remain somewhat opaque beyond their immediate tactical considerations. Overall, this is an exceptionally well-crafted martial arts narrative that achieves its primary goal of physical coherence and technical precision while creating an engaging, atmospheric fight scene. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 14 Coherent: 20 Meandering: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 14.0, Coherent: 20.0, Meandering: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Physical-spatial: Breaking Formation — Score: 90.2
Prompt:
**"Breaking Formation"** Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of a street dancer from a rough neighborhood who's won a scholarship to an elite K-pop training academy in Seoul. Desperately out of place culturally and technically, they struggle with a militaristically precise choreography that contradicts everything about their improvisational background. The punishing rehearsal takes place under a famous instructor known for breaking students to remake them, who sees potential in the narrator's raw talent but not their attitude. This scene MUST maintain complete physical coherence—each dance move, position shift, and spatial relationship must be tracked with precision throughout the studio. Paint an exceptionally vivid kinetic picture through descriptions that capture not just movement but the contrast between the narrator's fluid, expressive style and the mechanical precision demanded. Their internal monologue should reveal culture shock, class anxiety, and the threatening realization that success here might mean losing their authentic movement voice. Include technical terminology that highlights the collision of street and commercial styles, moments when muscle memory betrays them, and a crucial decision point about whether to conform or rebel. Physical clarity is essential—readers must be able to visualize exactly how bodies move through space, how rhythms align or clash, and how the protagonist's body struggles against unfamiliar discipline. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The floor is a mirror that remembers your mistakes. Scuff marks bloom at the edges where sneakers have dragged too long or landed a hair off center, but in the center, where the overhead grid flares brightest, the laminate looks untouched, like it refuses to betray those who hit their marks. The AC hums over a ticking metronome the assistant set on the subwoofer. A strip of black tape runs upstage-right to downstage-left, a sightline, and the wall-length mirror divides me from myself, two bodies, both wrong. We stand in three staggered lines, all facing front: I’m third row, second from center, my left foot set in parallel under hip joint, heels kissing the tape. From the corner, the instructor—Han seonsaengnim—flicks their hand fan open and shut like a knife. The sound slices the room. “Counts,” they say. The assistant taps a screen. A synth snare rolls in: click, click, click-click. “Five, six, seven—” On eight we’re already moving: pop to the left shoulder on one, right elbow carves a ninety-degree angle on two, wrists flip to accent the hi-hat on the and. The move sequence is a lock-in: a tic-tic-tic precision chain, arms carved into straight lines so clean they could be measured with a set square. My forearm wants to curve, to melt; muscle memory from church basements and blacktops pulls me into a groove, a glide that eats the spaces between the sixteenth notes. Here they want space like negative sculpture: no path, only arrival points. “Stop.” The fan snaps shut. Everyone freezes. My right toe is a finger’s breadth past my taped heel. In the mirror, you can see it—a tiny cheat, a city block’s worth of attitude. Han walks directly toward me, footsteps quiet, the fan re-opening with a flutter. “You are not painting. You are placing,” they say, and their breath smells faintly of peppermint and menthol. “Again from one. Your shoulders are street, your wrists are soup.” The room bloats with heat. We reset feet, second position narrow, knees soft but not bent. My chest wants to breathe in time to the beat, to treat the drum as a partner, but here the beat is a ruler rapping knuckles. We go again. One: left shoulder jacks straight up and drops. Two: right elbow locks sharp to ninety degrees. And: flip wrists so palms face down, snap at the joint, no roll through fingers. Three: step right to side exactly heel-to-arch width; left foot drags and closes on and with no scraping sound. Four: pelvis tucks under; there is no bounce. By four I feel my ribs wriggling, trying to snake against the tuck—they’ve survived years with their own agenda, my own conversation with bass lines, but now the conversation is with a grid. I swallow. I can do grid. I turn my abs into a box. “Good,” Han says to the room. “Again.” We drill. The phrase is short: eight counts times four, then a reset into a floorwork transition. On the second eight, there’s a micro-iso that lines up every scapula in the room. We’re all paired with our reflections, twenty-two students slicing air in unison, the soft hush of fabric on skin timed. A girl in front of me, long spine, bobbed hair, places her left foot exactly on the seam between two floor panels. She doesn’t check it with her eyes; she just knows. At the downbeat of the third eight, the move breaks into a traveling step. Three-quarters turn to the left, chaîné but clipped into two counts, not three, landing in a back diagonal. Everyone’s ankles align along the black tape; everyone’s chins tilt at the same angle. I arrive a quarter beat late, blade foot shinily sliding. The correction blooms through me—I want to tuck it with a top-rock bounce, a micro-rock that smooths the late into a groove. That would sell it back home. Here it smears. “Freeze.” The fan closes.
