Han is next to my right shoulder now, not touching but close enough for the air to feel occupied. They tilt their head, eyes scanning from my toe to my neck. “You compensate with flavor because you missed the count,” they say, quiet enough that only the third line hears. “Do you think I don’t see that?” I don’t answer. In my head, the South Side cranes down hard. Flavor is how we survive bad speakers, power cuts, cops driving by too slow. Flavor is the difference between staying and being dragged. My throat tastes like iron. “Again.” The fan opens. “From the travel. Five, six—” I count internally, half-singing: one-e-and-a, two-e-and-a. My weight’s over my toes. The assistant raises a hand—my cue to correct the spot. On the turn, the world spins to a smear of bodies and black tape. Spot front, spot mirror, spot front again. I place my left foot on the tape line and lock my hips square to corner two. Arms cross at chest like shutters on four; then, wrist isolation on five, six, seven—this is the part where the choreography turns almost robotic, forearms parallel to floor, fists tight, retraction only at the scapula. My muscles itch to let the energy rebound through me, a wave that leaves fingers trailing. I clamp it. I shove it back. “Better,” Han says, glancing at me without approval. “But your face leaks.” I check my face in the mirror. My eyebrows are doing their own choreography, a silent commentary that reads: this is a joke we all understand. I tell them to stand down. We run the A section into B: a switch from hard-hitting vogue arms into a slick commercial glide, then dropping into a floor combo that my knees hate. Eight counts to lower: right knee lowers to the floor on two, left follows on three, palms plant on four under shoulders—align wrists under joints, no splay. On five, shoot the right leg through underneath, thread to a kneel facing upstage. Six: recover into a half-standing crouch; seven: stand, sit into a hip as your arms snap above head; eight: step into a diagonal tuck jump. My body wants to torque the thread, to roll a bit of capoeira through the space, to let the knee replace be a conversation. The room wants a slot change in a vacuum. “Again,” Han says. Their fan whispers over my shoulder like someone telling me a secret I don’t want to hear. We go until my quads are trembling. The assistant turns off the click; music spills in: a track with a bright synth hook and a kick drum too fat for this clean studio. The choreography welds to it like a machine to a conveyor belt. We become parts. They are precise pieces; I am a bolt still warm from the forge. Between runs, we watch one another in the mirror. Many of them are from academies, pliés disciplined into the hips, tendus straight as rulers. Their sneakers are clean. Mine are a little chewed at the soles, leftovers from battles where asphalt ate rubber and moves slipped from night into legend. Their skin creams smell like lavender and something sweet. I smell like train grease and frankincense from my auntie’s house. The class chatter during water breaks floats across me—dialect flavors I can’t catch, the soft click of a foreign language knitting itself without me. “Partner counts,” Han orders. We pair off. The girl with the bob—Minji—gestures for me. We face each other at a diagonal, thirty inches between shoes. In the mirror we’re a V. The exercise is strict: my right becomes her left, our lines must mirror down the seam between us. We do the wrist retraction sequence in slow motion, two counts per isolation, then add speed. My muscles eventually find the path; they hate the leash. A tiny jerky thread snakes through my right shoulder. “See,” Minji says, polite, breath shallow. “Your scapula slides too far. Think of your shoulder blade suction-cupped.” I imagine the suction; my blade obeys. The move becomes smaller and suddenly right. I want to laugh because small feels wrong; small never fed me. Big got people to pay attention. But here, small is currency. We break the wall again in full-out. I nail the travel. I manage the thread without capoeira creeping in. On the chorus, there’s a moment: arms flick outward in a series of tutting squares, then shift into a body roll locked through eight little micro pulses, like a hummingbird trapped and trying not to show it’s trapped. My roll is liquid; it wants to flood. I build a dam. I count the eight. My teeth are clenched. Up front, Han sees the dam, nods once, and the fan snaps in approval instead of reprimand. “From the top. This time, commit,” Han says, and their eyes slice into me. “Commit to this. Not to what you think this could be.” What I think this could be is a conversation between my block and their mirror. But their mirror doesn’t talk; it interrogates. We go again, and my lungs start burning as much as my thighs. Somewhere on the third run, my brain misfires a familiar pattern: a sixteenth-note off-beat where I normally slide my heel back in a baby backslide, that beautiful ghost walk we all learn behind grocery stores. The choreography here calls for a step-ball-change standard, weight over midfoot, no drag. My heel skates backward a half inch. The sound is a whisper. It pulls me into my own dance for an instant—a glitch, a glimpse of home. The fan slams shut so sharp it echoes. “Stop.” Han walks into our formation, slicing between lines. This time they do touch, two fingers under my sternum, a pressure reminding me to knit my ribs in. “You,” they say, “you are trying to keep this—” tap tap, my sternum, “—while you do this. You cannot. You will choose.” My heart, traitor, tries to jump into their hand for a second. I breathe it back. “What if this is the only way I know how to choose,” I say. It comes out softer than I mean, less South Side, more someone approaching a border crossing with no papers. Han’s mouth twitches, not a smile. “Then learn another way.” They step back. “Again from chorus. All eyes on him.” The pressure is hot and public. The count begins. I choose: I lock every joint the way they want. My body becomes a series of right angles and straight lines, the grooves shaved down, the flavor resealed in a jar. The wheels of the choreography hum under me. The eight counts line up in the mirror like soldiers in drill. It feels like holding my breath under a long tunnel; the other end shines, and the cars on either side blur. When the chorus ends, and we hit the final hold—left arm high, right at chest level, right foot pointed but grounded, chin one inch down—I’m in exactly the right place. I know it before anyone tells me because the room clicks, a sound like twenty-two exhalations choosing now. The fan pops shut once like a conductor’s baton on the podium. “Yes,” Han says. “Again.” We run it two more times. I’m compliant. I am the academy version of myself, as close as I can get in an afternoon without bleeding. But between four and five of the last eight, a tiny tremor runs through my right hand. It’s not fatigue. It’s something moving in the jar. The assistant starts the music again, but Han holds up the fan. “Break.” The word hangs there. People drop to the floor, stretch, sip water, check their phones. My calves buzz. My joints hum like neon. I walk to the corner where my bag leans against the barre. Outside, the city is something I can’t read yet—all square glass and polite silence. Inside, my sweat dries to salt. I look at myself in the mirror: a kid from a rough block in a room where everybody hides how easy it is for them. My reflection shifts, a fraction of an inch forward and back as I breathe. It looks like a nod. This is the decision, and it surprises me because it doesn’t feel dramatic. It’s not rebel or conform. It’s when to choose which, and how much without breaking the bones that hold me up. I think about the Metra rattling past my bedroom window at night, how you learn to sleep between the clacks. I think about how I shaved edges off my footwork to battle on slippery floors, how I softened elbows to keep from breaking fingers in crowded circles. Adaptation didn’t steal anything; it just hid it until the floor asked for it. Han appears in the mirror next to me, not looking directly at me. The fan is closed, the rounded edge tapping their leg. “You have something,” they say. “Raw is not a compliment here. Raw is a start. Do you want to be rebuilt?” I meet my own eyes in the mirror, not theirs. My right hand opens and closes once, checking the tremor. The beat in my head, my beat, counts off without music: one-and, two-and, three-and. “Yes,” I say. “But I want to keep my screws. You can tighten them. Don’t replace them.” Han’s reflection lifts an eyebrow. “We will see,” they say. They flick the fan open. “Places.” We file back to lines. I set my foot on the tape, heel exactly on the edge, toes forward. The counts start. And as the grid drops onto me again, as my body slices into their clean air, I make a small space inside the lock where my breath can be a little off, a secret syncopation only I can hear, a promise jarred and sealed for later. I hit each mark. I place, not paint. But I am keeping a color hidden in the brush.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative successfully captures the experience of a street dancer from a rough neighborhood struggling to adapt to the rigid discipline of a K-pop training academy. The piece excels in its physical specificity, tracking movements with precision while maintaining the emotional and cultural tensions at the heart of the prompt. The writing demonstrates exceptional kinesthetic awareness, describing dance movements with technical accuracy while maintaining readability. The contrast between the narrator's fluid street style and the academy's mechanical precision is vividly portrayed through specific physical descriptions: "My forearm wants to curve, to melt; muscle memory from church basements and blacktops pulls me into a groove, a glide that eats the spaces between the sixteenth notes. Here they want space like negative sculpture: no path, only arrival points." The physical coherence is maintained throughout, with careful attention to spatial relationships, body positioning, and the technical terminology of both street and commercial dance styles. The writer effectively uses dance-specific language like "chaîné," "top-rock bounce," "tutting squares," and "baby backslide" to establish authenticity. The internal monologue successfully conveys the narrator's culture shock and class anxiety. Small details like the contrast between the other dancers' "skin creams [that] smell like lavender" and the narrator smelling "like train grease and frankincense from my auntie's house" effectively establish the class divide. The protagonist's fear of losing their authentic movement voice is palpable: "Flavor is how we survive bad speakers, power cuts, cops driving by too slow. Flavor is the difference between staying and being dragged." The piece builds to a nuanced decision point rather than a simplistic rebel-or-conform choice. The protagonist's realization that "It's not rebel or conform. It's when to choose which, and how much without breaking the bones that hold me up" demonstrates psychological complexity. The ending strikes a delicate balance, with the narrator outwardly conforming while "keeping a color hidden in the brush" – maintaining their authentic self within the constraints of the new environment. The prose is elegant and controlled, with effective use of metaphor and sensory detail. The rhythm of the writing itself mirrors the dance being described, with short, staccato sentences for precise movements and longer, flowing sentences for the narrator's internal reflections. A few minor weaknesses: occasionally the technical dance terminology might be challenging for readers unfamiliar with dance, and there are moments where the metaphors become slightly overwrought ("The room wants a slot change in a vacuum"). However, these are minor issues in an otherwise exceptional piece. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Gothic-fantasy-humour: Court of the Dreaming — Score: 94.3
Prompt:
Court of the Dreaming: Territorial Dream Dispute. Write a dark fantasy scene with comedic elements set in the Courts of Dream where a case is being heard to determine ownership of a contested dreamscape. Mora, the Slavic nightmare spirit who sits on sleepers' chests causing paralysis and terror, has recently invaded and subverted a carefully crafted recurring dream of a schoolboy, Max. The dream originally featured the boy lying in a field of wildflowers with his crush, always culminating in a muddled almost-kiss and a pleasant confusion of emotions. This dream was the meticulous work of "First Love" (a rosy-cheeked, slightly bashful entity who crafts formative romantic experiences). However, Mora has recently infiltrated the dreamscape, transforming the scene so that when the girl playfully mounts the boy, she morphs into a terrifying yet somehow still confusingly attractive vision who proceeds to sit on his chest and feed on his breath. Mora's defense largely consists of the practical argument that "a girl's gotta eat too, you know?" Write this scene as it unfolds in the courtroom of the Dreaming, with Dream's demeanour, typically impenetrable, betraying a sense of irritation at having to adjudicate such matters. The comedy should derive from the farcical situation, familiar elements of courtroom drama intersecting with the fantastical world of the Dreaming, and the droll portrayal of the characters and their interactions. The humor should be dark and understated throughout. Dream is tempted to some mischief in the resolution of the case. Use descriptives sparingly when setting scene. Write for readability & engagement. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The gavel is a metronome made from a child’s lost tooth and a twig. It clicks once, and the great chamber of the Court of the Dreaming exhales—benches creak like forest boughs, the gallery of drowsing jurors stirs, and a hush arranges itself upon velvet scaffolding suspended over nothing. The judge’s throne is a negative space shaped like expectation. In it sits Dream, expression blank as a closed door, eyes full of stars that know better than to fall. The bailiff, a headless suit of moth-eaten upholstery with a bell where the mouth should be, inhales a lungful of silence and bellows: “Oyez! Oyez! The Court of the Dreaming is now in session. The matter of Domain Disputation: Max-and-the-Nearly-Kiss v. Consumer—con-som-nom—con—Mora.” “Mora,” the defendant purrs, rising without needing to. Her dress is a nightfall stitched with frost, and she wears the easy smirk of a cat who knows which windows don’t latch. Her hair curls like smoke from a candle snuffed between fingers. Opposite her stands the complainant, “First Love,” blushing in gradients, daisies woven through their hair. They clutch a folder that leaks the scent of pencil erasers and clean laundry. When they speak, it sounds like someone clearing their throat before a confession they hope goes well. Dream lifts the tooth-and-twig gavel. His voice makes the air behave. “We will dispense with ceremony. Territory of dream is at issue. Numbers—” “Exhibits,” murmurs the court scribe, a quill writing by itself on a sheet of fog. “—exhibits will be reviewed in order.” “Calling to the not-stand the witnesses,” booms the bailiff. “Maximilian… Ma… Maaaaxmillipede.” A boy steps forward from a pew that resembles a line in a notebook. His pajamas drip grass stains that won’t exist in the morning. He stares at his sneakers, which have never been this clean outside of dreams. He looks twelve, but in the way that twelve contains the vapor trail of thirteen. “And…” the bailiff rattles, “the subject known as Eliza—Elixir—Elizth—Girl.” From a flutter of paper cranes, she appears, the girl from the field of wildflowers. She has a sunburn where a sun never rose. She’s more idea than person here, but an idea with very specific freckles. “Objections?” Dream asks, and no one dares. He gestures with a finger as thin as ink. “Proceed.” First Love clears their throat. “Your Honor, the dream in question is one I curated across eight and a half sequences. The boy, Max, lies among lupine and cornflower, the girl beside him. They discuss homework, the idea of kissing, whether ketchup is a smoothie. They almost—” First Love’s cheeks redden to a dangerous hue— “almost kiss. The moment is unspecific by design. It is a first attempt at mystery.” Mora files a nail with a sliver of midnight. “And then I improved it.” “The improvement,” First Love says, “consisted of sitting on the boy’s chest.” “I am a traditionalist,” Mora replies. “Also: a girl’s gotta eat too, you know?” She spreads her hands, palms pale as milk at moonrise. “I could go after anxious adults, but have you seen the cholesterol?” In the gallery, a gaggle of insomniacs cough into their hands and pretend not to be present. A mare with black foam at its lips stamps on a sigh. Dream’s eyes narrow in the specific way that means the stars inside them have opinions. “Let the facts be arranged.” The quill drags an ink line across fog: Exhibit A rises. A diorama unfolds midair—a field of improbable flowers, Max and Girl lying shoulder to shoulder. Their conversation plays back as overlapping whispers: “Do you think bees know their names?” “I think kissing is like tapping two phones together.” “My heart feels like homework I forgot to do, but in a good way.” Exhibit B blossoms, and the color leaches out. The Girl straddles Max. Her smile lengthens into something too many teeth wide and yet—Max’s ears go a little pink. The figure on his chest tilts her head. The scene stylizes into wet brushstrokes, breaths fogging, the weight a hammer, the fear a string pulled taut. Dream’s mouth sets flat. “Integration of nightmare vector detected,” he says. The words file themselves in triplicate. “Your Honor,” First Love says, hands making a little nest for their next sentence, “I do not deny the place of terror in the Dreaming. But Max’s dream was under my patronage. Adolescence is confusing, but it need not be devouring.” Mora clicks her tongue. “Adolescence is devouring by definition. Also, jurisdiction in the Dreaming is fluid. He was on his back, heart up, eyes wide. That’s my doorbell.” The bailiff lifts his headless head. “Ob-jerky-tion sustained? Overcast? I forget.” “We will sustain nothing yet,” Dream says, with a tiredness so old it comes around to newborn again. “Maximilian.” Max flinches at the full name. “It’s Max,” he says, then glances up at the judge and amends, “Your Honor Sir Dream… Mr. Dream? Uh.” In the gallery, a few nightmares snicker and are immediately smothered by pillows that did not exist a moment ago. Dream inclines his head the width of a shadow. “Max. Tell the Court the shape of your experience.” Max scuffs the dream floor. “It was, like, good. The first kind. My stomach felt like when you go down a hill on a bike you’re not supposed to. And then lately, it’s like the hill keeps going and I can’t stop, and I can’t move. And she—” He flicks his eyes to the Girl, then back to his shoes. “She looks like her and not-her at the same time. It’s scary. But also…” He reddens dreadfully. “I mean, my brain won’t stop being my brain.” “So there is attraction,” Mora says, bright with triumph. “And fear. Two cheeks of the same face. I am artisanal in my pairings.” First Love presses palm to sternum. “You are taking a taste that shall sour him on sweetness.” The Girl’s hand goes up timidly. Dream gestures. She stands, feet not quite touching the floor, voice soft as a folded note. “In the dream, I want to kiss him. And then I want to climb on top because the grass is wet and my jeans are expensive. And then—someone else is there too. It feels like being told how to feel. It’s loud.” “Ah,” Dream murmurs, the kind of sound judges make when they have always known the truth and are inconvenienced by hearing it aloud. He turns to Mora. “You fed.” “A little,” she says. “Enough to keep my nails shiny. I did not empty him. I am not a monster.” She winks at Max, and his breath fogs in his own throat. First Love flips through their file. A Polaroid flutters out—a shot of a sunset that never was, a kiss that never quite happened, perfect. “He needs this,” they say, voice so earnest the courtroom momentarily smells like rain on chalk. “Question for the Court!” cries a nightmare shaped like a geometry problem. “Isn’t it precedent that nightmares may cross-pollinate with developmental dreams, subsection Pubertatis, clause ‘We all did weird things at twelve’?” The scribe rustles. “Cited: The Case of Locker Room Teeth v. Homecoming Crown. Verdict: mixed custody, alternating Tuesdays.” Dream rubs two fingers together, and the ghoul of a yawn slinks under the benches. His expression shifts in micrometers—irritation slipping through the seams of implacable. This is the tenth dispute this night and the seventh in which a party has said “a girl’s gotta eat.” He leans forward, and the chamber tilts toward him. “Mora. Would you sit on him if he were not sweet?” Mora considers, gaze flicking over Max like a tongue over a toothache. “No,” she concedes. “The sweet ones dream with their chests open. It’s efficient.” “And First Love, if he were not frightened, would you persist?” First Love flinches as though accused of theft. “Yes. Fear is part of firsts. But not paralysis. Not the kind that makes your lungs count stones.” Dream closes his eyes. When they open, a new galaxy whirs inside them, irritated and perhaps slightly amused. “The Dreaming is not a buffet. Nor is it a monastery. Domain is not ownership. It is stewardship.” He taps the gavel. Time hiccups politely. “Ruling,” he says, and the word hangs in the air like a cold bell. “The field remains under First Love’s curatorship. The nearly-kiss shall occur, shall fail, shall ripple hope through the boy like heat through cold hands. Mora, you may approach, but not alight. You may be the breeze that cools a sweaty palm, the shadow that makes the sun more precious, the almost-thought that makes the heart race. You may not sit upon his chest. If you hunger, you shall feed from those who invite you—” Mora’s brows arc. “And who would—” “—such as the fifty-year-old who insists on eating cheese before bed to conjure you, and the poet who drinks black coffee at 2 a.m. because he thinks it makes his lines more honest.” A pair of hands in the gallery clap guiltily and stop. Mora pouts. “You would have me starve on art and dairy.” Dream’s mouth nearly, almost curls. “Art and dairy are plentiful.” The bailiff raises a sleeve. “What of en-force-ment? Con—conductification?” “Sanctions,” Dream says, voice dry as a salted cracker. “Should Mora sit again upon the boy’s chest without warrant, her own dreams shall be made subject to First Love for one cycle.” Mora stills. “You wouldn’t.” Dream’s gaze is abyssal. “Imagine, nightmare, a bloom in your ribs. A blush on your centuries. Someone carving your name into a bench and then walking past, never sitting. Breathing that catches not in terror, but in hope. It is not lethal, but it is… inconvenient.” Mora shudders. “Cruel.” “Instructive,” Dream replies. “Max.” The boy looks up. “You will wake with muscle-memory of the field. A laugh you cannot place will snag in your throat at lunch. The fear will not return tonight. It may return later, in another shape, and you will be larger then.” Max nods. He doesn’t understand, which is exactly right for now. “Girl,” Dream says, gentler. “Your jeans will remain unsullied. You may tell him about the bees.” She smiles, and two of her freckles change places, giddy. First Love glows with relief so pure the daisies in their hair open and close in applause. They bow. “Thank you, Your Honor.” Mora rolls her eyes, but there is a grin there too, sharp as a crescent. “Fine. I’ll nibble on artisans and dairy-men. But if the boy starts sleeping on his back—” “Then he has been warned,” Dream says, as though warnings were his favorite candy. He lifts the gavel. The courtroom hums. He hesitates a beat, mischief lighting him from within. “One addendum.” Mora leans in, wary. First Love straightens. “In the field,” Dream says, “the nearly-kiss may, on one statistically unlikely night, be an actual kiss. Neither of you will know which night. This uncertainty will feed you both.” Mora blinks. First Love gasps. Somewhere, the scribe writes exclamation points with great dignity. “Court is adjourned,” Dream says, and brings the tooth and twig down. The sound is a soft click, like a lock turning in a door. The world folds. Benches become tall grass. The jurors yawn themselves into lint. Max and the Girl blur back to future memory. Mora lingers, making a moue at Dream’s throne. “You are capricious,” she says. “Occasionally,” he allows. “It suits you,” she says, and the compliment hangs between them like a spider’s staircase, delicate, predatory, true. The bailiff’s bell-mouth booms one last time: “All rise for The Lord of Dreams, a.k.a. The Magni—Magnesium—Majesty.” Dream does not rise. He dissolves, like a held breath released. The courtroom empties itself, like a chest relieved of weight. In a suburb, a boy turns in his sleep, his hands finding, without thinking, the exact right place to rest—on his own ribs, protecting something delicate and ridiculous. Above, in the long hallway of the Dreaming, a nightmare and an awkward tenderness pass each other like ships at dusk, and neither admits they looked back.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece is a remarkable example of dark fantasy with comedic elements, set in the Court of the Dreaming. The author has crafted a world that feels both familiar and alien, drawing on courtroom drama tropes while infusing them with dreamlike surrealism. The writing demonstrates exceptional control of language. The prose is elegant without becoming overwrought, with descriptions that are evocative yet economical: "Her dress is a nightfall stitched with frost, and she wears the easy smirk of a cat who knows which windows don't latch." The author uses metaphor and simile to great effect, creating vivid imagery that enhances rather than distracts from the narrative. Character development is nuanced and effective. Dream is portrayed with appropriate gravitas and subtle irritation, maintaining his canonical demeanor while showing glimpses of mischief. Mora and First Love are well-realized opposites, each with clear motivations and distinctive voices. Even minor characters like Max and the Girl have depth and agency within their limited roles. The dialogue is particularly strong, revealing character while advancing the plot. Each entity speaks in a distinctive voice that reflects their nature: Mora's predatory playfulness, First Love's earnest concern, Dream's measured authority, and Max's adolescent awkwardness. The humor is dark and understated as requested, arising naturally from the situation rather than forced jokes. The comedic elements—like the bailiff's struggle with names, the insomniacs pretending not to be present, and Mora's practical approach to feeding—are woven seamlessly into the narrative. The pacing is excellent, with the courtroom drama unfolding at a satisfying rate. The resolution is clever and fitting, with Dream's judgment showing both wisdom and mischief. The ending avoids both saccharine positivity and unearned darkness, instead finding a balanced resolution that honors the complexity of the situation. If there are any weaknesses, they are minor. Occasionally, a metaphor might be slightly overextended, but these moments are rare and don't detract significantly from the overall quality. The piece successfully balances the fantastical elements with relatable emotional stakes, creating a story that is both otherworldly and resonant. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20 Elegant Prose: 19 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 2 Weak Dialogue: 1 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 1 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 20 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20.0, Elegant Prose: 19.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 2.0, Weak Dialogue: 1.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 1.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 20.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Fanfic-crossover: Blood Moon — Score: 89.5
Prompt:
Blood Moon Alucard & Yennefer Write a story where Alucard (Hellsing) encounters Yennefer (The Witcher) in medieval Europe. Yennefer's magical abilities intrigue the vampire, while she's both repulsed and fascinated by his monstrous nature. Their power dynamic shifts constantly as they circle each other, neither willing to show weakness first. **Alucard (Hellsing)** Alucard is an ancient, immensely powerful vampire who works for the Hellsing Organization. He can regenerate from almost any wound and shape-shift at will. He's sadistic, arrogant, and takes pleasure in toying with his enemies before killing them. Despite being a monster, he despises weak vampires who can't accept their nature. He wears a distinctive red coat, wide-brimmed hat, and orange sunglasses. He uses massive handguns loaded with silver bullets. He seeks worthy opponents who can challenge him and potentially end his immortal existence. Famous quote: "The bird of Hermes is my name, eating my wings to make me tame." **Yennefer of Vengerberg (The Witcher)** Yennefer is a powerful sorceress who magically altered her appearance to hide her congenital hunchback. She's ambitious, stubborn, and manipulative when necessary. She has violet eyes and smells of lilac and gooseberries. Despite her cold exterior, she desperately wants to reverse her infertility caused by magical transformation. She's centuries old but appears young. She's politically savvy and refuses to be underestimated. She has a sarcastic sense of humor and little patience for fools. Though she rarely shows it, she's capable of deep love and loyalty. Famous quote: "I'm not sweet and I'm not a maiden in distress in need of saving." Third person, present tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The wolves start first—one voice, then three, then none, then too many. The sound rides the wind through broken orchards and burnt stubble fields, combing the haystacks and rattling the shutters. It reaches a town that no map cares to name, empty save for a church spire and a tavern with a warped sign. The night is a dark loam, rich and heavy. Clouds wreathe the moon and peel away like skin. The wolves announce and re-announce themselves, never keeping time, as if the forest itself is learning how to speak. Alucard hears them the way a shark senses blood. Each voice is a pinprick of humor; this land has a flair for dramatics. He steps from a copse of trees and lets the long grass stroke the red of his coat. Mud sucks at his boots, but he leaves no prints. His hat is a black hole against the sky. When lightning tickles the top of the church spire in the distance, he tips his head, amused. He has walked through a hundred Europes salted with fear and faith. This one, tucked between centuries, tastes of both. He carries his handguns—one black, one steel—like ornaments. The silver in them purrs, hungry and useless against him. He does not come to hunt; he comes because something moves through this country that is not peasant superstition or drunk priestly rumor. He comes because a tremor went through the web of the world, and it resonated with the old, starving part of him that calls itself curious rather than lonely. Yennefer smells him before she sees him, which offends her. Not the scent—there’s little of decay, less of earth, more of iron and smoke. But that she senses him at all as a scent. It pricks memory: caves and old texts, mage councils, huntsmen returning with stories of men without reflections. She is on the road for her own purpose, and has no patience for a legend begging to be confirmed. Still, she is not foolish enough to walk past a door slightly ajar without peeking through. She steps into the same field from the opposite hedgerow, the hem of her black dress brushing thistle and rain-silvered nettle. The air shifts to accommodate her; it takes a breath and forgets, briefly, to exhale. Lilac and gooseberries push through the mud smell. The wolves falter, then continue their started symphony. She pulls up her hood, violet eyes glimmering in the dark like cut amethyst. Her fingers flex at her sides, rings whispering. He doesn’t turn, but his grin flashes like a blade. “Ah,” he says to the wind. “It was not just a tremor. It was the earth stretching.” “And the corpse crawls to watch,” Yennefer replies, and the wind carries the words between them. She favors talk as a weapon and a mask; it is cheaper than fire and more subtle than frost. Alucard pivots, coat fluttering. The hat’s brim cuts a clean line through fog. His orange lenses catch what little light there is and hoard it. He bows, elaborate and mocking. “Alucard,” he says, as though it is a polite introduction and not an old curse. “The bird of Hermes is my name, eating my wings to make me tame.” “Yennefer of Vengerberg,” she says, not bowing. “I’m not sweet and I’m not a maiden in distress in need of saving.” She does not give him the satisfaction of a smile. “Pity.” He takes a step forward and sinks a fraction of an inch into the earth and becomes thinner for it, like a lost shadow finding the ground again. “You move the world when you walk. A witch? No, that is too rustic a word. Sorceress?” “Magician,” she says, just to watch the word sit wrong in his mouth. “And you are... not of this century.” “I am of all of them,” he says, and it is less boast than admission. “You made quite a noise, little immortal.” Her jaw ticks. “Words like that have costs,” she says. “And for the last time, I am not little.” “Noted,” he says, gloved fingers opening as if to measure her by palmlength. “But immortal. I can smell the chemistry that stole your cradle.” She refuses the flinch that his accuracy requests. “You can smell nothing you can’t imagine. And you have no imagination. Monsters rarely do.” He laughs, sharp and unkind. “I’ve outlived poets and their delusions. I’ve seen castles kneel to cannons and gods whimper in gutters. Do not accuse me of lacking imagination; I am its hangman.” He tilts his head. “And you’ve carved yourself into an idea. It looks good on you.” She thinks, as she often does when men say such things, of chains turned into necklace and nails lacquered black to hide the soil beneath. “You’re a talkative ghoul.” He points, not at her but beyond her, toward the meager town. “I followed the scent of something dying badly. Not you. Something else.” The wolves choose that moment to harmonize into cacophony and then break apart again, as if the pack cannot decide whether to sing or sob. “There is a thing,” Yennefer says, because withholding everything is not strategy; it’s vanity. “It feeds without hunger. It crawled here from someplace that forgot to close its door. The villagers tried a shrine. Then they tried pitchforks. It liked both.” “You tried neither,” he says. “Why would I?” Yennefer lifts a shoulder. “If a wound wants to suppurate, sometimes you let it, to watch what it drains. But it began to pull at the lines. Blink hard and the moon stutters. I don’t tolerate that kind of arrogance.” “Ah,” Alucard says. “You and I share a dislike for competitors.” “I have no competitors,” she says, and the frost on the grass next to her retreats two inches, begrudging the admission warmth. He smiles. “Shall we kill it?” She wants to say no. She wants to say that she does not hunt with dogs. She wants to say many things. What she says is, “We’ll see.” They walk toward the town together, not side by side. He drifts forward and back, his coat swaying as if in water. She strides, each step a percussion note. The tavern’s sign—something once painted with pride, perhaps a stag—clacks against its chain in the unsettled air. The church door is closed, but the latch clicks, clicks, clicks like a nail being tapped by a bored god. In the square, the well has gone wrong. The stones around it bulge, breathing. A darkness hums there, not absence but glut. Someone’s ribbon floats, blue turned black in the night. The wolves fall silent, every one of them, as if a conductor lowered his arms. Yennefer lifts a hand. The pressure in the air changes; the well’s shadow thickens, then thins. It resists with the stupidity of anything powerful enough to be arrogant. Alucard is already moving, the edges of him unhooking. His legs soften into something sinuous; his coat becomes wings with feathers made of night birds. Teeth flower in his grin like white roses blooming too fast. “Don’t,” Yennefer says, barely turning her head. “Unless you know how to pull without unraveling.” “What a charming way to say ‘please wait,’” he says. He stops anyway. Their power touches like cats: back arched, fur raised, neither willing to be the first to settle. She speaks a word that is not a word, a curl of old language learned in a school that trains girls to kill their pasts. Threads show themselves to her sight, filaments of something raw and glistening, tying the well to the spire and the wolves to the road and the moon to its own reflection in a puddle. Her mouth tastes of copper. She plucks one thread and hears a laugh that is not human. Alucard’s hand closes around the steel handgun; silver gets eager. “You’ll irritate it,” he says. “I’ll flatter it,” she counters. “Everything that feeds wants to be believed.” “Do you?” She ignores him. The darkness at the well rises, substantial, a spill made vertical. It projects a face because faces are what prey understands. The face is a blur—wrong eyes, wrong mouth—like a charcoal portrait ruined by water. It speaks without sound; she hears a suggestion to give, to pour, to loosen. It remembers her, in the way that parasites remember the first skin. Under her feet, the well stones exhale. Alucard fires. The crack folds the square in half. The silver bullet hisses through the rising dark and buries in the church door beyond, punching it like a fist through paper. The thing jerks, astonished by pain. It looks at him, and a vertical pupil duplicates itself, multiplying until the night is full of terrible eyes. “Impolite,” Yennefer says. “I prefer to open the ball,” he says. He steps forward and the edges of him become dogs, mouths, a swarm of red eyes. “Dance with me.” She does not smile, but something in her posture loosens into delight. She cuts the air. The threads scream. The darkness tries to spread; she tightens. He wades into it, teeth and hat and coat, a grave made ambulatory, and tears pieces off that dissolve back into black. It is sloppy, joyous work. He laughs like a bell tolling for the end of a world. She keeps the limits—hem, seam, border—tight with mathematics and will. Together, by luck or design, he is the blade and she the sheath, containing the cut. The wolves attempt a chorus and fail, their howls scattering like cards. The moon slides into and out of a cloud and finds itself bleeding at the edges. The thing sends a tendril for Alucard’s face, wanting to wear him. He lets it. It slithers over his lenses and into the bone around his eye, testing him like a tongue. He does not flinch. He opens his mouth wide enough to suggest a misunderstanding of anatomy and bites the tendril in half. It shrieks in a register that turns Yennefer’s vision to static. She answers by burning its thread with a heat that remembers volcanoes. The square stinks of ruin and rain. “Stop toying,” she says, voice raw. “You say that as if it is not the point,” he says, spitting shadow like wine. But he obeys. He reaches, not with hands but with everything that he has become and has been, and seizes the thing where its lie is weakest. “You are not hunger,” he says, as if telling a child its name. “You are appetite with no art.” He drags it into shape. Yennefer—who understands better than most that names nail things in place—whispers a binding around the shape he insists on. It is ugly: a man too tall, knees bending wrong, mouth stitched with light that leaks. Shape hurts it. It cannot hide in ambiguity when they pin it to a body. Shape makes it killable. Alucard looks back at her, teeth bright. “Now?” She nods, and for a heartbeat the night is a pact between monsters. He puts the gun to the thing’s forehead as if posing it for a portrait. She tightens every thread until there is nothing left to slip through. Together, they fire—silver and spell. The head goes first, then the torso, then the idea of it. The well exhales and becomes, with relief, only a well. Silence unscrews itself like a top. Then the wolves, off in pieces of forest, remember their lesson and howl again, out of sequence, too early, too late. The church door lists. Yennefer’s knees ache. She refuses to show it. Alucard straightens, hat settling. He is a man again, if he ever was. He rolls his shoulders as if shedding someone else’s coat. “You hold the world like a lover,” he says. “And you bite it like an apple.” She wipes blood from her lip with a sleeve that refuses to stain. Her perfume is stronger now, as if exertion wrung it out of her. “You nearly let it take your eye.” “I wanted to see if it could.” He shrugs. “Disappointment keeps me honest.” “Honesty doesn’t suit you.” He laughs. It sounds less like a bell now and more like a window breaking somewhere cozy. He considers the well, then her, as if weighing which one is more dangerous. “You would make a superb vampire.” “I would make a terrible anything I didn’t choose,” she says. “And I’ve chosen enough.” “Ah.” He nods solemnly, mockery softened into respect. “So have I.” A wind stirs the ribbon near the well. It is blue again in the moonlight. The tavern sign sighs. The wolves tangle and untangle their song. Yennefer looks at the church and thinks, with annoyance, of villagers who will come back and call this a miracle performed by the virgin and not by a woman with burn marks on her throat and a man with a smile too wide. “They’ll rebuild,” she says. “They always do.” “They always forget,” he says. She considers him, the way hunger and performance and old hurt have arranged themselves in red cloth and tooth. He considers her, the way ambition and tenderness and scar tissue have been tailored into beauty cruel enough to be honest. The power between them, briefly, goes slack. “I should go,” she says. “There are threads to unpick elsewhere.” She does not say what they are. She will not say, to anyone, the word child. She will not ever say the word mother as something to be regained. “And I,” he says, “have a flock to terrify.” He tips his hat. “If you wish to be found, you will be. If you wish to be lost, you will be.” He smiles. “We are both good at both.” “Stay out of my way,” she says, and then generously, “or at least be interesting when you’re not.” “I am always interesting,” he says, affronted, which amuses her more than it should. She turns. The field greets her with a hush, then the whisper of grass on hem. The air closes around the space she vacates. He watches her go, not because he is a man who watches women walk away, but because she is a force and forces are, in their own way, beautiful in motion. The wolves take up their strange chorus again, staggering and overlapping until the night sounds like a throat clearing itself. The moon rides the clearing clouds, huge and red, a wound and a promise. Alucard takes off his hat and lets the light paint his face. He says, to no one and to the memory of the fight, “The bird of Hermes is my name, eating my wings to make me tame.” It is neither prayer nor curse. It is a reminder. In the distance, Yennefer pauses, as if she hears, and does not look back. She has no patience for souvenirs. He puts his hat on, melts into the trees, and the wolves mis-time their goodnights into her silence and his.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully creates a compelling encounter between Alucard from Hellsing and Yennefer from The Witcher, capturing both characters' essence while placing them in a medieval European setting. The writer demonstrates exceptional skill in atmospheric prose, creating a rich, gothic ambiance that suits both characters perfectly. The characterization is remarkably faithful to the source material. Alucard's sadistic playfulness, arrogance, and monstrous nature are well-portrayed through his dialogue and actions. His shape-shifting abilities and casual attitude toward violence reflect his character from Hellsing. Similarly, Yennefer's stubborn pride, magical prowess, and cold exterior hiding deeper motivations are excellently rendered. The subtle reference to her infertility ("She will not say, to anyone, the word child. She will not ever say the word mother as something to be regained.") shows a nuanced understanding of her character. The prose is highly stylized and poetic, with vivid imagery that creates a sensory experience. Lines like "The night is a dark loam, rich and heavy" and "Clouds wreathe the moon and peel away like skin" establish the gothic atmosphere effectively. However, at times the writing becomes slightly overwrought, with metaphors piled upon metaphors that occasionally obscure rather than illuminate. The dialogue is exceptional, capturing both characters' distinctive voices. Their verbal sparring demonstrates their power dynamic perfectly - neither willing to show weakness, both respecting the other's power while maintaining their pride. The incorporation of their famous quotes feels natural rather than forced. The plot structure works well, giving the characters a common enemy to face while allowing their interaction to be the true focus. Their cooperation against the well-creature showcases both their abilities and their contrasting approaches to power. The action sequence is well-executed, balancing Alucard's violent approach with Yennefer's more calculated magical strategy. The ending avoids cliché by neither forcing them into conflict nor creating an unearned alliance. Instead, it respects both characters' independence while acknowledging their mutual recognition of each other's power. Some minor weaknesses include occasional passages where the metaphorical language becomes too dense, potentially confusing readers. The nature of the antagonist remains somewhat vague, which may be intentional but leaves some aspects of the conflict underdeveloped. Overall, this is an exceptionally well-crafted piece that demonstrates a deep understanding of both characters and skillfully places them in a shared context that honors their respective universes while creating something new. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Fanfic-crossover: Prison Strings — Score: 89.3
Prompt:
Prison Strings Jolyne Cujoh & Makima Write a story where Jolyne Cujoh (JoJo's Bizarre Adventure) and Makima (Chainsaw Man) cross paths at a supernatural prison facility. Jolyne is immediately suspicious of Makima's falsely sweet demeanor, while Makima is intrigued by Jolyne's Stand ability. Their battle of wits escalates dangerously as Jolyne realizes how manipulative Makima truly is. **Jolyne Cujoh (JoJo's Bizarre Adventure)** Jolyne is the daughter of Jotaro Kujo and the first female JoJo protagonist. Her Stand, Stone Free, allows her to unravel her body into string that she can control. She's hot-headed, foul-mouthed, and doesn't take disrespect from anyone. She was framed for murder and sent to prison. She has a distinctive butterfly tattoo on her arm and wears her hair in two buns. Despite her tough exterior, she's deeply loyal to her friends and family. She can be impulsive but is highly adaptable in battle. She inherited her father's ability to stay cool under pressure but is more emotionally expressive. Famous quote: "If there's no Mickey, this shit ain't Disney!" **Makima (Chainsaw Man)** Makima appears as a young woman with auburn hair and ringed yellow eyes. She's the Control Devil who can dominate anyone she considers beneath her (nearly everyone). She maintains a pleasant, soft-spoken demeanor that masks her manipulative, cold nature. She can create contracts with humans and devils, often exploiting their desires. She's obsessed with Chainsaw Man and wants to control him. She keeps numerous people and devils as pets on leashes. She's practically immortal due to a contract with the Prime Minister. She views humans as lesser beings but mimics human emotions perfectly. Famous quote: "It's okay. Dogs are supposed to die for their owners." Third person, present tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The rumor starts as a whisper in the fluorescent hum: the cameras fuzz to snow when she walks by. Jolyne notices it first in the reflection of a Plexiglas shield—one second of static that blooms like a white flower and then collapses, leaving her own face staring back. Two hair buns like horns, a butterfly wing blue-black on her arm. If there's no Mickey, this shit ain't Disney, she thinks, shoving her tray forward in the cafeteria line. This prison is already off. Now it’s getting supernatural in ways that make her skin stand up. The new department—something between wardens and auditors—arrived at dawn with suits and blank faces. They took a wing, set up desks and wires and humming machines, and the rumor followed: the redhead with yellow eyes makes cameras forget what they saw. She enters without a key’s jingle or a door's grunt. She finds Jolyne in the corridor that smells like bleach and mold and old anger. Her hair is auburn, her coat a muted rust. The unmistakable ringed irises pin Jolyne like a pinned butterfly. “Jolyne Cujoh,” the woman says, voice soft as warm milk. “Thank you for waiting.” Jolyne does not remember waiting. She plants a foot, crosses her arms. “I didn’t.” A smile, precise as a scalpel. “I’m Makima. There was a question on your file, and I thought I’d answer it personally.” “My file has questions?” Jolyne’s mouth quirks. Stone Free hums under her skin like a guitar string tuned to a bad note. She’s been framed once; she recognizes strings someone else ties. “What are you, HR?” “Something like that.” Makima steps closer, hands folded like a schoolteacher. The air shifts—something invisible, pressurized. There are guards at the end of the hall, but they’ve turned their heads as if the far wall has become very interesting. The cameras above them blink. The red recording dot dies. Jolyne throws a glance at the lens. “Funny how equipment breaks when you show up.” “Electronics can be temperamental,” Makima says. “People are, too.” Stone Free unspools from Jolyne’s wrist in thin blue lines, a thread so fine it could slip between eyelashes. She keeps it low, in the seam where floor meets wall. She can feel the structure of the corridor through that thin whisper of herself: cracks in the cinderblock, a gum wad hardened under a pipe, the short heartbeat of a hazing fluorescent bulb. The thread curls behind Makima’s heel, a cat’s tail waiting to trip. “Do you always walk into people’s lives and start smiling like you own the lease?” Jolyne asks. “I prefer to think I keep people’s lives tidy.” Makima’s head tilts. It’s a gesture that reads as human, and also as something that learned humanity by watching, purposefully. “You have an unusual power. It must be comforting. To be in pieces and in control of those pieces.” The thread brushes leather. Jolyne twitches it. The heel doesn’t catch. Makima takes another step without looking down. Her shoe dips neatly over the string as if aware of the trap by some sense Jolyne doesn’t have a name for. “You’re a bug,” Jolyne says. “The kind that lands on your soup and pretends it’s flavor.” Makima doesn’t blink. “Words can be so cruel unless they’re on a leash. Who taught you yours?” “My old man,” Jolyne snaps, before she can stop herself. The mention is an offense and an anchor. She hears her father’s voice, sees the silhouette of his hat in her head. Keep your cool, his presence says. Find the angle. But she is not him. She is more, and messier, and her anger comes braided with bright strands of humor. “And he didn’t teach me to heel.” “Fathers are complicated,” Makima says, almost kindly. “Some men try to protect their daughters by leaving them in cages of their own making.” “And some women smile while they slide the latch,” Jolyne replies. The corridor is empty save for them. It is that eerie prison empty, the kind beyond schedules, where time goes thin. Once Jolyne would’ve been afraid of that kind of quiet. Now she listens to it. She hears the whisper in the walls: pipes murmuring, the buzz of the electric fence, the thrum of human bodies moving three floors away. Her strings spider through the cinderblock like veins. “Let’s talk somewhere less public,” Makima says gently. “Come along, please.” The please is a needle. The come along is a pull. It brushes Jolyne’s mind like a hand settling at the back of her neck. Her chin dips before she notices and then it snaps up, muscles locking against the pressure. Heat flashes down her spine. Stone Free flares, and part of her forearm unwinds into a braid tight as a whip. “Don’t,” Jolyne says. She means: don’t touch my head. Don’t touch my will. Makima’s eyes warm as if pleased with a pet refusing a treat for the first time. “Interesting.” “What are you?” Jolyne’s voice is low. Now the humor is gone. “You smell like a trick.” “That’s an unkind way to say ‘public servant,’” Makima answers, stepping into the shade of a doorway. And then, as easy as if she sawed a ribbon, the guard forty feet down the hall lifts his hand and drops his keys on the linoleum. He looks pained, confused. He presses his own thumb until a bead of blood rises and stains the floor. He doesn’t know why he’s doing it; he does it anyway. Jolyne’s lips peel back from her teeth. “You’re going to make me kill you, aren’t you,” she says almost conversationally, because if she says it like weather it won’t be the fear in her chest speaking. “It’s okay,” Makima says. The ringed eyes cut through the air. “Dogs are supposed to die for their owners.” Jolyne laughs, a short ugly sound, because otherwise she’ll be sick. “Newsflash, lady: I bite.” She throws her string. It snaps forward in a glittering line, invisible and then suddenly everywhere—looping, tightening. She wraps a thin garrote around the camera, yanks it to show Makima she sees the game, then lets it fall. Another lash goes for Makima’s wrist. It should have been a perfect wrap: eight-point tie, lock at the metacarpals. The string lands. It is there. And then Makima lifts her hand and nothing is there. The thread hums in Jolyne’s fingers but refuses to bite, as if the air around Makima’s skin is not permissioned for connection. The more she tries to tether Makima, the more she feels her own lines tug at her. Her shoulder jerks. Her hand opens. Makima’s gaze rests on her fingers. Open, it says. Stay. Heel. The words aren’t spoken—but the intent is a leash, slipping slickly around thought. Stone Free surges. Jolyne makes it a roar. She unravels herself up to the elbow, then to the shoulder, body liquefying into strings that snake through the ceiling and the floor. She is a harp in a storm. She anchors to everything: bolt threads, metal piping, the hairline cracks in the paint. She feels herself everywhere and refuses to be centralized enough to be held. Makima’s mouth curves a fraction. She watches Jolyne’s diffusion and catalogs it, an entomologist labeling a specimen. “You’re expanding to avoid control,” she notes. “Adaptable. Sloppy, but effective.” “You sound like a swim coach.” Makima takes one step closer, and everywhere Jolyne’s strings wrap around a structural something, there’s a pressure that says let go. It is polite. It is inexorable. Jolyne feels fibers in her own body tremble. She thinks of her cellmates and allies who look to her because she doesn’t break. She thinks of a father who didn’t say I love you well, but said don’t die with his whole chest. She thinks of the fact that being told to heel makes her see red. “No,” Jolyne says, and the word is a knot. She flips the corridor without moving. She sends string as thin as dust motes into the vents and finds the rust edge of a fan. She coils around it, hard, and yanks. The fan screams. Metal teeth bite concrete. The screech is a slap. Somewhere the fire suppression system thinks of turning on. Makima’s eyes flick up. For the first time, something like annoyance thins her mouth. Not much. Enough that Jolyne learns: noise is not the leash Makima is good at using. This woman is a conductor of people—crowds, guards, the twitching hands that drop keys—and Jolyne is not one person. She is in pieces. She is in the ceiling and the floor. She is an assembly that refuses to stand in a neat line and say yes. “You don’t want to talk,” Makima says. Her voice is still mild. “You want to be messy.” “You don’t want to talk,” Jolyne bites back. “You want me to sit.” Makima studies her. “I don’t have a chair big enough for you,” she says, almost smiling again. “Yet.” Pressure spikes. The guard further down the hall lifts his gun without ever deciding to. He looks terrified as his own finger tightens. Jolyne’s string leaps, wraps the barrel, jerks it sideways. The shot goes into concrete. Shouts start in a wing they haven’t heard from for minutes. The prison wakes. Makima doesn’t look at the guard. She doesn’t need to. She looks at Jolyne. “I can force outcomes,” Makima says. “You can force improvisations. Which of us tires first?” “Lady,” Jolyne says. “I was born tired.” She floods the corridor. She slams all her weight—literal and otherwise—into the sprinkler line above. It bursts. Water comes down like she ordered rain. The overhead light blows with a pop. The world goes strobe and then low. In the chaos of drops and sparks, Jolyne drags the string that brushed Makima’s heel a second ago and ties it off around a pipe bracket. She doesn’t try to bind Makima. She binds the space around her—webbing from lintels to floor drains, a geometry puzzle with one unsolvable angle. Makima takes a step and the world narrows to a choreographed maze. It is respectful in the way a net is respectful. Makima stops. Drops bead in her hair. She blinks water out of her lashes. The ringed eyes look almost human like this. Almost. She lifts her hand toward the guard. He freezes, his face a mask of devotion and terror. His knees bend as if to kneel. He doesn’t because Jolyne’s strings hold his pant leg to a grate. He strains like a dog on a chain. Makima’s hand stays up, and now the chain is on Jolyne’s mind again, a warmth that wants to be obedience. Jolyne closes her eyes. She sees her mother’s kitchen. She sees an ocean from a postcard her father never sent. She sees a butterfly’s wing in a tattoo parlor. She inhales chlorine and grit and the metallic sweetness of blood, and she chooses her own voice over the soft one that says come. “No,” she says again, and the word is bigger than her throat. Makima lowers her hand. The pressure steps back one pace, like a well-trained thing told to wait. “You’re inconvenient,” she says. “Get in line,” Jolyne says. She reels her strings tight. The web sings. The corridor becomes an instrument and she is both musician and chord. Makima turns her head fractionally. The rumor about cameras becomes fact; every lens along the hallway blooms white and dies, then blinks back to black. The red dots don’t come on again. Somewhere, someone will look at the footage and find only static and the sound of rain. “This facility will keep breaking as long as you’re in it,” Makima says, almost to herself. “This facility was broken when it took me,” Jolyne replies. They look at one another through a web and a rain. Two different kinds of monster, two women who have learned to survive cages by making them for others or refusing them entirely. Makima steps backward, her heels finding the single path Jolyne left on purpose without ever admitting it. She could push the issue. She could try to bend Jolyne’s will until it creaked. But Makima likes games. She likes long leashes. She likes to let a dog think it’s running free. “You’ll come see me,” she says mildly. “Later. When you realize I’m the only one here who can guarantee your friends keep breathing.” Jolyne’s jaw tightens. She doesn’t look away. “You’ll see me,” she says. “When you learn I cut leashes.” Makima’s smile is warmer now, a sunrise painted with careful brushstrokes. “I’m looking forward to it.” She walks away. The web sings around her and does not touch her. The cameras are blind. The guard sags as if a string has been cut, then sobs once without sound. Jolyne collects herself from the ceiling and the floor, feeling water drip off her as she winds back into bones and skin. She watches the outline of Makima’s coat turn a corner and vanish, leaving only the rumor of static in the air. For a second the corridor is just a hallway again. Jolyne flexes. The butterfly on her arm seems ready to fly. She shakes water from her hair, a dog refusing a leash, and bares her teeth at the empty space. “If there’s no Mickey,” she mutters to the dead camera, “this shit ain’t Disney.” Then she turns toward the shouts and the friends who will need her, strings humming, ready to tangle with whatever comes next.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively captures a tense confrontation between Jolyne Cujoh and Makima, staying true to both characters' established personalities and abilities. The writer demonstrates a strong understanding of both source materials, weaving together Jolyne's string-based Stand abilities and rebellious nature with Makima's manipulative control powers and falsely sweet demeanor. The prose is particularly strong in its sensory details and metaphorical language. Descriptions like "The rumor starts as a whisper in the fluorescent hum: the cameras fuzz to snow when she walks by" immediately establish an ominous atmosphere. The writer skillfully uses prison imagery—fluorescent lights, Plexiglas, cinderblock walls—to ground the supernatural confrontation in a tangible setting. Character voices are distinct and authentic. Jolyne's internal thoughts ("If there's no Mickey, this shit ain't Disney") and dialogue maintain her canonical foul-mouthed, defiant personality. Makima's soft-spoken yet threatening demeanor is captured perfectly in lines like "It's okay. Dogs are supposed to die for their owners." The writer understands the psychological dynamics between these characters, with Jolyne's resistance to authority clashing against Makima's need for control. The battle of wits unfolds organically through both dialogue and action. Rather than relying on exposition, the writer shows the escalating tension through Jolyne's strategic use of her strings and Makima's subtle manipulation of the guard. The physical confrontation mirrors their psychological one, with Jolyne refusing to be "centralized enough to be held" while Makima attempts to exert her control. The piece avoids common pitfalls of crossover fiction. It doesn't force unnatural friendship or romance between the characters, nor does it make one character unrealistically dominant over the other. Instead, it presents a nuanced standoff where both demonstrate their strengths and vulnerabilities. The ending leaves their conflict unresolved but establishes clear stakes for future confrontation. Some minor weaknesses include occasional overreliance on metaphor ("She is a harp in a storm") and a few instances where the action becomes slightly difficult to follow due to the abstract nature of Jolyne's string abilities. However, these are minor issues in an otherwise excellent piece. The story maintains thematic coherence throughout, exploring ideas of control, freedom, and resistance to authority that are central to both characters' source materials. The final confrontation, where Jolyne refuses Makima's control while acknowledging they'll meet again, provides a satisfying conclusion while leaving room for future conflict. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Scp: Notes from the Future — Score: 92.0
Prompt:
Write an SCP report about a researcher who begins finding handwritten notes from their future self, warning about a containment breach that hasn't happened yet. The notes become increasingly desperate and incoherent, sometimes containing information that contradicts known reality. Include the Foundation's attempts to determine if this is an actual temporal anomaly or psychological manipulation by a contained entity, and the researcher's struggle to trust their own perception. First person (researcher's perspective with interspersed notes), past tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
Item #: SCP-XXXX Object Class: Euclid (Provisional) Special Containment Procedures: I was placed in a standard research quarters at Site-54 with a second redundant camera and a redundant microphone array. A third passive laser vibrometry system was installed to measure desktop surface displacement at sub-millimeter resolution. All three video feeds were routed to separate analog recorders with staggered clocks, per Temporal Event Protocol TE-03. A stationary sealed document case with numbered and initialed anti-tamper seals was bolted to my desk. I was instructed to deposit any new handwritten notes into the case immediately upon discovery. No writing instruments were permitted within the quarters except a Foundation-issued pen I kept clipped to my lab coat; its ink was chemically tagged for post hoc discrimination. All entries and notes were subjected to non-destructive ink dating, paper fiber analysis, and chemical signature comparison. Contingency: If a note mentioned an imminent containment breach with verifiable specifics (time < 72 hours), a Level-2 temporal-response team was to be alerted, and containment tests or psychological evaluations suspended pending determination. Description: SCP-XXXX refers to a series of handwritten notes that began to appear on my desk on 2024-11-03, during my assigned analysis of Anomalous Object AO-4497, a stationary manipulator class object capable of subtle sensory distortions (audio pareidolia under white noise, slight temperature illusions). The notes purport to be written by me at a later date. The first note was unremarkable. The fourth warned me about a containment breach that had not happened yet. Subsequent notes were increasingly urgent, disorganized, and contradictory to observed reality. The exact moment each note appeared coincided with an observable glitch across all installed cameras: 0.72–1.04 s of static, followed by resumed normal operation with the note now present. During the glitch, the laser vibrometer recorded deterministic noise of unknown origin. I am recording this as a first-person report, per Ethics Committee recommendation, with scanned transcriptions of the notes interspersed. I understand the risks to objectivity. Initial Event (2024-11-03, 08:42): I left my desk to retrieve a reagent. I returned to find a folded sheet of Site-54 requisition paper on the blotter, my handwriting on the outside: “Don’t ignore this.” Security Review: Three cameras show normal feed until 08:41:39. At 08:41:40, all feeds bloom into vertical banding; audio cuts to carrier hiss. At 08:41:41, video resumes with the note present. The pen remained in the clip on my lab coat throughout. Note 1 (found 2024-11-03, 08:42): - Don’t ignore this. - Check under the keyboard. It’s clean; I made sure. - Look at the clock. It’s 08:42. We are in margin zero. Commentary: I checked under the keyboard. It was clean. The lab wall clock read 08:42 even though I had looked at my watch and thought it was 08:39 seconds earlier. That discrepancy became our first “hook.” Note 2 (found 2024-11-04, 07:17): - Coffee machine will sputter once at 07:19. Then a power blink. Don’t move the mug. - The cameras will drop again. You’ll think AO-4497 is doing it. It’s not. - Start recording yourself. At 07:19, the coffee machine sputtered once, the lights flickered, and a mug I had not touched slid 3 cm toward the edge of the counter. I started keeping audio notes at all times. Security installed the redundancy package. AO-4497 was moved to a Faraday cage in an adjacent room. The glitches continued. Note 4 (first breach reference, found 2024-11-06, 18:03): - They open the SCIF at 18:04 thinking it’s me inside. It’s not. It’s going to be empty. Then the alarms. Don’t be in the corridor. - This is the first breach, but it’s not the first for me. You think this is about 4497. It isn’t. It’s the Site. At 18:04, an access log showed a SCIF door opened on my badge. I was in my quarters, on camera. MTF Beta-7 secured the corridor. No breach occurred. The note was technically wrong, but the badge event was real. Later, Network Ops confirmed a phantom credential ping with my ID, origin unknown. Foundation Response: Temporal Anomalies Division (TAD) flagged SCP-XXXX as either a Class-Y “bootstrap” temporal leakage event or a manipulated predictive hoax. AO-4497’s influence radius was tested; it did not produce synchronous multi-camera dropouts on request. The ink on Notes 1–4 matched Foundation stock, but the actinic dye marker present in our pens was absent. The paper was from our storeroom, torn along known micro-perforations; the tear signatures did not match stock I had touched that week. That night, I dreamed of my own handwriting flaking like ash from my fingers. I woke at 03:11 to find Note 7 tucked under my cheek, warm from my breath. Note 7 (found 2024-11-09, 03:11): - Stop telling them everything. They will wrap you in telemetry until you can’t hear anyone but yourself. - If you move the stapler, it shifts the delta by 12 seconds. You already know this, but you don’t. - The breach isn’t in Keter. It’s in the clocks. I had not moved the stapler since 2024-10-28. On 11-09, as a test, I moved it 10 cm left. The next day’s glitch lasted 0.90 s, 12% longer than the prior median. TAD called that “not compelling.” My hands trembled when I wrote up the result. I noticed then that my baseline handwriting had begun to slant more steeply. The notes’ slant was worse, as if my wrist hurt. Note 9 (found 2024-11-10, 12:00): - The breach will be 11-14 at 02:23 during recalibration. They will call it a drill because they don’t want to believe. The doors will stick. Don’t trust the doors. - If you can hear me: do not go to Sublevel-3. Don’t go. I know you think you can change it. You can’t change it. You can only move it sideways. We notified Security of a possible 11-14 event. The Site ran an “unannounced drill” at 02:15 to preempt panic. At 02:23, an unrelated test of the backup chronometer system began. Doors did not stick. No breach occurred. TAD downgraded the credibility of the notes from “conditionally actionable” to “observational only.” I sat in my room afterward and tried to not pick up the newest note the way a patient tries to not scratch. I picked it up. Note 12 (found 2024-11-13, 21:58): - He will ask you what you think is happening. Don’t say “time travel.” Say “confabulation.” Make him feel safe. He’s not. - The cameras are not glitches. They’re edits. You know what an edit looks like. - When I write this, my knuckle is split. Is yours? If not, this is still early. I touched my right index knuckle. It was intact. Two hours later, I caught it on the edge of the document case. The skin split. My bandwidth for coincidence had been exhausted days ago. I started to avoid mirrors. Foundation Hypotheses (summarized): - Temporal Leakage Hypothesis: The notes are bilaterally causal artifacts from my own future, propagating backward along a micro-causal channel stabilized by synchronized environmental routines (coffee, stapler placement, badge use). Evidence: content specificity; partial correlation with events; deterministic noise on vibrometer concurrent with video glitch; handwriting match to my baseline with predicted drift curve. - Manipulative Entity Hypothesis: A cognitohazardous or infohazardous entity (possibly AO-4497 or an unknown) is generating false premonitions to induce behavioral patterns that precipitate a breach. Evidence: failures of predicted “breach”; contradictions in notes; increase in paranoia and self-referential content; the consistent appearance of notes where I will find them; video glitch window consistent with Site-54 known spectral anomalies at 50 Hz harmonics (see Incident 54-Halation). - Internalization Hypothesis: Early notes were seeded by a human actor with access; later notes are my own confabulations, introduced during camera gaps. Evidence: opportunity; my increasing insomnia; ink absence of actinic marker could be a deliberate forgery. Counter-evidence: independent observers were present for appearance of Notes 15 and 17 while I was under EEG monitoring; their cameras glitched too. By Note 15 I had stopped pretending this didn’t feel like a conversation. I wrote replies in a separate notebook that I did not show anyone. The actinic dye in my pen glowed pale under UV; the notes’ ink did not. Note 15 (found 2024-11-15, 04:31): - You are not saving anyone by warning them. Think sideways. The breach you know is not the breach you can touch. - Put the mug on its side at 05:00. Watch the surface settle. Count to 23. Breathe when the hum starts. - You are going to lose nouns for a while. It comes back. At 05:00, I laid the empty mug on its side. The building’s ambient hum seemed to rise 2 dB. I counted to 23. For the rest of the hour, I could not recall the word for “paperclip.” I described it as “the little silver spine” in my logs. TAD flagged this as a possible memetic side effect and ordered AO-4497 completely removed from the wing. The notes continued. Note 17 (found 2024-11-16, 19:02; appearance observed by Dr. Chen and Agent Morris): - Don’t trust the badge. - At 19:04 the corridor light will blow. Left side. Step right, two paces. - The breach isn’t in Keter. It’s in the clocks. It’s in us when we count together. At 19:04, the left corridor light blew. Dr. Chen and Morris both stepped right with me. We laughed. It was a short, hard laugh. Later we discovered that my badge had recorded a call to Maintenance at 19:03 from a station that no one had been at. The audio was a high tone and a scratch. By Note 20, the handwriting had become jagged. Letters stuttered, as if written while walking. Sentences contradicted each other. Note 20 (found 2024-11-18, 02:23): - The breach happened yesterday. It is happening now. It will happen on 11-21. It’s the same breach. None of that is wrong. - AO-4497 is the cause. AO-4497 is a decoy. - Your left ring fingernail will lift. Don’t pull it. On 11-18 at 02:40, I snagged my left ring fingernail on the case and lifted it. It bled. I did not tell anyone. The shame of making the note “right” sat in my throat like a coin. Foundation escalated containment. I was given sleep aids and a chaperone. The chaperone, Agent Stover, sat in my room reading magazines and carefully not looking at my hands. Note 23 (found 2024-11-19, 23:59): - They will ask for proof. You can’t give it to them without making it worse. - If you show them this note, it’s the version where the door doesn’t open. If you burn it, it’s the one where it does. - We are working with edits, not futures. I burned Note 23 in the sink at 00:03, sweating, watching the fibers blacken. The security footage showed static; when it returned, the sink was clean. The ash was gone. The vibrometer scribbled glyphs in noise amplitude that, histogrammed, spelled a plausible 23.
