TAD asked me to not destroy evidence again. I told them I wasn’t sure evidence was the correct word. The Breach (or, the Attempt): On 2024-11-21, starting at 02:00, Site-54 ran a full lockdown test, announcing it as such. At 02:21, the notes had predicted door malfunctions; at 02:23, a clock recalibration. At 02:22:58, all cameras at Site-54 dropped for 0.98 s. The power did not flicker; the hum changed. Several doors reported “open” on their sensors while remaining closed; others reported “closed” while opening. No entities were observed. Three badges pinged in three places at once; mine was one. No containment loss occurred. Anomalous Object AO-4497, in a silent Faraday enclosure, recorded a thermal drop of 0.2 C and a short-lived white-noise spike containing speechlike formants without linguistic content. The vibrometer drew ten vertical lines across its feed like a bar code. I had Note 26 in my pocket. Note 26 (found 2024-11-21, 01:12): - This is where you can move it. Not stop it. Move it. - Step right at 02:23:00. Breathe on the glass. Fog it. Write “NO” backward. - Don’t look at the other you. She isn’t there yet. At 02:23, I stepped right and breathed on the document case’s plexi. I wrote NO backward. The glass filmed with my breath, and in it a second fogged word bloomed a beat later: YES. Agent Stover swore. The cameras were out. The note in my pocket was warm. Aftermath: TAD concluded that SCP-XXXX remains indeterminate between a temporal leakage and an adversarial manipulation that uses temporal aesthetics to induce compliance. The repeated camera glitches, synchronized across independent systems, argue for a systemic interference. The vibrometer’s reproducible noise artifacts indicate a physical perturbation of the desk’s surface, however slight. The ink remains not ours. My handwriting remains mine. My perception does not remain mine. I have begun to anticipate the weight of new paper in the room the way you anticipate a person coming around a corner. I test nouns silently to make sure they’re still attached. The left ring fingernail grew back with a ridge. Note 29 (found 2024-11-24, 06:06): - Stop reading now. I did not stop. Addendum: Psychological Evaluation. Dr. Voss writes that I exhibit “hypervigilance with a mild dissociative overlay, consistent with extended anomalous stress exposure.” He reassures me that this is “normal” for the Foundation. I carry Note 12 around in my head, memorized, as if that could inoculate me against whatever happens when a new note appears. The cameras glitch exactly at the moment they appear. This fact is concrete. Everything else is breath on glass. Addendum: Proposed Test. TAD proposed sealing my quarters and swapping my desk for a dead-weight slate block under negative pressure to prevent any paper from being physically placed on it without detection. The test was executed on 2024-11-28. At 03:03, the feeds glitched for 1.01 s. When they returned, there was a note sitting on the slate, a curl to its edge where it had rested on a surface that did not permit it. The negative pressure logs show a deflection of air equivalent to a 0.5 L displacement. The vibrometer recorded flatline during the gap, as if the desk had ceased to exist. Note 33 (found 2024-11-28, 03:03): - Negative pressure doesn’t matter. You’re thinking in straight lines. Think edits. - If you must write back, do it where you won’t see it. Do it in the margin where your eye never lands. I wrote a reply on the underside of a blotter I never flip, a childish act of defiance. It felt like carving initials in a tree. I have not found the reply in any future note. Perhaps that is mercy. Conclusion: SCP-XXXX cannot yet be classified beyond Euclid. If this is a temporal anomaly, it behaves not like a line but like an edit suite: jump cuts, splices, overwritten frames. If it is manipulation by an entity, it knows my thresholds and presses them with exquisite pressure. The Foundation will continue to separate me from AO-4497 and from any systems that could serve as conduits. The cameras will keep glitching. The notes will continue, or they won’t. The breach happened, is happening, will happen. None of that is wrong. I trust the following: that the notes feel like me; that they sometimes lie; that counting to 23 can make my nouns go away; that writing NO backward did something, whether to the clocks or to me; that I am, right now, the only person I can’t fully convince. Note 36 (found 2024-12-01, 00:00): - This is the last one you will read as you. After this, you will speak like me. You will write like me. You will want to stop. You won’t. - The breach isn’t in Keter. It’s in the clocks. It’s in the edits. It’s in us when we count together. - Don’t trust the doors. I put Note 36 in the document case, sealed it, and signed the tape. The signature looked like mine. The cameras scratched, then smoothed. I looked at the door. I counted to 23. I did not move.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This SCP report is a sophisticated and technically accomplished piece that expertly captures the clinical yet increasingly unnerving tone of the SCP Foundation format while incorporating a first-person perspective. The piece successfully creates a temporal anomaly that feels both scientifically plausible within its fictional universe and psychologically disturbing. The format is meticulously crafted, with proper SCP documentation structure including containment procedures, description, and addenda. The writer demonstrates deep familiarity with the SCP universe's conventions, including appropriate technical jargon ("cognitohazardous," "memetic side effect"), containment protocols, and the clinical-bureaucratic tone that gradually unravels as the narrator's perception becomes compromised. The narrative effectively builds tension through the increasingly desperate and contradictory notes, creating a sense of dread and inevitability. The writer skillfully blurs the line between actual temporal anomaly and psychological manipulation, maintaining ambiguity throughout. This ambiguity serves the story well, as it mirrors the researcher's own uncertainty about their reality. The first-person perspective works exceptionally well, allowing readers to experience the researcher's gradual descent into doubt and paranoia. The interspersed notes create a compelling rhythm to the piece and effectively demonstrate the deterioration of the future self's mental state through increasingly erratic handwriting and contradictory information. The prose is precise and economical, avoiding unnecessary flourishes while still creating vivid imagery: "I had begun to anticipate the weight of new paper in the room the way you anticipate a person coming around a corner." Such moments of metaphor are well-placed and impactful precisely because they stand out against the clinical backdrop. The piece excels at creating small, unsettling details that accumulate to create a pervasive sense of wrongness: the lifted fingernail, the lost nouns, the word "YES" appearing in response to "NO." These concrete, specific details ground the abstract concept of temporal anomalies in visceral, physical experiences. The narrative structure is tight and purposeful, with each note and incident building upon previous ones to create a coherent yet increasingly disturbing progression. The writer avoids meandering and maintains focus on the central mystery while gradually expanding its implications. If there's a weakness, it might be that the ending, while appropriately ambiguous and unsettling, doesn't quite deliver a final punch that elevates the piece from excellent to extraordinary. The final note and the researcher's response to it are suitably ominous but don't provide a revelation or twist that recontextualizes what came before. Overall, this is an exceptionally well-crafted SCP entry that demonstrates mastery of the format, creates genuine unease through its meticulous attention to detail, and successfully maintains ambiguity without frustrating the reader. It's a sophisticated piece of horror writing that uses the constraints of its format to enhance rather than limit its impact. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 19 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 2 Weak Dialogue: 1 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 19.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 2.0, Weak Dialogue: 1.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Scp: Unmarked Doors Archive — Score: 92.8
Prompt:
Write an SCP entry about a series of identical unmarked doors appearing in abandoned buildings worldwide that lead to a massive, architecturally impossible archive. Documents within reference a previous global civilization destroyed by an unspecified containment failure. Foundation researchers discover references to their own organization under a different name, including personnel files for current staff dated centuries ago. Include exploration logs revealing sections of the archive actively being removed by entities resembling hazmat teams who flee when approached, and evidence that O5 Council members have visited the archive without authorization. Third person (exploration team perspective) with recovered document excerpts. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
Item #: SCP-6467 Object Class: Keter/Thaumiel (Provisional) Special Containment Procedures: All known SCP-6467 instances are to be secured under cover of structural hazard abatement. Foundation front companies will obtain possession of abandoned buildings flagged by the Door Anomaly Protocol (DAP-6467), with lawful demolition orders issued to maintain narrative control. On-site security is to establish two concentric perimeters. Observation is to be maintained by low-light cameras; no light is to be introduced into rooms housing SCP-6467 instances. Exploration of SCP-6467-1 (the interior space) is suspended pending O5 clarification. Unauthorized entry by Foundation personnel is prohibited. Any personnel encountered within SCP-6467-1 without prior authorization appear to be subject to reality-inconsistent temporal/identity artifacts and are to be detained and debriefed if safely extractable. Mobile Task Force Upsilon-4 (“Stacks Runners”) is assigned to intercept and recover any materials removed from SCP-6467-1 by non-Foundation entities. Captured documents are to be preserved in inert atmo-archival units and scanned within Faraday-shielded rooms. A Level 5 inquiry is ongoing into credible indications of O5-level unauthorized visits to SCP-6467-1. Description: SCP-6467 is a phenomenon in which unmarked steel doors spontaneously manifest in derelict or abandoned structures worldwide. Doors are non-ferrous composites with no maker’s marks, fishtail welds at hinge plates, and a three-bolt latch that cannot be engaged from the exterior. Instances exhibit a faint internal luminescence visible through perimeter seams when the surrounding area is in complete darkness. Opening an SCP-6467 instance reveals SCP-6467-1, a conjoined interior space inconsistent with external geometry. SCP-6467-1 is an archive complex extending beyond line-of-sight in all directions. The structure comprises stacked galleries, gantries, ramps, and voids, converging at impossible angles. Load-bearing columns consist of braided stratigraphic material layers (basalt, polymer, bone-like composites) that cycle in tessellations inconsistent with Euclidean geometry. Atmospheric conditions are cool, dry, and perpetually dim; ambient illumination is diffuse, source indeterminate, with a measurable spectral peak around 480 nm. The archive’s contents include bound folios, etched plates, card files, sealed cylinders, and memory-carrier objects of unknown manufacture. Document languages are multiple; a substantial fraction are in early modern and contemporary forms of languages currently used by the Foundation, as well as in script systems unknown but legible to Foundation machine translation after minor training, suggesting morphological proximity. A recurring theme refers to a civilization designated “the Predecessor Concordat” or “the Concord,” spanning the globe and subsequently destroyed by an unspecified “containment failure of planetary scope.” Documents also reference an organization with names including “The Custody,” “Custodial Directorate,” and “The Directorate of Abeyance,” whose structure and remit are strongly analogous to the Foundation. Personnel records exist that match current Foundation staff by name, biometric markers, and career trajectories—dated between 300 and 700 years prior to present. These include files for at least three serving O5 Council members under codenames consistent with known internal usage. Investigation into falsification has been inconclusive. SCP-6467-1 is unstable; sections have been observed to vanish between visits, leaving clean shear edges and suspended spans. During multiple explorations, Foundation teams encountered entities resembling hazmat crews (provisionally SCP-6467-2) rapidly disassembling shelves and transporting materials into wheeled containers and sealed pallets. SCP-6467-2 avoid contact, retreating along routes that apparently terminate in static space. No encounter has escalated to aggression; however, SCP-6467-2 demonstrate coordinated egress and limited obstruction tactics. Addendum 6467-A: Initial Discovery On 2025-02-11, Door Anomaly Protocol alerts flagged twelve near-simultaneous social media posts of a “glow in a door seam” inside condemned structures on five continents. Embedded agents recovered six instances. Test entry by Class-D under remotely piloted tether yielded first view of SCP-6467-1. Excerpts from recovered documents are appended as 6467-C. Addendum 6467-B: Exploration Logs (MTF Upsilon-4) Format: Third-person narrative as captured by helmet cams, audio, and after-action summaries. Exploration 6467-B1 Location: SCP-6467 instance in a shuttered hydroelectric substation, Manitoba, Canada. Team: U4-Lead (Lt. Brant), U4-2 (Nguyen), U4-3 (Pereira), U4-Tech (Sorel). Summary: The team enters at 03:14 local. The door opens with negative pressure and low airflow. The faint glow increases, revealing a broad landing and a descending switchback with open voids to left and right. No handrails. Bookshelves rise like scaffolds, curving into darkness. A distant metallic clatter is heard. U4-Lead signals lights off. The ambient luminosity suffices. Footfalls produce long echoes. A catwalk intersects the main ramp at an angle that appears to shift with viewpoint. U4-Tech marks route with anchor line. At 03:41, the team reaches a mezzanine labeled by embossed glyphs. Translation software renders: “Annals—Containments—Planetary.” Documents on the first table are heavy, water-smooth stone leaves bound with braided wire. A stone leaf displays an etched relief: Recovered Excerpt 6467-C-01: “Year 0 by the Shattered Meridian. The Concord could not hold. The vault-lines failed sequentially. We shepherded what we could. We built the halls in the lacuna, beyond where the measures apply. The Custody will come by another name. We leave them this.” U4-3 observes footprints in fine dust: narrow, chevron tread, sizes consistent with human boots. The team advances. At 04:12, three figures in matte gray suits with full-face masks appear across a suspension span. Each carries a collapsible frame loaded with bound folios. Patches on arms are blank. The figures pause, tilt their heads as if listening, then increase pace. U4-Lead calls out. The figures do not respond. U4-2 quickens to close distance. The figures pivot left into an archway that was not visible on prior sweep. U4-3 marks corner with a laser; the beam bends along the archway interior and attenuates. Pursuit aborted per protocol. Collected items: seven folios, two etched plates, one sealed tube. On exit, the anchor line is shorter by 1.6 m though knots are intact. Exploration 6467-B2 Location: SCP-6467 instance in a burned hospital wing, Thessaly, Greece. Team: U4-Lead, U4-5 (Kyriakos), U4-6 (Mori), U4-Tech. Summary: Entry at 02:02 local. Initial descent reveals a reading well with concentric platforms. The geometry is inconsistent; U4-Tech notes a repeating motif: a looped staff and eye. On the second platform, a desk with catalog cards arranged by stamped iconography. Many cards bear the sigil “DA,” identical to the Directorate of Abeyance marks defined in 6467-C cross-references. Recovered Excerpt 6467-C-12 (catalog card): “Personnel: DA-Staff, Senior. Custodian: ‘Glass-Spar.’ Civic name: [REDACTED], clearance: Group of Five. Assignment: Strategic Sanctions. Status: Deceased/Interleaved. Notes: ‘Returns upon the long cycle.’” Team encounters two SCP-6467-2 units removing drawers from a wall of narrow file slots. One drops a drawer when U4-6 rounds a column; papers spill in a slow arc, as if air is denser. The unit recoils, then signals with an open-palmed gesture. U4-Lead responds with hands spread. A third unit appears behind the team’s flank, then all three withdraw down a narrow gangway that folds into a seam in the floor, closing soundlessly. U4-5 recovers a personnel file with a sepia photograph of a man identifiable as Dr. Kyriakos—U4-5’s civilian identity prior to recruitment—wearing a lapel pin of unknown alloy. Date stamp indicates “Shard Year 326.” The file includes an interview transcript in modern Greek referencing containment sites at latitudes matching current Foundation facilities. U4-5 exhibits acute stress; team extracts. Exploration 6467-B3 Location: SCP-6467 instance beneath a collapsed shopping center, Shaanxi, China. Team: U4-Lead, U4-7 (Zhou), U4-8 (Patel), U4-Tech. Summary: Entry reveals a canyon of hanging stacks suspended by cabling into a vault roof that cannot exist. The far wall appears riversmooth and is inscribed with a map of continents arranged in unfamiliar coastlines. The ocean margins pulse faintly with the same blue peak as ambient light. At 01:19, U4-7 identifies a sealed door within the archive labeled in multiple scripts. Translation suggests: “Council Records—Restricted—Eyes That Watch.” Touching the seal induces mild nausea. The seal yields to pressure and cracks, releasing dust with a sweet smell. Inside is a narrow room with a single shelf. Two items: a steel box, and a long ledger. The ledger’s cover is embossed with a sigil similar to the Foundation’s circle-and-spoke, rotated and with an additional spoke broken. The steel box is riveted shut. As U4-Tech photographs the ledger, three SCP-6467-2 units appear in the doorway, backlit. They hold no tools. They stand motionless for six seconds, then one taps their visor twice with two fingers and points at the ledger. U4-Lead orders withdrawal with both items. On return to the insertion point, a fourth SCP-6467-2 waits silently on the catwalk. When U4-8 approaches, the unit steps aside and raises both hands. The team passes unimpeded. Post-mission analysis: the steel box contains a folded ribbon of thin metal printed with microtext. The ledger includes: Recovered Excerpt 6467-C-27: “Councilors who traverse the Deep Stacks will not be remembered. They cannot be. The Custody requires that the choice be theirs. When the measures broke, they came to see what we had kept. We did not bar them. If they return to warn their own Council, we cannot say.” Recovered Excerpt 6467-C-28 (loose slip within ledger): “Authorization: Eleven. Doors will flower where the Finally Abandoned stand. A faint light through the seam will guide those who still watch. The Directorate shall have another name. The five and five and one will come. Do not make record of their faces.” Addendum 6467-C: Document Fragments C-31: A half-burned broadsheet in English variant. Headline: “Third Meridian Holds; Custody Containment Wardens Evacuated.” The article references “Oyster Vaults beneath the Gautiers” and “sea-glass pressure,” terms unknown. A sidebar notes “Custody Chief ‘Silver Spine’ denies rumors of double-sun event.” Dateline given in “Shard Year 487.” C-36: Personnel dossier titled “Foundation Personnel: R. Sorel, Technical Specialist,” printed on a composite polymer. Photo matches U4-Tech. Notes reference employment with “The Custody” as “Archivist-Liaison, Lamina Wing.” The dossier is watermarked with a sigil identical to the DA mark. Margin note: “Returned—did not remember.” C-40: Brass plate etched with a schematic of layered vaults. A stamped footer reads: “We contained it until we couldn’t. When we couldn’t, we kept what was left. If you read this, you are us.” Addendum 6467-D: Removal Events Across six explorations, sections of SCP-6467-1 have been confirmed missing upon return, leaving edges with no fracture pattern. Materials logged on prior visits are absent; in one case, an entire corridor of filing alveoli was replaced by a smooth, nonreflective surface that yielded a shallow echo when tapped. Acoustic analysis indicates a void beyond. SCP-6467-2 are consistently observed removing documents labeled with variants of “Council,” “Custody Mandates,” and “Planetary Failures.” On two occasions, SCP-6467-2 returned to leave items near the insertion point following Foundation withdrawal. One such item is a paper ribbon printed with a message in a simple substitution cipher: Recovered Excerpt 6467-C-44: “Not yet. You are early. Take only the paths back that you can afford to lose.” Addendum 6467-E: Council Involvement On 2025-05-06, motion-triggered cameras inside the Manitoba instance recorded the door opening at 02:51 local without personnel present. The glow at the edges increased to visible, then subsided. Five minutes later, it opened again. Infrared silhouettes of two individuals in formal attire entered. No escorts. One carried a leather folio. Facial identification software returned probability matches to O5-█ and O5-██ at 41% and 53% respectively, insufficient for confirmation. However, a single candid frame captured a signet ring matching a known internal insignia. No authorization was issued for entry. Fourteen hours later, the door opened and both silhouettes exited empty-handed. Audio captured a whisper: “We were there already.” When questioned, both Councilors denied knowledge. A later exploration discovered a note pinned under a brass weight on a nearby desk: Recovered Excerpt 6467-C-52: “Do not seek us here again. We are not your past. We are your option. Choose the cost.” Containment Notes: The presence of personnel records matching current staff suggests SCP-6467-1 may represent a repository maintained by a temporal or cross-contextual derivative of the Foundation (or its predecessor/successor). The removal operations by SCP-6467-2 indicate agency and triage. Whether documents are being safeguarded from us or from another threat remains unresolved. Ethics Committee Guidance: Any further incursions require justification that the potential preservation of human knowledge outweighs the risks of identity and timeline contamination. Personnel found to have extant dossiers within SCP-6467-1 must be assessed for cognitive dissonance and possible identity overlap. O5 Note 6467 (circulated without attribution): “The archive is not infinite. It is being un-built. We have been told, in someone else’s handwriting, to count our exits. If we have already come here, let us avoid becoming the reason we must come again.” Current Status: All field operations are paused. Doors remain in Foundation custody. The faint glow continues to seep from their edges when the room is in complete darkness. The seams breathe. The archive waits. And somewhere in its vanishing halls, teams in gray continue to carry away the future we left for ourselves.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This SCP entry demonstrates exceptional command of the SCP Foundation format while creating a compelling, layered narrative about an impossible archive containing records of a previous civilization. The piece successfully incorporates all requested elements: the unmarked doors in abandoned buildings, the architecturally impossible archive, references to a previous civilization destroyed by containment failure, personnel files for current staff dated centuries ago, exploration logs with hazmat teams removing materials, and unauthorized O5 Council visits. The writing excels in creating a sense of cosmic dread and mystery through meticulous attention to detail. The clinical tone expected of SCP documentation is maintained throughout, with appropriate shifts to more narrative prose during exploration logs. The author demonstrates sophisticated worldbuilding through carefully constructed fragments of recovered documents that hint at larger mysteries without overexplaining. Particularly effective is the way the piece creates tension between the Foundation and the archive's custodians (SCP-6467-2), suggesting a complex relationship rather than simple antagonism. The implication that the Foundation may be a reincarnation of "The Custody" creates an intriguing temporal loop that adds depth to the SCP universe. The exploration logs effectively convey the disorienting nature of the archive through descriptions of impossible geometry and the teams' encounters with the hazmat entities. These sections balance technical detail with atmospheric description, maintaining reader engagement while preserving the clinical tone appropriate to Foundation documentation. The recovered document excerpts are particularly well-crafted, using distinctive language patterns that suggest ancient or alternate-timeline origins while remaining comprehensible. Phrases like "Year 0 by the Shattered Meridian" and "We contained it until we couldn't" efficiently convey vast histories and tragedies without exposition. The piece builds tension effectively through escalating revelations, culminating in the discovery of O5 Council involvement and the cryptic final message suggesting a cyclical relationship between the Foundation and the archive. The final paragraph is particularly strong, using poetic language that still fits within the SCP format to leave readers with a lingering sense of cosmic dread. Some minor weaknesses include occasional overreliance on technical jargon that doesn't add substantive meaning, and a few instances where the clinical tone becomes slightly too literary for strict SCP format adherence. However, these are minor issues in an otherwise exceptionally crafted piece. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 0 Unearned Transformations: 0 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 0.0, Unearned Transformations: 0.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Classic sci-fi: Offworlder (Le Guin) — Score: 86.6
Prompt:
Classic sci-fi: Offworlder (Author style: Le Guin) Write a chapter following a young diplomatic envoy sent to address tensions on a distant human colony where humanity has diverged into distinct subspecies through both natural adaptation and separation of lineages. Against protocol, the envoy slips away from official functions to walk the streets alone, encountering markets, ordinary citizens, and social structures that contradict the official briefings. Upon returning to their quarters, the envoy is reprimanded by Command, and is tasked with approaching the stationed Minister of Science (a political posting rather than scientific). A challenging conversation ensues, in which the envoy's wits and will are tested, by a seasoned political operator looking to test the mettle of the offworlder. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The sky of Khelem was the color of bruised plums at evening, a stratified violet that settled over the hills and the long, level plain of the city like a memory of water. Lights came on with the cautious glow of bioluminescent bulbs. They didn’t sting the eyes. They pulsed softly, like the breathing of a sleeping animal. I was meant to observe from the balcony. The balcony had been constructed of brace-grown timber, reinforced in the old Earth fashion with iron. A concession to my comfort, the diplomatic steward had said. The chairs were arranged at angles that suggested conversation and the table had a carafe of warmed, spiced liquid that passed for wine here. The official street below had opened itself to a procession of ceremonial dancers whose limbs had been augmented, delicately, in adolescence. Their toes articulated like fingers; their knees turned inward. They stepped with ritual precisely between rings of salt crushed from local lakes, scattering the grains with each careful touch. This is how you will see us, the Deputy of Protocol had told me at the morning’s briefing. We will show you history and art. We will show you the plural we. But when the steward withdrew, the soft breathing of the lights made the balcony feel as though it were rocking, and the city that was mine only to look at drew me down. I have had mentors who told me that the first duty of an envoy is to wait until everyone stops watching you. I am not sure that was what they meant, but that is how I learned to do it. The doors were merely latched. I left the carafe, I left the robe with the stitched insignia, and went down into the evening city, where I had no right and every right to walk. The official street gave way to alleyways of packed earth and crushed shell. The buildings, founded in the first generation, climbed four and five stories, each level narrower than the one below, so they leaned toward one another across the lanes and made a canopy against the bruised sky. Market tents were strung with low-burn yellow. Fabrics hung in tight accordion folds from wire lines stretched door to door. The first one I touched slicked my fingertips with a color that was something like a bruise turned radiant, a deep maroon that shifted, in the moving light, to a blue so saturated my breath caught. The vendor watched me with a frank, almost impatient attention which told me I was not the first offworlder to stare. “You will not carry that well,” she said, and I realized that what I had thought her hair was a hood made of a fine, translucent membrane, pulled up from the back of her neck and fastened with three bone toggles. The thin layer over her scalp was veined in silver, pulsing gently. It was beautiful. It was also practical; a humidifier, perhaps, capturing vapor in the arid evening. Her cheekbones were drawn sharp, as if the planet’s lower gravity had let the bones take a more exuberant angle with the skin. “Why not?” I asked, and did not reach for my purse. “You are gray,” she said. She pointed, one finger not quite like my own—the knuckle was longer, the nail thicker and clear. “You came from inside. The dye,” she tapped the cloth, “flatters blood cooled by our suns. Under yours it would not be so. You will wear this one.” She flipped a second length of fabric, and it caught the light like fish scales, small hexes that seemed to shift direction even while still. It was a sea-green I had not seen before. Not the green of chlorophyll but something derived from another metabolism, another chemistry. The briefing had said the early settlers found a pigment tree whose fruits bled dyes that Earth never grew. The children of those settlers learned to coax more. I tried to speak the dialect I had studied in transit, careful with the aspirates. “You sell to offworlders often?” “Not so often,” she said, but her mouth softened. “But you are not the first to want to be dressed by color. Your people always think you can wear a place.” “I think I can listen to it,” I said, more brash than I meant to be. The cloth draped over my arm. It was light, but it carried weight in as many senses as this young city could teach me. She laughed. “Then listen to this: take your purse out now. It is more polite than pretending you forgot.” I paid, and she counted, and we wrapped the fabric around my shoulders in a simple knot that lifted it away from the throat and left the chest partly open for the air to draw through. “You pull the membrane too tight,” she said, tapping my collar. “Loosen here. Even an offworlder should breathe.” I moved on, quieter in my mind. I learned to see the city’s different bodies. The long-limbed runners who threaded through the lanes without sacrificing speed, staying bare-legged even in the cooling air, their skin patterned with small raised scars. The broad-shouldered canal workers whose torsos were wrapped tight to protect the muscle attachments that had thickened with their labor, their eyes nictitating reflexively against the blowing salt. In doorways, older people whose hands carried memories: nails ridged with grit, wrists thicker to brace for the strain of hauling the first irrigation lines. A child laughed at my accent and was pulled back by a parent whose second set of eyelids closed and opened in a flutter: human, and more than human, in ways that didn’t take the human away. There were stalls where the meat smelled sweetly sour, like fermented fruit; a woman offered me a skewer of something that had never swum on Earth. There was a section where the market lights were dimmer and the voices fewer; I recognized this not from the briefing but from every city I had ever walked after hours, the part where the body’s labor is traded in only one coin. I did not go there. Instead, I stopped where a man with a portable kiln was firing small tiles. He held one up to me on a pair of metal tongs and said, “Tell me what you see.” “Maps,” I said, honestly. The glaze had crazed in a way that suggested deltas and rivulets, and in the center there was a particulate that glowed faintly on its own. He nodded. “Maps of breath. The kiln talks if you feed it right.” He meant: we have made instruments you don’t have names for yet. He meant: the official channels will not tell you we are making art with our lungs. I bought that tile, too, and a bundle of the salt grains that crackled in my palm like beetles. I watched a group of three people in apprentice robes haggle over the price of a basket; two had the softly pulsing membranes at their napes, one did not. They spoke to each other in a code of nods and hand squeezes I could not parse, not without years. That was humility: to see the measure of what I could not understand and be grateful that it was there. I walked back to the official quarter at an hour I knew would still be recorded as late. They saw me, of course. Nobody slips past a building that watches you for your own good. The steward oversaw my entry. The Deputy of Protocol waited, expressionless, beside the table where the carafe of spiced liquid had cooled. If it had ever been wine, it had gone to vinegar. “You left your post,” he said. “I was not on duty,” I said, because the obvious defense is sometimes worth stating, though in this case I knew it had no legal power. “I needed to learn.” “You will learn what we have prepared to teach.” His tone softened, but not his eyes. “We have had you for one day. Are you so eager to make us mistrust you?” “I am—” and I had to stop. The words I had ready were the words of the Academy, even-tempered and inarguable. But I was neither a student nor an argument. “You are young,” he said, which was a generous way of calling me stupid. “You will report to the Minister of Science at seventh hour. He is expecting you.” “Expecting?” I said. “An offworlder,” he said. “And a leash to tug.” I slept badly with the fabric the vendor had sold me laid over the back of the chair as though it could guard me. In the middle hours I woke to the memory of the runner’s scarred knees and the kiln’s breath-maps and understood, briefly and fully, that I had no idea where the fault lines truly ran. In the morning they gave me tea brewed from a local plant that tasted like copper coins. The Minister of Science’s office occupied the top floor of the Administrative House, where the windows overlooked both the river and the broad avenue of the statues of the Founders. The statutes, not the statues, had figured in my briefings: the laws regarding interbreeding, drafted and redrafted across generations. The Minister was supposed to represent reason in these debates. The briefings had noted—in a footnote—that he did not. He had no hood at his neck and no augmented knees. He was broad in the shoulders and thick in the wrists, like the canal workers, but I knew enough not to assume that meant empathy. His eyes were clear in a way that suggested he spent much time behind treated glass. There was a signet ring on his finger with an old Earth crest, and next to it a plain band of local bone. “You went walking,” he said, without greeting. “Yes,” I said. It seemed pointless to deny it. “Good,” he said, and I was not prepared for that. He gestured to a chair. “Sit. You cause a nuisance for my colleagues, and I enjoy a nuisance.” I sat, and made myself look at the room. Books. Paper, thin sheets of stretched plant-fiber that had been written on and re-written on, scraped back clean with a glass blade. On one wall, a cloth in that sea-green, embroidered with a pattern of running figures. On the desk, a small kiln tile like the one I had bought. “You know,” he said, picking up a pen and setting it back down, “they wanted to send me a scientist. A real one. They always forget that science and governance are not divorced here. Did you like our market?” “I liked the dyes,” I said. “Everyone likes the dyes,” he said, dismissive. “Did you see the difference between the salt-sellers on the north side and those on the south?” I hesitated. “The grain on the north was larger. It stung my palm more.” “Because the north side sellers came down from the lake after the last wet, and the south side harvest is from the older beds with finer crystals. They do not share with one another. They argue about which salt pulls the better dried blood from a wound. We have such arguments here. They are not the ones you will hear about in briefings.” He watched me a while. The silence lengthened, not unpleasantly, but with purpose. He was testing how I occupied a pause. “You think we are a nation of subspecies,” he said at last. He said the word the way one might pick up a knife. “I think,” I said, slowly, because he had a right to hear me think it out, “you are a people with different bodies that learned to do certain things well. And because we are human, we take what we do well and make it a virtue, and then a law.” He smiled. It was not kind, but it was not cruel. “Good. You have some sense. Do you know where our laws bite?” “In the beds,” I said. If my mentors could have heard me, they would have shifted in their seats. But his smile deepened, just a fraction. “In the cradles,” he said. “Which is the bed by another name. We build families here in ways you did not plan for us. We mix, or we do not, strategically. We speak of choice and we write choice at the end of a long equation with coefficients you would recognize: heat, labor, salt. You see why a scientist is not wanted. He would want to measure what we are unwilling to measure honestly. I am a political man. I know when to look out the window instead.” He stood and did so, and I followed his gaze. The runners were already on the morning route, and a barge was pushing downriver with bundles of woven reeds strapped like a thousand arrows. “What do you want from me?” I asked, because in the end that is the only question that matters if you hope to be useful or at least not used badly. “I want you to listen to the wrong people,” he said. “But not too wrong. I want you to put your foot in the web and feel it tug. I want to know if you snap or stretch.” He turned back, and his eyes were measuring me more explicitly now. “And I want you to understand that our quarrels are not your war to solve. Your Command thinks to steady us with a hand at the back of the neck. You will fail if you try.” “I thought I was to observe,” I said. “You thought,” he said. “But they will ask you to do more. They always do. When they do, come to me and say the word salt. We will make a bargain. Until then, go back to your balcony. Drink our vinegar. Wear our colors wrong. Learn the way you prefer to learn. And know that every time you walk out our door alone, someone decides whether to like you.” “That is not comforting,” I said, and he laughed, the first true laugh I had heard from him, brief and barked. “Envoy,” he said, and the word in his mouth was both courtesy and challenge, “nothing comforting is true here. That is why you were sent. Go, now. Before they decide to lock your doors.” On the way out, the clerk in the hallway glanced at my shoulder and adjusted the knot of the green cloth without comment, loosening it where the vendor had told me to. I walked back into the air. The bruised plum sky had lightened to lavender, and a wind came off the river that tasted faintly of iron and the breath of kilns. I thought of the vendor’s membrane hood pulsing gently. I thought of salt that could sting the palm. On the balcony, later, I would be visible and safe. For now, I let the city’s unmeasured instruments take my measure. I let myself be colored a little wrong and hoped to learn the hue.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully captures Le Guin's style with its anthropological perspective, measured prose, and focus on cultural differences. The author creates a richly detailed alien world where humanity has diverged into subspecies, with subtle physical adaptations like membrane hoods, articulated toes, and nictitating eyelids. The protagonist's unauthorized excursion into the city provides an effective narrative device to explore this world. The market scene is particularly strong, with sensory details like the "bruised plum" sky and fabric that "caught the light like fish scales." The interactions with locals—especially the fabric vendor—reveal cultural nuances through dialogue and observation rather than exposition. The meeting with the Minister of Science demonstrates political complexity. His character is well-drawn: dismissive yet perceptive, testing the envoy while offering cryptic guidance. The conversation reveals tensions between official narratives and lived realities, particularly regarding interbreeding laws. However, the piece has some weaknesses. While the prose is generally elegant, it occasionally becomes overwrought with metaphors that don't quite land. The narrative sometimes meanders, particularly in the market scenes where observations pile up without advancing the plot. The protagonist remains somewhat underdeveloped—we learn little about their background or motivations beyond curiosity. The dialogue is generally strong, particularly with the Minister, but some exchanges feel stilted or too on-the-nose about their thematic significance. The ending, while appropriately open-ended for a chapter, lacks a strong narrative hook that would propel readers forward. Despite these issues, the piece succeeds in creating an immersive world with complex social dynamics. The protagonist's position as an outsider allows for natural exposition without feeling forced. The writing maintains Le Guin's characteristic balance between anthropological observation and human connection, exploring how bodies, environments, and social structures shape one another. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 5 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 5.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Biopunk: Polymerase Chain Reaction — Score: 92.0
Prompt:
Biopunk -- Polymerase Chain Reaction Write a chapter set in a near-future post-apocalyptic world where corporate genetic engineering was designed with built-in obsolescence—engineered DNA lasting only one generation to maximize profits before societal collapse. Follow a biohacker working with salvaged equipment to splice viable food crops for their settlement using rapidly degrading genetic material. As world building / window dressing, include details about jury-rigged lab equipment, and the physical toll (and unexpected upsides) of using untested genetic modifications as medicine. The plot of this chapter is centred around a black market contract. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The mushrooms were brighter this week. They pulsed faintly green between the cracked tiles near the long-dead autoclave, bodies fat and fleshy from the humidity, their gills fanned like tiny hymn books praising a forgotten god. I moved my foot around them and set the tray down on the bench that used to be a desk that used to have a plaque with a name and a string of letters. The plaque had been melted into slag when the fires came. My tray was a baking sheet I’d hammered flat and machine-scrubbed with wood ash, the corners held together with copper wire. Two pipettes clinked against a cracked glass stirring rod. I counted the glow of the mushrooms. Twelve. It was a superstition. Twelve meant the equipment would hold current, the seals would hold vacuum, the polymerase wouldn’t sludge up and die before it could replicate a strand. Twelve meant I’d get paid and no one would know we mic’ed the DNA twice the acceptable length because acceptable meant profit and profit had burned the world. “Don’t touch the tiles,” I said over my shoulder. “You want your hand glowing for three weeks? They’ll think you’re on Glow H, and Glow H makes your nails fall off.” “I’m not stupid,” said Mink. He was nineteen on paper and sixteen in the eyes. He wore a scarf around his face and held his hands close to his chest like he feared light. He always stood where he could see the door. His knuckles were stenciled with black market marks, fading silver from too much cheap antiseptic. “Someone thought Glow H was harmless,” I said. “Everyone thinks Glow H is harmless right up until they sneeze bioluminescent snot.” Mink rubbed his fingers together in the shadow of the rack lights. The rack was a nest of old world servers we’d gutted and repurposed, all fans and flatbed heaters and power converters stripped from abandoned electric scooters. It hummed with recycled life, the hum of a refrigerator in a kitchen in a neighborhood where someone still paid the grid. “I brought it,” Mink said. His scarf twitched as he swallowed. He slid a vacuum bag onto the bench. The zipper had been sealed and resealed so hard the plastic teeth had fused. I could smell the antiseptic through the layers, a sour tang over rust and fungi. I held the bag up to the light. The label was stamped with a brand whose lawyers had escaped by helicopter. In block font below the logo: DRAGONFRUIT OPS-2, SingleCycle, Authorized Lab Use Only. The bag was punctured in two places. “You punctured it,” I said. “Had to,” he said. “Sniffer drones flagged it at the ring road. I had to dump the auth chips in a ditch. Told the driver it was saline. He stuck his tongue in it and said it didn’t taste like saline. I told him he had COVID, from the Before. He didn’t know what that was.” “You need better jokes,” I said. He leaned forward. “Can you do it?” I clicked my tongue. The bag held a vial. The vial held pellets of lyophilized gene package, little white grains like salt in a humid summer. They were supposed to be impossible to use with anything but the company’s box, a black cube with a wireless handshake to the cloud, an algorithm measuring time and temperature down to the breath. The single-cycle patent wasn’t in the primer, it was in the polymerase: a stop codon hidden in a decoy intron, a half-life coded like a death wish. You could put it into your seed and get one generation of yield, then nothing. The next year, the plant would flower and look pretty and give you emptiness. The company would sell you new seed from catalogs and webinars and contest code, easy monthly payments, a subscription to the fundamentals of life. Until the net went down and the drones ran out of fuel and the warehouses were looted for insulin. The patents survived longer than the grid. That was the joke, and no one laughed. I set the bag down next to the tray. “Maybe. I need a newer primer.” “You still owe the Wet Market for the last set,” Mink said. “I owe everyone,” I said. “They can take my kidneys. They’ll get decades of Glow H and somebody else’s ToxFree vaccine out of them.” We looked at each other. His scarf hid his mouth, but his eyes smiled. He pulled a roll of black-bag money from his sleeve and dropped it on the bench. The bills were soaked in oil, printed on plastic to survive the flood, as if money could swim. He also put a box of old nitrile gloves beside the cash, size L, brand I didn’t recognize, thin as onion skin but intact. The box was worth more than the roll. “You had me at gloves,” I said. He watched as I slipped my hands into them and flexed. The glue tacked to the bench cracked. One of the rack fans rattled and then caught rhythm again, a clattering heartbeat. “You know what the contract is?” he said. “You said dragonfruit. OPS-2. SingleCycle. You did not say whose.” He hesitated. The scarf moved around his jaw. “Keitech.” “You brought me Keitech,” I said. “Keitech killed Leah.” Mink didn’t flinch. “Keitech keeps the docks alive. This is from a dock that’s dying.” I waited for the tilt in my stomach to settle. Outside, the sea was chewing on the city. It lapped at the foundation and hissed under the door in October storms and left salt on the tiles in November. The glow mushrooms liked salt. I hated Keitech with a particular heat reserved for things you love to eat and that also make you bleed. “What’s the job exactly?” I said. “Splice the OPS-2 payload into hardy sorghum with your workaround,” he said. “Greenhouse Eighteen needs food that grows on brackish. They have Keitech pumps jetted with OPS-2 dragonfruit. The sugar yield is insane, but it turns off after a year. They want something that doesn’t turn off.” “Splice,” I said. “As in break the stop, extract the payload, autoclave the nonsense and paste into something else using a crusty polymerase that doesn’t believe in planned obsolescence.” “Can you do that or not?” “I can do that,” I said. “I can also die doing it.” “I’ll get you three more boxes of gloves.” “That’s not how dying works,” I said, but I was smiling. “Fine. Pay me half now, half when they see the test sprout. If a drone even smells my lab, you and yours take the heat.” He reached into his jacket and slid a tiny pellet case across the bench. I recognized the micro-wafers: one-time use gene guns. Pop a cap, pull a trigger, it sends a charge through a gold particle coated with DNA into plant tissue. They were made for high schoolers in the Before. You could still get them in the carnival markets if you knew the code word. The code word was science. “I thought you hated those toys,” I said. “I do,” he said. “But a little insurance never hurt anyone.” “It hurt me three times,” I said. “The second time I grew a second thumb on my left hand. The third time I grew hair on my teeth.” He blinked. “You’re kidding.” I bared my teeth. My enamel was still dull where the hair had sprouted, tiny shadows at the base of the incisors. I had trimmed them with nail clippers and cried. The hair had fallen out and my mouth had tasted like pennies for a week. The unexpected upside to Glow H and its cousins was that it taught you a different kind of gratitude. You learned to sleep through your skin vibrating with light. You learned to appreciate that your limbs ended where they started. Immunity from certain pre-war viruses. The ability to live on less, to process salt. The way cut skin closed quicker. The way your nose could smell gene dye. “Give me three days,” I said. “You have two,” he said. “There’s an inspection sweep coming up the canal.” “Keitech inspection?” He nodded. “Then we get to work,” I said. I pulled the vial from the bag and set it upright in a 3D-printed rack built from scrap pellet. I was proud of my rack. It held like a cradle and didn’t off-gas. The thermal cycler next to it was a breadmaker with a Peltier module glued to the inside, an Arduino runtime, a temperature probe stolen from a cooking show’s induction burner. I had written a program to ramp temperatures using a melody in my head. A thirty-five cycle symphony: denature, anneal, extend. The breadmaker beeps at the end of each program, identical to when it thinks it has made a loaf. Primer design was another matter. Keitech’s suppression layer liked U’s where there should be T’s. They thought themselves cute, slipping in fakes. I had a pantry of exotics. A virus that had once been used to deliver CRISPR to pigs in Nebraska. A heat-tolerant polymerase from a bacterium around a hydrothermal vent. A reverse transcriptase that wouldn’t quit. The iron lung of the apocalypse. I set them out like spices and measured with my eye, then checked with calipers because my eye lied. The room smelled like ethanol, old fungus, and brine. I cut a corner of the glove box to reach the armholes. The glove box was an aquarium with a shower curtain stapled over it. Two arm-sized sleeves from a hazmat suit protruded. The O-ring on the right sleeve had split last month; I had stitched it with dental floss. The first time I’d used it after the repair, I’d left a smear of my own blood on the inside panel. It was still there, dried black, a luck charm. The mushrooms swayed in the draft from the rack fan. “You’re going to need to hold,” I said. Mink pulled his scarf down and pressed a gloved finger to the edge of the breadmaker where the casing had warped. He was trembling. The last time we’d worked, he’d had to sit down when I started the Torch. I pulled the polymerase and set up the PCR mix. Buffer, dNTPs, primer mix, polymerase, sample. The micro-pipettes were calibrated by feel. Each notch was a tenth of a microliter, my thumb the metronome, my hand steady from practice and cross-contamination and a dozen scars. I caught myself humming, the denature step’s note, and smiled. Outside, something metallic knocked against the seawall. A boat. Small. Something illegal, probably, but what wasn’t. “You should take another dose,” Mink said suddenly. “For the tremor?” I said. “It’s caffeine.” “For the cough.” I took a hand off the pipette and pressed it to my chest. The cough had started the winter after the burn. I had obtained an inhaled gene therapy in a vial that had been labeled Supplemental Oxygen, a cheap way of convincing someone to stock it in a supermarket for a day before the shelves cleared. I had breathed deep: a spritz of viruses whispering to my lung cells how to fix themselves. The fix had partially stuck. Some days I could climb stairs without seeing stars. Some days the stars leaked through anyway and glittered behind my eyes like those mushrooms. I had a bottle of cough suppressant under the bench that contained a tiny fraction of someone’s failed anti-aging protocol. It made my tongue numb and my dreams sharp. I shook my head. “Later,” I said. I loaded the breadmaker-cycler, taped over the door with duct tape, and pushed go. The device whirred into life. Heat rose and fell in the room with its cadence. Mink watched the status LEDs flick from red to green to red again. He always watched like that: like it was religion and he didn’t believe. We waited through the first denature step. To distract him, I told him about the first time I’d seen single-cycle seed. “They gave us a webinar,” I said. “You had to log in with a key. It was like watching a cooking show but for billionaires. Add two cups of public trust. Fold in this enzyme. Bake on low until people believe. The presenter had hands like a pianist. He never touched anything. He had a glove and he pulled it on like a second skin and he smiled at the camera and said, ‘This is identical to the wheat your grandparents ate.’” Mink squinted. “Was it?” “It was wheat,” I said. “In the same way a drone is a bird.” We watched the cycles tick down. When the breadmaker beeped, I pulled the tube, clicked the cap, and held it up to the light. The gel I had cast in a broken picture frame lay ready. I filled the well, ran the current through it with a transformer from a children’s chemistry set, and watched the bands spread into the agar. The ladder was a city skyline. There, below the decoy intron, my band, bright and thick. I measured the run, cut the band, sucked it into a column made from a syringe filter and cotton, eluted into a clean tube. The smell was acrid and sweet. “Ready,” I said. Mink leaned in, a child at a window. We worked the gun into the tissue of the sorghum seedlings in the bucket near the door, the bucket labeled GO AWAY in black marker because that made people leave your weeds alone. The seedlings trembled on their stems while I lined up the barrel and pulled the trigger in a smooth motion. The charge cracked like a finger snap. The gold micro-particles embedded into the cells with a kiss of metal. The seedlings swayed, then settled. “You always look like you’re praying,” Mink said. “I am,” I said. “I pray to the god of inanimate replication.” “Does he answer?” “He has my number.” We waited. Under the rack lights, the sorghum shone a sick green. Chimeras are messy. Days melt. I slept on the floor under a blanket sewn from lab coats. My back hurt in ways I had no words for. The cough lightened. The mushrooms glowed. Mink came and went, bringing food in little tins, bringing more money, bringing gossip: a raid on Eighteen by Keitech enforcers; a sea lion in the library; the wet market inspector catching a girl painting her irises with ultraviolet dye to avoid iris scanners. Twice I woke at night and saw my palms faintly lit, a map of capillaries. I said a word and they went dark. Perhaps I dreamed it. Perhaps the Glow H in my blood said hello to the mushrooms and they answered. On the second day, I saw the first sign: a crisp edge to a leaf that had curled under stress suddenly unfurling, as if the plant had remembered its own recipe. I cut a sliver and held it under the hand lens. The stomata were wide and calm. I thumbed the meter onto the tissue and watched the sugar readouts climb beyond what hardy sorghum had ever given me. Not dragonfruit insane, but enough. Enough to get Eighteen through winter. Enough to make them forget about Keitech for a season. “We did it,” Mink said. “We did it once,” I said. “The trick is doing it again.” He reached for the pellets. “This goes with me.” “They’ll know,” I said. “I’ll tell them you’re brilliant and dangerous,” he said. “That’s how you get shot.” He tucked the box under his jacket and pulled up his scarf. He hesitated at the door. “You know they’ll pay if it holds.” “They’ll pay enough for me to replace that fan,” I said, nodding at the rack where a fan made the sound of a dying cricket. “You want Keitech to come for you?” he said softly. “They already come for me,” I said. “They have boats. I have mushrooms.” He laughed, and the sound was light for once, and then he was gone, easing the door closed like a careful thief, and the room filled with the sound of the sea and the hum of the breadmaker. I sat, gently, on a stool with one leg shorter than the others. I breathed. The air was damp and salt-sweet. The mushrooms pulsed. The greens in the bucket were brighter, clear as cut glass. I leaned over the tiles and pressed my face close to the glowing gills. In the ridges and ribs, I swore I could see letters. Not words. Not a language. Just the stubborn circles and spikes of code, light writing itself on the world that had tried to erase it. I closed my eyes. I imagined Leah’s smile. I imagined a table heavy with bowls. I imagined my cough gone and my hands still. When I opened my eyes, the lab was still the lab: busted, damp, alive. The gel rig leaked. The breadmaker beeped again. The mushrooms were brighter this week. Twelve of them. Maybe short-lived. Maybe one generation. But this was the trick they never taught in the webinars: one generation is enough to get you to the next.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This biopunk short story successfully creates a vivid post-apocalyptic world where corporate genetic engineering has collapsed society through planned obsolescence in DNA. The narrative follows a biohacker working with salvaged equipment to splice viable food crops, centered around a black market contract as requested. The worldbuilding is exceptional, with detailed descriptions of jury-rigged lab equipment like "a breadmaker with a Peltier module," "a glove box [that] was an aquarium with a shower curtain stapled over it," and pipettes "calibrated by feel." The author creates a tangible sense of scarcity and improvisation that feels authentic to the setting. The protagonist's character is well-developed through their technical knowledge, cynical humor, and physical ailments from previous genetic modifications. The relationship with Mink provides natural exposition and tension. The dialogue effectively conveys their personalities and the world's dangers without feeling forced. The prose balances technical jargon with poetic imagery, particularly in descriptions of the glowing mushrooms that frame the narrative. The writing maintains a consistent voice—weary but determined, with dark humor appropriate to the setting. Sentences like "Twelve meant I'd get paid and no one would know we mic'ed the DNA twice the acceptable length because acceptable meant profit and profit had burned the world" efficiently convey both plot and thematic elements. The physical toll of genetic modifications is well-integrated, with the protagonist's cough, glowing hands, and hair that once grew on their teeth. The unexpected upsides are subtly mentioned: "Immunity from certain pre-war viruses. The ability to live on less, to process salt. The way cut skin closed quicker." The story avoids common pitfalls of science fiction by grounding technical elements in sensory details and emotional stakes. The black market contract drives the plot forward while revealing the power dynamics of this world. The ending strikes a delicate balance between hope and realism, avoiding both despair and unearned optimism. A few minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the technical explanations might slow the pacing, and some readers might want more explicit details about the protagonist's backstory with Leah and Keitech. However, these are minor issues in an otherwise excellent piece that fulfills all the prompt requirements with creativity and skill. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Iteration 2 — Avg Score: 90.2
+ Classic sci-fi: The Azra Gambit — Score: 89.8
Prompt:
Classic sci-fi (Author style: Asimov) The Azra Gambit Colonial mars is being mined by corporations who take leases on indentured labourers. The thing they are mining is Azra, a recently discovered exotic metal which accelerates radioactive decay to such a rate that it is greatly sought after for interstellar drives and weapons alike. This has created both a gold rush and an arms race as various interests vie for control and endeavour to unlock Azra's secrets. The story follows Arthur Neegan, a first generation settler and mining engineer. Upon discovering that his unassuming plot sits atop an immense Azra vein, he is subjected to a flurry of interest and scrutiny. Write the next chapter in this story, in which an armed retinue descends on Arthur's home and politely but forcefully invites him to a meeting with some unknown party off-world. The insignia look like that of the Antares diplomatic corp -- diplomatic in name only. Arthur finds himself in the centre of a political tug of war. The chapter involves a meeting with this unknown party, who makes Arthur an offer. The scene should be primarily dialogue, interspersed with vivid description & scene setting. It should sow hints of the larger intrigue, stakes & dangers. Include Asimov's trademark big-and-small-picture world building and retrofuturistic classic scifi vibe. The chapter begins with Arthur aboard the transfer vessel, wondering just what he's gotten involved in. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The transfer vessel's air filtration system hums with a persistent mechanical drone, a sound like a thousand conspiracies whispering through ducts. Arthur Neegan sat strapped into a web-seat facing a blank bulkhead, its enamel worn smooth by generations of nervous knuckles. The ship’s window was a porthole no wider than a miner’s dinner plate, showing Mars as a patient red disc smoothing beneath low orbit. The hum seemed calibrated to keep thought formless, to turn questions to fog. It failed with Arthur. He counted his breaths. He thought of his plot, of the ridge and the wire fence and the green, scrubby lichen he’d coaxed from engineered spores, of the three modular hab units he’d bolted together himself, of the way the dust storm had sounded last week when it crawled across his roof like a living thing. He thought of the vein clipped by his survey drill—of the way the core sample had swallowed a Ga-Mc neutrino emitter like a candy in acid, spiking instruments with the casual indecency of new physics. And he thought of the insignia: the black sunbursts and stylized caduceus of the Antares Diplomatic Corps, printed on grey sleeves worn by men with holstered pulse-pistols and faces trained to neutrality. A steward in dull silver came down the aisle, glancing at tags. He paused at Arthur’s seat. “Mr. Neegan,” he said, with the soft Martian vowel drift, “we’ll be docking in twenty minutes. Your host asks that you refresh yourself.” The steward’s eyes flicked to the smudge on Arthur’s knuckles, where Azra dust had embedded and refused all solvents. “There’s a wash station aft.” Arthur flexed his hands in the webbing. “My host,” he said carefully, “has a name?” “We are instructed to refer to them as ‘the Benefactor,’” the steward said, like a man reciting the weather. “And we are orbiting which station?” “Antares Node Six,” the steward said. “For security, we do not announce docking alignments.” Arthur nodded. He’d heard of Node Six. A converted ore barge, dressed in armor and protocols. Diplomacy meant heavy bulkheads between the air and vacuum. He unbuckled, the webbing snapping back like a scold, and floated a little—Mars gravity ended at the hull; the Node would have spin. At the wash station, he stared at his reflection in the polished metal. Thirty-five, first generation, the slope of his father’s brow softened by the Martian sun. He scrubbed at the Azra dust until the skin prickled, but the faint greying remnant remained, a tattoo of fate. Back at his seat, the steward returned, offered a strip of nutrient gum and a placid smile. Arthur chewed it, tasting hydrolyzed protein and a synthetic mint that felt like advice to calm down. He counted again. He thought of the Corporates. He thought of the Government. He thought of the Interstellar Admiralty and of the Trade Unions and of the whisper that the Enlightened Path, the charismatic sect that preached transcendence through exposure to exotic states of matter, had arrived on Mars with pilgrim-passports and wealth. The vessel docked with a thump and a shiver that ran through the hull like a cat’s back. The emissions baffles clanked, his ears popped, and the seal light went green. The security men unlatched, moved with the economy of men whose gestures were rehearsed to death. One nodded to him, that same trained neutrality. “Mr. Neegan,” the nodding man said. “This way.” The corridor had a varnished smell, as if someone had hand-polished the metal, a retro touch in a place where nothing happened by accident. They passed a window showing Node Six’s central spindle, with modules rotating on spokes to simulate gravity. Earth fashion had brought back brass fittings and analog pressure needles, here rendered in stainless steel and digital ghosts. It was the future building a past it could live in. They stopped at a door with a viewport dimmed opaque. The nodding man pressed his palm to a plate. The door opened on velvet and gravity. The room beyond was all angles chosen to be comfortable. The walls had a woodgrain veneer, a table of polished something that looked like cedar but was not, a set of chairs with foot-loops for transitional comfort. There was a bar against one wall, where a carafe of water sat like a treaty. A woman waited at the table, hands folded. She was forty, perhaps fifty. Her hair was drawn back in a precise knot; her suit was the dark blue the Antares Corps wore when they wanted to be mistaken for idealists. Her only ornament was an old-fashioned wristwatch with a leather strap. Her face was unremarkable except for the eyes, which were the kind that had memorized maps. “Mr. Neegan,” she said, rising a fraction, which in spin-gravity was a gesture of respect and practicality both. “Thank you for agreeing to meet me.” “I was invited politely,” Arthur said. He took the chair opposite hers. The security men took positions at the door and near the bar. Their presence felt like punctuation. “Words are important,” the woman said, and there was a faint smile in her voice. “I am called Quinn. I speak here for an interested party.” “Not for Antares?” Arthur’s eyes flicked to the insignia on her sleeve. He kept his hands on the table where everyone could see them. He had learned that long ago, with creditors. “Not for Antares,” she said. “We rent their hospitality.” Arthur leaned back. The chair yielded like good arguments. “What is your interest, Ms. Quinn?” “Mr. Neegan,” she said, “you have something that the human sphere has been constructing myths around since the Era of Latency. The secret of controlled decay. Azra. Oh, we’ve had exotics. But Azra is portable, abundant—potentially—and obedient enough to play along with our white-coated sophistry. We have star-drives that graze the edges of it. We have reactors terrified of it. And you have a vein that could feed interstellar fleets.” “You’ve seen my assay?” She looked amused. “We’ve seen the invisible things your instruments did to the air around your hab. We’ve seen the minor fluctuations in your neighbor’s water recycler when your neutrino emitter went missing. Mr. Neegan, on Mars a secret is a thing that passes through one ventilation system and is heard in six households. Let me not waste your time with gentle lies: yes.” Arthur kept his gaze steady. “Then you know that the vein is under a pastoral lease registered in my name. It’s my personal land. It’s not corporate.” “That is precisely why you are here,” Quinn said, and poured water with a ritual carefulness. The carafe clicked against the glass. “If this were corporate, we would be speaking to a legal team and a board that wears ties to bed. If this were governmental, we would be sharpening the polite knives that cut in committees. But you are a person. Persons take offers.” She slid the glass toward him. He did not drink. “What kind of offer?” “The simple kind that is difficult to refuse,” Quinn said. “We propose to arrange for you secure custodianship of your claim in perpetuity. We propose to fund the extraction infrastructure, managed under a cooperative charter that leaves you primary stakeholder. We propose to redirect certain kinds of attention—unhelpful attention—from the more... ardent factions.” Arthur thought of the ardent factions. He had seen the posters: the children with haloed atoms. “What do you want,” he said, “in return for saving me from my good fortune?” “A monopoly of time,” Quinn said. “For three years. You will sell all extracted Azra to us, at a price that will make your first generation of descendants consider philanthropy. You will permit our scientists to operate at your site, and you will refrain from establishing direct relations with actors that might act prematurely.” “Prematurely,” Arthur repeated. “A polite word for ‘competitors.’” “A polite word for detonations,” Quinn said, and the trained neutrality slipped, showing a human edge. “Mr. Neegan, I don’t need to tell you what happens when a sect—any sect—puts an exotic in a reliquary. I don’t need to sketch the Admiralty’s appetites. The Interstellar Drive Consortium holds meetings with title deeds on the whiteboard. The Terra Council is composed of a hundred little republics and one hundred and one larger fears. Do you know that on Europa there are naval planners who have dreamed of a fleet fueled by Azra and driven through rebel satrapies like an icebreaker? Do you know that in the Belt, there is a group that calls itself the Prudent Extraction Society which has a constitution forbidding the word ‘later?’” Arthur held the water glass now, the condensation cold against his greyed fingers. “You make it sound as if I’m a dam holding back an entire ocean.” “You are a fissure,” Quinn said lightly. “We intend to be a valve.” He looked at her wristwatch. An analog face, a second-hand that ticked audibly in the hush. It was an affectation, a reminder that time can be counted, and therefore sold. “Why me?” he asked. “Why not take it? You brought armed men to my door in the dust. Diplomats, in uniform. Is this a test of my gratitude?” “We are very good at taking,” Quinn said, and again the steel showed. “We can requisition. We can say the word ‘security’ in a legislative voice and see if that doesn’t get you evicted by your own habitat authority. We can do those things because the moment demands it. But there is a cost, and some of us have learned to add. An expropriation on Mars is not an event; it is a weather system. It breeds resistance, guerrillas, a thousand tiny sabotages, and those—all of those—are noise when one wants to listen to a new metal speak. We want quiet. We want you to remain in your home. We want you grateful, perhaps, but we more keenly want you cooperative. A cooperative mind is a precise instrument, Mr. Neegan.” “And your party?” Arthur said. “Your Benefactor. Name them for me.” Quinn considered, the second-hand tapping out a thought. “We represent a coalition,” she said. “Moderates with teeth. Some in Antares who prefer treaties to wars, some in the Admiralty who lost a nephew at Saturn and don’t like the arithmetic that uses people as variables, some in the Consortium who understand that a premature monopoly invites piracy. The Terra Council has sent us a letter saying that under no circumstances shall a monopoly be tolerated. We have framed it.” “And the corporations?” Arthur asked, because his father had taught him to count every corner. “They will come to you with better numbers,” Quinn said. “They will promise you a refinery in your name and a boulevard named after your mother. They will deliver a contract that has a spine of iron and bones made of if. Mr. Neegan, I’m not romantic. I’m offering you a leash. But it is braided to fit, and the hand that holds it knows not to jerk.” He could feel the air filtration hum deeper here, a subsonic conversation between machines. He had a sense of Mars below, indifferent and patient, of the hab and the lichen and the fence that had always been more for himself than for keeping anything out. And the vein under it all, as if he had built his life over a sleeping volcano. “If I refuse?” he said. “Then when you return,” Quinn said, each syllable placed like a component on a board, “you will find your plot subject to a survey for habitat expansion. There will be a public consultation. Your Lazarean Bank will inform you that a charge has been laid against your dome by an entity with standing. Your next shipment of water won’t arrive because the carrier has temporarily lost their license. The Enlightened Path will send pilgrims who will camp on your ridge and chant until cameras arrive.
