And three different security forces will advise you to remain indoors at night.” “Diplomatic,” Arthur said. “Names are history’s jokes,” Quinn said, and the smile returned, genuine this time. “We are what we have to be.” “And if I accept?” “We begin today with an escrow account and two signatures,” she said. “You return to Mars with Antares escort. Your equipment arrives in crates stamped ‘Agricultural and Sanitation Supplies.’ A ring of bored men and women drink tea around your plot and deter visits by happening to be there. We lay plates, you dig. Our scientists will be civil, and if they are not, you will tell me, and they will learn the meaning of civility in the context of unemployment.” Arthur looked at the water. He thought of the ridge again, of the wind, of how a fence post had snapped two summers ago and he had repaired it with a piece of old machine casing and two bolts that did not match, and how proud he had been of the asymmetry because it was his. They would make his fence straight. That bothered him. He said, “Three years.” “Three years,” Quinn said. “And after, the market opens. We will have what we need then. Others will, too. But those three years could mean the difference between a hundred quiet decisions and one loud catastrophe.” “The Benefactor,” Arthur said. “They don’t want to be named because I might not like the names.” “You may learn them by their behavior,” Quinn said. “Or not. We all make our religions.” The air filtration hummed, of course. The second-hand ticked. The security men were very still; one had the habit of shifting his weight exactly every ninety seconds, which meant he had been trained not to shift his weight at all and was disobeying his training in a human way. Arthur drank the water, finally. It tasted of nothing. He set the empty glass down, precisely centered on the circle of condensation. “I’ll need to see the cooperative charter,” he said. “I’ll need to speak with whoever runs your logistics. I’ll need to choose the engineers at my site.” “You will choose them,” Quinn said. “We’ll veto only on grounds of security, declared in writing.” “And I want a letter,” Arthur said, surprising himself with the audacity, feeling the sentence assemble as he spoke it, “from your… coalition, to the Terra Council, lodged in the public record, stating that no claim shall supersede mine without due process.” Quinn’s eyebrows moved, which in her amounted to exclamation. “You read minutes, Mr. Neegan.” “I grew up watching men lose things on technicalities,” he said. “We can do that,” she said slowly. “It will cost us favors we may wish we’d kept. But we can do that.” He nodded. He felt as if he had just set a small stone on a very large lever. “Then we can do business,” he said, and reached out his Azra-grey hand. Quinn took it without looking at the stain. Her grip was dry, warm. “We will cause you troubles,” she said, almost kindly. “We will also prevent some. In history, that has been the bargain.” The door opened at some unseen signal. The steward reappeared, as if conjured by the watch’s tick. “Shall I bring the documents?” he asked. “Bring the documents,” Quinn said. As the steward went, Arthur glanced toward the porthole set into the far wall. It had been opaque when he entered, now clear as if someone had changed their mind about transparency. Mars wheeled below, red and old and amused, while Node Six turned a quiet circle in its own orbit, a brass instrument pretending to be a star. He wondered again what he had gotten himself into and realized that the question had grown too large to answer. He had not gotten into it; it had gotten into him, lodged under the skin like dust.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This response is a remarkably accomplished piece of science fiction that captures Asimov's style while maintaining its own distinct voice. The author has created a tense negotiation scene that effectively establishes the political complexities surrounding Arthur's Azra discovery. The prose demonstrates exceptional control, balancing vivid description with meaningful dialogue. The opening paragraph immediately establishes both setting and mood: "The transfer vessel's air filtration system hums with a persistent mechanical drone, a sound like a thousand conspiracies whispering through ducts." This sensory detail not only places us in a spacecraft but foreshadows the conspiratorial nature of what follows. Character development is handled with subtlety. Arthur is portrayed as a practical, cautious man with a miner's sensibility and enough intelligence to navigate a dangerous political situation. Quinn is masterfully rendered through small details - her precise hair, the analog wristwatch, and especially her speech patterns which reveal a calculating mind behind a diplomatic facade. The dialogue is particularly strong, avoiding exposition dumps while still conveying crucial information. Quinn's line "We are what we have to be" efficiently communicates volumes about her character and organization. The negotiation feels authentic, with each character maintaining consistent motivations and speech patterns. World-building is accomplished through small, telling details rather than information dumps - exactly as Asimov would do it. References to "the Enlightened Path," "the Terra Council," and "the Interstellar Drive Consortium" suggest a complex political landscape without overwhelming the reader. The description of Node Six with its "brass fittings and analog pressure needles" efficiently establishes both the technological level and aesthetic sensibilities of this future. The piece excels at creating tension through implication rather than explicit threat. The security men's "trained neutrality" and Quinn's carefully chosen words convey menace more effectively than overt threats would. The stakes are clearly established - Arthur's discovery could trigger interstellar conflict - without melodrama. If there are weaknesses, they're minor. Occasionally the prose becomes slightly ornate ("a sound like a thousand conspiracies whispering through ducts"), which might diverge from Asimov's typically more straightforward style. However, this doesn't detract significantly from the overall effect. The ending strikes the perfect note of ambiguous resolution. Arthur has made his deal, but the final image of Mars "red and old and amused" reminds us that human politics are temporary against the backdrop of cosmic time - a very Asimovian perspective. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Contemporary romance: Darkroom Revelations — Score: 91.3
Prompt:
Darkroom Revelations Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of Dani, a 25-year-old assertive art student known for her bold style and take-charge attitude in relationships. For the past semester, she's been quietly fascinated by Elliot (he/him), a 19-year-old boy in her experimental photography class. Dani has been intrigued by his unconventional masculinity: killer thrift-shop-nu-goth style, soft demeanour and quiet intellect. When they're paired for a final project requiring late nights in the darkroom, Elliot tentatively shares that he's been questioning his gender identity and expression. Set during one of these intimate darkroom sessions where the red light creates a confessional atmosphere. Explore Dani's complex attraction—her usual assertiveness complicated by her desire to protect Elliot's vulnerability, her excitement at witnessing his self-discovery, and her confusion about what this means for her own identity as someone typically attracted to more defined gender presentations. The narrative should capture the tender awkwardness of their conversations, Dani's internal struggle between taking charge and wanting to give Elliot agency, and the unexpected chemistry that develops as both find themselves in uncharted territory. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The red safelight made everything feel like it already had a memory. Grain in the air, chemical hiss, that faint metallic sweetness that clung to the back of my tongue since September. The darkroom was a bunker of black plastic sheeting and industrial sinks, a place where time slowed to the beat of the ventilation fan. We’d learned to count by drips, to speak without looking directly at each other, to pass things palm to palm with that half-ritual care. I liked how the red turned Elliot’s cheekbones into glass. I liked the blunt ends of his thrift-store bangles as they tapped the counter, careful music. I liked, against my will and training, the way I was thinking in liking. I’m not a liker. I go. I decide. I claim. He was rinsing a strip of negatives, his hands steady even though I could feel the tremor in him the way some people feel storm pressure. He wore a black button-down with tiny embroidered crosses, and a choker that would have looked ridiculous on most people but made him look low-key ceremonial. He had a softness to him that wasn’t fragility, exactly, more like he cushioned himself from the world. I’d spent the past semester tracking it the way I track light: edges, falloff, a hazard of focus. And now the final project had glued us together after midnight and made me his shadow. “You trust me with the fixer?” he asked, and he smiled, a small private thing that made my shoulder blades tighten. It meant he was teasing, and that meant we were okay. “I trust you with everything dangerous,” I said. “You’re the only one who actually reads labels.” He glanced at me, then away, like the light burned hotter for a second. “Black humor from the queen of improvisation.” “You say that like it’s not a viable methodology,” I said, and he laughed, breathy. We had settled into that rhythm—he’s careful and I’m the one who tricks stubborn machines into working by sheer attitude. But under it, tonight, something else was working. A hum. The kind of hum that, in a show, I’d try to find a way to manifest with neon and inflated trash bags. We moved in small orbits. I slid the tray toward him with the tongs. He dipped the paper, watching the image creep up like a bruise. The smell of stop bath made me think of high school dances in the gym, fluorescent and over-sugared. Memory is a prankster. My own reflection in the stainless steel was a shape with sharp earrings. He was the one who broke the stillness. “Can I say something weird?” “Yes. Always. I require it.” The hum rose. He swallowed. It was too dark to read his expression fully, but I watched the tiny twitch at the corner of his mouth, the way the light carved his profile into something almost Roman. Or maybe that was just me trying to make him into a statue because statues don’t move under you. “I’ve been… trying on names,” he said. “Not, like, out loud. In my head. Seeing which ones stick to the sides.” Names. The word made something in my sternum loosen and tighten at the same time. I forced my hands to keep moving. “Okay.” “I haven’t told anyone,” he said. “My roommate thinks I’m in a cult because I’ve been labeling things in neutral terms. ‘The garment. The timepiece.’” He laughed again; it curdled quickly. “It’s just— I don’t know what to do with—” He gestured at his body, his mouth, the air. “This.” I’m supposed to be good in situations like this. My friends call me when they need someone to send the email that gets results, to talk down a creep at a show opening, to decide what to order when nobody can choose. Take charge, make it better. But this was different. There are things you can’t muscle. The red light made him look like he was already bleeding and I knew he wasn’t, that it was a cinematic lie, but I still felt that unhelpful urge to bandage. “What does it feel like?” I said, keeping my voice level, curious, the way I talk to subjects who are about to cry in front of my camera. My wrists buzzed. He considered. The fan hummed, the sink gurgled. “Like… You know when you were a kid and you’d put on someone else’s sweater, and it was too big, and you could hide your hands in the sleeves, and that felt safe? But then also you couldn’t do anything useful with your hands, and that felt wrong? Like that. And sometimes the sweater is too tight instead, and I can’t breathe.” He grimaced. “Sorry. I’m mixing metaphors.” “No, that’s sexy,” I said, and I blushed about it immediately, which annoyed me more than the fact that I said it. I don’t blush. I turn blush into a weapon. “I mean, that’s—to me—compelling as an image. Also accurate.” He grinned, the brief relief of it cracking something inside me. “Trust the art student to make it an image.” “I contain multitudes,” I said, and the truth of it landed, and with it a bite of confusion. Because I usually contain a very organized set of multitudes. I like pretty hard edges. I like men who are uncomplicated in their masculinity because that makes it easier to play the game I’m good at—domineering but affectionate, queen-of-the-castle energy, clear roles so I can perform excellence inside mine. Elliot disrupted that. The soft wrists, the black eyeliner, the way he said “film” like it was a prayer, the way he apologized to a moth. The part of me that would normally just push—Take him home, make decisions—stuttered. His vulnerability was not a flaw but a helium balloon I didn’t want to pop. I held the tongs over the developer and watched deities emerge on paper—his shoes in a puddle, my hand reflected in a window, a portrait of our professor’s hands that had come out accidental and perfect. “Have you tried saying a name out loud?” I asked, softer. He shook his head, then nodded, then made a tiny exasperated noise. “Not here. Bathroom mirror sometimes, but then I feel like I should be doing it with—like—witnesses.” “You have me,” I said, before I knew I was going to say it. It came out like a contract. He looked up quickly. The light caught in his eyes like you could scoop it out. “I don’t want you to feel responsible for—” “Stop,” I said, reflexively, then caught myself. “Sorry. I mean—don’t do that thing where you manage me managing you.” He laughed. “Noted.” He set the next sheet into the developer and we both leaned over it, shoulder to shoulder. Our sleeves almost touched. I could feel the heat of his arm through fabric. It occurred to me that if I leaned one inch left, we’d be touching, forearm to forearm, and I wouldn’t know whether to name that contact as comfort or desire. The eccentric thrill of not knowing made me breathless. “What names?” I asked. He said one, then another. They sounded strange in his mouth, like instruments he hadn’t tuned yet. One of them landed in my ear with a little spark. I nodded. “That one,” I said. “I like the way you say it.” I had this sudden urge to go to the registrar’s office and change records, to call his mother and make her practice the syllables. “Why?” he asked. “It fits your face,” I said. “It makes your jaw look dangerous.” “My jaw?” He laughed in disbelief, touched his chin, and I had to stop myself from catching his hand midair, from turning his palm to my mouth. I put the sheet into stop. Vinegar stung my sinuses. I wanted, simultaneously, to kiss him against the drying rack and to draw a chalk circle around him that no one else could cross. The contradiction infuriated me. Power is clean when you aren’t emotionally compromised. This was not clean. “Do you—” he began, and at the same time I said, “Can I—” We both stopped, embarrassed. He gestured like, after you. I shook my head—no, you. He inhaled. “Do you ever… feel like you only know how to want certain… types? And then something else shows up and it’s like the syntax breaks? Like you can’t diagram the sentence anymore?” My throat clicked. “Every day of this week.” It came out too fast, too honest. I was forty percent relief and sixty percent panic. He exhaled like he’d been holding it for days. “Because I keep catching myself—” He paused. “I like it when you tell me what to do in here.” He looked at the tray, nowhere near my face. “But I don’t know yet if that’s—like—a thing I want, or just because you know what you’re doing and that’s hot. Or both. And also I don’t know what ‘boy’ means to me if I want that. If I’m allowed. It feels like I need permission but also permission seems like a trap.” The words hit every nerve I’d collected over the semester. I’m good at telling people what to do. It’s not just a personality trait; it’s an art. Negotiating consent, reading micro-moods, turning a moment so it catches light. But he didn’t need a director. He needed a partner. The red light throbbed. My palms itched. “Okay,” I said, slow. “So maybe… we don’t decide the system first. Maybe we test exposures.” He smiled, and I realized I was flirting in my lab dialect. “Test strips,” he said. “Always,” I said. “You set the parameter, you tell me when to stop. You can say ‘stop’ whenever. You can say ‘more’ whenever.” His breath hitched, and I felt the echo of it in my body. The composed part of me, the one that curates outfits like armor, almost scolded me for stepping into this without a full schematic. But another part—curiosity, hunger, care—answered back: he is not a project, but we can make something anyway. He nodded, small. “Okay. Can we… start with you saying my name?” I said the name that had sparked in my ear. I said it like it had been here all along. He shivered, and then grinned, an unselfconscious thing that made me briefly want to cry. “And again?” he asked, quieter. I said it again, this time letting myself put a little command in my tone. He closed his eyes. The silence was so full that when a loud thwack sounded, we both jumped. I looked down and watched in slow horror as the box of photo paper I’d left with the lid ajar emitted the sickly sigh of a patient dying. The top sheets flashed gray, then a sick, uniform fog as the ambient red betrayed its own rules. I lunged, slapped the lid on, but it was too late. The damage was done; you can always smell wasted paper, a weird sweet rot. “Shit,” I said, and then laughed, because of course. The universe did not want me to have any illusions about control tonight. “I’m so sorry,” he said, as if he’d knocked it. He hadn’t. It was my fault. I’ve always made a case for cockiness; this was one of those dumb errors you make when your brain is elsewhere. “Don’t be,” I said. “I did that. That’s on me.” I peeled back the top sheet to confirm: uniform gray, a square of nothing. He looked stricken anyway, like we’d lost something more valuable than paper. “We can still salvage some of the session,” I said, rallying. “We’ve got enough for test strips, and the rest we can print tomorrow morning if we charm Marisol.” I forced brightness into my voice. “Which I can do. I have compromising information on her third-year crush.” He was still frowning. “You don’t have to fix everything.” “Shut up,” I said, and softened it with a smile he couldn’t fully see. “I like to.” He hesitated, then smiled back. “I know.” We cut the ruined paper into strips like making do was a sacrament. There was a tenderness in the waste, a weird intimacy in admitting we’d messed up. The room felt closer now, and I felt—if not smaller, then thinner-skinned. Less queen, more person. “Say it again?” he asked, after a while, as I slid a strip into developer. There was hunger in it, but not just the bright kind. The human kind. The kind you feel when you watch something blurry sharpen in the tray. I did. I let it be both an offering and a request. He breathed with it, like we were counting together. Call, response. We were doing something risky without touching. “Are you—” I began, and this time I pushed. “Are you okay with me liking you this much?” The sentence surprised me by coming out bare. No lace, no jokes. He leaned his hip against the counter. The red light made the line of his mouth a soft curve. “I think,” he said, “I’m okay with it if I get to like you back in my way. While I figure out what ‘my way’ is.” Relief and heat and confusion braided together. I nodded, even though he could probably hear the movement more than see it. “Deal,” I said, and it felt like an art critique where someone finally saw the thing I did that I didn’t know I was doing. We worked, then, in a rhythm we built together. He’d ask me to say his name; I’d ask him to tell me to wait before moving the tray. He’d decide when to pull the strip. I’d decide which contrast filter to try. The pictures came up like secrets. Some failed completely and that was fine. The ruined stack sat like a reminder: some exposures go too long. Some things fog. It’s not the end of the world; it’s just part of the process. You learn to cut out the salvageable parts and make something new with them. When we finally washed our hands and turned on the white lights, we both squinted, raw. He looked different in the bright—no illusions, just skin. He looked like someone who could make and unmake himself and let me watch. I felt like someone who could take up a little less space and still be huge. “Tomorrow?” I said. He nodded. He said his name again, with a little more confidence. I said it back. It sat between us like a developing image you already know you’re going to love, even if it dries with edges you didn’t expect. We stepped out into the hallway, carrying wet prints that dripped onto the linoleum like a trail we could follow back.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative successfully captures Dani's perspective as she navigates her attraction to Elliot during their darkroom sessions. The piece excels in creating a distinctive voice for Dani that reflects her assertive personality while revealing her vulnerabilities when confronted with Elliot's gender exploration. The darkroom setting is masterfully utilized as both physical space and metaphor. The red safelight creates the "confessional atmosphere" requested in the prompt, and the author cleverly weaves photography terminology into the narrative as metaphors for the characters' emotional states. The chemical processes of developing photographs parallel the development of their relationship and Elliot's identity. The characterization is nuanced and complex. Dani's internal conflict between her usual assertiveness and her desire to give Elliot agency is well-portrayed: "The part of me that would normally just push—Take him home, make decisions—stuttered." The narrative effectively explores how Elliot's gender questioning challenges Dani's understanding of her own attraction patterns. The dialogue feels authentic and reveals character. When Elliot says, "I don't want you to feel responsible for—" and Dani interrupts with "Stop," then catches herself, it demonstrates her struggle to balance her natural dominance with respect for Elliot's autonomy. The prose is elegant without being overwrought. Sensory details like "Grain in the air, chemical hiss, that faint metallic sweetness that clung to the back of my tongue" create immersion. Metaphors are fresh and appropriate to the characters: "I liked how the red turned Elliot's cheekbones into glass." The narrative builds emotional complexity through Dani's contradictory feelings: "I wanted, simultaneously, to kiss him against the drying rack and to draw a chalk circle around him that no one else could cross." This tension drives the story forward. The incident with the ruined photo paper serves as an effective plot device that reveals character and advances the relationship. It shows Dani's fallibility and creates a moment of vulnerability that deepens their connection. The ending avoids simplistic resolution while offering emotional satisfaction. The relationship remains in development—like a photograph not yet fully processed—but with a sense of hopeful possibility. A few minor weaknesses: occasionally the metaphors become slightly strained, and there are moments where the introspection slightly slows the narrative momentum. However, these are minor issues in an otherwise accomplished piece. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 19 Emotionally Complex: 19 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 19.0, Emotionally Complex: 19.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Contemporary romance / drama: Stolen Moments in Roma — Score: 90.9
Prompt:
Contemporary Romance / Drama: Stolen Moments in Roma. Write a series of interconnected short scenes and dialogues that span a single day in modern-day Rome, in narrative form. This will form the beginning of a larger story. Alessandra, a fiery, independent Roman woman who works as a motorcycle courier, nearly collides with Ben, a somewhat clumsy, overly polite British academic on sabbatical, who is engrossed in a guidebook near the Trevi Fountain. The initial encounter is a clash of cultures and personalities – Alessandra is all sharp wit and rapid-fire Italian, while Ben is flustered apologies and awkward attempts at speaking the language. However, as they sort out the near-miss, a spark of unexpected humor and connection emerges. Alessandra, it quickly becomes clear, is a whirlwind of energy and mischief. She's a self-admitted troublemaker with a secret penchant for kleptomania, a detail she doesn't explicitly reveal, but which manifests in subtle, daring acts throughout the day. She impulsively decides to take Ben on a wild, unsanctioned tour of Rome, dragging him in some specific instances far outside his comfort zone. Ben, despite his initial apprehension and inherent politeness, finds himself utterly captivated by Alessandra's unapologetic spirit and zest for life. He is drawn into her orbit, a willing participant in increasingly outlandish situations, a quiet rebellion brewing beneath his scholarly exterior. The narrative should primarily consist of short, vivid scenes and dialogue exchanges, revealing their contrasting personalities and backgrounds, and the growing, ambiguous tension between them. Ben is captivated by Alessandra's energy and the thrill of breaking free from his routine. There's a clear sense that Alessandra is toying with Ben, pushing his boundaries and enjoying his reactions, but her own feelings remain somewhat enigmatic. The day should be a rollercoaster of exhilarating, slightly dangerous, and humorous moments, leaving Ben completely disoriented but utterly smitten. Explore the underlying tension & chemistry between them, culminating in some payoff as they part ways (or not -- your choice). Include this detail: Write in narrative prose, using immersive storytelling. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The near-collision happens at noon, in the white roar of the Trevi Fountain, where coins arc and dreams are exchanged for copper. Alessandra threads her motorcycle through the crowd the way a needle pulls a bright thread through stubborn cloth—impatient, deft, humming under her breath. There’s a colorful scratch along the bike’s gas tank, a flash of teal and fuchsia like a bruise turned festive. From some unnamed escapade. She wears that the way she wears everything: with a grin you don’t dare question. Ben stands almost in her path, guidebook open, lips moving as he tries to sound out “Acqua Vergine” like a schoolboy. He’s neat even in the heat, sleeves cuffed, hair ungovernably earnest, tote bag with a university crest slung over his arm. “Attenzione!” she barks, leaning on the horn. He looks up, flings himself sideways with the reflex of someone who’s never dodged anything faster than a library trolley. The bike skids, settles. Alessandra’s boot hits cobblestone, steady as a dancer coming off a spin. “I am so terribly, terribly—” he begins. “Don’t apologize yet,” she counters, cutting the engine. “First figure out if you broke your legs. Then you apologize.” “I—my legs—seem intact,” he says, patting himself down as if inventorying limbs. “My guidebook, however—” She plucks the guidebook from where it’s fallen, blows a kiss of dust off the cover, and hands it back. “Su Roma? Englishman’s shield,” she declares, tapping it. “What’s your name, cavaliere dello scudo?” “Ben,” he replies, flushed, trying to decide whether he’s supposed to bow. “Benjamin, technically.” “I’m Alessandra,” she says, and her mouth lingers on the consonants as if each one is a dare. “You were reading to the fountain, Benjamin? She is old; she knows the story already.” “I was… verifying a detail,” he says, weakly. “I like to be accurate.” She squints at his tote. “Oxford?” “Cambridge,” he corrects, as if it matters somewhere beyond his skull. “On sabbatical. Well, holiday. Well, sabbatical and holiday.” “Sabbatical and holiday,” she repeats, savoring his hedging like a sweet. “Perfect. Do you like to ride, Benjamin?” “I—ride? Horses, a long time ago. Bicycles. Not—oh.” Her gaze has gone to his shoes. Sensible, decent, the shoes of a man who ties knots carefully. “Come,” she says, instead of asking. “I nearly killed you. The least I can do is show you where to live dangerously. Hop.” He hesitates, then adjusts his glasses, and hops. It is the hop of a man whose body disputes his brain’s permission. He ends up behind her, hands hovering in polite no-man’s-land until she reaches back, catches his wrists, and plants them firmly on her hips. His breath hitches. She grins. The engine trembles awake. They slip through traffic like a rumor. He discovers Rome at waist level: bread smells and wet stone and a thousand shouted ciao!s flaring and fading. Alessandra laughs at lane markers, at red lights that mean maybe, at a man in a suit eating gelato with a spoon he pulled from his pocket. “He always carries a spoon,” she says, like a naturalist. “You never know when dessert will happen.” They stop at a light that drips sunlight. Ben leans forward, voice just under the buzz of the engine. “Is this—strictly speaking—legal?” “No,” she says. “But it is correct.” The light blossoms green. “Hold tight, professore.” He does. There’s a thrill to being a woman’s cargo. She takes him to a coffee bar with no sign and less patience. The countertop is burnished by elbows, the barista’s eyebrows are a religion. Alessandra slams coins down, drags Ben forward by the sleeve. “Un caffè per me, americano per lui,” she says, and when he stiffens at the word, she smirks. “The drink, caro. Not your citizenship.” He tries to pay, but she’s faster, a coin already tipping the saucer’s edge. She has the hands of a thief, though Ben doesn’t know that word yet; he only notes the nimble grace of her fingers, the slight tilt of her wrist as she pocketed a sugar packet with the absentmindedness of a magpie. “You do this daily?” he asks, cradling his cup, trying not to wince at the heat, at the boldness of black coffee that doesn’t care if he approves. “I do everything daily. And then often at night.” She tosses back her espresso like an insult. “You take notes?” “I take… mental notes,” he lies. “Some physical.” “Write,” she advises. “Otherwise stories escape. They don’t like cages. But they like nets.” He looks at the colorful scratch along the tank outside, catching the light like a scar with a sense of humor. “How did that happen?” She holds his gaze. “A door opened where it should not have been. And then someone laughed.” “Was it you?” “Always.” She drags him away, leaving a stirred sugar packet on the counter, minus one that sleeps in her pocket. They detour through an alley where laundry makes flags of ordinary lives. A cat judges them from a windowsill. Alessandra stops to exchange greetings with a florist who kisses her cheeks and calls her “peste,” pest. She steals a carnation with theatrical flourish, and the florist pretends not to see. “For you,” she tells Ben, tucking it behind his ear. It looks ridiculous and right. “I feel conspicuous,” he says. “Good. Conspicuous means you exist.” Her hand remains a second too long against his temple, then drops. “Come. The best view is illegal.” They end up on a roof. She knows which gate is broken, which staircase is friendly, which ladder trusts her weight. Ben follows in a sweat of fear and fascination, climbing into blinding sky. The city spills in every direction, domes like thoughts, the river a moving secret. Someone has left a broken chair up here. Someone has left a bottle. Alessandra perches on the ledge as if it loves her. “You do know this is trespassing,” Ben says reflexively, and hears himself, and wishes he didn’t always carry the rulebook in his throat. She leans back, palms flat on warm tile, face upturned to the light. “Only if you’re caught. And even then, only if you are boring about it.” His laughter startles him, as if a bird had flown out of his ribcage. He sits. They share the bottle with two paper cups she produces from nowhere, cups that have a coffee shop’s logo he recognizes and wonders if she asked permission to take. The wine tastes like an afternoon meant to be squandered. “What do you do, Benjamin?” “Teach,” he says. “Read. Argue with footnotes. I’m here to… not do those things for a while, theoretically.” “And yet you hold your cup like a citation.” She mimics his grip, thumb where his is. He loosens, just to have her adjust him again. “And you?” She considers. The wind tosses her hair, turns it into a flag for chaos. “Today? I was going to deliver two packages and flirt with a police officer and maybe take a nap. Now I am stealing your afternoon.” “Successfully,” he says softly. They watch swifts stitch the sky. Someone plays a violin nearby and gets it wrong so beautifully it’s perfect. His phone vibrates with an email and he, with deliberation, turns it face-down. Her smile acknowledges the ritual, as if to say: good, you are trainable. “What’s the oddest thing you’ve delivered?” he asks. “Keys to a house someone was being locked out of,” she says. “Love letters written by two people who did not speak the same language. A dress, white as a threat. A dog once—tiny, insulting dog. He bit me.” She shows a crescent scar on her knuckle. “I bit him back.” “I don’t believe you.” “That’s wise,” she says. “Belief is a leash.” They climb down. He wants to hold her waist again, and he does, and the city becomes a blur of sun-hot stone. She runs a red light and winks at a policeman who should stop her and instead tips his hat. Ben is both scandalized and relieved at how easily rules bend around her like reeds. He lowers his guard the way you lower your voice in a church. At Campo de’ Fiori she cheerfully heckles a fishmonger into giving her a handful of basil “for good luck,” and when the basil disappears into her bag while she flirts with an old woman buying artichokes, Ben tells himself he mis-saw it. At a stand of bric-a-brac, she spins a tarnished lighter, flicks it once, twice, then pockets it, then later pulls from that same pocket a crumpled bus ticket with a flourish. He can’t tell if she’s hiding anything or everything. They eat standing up, paper cones of fried zucchini blossoms burning their fingers. Oil kisses their sleeves. She licks her thumb and presses it to his wrist to wipe away a stain; her touch brands. “You’re too clean,” she says. “I’m trying,” he replies. She eyes him. “To be dirty?” “To be brave.” “Brave is easier,” she says. “It doesn’t ask you to be good.” He follows her into a church just for the coolness. A sign says silence; they obey in the way of tourists who can’t help narrating in their heads. Candles pool wax and shadow. A nun with a walk like water glides by and frowns at Alessandra’s bare knees. Alessandra bows theatrically, then kneels in a pew with a seriousness that startles him. “What do you pray for?” he whispers. “For lightness,” she says, without opening her eyes. “For mischief that doesn’t ruin the right things.” Then she looks at him, suddenly sharp. “What do you pray for?” “For permission,” he says before he can stop himself. “From whom?” He shrugs. “Everyone.” She touches his cheek, fleeting as a moth. “Then ask the wrong person.” Outside, the sky is a bruise turning peach. She checks her phone, makes a face like a cat discovering tap water. “I have to go,” she says. “Work that is actually work.” He tries not to be obvious about deflation. “Right. Yes. Of course. Thank you for… everything.” “We’re not finished.” She says it like a threat disguised as a promise. “You still have to see where the water runs.” “The aqueducts?” “Your thoughts.” She swings a leg over the bike, then pauses. “Come. One more thing.” They end at the Tiber. The river is sullen and beautiful. A man paints on cardboard. A kid kicks a football that nearly takes out a couple kissing against a wall that’s seen worse. Alessandra leads him down to a landing where old steps, slick and ancient, descend into murky water. She dangles her hand until her fingertips skim the surface, gasps at cold like a delighted child. “Give me your watch,” she says. He recoils. “My watch?” “It’s drowning time. Two minutes without measuring anything will not kill you.” He unbuckles it, reluctantly. She takes it without looking, slips it into her jacket, and he feels a peculiar relief, like he’s shed a skin. She offers her hand. He takes it, and together they knock their knuckles against the river, as if to ask if it’s home. “You stole my watch,” he says. “Borrowed,” she says. “You can have it back when you forget to want it.” They climb. They walk. She steers him by the elbow into shade when tourists clog the light. He learns the exact sound she makes when she sees a pigeon strut like a cardinal: a stifled snort. She learns that he knows a ridiculous number of Latin inscriptions and translates them without superiority, as if he’s introducing her to cousins. Dusk drapes itself over everything. They find a gelato shop with a queue like a pilgrimage. She cuts, installing herself near the front with the shamelessness of someone practiced at being forgiven. She orders pistachio for him without asking—“Your face says nutty with a hint of regret”—and lemon for herself, and when he goes to pay, she has already walked away, two spoons tucked into her hair like pins. He doesn’t see the way her hand lingers near the tip jar and then withdraws, empty; he only sees her glance back to make sure he follows. They stand on a bridge and eat slowly, as if time’s viscosity has changed. Streetlights braid themselves into the river. The day has been absurd, reckless, tender. Ben is disoriented and delighted, a man who stepped out of a scholarly footnote and stumbled into a poem. “I won’t keep you,” he says, when they’re down to the last cold bites. He means: I want to be kept. “You are very keepable,” she says. She takes a final fierce mouthful, tongue against spoon, and there’s a kind of dare in it. “Will I see you again?” He hears need in his voice and lets it sit there, honest. She walks to the bike, taps the colorful scar on the tank as if to knock on memory. “I’m not hard to find,” she says. “I’m where the noise is.” “That’s everywhere.” “Exactly.” She pulls his watch from her jacket, weighs it in her palm. For a second he thinks she’ll slide it onto her own wrist and smirk. Instead, she holds it to his ear. The tick seems louder than it should be, the heart of a small thing amplified. “Time,” she says, soft now, as if speaking to both of them. “It likes to be stolen. It gets bored of being counted.” She buckles the watch back on him. Her fingers rest against the inside of his wrist longer than necessary. The pulse there makes a question of his skin. “Thank you,” he says. It’s not about the watch. “Don’t be boring, Benjamin.” She swings onto the bike, kicks it into being, the engine answering like an animal that knows its name. He does something that surprises them both. He steps forward and, with the careful clumsiness that is his signature, presses his mouth to her cheek, just at the curve where laughter would begin. She smells like lemon and petrol and a daring he hasn’t learned yet. Her expression flickers from mockery to something else, then back. She catches his collar, pulls him in the barest fraction closer, and for a heartbeat their noses almost touch. “Careful,” she murmurs. “You might like this.” “I already do,” he says, too quick. She releases him and laughs, a sound like pockets full of stolen coins. “Good,” she says. “Then write it down.” She is gone in a ribbon of noise and color, and he stands on the bridge with melting sweetness on his tongue and his watch ticking faithfully, treacherously, on his wrist. He looks at the scratch on the day she left on him, the little dent on his clean life. He touches his cheek, where her almost-kiss isn’t and is. The river takes its dark time. People throw their hours into it as if they’ll get them back. He doesn’t move for a long moment, as if stillness could make the city pivot around him again, bring her back by centripetal force. Then he laughs—startled, young—and turns his guidebook into a pillow under his arm. The page with “Acqua Vergine” is creased. He does not smooth it. He finds a pen, writes on the inside cover. Stolen moments in Roma, day one. Below the words, without meaning to, he draws a line: a small slash in teal and fuchsia. A bruise made festive. A promise.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece is a remarkably well-crafted response to the prompt, delivering a vivid, immersive narrative of a day in Rome between two contrasting characters. The writing demonstrates exceptional control of language, with prose that is both lyrical and precise, creating a sensory-rich experience without becoming overwrought. The characterization is particularly strong. Alessandra emerges as a fully realized character—impulsive, mischievous, and enigmatic with her klepto tendencies subtly woven throughout (stealing sugar packets, basil, possibly a lighter). Ben is equally well-drawn as the proper academic gradually seduced by spontaneity. Their contrasting personalities create natural tension and chemistry that evolves believably throughout the day. The dialogue sparkles with authenticity and wit. Lines like "Time likes to be stolen. It gets bored of being counted" reveal character while advancing thematic elements. The exchanges feel natural yet purposeful, each revealing something about the speakers. The narrative structure effectively delivers a series of interconnected scenes that build momentum while maintaining coherence. The piece moves from the Trevi Fountain through various Roman locations, each vignette adding layers to both characters and their developing connection. The pacing is excellent, with moments of action balanced by quieter, reflective scenes. The imagery is consistently strong, with sensory details that ground the reader in Rome: "bread smells and wet stone," the "white roar of the Trevi Fountain," gelato "burning their fingers." These details create an authentic sense of place without resorting to guidebook descriptions. The prose demonstrates sophisticated control, with metaphors that illuminate rather than distract: Alessandra threads her motorcycle through crowds "the way a needle pulls a bright thread through stubborn cloth." The writing maintains a consistent voice throughout—lyrical but not purple, with moments of beautiful insight that feel earned. The ending strikes the perfect note of ambiguity and possibility. It doesn't force a romantic resolution but leaves the reader with the sense that something significant has begun. The final image of Ben writing "Stolen moments in Roma, day one" suggests both reflection on the day and anticipation of what might follow. If there are weaknesses, they're minor. Occasionally a metaphor might reach a bit too far, and there are moments where the prose risks becoming too self-consciously literary. However, these instances are rare and don't detract from the overall quality of the piece. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 19 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 19.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Cozy sci-fi: The Last Outpost — Score: 93.4
Prompt:
Cozy sci-fi The Last Outpost Nettle (or Nets to her friends) bartends at The Last Outpost -- a lazy hub for miners and merchants in an asteroid belt on the Andromeda outer rim. Escaping from her past life, Nets found a home here at the Outpost. They have, thus far, tolerated Net's flaws which she tries to keep in equilibrium with her assortment of talents. Her evenings involve chatting with patrons, negotiating the drama, intrigue, problems & love lives of the diverse crowd that filter through the Outpost. Tonight is no different, at least, until a frazzled looking stranger, tentacled dreads askew, quietly plops down at the bar: "Vega whisky, neat. Better make that a double." Write a chapter in this story. Establish conflict for narrative interest. Don't resolve the conflict within this chapter. Aim for about 60% dialogue. First person, present tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The Overwatch light over the bottles is a long soft ribbon, amber and cold, the way the Outpost likes to pretend it’s a hearth. I polish a glass because it gives my hands somewhere to be while my head is everywhere else. Nights cycle into mornings out here without much ceremony; chronos are personal, time is a rumor. The Last Outpost hums like a cat with a bad conscience—air recyclers, mining skiffs docking on lazy vectors, a card game five tables back erupting in laughter without anyone smiling. “Two mint hydrates and a sunken Nebula,” I say, sliding the stripe of credit across the rail for the pair of drillers who look like brothers and probably aren’t. They grin with identical teeth. “Keep the mint sprigs, you’ll need the vitamins,” I add. One of them blushes at my fake scolding and flicks me an extra chip for luck. I pocket it. It’s not luck, it’s gravity. “Netts!” Karo yells from a booth where he’s using three limbs for poker and the fourth to scratch his collar seam. “When’s the patcher gonna fix the vent? It smells like hot socks.” “Smell is ninety percent memory, Karo. You’re smelling you.” I pull down the bottle of Vega, its glass heavy as a promise, and top off a pair of shot glasses for the mechanics at the far end. The door hisses a stuttering breath. Portside lock hasn’t been the same since a tug captain tried to bring a potted fern through at speed. A newcomer slips in and nobody looks up, because the Outpost has rules. The first is you mind your own business. The second is you mind everyone else’s without being obvious about it. They come up to the bar with their tentacled dreadlocks pulled back in a string that’s come loose, slate-gray skin and a scatter of silver across one cheek that could be freckles or a rash of stars. They sit like a dropped battery: heavier than they look. The tentacles unfurl for a second as they settle, then re-twist. Frazzled. There’s a clean panic to it, and the way they don’t meet my eyes is a different kind of alarm. “Vega whisky, neat,” they say, voice like fabric snagging on a nail. “Better make that a double.” “House policy says singles only until you tell me your name,” I say, because I’m not a cop but I like knowing who I’m feeding. Also because rules are comforting when your life depends on strangers not losing it. They hesitate a beat. “Nettle is the bartender, right?” “Depends who’s asking.” “I’m asking,” they say. “Name’s Solace.” They grimace. “Sol, if you prefer.” “We do prefer monosyllables.” I pour one double anyway because they look like someone who’s been practicing breathing all day and hasn’t gotten it right. The bottle sighs. “Trying to quit drama, Sol?” “Trying to quit getting followed,” they mutter, and toss the first half back in a clean snap. In the mirror behind the bottles I catch Karo looking. He’s got that expression he wears when a bearing goes hot. The mechanics at the end stop clinking their shots together. Someone on the upper catwalk laughs too loud at nothing. The Outpost hears an off note like a herd animal. Sol cradles the glass. “Nice place,” they lie. “You’ll like it better after your second,” I lie back. “Food?” “No.” “Air?” “Maybe later.” “Company?” They huff. It could be a laugh. “Hard pass.” I put a clean coaster under their glass and leave them to marinate while I pull three micrograv beers for a loader crew from Pygmy Nine. They pay in rad-worn credits that make the scanner cough and then accept scrip. When I circle back Sol’s shoulders have lowered by a centimeter. Progress. “Okay,” I say, low. “You said followed. Past tense or I should call a favor?” “Do you do that?” The tentacles twitch toward the ceiling like they can taste the vents. “Call favors?” “I collect them. Different habit.” Sol taps their finger against the rim. “I’m not here to bring you trouble.” “That sentence never, in the history of flung humans and adjacent life, has been true.” “Adjacent life.” They eye me. “You’re charming.” “I’m bored,” I say. “Don’t make me clean. Tell me how big.” “Not… huge.” Sol’s gaze flicks to the door, then the shadow that isn’t a shadow under the far holo menu. “Just persistent.” “Local persistent or docking-bay persistent?” “Belt persistent.” “Ah,” I say. “We get the fun ones.” “Look, I just need an hour,” Sol says. “A place to sit where the feed can’t ping me and where nobody thinks to look. I’ll pay.” They slide a strip across. It’s thick—heavy with million-credits. Minted this cycle. Clean. “Why’s it mint?” I ask before my better judgment can put its hand over my mouth. Sol inhales, then spits it out. “Fine. I ghosted a collection. I made some people sweaty. I took something that was mine.” “For a person who’s trying not to bring me trouble,” I say, and hey, maybe I can help, maybe I can pretend I should. The glass in my hand squeaks under the rag. “You’re doing… poorly.” They give me a look that suggests their day has been composed entirely of poor. “You ever just try to be no one? And the universe refuses?” “I tried,” I say, and swallow the old thick memory of corridors with fabric walls and soft voices and sharper hands. “I failed. I’m a bartender.” “What do you charge for failure?” “More than you’ve got.” I lean in, lowering my voice. “You have ten minutes before whoever is feeling Belt persistent finds the Outpost in their search tree. It’s comfy, but it isn’t invisible. You can use a maintenance nook in the cold pantry, but the snow crabs get territorial.” “I hate crabs,” Sol says, without smiling. “They hate you back.” “I only need an hour.” “You’ll get fifteen,” I say. “Starting now. Finish your drink.” They do, and the tentacles on the right side of their head relax. That’s when a glass shatters somewhere behind me in the tangle of the bar back—sharp and mean. Half the room flinches on reflex. I don’t, but my shoulders remember. “All good!” I call, and Aria from the kitchen pops her head through the slit with an apologetic shrug and a dish towel bleeding glittering shards. “You need a second?” she mouths. “I need a hundred,” I mouth back, but wave her off. She vanishes. The air is different now. The Outpost is listening harder. Sol puts their empty down like it might explode. It doesn’t. “You have a back way?” “We have seven,” I say. “You can use number three. It looks like a drier for ballast moss. You’ll have to scoot.” “I can scoot.” I nod toward the end of the bar where the hatchmouth lives half-hidden behind a poster advertising a festival that never happens. I hit the mag-lock switch with my hip. “Go,” I say. “Wait for my knock.” Sol rises, center of gravity cautious, and slides off the stool. As they move, the door hisses again. The lock stutters, groans. It’s a horrible sound. It sounds like a warning and an argument both. The newcomer is all black fabric and modular armor with the edges filed down so they don’t scream military, but they whisper. Their face is ordinary, but ordinary in a way that’s been constructed—the exact right amount of forgettable. What gives them away is the shoes. Nobody wears polished boots out here. Not unless they brought them fresh, and nobody brings fresh boots to the Belt unless they think they’ll need to make a particular kind of impression. The boots are quiet. The Outpost goes quieter. “Nets,” Karo says under his breath, and I hear my name roll through the room like a marble looking for a slope. “Evening,” I say into the silence, smiling with half my teeth. “You’re late to happy hour.” The newcomer scans, not with their eyes, not really. With the posture of someone who expects a target to betray itself. Their gaze slides over Sol, slides over me, catches on the mirror and bounces. They take the stool that Sol vacated like they rehearsed it. Sol is halfway to the hatch—another three steps and they’ll be in the tunnel. Don’t look back, I will at them. Don’t. They don’t. “Vega,” the newcomer says. “Neat. Double.” “Singles until you tell me your name.” They consider pretending, then decide to play along. “Call me Gray.” “I’ll call you what your cred chip calls you,” I say, and pour them a single anyway. “You new to the Outpost?” My voice is air. I can be anyone you want until I’m not. “First time,” Gray says. The codex of polite lies. “I hear you keep it… friendly.” “We keep it neutral,” I correct. “Lots of air to share.” They take a sip, grimace like they weren’t expecting flavor. “Seen anyone matching this?” Gray slides a holo across. It flares to life on my rail, floating blue. It’s a face like Sol’s but less exhausted. The tentacles are braided tight. The silver on the cheek is a laugh. “I see a lot of faces,” I say, and keep my eyes on Gray’s without once letting them tick to the poster that breathes because the hatch behind it isn’t closed all the way, because the track sticks, because I have grease on my fingers and a future anyway. “Most of them are bad with names.” “Solace,” Gray says. “Last ping was two docks over. They came in hot. Disappeared. They have something that belongs to an investor who is not patient.” “Investors are famously patient,” I say. My hands are very calm. “We don’t do collections.” “Everyone does collections,” Gray says. “You just call it a tab.” “You want me to check the back?” I offer in my sweetest danger voice. “We have a lot of back.” Gray smiles. It’s a control panel lighting up. “Please.” I lift a brow toward Karo, who pretends to sneeze a yes, and toward the mechanics, who drop their shoulders a millimeter which means they’re ready to start a fight they don’t plan to finish. I lean into the slit to the kitchen. “Aria, darling,” I say, loud enough for the room to hear and quiet enough that the vent only grabs the edges. “We out of moss biscuits?” “We were never in moss biscuits,” she says, which is code for no one a problem is hiding where we usually hide problems. Okay. Sol is in number three. Which is the cold pantry adjacent to the condensers and the snow crabs. If I take Gray to number two, I can lose them in the coolant maze. If I get them under the heat coils, maybe their boots will finally squeak. “Be right back,” I tell Gray, and put out a saucer of bar nuts like it’s a spell. “Try not to recruit my patrons while I’m gone.” “I’d never,” Gray says, and watches me go like they are memorizing my skeleton. I slide down the bar, step over the misaligned plate near the ice well, and duck behind the festival poster. The hatch is ajar, just, a breath of cold on my knuckles. I shut it with a knee and turn left instead, into number two. Pipes thrumming. It smells like old copper and a Christmas that never happened. My body is a map of this place; my fear is a lantern in it. I rap once on the number three bulkhead—a stupid risk—and Sol raps once back, quick. Alive. I don’t say anything. No voice goes down that corridor. I keep moving, take number two’s ladder, drop into the dark between two ducts, and emerge into the hallway behind the kitchen like a ghost that tips. Aria gives me a look that says both I know and I wish I didn’t. “Shift drink,” she says, shoving a cup into my hand. “In a minute,” I say. “Keep an eye on Gray.” “Boots?” she asks. “Boots.” I pop back up behind the bar in less than twenty seconds with a story in my hands. Gray is sampling a bar nut, disdainfully. “We didn’t have moss biscuits,” I say. “Supply chain.” “You searched very fast,” Gray observes. “I’ve been doing this a long time,” I say, then lean on the rail. “And if you think the person you’re looking for would hide in a pantry, you’re very bad at this.” “People are reliable under stress,” Gray says. “They go to holes.” “I go to bars,” I say. “I noticed.” “You want another single?” They glance at the door. “I’ll take a tour.” “Not on the menu,” I say. They look at me like they want to peel me back to see what I’m hiding under. “Your owner—” “We don’t have one.” “—manager, then. Maybe they can be more accommodating.” “Good luck,” I say, and tilt my head toward the side stairs. “He’s up the catwalk, playing a losing hand.” Gray drags their gaze upward. Tash is indeed up there, losing politely, his long fingers moving chips that aren’t his in a way that makes people believe they are. He catches my glance, lifts his chin a millimeter. Don’t. I smile with the other half of my teeth. I wasn’t going to. Gray finishes their single, sets the glass down with a small click. It’s almost a courtesy. “If Solace reaches out,” they say, “tell them I can keep them breathing. For a while.” “For a price,” I say. “For a truth.” “Which one?” “The one they keep pretending isn’t theirs.” “Lot of those walk through my door,” I say. “They tip badly.” Gray’s mouth moves, not a smile, a calculation. “I’ll be around,” they say, tossing a coin of cred without watching where it lands. It doesn’t bounce. The Outpost hums. The door hisses. They leave. It takes ten long seconds for the air to start moving again, for Karo to blow the breath he was smothering, for the mechanics to clink their empty shot glasses together with exaggerated relief. Somebody in the back starts up the card shuffler again. The broken-glass glitter is gone from the pass, Aria already swept it, like it never happened. But it did. The sound is in my bones. I slide back to the hatch, flick the mag-lock twice. Knock: my pattern. Sol opens it a slit. Their eyes are bigger in the cold. “You have crabs,” they whisper. “They like your scent,” I whisper back. “Did you meet the gray one? He likes your scent.” “Who is he?” “Debt with legs,” I say. “What did you take?” Sol swallows. The tentacles shiver. “A seed.” “Like a plant?” “Like a ship,” they say. “Prefold. Grown.” The words are a kind of heresy. “It was mine. They licensed it out of my head without paying me. I just… repatriated.” “Sol,” I say, and I think I say it like a prayer, or a warning. “That’s not a small collection.” “I know,” they say. “But I don’t know who to trust, and the only person I trust told me to come here.” “Who?” They hesitate. “Your name comes up in bad places for good reasons.” I wish that were comforting. I wish I were someone who could be comforted by reputation. The Outpost creaks as a tug sidles up to dock. My hands know what to do—wipe, pour, smile—but my brain is already counting exits I haven’t even shown my regulars. “You have an hour,” I tell Sol, even though I promised fifteen. “You didn’t hear me say that. After that, I can get you to a person who takes seeds and makes them disappear.” “I don’t want it to disappear,” Sol says, and for the first time I see the blazing under the exhaust—the thing that animates them. “I want it to fly.” “Then you’re in the wrong bar,” I say, because honesty is a luxury and a trap. “But for now, you’re in a bar. Drink water. Pretend you’re ordinary.” Their mouth twitches. “I’m terrible at ordinary.” “Practice,” I say, and shut the hatch. I turn back to my bottles and my people and the hum that I tell myself is home. My hands find the Vega again, heavy as a promise I should have never made. I pour a single for someone who doesn’t know they want it yet, and I listen to my glassware like it’s going to tell me when the next crack will happen. The door will hiss again. It always does. That’s the thing about the Outpost: we pretend to be a hearth. We’re really an airlock. “Tash is going to love this,” Karo mutters as I slide by him to drop off a tray. “Tash is going to pretend he doesn’t,” I say. “Smile big.” “Who’s smiling?” he asks, and bares his teeth at the room like a wolf who took up knitting. “Everyone,” I say. “Everybody smile.” And we do, until Gray’s boots echo back up the corridor from somewhere they shouldn’t be, and my glass doesn’t break, but it thinks about it, and I don’t have time to finish the thought.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece is a remarkably well-executed first-person, present-tense chapter of cozy sci-fi that successfully establishes the setting of The Last Outpost and introduces compelling conflict. The author has crafted a rich, lived-in world with distinctive characters and a strong narrative voice. The prose is particularly impressive, with a distinctive noir-tinged style that fits perfectly with the bartender protagonist and the seedy-but-homey asteroid bar setting. Lines like "The Last Outpost hums like a cat with a bad conscience" and "I pocket it. It's not luck, it's gravity" establish both the setting and Nettle's character efficiently and memorably. The dialogue comprises roughly 60% of the text as requested, and it's consistently strong—natural yet distinctive, revealing character and advancing plot simultaneously. Each character has a unique voice, from Karo's casual familiarity to Gray's menacing formality. The dialogue never feels expository or forced. The conflict is well-established: Sol has stolen a "seed" (a ship design) from powerful people who want it back, and Nettle is now caught in the middle. The chapter ends with a clear sense of impending danger as Gray returns, creating effective tension without resolution. The world-building is subtle and effective, introducing concepts like "prefold" ships and "rad-worn credits" without overwhelming exposition. The author trusts readers to piece together the world from context clues rather than explaining everything. Character development is strong. Nettle is complex—capable and confident in her domain, but with hints of a troubled past. Secondary characters like Sol, Gray, Karo, and Aria are distinct and memorable despite limited page time. The relationships between characters feel lived-in and authentic. The pacing is excellent, balancing moments of tension with quieter character beats. The narrative flows naturally between dialogue, action, and internal reflection. The chapter maintains momentum throughout, with the stakes gradually escalating. The imagery is vivid and specific, creating a tangible sense of place. Details like the "amber and cold" Overwatch light, the stuttering door hiss, and the snow crabs in the cold pantry make the setting feel real and lived-in. If there are weaknesses, they're minor. Occasionally the prose veers slightly toward the purple side with metaphors that call attention to themselves, but these moments are rare and generally effective. The complex network of hidden passages and codes might be slightly confusing on first read, but this complexity serves the story's themes of secrets and survival. Overall, this is an exceptionally strong piece of writing that fulfills all the prompt requirements while creating a compelling narrative with memorable characters and a richly realized setting. The author has successfully created a chapter that stands on its own while clearly being part of a larger story that readers would want to continue. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 2 Weak Dialogue: 1 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 0 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19

+ Young adult drama: Gone South — Score: 88.2
Prompt:
Young adult drama Gone South Taylor is a 16 year old teen with a history of "concerning behavioural patterns" (or that's how the stupid smug school counsellor worded it on the phone call to Mom). It shouldn't be a surprise: When you live in a backwater town in Tennessee, your choices are: a. be mind-fuckingly bored, or b. invent some drama. Two days ago, Taylor came out to their family as trans. This disclosure was *not* in the category of invented drama -- it was, in fact, the real deal, and a long time coming. It didn't go well. The last 48 hours had been pure disaster. In a moment of desperate inspiration, Taylor had decided to get the hell out of dodge. And so an escape plan was hatched and executed within the space of 30 minutes. That was last night. Now Taylor was two states away, having been unceremoniously ejected from their hitched ride in downtown New Orleans. Write the next chapter in Taylor's story as they find their feet in this new environment. Tell the chapter over the course of their first day in New Orleans, in which Taylor meets another runaway with issues and secrets. Taylor navigates this new world, not knowing who to trust or what the dangers are. Write in Taylor's voice, and incorporate their internal monologue as they grapple with intense & conflicting emotions. Also incorporate dialogue with the interesting characters Taylor meets. First person, mixed tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The street is boiling. Not heat—though that too, the kind that turns your spine into a licorice whip—but sound. It’s noon and everything is already loud like the inside of a tin roof when it rains. People everywhere. The saxophone is the loudest thing, like a voice I don’t know but recognize anyway, slicing up the air and rearranging it into something you can breathe. I keep touching the straps of my backpack like I can make it part of me. It’s all I have: thrift-store hoodie even though it’s August, three pairs of socks, phone with fifteen percent battery and a cracked corner, the bottle of nail polish I stole from Walgreens back home because it had a stupid name (Bad Decisions Blue), and the photo of me and my brother from when we were eight and six, our faces smeared with birthday frosting. He texted once, at three a.m.: u okay? Nothing since. No one looks twice at me, which I’m taking as both a blessing and an insult. The saxophone player is older, with a beard that’s gone white and gray like driftwood and a newsboy cap that makes him look like he’s from a movie. He’s leaning into the notes like they’re a conversation he’s serious about. His tip jar (a coffee can with black marker writing: Thank U) is almost empty. There are beads on the street, ground into glittery dust. The air tastes like beignets and spilled beer and tourist sweat. I wonder if you can live on powdered sugar. Probably not. Probably. I stop when the song ends. The coffee can sits there like a mouth open for a dentist. My wallet has three crumpled singles. I put one in. He nods at me without breaking eye contact. His eyes are soft like warm bread. “You look like you need a shade more than me,” he says. His voice is low and sandpapery. “I’ve got sunscreen,” I lie. “And a hoodie.” “Fair.” His mouth tilts. “You from here?” “No.” I am suddenly aware of the accent I didn’t know I had until I started talking somewhere else. “Tennessee,” I say, and I hear how it does that thing with the vowels, lazy and stretched, like someone pulled saltwater taffy in my throat. “Mmm,” he says. “Welcome.” His mouth says it like he means it, like a blessing, like a church lady pressing a cookie into your palm. I don’t look behind me. If I do, I might turn into salt. I don’t know if my mom called the police. I don’t know if they can drag you back when you’re sixteen. Probably. I didn’t Google it. Why didn’t I Google it. A hand brushes my elbow. “Watch it,” I snap, but it’s a girl—no, kid—my age-ish, with hair that’s a frizzy halo the color of oak leaves in October. She’s wearing a tank top with a faded cartoon dinosaur lifting weights. Her eyes are almost the same green as the trash bags piled against a brick wall. The good kind of green. She does a little backstep, hands up. “Sorry,” she says. Southern but not my kind of Southern. “You were about to walk into Bicycle Dude.” “Bicycle dude?” I ask, and then a guy appears, pushing a bike with a basket full of plastic cups. He whistles the sort of off-key whistle that makes your heart crumple. He says, “Hot today,” to no one, to everyone. “See?” she says, aiming her chin at him like she wins. Then she grins. It’s the shark grin of someone who’s gotten away with things, whose mouth remembers being full of stolen cherries. “You new-new,” she says. “What gave it away, the paleness or the whiplash?” “Both. Also the way you look at the balconies like they’re going to fall on you.” “They might,” I say. “Heavy iron. Gravity. Sinners.” She laughs, quick and bright. “You’re weird,” she says. “You got a name?” “Taylor.” Saying it here feels different than saying it in my kitchen while my mother’s mouth turned into a straight line that wouldn’t bend. It feels like scaffolding. It holds. “Lucky,” she says. “Gender-neutral. You were born ahead of the game. I’m Ari. Just Ari. It was Ariel until I strangled that last syllable in my sleep.” The saxophone starts again, a slow something, blue as my nail polish bottle. The sound lifts the sweat off the back of my neck. I feel myself unfold like a paper crane. “Hungry?” Ari asks. I shrug. My stomach answers with betrayal. She tips her head like a pigeon and then gestures. “Come on. My guy at the corner grocery gives me bread ends. You can chew them if you pretend it’s fancy.” We walk through the crowd. Every other doorway’s a bar. Every third person has a drink in a plastic cup, lemon slice like a flag. There’s a woman on a balcony in a sundress who yells, “Woooo!” just because it’s a day that ends in Y. Ari slides between bodies like she’s practiced. I follow, apologizing to elbows. She leads me into shade, and it’s like the world lets out a breath. A red sign says Troy’s Grocery. The inside is cooler than I thought it would be. The smell is old bologna, spilled mop water, candy bars. Ari nods at the cashier, a man with nineties boy-band hair and the flat look of someone who’s worked two double shifts back-to-back. “My guy,” Ari says. “Girl,” he says, and he says it like it’s easy. I file that away in the part of my brain labeled good things that still happen. He gives us a paper bag with two loaves worth of the weird tail ends, a dozen eggs with a date from last week, and a can of black beans that’s dented so hard it looks like it’s trying to suck its own stomach. No charge. He winks like a tired uncle. We say thanks. Outside again, Ari pulls me down a narrow alley that smells like fryer oil and something dying, but in a comforting way, if that’s possible. There’s a milk crate. She sits. She cracks two eggs into the top of the can, which she has stabbed with a key. Raw. She drinks the Golgotha mess like it’s a smoothie. I try not to be impressed. I am impressed. “You’re hardcore,” I say. “Hard broke,” she says. She offers me the beans. “Protein,” she adds. “If you’re squeamish, chew the bread and pretend it’s steak.” I’d rather eat my hoodie. I eat the bread. It tastes like other people’s lunches. The saxophone is a thin ribbon now, I can still hear it from here, like a thread leading me back to the street if I get lost among dumpsters. I want to text my brother. I want to throw my phone in the Mississippi. I want to curl around the buzzing core of this afternoon and let it grow inside me like a new organ—one that understands motion, and the way you can be something else if you keep walking. Ari watches me like she’s reading subtitles. Her eyes flick to the backpack, the way I hold it too close. “You running?” she asks. “I’m walking extremely fast,” I say. I don’t mean to be clever. It just comes out like that when I don’t want to talk about something and also do, desperately. “Family stuff.” She nods like she has a drawer for that. “Same,” she says. “Different. Not sharing unless you do.” Fair is fair. I pick at the bread. It makes satisfying crumbs. “I told them I’m trans,” I say. The word is a lighthouse. I say it and it says, okay, here we are. “They took it like it was a prank. Or an illness. Like I could go back to school Monday and not be… me. Like if you throw salt on a slug and it just—” I shut up. I don’t know where I’m going with that. I hate slugs. Why did I say that. Ari breathes out through her nose. “Shit,” she says. “I’m sorry.” She says it without pity, just acknowledgment. She scratches something on her forearm with her nail. There’s a tattoo there—little stick-and-poke stars flaking at the edges like dried glue. “I told mine I like girls when I was thirteen,” she says. “My mom said she already knew, which was the worst because she didn’t, she just liked being right about me. My dad said I should be careful at school. Which is parent code for hide. I didn’t. I got suspended for kissing someone behind the bleachers and then I left. Been here a month and change. Not saying I’m a role model.” “Same,” I say. “Definitely not taking life advice from me.” She smirks. “That’s okay. I have enough life advice for both of us: don’t take life advice from anyone.” We sit. The alley hums with flies who are also on the run. My phone pings—a battery alert. Fifteen percent now fourteen, the number is a countdown to something I can’t name, like a bomb that replaces your old life with a different shape. “You got somewhere to sleep?” Ari asks. I don’t. I shake my head like a maraca. “I was going to figure it out,” I say in the voice of someone who has never figured anything out, not really. She nods once like she’s been waiting for that. “There’s a place,” she says. “Not a shelter-shelter. Those are hit or miss. A church lets us crash in the rec room sometimes. You help stack chairs, you listen to Pastor Dan say something about the prodigal son but nicer, and you don’t steal the extension cords. Rules.” “Are you trying to convert me?” She snorts. “God no. Dan’s cool. He wears Crocs with socks and says he sins daily. He’s chill about Steph and Jaz being boyfriends, but he still calls them ‘friends’ like he’s trying to ease his heart into the twenty-first century. You want to come, you can. Or you can try the riverfront. That’s all right if you got a blanket and a lookout. Just… you know. Watch your stuff. And your body.” The way she says it makes my skin a little electric, like when you realize someone saw you almost step into traffic and you’re like, oh. I look at my feet. My shoes used to be white. They look like they’ve been run over by a truck and then adopted out to a loving family of raccoons. “What do you want?” Ari asks me suddenly. “I mean… bigger than a shower and a sandwich. If you say a pony, I will respect your honesty.” The question hits me in the sternum. What do I want? What did I want yesterday? To be called by my name. To have a closet that isn’t a coffin. To be in my skin and not feel like it was a Halloween costume I forgot to take off. To not have to perform normal. To have a room with a lock. To walk into a place and not plan an exit. “A quiet morning,” I say. The words come out small. “No one yelling. Coffee. A shirt that fits right. A mirror that doesn’t lie. And to not feel like my heart is a thrown rock all the time.” Ari rubs her lips together. “That’s not unreasonable,” she says. “The mirror is tricky. The coffee is easy.” She stands, flipping the milk crate upside down. “Come on, Taylor. We’ll go hear Joe play another song and then we’ll see about the church or the river or the cafe where they will let us sit until we get kicked out. It’s like musical chairs, except the music is sax and the chairs have secrets.” We end up back where we started. The saxophonist nods like an uncle who lives in an armchair on a porch that faces sunset. He’s playing something lazy and sweet. Ari throws a piece of bread into his coffee can. He laughs. “You throwing me carbs?” he asks. “Fiber,” she says. “For your art.” He looks at me. “You alright?” he asks. I want to say yes. I want to say I’m a house and all my lights are on. Instead I say, “Getting there.” He plays a note that makes the pigeons pause, like they’re all reconsidering their life choices. “That’s all anyone can say,” he says. We walk. The afternoon tilts into gold. A drag queen passes us wearing a robe like a galaxy and two toddlers wave at her like she’s a Disney princess. She waves back with a hand full of rhinestones.
