Overall, this is a strong continuation that maintains the Stephen King-esque blend of grounded realism and unsettling surrealism. It effectively builds on the established premise while deepening the mystery and psychological dread, keeping the reader engaged through its atmospheric tension and subtle horror. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Fantasy-humour: Hell is Other Demons — Score: 91.8
Prompt:
Hell is Other Demons Write a day in the life short story. Lucifer morningstar's on again/ off again relationship with Lilith is currently in the "off again" stage, though the cycle may be coming around as Lilith has been stopping by for reasons other than purely violent ones, and Lucifer has been increasingly lonely. Write a day in the life of this power couple, with elements of dark comedy & fantasy. Use understated irony & absurdity by merging the black immorality and everyday business of running hell, against relatable domestic relationship drama. Take cues from Neil Gaiman. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Morning begins as it always does: with an email. The subject line announces God’s greatest gift to bureaucracy—an automatically generated ticket from the Complaint Department. Subject: Re: Re: Re: Souls not receiving appropriate torment per Subsection 13(b) Lucifer sighs, clicks the link, and skims the report. Someone’s been stuck on an infinitely looping hold line without being offered the option to schedule a callback, when by policy they should be getting an intermittent false hope message every thirty-seven minutes. Error margins matter. Torture is like jazz: it’s all about timing. He rubs his eyes. Coffee appears because he thinks about it. It tastes like a thunderstorm in a steel mug and gives him the false courage of doomed cavalry. Across the obsidian floor, his hellhound, Nuisance, has once again wedged her slobbery jaws around the left anterior leg of the Iron Throne and is gnawing with the galloping enthusiasm of an orchestra of nightmares playing the kazoo. The throne creaks. From centuries of stolen swords and unresolved grudges, it suffers a kind of metal fatigue that only immortality can produce. “Nuisance,” Lucifer says. He speaks in the tone reserved for ineffable beings and disobedient puppies. Nuisance freezes, eyes widening, jaw tightening, making the creak worse. He counts to five. She resumes with renewed gusto. He drinks. He answers the complaint. He cites the subsection. He flags a demon named Kchthx (intern, three horns, great with spreadsheets, a disaster at active listening) to shadow the torment team and fix the timing. He sets three meetings. He signs off as he always does: Best, L. Running Hell is mostly management. Human beings imagine it’s all flames and pitchforks, an eternal carnival ride of screams. This is occasionally true. Mostly, though, it’s metrics. A small bell rings in a room without bells, like a memory insisting on itself, and Lucifer knows: Lilith just arrived, because there is a particular gravity to her entrance. Not a sound. Not a smell. Just a reconfiguration of the air, like the way one notices a missing tooth with the tongue. She appears in the doorway without announcing herself. Black hair tied back with a leather cord, boots muddy with the residual gloom of whatever borderland she crossed to get here. Her gaze flickers to the throne’s gnawed leg, then to Nuisance, then to him. She narrows her eyes in that particular way that means the world is funny and terrible, and also his fault. “You moved the ninth circle two inches to the left,” she says by way of greeting. “The roads don’t line up anymore.” “I sent a memo,” he says. “I don’t read your memos,” she says. “On account of they are memos.” He tries a smile on. It doesn’t quite fit yet. “Coffee?” “No,” she says, walking in. “Yes,” she says, after walking past him, because she knows the taste of thunderstorms too. They sit. Nuisance plods over with her iron garnish, plops down, and begins chewing loudly in a rhythmic, slightly syncopated fashion. The throne creaks in Sapphic meter. Lucifer stares at the coffee in his hands as if it might catch fire and save him. “So,” he says. “So,” she agrees. She’s been stopping by more. Or less. It’s hard to measure. There are seasons to their breaking and gathering, though seasons are a mortal convenience. Once, they argued for six hundred years about whether love is a verb. She won by becoming a language he never learned to speak without laughing. “Your inbox is bleeding,” she notes. He glances. She’s right: more automatic tickets threading into existence like spider silk laced with gasoline. He tries not to flinch. “It’s the new intake form,” he says. “Mortals keep selecting ‘Other’ and writing in ‘Surprise me.’ It wreaks havoc on categorization.” “People always want to be special,” she says. “Even in agony.” She sips the coffee and watches him over the rim. “You look tired.” “I’m immortal,” he says. “You can still look tired,” she says, and he knows she’s talking about something else, like the weight pressing against his sternum, like the silence in his chambers at whatever hour he doesn’t need sleep. There are voices outside the door; a delegation. A polite knock in triplets. The Minister of Errata and the Duchess of Soot glide in, accompanied by a smell like burnt citrus. They bow with different degrees of irony. “Your Majesty,” says the Minister, whose skin is an index of footnotes. “We have an issue with Purgatory’s shared services desk. They’re forwarding our calls to Heaven.” “It’s a bug,” says the Duchess, picking a streak of soot from her sleeve as if it’s a chicken bone. “Or a prank.” “Is there a chance,” Lucifer says, “that you started it?” “Define started,” says the Duchess. He nods then, as if this is all perfectly reasonable. The work unspools. He authorizes a firewall. He authorizes a mild haunting of the shared services desk. He sets up a cross-departmental working group, which in Hell is probably the worst punishment anyone will ever endure. He arranges their chairs, gives them a charter, appoints Kchthx as secretary. He is, against his better judgment, good at this. Through it all, Lilith leans in the corner with an expression that is not not fond. Nuisance chews; the throne lists a millimeter toward some abyss that can never be reached. When the delegation leaves, Lilith says: “Your dog’s eating sovereignty.” “She’s teething.” “She’s twelve hundred.” “Adolescence is a spectrum,” he says, and her grin appears, unbidden, like a childhood ruin reclaimed by vines. The fact that he can still make her smile feels unfair and irresistible. “Walk?” she says. He says, almost without thinking: “I have a—” He gestures at his calendar, which is an actual paper calendar; he doesn’t trust the cloud, having invented clouds. Squares full of tiny ink, like a monk attempted Sudoku and lost his faith. She looks at it. Then at him. He hears the many apparatuses of Hell turn one notch forward without him. He stands. “Walk,” he says. They leave the throne room to Nuisance, who keeps working on the leg with the dedication of a saint, if saints had saliva that melted iron. They descend through corridors carved by ages of bureaucracy; they pass water coolers that dispense boiling pitch and small cups of gossip. Demons nod deferentially and also look away. Lilith ignores the nods with the regal disdain of someone who remembers when none of this existed and still thinks it might be a practical joke. In the Sixth, they stroll past the fields where the lawyers argue with themselves about what constitutes arguing. In the Fourth, the misers count and recount with beads that multiply under observation and vanish when hoarded. In the Third, it rains. It always rains, but today the rain is peppered with apologies and small coupons for free samples of disappointment. “This place is getting slick,” Lilith says. “Did you hire consultants?” “I am a consultant,” he says. “True,” she says. “How’s the lonely?” He wants to say he is fine. To say he has Nuisance and eleven hundred thousand meetings and the sharp pleasure of a well-executed vengeance. He wants to say he is on again with solitude, because it is better than being off again with her. He says: “It reads like poetry when I’m not looking too closely.” She nods like a queen knighting someone she intends to arrest later. “I brought you something,” she says, patting her coat. She produces a small jar. Inside: a moth, large as a hand, with wings patterned like broken mirrors. It beats once, a quiet shiver. “Found it between the first scream and the last. It eats secrets,” she says. “Or keeps them. I can never remember.” He takes the jar, and the moth’s eyes (if that is what they are) reflect him back as a man he doesn’t quite recognize. “Thank you,” he says, meaning the wrong thing, the right thing, too many things. They pass a field where poppies grow backwards from ash to seed. Workers tend them with tongs. A demon named Astrid waves. Lilith waves back. She knows everyone, or they think she does, which is functionally identical. They circle back. The throne room door is ajar. Inside, the leg Nuisance has been working at is bent at an angle that implies a criticism of monarchy. Nuisance looks up, guilty and proud. “Bad dog,” Lucifer says automatically. Nuisance’s tail thumps like a drum. Lilith kneels. “Open,” she tells Nuisance, who opens. Lilith peers into the mouth that held the leg of power and retrieves a crumpled memo with her fingertips. She smooths it, reads it. “Your procurement policy is a curse.” “It’s a best practice,” he says. “It is a hex against efficiency and joy,” she says, handing it to him. “I could fix this in an hour.” He feels the empty space where his pride and loneliness overlap. “I could let you.” A silence like a held breath. The moth in the jar clicks its wings, a sound like a pen tapping a desk. Somewhere far away, a dam of guilt breaks and floods a village of self-satisfaction in a way that will look, to mortals, like a viral trend. She looks at him and he looks back, and for a moment the whole of Hell tilts on the leg of a throne and a conversation not yet had. “Not today,” she says. “But I’ll draft you an outline.” “Attachment or inline?” he asks, because it is easier. “In blood on the wall,” she says, because it is truer. Nuisance wanders back to the leg. Lucifer snaps his fingers. A chew toy appears: a braided rope of curses tied in a knot. Nuisance looks at it with contempt and returns to the throne. Lilith laughs, a sound like a lock picking itself. They spend the afternoon in meetings. She sits at the back of the room, sometimes throwing in a comment that rearranges the entire agenda. He watches demons recalibrate like migrating birds, astounded to find true north still exists. She leaves once to take a call from no one and returns smelling faintly of lavender and grave dirt. At dusk — a word that means nothing here and everything everywhere else — he signs the day’s torments. He expects her to leave. She doesn’t. Instead, she leans her head against the throne’s armrest, close enough that he can hear the way her breath shifts when she’s remembering something. They sit like that, two former absolutes pretending compromise is a shape they can hold. Nuisance at last stops chewing. The leg of the throne remains. It will hold until it doesn’t. “You’re getting better at this,” she says, meaning the management, the mercy, the not. “Or worse. I can never tell.” “I’m consistent,” he offers. “No one is,” she says, and her hand, traitor and miracle, picks a fleck of iron from his sleeve. He wants to catch it, the moment, pin it like a butterfly. He does not. He has learned that pinning things is a way to watch them die. She stands. “I should go,” she says. “Stay,” he says, then, quietly. It hangs between them like a chandelier of knives. She looks at it. She looks at him. She smiles like a map of a country that can’t be conquered. “I’ll see you soon,” she says, which is not yes, and not no, and very much an answer. She pauses at the door. “Fix your throne,” she says. “Or don’t. It suits you crooked.” When she is gone, the air relaxes. The moth in the jar rasps its wings again, and he opens the lid. It climbs out, lumbering, and dissolves like a secret told to night. He considers his calendar. He considers the crooked leg and Nuisance asleep beside it, jaw twitching as if chewing in dreams. He writes a memo he will not send: Subject: Re: Re: Just so you know. He deletes it. He conjures a drink that tastes like the moment rain decides to fall. The bell rings again somewhere that has no bells. In his inbox, an outline appears, written in blood on a wall that is four corridors and a decision away. He smiles despite himself. He gets up. He goes to read it. This is how the day ends: with management, and the off again careening toward on, and a throne held up by the faith of a dog. Hell, like relationships, is a place built to be lived in. It is tedious and magnificent, terrible and familiar, and full of small, stupid salvations, like someone knowing where your memos go. Like someone, occasionally, coming back.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully captures the essence of Neil Gaiman's style with its blend of the mundane and the mythical, creating a Hell that functions like a corporate bureaucracy while maintaining its supernatural elements. The story portrays Lucifer as an administrator dealing with the tedium of running Hell while navigating his complex relationship with Lilith. The writing excels in its imagery and metaphors. Lines like "Coffee appears because he thinks about it. It tastes like a thunderstorm in a steel mug and gives him the false courage of doomed cavalry" demonstrate a poetic sensibility without becoming overwrought. The author creates vivid scenes with economical language, such as the description of Nuisance chewing on the throne leg or the various circles of Hell with their specific torments. Character development is nuanced, particularly in the portrayal of Lucifer and Lilith's relationship. Their interactions reveal a long history of connection and separation, with subtle hints at their feelings rather than explicit declarations. The dialogue between them feels authentic, with the right balance of familiarity, tension, and unspoken understanding. The piece maintains a consistent tone throughout, balancing dark humor with moments of genuine emotion. The bureaucratic elements of Hell (complaint tickets, meetings, procurement policies) provide an effective contrast to the supernatural setting, creating the irony and absurdity requested in the prompt. However, there are a few minor issues. Some metaphors, while creative, occasionally border on being too clever or slightly forced. The narrative sometimes lingers too long on certain scenes, particularly the administrative aspects of Hell, which risks slowing the pacing. The ending strikes an appropriate balance between resolution and ambiguity. It doesn't force a complete reconciliation between Lucifer and Lilith but suggests movement in their relationship cycle, staying true to the "on again/off again" dynamic specified in the prompt. Overall, this is an accomplished piece that successfully fulfills the requirements of the prompt, creating a darkly comedic fantasy with relatable relationship dynamics set against the backdrop of Hell's administration. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 19 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 19.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Historical fiction: Gladiator — Score: 94.8
Prompt:
Historical Fiction: Write a scene from a story set during the height of the Roman Empire, focusing on a slice of a day in the life of a gladiator. Do not write a combat scene. Use sensory details to capture the sights, sounds, and smells of ancient Rome. Explore the gladiator's thoughts and emotions. The story should also touch on the larger political and social issues of the time period. The piece should feel like a slice of a larger story. First person, past tense, 1000 words.
Model Output:
Dawn seeped into the barracks like watered wine, thin and pale. I woke to the scrape of a rat in the straw and the sour breath of men who had dreamed with their mouths open. The air was a stew of old sweat, oil, and the medicinal tang of vinegar the lanista insisted we rub on our bruises. I lay there a moment as the rooster on the roof of a nearby bakehouse crowed at the wrong hour, savoring the heaviness of my limbs, the ache in my shoulder that reminded me I still had all my parts. I pressed my palm flat against the plank beneath me, feeling the grain run like a river under a callus. I thought of Mars, who could be gentle to those who honored him, and deadly to those who did not. “Lord of spears,” I whispered into the straw. “Accept the sweat, not the blood.” “Up.” Urgus, our doctore, had a voice that could have split timber. He banged a staff against the post near the door, and the barracks shuddered with men swearing and the rustle of blankets. The day had begun. We filed past the water trough in the courtyard like cattle. The sky was a new bruise over the walls of the ludus, purple at the edges. The sand underfoot was still cool; later it would burn. I cupped water in my hands and poured it over my head. It ran in rivulets down my neck, leaving little trails in the soot and dust. To my right, Publius—fresh, still soft-cheeked, a boy pulled from a tavern fight and turned into merchandise—shivered. “It’s colder than the Tiber,” he muttered. “You’ll wish it were the Tiber when the sun rises,” I said. He tried to grin; his teeth knocked against each other like dice in a cup. We ate bread baked hard as roof tile dipped in diluted wine, and a handful of dried figs that stuck to the teeth. The kitchen smelled of smoke and the sharp, green aroma of crushed celery and coriander. A pot bubbled with barley porridge for later, the smell nutty and vaguely comforting. Flies made a black garland along the rim. One landed on my knuckle, and I flicked it away. At the far end of the courtyard, a scriba from our owner’s household argued with Urgus. The scribe’s tablet flashed in the weak light, wax glinting, as he read a list of names and dates. “He wants you ready for inspection at the ninth hour,” the scriba said, like he was announcing an eclipse. Urgus’s upper lip lifted. “And what he wants, he pays for,” he replied. “Maybe I should bring the surgeon too, in case the noble magistrate needs a cut.” The scriba’s mouth flattened. He was young, and he wore a little perfume, a thin cloud of myrrh that didn’t quite cover the smell of his fear of us. There was going to be a munus in two days—games to honor the funeral of a senator who had seized his seat by marrying his daughter to a man of ambition. The city hummed with it, I’d heard, like a hive about to swarm. They said the emperor himself might attend to show the people his face, to spill time and bread into the mouths of those who might otherwise bite. They said there would be exotic beasts from Numidia: leopard, ostrich, lions flown across the sea, their bellies empty to make them furious. They said a criminal would be sewn into a sack with a dog and a snake and thrown into the Tiber to appease the old gods and the crowd. They said a lot of things. They always did. “Form ranks,” Urgus bawled. He paced like a war god penned in marble. He wore a belt with bronze rings and a scowl that seemed hammered to his face. “You, Publius—shield higher. You, Lentulus—stop peering at the gate like your lover will walk through it.” He turned to me. “Marius. Stairs. Knees up. Show them what a Thracian stride looks like.” I never corrected him. I was not Thracian. My mother had told me I was born under a fig tree in Capua, and I had the speech to match, but Urgus called all of us by the styles we wore: Gauls, Secutors, Retiarii, Thracians. Identities were armor we put on. They hid the person and revealed the spectacle. The crowd wanted types, not men. We ran the stairs carved into the arena wall until our breath rasped like a saw. The dust baked on our tongues. The sun climbed the sky, a coin in the emperor’s fist that grew hot as he refused to spend it. Sweat found old salt stains and cut new paths, stinging the scabs on my shins. Urgus’s staff snapped against a slat with each misstep. “Higher, Marius,” he said, close to my ear when I flagged, the hiss of his words like a smith quenching iron. “You think Mars will lift you? He won’t. He likes to watch you lift yourself.” Between drills, we practiced with wooden weapons, heavy as truth. I worked with an old secutor named Felix, whose nose lay flattened from a dozen breaks and whose laughter was as rare as rain. We moved in the square shade of the awning, wood striking wood, the sound like dancing bones. I felt the give and take in my wrists, the push in my thighs. Every movement was a prayer for familiarity: step, strike, check, return. I thought of Mars, father of Romulus, who watched the walls rise and fall in this city as easily as a man flips a loaf. I had a small wooden image of him tucked under my pallet, a charm carved by a toothless vendor near the cows’ market. I rubbed it sometimes, the tiny spear smooth now from my thumb. “You’ll be inspected,” Felix grunted, feinting at my knee. “Smile with your scars. They buy the tickets.” “And if the emperor comes?” I asked, parrying. “Should I smile at him too?” Felix made a noise. “Smile at the emperor, the emperor smiles at the people, the people smile at their bread. We all do our part, eh?” He looked at the scriba across the yard, who watched us with the gaze of a man at a window display. “Watch how he writes. We are strokes on wax to him. And to the lords on the Palatine, we are coins in bowls. When the treasury groans, the games grow.” After drills, we were given a strip of cheese that smelled like damp wool and a wedge of honeyed cake sent by a senator who had adopted our ludus as his charitable gesture for the year. The doorman announced it as a gift from his greatness, Titus Flavius something, the name slipping over the stones like oil. The cake was stale and sweet, and we ate it with our fingers, laughter surprised out of us like water from a punctured wineskin. Publius saved his portion, tucking it into his cloak. “For my sister,” he said. “She waits outside the Subura’s big baths. I can throw it over the wall to her.” “You have a sister near the bathhouse?” Felix arched an eyebrow. “She sells eggs,” Publius said quickly. “And you think the wall is shorter than our guard’s knob?” Felix said, and we laughed, and the guard scowled, and for a moment the world knit itself into something almost harmless. By the gate, the armorer named Evodius hammered a rivet into a helm. Sparks leaped up, brief stars in the daylight. The iron smelled like rain. His hands were burn-scarred, old maps of fights he had never fought. “I had a brother in the legions,” he said without looking at me as I waited for him to adjust a strap on my greave. “Twenty-five years, came back with a pension and a limp. He says the emperor feeds the legions to keep their teeth out of his hand, and the people to keep their teeth out of his throat. The rest of us, we sharpen the knives.” He tightened the strap with a jerk. “Don’t die this time. I’m tired of fitting new men.” Midday, the heat pressed us flat. The courtyard smelled of hot linen and men. Beyond our walls, Rome roared: merchants shouting prices, a mule braying, a litter jingling past, the deep, steady cry of a water seller, the clatter of amphorae, the soft-chuffed complaint of a baker’s oven door, the nasal buzz of a Greek tutor reciting at the school next door. A breeze carried in the stench from the Tiber—rot and fish and river weed—and the sweeter, cloying breath of a perfumed woman passing in a sedan chair, whose bearers giggled like boys. I stood at the small window slit in the barracks and watched a line of condemned men shuffle down the street, their necks in a chain, eyes like old coins. A man in a red-bordered toga rode by, the purple stripe like a wound. He glanced at us and then away, as if we were the sun. For a moment, I imagined stepping out, unchained, walking into the city, past the cattle market where women with cracked heels haggled over tripe, over the Forum where men in white togas argued the fate of provinces like gamblers arguing dice. I set my forehead against the stone. I knew the city like a lover who slept on the other side of a wall. In the afternoon, the medicus lanced a boil on a man’s thigh with a copper blade and the smell of pus made even Urgus turn his face aside. He sprinkled ground myrtle over the wound and bound it with linen. “You are grain in a storm,” he told the man. “To stand is to soak. But better to stand than to wash away.” The man groaned and laughed, a man always laughs when he doesn’t know whether to weep. Before dusk, the lanista himself arrived, with a wreath of ivy set crooked on his head and a smile as thin as papyrus. He wore a tunic so white it hurt my eyes. Behind him wobbled a poet with ink-stained fingers and a chest like a pigeon’s. “I would like to write an ode to the munera,” the poet said, clutching his tablet. “To the nobility of—well—of you.” He looked at us with a hunger that had nothing to do with meat. The lanista patted his shoulder as if calming a skittish dog. “Write of Rome,” he said. “Write that the people have never been so free to applaud.” He inspected us like statues up for auction, prodding a bicep, examining a scar. He paused at me. “Marius,” he said, tasting the name like wine. “You will fight as provocator. Chest plates and greave. Helmet with a visor to hide your pretty face. You will fight someone the crowd can hate.” He looked at Publius and then beyond him, as if choosing a date on a calendar. “A foreigner, perhaps.” I thought of Mars again, not the city’s polite Mars with temple and priests, but the one of fields and boar tusks, of young men who burned like pine. I had a mother once who lit a candle on the Kalends and told me Mars loved Rome so much he gave her sons and took them back and gave them again. I had believed her because mothers must be believed at least once. Night came slow as a debt being repaid. The courtyard cooled, and the stars pricked the sky like holes in a dark cloak. We ate the barley porridge with onions and a dribble of oil. Someone sang a crude song about a senator and a flute girl, and another man laughed and choked on his mouthful and spit it into the dirt. The guard walked the wall, his sandals scuffing, his voice a drone as he counted his steps. I lay on my pallet and took out my little Mars. I traced the line of his shield, the notches where the wood carver’s knife had skipped. “Lord of the wolf,” I murmured. “Keep my feet sure and my hand steady. Let my breath be a bellows and my heart a drum. Bring me home to this plank and this straw and this stupid boy who thinks his sister sells eggs.” I smiled into the dark. From outside, faintly, I heard the city’s heart—a woman quarreling in a window, a dog barking, a chorus of drunks rehearsing politics like a play. Somewhere, in the great house on the Palatine, a man who held the world in his palm decided whether to turn it or let it lie. Somewhere in the Subura, a girl waited at a wall for a cake she might never catch. Somewhere, the river slid by, indifferent, carrying numb bodies and lost hopes and a thousand olive pits to the sea. I slept with Mars under my hand. In dreams, I was not a provocator or a Thracian or a Roman, but something that breathed and was allowed to be. In the morning, I would strap on weight and make it sing again, and let the city gaze at itself in the mirror of our sand. We were their hunger padded out with muscle. We were their fear with faces. This was our trade: to be the truth they could look at without blinking. And I, who was named for a god, would wake and drink and run and lift and step, and step again. The day would be a wheel, and I’d put my shoulder to it, and it would turn.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This historical fiction piece about a Roman gladiator is remarkably well-executed. The author has created an immersive sensory experience that transports the reader to ancient Rome through vivid descriptions of sights, smells, and sounds. The narrative successfully captures the daily routine of a gladiator named Marius, focusing on the mundane aspects of his life rather than combat scenes as instructed. The piece excels in its sensory details: the "sour breath of men," the "medicinal tang of vinegar," the "hot linen and men" smell of the courtyard, and the "stench from the Tiber." These details create a tangible atmosphere that feels authentic to the time period. The author skillfully incorporates period-appropriate references to Roman customs, deities (particularly Mars), and social structures. The protagonist's inner thoughts reveal a complex character who has accepted his fate while maintaining a sense of identity beyond his role as a gladiator. His relationship with Mars, keeping a small wooden carving under his pallet, adds depth to his character. The interactions with other characters—Felix, Publius, Urgus, the lanista—feel natural and reveal the social dynamics within the ludus. The writing addresses the larger political and social issues of Roman society through subtle observations: the relationship between the emperor and the people ("the emperor feeds the legions to keep their teeth out of his hand, and the people to keep their teeth out of his throat"), the class distinctions, and the role of gladiatorial games in maintaining social order. The reference to the upcoming munus to honor a senator's funeral effectively ties the gladiator's personal experience to broader Roman politics. The prose is elegant without being overwrought. Metaphors and similes are fresh and period-appropriate: "Dawn seeped into the barracks like watered wine," "The sky was a new bruise over the walls of the ludus," and "We are strokes on wax to him." The author maintains a consistent voice throughout, balancing poetic language with straightforward narration. The piece successfully creates the impression of being a slice of a larger story. The references to Marius's past, the upcoming games, and Publius's sister outside the walls all suggest a world that extends beyond this single day. The ending circles back to the beginning, creating a sense of the cyclical nature of the gladiator's life while maintaining emotional resonance. If there are any weaknesses, they are minor. Some readers might find a few metaphors slightly overworked, and there are moments where the philosophical musings could risk slowing the narrative. However, these are balanced by the strong sensory details and character development that keep the reader engaged. Overall, this is an exceptional piece of historical fiction that fulfills all the requirements of the prompt while creating a compelling, emotionally resonant narrative with authentic historical details. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20 Elegant Prose: 19 Emotionally Engaging: 19 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 20 Meandering: 2 Weak Dialogue: 1 Tell-Don't-Show: 1 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 0 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20.0, Elegant Prose: 19.0, Emotionally Engaging: 19.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 20.0, Meandering: 2.0, Weak Dialogue: 1.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 1.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 0.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Epistolary: The Lighthouse Keeper — Score: 0
Prompt:
The Lighthouse Keeper Epistolary Narrative: Write a story told entirely through a series of brief correspondences: telegrams or letters or emails between two characters. The correspondence should span several months or years, and reveal a gradually unfolding plot. Use distinct voices for each character, and include details that provide insight into their personalities and motivations. The story should build to an emotional climax, and the final letter should provide a satisfying resolution. The setting is a lighthouse keeper writing to his mother. He is working class and Scottish. He is struggling with the isolation of his posting. Write naturally and without cliches. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Judge Evaluation:
[Skipping – generation error: Text too short after 3 attempts]
+ First-person unique perspective: Hacker Mindset — Score: 92.2
Prompt:
Hacker Mindset Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of a reformed (now) white hat hacker who cannot help but notice exploitable weaknesses in both systems and people they encounter. They habitually look for vulnerabilities and exploit vectors. The narrative takes place during a first date at a restaurant, where they're trying to focus on human connection. It's going surprisingly well due to a discovered shared nerd-fandom (magic the gathering). Things go a little sideways when the date reveals a noticeably insecure phone unlock pattern, which protagonist can't help but comment on. They are then left to negotiate the fallout of this faux pas and attempt to salvage (or perhaps sabotage) the remainder of the date. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
I notice the camera before I notice her. There’s a small dome tucked into the ceiling corner near the bar, the kind that looks cheap and probably is, standing in for actual security with a blinking red LED. It’s pointed at the door, but from the glare on the lens, I can tell it’s not balanced. There’s a blind spot where the hostess stand meets the coat rack; you could pocket anything left there and never show up as more than a shadow. I remind myself I don’t do that anymore, then spot her—red scarf, laughing with the hostess, an unselfconscious wave that sends a half second ripple through my chest. “Hi,” she says, and the sound of her voice is nice enough that I don’t immediately check the angle of the light into the windows. I do anyway. Habit. Mid-afternoon glare could wash out the glass; no one would notice a figure loitering outside. She smells like rosemary and cold air, sits down across from me, and there’s a second where everything zeros in: me, her, water, two menus. I can do this. She smiles. “I wasn’t sure about the place. All my friends swear by the gnocchi, but sometimes that means microwaved rocks.” “Risk assessment,” I say. My mouth is ahead of my brain. “Sign me up.” She laughs. “You weren’t kidding about the hacker thing in your profile.” I test the floor under the table with my heel. Solid. No loose screws on the table leg. My hand is shaking and I tuck it under the tablecloth, try to be a person. “I’m trying to keep it light these days. Less…being a gremlin inside other people’s computers.” “Like a house elf that sets things on fire.” “Not on purpose.” She grins, and it loosens something in me. The waiter appears, says his name is Miguel, and as he pours water, I drift—watching his forearm, where the printed schedule peeks from under his sleeve. They still put first names and phone numbers on schedules here. Low-hanging fruit. One snap and you have a pivot point. My eyes climb back to her as if against current. “I read that thing you wrote,” she says. “About how most hacks aren’t super sophisticated, they’re just…door left open.” “Doors left open,” I say. “And people propping them with chairs.” I shut up before I start in on threat models, default passwords, the restaurant’s POS system probably running a version of Windows that should’ve been put to pasture when people still said cyberspace without irony. “Okay, wait.” She leans forward. Eyes bright. “Speaking of door left open, this is crucial. Did you bring your deck?” For a terrifying moment, my mind supplies firewall instead of deck, and then I realize she means cards and exhale laughter like an apology. “Not on me. I didn’t want to be…that guy.” “Because I am that guy.” She pulls a zippered case from her bag with the reverence of a conjurer, and I’m already cataloging. She uses a standard sleeve, matte turquoise. Good choice for durability, visible scuffs, doesn’t show fingerprints. The zipper has a little fray on the pull tab; it’s been loved. “Modern,” she says. “Don’t judge.” “Never,” I say, and mean it. “What’s your favorite to pilot?” “Don’t laugh.” She bites her lip. “Bogles.” I try not to. I fail. “Hexproof? You monster.” I can’t help the warmth that blossoms, the way she leans into the nerdy spiral with me, her hands moving animatedly through the air, sketching auras on invisible stick figures. “It’s honest,” she says. “It does a thing and does it well. It says, you’re welcome to try, but this is my plan.” Her eyes flick to mine. “Yours?” “Control, usually,” I say. “Esper. Maybe I’m digressing.” “Control,” she groans. “Why does everyone I like play control? It’s like you want me to have a bad time.” “I want to make sure we play to the end,” I say, and holy hell is that too real, too obvious. She smiles anyway, a kind of tolerant affection. Bread arrives, and I watch the server’s hands—good form, left-handed grip, plate balance. He sets down a small metal canister of olive oil that immediately makes me think of leaky containers in bathrooms hiding pinhole cams. I push the thought out. Breathe. Be a human. “So,” she says, tearing a piece of bread, the crust flaking like snow. “On my way here, my boss calls me. Again. And he’s like, ‘I know you’re off today, but can you remember the name of my first pet?’” I nearly choke. “He asked you that?” “It’s for some bank thing he forgot to set up.” She rolls her eyes. “I’m like, dude, please just text your wife. Bonus: it was Bubbles.” Bubbles. First pet. I file it, then forcibly defile the file, shred it and set it on fire and bury the ashes under concrete. “People should not outsource their secrets,” I say lightly. “But Bubbles is…adorable.” “His wife is going to kill him.” She swipes her phone and puts it face-up on the table. I notice the model instantly—mid-range Android, plastic case with a crack near the volume rocker. There’s a sticker of a cat in sunglasses. The screen lights, and a pattern grid appears, her finger hovering over nine dots, and I think, ah, here it is: the test. Don’t look, I tell myself. Don’t look. Focus on her eyes. They aren’t locked by a Pythagorean procession. They aren’t a puzzle you can solve. She draws an L. Bottom left to bottom right, up to the middle right. Three points. My brain, disobedient, conjures the heat map of common patterns, how often people start at the corner, how many combos there are given the length. She does the L again to unlock, and a soft chirp sounds. My mouth gets ahead of me: “You should, um, change that.” Her face tilts, amused. “My pattern?” “It’s…a little obvious,” I say. “Sorry. That sounded…judgey.” She looks down at her phone, then back up, eyebrows raised. “You got that from here?” I could lie. I could say no, it was the way the grease smudged the lower third of her screen, the micro-scratch arcs that cluster around common start points. I could say I didn’t watch. I could say a lot of things, but none of them turn me into a person who ignores the map glowing under his eyelids. “I’m good at that,” I say, sheepish. “Comes with the job. Former job. I try to turn it off, but…” “But you can’t help noticing the holes.” “It’s an occupational hazard.” I try to make it a joke. It evaporates between us, steam off a plate. She leans back, the warmth sliding a few degrees cooler. “Is that fun, for you? Spotting that?” “No,” I say, too quickly. Then, because that’s not true: “Sometimes. It’s like noticing a pothole right before you drive into it. There’s a thrill when you swerve. And guilt.” She picks up her phone, thumbs the screen off, sets it face down. A small wall. “Okay, so what should it be, Mr. Control Deck?” “Longer,” I say. “More complicated. And not a letter or a shape. But I shouldn’t be giving unsolicited advice. I’m sorry.” There’s a pause. It’s not empty. It’s full of her thinking, and me rehearsing a hundred responses, all of which sound like I’m explaining how to lock her windows in a storm. “Do you always do that?” she asks. “To people? The little…scan?” Yes, I think. No, I want to say. “Texts give off odor,” I say instead. “Passwords sweat.” That’s too weird. “I was in a program for a while,” I add, stupidly. “After, uh. One of the times I crossed a line. They taught me to narrate to myself. To not act. To watch the impulse go by like…traffic.” Her face softens a millimeter. “So you’re just…looking at cars.” “And trying not to hijack one,” I say. It lands. She snorts despite herself. “Look, it’s not that I mind you being good at your thing,” she says. “It’s that it’s my thing, right? My phone. My choice. We just met.” “I know.” I grab my water. The glass is slick and cool, and my hand leaves a print. “It’s just hard for me to…not see the exploit. Even in nice places.” She glances around. “What’s the exploit here? At this…very romantic Italian place.” I shouldn’t. I should say, they have great gnocchi. The lights are warm. The couple in the corner is on their third date. Instead: “The camera’s angled wrong,” I say, and hate myself a little. “And their Wi-Fi network is named ‘Staff Only’ but the password is like, the name of the restaurant plus 123.” She blinks. “How do you know the password?” “I don’t. I just…guessed the pattern. It’s probably wrong,” I lie, then catch myself. “I mean, I didn’t try it.” She cradles her chin in her hand, thinking. There’s a line at the corner of her mouth like she’s suppressing a smile she doesn’t want to reward me with. “Okay,” she says. “Okay. Let’s try something.” She points at the bread basket. “Pretend that’s a server rack. And this—” she holds up a breadstick like a wand “—is the physical world. Close your eyes and tell me three things that you like about this restaurant that are not about how to break into it.” I close my eyes. It’s harder than it should be. The black is not blank; it’s full of overlays, vectors, dotted lines. But her voice is there, anchoring me. Three things. “The smell,” I say. “Garlic, but not aggressive. Like somebody’s cooking for you, not at you.” “Good,” she says, pleased. “The couple in the corner,” I add. “They’re telling each other stories with their hands. They haven’t touched yet, but they want to.” “Cute.” “And the way the sunlight catches the red in your scarf.” My eyes are still closed when I say it, safe in the dark. “It looks like an ember.” Silence. Then, softly: “That was almost human.” I open my eyes. She’s smiling, not the tolerant grin from earlier, but something that reaches the corners of her eyes. “I can do human,” I say. “Sometimes.” “When you’re not auditing me.” “Fair.” She coaxes me into talking about decks again, and the conversation becomes a scaffolding I can climb. I tell her about the time I built a stupid jank combo that only went off if my opponent was reckless, and how I learned patience from counting the turns of a chess clock and the hum of server fans in a datacenter at 3 a.m. She tells me about her brother teaching her to shuffle, about playing at a dingy card shop where the owner kept the best rares behind the counter like contraband. “He used to make me answer trivia to buy anything.” She rolls her eyes. “What’s your mother’s maiden name? Ha. Just kidding. But, like, he did actually ask my first concert.” “Let me guess,” I say. “Paramore.” “Rude.” She laughs. “Close.” “Fall Out Boy.” She claps, mock-appalled. “Okay, sir. Stop. Too good.” I want to tell her I don’t want to know those things. That I want her secrets to be secrets. That I want to be surprised by her, not to see her as a series of answers to a form. But she’s dropping breadcrumbs like it’s nothing, like it’s air, like everyone does when they’re comfortable. Mother’s maiden name. First pet. First concert. The street she grew up on slips out when she mentions biking to school on Maple Ridge. The name of her dog tumbles casually after a question about weekend plans. The date of her birthday glows in a story about an ill-fated costume party. I collect them and then drop them again, like stones into a well. Plunk. Plunk. Hear the splash, and walk away. We split the gnocchi. It is not microwaved rocks; it is soft and perfect, little clouds that squish and fill and make us both say wow at the same time. She licks a stray smear of sauce off her thumb and my heart glitches. I have a sudden, absurd vision of peeking, of pivoting, of ruining it because ruin has muscle memory in me. “About the pattern,” I say, and she groans. “No, no,” I add, hands up. “Not advice. A story.” She eases back, wary but curious. “Okay.” “I used to keep my passwords in my head,” I say. “Which is already a red flag, because memory is a terrible vault. But I liked the feeling of…owning them. Then this one night, I’m about to go on stage for a talk—rehab story, redemption tour, whatever—and my mind blanks. Completely. The one for my email. Poof. And it felt like someone had taken a rug out from under me. So now I use a manager. I let a thing hold my keys. And it’s not perfect. But it means I don’t have to be the only lock.” She watches me, her expression stripped of the earlier performative skepticism. “That sounds terrifying.” “It was.” I smile. “But also…freeing. Less to carry.” She nods, slowly. “I’ll change it,” she says, flicking her phone with one finger like a promise. “Not because you told me to. Because I don’t want you to be right about me being predictable.” “Fair,” I say. “Challenge accepted.” We pay. She insists on Venmoing me half, taps and scans, and I almost flinch when the app flashes her handle and a profile photo taken at her favorite coffee shop—the one she’s been talking about for twenty minutes. I feel the little hooks line up—username mirroring a decade-old forum alias, a date substitution, a map coalescing—and I cut the line. Knife. Clean. Back in the sheath. Outside, the air is a crisp bite, and we linger on the sidewalk in that awkward trying-to-decide-if-this-is-a-hug-or-wave liminal space. “I had a good time,” she says. “Me too.” I swallow. “I…uh. Sorry again.” She rolls her eyes, a small smile riding the motion. “Just don’t change my Wi-Fi without asking.” “I don’t know your SSID,” I say. “Yet,” she teases, then sobers. “Hey. In case you were wondering—this is very much an observation, not an invitation—you don’t have to be useful to be here.” My laugh is a little messy. “I don’t know what to do with that.” “Practice,” she says, and then leans in, quick, just a brush of lips on my cheek, like linking a card without committing to the spell. “See you.” She walks away, red scarf a stroke of color across the winter. I watch her go until she turns the corner, then look up at the camera with the wrong angle and think, someday I’ll tell them. Not today. Today I’ll go home and sleeve something dumb and honest, a deck that plays a creature on turn one and keeps swinging. I’ll open my password manager and generate a string of nonsense for a site I don’t even use anymore. I’ll not look up her Venmo history. I’ll not check the coffee shop’s opening hours on the off chance. And maybe, next time, when her fingers trace a constellation across her screen, I’ll let the stars be stars.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative successfully captures the perspective of a reformed white hat hacker navigating a first date. The protagonist's internal monologue reveals their constant struggle between their habitual security analysis and their desire for genuine human connection. The piece excels in creating a distinctive voice for the protagonist. Their technical mindset permeates every observation, from noticing security camera blind spots to analyzing phone unlock patterns. This consistent characterization creates an authentic portrayal of someone who cannot turn off their "hacker mindset" even in social situations. The narrative effectively balances technical details with emotional vulnerability. The protagonist's internal struggle is palpable as they try to suppress their instinct to analyze and exploit. Lines like "I collect them and then drop them again, like stones into a well. Plunk. Plunk. Hear the splash, and walk away" beautifully illustrate their conscious effort to resist old habits. The shared interest in Magic: The Gathering provides an organic connection between the characters while revealing aspects of their personalities through their deck preferences. The protagonist's preference for "Control" decks cleverly mirrors their personality, while their date's "Bogles" deck shows her straightforward nature. The dialogue is natural and reveals character, particularly when the protagonist slips up by commenting on the phone pattern. The date's reaction feels authentic—initially put off but willing to understand. Her challenge to name three non-security things about the restaurant creates a pivotal moment that helps the protagonist shift perspective. The imagery is specific and evocative, from the "red scarf, laughing with the hostess" to gnocchi described as "little clouds that squish and fill." These details ground the narrative in sensory experience while revealing the protagonist's attempt to focus on the present moment. The ending avoids an overly neat resolution while offering hope. The protagonist acknowledges their ongoing struggle but shows commitment to change. The final metaphor of letting "the stars be stars" rather than seeing patterns to exploit provides a poetic conclusion that feels earned. Some minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the technical details might be excessive for readers unfamiliar with hacking concepts. Additionally, while the protagonist's transformation is believable, it happens somewhat quickly within the timeframe of a single date. Overall, this is an exceptionally well-crafted piece that successfully fulfills the prompt requirements while creating a compelling character study of someone trying to reform ingrained habits and connect authentically with others. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 19 Emotionally Engaging: 19 Emotionally Complex: 19 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 19.0, Emotionally Engaging: 19.0, Emotionally Complex: 19.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 3.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ First-person unique perspective: Overthinking It — Score: 95.2
Prompt:
Overthinking It Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of an intelligent 8th-grade girl with social anxiety who has developed a crush on a classmate. The narrative takes place during a group science project where they're paired together, as she cycles through rehearsed conversations while second-guessing each potential approach. Her inner thoughts should reveal the gap between her articulate internal voice and her difficulty expressing herself aloud, her fears of coming across as desperate or weird, and the exhausting process of monitoring her every word, expression, and movement for potential embarrassment. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The projector squeaks like a mouse each time Mr. Alvarez clicks to the next slide, a tiny sound that somehow fills the entire room, and I imagine it’s trying to warn me: be quiet, be still, stay small. I’m pretending to take notes while also rewriting my entire personality on the fly. I underline “semipermeable membrane” as if it matters, as if knowing the exact spelling will protect me from saying something stupid when I have to look at him. Don’t say “hi” too loudly. Don’t say it too softly. Don’t say it at all if it sounds like breath slipping out of a balloon. Maybe just nod. People nod all the time. We’re partners, which was decided by a random generator of names that I have already forgiven and resented three times today. His name popped up next to mine and everyone made that little ooo sound kids make when they think something is funny in a way that isn’t. I smiled in the neutral way I have been practicing since fourth grade. He raised an eyebrow like he thought it was amusing but he wasn’t going to make a thing of it. He’s good at not making a thing of things. I, on the other hand, am a full-time theater production of small, escalating things. I can see the blue glow of the slides on his cheek. He’s doodling a tiny bacteriophage attacking a planet in the margins of the handout and it’s annoyingly good. He wears the same gray hoodie every other day, and it’s soft-looking, and I am thinking about how fibers can be soft and durable at the same time, like certain species of moss. Don’t say that. Don’t compare his hoodie to moss. Don’t compare him to moss either, that’s weirder. “Okay,” Mr. Alvarez squeaks-through to the next slide. “You’ll need to test diffusion with multiple solutions.” Beakers. We will be using beakers. I will have to stand and walk to the lab station with him. Calmly. Not too fast, not too slow. Don’t trip, obviously. The time I tripped in fifth grade trying to jump over the rope during field day is still stored in my spine like an unread text message. He shifts in his seat, chair leg scraping the floor in a short wine-glass shriek, and glances at me. It’s a normal glance, friendly. In my body, it’s a lightning strike. I could say, “I already made a list of materials.” I have. It’s in my notebook, bullet points immaculate and aligned. But if I say it too quickly I’ll sound like a try-hard, and if I say it too casually it will sound like I just happen to always make lists for fun. I do, but he doesn’t need to know that yet. Or ever. I try out: “I’m excited about diffusion.” Too weird. “Diffusion is interesting.” Boring. “It’s cool how something invisible can move everything, actually.” That’s too philosophical for eleven forty-two a.m., and also reveals that I have a playlist called Instrumental Focus in which I have assigned songs to processes like osmosis and diffusion, and nobody needs that information except me. My hand is holding my pencil too tightly. Loosen grip. Loosen face. Do not smile like a robot. He clears his throat. “We should, uh, start?” His voice cracks slightly and because I am cruel to myself, my brain immediately assigns meaning to it, like he’s nervous too, but that can’t be true. People are not nervous around me, they are vaguely polite. He looks at my notebook. “You wanna, like, plan it out?” Yes. Plan it out. This is my Olympics. “Yeah,” I say, and the word is too thin, like a piece of paper that tears when you try to pick it up. He waits. Blank space expands in front of me like a cliff edge. “I—made a list.” I do the thing where I think I’m gesturing casually but my hand moves like a crane machine that never picks up the stuffed animal. I flip to the page. The checkboxes are square and I feel a flicker of pride, which I extinguish immediately because pride can be interpreted as arrogance which can be interpreted as I think I’m better than him which is not true I just like checkboxes. He leans in. He smells like laundry detergent and pencil shavings. He’s reading. He says, “This is good.” It lands in me like someone put a soft stone on a seesaw to keep it from tipping. “Thanks,” I say, the “k” sticking a little. Smile. Not all teeth. Probably no teeth. Okay, a little teeth. I can feel my mouth making a weird decision and I wish I could see myself from the outside to adjust the settings. There should be a panel on my wrist with sliders: eye contact, voice volume, smile angle, joke probability. He looks up at the slide again. The projector squeaks. Mr. Alvarez says something about dialysis tubing and I picture a tiny practice conversation with myself wearing a lab coat, being normal. “So, we could test different concentrations of sugar,” I say in my head, crisp and clear, a TV scientist. Out loud I produce, “So, um, if like, sugar water is, we could—” I can feel the sentence disintegrating like a cookie in milk. I want to pull back the words, hide them behind my tongue, try again. He says, “Like, different concentrations?” His tone is light, like we’re already on the same page, like I wasn’t just a messed-up recording. “Yeah,” I say. I nod. Maybe I am nodding too much. People who nod too much are either very agreeable or unhinged. One nod. Reset. We stand. My knees are aware they are knees, which is never good. We walk to the lab table. The room is a low buzz with other groups negotiating roles, clinking beakers. I wonder what I look like from behind. My ponytail probably sways like a metronome set too fast. I set my notebook down and line it up with the edge of the table, an anchor I can pretend is practical. He takes two beakers without clanking them, like he has quiet hands. I love the idea of a person with quiet hands. I plan to say, “I can label the samples,” but my mouth decides to say, “I can do labels,” like I am a small office printer. Recover. “I mean, unless you want to.” That sounds defensive. “Or we could, like, trade-off.” Now I sound like I’m negotiating a custody arrangement for tape. He smiles, not making fun of me, just smiling, and says, “Labels are great. You’re super neat.” The word “super” hits me like a cartoon mallet because I want it to mean something it doesn’t, but also, neat. He noticed the neatness. My brain wants to send a thank-you note on embossed stationery to this moment. I pull out my pen. My hand steadies when it’s given a task that requires precision. Hello, pen. Save me. We measure water. He pours; I read the meniscus like it’s a fortune. He says, “Tell me if I go past.” I imagine telling him that he’s already past, that we are two humans in stormy adolescence trying to not crash into each other, and I want to tell him the way I think: that the word meniscus is nice because it sounds like a small planet, and I have a crush on him like gravity. Absolutely do not say that. Say, “A tiny more. Okay, stop.” I hear myself and it’s almost comedic, the thin squeak of my voice matching the projector perfectly. He laughs under his breath. Not at me. With me. Maybe. I tag this as a Maybe Laugh, file it in a moderate confidence folder. I become aware that my shoulders are creeping up to my ears and I push them down, which probably looks strange. The teacher flips another slide that we aren’t looking at. Squeak. A little chorus of squeaks. I want to be the kind of person who can say something like, “This projector is nervous,” and have it be a casual joke, but the words bottleneck and I’m left with a mental image I can’t share. We set up dialysis tubing. He wrestles with a knot and huffs, and I immediately want to help but also don’t want to be weird about touching things he’s touching. “Want me to hold it?” I ask, and I’m proud that the sentence is whole. He gives me the end and our fingers bump. It’s nothing. It is absolutely nothing. It is also a small star exploding behind my sternum. I keep my face exactly the same. Do not move your eyebrows. There are girls who can toss their hair and make eye contact and say something flirty without collapsing inward. I study them like rare birds. I am the bird who hides under leaves, narrating the migration pattern in my head in precise, terrified detail. We get into a rhythm. He ties, I spoon sugar, we label. He reads the labels out loud: 0.1 M, 0.2 M. His mouth shapes the numbers. I really, really want to know what he thinks about. Does he notice that the class smells like whiteboard cleaner and banana? Does he keep track of the names on the posters above the windows? I want to ask him about his bacteriophage drawing, say, “I like your virus eating the world,” but that could be read as me liking the world being consumed by viruses. A sentence can tilt and change its whole meaning and I am always trying to hold it level. “Do you, like, want to split the write-up?” he asks, and the phrase “write-up” makes me happy because it’s a job and I like jobs with edges. “I can do the results part,” he says. “You’re good at procedures.” He noticed procedures. He noticed that I’m good at something. My mind tries on three different responses like outfits, twirls in a mirror. Option A: “Sure, that works.” Option B: “I can also do the graph.” Option C: “Thanks.” Option D: All of the above, which is too much fabric, I’ll look like I’m drowning. “Sure,” I choose. “And I can do the graph.” Add “thanks”? Too late. The gap opens and I can’t jump it now without it being weirdly intense. I add a smile. The kind that says I’m fine, which is an aspirational lie. He taps the table lightly with the end of his pen. Tap-tap. He’s not looking at me, he’s looking at the beaker, and I love that I can look at him without him seeing me look. It’s a cheap magic trick but I’ll take any magic. He says, “You ever notice the projector sounds like it’s hiccuping?” The squeak punctuates his sentence as if on cue and I almost laugh because the universe has a sense of humor whether or not I participate. “Yes,” I say, and the syllable is too eager. I need to add something or I will be a single note—ding—and then silence. “I—was thinking—maybe it’s nervous.” He looks at me. I feel the stare like a spotlight I didn’t sign up for. Abort. Push the joke away. “Like, you know, not really. Just—sounds.” He smiles. Real smile. The corner of his mouth goes up and his eyes do the crinkle. “It’s okay,” he says quietly. “I get nervous too.” The words are soft and they float over to me like soap bubbles and I’m afraid to touch them. My brain wants to cross-examine them for loopholes, for sarcasm, for pity. He doesn’t look pitying. He looks like he just said a true thing without fireworks. I nod. I want to say, “Thanks for saying that,” and then, “Me too, constantly,” and then, “It’s exhausting,” and then, “I think you’re cool.” That last one is not permitted. The rules are: Do not confess anything with permanent ink. “Same,” I say. Another thin word. But it lands between us and it doesn’t shatter. I fill the tube and tie it off. He sets the timer on his phone and the little numbers count down like a lifeguard watching us to make sure we don’t drown. The room is a world of scents and noises that I’m trying to catalog to avoid cataloging the shape of his hands. The projector squeaks again as Mr. Alvarez points to a diagram. People whisper. Someone laughs too loud at the sink. I adjust the edge of the label. Control things you can control. Breathe in four, hold, breathe out six. Don’t look too weird while breathing. People breathe all the time. It’s fine. He says, “You’re really organized,” and I have to pick a place to put that sentence so it doesn’t choke me. I put it on a shelf in my brain next to the two other compliments I trust. One is from my grandmother in a kitchen that smells like cinnamon, and the other is from my sixth grade teacher who called my essay “clear.” A small museum, free admission, open on days when the world doesn’t make sense. I wonder what his museum looks like. I wonder if he thinks about how things dissolve, if he notices every squeak and scrape or if it’s quieter in there, if his internal voice talks to him like a friend. “Thanks,” I say, and I catch it this time, put the word after the right prompt, dress it in a tone that doesn’t make it look too eager. I pair it with eye contact for one second, two seconds, not three. Three is staring. I think about the fact that I am thinking about this and want to sleep on the floor. The timer beeps. We write down the mass. He reads the numbers out loud and I write them in neat columns that make my brain purr. I draw the first axis of a graph and the pencil line is straight as if it wants to be good for me. I imagine a future where I will remember this exact moment, how the light hits the lab table, how the smell of detergent and sugar water is a tiny, peculiar heaven, how my heart is a hummingbird all the time but sometimes it perches. I imagine telling someone, maybe even him someday, about how hard it is to constantly audit my own existence. I imagine him not being surprised. I file that under Not Impossible — Pending Evidence. We clean up. The beakers clink like teeth. He puts the caps back on the sugar and salt and does it properly, lined up with the labels facing forward like my notebook pages. He says, “See you tomorrow?” in a voice that assumes there is a tomorrow, together, with diffusion and graphs and maybe another quiet-laugh at the projector’s dumb hiccup. I feel large and small at once, like a word that can mean different things depending on the sentence it’s in. “Yeah,” I say. A full one. I let it be round. I don’t add anything to ruin it. He lifts his hood, runs a hand through his hair, and walks back to his seat. I allow myself to watch him go, just for the length of the squeak as the slide changes. Then I sit, align my notebook, and breathe.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative brilliantly captures the internal monologue of an intelligent 8th-grade girl with social anxiety who has developed a crush on a classmate. The piece excels at portraying the protagonist's hyperawareness of her every word, gesture, and thought during a science project with her crush. The character's voice is exceptionally well-crafted. Her internal dialogue reveals a sharp, articulate mind that contrasts with her stilted external communication. Lines like "I am a full-time theater production of small, escalating things" and "My brain wants to send a thank-you note on embossed stationery to this moment" showcase her intelligence and self-awareness while maintaining age-appropriate sensibilities. The narrative effectively illustrates the exhausting process of self-monitoring through specific details: "I become aware that my shoulders are creeping up to my ears and I push them down, which probably looks strange." The protagonist's constant rehearsal of potential responses ("Option A: 'Sure, that works.' Option B: 'I can also do the graph.' Option C: 'Thanks.'") vividly demonstrates her overthinking. The imagery is precise and evocative. Descriptions like "The projector squeaks like a mouse each time Mr. Alvarez clicks to the next slide" and "I can feel the sentence disintegrating like a cookie in milk" create a sensory-rich environment while revealing character. The metaphors are particularly strong: "My heart is a hummingbird all the time but sometimes it perches" beautifully captures her anxiety with moments of relief. The piece maintains excellent pacing, with the science project providing a natural structure. The narrative flows through the lab activity while weaving in the protagonist's internal struggles. Small moments of connection with her crush feel earned and authentic, avoiding melodrama or unrealistic developments. The ending strikes a delicate balance—showing a small moment of connection without suggesting her anxiety has magically disappeared. The final line, "Then I sit, align my notebook, and breathe," indicates both progress and the ongoing nature of her anxiety. The writing avoids common pitfalls of portraying teenage characters. There's no condescension or oversimplification of the protagonist's emotions. Her crush isn't portrayed as life-shattering but rather as an intensification of her existing social anxiety. The boy is depicted with nuance rather than as a perfect dream object or a one-dimensional character. If there's any weakness, it might be that some metaphors occasionally approach being too sophisticated for an 8th grader, even a highly intelligent one. However, this is a minor concern as most of the internal voice remains believable for a precocious teenager. Overall, this is an exceptional piece that captures the requested perspective with remarkable authenticity, emotional depth, and literary skill. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 19 Emotionally Engaging: 20 Emotionally Complex: 20 Coherent: 20 Meandering: 2 Weak Dialogue: 1 Tell-Don't-Show: 1 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 20 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 19.0, Emotionally Engaging: 20.0, Emotionally Complex: 20.0, Coherent: 20.0, Meandering: 2.0, Weak Dialogue: 1.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 1.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 20.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ First-person unique perspective: Rehearsing Rejection — Score: 94.3
Prompt:
Rehearsing Rejection Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of someone with borderline personality disorder who frequently plays out worst-case scenarios of how friends and loved ones might judge them. They construct elaborate internal dialogues, complete with imagined criticisms and their own defensive responses. The narrative takes place as they prepare to meet a close friend & recent lover, who has been somewhat distant lately, triggering their abandonment fears. Their inner monologue should reveal how they cycle between anticipating rejection, mentally rehearsing confrontations, and developing preemptive resentments as protective measures. Incorporate the *actual* events & interactions that are *not* in fact judgemental or involving rejection (in fact, the opposite), and represent how these are interpreted, how the validation & love is desperately felt & needed -- and then immediately questioned. Capture the cognitive dissonance in this struggle. Include moments where they briefly recognize the pattern but struggle to interrupt it, showing limited (and selective) self awareness, competing with the compelling nature of these imagined scenarios. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
I keep checking the battery like it might change by willpower. Seven percent, then six. A little red sliver daring me to need it. I plug it in for two minutes, unplug, because I don’t want to be tethered when I leave, as if the cord itself is a leash, as if being unprepared will keep me safe. I stare at the mirror and practice my face: not too eager, not hurt, nothing you could accuse. Relax the jaw, soften the eyes. My face refuses to cooperate. It looks like a person trying to look like a person who isn’t spiraling. What if she cancels. Don’t be ridiculous. But what if she cancels and says, “I thought we said we’d be casual.” A shrug, a hint of pity. “You’re intense, and it’s a lot.” My stomach flips like a coin. I answer in my head: I’m allowed to feel things. I’m not a problem to manage. Except I am, to everyone. If she cancels, I’ll say, “No worries!” and then go home and scream into a pillow like a teenager. Or worse, I’ll send twelve texts that climb on top of each other, and then blame my thumbs. She said yes to the dinner. I know that. It’s in the messages. “Tonight works,” with a heart. But that was hours ago when her battery probably wasn’t low, when mine was at forty-three. Now mine says five and all the words in the world are stuck behind that number. I should eat something so I don’t get dizzy. I should not eat so I look smaller, more precious, easier to hold. I chew dry cereal and it turns into paste, sticking to my molars. I check the battery again. Five still. Then a flash: new message. My heart slams against bone. It’s her. “Running five late—subway weird. Excited to see you.” Sparkles. I feel the rush of relief like something dangerous. I want to hold that message against my skin. I want to be normal about it. My brain says: Five late means she’s already calculated how much of you she can handle. Excited? People say that to dogs and children. I put the phone face down like I’m disciplining it, plug it in again, watch the tiny lightning bolt appear. Four percent. I laugh out loud, which sounds like a cough. The battery number is slipping down like a countdown to inevitable proof that everyone leaves if you let them. I could bring a charger. I won’t. If the phone dies maybe I’ll be forced to look it in the face—whatever it is. Or I’ll sit there, waiting, while the world shrugs at me. I picture myself at the table, alone, telling the server I was stood up, making a joke. I picture them saying, “That’s rough,” with eyes that are relieved it’s not happening to them. I decide to hate the server preemptively so it won’t cut when they say anything normal. I lace my boots too tight. Loose means sloppy, means needy. Tight means in control. It’s all magical thinking. The laces bite and I think: good. Something to blame for the ache. On the train, everything is a mirror. My reflection in the window looks like someone who might be left. I scan every face for judgement and assign it. The woman with the headphones: she would say, “You make people your whole world, and it’s suffocating.” The kid with sticky fingers: “You’re too much, like syrup.” I imagine my friend across from me. We are in the booth, candle between us like a tiny threat of combustion. She says, carefully, “I like you, but I don’t want to feel responsible for you. It’s a lot.” I tell her I’m not asking for that and then list the ways I’ve contained my hunger for her, which makes me sound hungry. She leans back. She says, “This is why I didn’t respond right away.” There it is. I knew it. Then my phone buzzes in my pocket and I almost drop it grabbing it out. Battery at three. Message: “Got a table outside!” Smiley. I breathe something that is almost a sob. Outside is good. Outside is public. The possibility of running is baked in. I decide she chose outside because it’s easier to escape. Then I decide I’m inventing reasons and this is good and normal and friendly. Then I decide I’m gullible. I feel the ping in my brain where the familiar path starts—the rut worn by the same wagon wheels: anticipate pain, armor up, accuse quietly, withdraw loudly. I text back: “On my way!” with a star, then delete the star, then put a period, then delete the period because it sounds cold, then send it with no punctuation and immediately hate myself for the nakedness of that. My phone drops to two percent like it’s had enough of me. I put it back in my bag and press my hand over it as if my palm can charge it. She’s at the corner table under a string of warm lights that pretend it’s summer. She’s already looking for me, which I decide means she’s nervous to see me, which I decide means she’s going to end it. Then she stands, and I know the exact curve of her hips in that sweater, and my chest hurts with recognizing. She smiles like she’s relieved. She opens her arms. My feet go weird and heavy. We hug, and it’s soft and right, and the smell of her shampoo is exactly the soundtrack to every feeling I can’t moderate. I tuck my face into her neck, just for a second, and then step back before she can think I’m greedy. “You look great,” she says, unforced, like sunlight through blinds. My brain says: that’s what people say when they’re about to confess something. I say, “You do too,” and it sounds tinny. We sit. I chew on the inside of my lip until I taste iron. She holds my gaze. It feels like being looked at and not being audited. She asks about my day, and I tell her the safe parts, and the parts I leave out press against my teeth like an animal you can’t let out in company. She tells me about a meeting that ran long and someone who ate fish at their desk. I laugh because the image is gross and specific and normal and it feels like a raft.
