Your age sits on you like a spell you forget until you pass a mirror.” She doesn’t look at him. “You are old like a prison tower is old,” she says. “And just as full of other people’s bones.” He likes that too much. His grin goes razor-thin. The power between them twangs. For a moment she is certain that if she looks into those orange lenses she will see a shape that is not a man and she will not look away in time. She squares her shoulders instead. “I don’t have patience for theatrics.” “You love theatrics,” he says, and the scorn is tender and vile at once. “You love to walk in as the solution to a problem you invented, and only occasionally fix something no one else could. You like being the storm that the village remembers.” Her magic flares. A gust slaps him back a step, rearranging his coat into fire-bright streamers. Her voice goes silk-quiet. “And you like to pretend your leash is a choice. Keep speaking and I’ll turn that mouth into a useful purse.” He has to laugh. He does it because he must, because he is compelled by the perfect audacity of the threat. He is also evaluating, always: the temperature of her power, the quickness with which she sets a ward, how the fatigue does not show in her cheekbones. She is dangerous. She is in control. He wants to see her lose it. “Stop circling,” he says suddenly, smiling. “Hit me.” She blinks once, lazy, affronted. She considers genuinely. The raven circles back and kaws once: northwest, the sound means. She doesn’t look at it. She looks at him. “If I hit you,” she says, “you’ll like it.” “You know me so well,” he says. She hits him. It is not a fireball and not a bolt; it is gravity, concentrated and toppled sideways. The barn bows as if a giant places a hand on it. The red coat slaps to the floor with an indignant grunt that sounds far too entertained. He fractures, not bones—in him bones are theory—but self, a smear of violence across planks. He pulls back together very quickly, licking his teeth with a tongue that was not in his mouth a second ago. “My turn,” he says, warmly, almost grateful. He doesn’t move. The shadow at her feet moves for him. It flowers up like a black rose, petal on petal of cold, and clamps her ankles. She is up to mid-calf in midnight before she cuts herself free with a hand gesture so small it seems rude. The shadow shrieks without sound, offended that prey refused it. He applauds once, mockery formal as courtly courtesy. They stand again, reset, both flushed in the ways that matter for them. He could rip her head off. She could turn him into a thought stored in a beeswax candle and blow him out. Neither wants an end; both want the edge. “Northwest,” she says to the raven, as if speaking only to herself. “Let’s go.” “Running to him?” he asks, amused. “Or from me?” “Neither,” she says. “Doing my job. I do have one.” He falls into step at her side, a parody of an escort. They take the street, then the footpath through the fields where the wheat sheaves look like sleeping monks under the harvest moon. He keeps half a pace behind, gentleman as predator; she keeps her hands loose, fingers making circles that taste the ley lines humming under the earth. “Perhaps,” he suggests casually, “you want something from me, and that’s why you haven’t turned me into a goat.” “Darling,” she says, and the endearment is a blade. “If I wanted something from you, you wouldn’t even know you’d given it.” He’s charmed, and he despises charm. His eyes—somewhere behind the lenses—narrow. “You want an end,” he says, abruptly serious. “As I do. A different end. A child’s laugh in a house that doesn’t burn at dawn. You’d make bargains with devils for it.” “Says the devil,” she replies. The words hit him like a caress and a slap. She doesn’t speed up. She doesn’t slow down. A faint crack opens in the night; she smells of lilac and gooseberries and stubborn iron. He wants to pry the crack wider. He wants to be the one to hear her voice break. “You do not know what bargains I’ve made,” he says, and for the first time the voice is a little less certain. Memory crosses the path like a fox. He steps on it deliberately. “You do not want to.” “Oh, but I do,” she says, and there is naked truth in it that startles them both. “And I don’t. Don’t mistake curiosity for desire, Alucard.” The name is a touch. He notices she did not ask it; she reached for it and took it. He likes that more than he should. The ravens leads them to a hill crowned with junipers. The smell there is old and green. A circle of stones marks the place where witches used to dance badly and men sharpened their fear into knives. A man stands at the center, or what was a man until longing turned him inside out. His eyes are pits where his wife and son fell. He raises his arms, and the wind comes. The wind screams not because of him but for him. Yennefer’s expression shifts infinitesimally; he knows that kind of grief. She hates that she knows. Alucard does not care. He cares for the spectacle. “Don’t kill him,” she says, already moving, beginning the careful work of unspooling a spell without letting it remember it is a knot. “He is stupid, not evil.” “Stupidity is the parent of evil,” he counters, but holsters his gun. For her. For now. He watches her work. It is needlework, and blood magic by way of mercy, and it hurts her to be gentle. The vortex trembles under her hands like a horse unused to reins. He steps in when the revenants try to require a more permanent solution, his bullets making decisive arguments. She spares him not a glance. He spares her too many. It takes time. The harvest moon tilts toward weary. The man at last collapses, emptied, sobbing like a bellows with no fire left. The power drains from the hill into the stones, into the soil—into the sleeping fields. Yennefer is pale against the night now, the violet of her eyes nearly black. Alucard is as he was—because he always is. He offers her a hand up from where she knelt to draw a last line of unbinding. She looks at it, at the glove and the implication and the unbearable arrogance of it. She takes it. He pulls her to her feet and does not let go for half a heartbeat too long. “Pity doesn’t suit you,” he says. “Neither does obedience suit you,” she answers. She steps away, shakes her skirt as if to rid it of the smell of him. Her lip curls and then smooths. “You are a monster.” “And you,” he says, “are a monster that prefers candles to torches.” She almost smiles. “I told you. I’m not sweet and I’m not a maiden in distress in need of saving.” “And I,” he replies, bowing as if mocking court, as if honoring a queen, as if unable to decide which, “am not a knight. The bird of Hermes is my name…” “Eat your wings somewhere else,” she says, and makes a door in the air that reflects the harvest moon as if it were a coin. The smell of lilac and gooseberries deepens. The hinges of reality groan. “We won’t be sharing anything.” He tips his hat. “Not even a dance?” “Especially not that,” she says, and steps through. The door closes on the scent and the heat and the glimpse of a woman who could love someone and ruin him carefully. He stands on the hill and watches the moon sink, and his smile is a wound that he refuses to let heal. He could follow. He does not. The village, emptied and blank as a sheet awaiting a story, breathes once in its sleep. He turns his face toward the next hunt, toward anything that might be bait worthy of him. The harvest moon bleeds down the sky and takes its shadows with it. He does not leave footprints when he goes.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece is a remarkably sophisticated character study that brings together two powerful figures from different fictional universes. The author has crafted a tense, atmospheric encounter that perfectly captures the essence of both Alucard and Yennefer while creating a compelling dynamic between them. The prose is exceptionally strong, with vivid imagery that establishes a gothic, foreboding atmosphere from the opening paragraph. The description of the "crimson harvest moon" that "hangs swollen over the thatch and timber" immediately sets the tone, while phrases like "its light lacquered onto puddles and broken cart wheels like blood on a butcher's block" demonstrate sophisticated metaphorical thinking. The characterization is outstanding. Alucard is portrayed with all his menacing arrogance and predatory nature intact. His introduction as "an outline of absence: too tall, too still, hat brim devouring moonlight" perfectly captures his otherworldly presence. Similarly, Yennefer is depicted with her characteristic cold exterior, magical prowess, and underlying complexity. The author has clearly understood both characters deeply, incorporating their canonical traits while allowing them to interact in ways that feel authentic to their established personalities. The dialogue is exceptional, with each character's voice distinct and true to their source material. Yennefer's cutting remarks ("You are old like a prison tower is old... And just as full of other people's bones") and Alucard's predatory playfulness ("Perhaps you want something from me, and that's why you haven't turned me into a goat") create a verbal sparring match that reveals character while advancing the narrative. The power dynamic between the characters shifts constantly as instructed, with neither willing to show weakness. Their interaction is a dance of power, curiosity, and reluctant respect. The author skillfully weaves in references to both characters' canonical backgrounds—Yennefer's infertility and Alucard's search for worthy opponents—without making these references feel forced. The plot, while simple, serves as an effective vehicle for the character interaction. The necromantic threat provides a reason for their paths to cross and allows them to demonstrate their respective abilities. The resolution with the grieving man adds emotional complexity, highlighting the difference in their approaches—Yennefer's unexpected mercy versus Alucard's cold pragmatism. The writing maintains a consistent tone throughout—gothic, atmospheric, and tinged with dark beauty. The author employs sophisticated sentence structures and vocabulary without becoming overwrought. There are occasional moments where the prose verges on purple ("The red of his coat drinks the color from the world"), but these generally work within the gothic atmosphere being established. The ending is particularly strong, with Yennefer departing through a portal and Alucard choosing not to follow, maintaining the tension between them without resolution. The final image of Alucard turning "his face toward the next hunt" reinforces his eternal nature and restlessness. If there are weaknesses, they are minor. Occasionally the metaphors become slightly strained, and there are moments where the prose risks becoming too ornate. However, these instances are rare and don't detract significantly from the overall quality. In summary, this is an exceptional piece of crossover fiction that demonstrates a deep understanding of both characters, sophisticated prose skills, and the ability to create a compelling narrative within a relatively short word count. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 1 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 1.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Fanfic-crossover: Prison Strings — Score: 87.2
Prompt:
Prison Strings Jolyne Cujoh & Makima Write a story where Jolyne Cujoh (JoJo's Bizarre Adventure) and Makima (Chainsaw Man) cross paths at a supernatural prison facility. Jolyne is immediately suspicious of Makima's falsely sweet demeanor, while Makima is intrigued by Jolyne's Stand ability. Their battle of wits escalates dangerously as Jolyne realizes how manipulative Makima truly is. **Jolyne Cujoh (JoJo's Bizarre Adventure)** Jolyne is the daughter of Jotaro Kujo and the first female JoJo protagonist. Her Stand, Stone Free, allows her to unravel her body into string that she can control. She's hot-headed, foul-mouthed, and doesn't take disrespect from anyone. She was framed for murder and sent to prison. She has a distinctive butterfly tattoo on her arm and wears her hair in two buns. Despite her tough exterior, she's deeply loyal to her friends and family. She can be impulsive but is highly adaptable in battle. She inherited her father's ability to stay cool under pressure but is more emotionally expressive. Famous quote: "If there's no Mickey, this shit ain't Disney!" **Makima (Chainsaw Man)** Makima appears as a young woman with auburn hair and ringed yellow eyes. She's the Control Devil who can dominate anyone she considers beneath her (nearly everyone). She maintains a pleasant, soft-spoken demeanor that masks her manipulative, cold nature. She can create contracts with humans and devils, often exploiting their desires. She's obsessed with Chainsaw Man and wants to control him. She keeps numerous people and devils as pets on leashes. She's practically immortal due to a contract with the Prime Minister. She views humans as lesser beings but mimics human emotions perfectly. Famous quote: "It's okay. Dogs are supposed to die for their owners." Third person, present tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The lights in the corridor flicker like a heartbeat that can’t decide if it wants to stop. A sewage tang hovers over the damp concrete, and the distant groan of pipes sounds like something breathing. On either side of the corridor are cells with slit windows and reinforced doors; most are empty. In one, a girl with green hair and two buns leans back against the wall, fingers drumming her thigh to the rhythm of the flicker, as if daring the light to blink at her again. Jolyne Cujoh rolls her shoulders, tattoos catching the pallid strip of light. Stone Free’s thread loops idly around her wrist, almost invisible. She pretends to ignore the footsteps at the far end of the corridor, slow and steady, too quiet for boots, too polite for a guard. They come anyway, soft as breath, and the shadow that arrives ahead of the person is long and neat. Makima appears as if the corridor had been expecting her. She is immaculate in a plain shirt and black tie, auburn hair braided loosely, eyes a careful gold that reflects every flutter of the broken light. She smiles with a gentleness that looks like the cover of a kindness she’s rented for the day. “Hello, Jolyne Cujoh,” Makima says, stopping three bars short of the cell. “I’ve been looking forward to meeting you.” Jolyne snorts, rising with a cat’s ease. “That right? Well, I wasn’t looking forward to meeting the Easter Bunny either, but here we are.” Makima’s gaze drifts to the filament around Jolyne’s wrist. “I heard about your ability. It’s quite beautiful.” “Don’t talk like you already know me.” Jolyne’s eyes narrow. “Only creeps do that. And the light here’s bad enough—your eyes don’t help.” Makima chuckles softly, like she’s humoring a child. “The lighting is unpleasant. I can put in a request for changes. These facilities are… utilitarian.” “Yeah? Put in a request to let me out, too. Since you’re apparently miss connections.” Jolyne flicks the thread, and it whispers through the bar slot, an absent-minded cat’s tail testing the edge of a door. Makima tips her head, measuring everything in the cell in one glance, including the empty cot, the scuffed floor, the food tray abandoned under the bench. “You want out because you’re innocent,” she says, as if stating the obvious is charity. “Wow, you’re intuitive. You got a receipt for that, or you just say things?” Jolyne’s voice turns a shade rougher. “Since you’re name-dropping, what’s yours?” “Makima.” “Makima, huh.” Jolyne repeats it like she’s trying on a pair of handcuffs to see how easy they are to slip. “You with the prison? The government? Something with a big table and a room full of men pretending they matter?” Makima’s smile tightens, too slight to be insulted. “I’m with an organization that deals with unusual threats. Your Stand, Stone Free… it interests me. You turn yourself into string, but you remain yourself. Most people struggle not to come undone.” “And you always talk in riddles, or are you saving actual answers for a premium package?” Jolyne steps closer to the door. The flicker over them gives Makima strobing halos. Makima doesn’t move. She watches Jolyne with the easy stillness of a handler watching a leashed dog test how far the collar lets it run. “You’re interesting because you’re disciplined,” she says. “Stubborn. Loyal. If I released you, you’d run to your friends, your father, and you’d fight for them even if you died doing it. You’d be useful.” Jolyne smiles, thin and wolfish. “There it is. The pitch.” “I could arrange your freedom,” Makima says, not bothering to lie about it being difficult. “You would follow my orders in return.” And there’s the leash. Jolyne’s thread stiffens with a sound like a plucked harp string in a bad dream. She’s met people like this. Not many wear the face so perfectly; the ones who do always hold the knife close to their chest, smiling, waiting to see if you’ll bend. “It’s okay,” Makima adds gently. “You don’t need to decide immediately.” “Lady,” Jolyne says sweetly, “if there’s no Mickey, this shit ain’t Disney. Don’t sell me a fairy tale and think I’ll wag for a biscuit.” Makima laughs, delighted. “Oh, that’s good.” The corridor hums. Somewhere far away, a gate slams. The air shifts, a pressure difference like an elevator car moving. Jolyne angles her head. “What’s your thing, Makima? Besides being creepier than a tickle in a morgue. Do you make contracts? Sniff out weakness? Take people apart and wear them like jewelry?” Makima’s eyes soften as if Jolyne has just said something endearing. “I prefer dogs to jewelry.” Jolyne grins, daring her. “I bite.” “I know,” Makima murmurs. “That’s why I came in person.” The thread on Jolyne’s wrist flows forward, a pale line sliding through the bar slot, drifting in the air like a lazy serpent. It splits, tips fanning, mapping, tasting. The corridor is a geometry problem, and Jolyne solves it in a breath. Stone Free anchors threads to the ceiling, to the hinge of the cell door, to the drain grate, to the weight sensor under Makima’s right heel. It’s all very neat. Jolyne is neat when she fights. She learned to be. Makima glances down, not alarmed, only curious. “Will you restrain me, Jolyne?” “Trying to decide if you’re worth keeping still,” Jolyne says. “I could cut you, too. Or choke you.” The string tightens. “But you know what? I don’t get the vibe you’d care. I get the vibe that if I pulled hard enough, you’d smile at the blood.” Makima doesn’t deny it. She steps forward once. The strings bend like grass around a slow river. Jolyne feels the tension change, the way a fishing line whispers when something big touches it. She feels something else, too—the faintest pull on her mind, like a gentle hand smoothing her hair in the wrong direction. “You will be a good girl,” Makima says, soft. “You will—” Stone Free detonates into a thousand sharp threads that rattle the bars and scream against the corridor like the world is tearing a zipper. Jolyne’s eyes blaze. The threads knot crude words in the air between them: NO. “Wrong bitch,” Jolyne says, voice low. “Try that again, and I’ll turn you into confetti.” Makima blinks once, slow. The pull retreats, not offended. Patient. “It’s been a long time since anyone resisted even a suggestion.” Jolyne rubs at her temple with three fingers. The headache is sudden, like chewing tinfoil. “Yeah, well. I don’t do ‘heel.’ Try ‘sit’ and see if I fetch.” Makima takes one step back, and the pressure lightens. Her smile becomes less of a thing she wears and more of an expression. “You really are interesting.” The lights flicker again. One burns out with a faint pop, leaving a stripe of shadow that cuts across Makima’s face like a censor bar. Jolyne’s threads bristle in that darkness, alert. The corridor’s emptiness feels staged, like someone cleared it. “So what’s the real plan?” Jolyne asks. “Make me a pet? Use me to get to someone else? You’re not here just for me. No way.” “Observation first.” Makima’s voice is mild. “Then decisions. Do you know what happens to people who resist me?” “Let me guess,” Jolyne says. “You put them down. Because in your world, dogs are supposed to die for their owners, right?” Makima’s eyes brighten, as if Jolyne has quoted a poem back to the poet. “Exactly.” The thread behind Makima twitches. Jolyne anchors it to the lock, splits it into delicate filaments that feel for tumblers and pins like nimble fingers. The lock is not normal. It tastes like a contract, like something signed in someone else’s blood. Jolyne feels the pushback, the way her strings burrow into a mechanism that doesn’t want to be understood by string or touch or time. “Uh-huh,” she mutters. “Knew it wouldn’t be easy.” Makima watches her reach. She doesn’t move to stop her. The corridor is a chessboard, and Makima is content to see which piece Jolyne thinks she is. “You want me to break out,” Jolyne says, realization dropping like a coin in a jukebox. The song is old, and she knows the lyrics. “You want to see what I do when the walls go down. Who I run to. What I choose. Then you can tug the line.” Makima nods slightly. “I want to see who you love.” “Yeah?” Jolyne bares her teeth. “So you can use them. That’s your kink, right?” “Loyalty is a useful lever,” Makima says, unapologetic. Jolyne breathes, slow and sharp. She thinks of her father, silent and huge in her life like a mountain in fog. She thinks of friends with hands calloused by prison and grief. She thinks of not being able to save everyone, of saving anyone anyway. “Here’s a counteroffer,” Jolyne says. “I walk out. And you don’t follow.” Makima’s lashes lower, amused. “That’s not how this works.” Stone Free hisses through the lock again, threads splitting so fine they become vibration, hum, friction. The mechanism fights. Jolyne smiles at it like a stubborn child. “I’m good with things that don’t want to open.” “You’re very good,” Makima agrees. “But do you know why the other cells are empty?” Jolyne does a quick count of silence. No coughs. No muttered curses. No life. She glances sideways, and the shadow in her look is older than she is. “Because you moved them. Or erased them.” “Because I asked them to leave,” Makima says. “And they did.” The lock clicks, soft as a throat clearing. The door doesn’t swing; it waits. Jolyne’s threads hold it closed, trembling. She stares at Makima. Makima stares back, patient as inevitability. “Walk out, Jolyne,” Makima says, voice faintly kind. “Show me how far your string reaches.” Jolyne’s fingers flex. Threads run up and down her arms in tattooed patterns. She laughs once, hollow. “You really think I’m going to perform for you?” “I think you’ll do what you always do,” Makima says. “Fight.” Jolyne takes a step. The door opens a breath. Cool air slides in, smelling like rain that never comes. Her thread throws a loop over Makima’s wrist, loose, not enough to bind. A threat. A promise. A message she can yank if she needs to. Makima looks down at the loop like it’s a ribbon a child gave her. “Careful,” she says softly. “Tying a line to me ties a line to you.” Jolyne leans forward, close enough to feel the edge of Makima’s calm like a temperature, like a knife. “Good,” she says. “Then if you try to pull, you’ll find out I pull back.” Makima’s smile is serene. “I hope so.” The lights flicker like applause withheld. Jolyne steps out into the corridor, every sense up like a cat’s fur in winter. Threads splay in a network so fine it could catch the dust. Makima falls in step a pace behind, unhurried, as if walking a dog who has chosen her own route but still understands the leash exists. “You can walk,” Jolyne says without turning. “But if you try to talk to my head again, I’ll garrote that pretty voice right out of your throat.” Makima’s answer is polite. “I wouldn’t want to ruin our conversation.” They move through the corridor’s throat, past doors that gape like missing teeth. The facility murmurs with distant forces, the sigh of vents, the scrape of unseen boots, the faint rustle of paper being turned by no one. At the next intersection, Jolyne’s threads taste iron and something older than prisons. Makima’s presence behind her is the quiet of a hunter who has never once tripped on her own breath. “Tell me something true,” Jolyne says suddenly, not sure why she’s asking, only sure she needs to hear the sound of honesty in this place. “Just one thing.” Makima considers. “You will not like me more tomorrow.” Jolyne grins without humor. “I don’t like you now.” “And yet,” Makima says, and when the light flickers again, her eyes glow like coins offered to a river. “And yet what?” Jolyne asks. “And yet we’re walking the same way.” Jolyne glances at the loop on Makima’s wrist and tightens it a fraction, enough to make sure both of them feel it. Her voice is a blade wrapped in ribbon. “For now.” The prison breathes, and they breathe with it, two different predators under the same flickering light, each testing the length of the other’s string.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively captures the confrontation between Jolyne Cujoh and Makima, creating a tense psychological battle that showcases both characters' abilities and personalities. The writer demonstrates a strong understanding of both source materials, incorporating key character traits, abilities, and even signature quotes from the prompt. The prose is atmospheric and taut, establishing the prison setting with sensory details that create a foreboding mood. The flickering lights serve as both literal setting elements and metaphorical punctuation for the power struggle between the characters. The writer skillfully uses imagery that feels appropriate to both anime universes while creating a cohesive style. Character portrayal is particularly strong. Jolyne's defiance, street-smart attitude, and crude language match her canonical personality, while Makima's false sweetness, manipulative nature, and view of humans as pets are all accurately represented. Their dialogue exchange feels authentic to both characters, with Jolyne's colorful expressions ("creepier than a tickle in a morgue") contrasting effectively with Makima's controlled, soft-spoken menace. The writer demonstrates technical skill in maintaining third-person present tense throughout, as requested. The pacing is well-controlled, with the tension building naturally through the confrontation and culminating in Jolyne's escape attempt, which Makima appears to have orchestrated. The story effectively shows rather than tells, using physical descriptions and actions to reveal character motivations and emotions. However, there are a few minor weaknesses. Some metaphors, while evocative, occasionally border on purple prose ("The corridor hums. Somewhere far away, a gate slams. The air shifts, a pressure difference like an elevator car moving."). The ending, while thematically appropriate, feels somewhat abrupt and unresolved, though this may be intentional given the word count constraint and the nature of the confrontation. The dialogue is generally strong, but a few exchanges feel slightly forced in service of showcasing character traits rather than advancing the narrative naturally. For instance, Makima's line "I prefer dogs to jewelry" feels a bit too on-the-nose as a reference to her character's known traits. Overall, this is an impressive piece that successfully merges two distinct fictional universes while maintaining the integrity of both characters. The writer creates genuine tension and intrigue through a battle of wills rather than physical combat, effectively capturing the psychological cat-and-mouse game that would likely occur between these two powerful, strong-willed characters. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Scp: Notes from the Future — Score: 83.8
Prompt:
Write an SCP report about a researcher who begins finding handwritten notes from their future self, warning about a containment breach that hasn't happened yet. The notes become increasingly desperate and incoherent, sometimes containing information that contradicts known reality. Include the Foundation's attempts to determine if this is an actual temporal anomaly or psychological manipulation by a contained entity, and the researcher's struggle to trust their own perception. First person (researcher's perspective with interspersed notes), past tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
Item #: SCP-XXXX Object Class: Pending (Under Review: Euclid/Keter) Special Containment Procedures: SCP-XXXX is presently defined as a phenomenon localized to Dr. [REDACTED], hereafter “Subject.” Subject is to remain on Site-19 under psychological observation. All instances of Note-XXXX (handwritten notes allegedly authored by Subject’s future self) are to be immediately surrendered to Security and submitted to Temporal Anomalies Division (TAD) for analysis. A clean-room office environment (Office-XXXX) has been prepared for Subject with continuous audiovisual recording, sealed stationary supplies, and weekly inventory verification. Foundation memo pads in Office-XXXX are serialized, stored in transparent tamper-evident containers, and tracked by microdot-embedded fiber tagging. Subject is prohibited from bringing personal stationary into Office-XXXX. All memo paper throughout Site-19 has been cataloged and marked with covert isotopic tracers; any Note-XXXX instance not bearing site-authenticated tracers is to be flagged as anomalous. Subject is to undergo daily reality-check protocols, including cognitively anchored questionnaires (RAISA Form 11-T), baseline memory reconsolidation interviews, and Class-W mnestic challenges. No cognitohazardous entities are to be housed within two sublevels of Office-XXXX. Any major containment breach or drill must be followed by a Note-XXXX sweep. Pending determination, no temporal intervention (e.g., Prime-Event Preclusion, Project Butterfly) is authorized. Description: SCP-XXXX refers to the spontaneous appearance of handwritten notes in Subject’s immediate environment, all on Foundation-standard memo paper (Form F-19-M, 3” x 5”), reportedly written by Subject’s future self and predicting a future containment breach at Site-19. Instances escalate in frequency and emotional intensity and have contained contradictory information about Site personnel, floor plans, and containment protocols. I am the Subject. I served as a researcher on Thaumiel-labeled projects and currently consult for TAD. I will write this as a formal report, with my perspective, per Ethics Committee recommendation. Where relevant, I will interleave exact transcriptions of Note-XXXX instances verbatim. I found the first note on a Monday, underneath the keyboard in Office-XXXX. I do not store paper under my keyboard. Note-XXXX-01: If you read this, put the coffee down. Today at 14:32, there will be a false fire alarm. Don’t evacuate. Stay. You’ll want to leave. Don’t. At 14:31, the alarms sounded. My supervisor waved me toward the exit. I did not evacuate. Security later declared the event a sensor fault. No containment units registered anomalies. I showed the note to Security. They confiscated it and informed me that the memo stock bore Site-19 tracers and my fiber microdots. The handwriting matched my own under analysis, but with tremor artifacts I do not display. I had not written the note. I had not locked any stationary under the keyboard. The next day, a memo appeared taped to the inside of my glasses case. The case had been in my pocket. Note-XXXX-02: You didn’t leave. Good. Don’t drink from the south wing fountain. You were right about the copper taste. It’s not copper. I hadn’t mentioned the metallic taste to anyone. I avoid paranoia for breakfast, but I brought a sample to Chem Lab. Trace analysis found ion exchange resin fragments and elevated manganese. Nothing anomalous. TAD flagged the note as “low-grade predictive accuracy, plausible coincidence.” I began keeping the memo pad inventory under video lock. I watched it for three hours. I blinked. A note appeared on the top sheet. Note-XXXX-03: Stop watching the paper. It doesn’t help. You miss the important thing. The breach begins in Maintenance. It’s not Maintenance. It’s us. I asked for a transfer out of Office-XXXX. Denied. RAISA requested a daily written narrative to track my cognitive anchors. This is part of that. It’s important to say: the notes were always on Foundation memo paper. The watermark, the microdots—everything authenticated. I kept my memo pad locked. The notes still came from my own stock, even after I switched to a sealed, serialized pack that Security opened in front of me. They arrived between frames, between glances, at the hinge of a blink. I never caught the moment. Attempts to determine psychological manipulation versus temporal anomaly began within 72 hours. - Hypothesis A: Temporal leakage from a proximal event horizon (localized time loop, pre-breach echoes). - Hypothesis B: Cognitive infiltration by SCP-████ (Class-II reality-adjacent memetic parasite, contained two sublevels down). - Hypothesis C: Non-temporal thaumaturgic forgeries (spoofed tracers, replicated handwriting). - Hypothesis D: Stress-induced cryptomnesia (I write the notes and forget). To test Hypothesis D, Ethics authorized Class-W mnestic exposure. After mnestic dose, the next note arrived in the pocket of my lab coat, which had been sealed and logged. Note-XXXX-04: Mnestics won’t save you from yourself. Or me. Stop trying to remember what I couldn’t forget. The breach date moved because you looked for it. We can measure arrogance in nanometers, I suppose. Still, TAD loves a paradox. They ran a closed-time curve consistency test with a sealed box containing memo paper, a pen, and a high-speed camera. I volunteered to sit with the box. Hours passed. Nothing appeared. When I left to use the restroom, Security sealed the room. On returning, I opened the box. A note lay on top, written in my hand: Note-XXXX-05: You’re going to think this is confirmation. It’s not. The breach is not a breach. It’s a rehearsal you won’t be told about. You’ll screw it up if you stay here. Go to Sublevel 3 at 16:10. Don’t talk. Just count to 200. At 16:10 I went to Sublevel 3. I counted to 200 in the hallway, feeling idiotic. At 16:08, per logs, there was a silent drill among MTF guards I was not cleared to witness. At 16:12, a janitorial cart overturned near me, spilling solvents. I helped upright it. No anomalies occurred. TAD split. Half saw this as predictive validity. Half saw post-hoc pattern-making. I saw a reflected image of my own handwriting that knew I would need belief. The dissonance increased. Contradictions crept in. Note-XXXX-06: Director Halley lost her left eye in the breach. Remember the patch. Her right. It was the right. No. Both. Stop writing this down. You’re making it worse. Director Halley is fine. Both eyes intact. She plays racquetball on Wednesdays. I checked. Note-XXXX-07 arrived on my pillow at home. I live in on-site housing. My door locks are biometric and mechanical. Security found no tampering. Note-XXXX-07: They’re going to ask you to move the 914 key. Don’t. It’s already moved. It never existed. If you move it, the breach starts in Maintenance. In the walls. In the words. We do not store keys for SCP-914 at Site-19. That machine isn’t here. TAD marked this as contradiction-grade. I marked it as a fracture in either me or the phenomenon. My hands shook as I wrote the daily narrative. Psychological evaluation noted increased hypervigilance and derealization. I feared my own interiority, like a hallway with mirrors opposite each other, receding into infinity where I stand to watch myself watch myself. A control experiment placed a Foundation memo pad inside an extradimensional pocket (SCP-███-B) monitored by three separate recorders and a metronome. The metronome stopped at 03:17. The recorders glitched. When the system recovered, Note-XXXX-08 was present, written across four sheets: Note-XXXX-08: We thought shields would work. I thought compartmentalization would make it safe. But it isn’t a place. It’s intention. It’s the memo paper because that’s what we agree is “official.” If it can be official, it can be true. If it can be true, we can make it real. Stop authenticating the notes. We stopped authenticating the notes. RAISA reprimanded me for light sarcasm when I wrote that down. The “breach” became a specter at the periphery. We scheduled a site-wide breach drill and kept me isolated, to see if the notes anticipated the exercise. They did, in a fashion: Note-XXXX-09: It’s July 19. 02:40. You’ll hear the metal sound first, like a dentist’s tray dropped in an empty pool. Don’t move when you hear it. It’s not metal. Don’t run when the lights go yellow. The yellow is not for you. On July 19, at 02:42, the drill sirens triggered. The audible tone is not metal. There was no dentist tray. The lights are red, not yellow. I stayed still anyway. My heart made a noise I have never heard again. I keep thinking of the earliest note: Don’t evacuate. The false fire alarm. The echo of a future calm. Each new note eroded that calm. If this is a malign entity, it knows me intimately. If it is me, I am doing this to myself. TAD introduced a permutation: they replaced my memo pads with blank white slips without watermark or tracers. They told me the replacement, but not when. I woke to Note-XXXX-10 on my desk. Note-XXXX-10: You think you can trick yourself by removing the watermark? This isn’t paper. It’s a promise that we’ll take what is written seriously. They will too. So listen: The breach is a contagion of attention. Don’t write about it. I am writing about it. I am instructed to. I feel sick. On a Thursday I found two notes. One in my shoe. Note-XXXX-11: Scratch behind your right ear if you can read this. They’re watching. Good. Keep them watching. The not-breach starts when nobody looks. And one under my skin, in a lottery of gooseflesh as if raised by static, but later I found the paper tucked in my sleeve cuff. Maybe that was a hallucination. Note-XXXX-12: Halley is dead. She’s not. She will be. She will be the one who saves you. Don’t let her. You save her by not being there. Be late. Director Halley is alive. I have begun arriving late to everything. I suspect harm, causally, in either direction. Security cleared SCP-████’s ward for cognitohazard checks. That entity manipulates trust. Its lexical footprint doesn’t match the notes, and containment was uninterrupted. Another suspect, SCP-███-K, can induce predictive text illusions; it’s in Antarctica. Distance is not always prophylaxis, but patterns did not align. We affixed a simple test: write a note for the future and leave it where the future notes tend to appear. An invitation. I wrote: Control Note: Future me. Stop. The return came three hours later, slipped into my lab coat collar. Note-XXXX-13: If I could have, I would have. If you can, you must. Don’t look at the door at 03:15. It will be open and closed. You will be in and out. At 03:15, I did not look at the door. I stared at the corner of my desk until my eyes watered. When I finally looked, the door was closed, and the hall was empty. Security footage shows the door remained closed. The timestamp jumps. The jump is 23 milliseconds. Enough to nest a heartbeat. Morale is a brittle thing. They gave me a counselor who taught me grounding techniques. Texture of the desk. The smell of coffee. The sound of my own voice naming colors. I would catch a note in the act, and it would already be in my hand. Note-XXXX-14: Rough. Bitter. Blue. Your voice breaks on “green.” You make meaning of it because that’s what we do. Stop making meaning. Start making choices. Choose not to go to Sublevel 4 on the 23rd. The 23rd came. I did not go to Sublevel 4. On Sublevel 4, an electrical surge tripped breakers. No casualties. The surge was scheduled for maintenance. I want to be grateful to the me who warned me, if she exists. I want to be angry at the thing that lies to me, if it exists. The notes grew more frantic. Note-XXXX-15: It’s inside the paper. It’s inside the you that signs forms. Don’t sign the evacuation order. Don’t blink. Don’t breathe. It’s in breath. You cough and it knows. JUDGE THE SQUARES. FIRE IN THE WALLS. HALLEY’S EYES ARE COINS. The yellow is for them. The shift into word-salad suggests increasing stress, either in me or in the source. TAD calls it “conceptual noise.” The handwriting grew jagged. The paper remained Foundation memo paper, even when we swapped to decoy stock, even when I stored the real stock in a safe within a safe, numbered, logged, watched. Note-XXXX-16 appeared in a sealed specimen jar. Note-XXXX-16: You asked if this is manipulation or a temporal anomaly. Yes. If you believe me, I’m an anomaly. If you don’t, I’m manipulation. The breach is the argument we’re having with ourselves. We take a thing seriously enough and we build a protocol and a door to go with it. We taught the world to be formal. It listened. Stop. Stop writing the door. I have tried not to write the door. It is difficult to draft a report without building hinges. Addendum: Determination Protocols - Language analysis across Note-XXXX instances reveals a 0.83 correlation with my written syntax, increased pronoun contraction, and a shift toward imperative mood over time. The tremor amplitude corresponds with sleep deprivation metrics logged in my wearables. Self-fulfilling? Likely. - Tracer analysis: all Note-XXXX instances bear site-authenticated isotopic signatures and microdot fibers matching the memo pads I have access to, including lots I never opened. This indicates either prepositioning in supply chains, retrocausal tagging, or spoofing at fidelity that defeats current detection. - Temporal diagnostics: standard chronometric array shows no consistent metric deviation coinciding with note appearances. One 23 ms video jitter and two recorder dropouts are insufficient for classification. - Cognitohazard screening: no stable memetic signature across notes. No glyph replication. No semantic anchors of known entities. - Psychological evaluation: Subject exhibits stress response consistent with medium-term harassment by an uncertain signal. No psychosis markers. High suggestibility under threat, normal resilience otherwise. I am writing this and I would like to sleep. Conclusion: Undetermined. Provisional classification: Euclid. Ethics Committee Guidance: Limit Subject’s exposure to Note-XXXX by filtering messages through a small team. Do not feed the phenomenon by amplifying its authority. Maintain a record, but do not ritualize it. After I was told that, I found a note in the authorization binder, between “Maintain a record” and “do not ritualize it.” Note-XXXX-17: Ritual is a door. Record is a window. Sit with your back to both. Breathe. I’m sorry. There isn’t a breach. Or there is, and it’s so quiet you mistook it for thinking. If you must choose, choose to be wrong in person. I started coming in late. I started leaving early. I avoid the fountain. I sign my name slowly, as if handwriting itself is an incantation. When the alarms sound, I follow protocol, because we built protocols for a reason. I read the notes and then hand them over. I am trying to trust my perception long enough to let others test it. If this is manipulation, it is elegant and cruel. If it is me, it is a mercy from a worse me. The Foundation’s attempts have been thorough. Mine have been human. There was one more note, this morning. It was folded under my palm when I woke, on my skin but not attached, warm as if it had slept there with me. Note-XXXX-18: It didn’t happen. That’s the breach. It won’t, if you let it. Don’t look for the sound of metal. Drink the coffee. Evacuate when told. Trust not because I said so, but because you can. Trust is also a door. Pick the right one. I drank the coffee. At 09:00, there was a drill. I evacuated with everyone else. The lights were red. Director Halley smiled with both eyes. In the hallway, a janitorial cart squeaked its wheel. It sounded a little like metal, because everything does, if you’re listening for it. I will file this report now, and let it be a window, not a door. I will stop looking at the paper. And if a note appears under my keyboard when I look away, Security will take it, and TAD will test it, and I will drink my coffee and trust that not everything written in my hand must be true. Pending reclassification. Pending me. Pending the moment I blink.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This SCP report effectively captures the essence of the Foundation's clinical documentation style while weaving in a compelling first-person narrative about a researcher experiencing a potentially temporal anomaly. The piece successfully creates an atmosphere of mounting dread and uncertainty, as the researcher struggles to determine whether they are experiencing genuine warnings from their future self or manipulation by an unknown entity. The format adheres well to SCP conventions, beginning with containment procedures and a clinical description before transitioning to the researcher's personal account. The integration of the notes as evidence is particularly effective, showing a progression from relatively coherent warnings to increasingly desperate and incoherent messages that suggest either temporal degradation or psychological deterioration. The writing excels at maintaining ambiguity about the nature of the phenomenon. Is it truly a temporal anomaly, a psychological manipulation, or perhaps even the researcher's own deteriorating mental state? This uncertainty drives the narrative tension and reflects the researcher's own struggle with perception and reality. The prose is appropriately clinical when describing containment procedures but shifts to a more personal, increasingly anxious tone in the researcher's account. This tonal shift effectively conveys the character's growing distress while maintaining the Foundation's methodical approach to anomalies. The piece creates a sense of mounting dread through the escalating nature of the notes and the researcher's increasingly desperate attempts to make sense of them. The contradiction between notes adds to the unsettling quality, suggesting either temporal instability or deliberate manipulation. Where the piece could be stronger is in its resolution. While ambiguity is appropriate for an SCP report, the ending feels somewhat anticlimactic given the buildup. The final notes suggest a potential resolution (that perhaps there was no breach, or that the breach was something more conceptual), but this insight doesn't fully pay off the tension established throughout. Additionally, some of the notes become rather abstract and philosophical ("Ritual is a door. Record is a window."), which, while intriguing, occasionally verges on being too cryptic without sufficient grounding in concrete details. Overall, this is a strong SCP entry that effectively blends the clinical with the personal, creating a compelling narrative about perception, reality, and the nature of containment itself. It successfully captures the paranoia and uncertainty that would accompany such an experience while maintaining the Foundation's methodical approach to anomalous phenomena. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 4 Tell-Don't Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 17.0, Meandering: 4.0, Tell-Don't Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Scp: Unmarked Doors Archive — Score: 91.8
Prompt:
Write an SCP entry about a series of identical unmarked doors appearing in abandoned buildings worldwide that lead to a massive, architecturally impossible archive. Documents within reference a previous global civilization destroyed by an unspecified containment failure. Foundation researchers discover references to their own organization under a different name, including personnel files for current staff dated centuries ago. Include exploration logs revealing sections of the archive actively being removed by entities resembling hazmat teams who flee when approached, and evidence that O5 Council members have visited the archive without authorization. Third person (exploration team perspective) with recovered document excerpts. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
Item #: SCP-7094 Object Class: Keter Special Containment Procedures: All reports of identical unmarked doors discovered within abandoned buildings, industrial ruins, failed infrastructure projects, and condemned municipal structures are to be immediately investigated by Foundation assets. Field personnel are to document all doors matching SCP-7094-A criteria and establish a two-block exclusion zone. Civilian access is to be prevented under cover of demolition, hazardous material abatement, or urban renewal projects. Standard portable perimeter beacons and internal anchor lines are to be placed prior to any entry. No more than two exploration teams (4 personnel each) may be inside SCP-7094 at any one time. Teams will carry tether lines of 1 km length, inertial trackers, and non-networked data capture equipment. Weapons are authorized only for disengagement; discharge within the archive is discouraged due to unknown load-bearing relationships of the environment. All collected documents are to be quarantined for infohazard review prior to transmission to Site Archives. Any reference to “Council,” “Curators,” or “Custodians” is to be redacted pending O5 review. Unmarked hazmat-appearing entities (designated SCP-7094-B) are not to be pursued beyond visual range; capture attempts are suspended following Incident 7094-Ω. Description: SCP-7094 is a global phenomenon consisting of a series of physically identical, unmarked wooden doors (SCP-7094-A) intermittently appearing in abandoned buildings worldwide. To date, ███ instances have been recorded on six continents. Each SCP-7094-A is of late 20th-century commercial manufacture, latch type mortise, with identical microscratches surrounding the doorknob forming a shallow, inverted crescent pattern consistent across all documented instances. No manufacturer marks or serials are present. X-ray imaging reveals internal components inconsistent with any single known standard. When opened, SCP-7094-A does not reveal the immediate interior of the hosting structure but instead provides access to a continuous, enclosed environment: a non-Euclidean archival complex of indeterminate size designated SCP-7094-Ω (“the Archive”). Internal geography includes corridors, stacks, mezzanines, scriptoriums, and vault chambers that cannot be reconciled with external dimensions. Bearings rotate unpredictably; gravity and horizon remain constant. The Archive contains shelves, cabinets, map cases, and paletized containers filled with a heterogeneous mixture of media: codices, vellum rolls, bound folios, microfilm, tab cards, magnetic tapes, optical media, and certain substrates not yet characterized. Cataloging systems present are inconsistent, employing scripts known and unknown. Numerous documents reference a prior global civilization with advanced anomalous and para-technological capacity that underwent a catastrophic failure of containment approximated as sudden and total. The entity or mechanism of failure is unspecified; references are euphemistic and redacted within the documents themselves. Of particular note are multiple references to an organization functionally congruent with the modern Foundation, here rendered in archival documents as “The Custodial Directorate,” “The Directorate,” or “The Foundation of Custody.” Documents include personnel records that map one-to-one with current Foundation staff, including living personnel, with accurate biometric and biographical details and photographs consistent with centuries-old capture media. Dates range from 300–700 years prior to present day. Cross-checks with personnel files confirm alarming fidelity. SCP-7094-B are mobile entities resembling hazmat teams (smooth, off-white positive-pressure suits; dark visors; no insignia) observed removing materials from the Archive and transporting them toward areas that terminate in occluded apertures or fogged bulkhead doors. SCP-7094-B avoid contact, do not vocalize, and retreat upon approach. On two occasions, SCP-7094-B displayed coordinated evasion and deployed occluding smoke that did not disperse under conventional air movement. Items removed by SCP-7094-B are not observed elsewhere in SCP-7094-Ω. Discovery: The first confirmed SCP-7094-A was discovered in a condemned tram depot in ███████, Latvia. Local urban explorers reported “a library door where a workshop door used to be,” accompanied by photographs of distinctive scratches around the knob. Agents dispatched entered the door and emerged with four vellum folios describing containment protocols for an entity class called “King-Swarm,” cross-referencing “Custodial Director O5-3.” Subsequent instances appeared in rapid succession in Detroit (USA), Campo Grande (Brazil), Newcastle upon Tyne (UK), and Tamanrasset (Algeria). All bore identical knob scratches. Addendum 7094-1: Exploration Logs (Excerpts) Exploration Alpha-3 Team: MTF Rho-10 (“Card Catalog”), 4 personnel. Lead: Lt. D. Varma. Entry Point: SCP-7094-A in a shuttered textile mill, Ghent, Belgium. Objectives: Reconnoiter adjacent stacks, recover catalog schema, avoid engagement with SCP-7094-B. [Begin Log] 00:00:16 – Entry achieved. Temperature 17°C. Ambient noise: distant ventilation, intermittent page rustle with no obvious source. Lighting: diffuse, ceiling-paneled. Architecture: Early-Modernist stacks suspended by tension trusses over voids of unknown depth. 00:07:31 – Team identifies first signage: carved wooden placard inset with brass. Script resembles German Fraktur with Cyrillic features. Translation incomplete: “…Department of Lost Cities (Annex A–J).” 00:11:05 – Sgt. Karanja retrieves a ledger. Pages foxed but intact. Ink stable. Notation: “Index of Post-Event Municipalities, Containment Lifted for Cause (Authorization: Custodian Council).” Cross-reference: “Curators: O5-1, O5-7, O5-9.” Note: “Council convened at Depth Blue; minutes sealed.” 00:15:22 – First encounter with SCP-7094-B. Two entities at end of aisle, loading folios into gray hard cases. Marked behavior: glance toward team, then immediate withdrawal down a side corridor, leaving one case. 00:17:48 – Case opened under quarantine protocol. Contents: personnel dossiers. Names: Dr. A. █████, Technician H. Molina, Researcher F. Okoye (currently assigned Site-19). Photographs on silvered plates dated 421 years prior to present; image fidelity high. Marginalia: “Transfer to Directorate Annex Seventeen upon ascendancy. Deny public death.” 00:19:02 – Lt. Varma orders partial retreat. Markings at junctions: numeric sequences that do not match inertial map. 00:28:40 – Team reaches a balcony overlooking a reading hall. Floor plan impossible: four identical staircases descending in parallel orientations that ought to intersect. A brass plaque bolted to the balustrade reads: “Archive 0: The Continuance of Memory. Admission by Writ of the O5 Council Only.” 00:29:10 – Lt. Varma: “Council? Our Council?” No response. 00:35:50 – Extraction via tether. One dossier carried out; remainder sealed. [End Log] Recovered Document Excerpts (Post Alpha-3) - “There was never a single breach, but one failure. All chambers opened in chorus. The Custodians had prepared a million keys and one lock, and it was the lock that failed. Let it be written so the next Directorate will not repeat the mercy that made us vulnerable.” — Folio 12, Archive 0. - “O5-3 objects to the term ‘Foundation’ for the Directorate’s new mandate, stating it invites recursion. O5-11 supports the poetic symmetry.” — Minute scrap, charred, legible margins only. Exploration Gamma-2 Team: MTF Psi-4 (“Stack Watchers”), 3 personnel. Lead: Cpt. H. Abassi. Entry Point: SCP-7094-A in a decommissioned air-raid shelter, Osaka, Japan. Objectives: Penetrate deeper vaults, track SCP-7094-B, retrieve catalog tags. [Begin Log] 00:05:12 – Team passes through a series of steel fire doors labeled “Deacidification Bay” and “Spores.” Air tastes alkaline. White dust on floor shows boot prints similar to Foundation standard, size variance suggests multiple groups over time. 00:12:44 – Contact with SCP-7094-B (four entities). They are pushing a wheeled cart loaded with sealed binders. When hailed, they deploy gray vapor. Thermal shows silhouettes retreating into side corridor whose walls bear fresh scrape marks. 00:13:30 – Cpt. Abassi orders pursuit. B turns down a ward labeled “Custodial Council – Restricted Proceedings.” 00:15:01 – Door ahead is shut by B. Surface: brass, handprints visible. Lock: six-disc assembly unknown to team. On the door, etched: “Council Summaries: Sealed by O5 Vote (Unanimous, 13/13).” 00:19:25 – Sgt. Takeda produces photos of a noticeboard adjacent to door. Paper notices pinned with iron nails. One reads: “Visitation Log: O5-4, O5-5, O5-8. No record in schedule. Admonishment delivered by Curator-Prime.” Ink wet. No time signature. Abassi remarks: “They’ve been here.” 00:24:40 – Audible movement behind walls. Shelving begins to retract into slots; a conveyor belt draws entire sections into an unseen recess. The corridor shortens in real time; floor markers move underfoot. Team withdraws. 00:32:50 – On exit route, the hallway formerly taken no longer exists. In its place, a thin gap behind a roller — evidently an interface where stacks are removed. A single paper rectangle remains wedged in the track: “Directive 0: Continuance. If the Directorate falls, memory must be made harder than time.” 00:46:20 – Extraction achieved with difficulty. One iron nail recovered for metallurgical analysis. [End Log] Recovered Document Excerpts (Post Gamma-2) - “We will abandon the public face. We will be names on paper, then names on film, then names encoded and salted. A city that forgets dies like an animal. We will be the city that never forgets.” — Preamble, Custodial Charter (Undated). - “Personnel: Abassi, Hadiyeh. Assignment: Director’s Runner, Archive Logistics. Note: ‘Remains noncompliant with inventory protocols. Promoted regardless.’ Date: Year 612.” — Dossier leaf with organizational crest resembling Foundation sigil inverted. Exploration Delta-5 Team: MTF Mu-9 (“Binders’ Sons”), 4 personnel. Lead: Dr. K. Delaney (attached researcher). Entry Point: SCP-7094-A in a collapsed municipal amphitheater, Córdoba, Argentina. Objectives: Deep dive into “Annex: Aftermath.” Confirm Council visitation. Document removal mechanics. [Begin Log] 00:02:10 – Entry. Ambient humidity rises. Walls clad in ceramic tile lettered with an unknown abjad. Shelves hold sealed clay envelopes with wax stoppers and bar-coded plastic bands; temporal inconsistency noted. 00:09:00 – Team encounters an observation platform. Below: vast carousel of stacks rotating slowly around a central shaft emitting cool light. At equidistant points, large square apertures open, and segments of shelving slide into darkness as if harvested. 00:11:45 – SCP-7094-B observed operating at two apertures. One entity notices the team and taps a wrist device. A chime sounds. Floor vibration increases. More shelving retracts. 00:15:22 – Dr. Delaney retrieves a clay envelope that resisted removal by B. Seal impression: two concentric circles, thirteen radial marks. 00:19:31 – Cpl. Ibarra shouts; points to a glass-walled office above the carousel. Inside: silhouettes of three individuals in business attire, posture consistent with observation. One raises a hand in a wave that could be interpreted as acknowledgment or warning. Office door marked: “O5 Oversight Gallery.” When approached, the office is found empty, dust intact; only a visitor’s card remains on a blotter reading: “Appointment: Custodian Council, Ad hoc. Attendees: 4, 5, 8.” 00:24:05 – Public address voice (nonlocalizable, neutral male): “Annex Aftermath is in motion. Please conclude your work.” SCP-7094-B close ranks and accelerate removal. Team captures a binder dropped in haste. On its spine, stamped: “Site-19: Decommissioned Artifacts.” 00:29:48 – Delaney attempts to access central shaft. Heat increase registered; Geiger counter mild elevation. Internal light modulates in a slow pulse. Sounds like distant ocean. 00:33:00 – Withdrawal initiated as floor plates shift toward apertures. Tethers remain taut. A B entity, cornered, makes a universal stop gesture and points emphatically at the exit route. No hostility. 00:40:22 – Extraction complete. Recovered materials sealed. [End Log] Recovered Document Excerpts (Post Delta-5) - Envelope contents: brittle vellum strip. Text: “O5-4, -5, -8 visited without writ. Curator-Prime notes: ‘They think memory obeys authority.’ Sanction: None. Remedy: Remove their footprints.” Ink analysis: iron gall, anomalously resistant to oxidation. - Site-19 binder, tab: “Decommissioned Object File: SCP-173. Decommission refused. Returned to Containment. Reason: Recurrence parameter exceeds archive capacity.” Handwritten marginalia: “Stop sending it here.” Incident 7094-Ω: Following Delta-5, Overseer liaison O5-█ instructed a halt to further exploration pending Council review. Within 72 hours, seven known SCP-7094-A instances spontaneously vanished, leaving only empty, unscarred jambs in the host structures. A remaining instance in a South African pump station was used for an unscheduled entry by an unknown three-person team matching Foundation professional profile but lacking transponders. Interior cameras show them bearing O5-level access badges. They entered the SCP-7094-Ω Oversight Gallery, stayed 11 minutes, then departed. No recovery of materials observed. Shortly thereafter, the pump station portal sealed; door reappeared as a standard, locked maintenance door. Scratches around the knob restored, but mirror-reversed. Notes: SATCOM later recovered a short-range transmission from within SCP-7094-Ω: “Memory does not belong to you.” Source unconfirmed. Addendum 7094-2: On the Scratches All SCP-7094-A doors display identical scraping around the doorknob: an inverted crescent roughly centered on the spindle axis, two millimeters deep at apex, feathering outward. Microscopy reveals minute scoring lines radiating from a common template; the pattern appears to be a negative-relief of a fingerprint spiral repeated at decreasing scales. Symbolically, this may constitute a key-signature or sigil. Analysis ongoing. Addendum 7094-3: Personnel Cross-References Of 1,382 personnel files recovered or imaged within SCP-7094-Ω, 407 correspond to current staff. Dates of birth, education, and postings match Foundation records with uncanny precision, except for dating offsets from 300 to 700 years prior. Several files include annotations predicting career moves that subsequently occurred after recovery. In one case, a file for Dr. H. Molina included the note “will suffer a left hand injury in year +2; assign to one-handed terminals,” preceding an accident by fourteen months. Ethics Committee Commentary: “We cannot treat this Archive as merely a resource. It is either our future recording our past or our past recording our future. In either case, theft is still theft.” O5 Note (Redacted): [Expunged in full.] Closing Statement: SCP-7094 continues to represent an existential and epistemic threat to the Foundation’s self-conception and operational security. Its contents suggest that a prior Custodial organization, whose structure mirrors our own, failed to prevent a total containment collapse but succeeded in encasing memory within an impossible architecture subsequently set to cull itself when approached unlawfully. Evidence that certain O5 Council members have visited SCP-7094-Ω without authorization is under active review. Hazmat-like entities continue to remove sections in ways that reduce exploratory access and erase physical traces of visitation. The Archive appears to remember who walks its halls — and to remove what it decides we should not see. Pending Council consensus, all non-critical explorations are suspended. The doors remain. The scratches are the same on every one.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This SCP entry is a remarkably well-executed piece that demonstrates a deep understanding of the SCP Foundation format while creating an intriguing and conceptually rich anomaly. The response crafts a compelling narrative about an impossible archive that contains records of a previous civilization and a previous iteration of the Foundation itself. The piece excels in its adherence to the SCP format, including containment procedures, description, exploration logs, and recovered document excerpts. The clinical tone is maintained throughout while still allowing for moments of existential dread and philosophical questioning that characterize the best SCP entries. The concept of the archive is particularly strong - an architecturally impossible space that contains records of a previous civilization destroyed by a containment breach, with the implication that history may be cyclical. The inclusion of personnel files matching current Foundation staff dated centuries ago creates an effective sense of uncanny dread. The hazmat teams removing sections of the archive add another layer of mystery and tension. The exploration logs are particularly well-executed, providing a sense of discovery and escalating mystery while maintaining believable character actions. The recovered document excerpts are concise yet evocative, hinting at larger mysteries without overexplaining. The prose is clinical when appropriate but allows for moments of evocative description. Phrases like "Memory does not belong to you" and "A city that forgets dies like an animal" are particularly effective in establishing the philosophical themes of the piece. The narrative builds effectively to the revelation that O5 Council members have been visiting the archive without authorization, creating internal tension within the Foundation itself. The closing statement effectively summarizes the existential threat posed by the archive while leaving enough mystery to maintain reader engagement. There are no significant weaknesses in the piece. It avoids purple prose, maintains a consistent tone, and creates a coherent narrative despite the complex concept. The characters, while not deeply developed (appropriate for an SCP entry), act in believable ways within the context of the Foundation universe. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Classic sci-fi: Offworlder (Le Guin) — Score: 88.0
Prompt:
Classic sci-fi: Offworlder (Author style: Le Guin) Write a chapter following a young diplomatic envoy sent to address tensions on a distant human colony where humanity has diverged into distinct subspecies through both natural adaptation and separation of lineages. Against protocol, the envoy slips away from official functions to walk the streets alone, encountering markets, ordinary citizens, and social structures that contradict the official briefings. Upon returning to their quarters, the envoy is reprimanded by Command, and is tasked with approaching the stationed Minister of Science (a political posting rather than scientific). A challenging conversation ensues, in which the envoy's wits and will are tested, by a seasoned political operator looking to test the mettle of the offworlder. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The first thing was the way the light did not belong to me. The station had the narrow, old windows of the early colonial period, set deep into stone that had been quarried from this hillside centuries ago. The light came in at an angle and came pale, and what it struck held more of it than I did. The carved lintels over the doorways were crowded with glyphs—spirals, blades, a bull with the moon between its horns, a woman whose hair was serpents. They had told us about the glyphs on the shuttle, but I hadn’t expected them to be so deft, or so patient. The stone curved like a knuckle around each little myth. “We are guests,” the Aide had said. “We are honored to be welcomed. We do not walk alone.” I walked alone. It was not bravery. It was an argument I could not win by speaking. When the speeches in the Hall of Assemblies had concluded, when the wine had been lifted three times to ancestral names and to the names of ships, when the Minister of Commerce had smiled and placed his hand on my sleeve as if it were a brooch, I slipped through a side door and down a stair, and let the air of the building cool my face. I told the guard in my best dialect that I needed air. He looked, not at me, but at my neck, at the V of skin unadorned, and did not stop me. The street broke open below with the sound of selling: a river with the different tongues of fish. On one side, the old stone, a whole cliff of it, pocked with niches and carved with those Earthly pictures—Athena’s owl, the fox that ate the sun in a story I remembered from my grandmother. On the other side, a row of stalls on wheels, made from thin metal, painted in colors that the dust had chastened. Between them, people moved like weather. I had been briefed. I knew that after Advancing Day, after the third generation, there had been a separation—not an official one at first, but gradual. The long-night uplanders lengthened and thinned, the joints of their hands a little more winged, their eyes widened against the dark. The river-country people thickened, shorter bones supporting wider feet, their hair growing fast and thick with oils that kept the mosquitoes at a distance. In the coastal towns, the gills were rumored, but the briefings insisted they were merely decorative folds, as useful as the rings in their ears. We’re all human, the briefing said; no one wanted to say more. Here, no one was saying much. They were talking to each other, bargaining in a manner that did not perform itself for me. A woman with high cheekbones and the sort of eyelids that shadowed her eyes even when she was fully awake laid a scatter of something like blue nuts into a basket. A boy with fingers so long that his knuckles had an extra knuckle looped his hand over a rack of dried skins. At the end of the stall a thin uplander girl took a coin between the crook of two fingers and held it up to the light, turned her mouth away to spit a husk from her teeth. “Forgive me,” I said, and the girl looked at me without moving her head. “For what?” she said. “For looking like a thief,” I said. “I mean—” I turned to the glyphs cut into the stone behind her, a boat riding up the peak of a wave, a man with oars and a lion’s tail. “Everything looks not how I was told it would look.” “Then your telling was wrong,” she said, and put the coin in a little iron box. “Or your eyes are wrong. Which is it?” “Likely both,” I said. “What do you call these?” I pointed at the blue nuts. They looked like stones gnawed by the sea. “Dry seaflower,” she said. “You eat them when the rains end. They make you sleep without dreams.” “And those?” A rack of braids hung like cured meats. “Wrist-warmers,” she said. “For uplanders when they come down. Their blood is too quick in them. You are not upland.” “No,” I said. “I’m offworld.” That word moved across her face and left nothing. “Farther than the desert?” she asked. “Farther,” I said. “Then why is your hair like theirs?” She nodded toward a middle-aged man whose hair had been braided with red thread. He had river-feet, wide and split almost, the toes spread. “My hair is like my mother’s,” I said. “She would like your dry seaflower. She dreams too much.” The girl shrugged. “Your mother is far. You cannot bring it to her. You will eat it and sleep alone.” Then she looked at me with interest that arrived abruptly. “What did they tell you, in the telling place?” “They told me you had gills,” I said, before I could weigh it. She opened her mouth very slightly and showed me the delicate scalloping at the back of her jaw. “I do,” she said. “For beauty. And for the river when it is cold. And for the men from the coast, who like to think I am something else. What are you, Offworlder? The same, and like a far cousin.” “I am a listener,” I said, because it was on my seal. “I am here to help.” She picked up a wrist-warmer and turned it so that the seam caught the light. It had been sewn with a thread that reflected green, like the bottom of a pool. “We help ourselves,” she said. “You can help by not buying badly. Those are not for you. They would make your blood too quick.” I bought a handful of dry seaflower. I bought a small strip of cloth with a glyph stitched into it—a crescent and a woman’s eyes, which, on Earth, had once been a goddess. The girl took my coins. When I turned again, two boys were running past me, their feet smacking, and behind them a man shouting, not angrily, but with the urgency of bread. Further down the street, a woman in an apron washed stone with a bowl—a gesture that made no sense until the light swung and I saw that she was painting the stone with a thin milk. The glyph under her hand became brighter as the milk sank into it. Her apron was stitched with the head of a bull and a labyrinth of lines that twisted and doubled back on themselves. “Why do you paint them?” I asked her. She smiled, and the smile had missing teeth. “So they remember us,” she said. “Not the other way around?” “You remember yourself every day,” she said. “You look at a spoon. You see your face. The stone is slow. It needs our help.” In that moment I was more angry than I had been in months, because in the briefing no one had said anything like this. We had lists of factions, and of trade imbalances, and of disputes over water rights in the upland swales. I had underlined “mutual suspicion regarding reproductive partnerships” and circled “Minister of Science (non-scientist).” There were bullet points. There were no spoons. When I came back into the station, and climbed the spiral stairs—each step worn down on its outer edge—I could hear the Aide’s voice and our Commander’s voice overlapping. The sky had tilted into evening, thinning to violet. The air smelled like the seaflower in my pocket, a chalky sweetness. “I went for a walk,” I said when I came into the room. “You went alone,” the Commander said. He was younger than the stone and older than me in the way that a man can make age a garment. “Against protocol.” “I did not disappear,” I said. “I went one street down. I bought something. I listened.” He did the thing with his mouth that is not quite a smile and not quite the keeping-in of a smile. “You listened when we were listening,” he said. “We would have let you speak in the Hall. The Minister of Science—” “Is a politician,” I said. “I know. I’m to keep my head. I’m to speak as if I have a head.” “You are to speak to him in an hour,” he said. “He is expecting you. He is in his office on the north side.” “Now?” I said. “You will go now,” the Aide said, like a hand pushing my shoulder without contact. “And you will remember that you speak for us.” “Do I?” I said. I meant it as a question. It came out as something else. The Commander’s eyes narrowed. The Aide’s mouth thinned. “You speak for us,” the Commander said. “Who else?” “For myself,” I said. “Sometimes.” He let that sit like a stone on a table.
