Then he nodded. “Do both,” he said. “If you can.” The Minister of Science—whose name was Malen, but whose title dragged behind him like a cloak—had his office at the end of a passage lined with niches. In each niche a little figure stood: a woman welding a spear, a goat stepping over a sleeping boy, a man whose head had been the head of a bird, though here the carver had made the bird a fish. The office door had a lintel carved with a gear and a cluster of grapes. The Minister liked to be called Doctor, though he had never worked a lab more complicated than the inside of a council chamber. He stood when I came in and came around the desk as if we were friends. “So this is the Offworlder,” he said, and took hold of both my hands with his. His palms were soft and dry. “And young. Commander sends me a child.” “Sir,” I said. “Minister.” “Doctor,” he said, and his smile sharpened. “You come to tell me what the stars think of us.” “We don’t have stars of our own to think with,” I said. “Just your sun, while I am here.” He laughed, and then he did not. He sat back, and his face changed. He was not tall. He had a wide waist. His hairline was even, like a line someone had drawn with a ruler. There was a ring on his thumb made of the same stone as the lintel. “You were seen,” he said, “walking the lower street alone.” I said nothing. “You are either brave, or foolish, or very sure of us,” he said. “Which is it?” “I wanted to see,” I said. “A street is a simple place to begin.” He put his hands together. They looked as if they had not done much hard work; he was clever enough to know that I had noticed. “And what did you see?” he said. “Be careful. I will know if you are telling me what you think I want to hear.” “I saw seaflower,” I said. “Blue nuts. Children who run with their toes spread to catch the stones. A woman painting milk on old stories so the old stories remember her. Wrist-warmers that would make my blood too quick. The fact that you like to be called Doctor.” He sat very still. Then he laughed again, but this time there was something like approval in it. “Ah. So you will not be easy,” he said. “Good. We have had too many easy people from your ships.” “I am not from a ship,” I said. “I am from a town that smells like kelp and diesel and old paper. The ships came later.” “You are trained,” he said. “They have told you about our divisions, about the water rights, about how the uplanders marry late and the river-folk young, and the coast-folk not at all sometimes, and about the children with the tidy lungs who can go from hill to river without the spinning sickness. They have told you that this is a problem.” “They have told me there is tension,” I said. “And what do you say?” “I say that the tension is not a problem,” I said. “It is a signal. It says the body is alive.” He watched me as if he could lean into my skull and read the glyphs there. “That sounds like a clever thing to say,” he said. “It also happens to be true,” I said. “I’m not here to solve you. I’m here to listen, and perhaps to suggest—to try not to make anything worse.” “You can always make things worse,” he said. “That is the easiest human skill.” “And always make them better,” I said. “Sometimes by not standing between people and what they already do for themselves.” He let out a long breath. “The Hall will want concessions,” he said. “Your Commander will want me to say that we will agree to the shared water charter without delaying three sessions while the uplanders fast and make proverbs. He will want a timeline. He will want a piece of paper to send to his superiors.” “I’m not my Commander,” I said. “I want to understand why your uplanders fast. What proverb comes from three sessions of hunger that does not come from one?” Malen’s face changed again. He settled back into himself, like a cat into a bowl. “You ask questions that have answers,” he said. “Most people ask questions that are invitations for a speech.” “So,” I said. “Tell me one of your answers.” He looked toward the window, where the light was becoming very thin. “When the uplanders fast for three sessions, they say the question descends from the head into the hands. On the first day, you are hungry in the mouth. On the second, you are hungry in the belly. On the third, you are hungry in the bones. If the question survives the bones, then it is a question worth answering. If not, it will die with the hunger.” “And will your water charter survive your bones?” I asked. He looked back at me. There was no smile now. “That,” he said, “is what you are here to help me know.” “I cannot make your uplanders’ bones decide,” I said. “But I can ask them to tell me how the question feels there.” He nodded, slow as the stone. “Do you know,” he said, “what the glyph over my fireplace says?” There was a small hearth with a low flame. Above it, a relief of a man with a hammer, a woman holding a spindle, a child with a bowl. “I don’t read your script,” I said. “Only your mouths.” “It says, in Earth-speech we have kept for when we want to be serious, Know thy measure,” he said. “Not yourself. Measure. The length of your stride. The strength of your hand in water. The reach of your saying. You have a short stride, Offworlder, because you are young. That may save us. Or it may break your ankle.” “I will mind the stairs,” I said, and for a moment he almost laughed. Then he stood up. “You will come to the Hall tomorrow,” he said. “You will sit and say nothing until I say your name. When you walk through the lower streets again, take someone with you who knows where the quick blood is. And do not buy wrist-warmers.” “I did not,” I said. He raised his thumb and showed me the stone ring. “You bought something else, though,” he said. “I can smell the seaflower. You will sleep without dreams tonight.” “Perhaps,” I said. “Do not make a habit of it,” he said. “We need your dreams. We need to know how the old stories look to someone who has not been painted with milk.” When I left his office the passage seemed longer, the little myths in their niches leaner. At the top of the stairs the Aide was waiting like the last step that has been worn away under your foot. “Well?” he said. “He will let me listen,” I said. “And test you,” the Aide said. “He is testing you already.” “So am I,” I said. I put my hand in my pocket and felt the dry seaflower, the hard smoothness of the nuts. In my mind the woman on the street lifted her bowl and poured milk over the stone, and the stone drank and knew us, not forever, but for today. I could not say if that was comfort, but it was a measure. I took it. I kept it, like a coin in an iron box.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This response demonstrates a remarkable grasp of Le Guin's style, particularly her ability to blend anthropological observation with philosophical depth. The prose is measured and thoughtful, with a distinctive voice that maintains consistency throughout. The author has created a rich, textured world where humanity has diverged into subspecies, using subtle details rather than exposition to illustrate these differences. The protagonist's unauthorized excursion into the local market serves as an effective vehicle for worldbuilding. The descriptions of the market, its vendors, and the physical characteristics of the different human subspecies are vivid without being overwrought. The protagonist's interactions with the market girl reveal cultural differences and tensions without resorting to info-dumping. The meeting with the Minister of Science (Malen) is particularly well-executed. The dialogue feels authentic, with each character maintaining a distinct voice. The power dynamics and subtle testing between them create tension and reveal character. Malen's explanation of the uplanders' fasting ritual demonstrates how the author has thought deeply about the cultural practices of this world. However, there are some minor issues. While the prose is generally elegant, there are occasional moments where the metaphors become slightly strained or unclear. The narrative sometimes lingers too long on descriptive elements at the expense of advancing the plot. The protagonist's character, while thoughtfully rendered, could be more distinctly drawn - we learn more about their observational skills than their personal motivations or background. The ending feels somewhat abrupt, though it does circle back to imagery established earlier. The seaflower motif provides a satisfying thematic closure, but the narrative arc itself feels incomplete - more like a chapter from a larger work (which was the prompt) than a self-contained story. The piece excels at creating a sense of cultural difference without othering or exoticizing. The various human subspecies are portrayed with nuance and dignity, and the political tensions feel organic rather than contrived. The writing demonstrates a sophisticated understanding of how to use physical details to suggest cultural and political realities. Overall, this is a highly accomplished piece that captures Le Guin's anthropological sensibility and philosophical depth. It creates a complex, believable world and populates it with characters whose interactions reveal the underlying tensions and connections between different human groups. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Biopunk: Polymerase Chain Reaction — Score: 88.7
Prompt:
Biopunk -- Polymerase Chain Reaction Write a chapter set in a near-future post-apocalyptic world where corporate genetic engineering was designed with built-in obsolescence—engineered DNA lasting only one generation to maximize profits before societal collapse. Follow a biohacker working with salvaged equipment to splice viable food crops for their settlement using rapidly degrading genetic material. As world building / window dressing, include details about jury-rigged lab equipment, and the physical toll (and unexpected upsides) of using untested genetic modifications as medicine. The plot of this chapter is centred around a black market contract. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The first time the solar rig coughed, the thermocycler hiccuped and threw the whole lattice of A, T, C, and G into disarray. The second time, the voltage dipped low enough to turn the lab lights brown. By the third flicker, I had the habit: tap the inverter housing twice, curse once, and lean into the exhalation until the LED steadied. In my lap the salvaged cycler—two aluminum plates sandwiching a hacked heating element, scavenged from a dead coffee maker—hummed again. The little wheel of oil I’d set atop it sloshed, cracked the surface with the scent of burnt rosemary, and I made a note: replace the heat sink. We were all making notes. It was how we made a future. Corporate genetic lines had been made to die. Built-in sunset clauses; DNA that frayed like cheap rope at the ends of a generation; telomerase inhibitors folded into the seed’s metabolic code like a countdown. Heat and dust and time did the rest. Before the collapse, they called it controlled lifecycling. In the settlement we called it paying for air you’d already breathed. “You sure it’s good?” Sael asked, voice half swallowed by the surgical mask. He perched on a crate of ceramic resistors, tapping his nails on their cardboard. The movements were always jittery with him these days, the way life got when you’d had your immune system rewritten by something you synthesized in a jam jar and dosed at midnight because the fever wouldn’t break. I twitched my wrist and the cycler’s display—salvaged Kindle screen—scrolled a step chart. Forty cycles, ninety-five, fifty-eight, ninety-five, sixty-three. “As long as the panel doesn’t stall again,” I said. “I’ve tweaked the annealing temp. The primers will stick.” He laughed behind the mask, hollow. “That panel,” he said, “is trying to kill you.” Maybe. The panel rig struck out of the scrap dunes like a spine of broken ribs, a dozen mismatched sheets wired in parallel with copper gleaned off dead streetlights. I’d bolted it to the roof with bicycle spokes and hope. At dawn today, it had produced eight hundred watts. By noon, with dust in the air and the clouds a dirty silver, it was faking it at best. It was enough to keep the thermocycler and the fridge running. It was not enough for much else. On the bench, the gel rig glowed anemic blue. I’d spared no electricity for a transilluminator—just a shallow Pyrex lasagna pan filled with a solution of ethidium’s safe cousin and a homemade LED strip taped beneath, tied to a 9V battery. The comb was carved out of a hair pick. The lanes were crooked as a child’s teeth. “What is it this time?” Sael gestured at the pipette in my hand. The tip quivered, the drop clinging to its plastic mouth. “Kale with less attitude?” “Chickpea.” The drop fell, sank into the loading dye, and bloomed. “Iron uptake metatransporter. The old lines told the roots to ignore it after two harvests. I found a fragment of the unsubstituted gene in some pre-crash literature, but it’s in pieces, and the last two kilobases refuse to hold. I’ve designed a chimeric bridge.” I flashed a smile I didn’t feel. “It will be beautiful. And ugly.” “Like everything else,” he said, and the mask couldn’t hide the way he was grinning now. “Our kids are going to hate chickpeas.” “If I get it to stick, they’re going to have chickpeas,” I said. “Hate is a luxury.” The settlement’s medical tent was patched from billboard vinyl. It said LIVE BETTER, repeated as a mantra down the aisle. The crops we’d found in the municipal seed vault had sprouted and then turned feral—scrawny, brittle, bearing blossoms that were sterile in ways that were patent-protected. We had three fields of brown-green ghosts and one of tubers only rodents could love. The black market was all that was left for things not made to die: contraband germplasms, ancestral lines concealed in old coffee tins by grandmothers with foresight, rogue constructs spliced by lab rats who’d seen the crash coming and wanted to see us survive it. Someone knocked at the heavy-lidded door. Three taps, pause, two taps. Sael turned his head as though the noise itself would tell him who it was. I set down the pipette, breathed until the thermocycler held steady, and called, “Come.” A woman slid in, so tall she seemed to fold herself into the room. She wore a raincoat bleached by sun until it was the pale of a shark’s belly. Her hair had the ringlets of someone who’d once had money, or showers. Her eyes did a quick check: solar rig, improvised fume hood (a duct fan married to a aspirator bottle), the bucket of copper sulfate petals I used as a makeshift electrophoresis buffer when the store powders ran out. The pistol at her hip stayed where it was. “You’re the splicer,” she said. Not a question. “I’m the one who pretends to be,” I said. “Names are currency.” “I left mine at the door,” she said, and then she was in front of me with a black mushroom of polymer in hand: a cryo-pod cannibalized from a biotech’s cold chain, the logo scraped off but not gone. “You were recommended, Ara.” The name made me want to look over my shoulder, make sure there wasn’t another Ara, the one before the collapse, before the storm, before telemarketer drones got repurposed as crop dusters and then found their way into swarms. But there was only me. I took the pod. The surface was smooth, oily with the residue of fingers. A tiny LCD flickered just enough for me to make out low battery in a pixelated font. “I’m not cheap,” I said. “I’m not poor,” she answered. That erased a few possibilities, none of them comforting. “Open it.” The latch was the kind no blade would pry without a scar. I leaned the pod against the bench, set the tip of a soldering iron into the seam, whispered hello to the power grid in prayer. The iron was a castoff, its cord wrapped in electrical tape, its tip filed down and then re-tinned. It stammered to heat with the panel’s mood, but in a moment it bit the polymer, and the pod sighed open on a breath of wet, cold air. Inside, nested in a decapitated eppendorf rack, were two cryo-vials. Each had a serial etched in the plastic: GRAIN/10086/S.CERE. That last I knew as a reflex, like my own pulse. A yeast. Not any yeast. A S. cerevisiae line marketed once on glossy screens as Guardian—engineered to outcompete wild strains in souring dough and beer, with a switch for hydrogenase pathways that dried out in eighteen months, leaving bakers with crumb that fell apart in the hand. There had been lawsuits. They had died with the courts. “It’s spoiled,” I said, and then checked myself. The pellet inside the tube was beige. A little slumped. The screw cap’s O-ring had cracked. It might have seen the inside of a freezer yesterday, or six months ago. “Maybe. Where did you—” “Black Yard,” she said. “Babbage’s lot.” I cursed, softly. The Yard would sell you copper sheeting with the oxide polished off only on the top. They’d paint bolts silver and swear they were argon. They’d steal the occlusive from your arm while shaking your hand. “Why are you in my lab with this?” She pointed with her eyes to Sael. “He’s the reason.” Sael stiffened. “I don’t know you.” She laughed, and there was not much humor in it. “You don’t have to. You took my boy last winter when his lungs choked on ash. You gave him a mist from a bottle with a label scraped off. You told me it was engineered for pigs, but lungs are lungs.” I remembered now: a boy with eyes like lakes after rain, breath wheezing through ducts so narrow I could put my finger on his chest and feel them vibrate. The pig lung growth factor had re-opened his alveoli like hands unfurling. He’d coughed pink foam and then he’d breathed. He might be growing bristles at fifteen. Even my black humor didn’t want to imagine it. “He lived?” I asked. “He plays in dust storms,” she said. “I wanted to pay you back. But then I wanted to eat.” She gestured to the pod. “This is meant to be a bread base that doesn’t die. They say it’s been reworked from old lines, no obsolescence. Clean. I need you to tell me if it’s a lie.” “Even if it is,” I said, and lifted the vial, “I might be able to make it tell the truth.” The voltage stuttered. The LED display on the cycler blinked into a set of hieroglyphs that meant nothing to anyone but me: the coil opened, the triac shut down, power conserved, DNA saved. The upside of building your own lab was that its failures were yours, but so were its habits. I tapped twice, cursed once, reached for the inverter case and felt the heat lick my palm. I pulled back with a hiss. “You okay?” Sael asked. “I have three layers of callus there for a reason.” I smiled without teeth. “Let me see your boy’s yeast.” I swabbed my finger in ethanol—we’d lifted a drum of the stuff off a drowned pharmacy, and winced every time we burned it for light—and cracked the cap. A smell like the bottom of an old beer bottle hit my nose, sour-sweet. I made a streak on a makeshift agar plate: gelatin stiffened with potato flake and sugar. I set it in the warm zone near the cycler, where the heat bled off into an ambient thirty-seven. I marked the plate with grease pencil: G-Guardian, date. The lid was a repurposed plastic clamshell from a time when people bought salad in boxes. “What do you want for the test?” the woman asked. She had her hand on the pistol now, not menacing, more like she wanted something to hold that had weight. “Not money,” I said. “Don’t take that the wrong way. Your money will be good at Black Yard. It’s goobers up here. I want options.” “Options?” “Your source. Your routes. If this yeast is truly clean, I don’t want to buy it once. I want to buy ten times until I can learn it. If it’s a lie, I want to know who told it.” Her mouth drew down. “I don’t sell names.” “I sell food,” I said, pointedly. “A contract, then. Black market or not." Sael got off the resistor crate. “You don’t have any choice,” he told her, voice soft. “We don’t have any choice. If it’s clean, the settlement will pay you in iron nails and salt and labor for a starter that doesn’t quit. If it’s not, she’ll fix it, and then you’ll own a liability with a lesson.” Her eyes hardened. Then she nodded. “Half now,” she said, and slid a wrapped packet onto the bench. In it were two syringes and a vial. The glass held a liquid the color of old pennies. “Metformin derivative. They stole it off a container. The real stuff. Your pancreas is going to give up before your generator does.” Ice crept up the spine of my back. “I didn’t tell you—” “You didn’t have to,” she said. “Your hands shake when the panel dips. The tremor is worse mid-day. Your neighbor said you eat sugar packets like communion.” This was the toll. We used untested constructs because we had to; sometimes they made us better at healing in strange ways. My influenza didn’t last two days anymore after the adenoviral thing I brewed in a jar under a desk lamp. My blood clotting worked like a charm after I knocked a femur on a swing hinge. My teeth regrew enamel where a dentist would have said they couldn’t. But the endocrine tweaks had come with a price. My pancreas had taken one look at the metabolic modulators I’d used to keep Sael alive, and decided it was tired. “Metformin makes me foggy,” I said. “This is cleaner,” she said. “Or it’s not. That’s the world we live in.” I laughed, and it broke out of me like a broken test tube. “Fine,” I said, and then it was a deal. We shook hands. I noticed her nails were very clean; she noticed mine were crescents stained with silver nitrate. The gel rig buzzed. The blue light in the pan pulsed. I slid the loaded gel in. The anode was a chunk of graphite shaved off an old motor; the cathode was a strip of stainless steel rescued from a dead dishwasher. I clipped the battery, watched the dye climb the thick of agar like ants climbing honey. The voltage held, by some miracle, and the bands began to resolve out of the smear. Soon I’d tell the woman whether her yeast carried the obsolescence bomb. If it did, the motifs would be there: repeats like a chant, designed to fold in on themselves and self-immolate generation by generation. If it didn’t, I’d still be inclined not to trust it; trust was another luxury, like hating chickpeas. The plate with the yeast sat and sweated and, under the warmth, lifted tiny pearls of gas. It would grow or it wouldn’t. The cycler ticked through its cycles as I patched together chickpea iron transporters and the pieces of our future. Sael stood at the door and watched the light beyond dim, and then flicker, and then dim again. The panel wobbled. The world held its breath. My heartbeat synced to the inverter’s hum. “Hey,” the woman said, softly now, the pistol an anchor and not a threat. “Thank you, for my boy.” I didn’t tell her about the boars’ gene that rode his cells now, tucked in like a gift and a trap, expressing when it shouldn’t, sleeping when it should. I didn’t tell her the erosion of names freaking me out less than the erosion of functions in everything we touched. I didn’t tell her that my own mouth tasted like copper pennies and that the drug she’d brought me would make it taste like nothing at all. Instead I said: “Bring me more. Anything that isn’t built to die. We’ll make it live.” The panel coughed and the thermocycler’s LED blinked, and this time I didn’t tap or curse. I put my fingers on the housing and felt the little tickle of low-voltage, the way you feel a cat walk across a bed in the dark. I heard the settlement outside, the clatter of pots, the laughter that was defiance, the cough you could hear through three tents. I thought about bread that wouldn’t cave. I thought about chickpeas as fat as fists. I thought about kids hating them, and therefore alive. Our contract sat between us like a third person. The gel bands sliced into clarity. They told me a story I didn’t yet know how to read. “Let’s see what kind of lie this is,” I said, and smiled with all my teeth.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This biopunk chapter successfully creates a vivid post-apocalyptic world where genetic engineering's built-in obsolescence has devastated society. The author excels at world-building through technical details about jury-rigged lab equipment, creating an authentic scientific atmosphere while maintaining accessibility. The protagonist Ara is well-developed as a resourceful biohacker working with salvaged equipment. Their interactions with Sael and the unnamed woman reveal a complex character who balances scientific pragmatism with genuine care for the settlement. The physical toll of genetic modifications is effectively shown through Ara's pancreatic issues and the references to Sael's immune system modifications and the woman's son who received pig lung growth factor. The prose is technically strong, with scientific terminology woven naturally into the narrative without overwhelming the reader. Descriptions like "the panel rig struck out of the scrap dunes like a spine of broken ribs" create powerful imagery that enhances the setting. The author effectively uses sensory details throughout, from the "burnt rosemary" scent to the "sour-sweet" smell of the yeast. The black market contract that drives the plot is well-integrated, creating tension and revealing character motivations. The woman's arrival with the potentially valuable yeast strain creates a meaningful conflict that ties directly to the settlement's survival needs. However, there are a few minor issues. Some of the scientific explanations, while generally accessible, occasionally become dense enough that they might momentarily disengage readers unfamiliar with genetics. The dialogue, while generally strong, occasionally becomes slightly expositional. The ending, while thematically appropriate, feels somewhat abrupt - we don't get resolution on whether the yeast is viable or not, though this may be intentional to create suspense for a subsequent chapter. The piece excels at creating a morally complex world where survival necessitates risk and compromise. The relationship between scientific advancement and human cost is thoughtfully explored, particularly through Ara's reflections on the modifications they've made to others and themselves. Overall, this is an impressive piece of biopunk fiction that successfully balances scientific detail with human drama, creating a compelling narrative about survival and adaptation in a genetically compromised world. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Iteration 3 — Avg Score: 89.8
+ Classic sci-fi: The Azra Gambit — Score: 90.0
Prompt:
Classic sci-fi (Author style: Asimov) The Azra Gambit Colonial mars is being mined by corporations who take leases on indentured labourers. The thing they are mining is Azra, a recently discovered exotic metal which accelerates radioactive decay to such a rate that it is greatly sought after for interstellar drives and weapons alike. This has created both a gold rush and an arms race as various interests vie for control and endeavour to unlock Azra's secrets. The story follows Arthur Neegan, a first generation settler and mining engineer. Upon discovering that his unassuming plot sits atop an immense Azra vein, he is subjected to a flurry of interest and scrutiny. Write the next chapter in this story, in which an armed retinue descends on Arthur's home and politely but forcefully invites him to a meeting with some unknown party off-world. The insignia look like that of the Antares diplomatic corp -- diplomatic in name only. Arthur finds himself in the centre of a political tug of war. The chapter involves a meeting with this unknown party, who makes Arthur an offer. The scene should be primarily dialogue, interspersed with vivid description & scene setting. It should sow hints of the larger intrigue, stakes & dangers. Include Asimov's trademark big-and-small-picture world building and retrofuturistic classic scifi vibe. The chapter begins with Arthur aboard the transfer vessel, wondering just what he's gotten involved in. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
Arthur kept adjusting his collar, unused to the formal attire he had been instructed to wear. The fabric had a synthetic sheen that tugged uncomfortably at his neck as the transfer vessel purred around him with the precise, anesthetic thrum of military-grade reactionless drives. The Antares insignia—three concentric stars embracing an arrow—glinted on every bulkhead fixture and shoulder patch. Diplomatic Corps, he had been told, in the way one is told that a scalpel is a spoon. He ran a thumb along the edge of his cuff and studied the viewport. Mars fell away like a rusting coin, its wafer-thin atmosphere a smear at the rim. Beyond it, the tether-spined ring of the orbital network stitched light into emptiness. The cabin door whispered, and two attendants in grey-black with clipped hair and the dispassionate posture of good furniture stepped in. Their holstered pistols curved like accents. One of them inclined his head enough to qualify as polite. “Mr. Neegan,” he said. “We’ll be docking in five. If you’ll come with us.” Arthur stood, the collar resisting him like a moral principle. “You could just tell me where I’m going.” “You are going to a meeting,” said the other. “As requested.” “As compelled,” Arthur said. “Words,” the first replied, with such blandness that Arthur had to admire it. They guided him down a corridor that smelled faintly of ozone and old plastic. The vessel had the deliberate cleanliness of something that contained secrets whose protection budget outran anyone’s imagination. They reached a hatch that recognized a palm and slid apart: a lounge with a view like a cut jewel. In the center stood a table that was trying very hard to be humble. Facing the planet, in a chair that placed her in silhouette, sat a woman whose posture was supremely relaxed without being careless. She wore a suit the colour of wet slate, no insignia. A small pin, however—an abstract spiral—sat at her lapel. “Mr. Neegan,” she said, without turning. “Please sit.” Arthur took the seat opposite. He found that the chair had anticipated his height. The two attendants became part of the walls, as if they earlier had simply been temporarily separated from them. The woman glanced at him then, and her face resolved into planes of middle-aged poise. Her hair was cut short in a way that suggested both discipline and emergency practicality. Her eyes were unremarkable, which is a remark in itself. “You’ve had a week,” she said. “I apologize. Sudden ascents are rarely dignified.” “I’ve had less than a week,” Arthur said. “Three days ago I lived in a prefab with a faulty heater coil and a kitchen that sang when the wind hit the door. Now I’m on a vessel with no corners.” He adjusted his collar again. “Who are you?” She smiled, not with surprise. “My name is Cestine Varro. I represent an interested party not formally affiliated with any of the corporations currently leasing Martian extraction rights. Nor with the Antares Diplomatic Corps, though their insignia has its uses.” Arthur let his gaze flick to the attendants’ shoulders. “Borrowed livery,” Cestine said. “Antares likes to believe they control impressions. We purchased this one for the hour. Will you drink?” The table noticed the question and extruded two glasses with a sound like small rain. The liquid was colourless and claimed to be water. Arthur ignored it. “You found an Azra vein,” Cestine said. She looked back out at Mars, which had settled into a dignified distance, touched by sunlight that did not expect thanks. “And not merely a vein. A body. It sits under old lava, like a hesitating heart.” “You know a great deal about my property,” Arthur said carefully. “Property,” she said, tasting the word. “Yes. The land grant was issued to you as a first-generation settler. After two harvest cycles, the land and subsoil rights revert to the colony administration unless a productive economic use is declared. You declared. That declaration was, shall we say, amplified. The administrative network is a sieve. We selected which holes to widen.” “Selected?” “To attract attention. The right kind, and not too much of the wrong. You were going to be noticed anyway. We arranged a map of attention that would favor this conversation.” “What kind of party are you?” Arthur asked. “Unknown.” “A coalition of conservationists and strategists,” Cestine said. “Which, I admit, sounds like a paradox. It is not. Azra speeds decay, Mr. Neegan. The universe has a timetable. We are in the business of ensuring that no one moves the clocks too far forward.” Arthur folded his hands on the table. They were too clean. The last four years he’d measured worth in how dust settled into the knuckles. “You want to stop the mining.” “We want to control it,” Cestine said. “Stop is a fantasy. Azra is a lever on entropy. Once the picture of the lever exists, someone will pull it.” She tapped the pin at her lapel. The spiral wasn’t a spiral; it was a stylized decay chain, the child and grandchild nuclides simplified to art. He felt a small chill—the kind you feel in the spinal metaphor of your backbone, when a story becomes more precise than comfort recommends. “You know what it does,” he said. “I have devoted twelve years to knowing enough to fear it,” she said. “There have already been tests. Spurts of funding in obscure journals. Anomalies scrubbed from reactor logs. Antares ships docked near prospector stations where the radiation counters like to sing lullabies.” “And the corporations?” “They are enthusiastic,” she said. “Enthusiasm is the polite cousin of hunger.” Arthur watched her watching Mars. “You didn’t bring me here to philosophize about clocks.” “No,” she agreed. “I brought you here to offer you a contract.” She slid a wafer across the table. He did not touch it. The wafer shimmered with microscopic script, layered like a palimpsest of legality. He had seen such things in the colony offices when the lease agents smiled with their entire dental history. “You retain title to your land and subsurface rights,” Cestine said. “You declare exclusive development under a new classification: controlled catalytic resource. You will then lease extraction rights to a consortium we have organized. The terms: a guaranteed dividend, equipment sufficient to remove the overburden to a safe standby level, scientific oversight we provide, and a cap—a hard cap—on extracted Azra per quarter. An off-world escrow holds the title in trust. No one moves equipment without three keys, one of them yours.” “And in return?” Arthur said. “In return you swear to a patience most men cannot afford. You will become unpopular. You will be accused of sabotage, greed, treason to your species’ manifest destiny. You will be offered money at numbers you did not know had names. You will refuse. And you will call us before you call anyone else when the ground quivers in a new voice.” He picked up the wafer and held it to the light. Sections of the text infiltrated his vision: terms of art, vacuum-hard clauses, contingency strategies for sabotage, clauses that contemplated planetary injunctions. “And if I say no?” “The Antares Corps,” Cestine said, with no malice, “will arrest you on suspicion of illicit materials trafficking. They will find Azra cores in your freight. They will have planted them with care. You will be held, then released, then held again. In the meantime, interim receivers will declare your claim common. The corporations will begin their work with a legal smile.” Arthur let the wafer sit. He thought of the fault map that he had made in pencil, because pencil was proof against power failures. He thought of the vein that gave his instruments a headache, a lump of reluctant miracle. “You said you arranged attention,” he said. “Why me? There are other veins. Other miners.” “Because you are dull,” Cestine said. She held his gaze as his expression hardened. “Do not take offense. Dullness is virtue. You have no debt beyond the mainline loan. You have no family obligations beyond a sister who has not spoken to you since the civil registry argued about her surname. You did not enlist in the Belt wars. You did not play cards you could not count. You are a man whose calendar has blank squares. That makes you rare and useful.” “And if I were more interesting?” Arthur asked dryly. “We would not be here. Interesting men are full of levers too easily acquired by other hands.” He considered the window. Earth was a pale thought somewhere in the dark. Mars turned with the implacability of old machines. He remembered his cabin’s heater coil, which he had coaxed with a screwdriver and a curse. He remembered the smell of his own sweat under the dust when the wind laid down and sound carried. A man with blank squares. It was not flattering, but it had been true. “You said you’re not Antares,” he said. “And yet they escorted me.” “Antares is not a person,” Cestine said. “It is a set of overlapping ambitions held together by semaphore and habit. Parts of it dislike parts of it intensely. The part that brought you here owes us a favor and hopes to embarrass another part later. This is how things are done when no one wants to say so out loud.” “And the consortium?” Arthur asked. “Who’s in it?” “Universities that still believe in peer review,” Cestine said. “Insurance underwriters who truly understand catastrophic risk curves. A small nation-state without space capacity but with excellent mathematicians. An offshoot of a faith that thinks the universe should be allowed to age as intended. A few miners who know that fast money can be a solvent.” “You romanticize,” Arthur said. “I inventory,” Cestine said. “The romance belongs to those who want to fly sabers into stars.” He found that he was breathing more slowly. The chair had adjusted his posture; the ship had dialed down its hum. He wondered what else they had dialed. “You didn’t mention weapons,” he said. “I did not need to,” Cestine said. “Azra will turn weapons into policy the way a fire turns a map into air. It will make blockades obsolete and fortresses into suggestions. It will let an angry provincial administer vengeance to a planet. The arms manufacturers need no salesmen when an element does their job for them.” “I’m an engineer,” Arthur said. “I know what you’re saying. I also know that every cap invites a pry bar. How do you expect to hold the cap?” “By making the pry bar costly to wield,” Cestine said. “By making the story of restraint more compelling than the story of conquest. By embedding reactors with failsafes that turn Azra on Azra if tampered with.” She smiled faintly. “And if those fail, by applying the kind of pressure polite people call diplomacy.” He thought about the attendants’ pistols, the curve of their holsters like commas. There was grammar to this. “You will not be alone,” Cestine said. “I do not mean that in the comfortable sense. I mean it as a logistical statement. We intend to place observers in your operation. Two, perhaps three. They will be polite. They will be unwelcome. They will be very difficult to remove.” “So, a leash.” “A harness,” Cestine said. “You can pull against it, and we can pull with you, and the horse has some say about where the cart goes.” He surprised himself by laughing. It came out like a cough. “Do you ride?” “I count,” she said. “Numbers behave like horses when you have their trust.” Arthur let the wafer rest against his palm again. He had once thought of wealth as something that came in shipments, in the respectable clink of credit. It was now a weightless thing that occupied the air around the table, making conversation cautious. He could not pretend he would not like to be wealthy. He could not pretend that wealth arrived without neighbors. “What happens to me if I sign?” he asked. “Beyond the unpopularity.” “You will have to hire,” Cestine said. “Not the indenture contracts the corporations like. Real contracts. You will become an employer of free men and women and at least one person who declines a binary. You will live under a dome we will upgrade to withstand explosive decompression. You will have a legal team you will never meet. You will learn words you hoped to avoid. You will go to bed often with the feeling that you have forgotten to lock something essential.” “And if I do not sign,” Arthur said, “you already told me what happens.” She inclined her head. “It is clumsy to threaten a man and then ask him to trust you. Yet here we are.” The ship shifted; somewhere, docking clamps performed their small ballet. Mars slid a fraction. Arthur studied Cestine. The absence of insignia, the quiet spiral. He thought of the first day he had set foot on his land, when the wind attempted to remove his nose and the sky had the colour of careful blood. He had not come to Mars for romance. He had come because the Earth had too many people who wanted to tell him how to be interesting. “Why is it called Azra?” he asked suddenly. She blinked. “Naming rights fell to an astronomer whose daughter had that name,” she said. “The daughter drowned on a world with more water than wisdom. He chose to put her name on something that would not dissolve.” “That’s a myth,” Arthur said. “All names are,” Cestine said. “Will you sign?” He put the wafer down. He did not touch the stylus. “I will agree to a preliminary,” he said slowly. “You will send me your scientists. I will send you my maps. We will set a cap. We will test each other’s patience before we promise forever.” Her shoulders relaxed by a millimeter. It was the most honest gesture she had made. “A preliminary,” she said. “Very well. That is already more than most men would offer in a room with this view.” She rose. He stood. The attendants detached from the walls and became men again. “One more thing,” Cestine said, and now her voice held something that could nearly be warmth. “Hide the heater coil from the inspectors. It is against regulation.” He stared. “You’ve been in my home?” “We have been within it,” she said. “Glass walls are fashionable in this century. We prefer to look through them only when necessary.” He did not ask what necessary meant. They walked him to the hatch. The door opened onto a short corridor and the mouth of a docking tunnel. Through its oval he saw a station module with an Antares crest and the polite bustle of people paid to look like background. “Mr. Neegan,” Cestine said. “In the next days, you will be approached by an Antares official named Pelk and by a representative of the Rittmann Consortium who will offer to buy your soul and lease your shadow. You will find their arguments sensible. You will find ours exhausting. Remember that exhaustion does not make sense wrong.” “And if I get tired enough to forget?” Arthur asked. “You will call me,” she said. “The number is in the wafer, under the clause about dispute resolution. It will look like a footnote. It is not.” He stepped into the tunnel. The pressure differential sighed. He adjusted his collar again, and it yielded this time, just enough. He did not look back until he was halfway across, and then only because a man counts his steps when he knows that the ground ahead has learned his name. Cestine was watching him. She lifted a hand, a wave or a signal; he could not tell. Behind her, Mars turned, and beyond that, the patient dark did not care who set the clocks. But men did, and their care could burn a world or save it a little time. Arthur walked on. The pistols, the spiral pin, the wafer that weighed nothing—these lodged in his thoughts like pebbles in a boot. He did not yet know if he would limber or limp. He did know that when he got home, he would check the coil, and then he would bury, with care and in a place only the wind knew, a small sample in an unremarkable box, because dull men take precautions even against their allies. At the end of the tunnel, a man in an Antares sash smiled with all his teeth and extended a hand. “Mr. Neegan,” he said. “Pelk. So glad you could make time. I believe we can help each other avoid unnecessary delays.” Arthur took the hand and felt the tug of war tighten, invisible and absolute. He smiled back, because the universe did not move its own clocks, and someone had to watch them.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This response is a remarkably accomplished piece of science fiction that captures Asimov's style while maintaining its own distinct voice. The author has created a tense, dialogue-driven chapter that effectively builds the world of colonial Mars and the political intrigue surrounding Azra. The prose demonstrates exceptional control, with vivid descriptions that establish setting without overwhelming the narrative. The description of Mars as "a rusting coin, its wafer-thin atmosphere a smear at the rim" efficiently conveys both the physical reality and emotional distance. The writing maintains a retrofuturistic feel appropriate to classic sci-fi, with technology that feels both advanced and slightly analog. The dialogue between Arthur and Cestine forms the backbone of the chapter, revealing character, plot, and worldbuilding simultaneously. Their conversation has the measured, slightly formal quality characteristic of Asimov, while maintaining natural rhythm. The power dynamic is clearly established through subtle cues in their interaction. Character development is handled with restraint. Arthur is portrayed as practical, cautious, and principled—a believable protagonist for this scenario. Cestine is enigmatic but three-dimensional, with motivations that extend beyond simple villainy or heroism. The description of Arthur as "dull" is particularly effective, reframing an apparent insult as a valuable trait in a world of competing interests. The worldbuilding excels at Asimov's trademark balance between immediate concerns and larger implications. The political landscape is sketched efficiently through references to corporations, the Antares Diplomatic Corps, and various factions within the consortium. The nature of Azra and its potential consequences are explained without excessive exposition. The chapter successfully plants seeds of the larger intrigue. The competing interests in Azra, the potential for weapons development, and the surveillance of Arthur's home all create tension and raise the stakes. The ending with Pelk's appearance perfectly sets up the next phase of conflict. There are a few moments where the prose becomes slightly overwrought ("the universe has a timetable"), but these are rare and generally fit the philosophical tone of classic sci-fi. The pacing is excellent, with the conversation building naturally to Arthur's decision. Overall, this is an exceptional response that fulfills all requirements of the prompt while creating a compelling narrative with depth and nuance. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19

+ Contemporary romance: Darkroom Revelations — Score: 90.7
Prompt:
Darkroom Revelations Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of Dani, a 25-year-old assertive art student known for her bold style and take-charge attitude in relationships. For the past semester, she's been quietly fascinated by Elliot (he/him), a 19-year-old boy in her experimental photography class. Dani has been intrigued by his unconventional masculinity: killer thrift-shop-nu-goth style, soft demeanour and quiet intellect. When they're paired for a final project requiring late nights in the darkroom, Elliot tentatively shares that he's been questioning his gender identity and expression. Set during one of these intimate darkroom sessions where the red light creates a confessional atmosphere. Explore Dani's complex attraction—her usual assertiveness complicated by her desire to protect Elliot's vulnerability, her excitement at witnessing his self-discovery, and her confusion about what this means for her own identity as someone typically attracted to more defined gender presentations. The narrative should capture the tender awkwardness of their conversations, Dani's internal struggle between taking charge and wanting to give Elliot agency, and the unexpected chemistry that develops as both find themselves in uncharted territory. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The red light traps time the way a snow globe traps a winter. Every dust mote is a planet; each drip from the faucet marks a century. The trays are shallow constellations, moons of developer and fixer, our prints floating like secrets just revealing themselves. Elliot’s breath fogs in the cold of the room and makes me wonder if the images can sense us, if the silver halides know we’re both different people in here. His hands are steady in a way mine aren’t. I love that he’s precise, the way his fingers move through the tongs like he’s playing an instrument he grew up with. He’s careful. I am not. I am a fireworks display by comparison: abrupt and bright, all teeth and certainty and the clatter of brass bangles. Even in the thin red light, my rings flare when I gesture. He watches them for a beat, like he’s memorizing a language he doesn’t fully speak. “It’s like they’re underwater until they decide to breathe,” he says, leaning over the tray. The print is just starting to appear—our shot of the back staircase, the way the rails cut the light into squares that look like a fallen chessboard. “More like they’re mid-transformation,” I say, because I can’t resist an argument, a reframe. “We’re coaxing them. Making choices for them.” He smiles and I feel something in me list toward him like a ship caught by a minor current. He’s wearing a thrifted shirt, pearl snaps dulled with age, the kind of thing that shouldn’t look goth at all but somehow does on him, paired with a belt that has a silver buckle shaped like a bat. His eyes catch the red and go mulberry-dark. He smells like old books, developer, and winter air. “You always want to call it a choice,” he says. “I’m not sure it is.” “Everything is a choice,” I say, reflexively militant, and want to roll my eyes at myself. I’ve made a persona out of choosing; out of being the one who goes first. Girls in my cohort admire and fear the same quality in me. Professors too. Dated people who thanked me for taking the lead like I was granting them a favor. It’s a good costume most days: leather jacket, clipped hair, the right eyeliner, the loudest laugh. Me, as a decision. Elliot’s not a costume. He’s a pair of boots worn in weird places, a book with marginalia in someone else’s handwriting. I’ve been watching him all semester without letting my gaze be obvious about it. He’s the kid who brought in xeroxed zines of Foucault and zipties for our sculpture project. He never volunteers unless called on, but when he talks, it’s like he’s picking a lock in front of the class. The print deepens. I use the tongs to flip it and he flinches like I almost touched him. The room hums with the fan above us, the slow pulse of the timer beeping in intervals. My phone vibrates, a small mosquito buzz deep in my back pocket, then again, insistent. People want things from me. They always do. I ignore it, almost ceremonially. If I take it out, I’ll split myself into Dani-who-answers and Dani-who-watches, and right now I want to be the latter. “I’ve been thinking about our concept statement,” he says, gaze fixed on the paper’s milky surface. “Like, about liminal spaces.” I hum. We picked the concept because it sounded academic without being dead. Doors ajar, mirrors half covered, stairwells between floors, hallways to nowhere. In my head it was also about us, and how we are both a little bit thresholds, though I’d never say that and ruin it. “I’ve been thinking…” He stops. I watch his throat shift when he swallows. I want to reach for it without touching, to say go on, to place my palm near his sternum and promise I won’t push. He sets the tongs down with a click that sounds louder than it should. “God, this is going to sound like I’m making it about me. I know the deadline. I know we have to print and mat and whatever. But the thing I’ve been thinking about…” He breathes like he’s bracing for a wave that might not stop. “I’ve been thinking that I might not be a ‘he,’ or I might be a ‘he’ differently. Some days I look in the mirror and the pronouns slide around like oil on water, and other days I feel like my reflection is a lie I agreed to tell.” I keep very still. The developer smells like pennies and the past. He doesn’t look at me. The print in the tray darkens into itself, a staircase that knows it leads somewhere. “I don’t know if I’m allowed to say that,” he says quickly. “Or if that makes sense. I’m not trying to be special. It’s just… it’s been getting louder. And I put on the clothes and I feel half right. I paint my nails and I feel more right. I bind sometimes. Or I want to. And then I think I’m performing. Like I’m making a collage out of somebody else’s images instead of taking the picture myself.” He laughs a small, brittle laugh. His hands are on the edge of the sink, knuckles pale. “Sorry.” There’s a version of me that would fill the room with advice and action. There’s an impulse to produce a to-do list: names of clinics, pronoun pins, Instagram accounts, a list of books and binders and how to tape safely. I have those things. My friends are a compendium of experiments. My body leans forward, wanting to fix, to lead, to wrap my certainty around him like a coat. But the red light makes a church out of this place and me a parishioner instead of a preacher. The fan hum becomes a choir, the water a liturgy. I make myself count to five before I say anything. It hurts, the restraint. It stings like a chemical splash that hasn’t yet been washed off. “What would feel good to hear right now?” I ask, and it’s so unlike my default that I have to chew on the words before they go out. He looks up, startled, then relieved. “I don’t know. Maybe just… that it’s not nothing? That I’m not being dramatic?” “It’s not nothing,” I say. “You’re not being dramatic.” I let my voice go low, the persuasive register I use when convincing donors to fund student shows. “You’re allowed to be figuring it out. You don’t have to land.” He nods, once, and his shoulders drop like they’ve been carrying a rolled-up map that’s finally set on the table. In the tray, the staircase is fully formed now. It’s more interesting than I thought it would be—there’s a blur of movement at the edge where my sleeve accidentally got into frame, a smear that looks almost like a person slipping between frames. Elliot lifts the print with the tongs and moves it to the stop bath. The little hiss when it meets the chemicals is unbearably intimate. “I worry that I’m… fake,” he says. “That wanting to be softer, or different, or to try a dress sometimes—like, what if that’s just an aesthetic and not a self? You know? I don’t want to be a tourist.” I can’t help it. I reach out and put my hand over his on the edge of the sink. Not guiding. Just neighboring. His skin is colder than mine; he flinches, then doesn’t pull away. “You’re the only person who can call you real,” I say. “But from where I’m standing, nothing about you feels tourist.” He looks at our hands. The red light makes us look like we’re both made of pomegranate. I swallow. Here’s the confession I didn’t know I’d be making in this room: “I like—the way you are. I mean, I’ve been trying to categorize you so I could know what to do with my crush, and I can’t. And it’s made me—uncomfortable.” The word tastes like daring. “I’m used to women with knives in their smiles or boys who come wrapped in their own definitions. You’re… a door that keeps opening.” He blinks, then laughs, a real one this time, soft and stunned. “A door that keeps opening?” “Don’t let me workshop metaphors out loud,” I say, embarrassed and amused at once. “Point is, I’m attracted to you. And I don’t know what that means for me either, exactly. Which is both annoying and—it’s also kind of exciting.” “Yeah,” he says. He doesn’t pull his hand away, and the relief that rushes through me is embarrassing in its size. “It’s… I’m glad you said that. I’ve been—trying not to be weird. You scare me a little.” “Good,” I say, too fast, reflex bristling, and then catch myself. “I mean, okay. Also not good. I don’t want to scare you. I just—” I grope for a softer word and find one I don’t usually admit I own. “I want to take care of this. Of you.” He looks at me then, straight, and for a second the world shifts its weight. “What does taking care mean, for you?” “Usually? Making decisions. Setting the pace. Carrying the bag. Color-coding the calendar.” I hear the list’s edge and wince. “But also listening. And not deciding for you.” His mouth curves. It does something to my ribs. “I could be into parts of that.” “I thought you might,” I say, and then my phone buzzes again: a little tap-tap against bone. I ignore it, feeling the ghost of the screen the way you feel a missing tooth with your tongue. There will be messages, little landmines of expectation. I’m not picking them up right now. We move through the prints. He manages the times like a monastic liturgy; I handle the exposure test strips with my habitual impatience, wanting to skip steps and leap to the conclusion. The safe light paints us as if we’re already in a photograph, and I catch myself wondering how we look like this to someone else—to an instructor walking by, to the ghosts of former students, to the future versions of us who might or might not remember. “Do you want me to try different pronouns for you?” I ask later, while we’re hanging the prints on the line with wooden clothespins that make little dull clicks. “Here? Or with just us? Or not at all?” He inhales. “Maybe… you could try they, sometimes? See how it feels? Or… if you want, you could pick one and surprise me.” “That is a lot of power to hand me,” I say, teasing, and not. “I know.” He meets my eyes. “I trust you.” There it is—the place where I’m tempted to surge forward and plant a flag. Instead I slow down. I consider the little word he offered me and how it could tuck into my mouth. “Okay,” I say. “They.” I test it lightly, set it in the air between us like a piece of folded paper boat on black water. “Do you want to pass me that clothespin? They’re right behind you.” They nod. The relief in their face is not subtle, and it makes my throat tight. I want to kiss it. Not them. It. The relief, the softness. The plant that’s finally turning toward the window. “I didn’t think it would feel that different,” they say, voice dazed. “It feels… like warm.” “Good,” I say. I sound hoarse. We stand there, students of our own language, letting it rearrange our bones. It occurs to me that I don’t have to classify my desire before I act on it; that I don’t have to know what it makes me to know what I want. But I also don’t want to be the storm that knocks over their sapling. My urgency meets an equal, gentler force, and they lean into each other until it’s a balance. “Can I—” I begin, and stop. I aim for honesty, not performance. “Can I hold your hand?” They look at my hand like it’s a print developing in front of them. “Yeah,” they say. “Please.” I take their hand with the same care they took the tongs, the way you lift something you plan not to own but to admire. Their fingers are slender, ringless. My thumb finds the soft web between thumb and forefinger, an anchor. The heat exchanges. It’s electric and quiet at once. We stand like that in the red, as the prints drip and set and the room does its chemical magic. The fan thrums. The faucet whispers. My phone buzzes a third time, small and far away now, like a world I may go back to later. I can be decisive about that, at least. I can decide to stay here where the silver salts decide to become image, where a person can pick a pronoun like a lens and try it on and the perspective shifts. “Dani?” they say, soft. “Yeah?” “Thank you,” they say. “For not—taking it out of my hands.” I squeeze their fingers. “You’re welcome,” I say. “You can ask me to take more, if you want. Later. When you want.” “Okay,” they say. The word settles into our intertwined palms. We clip the last print and make a note of our times and exposures and paper grades with a pencil that leaves gray snow behind it. When we turn off the safelight, the room goes absolute for a second, a heavy velvet. Then the fluorescent flickers on outside, harsh and throat-clearing. We blink, separate our hands, and I feel the absence like a picture taken from a wall. “We’ll come back tomorrow,” I say, as if tomorrow is neutral. It suddenly isn’t. It’s a place with a door that keeps opening. They smile, half shy, half certain. “Yeah,” they say. “Tomorrow.” We push through the heavy darkroom door and into the hallway, a liminal space if there ever was one, and for once I don’t rush to fill it with my stride. I match theirs. The prints are behind us, hanging like a series of possible futures, quietly becoming themselves.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative successfully captures Dani's perspective as she navigates her attraction to Elliot during their darkroom session. The piece excels in creating a distinctive voice for Dani—assertive yet vulnerable as she confronts her own preconceptions about attraction and identity. The darkroom setting functions brilliantly as both physical space and metaphor, with the developing photographs paralleling the characters' evolving understanding of themselves. The prose demonstrates considerable craft, particularly in its sensory details and metaphors. The opening paragraph's comparison of the darkroom to a snow globe immediately establishes the intimate, suspended-in-time quality of the setting. The writer skillfully employs imagery related to photography and development throughout, maintaining thematic coherence. Character development is nuanced and believable. Dani's internal struggle between her usual take-charge attitude and her desire to give Elliot space feels authentic. Her self-awareness about her tendency to "fill the room with advice and action" and her conscious effort to restrain this impulse shows meaningful character growth. Elliot's vulnerability in sharing their gender questioning is portrayed with sensitivity and complexity. The dialogue serves the narrative effectively, revealing character and advancing the relationship. Exchanges like "What would feel good to hear right now?" demonstrate Dani's growth, while Elliot's confession about feeling "fake" reveals their insecurities. The conversation flows naturally and avoids exposition dumps. The piece handles the theme of gender identity exploration with subtlety. Rather than presenting simplistic answers, it portrays the questioning process as ongoing and personal. The metaphor of Elliot as "a door that keeps opening" is particularly effective, if slightly overwrought. There are moments where the prose becomes slightly purple, with metaphors occasionally stacked too densely. Lines like "The red light makes a church out of this place and me a parishioner instead of a preacher" work beautifully in isolation but can feel excessive when combined with similar figurative language throughout. The narrative maintains excellent pacing, with the physical task of developing photographs providing structure while the emotional revelations unfold. The ending strikes an appropriate balance—hopeful without being unrealistically resolved, acknowledging that both characters are at the beginning of something rather than its conclusion. Overall, this is a sophisticated piece that successfully fulfills the prompt's requirements while creating a distinctive atmosphere and complex characters. The writing demonstrates considerable skill in balancing internal reflection with external action, and in using setting as an extension of the characters' emotional states. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 19 Emotionally Complex: 19 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 19.0, Emotionally Complex: 19.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Contemporary romance / drama: Stolen Moments in Roma — Score: 92.8
Prompt:
Contemporary Romance / Drama: Stolen Moments in Roma. Write a series of interconnected short scenes and dialogues that span a single day in modern-day Rome, in narrative form. This will form the beginning of a larger story. Alessandra, a fiery, independent Roman woman who works as a motorcycle courier, nearly collides with Ben, a somewhat clumsy, overly polite British academic on sabbatical, who is engrossed in a guidebook near the Trevi Fountain. The initial encounter is a clash of cultures and personalities – Alessandra is all sharp wit and rapid-fire Italian, while Ben is flustered apologies and awkward attempts at speaking the language. However, as they sort out the near-miss, a spark of unexpected humor and connection emerges. Alessandra, it quickly becomes clear, is a whirlwind of energy and mischief. She's a self-admitted troublemaker with a secret penchant for kleptomania, a detail she doesn't explicitly reveal, but which manifests in subtle, daring acts throughout the day. She impulsively decides to take Ben on a wild, unsanctioned tour of Rome, dragging him in some specific instances far outside his comfort zone. Ben, despite his initial apprehension and inherent politeness, finds himself utterly captivated by Alessandra's unapologetic spirit and zest for life. He is drawn into her orbit, a willing participant in increasingly outlandish situations, a quiet rebellion brewing beneath his scholarly exterior. The narrative should primarily consist of short, vivid scenes and dialogue exchanges, revealing their contrasting personalities and backgrounds, and the growing, ambiguous tension between them. Ben is captivated by Alessandra's energy and the thrill of breaking free from his routine. There's a clear sense that Alessandra is toying with Ben, pushing his boundaries and enjoying his reactions, but her own feelings remain somewhat enigmatic. The day should be a rollercoaster of exhilarating, slightly dangerous, and humorous moments, leaving Ben completely disoriented but utterly smitten. Explore the underlying tension & chemistry between them, culminating in some payoff as they part ways (or not -- your choice). Include this detail: Write in narrative prose, using immersive storytelling. 1000 words.
Model Output:
He doesn’t notice the scooter until the wind of it licks his calves and the horn rips across the piazza like a curse. The guidebook leaps from Ben’s hands, pages yawning like startled gulls. The Vespa skids, a sharp S on ancient cobblestone, halts with its nose inches from a municipal trash bin. Time resumes. Shouts rise around the Trevi Fountain—tourists with their phones, vendors hawking bottled water, a couple arguing in rapid Portuguese. “Guardi!” she barks, snapping off the helmet. Her hair pours out, black and impatient. “Che fai, professorino? Leggi mentre cammini? Vuoi morire sotto le ruote?” “I—sorry—mi dispiace,” Ben stammers. He bends to grab the guidebook, knocks it with his elbow, watches it skate under a German family’s stroller. “I wasn’t—looking.” “No kidding, Sherlock,” she says in English, rolling her eyes. Then she laughs, a precise, ringing sound that says she’d rather have the story than the peace. “You’re fine. I didn’t kill you. Yet.” He straightens. She’s shorter than he expected but seems taller, all kinetic lines and impatient eyebrows. He registers a leather jacket scuffed pale at the elbows, a messenger bag strapped crosswise like a sash. There’s a sticker on the Vespa that reads: CHE PAURA? “I’m terribly sorry,” Ben says, British apology falling from him on instinct. He tries Italian again. “Io... sono... un idiota.” Her mouth curves. “Finalmente, verità.” She claps him on the shoulder. “I’m Alessandra. Courier. Occasional life-saver. And you?” “Ben,” he says, clearing his throat. He’s felt ridiculous since arriving in Rome, and now feels newly minted in it. He reaches for the guidebook again. She gets it first, with a fast, easy bend, and hands it back without a flourish. Her fingers brush his. She has ink stains on her thumb, a crescent of midnight. “Ben,” she repeats, tasting it, making it sound less tinny. “Ben. Okay.” She tilts her head. “You owe me a coffee for almost becoming a hood ornament.” “That seems... fair.” “Good. Get on.” He blinks. “On... your scooter?” She’s already pulling her helmet back on, handing him another from the hook. It’s a gaudy thing, pink with glitter, probably a joke at someone’s expense. “Unless you prefer to stay here, marry your book, and get pickpocketed.” “I—no, I—” He looks at the fountain, luminous even at midday, at the crowd, at the thought of getting on a stranger’s scooter in a foreign city. At the line of her grin. “Right. Okay. Why not.” “Ecco,” she says, pleased. “You say ‘why not’ like a man who has said ‘why yes’ only to footnotes.” He flushes, tries to adjust the helmet, which squeaks and sits a little crooked. She reaches up without asking and straightens it, a swift tug that brings her face too close to his. He can smell pepper and petrol, and something sweet that might be soap. Her eyes flick over his and away, assessing. “Hold on,” she says, and when he hesitates—where?—she grabs his hands and plants them at her waist. “Not too much. I’m not your mother. Or maybe I am. We’ll see.” He laughs, scandalized, and they take off. Rome peels open like an orange under her driving. She weaves through taxis that honk as if it’s a national anthem, past a tour bus with a cartoon Caesar on its side. Ben tries to keep his knees from knocking into cars, tries not to shout apologies at people they almost clip. Alessandra is humming cavalierly, cutting left, cutting right, laughing once when a policeman eyes them and then looks away. “What were you reading?” she calls back over her shoulder. “Um. About Bernini.” “Ah. The curly one.” She makes a loose, twirling motion with one hand. “Saints in ecstasy. People lose their minds.” He swallows. “You know art?” “I know tourists,” she says. “Also the city pays me to carry things through traffic without dying, so we are all specialists here.” They pull up outside a bar with a narrow countertop crowded with elbows. She orders them caffè with a charm that plucks smiles from men and women alike, and Ben fumbles with coins that seem to multiply in his palms. “Here,” Alessandra says softly, and plucks a coin from behind his ear. He startles; she grins. “Your lucky euro.” He blinks. There is no coin behind his ear. And there is one in her palm, then between her fingers, then in the saucer by the caffè like it had always been there. He’s halfway through deciding whether it was a trick when he sees her hand dart—quick as a thought—toward the small stand of toothpick flags at the register. One disappears. She tucks it behind her ear and pretends not to have done it. The barista laughs as if she’s told a joke he didn’t catch. They drink standing up. The coffee is a small miracle—hot, dark, the bitter slide of it cutting through his jet-lagged fog. Alessandra watches him over the rim of her cup, interested the way a cat is interested in a moth. “So,” she says. “Ben. What did we almost kill? A historian? A librarian?” “A... lecturer.” He clears his throat. “Oxford. On sabbatical.” “Of course,” she says, as if this explains everything about his posture, his careful hair, his shoes. “You study love, beauty, death?” “Seventeenth-century Rome,” he admits. “Baroque architecture.” She tips her head. “So you came to the right place to get your heart broken.” He laughs, surprised by the way it comes out of him without apology. Alessandra smiles, a softer thing that doesn’t stay long. They’re back on the scooter and then not. A narrow street. Laundry like flags above them, a grandma yelling from a fifth-floor balcony, two boys kicking a ball that ricochets off a shrine to the Madonna with a blue bulb. Alessandra stops without throwing down the stand and leaves the scooter leaning precariously. She pulls Ben by the sleeve to a tiny, dark doorway where a man is slicing porchetta into bread as if cutting through argument. “Eat,” she commands. “You can pay me back in footnotes.” He takes a bite and makes a sound he didn’t expect to make in public. She hears it and laughs again. He watches her watching him and feels the ground under him shift, as if the city were balancing a little differently. When she’s looking away—at a dog with a red bandana—her fingers are busy again. A postcard slips from a rack into her messenger bag, just a fold of movement, the way you might brush hair from your face. Ben’s eyes widen. He is sure he did not see that. He is also sure he did. “Your bag,” he says lightly, polite even in his caution. “It seems quite... accommodative.” “Everyone in Rome steals,” she says airily. “Time. Space. Parking spots. Kisses.” “I—don’t,” he says, because he doesn’t know what else to say. “You will,” she counters. “By dinner I’ll have you stealing hours from your boring future.” He should argue. He eats instead. They rejoin traffic like a slapstick routine. A taxi cuts them off. Alessandra responds with a fluid insult that even Ben can tell is anatomically inventive. The taxi driver grins. Rome is a conversation that sometimes pretends to be an argument. At the Pantheon, she refuses to let him shuffle inward with the herd. Instead she pulls him around the side to a crack in time—an iron gate ajar, a courtyard that smells like damp stone and oranges. They stand beneath the round eye of the oculus, rain beginning as a murmur up there and then, a minute later, fat drops that find them as if they’ve been individually addressed. “Run,” she says, and they do, laughing, out through the shadows, across the piazza, as the sky decides to open with the sudden, theatrical certainty of a stage curtain ripping. Tourists squeal. Vendors swear. A waiter, with salute and flourish, whisks tablecloths like sails. Alessandra grabs his wrist and tugs him toward a sodium-yellow awning stretched over a gelato shop, crowded already with damp strangers. “Perfetto,” she says, shaking rain from her hair like a dog. “A storm. The universe is bored.” They press in under the awning. The cold sweetness of the shop breathes out at them. Children line along the glass, their noses fogging the panes. Ben can see pistachio like a field, a dark river of stracciatella. His shirt clings to his back. Alessandra’s jacket gleams darker, her eyelashes jeweled with drops. He watches one bead travel down her jaw like a decision. “Which?” she asks. “No, wait. Don’t think. First word.” “Pistachio,” he says, surprised by the clarity of the choice. She nods as if he has passed a test, and orders without looking at the board, in a stream of Italian that makes the teenager scoop generously. When the cups come, she’s already palming an extra napkin dispenser and then not—the kind of thing no one misses, because the universe replaces napkins like it replaces breath. Ben notices and pretends not to. They stand close, cheeks cold from the gelato, shoulders warm from proximity, rain drumming above them in a steady, intimate rhythm. A couple argues nearby in hissed Italian that even Ben, with his textbook phrases, can read—jealousy, a watch, a lie about where. Somewhere, a man plays a melancholy accordion under the deluge, a soundtrack for their shelter. “I can’t feel my feet,” Ben says. “But I can feel my mouth. Is that a Roman thing?” Alessandra’s smile is quick. “In Rome we keep the important parts awake.” He wants to ask what parts those are. He doesn’t. They watch the street become a river, the scooters crowding like dark fish under every overhang, the tourists huddled. They share a spoon between the cups, an inevitable intimacy. When she hands it to him, her fingers touch his knuckles, lingering half a second longer than necessary.
