He looks up; she looks away; a decision is asked and not yet made. “You’re dangerous,” he says softly, because if the day is a confession, let it be this. “Si,” she says, just as softly. “But I’ve kept you alive for, what, three hours?” “Three?” He glances at his watch and realizes it’s somehow six in the evening. The rain has stolen whole blocks of time. “How did—” She taps his watch face. “Thief,” she says, and makes it a joke. He laughs because the alternative would be to say something that would require the rest of the day to agree. The rain thins to threads, then to a fine mist. They step back out into a city rinsed and gleaming. The asphalt shines like obsidian. The sky is the color of a fading bruise. Alessandra kicks the Vespa into life and the city flares around them like a match. On a hill that lifts them toward the clouds—Aventine? Janiculum? He’s lost—she stops at a terrace with a view that explains why artists have been unbearable about Rome for centuries. A ribbon of river. Domes like shoulders in a bath. The air washed clean, the bells finding each other and ringing as if sharing news. She sits on the low wall and offers him a cigarette. He hesitates. She snorts. “Of course not,” she says, and lights it herself, dragging in smoke, eyes half-lidded. He wants to be her vice. He wants to be her reprieve. “Why me?” he asks, before he can convince himself not to. She exhales toward the city. “Because you almost died prettily,” she says. “Because you look like you haven’t said yes in years. Because your shoes are a joke.” He looks at his shoes, soaked and earnest. He thinks she’s lying a little, and also telling him something true. She reaches into her bag, pulls out a small thing, offers it to him. It’s the postcard he had not noticed disappear—the Pantheon at dusk, a painterly version with a sky like wine. On the back, she has already scrawled: Non pensare. Chiama. A Roman number, round and generous. Her handwriting leans forward, as if even the letters are in a hurry. “You stole this,” he says, because the dance requires partners. “Don’t be English,” she says, which is also an answer. He takes it. He feels ridiculous. He feels younger. He feels like he could be someone else for a while. They ride again. Trastevere at night is a party you’re late for but welcomed into anyway. A street musician plays something with too many minor chords. A woman leans out of a window to shake a rug. Men smoke and talk with their hands as if shaping the air could make it more their own. Alessandra knows people everywhere. She is kissed on both cheeks by a butcher with a ring in his ear, waved at by a tattooed boy who might owe her money or love or both. At a red light, she turns her head a fraction. “Are you having fun, professor?” He thinks of the seminar packets he did not bring, the notes waiting in a quiet room he cannot conjure now without it seeming absurd. He thinks of the hours he’s been stolen from and given back in new currency. He thinks of the rain on the awning and the way she orders for him without making him small. “Yes,” he says simply. “Good,” she says, and the light goes green. At the edge of a square he will not be able to find tomorrow without help, she stops. “Here,” she says. “I work.” She taps the messenger bag. “People wait. I disappear.” He steps off, legs jelly. He hands her the helmet awkwardly, like it might bite him. She leans in and adjusts his collar, unasked. No one has touched him like this in a long time, the small, domestic fix that says: you are in my world for a minute. “Will I see you again?” he asks, careful, casual as a man standing on a cliff. She looks him over, amused and unsparing and something else peeking through like a coin on the bottom of a fountain. “If you don’t die crossing the street,” she says. “And if you call. And if I feel like it.” “That’s... a lot of conditions.” “I like to think of them as luck.” He holds up the postcard. “I’m an academic. I don’t believe in luck.” Her smile goes slow and then sharp. “You will,” she murmurs, and the Vespa coughs, snarls, becomes a note disappearing into the city. He stands in the wake of her, heart going too fast, hands smelling faintly of petrol and sugar, Rome humming around him as if it has swallowed his name. He looks at the postcard again. There is a smudge at the corner where her thumb must have been, a little dark moon. The guidebook is heavy under his arm. He could open it and be told where to go next. He could follow the map back to his safe apartment with its interestingly dangerous plug sockets and the books stacked like polite hostages. Instead he tucks the card into the back of the guidebook, as if it had always been there, as if he had taken it from a page he’d forgotten he'd dog-eared years ago. Non pensare, she wrote. Don’t think. He steps off the curb without looking, and then laughs at himself and looks anyway. A taxi whooshes past, close enough to lift the hair on his arms. He breathes. Somewhere, bells. Somewhere, a woman swears and a man laughs as if it were a compliment. The day is behind him like a train rushing into a tunnel, leaving him bright-eyed and a little deaf. He looks up at the slice of moon, thinks of a coin arcing through the air over water, a promise for tourists. He is not a tourist anymore, he thinks, and then refuses to think at all. He begins to walk, not home exactly, but toward the idea of one, and the city, mischievous and old, falls in beside him.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece is a remarkably accomplished contemporary romance that captures the essence of Rome through the chance encounter between Ben, a British academic, and Alessandra, a spirited Italian courier. The writing demonstrates exceptional control of pacing, characterization, and atmospheric detail. The narrative successfully creates two distinct characters whose personalities emerge organically through their actions and dialogue. Alessandra's impulsive, boundary-pushing nature contrasts beautifully with Ben's cautious academic demeanor. Her kleptomania is subtly revealed through small acts throughout the day—swiping a toothpick flag, a postcard, napkins—rather than being explicitly stated, which shows sophisticated restraint. The prose is particularly strong in its sensory details and imagery. Rome comes alive through specific, evocative descriptions: "Rome peels open like an orange under her driving," "The asphalt shines like obsidian," and "Domes like shoulders in a bath." These images avoid cliché while remaining accessible and vivid. The dialogue exchanges are natural and revealing, with Alessandra's quick wit ("You say 'why not' like a man who has said 'why yes' only to footnotes") and Ben's polite responses creating authentic tension. The writer skillfully uses dialogue to advance characterization rather than merely plot. The narrative structure follows the prompt's request for interconnected scenes spanning a single day, moving from the Trevi Fountain to cafés, the Pantheon, and various Roman neighborhoods. Each location serves the character development and growing attraction between the protagonists. The chemistry between the characters builds convincingly through small moments of physical proximity, shared experiences, and the gradual breaking down of Ben's reserve. The writer avoids rushing their connection, instead allowing it to develop through meaningful interactions. One of the piece's greatest strengths is how it balances the external journey through Rome with the internal journey of the characters. Ben's transformation from cautious academic to someone willing to embrace spontaneity feels earned through his day with Alessandra. The ending strikes the right note of ambiguity and possibility. It doesn't force a romantic resolution but leaves the reader with the sense that Ben has been changed by the encounter, now willing to step "off the curb without looking" and embrace the unpredictability that Alessandra represents. If there are weaknesses, they are minor. Occasionally, the prose risks becoming slightly overwrought in its metaphors, though it generally pulls back before crossing that line. There are also moments where the pacing slows slightly in descriptive passages, though these still contribute to the atmospheric quality of the piece. Overall, this is an exceptionally well-crafted romance that fulfills all the requirements of the prompt while demonstrating sophisticated storytelling techniques, nuanced characterization, and evocative prose. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20 Elegant Prose: 19 Emotionally Engaging: 19 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 20 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20.0, Elegant Prose: 19.0, Emotionally Engaging: 19.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 20.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Cozy sci-fi: The Last Outpost — Score: 85.5
Prompt:
Cozy sci-fi The Last Outpost Nettle (or Nets to her friends) bartends at The Last Outpost -- a lazy hub for miners and merchants in an asteroid belt on the Andromeda outer rim. Escaping from her past life, Nets found a home here at the Outpost. They have, thus far, tolerated Net's flaws which she tries to keep in equilibrium with her assortment of talents. Her evenings involve chatting with patrons, negotiating the drama, intrigue, problems & love lives of the diverse crowd that filter through the Outpost. Tonight is no different, at least, until a frazzled looking stranger, tentacled dreads askew, quietly plops down at the bar: "Vega whisky, neat. Better make that a double." Write a chapter in this story. Establish conflict for narrative interest. Don't resolve the conflict within this chapter. Aim for about 60% dialogue. First person, present tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The Last Outpost hums like it’s purring, a content cat of patched titanium and borrowed gravity. The mag-ads along the far wall flicker in a sluggish rainbow and the neon OUTPOST sign jitters on its second O. The grav plates have been touchy all week; everyone’s drinks sway like they’re listening to music only the liquids can hear. Mine too, a chipped mug of ginger fizz I keep under the counter, rocking the way a heart does just before it skips. I wipe a ring of condensation off the bartop and pretend I don’t notice the way the floor dips for a second as the plates adjust. The late shift means the knots of miners are looser, the merchants down to their second stories and third lies. Behind me, the old holo of Andromeda’s rim—a touristy loop of dust and blue gas—glitches in and out of a pale square. Boss calls it ambience. I call it depressing. “Seven salts, Nets,” Yorel says from a stool and taps the side of his empty glass. His hands are raw, his nails rimed with something that’s probably not legal to inhale. “You’re on six, Yorel.” I tip my chin at him. “You want to go home vertical?” He grins, all teeth and stubble. “Home misses me.” “Home is a cot in Block D with a heater that hasn’t worked since the last solar flare. It doesn’t miss anyone.” I pour him a half-shot anyway. He groans, then laughs, because that’s the joke of The Last Outpost: nothing is ever enough, so we pretend it is. The door sighs open. The station moans, then stills. A breeze that isn’t a breeze slips past my cheeks and the hair on my arms lifts. I don’t know how to explain that sensation to anyone who isn’t born station-side. It’s like Mass wants you to notice her for a second and then forget again. They slip in quietly. Tentacled dreads, slicked to the left as if slept on, eyes like dark syrup edged with heat. Pale, not in the human way but in that washed-out glow some of the aquatic-born get when they’ve been too long between humidity cycles. They don’t look like a miner. They don’t look like a merchant. They look like a story. They slide onto a stool, trying to look anonymous, which is hilarious because anonymity at The Last Outpost is neon. The tentacles twitch and then settle. They keep their hands under the bar lip like they’re hiding them. “Vega whisky, neat,” they say, voice soft but hoarse, sanded smooth by a lot of not sleeping. “Better make that a double.” “That’ll ruin your evening in one go,” I say. “That’s the plan.” “Ruin your evening here and I got cleanup,” I say, because banter is how I measure danger. Even in new faces, there’s a way people lean into or away from a joke. The stranger’s mouth twitches, a tug at the corner. “I’ll try to lubricate neatly.” “Lubricate somewhere else,” Yorel throws in. A couple stools down, Jaya snorts fizz out her nose. Laughter trickles and fades. The stranger’s eyes flick over heads, calculating. I pour the Vega. The amber clings a breath too long to the glass before it yields. Gravity dips, and the surface makes a little dome, then quivers and flattens. I set it down carefully. Their hand emerges, and I clock the glove immediately. It’s a good glove. It’s also hiding. “Lot of folks wear gloves,” I say, mostly to myself, mostly for the universe to hear I’m paying attention. “Lot of bars have house rules,” they say, and drink. “Lot of bartenders keep quiet unless the gloves got claws,” I say. “Mine don’t.” They drain the first half like it’s medicine and not invention. The tentacles soften, uncoil a little. The pupils widen, then contract again. I see the moment the burn hits. Their shoulders drop. They inhale that thin Outpost air as if it’s sweeter now. “You new to this belt?” I ask, like I’m just filling air. “Passing through,” they say. “Everyone says that.” I lean in. “What’s your name, passing through?” They roll the glass between thumb and forefinger. The glove squeaks. “Do you prefer the truth or the version where we pretend we’ll never meet again?” “I prefer names that fit in your mouth.” “Nettle, isn’t it?” they say, lifting their gaze to me. Not a guess. The tentacles twitch, the smallest quiver, like they’re tasting something electric. “Or Nets. To your friends.” I keep my face pleasant. The veil between I’m-just-the-bartender and please-do-not-say-my-past out loud is thin but resilient. I’m practiced at it. I smile the way I do when someone’s about to start a fight and I need them to think they’re winning. “And you are?” I say. They consider. “Call me Quill.” “That’s not your name,” I say. “It’s the one I can afford today.” Yorel knocks the bar. “Nets, you ignoring me now? I got needs.” “Your needs owe me two hundred and twelve credits, Yorel,” I say. “You’re lucky I nurture your bad habits at all.” “I can pay,” Quill says, almost too quickly. I cock an eyebrow. “For Yorel? That’s charity.” “For your time,” Quill says. They tilt their head toward the end of the bar, where the private nook is topped with a busted star-map and a misaligned privacy screen. “Five minutes.” “Five minutes is one hundred credits and I get to keep your drink if you’re boring.” “Deal.” “You hear that?” Jaya says, raising her glass. “Nets charges by the minute now.” “I charge by the caliber of nonsense,” I say, scooping Quill’s glass and angling my chin toward the nook. I flick the privacy screen on. The static hums, not perfect, never perfect. Station hum adds to it, a harmony of failing systems and stubborn perseverance. Quill slides into the booth opposite me. Close, but not too. The glove stays on the table. Their other hand, ungloved, is bare, webbed between fingers. Riverborn. They see me clock it and tuck it back. Old instinct. Some places don’t serve Riverborn. The Outpost is not some places, but people bleed habits. “What’s the caliber?” I ask. “Explosive,” they say. “And timed.” “I prefer slow burns.” Their smile is small and gone quickly. “There are three ships in orbit that don’t belong here. One is broadcasting a sanitation crew code from Vesta-Three. One is dead silent, but the transponder pings off a registry that got scrubbed in the last Ceril Syndicate sweep. One is trying not to look like a patrol.” I swirl my ginger fizz and glance toward the bar. Yorel drags a finger through salt on the counter, sculpting a snake. Jaya is oranges and laughter. The rest are shadows with credit chips. “We get patrols,” I say. “You get bored patrols,” Quill says. “You don’t get these. And you don’t get them together.” “You been looking up a lot.” “I listen,” they say. The tentacles settle, the ends splay. “Officially? I’m a courier. Unofficially? I’m freelance problems. I was hired to move a package. Someone changed their mind. Now everyone is nervous, including me.” “You want me to hold a package.” I make it flat, so it sounds like something else. “We’re not a storage cube.” “I want you to pretend to be loud and obvious,” Quill says. “For a handful of hours.” “Ah.” I grin despite myself. “My specialty.” Quill leans forward. The privacy screen fuzzes around the shape of their face. Up close, their pupils are flecked with amber, like a galaxy under oil. “The package is here,” they say. “Under your feet, probably. In the ducting. Someone slipped it into the Outpost three hours ago, put it where it would be least obvious and most safe because everyone here is too lazy to crawl. They used your name to open a maintenance hatch.” I keep the grin. It’s fun until it’s not. “My name travels well.” “They used it because it was in the system,” Quill says. “Nettle Marc. Pressed old credentials. The kind you don’t like anyone saying out loud.” That stops me. Not long, not visible enough to show, but enough that Quill sees it. Of course they do. They drink another mouthful to give me space to decide whether to lie. The liquor surface bulges with the gravity’s sigh and they hold it steady with a finger pressed to the rim, steady as a pin. “We’re not doing the part where I deny I ever had credentials,” I say. “We’re skipping to why I shouldn’t toss you out an airlock.” “Because I came to you,” Quill says. “Because the package is tagged. Because if the wrong ships ping it, this place becomes an example.” “You’re a ray of sunshine.” “I’m telling you because you can bake a distraction like nobody else,” they say. “Because you know the ducts. Because the Outpost protects its own, and you are that too now, whether or not your bones remember.” We sit with that. My mug wobbles. The gravity dips and rises like a breath. “What’s in the package?” I ask. Quill’s eyes flick. “Does it matter?” “It will if it leaks.” “It won’t leak,” they say, absolutely certain. “It will explode.” I don’t laugh. “You said timed.” “Triggered,” Quill corrects. “Wrong hands, wrong room, wrong signal. It’s data mostly. Wrapped around something unpleasant.” “Like how you’re wrapped around ‘mostly,’” I say. “If I say no?” “Then I take it and run,” Quill says. “And the ships upstairs take me and cut me apart, and maybe they don’t find it in time, and maybe the Outpost gets to become a cautionary tale you tell the next crowded bar.” I tap a rhythm my mother used to hum when she wanted me to stop asking questions. It doesn’t work on me any more than it did then. I glance toward the bar. Del, the dockhand with the tattoo of an anchor on her wrist, has drifted in. She lifts her chin at me, the subtle signal that means someone is cruising for trouble on the docks. I lift my chin back, the signal for later. “I need more than promises,” I say. “And more than credits.” Quill nods. “Bring me a bar rag.” “Excuse me?” “A bar rag,” they repeat. “And a glass. And a spoon. And your hand for two seconds.” “Now you’re making this weird,” I say, but I get up anyway because curiosity is the only drug I never quit. I swipe three glasses, snag a clean rag, grab the long stirring spoon. Yorel wolf-whistles. I ignore him. The air near the door shivers as two new bodies come in. They smell like ozone and too-new boots. I feel it more than see it. Back in the nook, I set the items down. Quill pushes the rag toward me. “Hold that.” I do. They slide the glove off slow, and I get a flash of what they were hiding: not claws, not illegal mods. Scars, precise and ringed, like someone burned circles into their skin over and over to map a constellation. Each circle has a thin line etched into it. The spaces between run faintly with bioluminescent blue. It’s delicate and horrifying in the way that makes your throat tight. Quill dips two fingers into the water I didn’t bring and yet is there—condensed from the air, pulled into their palm, a trick Riverborn learn at twelve. They smear it on the spoon and then trace something onto the rag. The gravity hitches to hear it. The lines glow briefly and then sink. The rag looks like a rag again. “That,” they say, voice low, “is a scrambler a degree above what your boss can afford. Toss it in the ducting above your coolant lines. It will make the tag read like a thermal hiccup for a while.” “And the glass?” They tap the rim. The glass hums. It picks up the station frequency, the whisper of the grav plates. “You’ll hear when the patrol pings. You’ll have seven minutes from the first note to get loud.” “How loud?” “Loud enough that whoever’s watching thinks the thing they’re looking for isn’t worth exploding beneath a hundred bodies and a dozen bets.” “People aren’t cover,” I say. “They are the point,” Quill says, and their face is more tired than I thought it could be. “I don’t want anyone to be cover.” The two new arrivals stop at the end of the bar. One has a jaw like a landing strip, the other wears a smile wrong. The Outpost’s neon paints them green. They don’t sit. They search the room. They are the kind of problem that has a uniform even when it doesn’t. “Friends of yours?” I ask. Quill doesn’t look. The tentacles stiffen, just a hair. “They think so,” they say. “They don’t know who the package chose.” “Packages don’t choose.” “This one did,” Quill says. “It likes vents. And names that fit in your mouth.” “Cute.” My grin is back, thin as foil. “We got seven minutes?” “If you drop that rag now,” Quill says. “Maybe less. They’re impatient upstairs.” “Listen,” I say, because my mouth is ahead of me and my brain is a step late, “you bring a mess into my bar, you say my name like it’s a key, you ask me to cover you with a crowd, and you don’t even offer me a terrible secret to hold for later?” “Terrible secret,” Quill says, as if testing the syllables. Then they look at me, really look, and their voice goes softer. “When they burned those circles into me, they told me I was a map. I left before they could decide where I had to go. Every star above us looks like a promise and a trap, and I choose the promise every time. Is that terrible enough?” “It’ll do,” I say, and I fold the rag. The gravity dips. The glasses on the bar shiver. The two at the end shift closer, like they’ve scented something. I slide out of the booth. The station feels smaller all of a sudden, as if the walls have leaned in to hear. “Last question,” I say, casual as I can fake. “Who used my name?” Quill’s mouth quirks. “Someone who knew it belonged to a person who could handle this. Someone who thought you might miss being useful.” “I pour drinks,” I say. “You hold a room,” they say. “Please hold it now.” I tuck the rag into my apron. I walk back behind the bar like nothing is happening. Like I’m not about to use a bit of wet cloth and a glass song to blind three ships and a pair of bastards with too-new boots. I set the glass by the sink and listen. It sings, faint, a high keening noise that makes my molars ache. “Okay,” I say, under my breath. “Okay.” Yorel looks up at me, catches something in my face. “Nets?” “Shut up and bet me ten credits I can get the whole bar to sing along to Orion Blues,” I say, voice sharp and bright. He grins, because he knows a show when he’s being handed one, even if he doesn’t know why. “I’ll bet you fifty,” Jaya says, leaning in. “If you also throw a glass and don’t break it.” The gravity dips again, almost playful now. My drinks wobble. The station hums. The two at the end of the bar straighten like hounds. Above us, something pings distant as a star dying. “Fifty credits?” I flash my teeth. “Make it a hundred. And hold onto your drinks.” Behind me, the ducting whispers. The rag in my pocket is ordinary, damp with a map I don’t understand. Quill sits very still in the nook, eyes on the street outside the privacy screen, on the new arrivals, on me. The Outpost waits. I lift my hands. The room leans forward, and I feel the moment I love and hate most in equal measure: where everyone’s breath is mine to shape. I smack the bar twice with the spoon. Glass hum answers. The song is ready to start. And then the door opens again, hard enough to rattle the neon. A shadow fills the entrance, shoulders brushing the frame. I know that silhouette. I know the way she tilts her head to see a room as if every person in it is a chess piece and she’s three moves ahead. Nara walks in, the past I left coalesced into boots and a jacket and a gun at her hip. Her eyes find me in three beats. Her mouth does not smile. “Nettle,” she says, like gravity reasserting itself. Quill’s head drops. Yorel swears softly. The glass by the sink sings higher. The Outpost holds its breath. My heart does the same stupid wobble as the drinks. “Hi, Nara,” I say. “Want anything to drink?”
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully creates a cozy sci-fi atmosphere while establishing clear conflict and tension. The author has crafted a vivid setting in The Last Outpost, a bar in an asteroid belt with failing gravity plates and a diverse clientele. The first-person present tense narration through Nettle's perspective is consistently maintained throughout. The strongest elements are the worldbuilding and atmosphere. Details like "drinks sway like they're listening to music only the liquids can hear" and the way gravity "dips" create a tangible sense of place. The author skillfully introduces sci-fi elements without overwhelming exposition, allowing readers to infer the setting's rules naturally. The dialogue comprises approximately 60% of the text as requested, and it serves multiple purposes effectively: revealing character, advancing plot, and providing exposition without feeling forced. The banter between Nettle and the patrons establishes her as quick-witted and experienced, while her conversation with Quill builds tension and mystery. Character development is nuanced. Nettle is established as someone with a mysterious past she's trying to escape, now finding a home at the Outpost. Secondary characters like Yorel and Jaya have distinct personalities despite limited page time. Quill is intriguing - clearly in trouble, with physical characteristics (tentacled dreads, webbed fingers) that mark them as different. The conflict is well-established: a mysterious package hidden in the ducts, ships in orbit that "don't belong," and the arrival of Nara from Nettle's past. The chapter ends on a perfect cliffhanger that leaves multiple questions unanswered, creating narrative tension without resolution. However, there are some weaknesses. Occasionally, the prose becomes slightly purple, with metaphors that call attention to themselves rather than enhancing the narrative. Some descriptions, while evocative, could be tightened for clarity. The relationship between Nettle and Nara could have been foreshadowed earlier to make the ending revelation more impactful. The piece also introduces several plot elements in quick succession during Quill's explanation - the package, the ships, Nettle's past credentials - which creates a slight feeling of information overload. While this contributes to the tension, it risks confusing readers about what the central conflict actually is. Overall, this is a strong piece of cozy sci-fi that successfully establishes an intriguing world, complex characters, and compelling conflicts while adhering to the prompt requirements. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 17.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Young adult drama: Gone South — Score: 88.8
Prompt:
Young adult drama Gone South Taylor is a 16 year old teen with a history of "concerning behavioural patterns" (or that's how the stupid smug school counsellor worded it on the phone call to Mom). It shouldn't be a surprise: When you live in a backwater town in Tennessee, your choices are: a. be mind-fuckingly bored, or b. invent some drama. Two days ago, Taylor came out to their family as trans. This disclosure was *not* in the category of invented drama -- it was, in fact, the real deal, and a long time coming. It didn't go well. The last 48 hours had been pure disaster. In a moment of desperate inspiration, Taylor had decided to get the hell out of dodge. And so an escape plan was hatched and executed within the space of 30 minutes. That was last night. Now Taylor was two states away, having been unceremoniously ejected from their hitched ride in downtown New Orleans. Write the next chapter in Taylor's story as they find their feet in this new environment. Tell the chapter over the course of their first day in New Orleans, in which Taylor meets another runaway with issues and secrets. Taylor navigates this new world, not knowing who to trust or what the dangers are. Write in Taylor's voice, and incorporate their internal monologue as they grapple with intense & conflicting emotions. Also incorporate dialogue with the interesting characters Taylor meets. First person, mixed tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
I’m trying to pretend that my stomach isn’t one clenched fist of hunger and anxiety, but it’s hard when I can literally smell powdered sugar on the air and hear someone laughing like their lungs aren’t strapped shut like mine. New Orleans is too loud to be a real place. It’s like someone turned up the saturation in Photoshop and hit “random.” The buildings slouch into each other with those fancy balconies like they’re gossiping, the street musicians are already out even though it’s barely ten-thirty, and tourists shuffle past in packs, mouths open, pointing at everything like it’s a zoo and we’re the animals. I keep wanting to yell at them to stop staring at me, which doesn’t make sense because they’re not. I’m not wearing anything weird—cutoff shorts, hoodie tied around my waist because the air is wet and hot but I might need to disappear—but I feel like the words TRANS KID are stamped across my forehead in neon. Also, my phone is at twelve percent, which is basically the same thing as being shipwrecked. I stand under a wrought-iron balcony that drips ferns and try to act like I belong. This is the new plan: look like I’ve made decisions before. My backpack is half-empty (bad move) but zipped tight (good move). I’ve got sixty-four dollars crumpled and sweaty in the pocket of my hoodie. There’s a busker with a trumpet playing something that’s almost a lullaby, almost a threat. Behind me, in the alley, a woman negotiates with a guy over a set of beads like it’s James Bond tech. A bead deal. Okay. I’m here. Not in Tennessee. Not in that kitchen where Mom’s fingers shook around her mug and Dad—no, not Dad—just stared like he was waiting for someone to yell “cut” and fix the script. I should find a charger. I should find a bathroom. I should find... a life? Ha. “Hey, Red.” I flinch so hard my teeth clack. The voice comes from my left, where a boy is leaned up against a streetlamp like he invented leaning. He’s a little older than me—maybe eighteen?—with a haircut that’s trying very hard not to be a mullet and a face you trust until you notice his eyes are cataloging the world like a shoplifter. His sneakers are taped at the toes with black electrical tape. He’s got a plastic bag that says THANK YOU THANK YOU THANK YOU in red letters, and I realize he’s just called me Red because of my hair. The dye is almost grown out at the roots, and the rest has faded from ruby to rust. Red. Cute. He smirks when I don’t answer. “You look like you got dropped into the wrong video game. Need a map?” “I’m good,” I say, because I’m not going to be that kid. My voice is steady enough that I want to fist-pump. Two days ago, saying anything felt like my throat was full of broken glass. Two days ago, I had a name that wasn’t mine and a house that wasn’t safe. Today, I have nothing except a hoodie and almost a dozen percent battery. “Good,” he echoes, pushing off the pole. “Great. Super. I’m Ash.” “Like the Pokémon trainer?” He grins, teeth small and uneven. “Like what’s left after the fire.” Okay, intense. “Taylor,” I say. There’s a beat where I think, do I add that I’m trans like a footnote, like a caveat? Hi, I’m Taylor, and. Nope. Not his business. Not because I’m ashamed. Because it feels like offering meat to a dog I don’t know. “You run away, Taylor?” he asks. He says it in a breezy way, like it’s a guess, like he didn’t clock my whole life in one look. “No.” “Yes,” he says, like we’re playing Truth or Dare and he’s the dealer. “You smell like Greyhound and existential dread.” “I smell like the rain,” I retort, because I walked through a sudden shower, because the sky here doesn’t bother with foreplay. It just opens. He points across the street at a café with a chalkboard sign promising chicory coffee and a beignet that looks as big as my face. “Come on.” “I don’t—” “What, you think I’m kidnapping you? In a café? Relax. I just know the bathroom code.” He doesn’t wait. He snakes through the crowd, and I follow because I don’t have a better plan. My phone vibrates in my pocket like a mosquito: 11% now, and a text from Mom that I don’t open because I don’t have the stomach for the word please in her voice. The café smells like a hug from someone you used to like. We slide into a back corner because Ash is apparently allergic to visibility. He palms a sugar packet the way some people breathe. “Bathroom code’s 1023,” he says. “Wash your face. Cry, if you need to. Whatever. You look like your heart is about to punch its way out.” In the mirror, I look like someone who hasn’t slept, which—ding ding—correct. My eyes are red-rimmed, my hair is a cautionary tale, and there’s a zit brewing on my chin like a tiny volcano. I splash water that tastes like metal and old pennies, blot my cheeks on a paper towel, and I do not cry. I’ve spent two days shaking like a washing machine and I’m tired of it. Sixteen and tired. That should be illegal. Back at the table, Ash has acquired a beignet the size of my face and a coffee that smells like someone burned a flower and decided it was a delicacy. He pushes the plate toward me with a little flick of his wrist. “I can’t—” “Take it,” he says. “I’m not nice enough to do charity. Consider it a strategic investment in not watching you pass out.” The powdered sugar hits my tongue and suddenly my brain is like oh hello, dopamine. “Thanks,” I manage around a mouthful. He watches me, not in a gross way. More like he’s on recon. “Where’d you come from?” he asks. “Tennessee.” He nods like I’ve said Mars. “Cool. Nobody comes here from Tennessee. It’s all Ohio and Texas this time of year.” “You keep stats?” “Working theory. You learn the migratory patterns of the weird. You from Nashville? Memphis? Random cousin of Dolly Parton?” “Small town,” I say, and the words taste like dust. “The kind where the Walgreens is a destination and if you sneeze, your neighbor says ‘Bless you’ from across the street.” He smiles, then sobers. “Why’d you run?” “Why did you?” I shoot back. I’m not telling him my everything in a café after three minutes. I’m not telling him about how my mother said his name with more care than mine, how my uncle stared at my chest like it offended him now that it meant nothing to me. I’m not telling him about Dad—nope, stop, not Dad—standing with his arms crossed and unmoving, like a monument to denial. I’m not telling him how I packed in the dark, hands shaking so hard the zipper snagged four times, and walked to the highway like it was a church aisle. Ash’s jaw twitches. “I don’t like dudes with rings telling me when to be home,” he says. It’s a joke, but it isn’t. “And I don’t like fists. So I left.” I nod, and for a second we’re two planets sharing a sun. The beignet is gone before I know it, and I’m licking sugar off my thumb like a raccoon. Classy. “You got somewhere to sleep?” he asks. “I was going to find a hostel,” I lie, because the words I have nowhere sound like the end of a magic trick. He laughs, not mean. “You and the backpackers with trust funds from Vermont. Cool. Hostels ask for ID most times. You got ID?” I have a learner’s permit with the wrong name on it and a face that looks like me but also like someone I used to play on TV. “Sure,” I say. “Technically.” He tilts his head. “You’re a terrible liar.” “I’m a decent liar,” I say, because evidence suggests I’m at least functional at it. I look at the window, at a girl with glitter on her cheeks walking a dog that’s wearing sunglasses. For a heartbeat, I want to be her, careless and weird and owned by nobody. Ash taps the table. “Okay. This is where I do my Good Samaritan routine, but with disclaimers. There’s a place you can crash, no questions asked for a night or two if you keep your head straight and don’t steal anybody’s stuff. It’s not glamorous. It’s damp. Smells like old vape. Also, sometimes cops swing by and make trouble. You in?” I should not follow a stranger to his damp vape palace. I should find a Salvation Army or a youth shelter and sign forms and let my mother come get me and go home and apologize until my tongue dissolves. My stomach lurches. “Where?” I ask. “By the river,” he says. “Old warehouse. You share the space, you share the risk.” “Why help me?” I ask, because I don’t believe in free rides, or free beignets, or free kindness. Not anymore. He shrugs, but his mouth goes tight. “Because someone helped me. Because you looked like your bones were ringing.” He looks at my hoodie. “Because you said Tennessee like you were choking on it.” We leave the café, and the heat slaps us like a teacher’s hand. The sky is bright and oppressive, a blanket you can’t kick off. The French Quarter gives way to broader streets, fewer tourists, more actual people: a woman pushing a cart of cold water bottles, a guy sleeping on a strip of lawn under a tree that hoards shade like secrets. The river is a brown muscle flexing behind low walls. My phone buzzes again. Ten percent. “Hey,” I say, as we walk, “do you know where I can charge my—” “Phone?” Ash finishes, like an oracle. “Yeah. There’s a corner in the mall by the aquarium where the outlets aren’t monitored. Or the library on Loyola if you can sit still and pretend to read.” “Can you sit still?” I ask. “Only under duress.” We cut down toward the water, past a man selling pralines out of a tin that I want to bury my face in. The warehouse is really a skeleton of one. It’s brick, but parts of it are scabbed with plywood, and the door is a slit in the middle like a scar. Inside, it’s cooler and it smells like damp cardboard and cinnamon gum. There are blankets set up against one wall in a patchwork, a couple of milk crates, and a plastic tarp ceiling that flutters like a weak heartbeat. There are three other people: a girl with a shaved head and gold hoops who is sewing something purple by hand; a kid who can’t be more than fourteen, asleep with his arm thrown over his face; and a person whose gender is a question mark in a black tank top, drawing with a Sharpie on a piece of cardboard. They all look at me like they’re deciding. “This is Taylor,” Ash announces, as if that’s a completely normal thing. “They’re cool. From Tennessee.” “Yeehaw,” says Hoop Girl, deadpan. She squints. “You use they because…?” “Because that’s what I use,” I say, and it comes out easy and hard at the same time. I stand straighter without meaning to. The relief is sudden and stupid. A name is a door. A pronoun is a bridge. “Nice,” says Hoop Girl. “I’m Mel. He-him over there is Cricket,” she nods at the sleeping kid, “and they-them is Jess,” she nods at the Sharpie artist. “Don’t touch my thread. It bites.” “Hi,” says Jess without looking up. “Boundaries are sexy. Also, we all have knives.” “Okay,” I say, trying to smile like that’s not the most alarming Welcome to the Club sentence I’ve heard in my life. “You can put your bag there,” Ash says, pointing. “Watch for roaches. They’re like tiny landlords.” I lower my backpack carefully. My fingers shake. I hate that my hands still do that. I don’t want them to. I don’t want to be the fragile one in the room. “You look like your last three days were a novel,” Jess says, uncapping the marker with their teeth. Their eyes are kind, which makes me suspicious. Everything kind feels like a trap. In my head, my mother is crying again, her fingers worrying a napkin to death. My not-Dad is staring. Unclench, unclench, unclench. “Short story,” I say. “Badly edited.” Mel snorts. “You write?” “I used to write angsty poems about the sky and how nobody understood me,” I say. “So yes. I am, in fact, a teenager.” “Poems are currency,” Jess says. “You can pay rent with a metaphor if you’re good enough.” Ash disappears for a second and comes back with two extension cords coiled like snakes. “Okay,” he says. “Moment of grace.” He plugs one into a strip anchored suspiciously to the wall. “Power. For the needy.” It feels like church. I plug my phone in and it bings, and the screen lights up with more messages than I want to look at. Mom, Mom, blocked number, Uncle James (ew), unknown. A voicemail from a number I don’t know. I stare until the messages blur, then flip the phone face down like it’s misbehaving. “You good?” Ash asks, quiet. “Yes,” I lie again, because the truth is a forest with no paths. But the cord is real, and the cool is real, and the air tastes like rust and sweetness, and my name on these people’s tongues felt like something that might not be a weapon. I sit on the blanket, and for the first time in two days, I let my back lean against a wall without flinching. We spend the afternoon breathing. Mel shows me how to sew up a rip in my hoodie and calls me “kid” in a way that isn’t an insult. Cricket wakes up and eats crackers with surgical precision and tells me he’s been on the road for nine months because his foster dad was a clown (like, literally) who never took the paint off, and honestly, if that isn’t a reason to run, I don’t know what is. Jess draws a city on cardboard, a maze of streets that loops back into itself like a spell. Ash goes out and comes back with a bag of day-old bread from a bakery where “the lady knows my eyebrows.” We tear pieces off and eat them with our hands like goats. At some point, a cop car idles out front and my lungs stop. Ash squeezes my wrist once, his thumb hard bone against my pulse. The car moves on. I breathe again, shaky. My phone pings. Seven percent. It’s almost evening when he says, “There’s a place tonight. A lady named Miss Rayna gives plates of food to kids like us behind a church. No sermons. Just jambalaya that could make you cry. You in?” I nod too fast. “Yes.” We go. The sky is pink at the edges like it’s embarrassed. The church is small and stolid and the woman with the food is tall and soft and doesn’t look at me like a problem to solve. “Baby,” she says, ladling rice and meat into a bowl I don’t deserve, “you need a second helping, you ask.” Her eyes slide over my face like she’s reading a poem she’s seen before. “You safe tonight?” I glance at Ash, who is messing with a plastic fork like it wronged him in a past life. “I think so,” I say. “You call me if you not,” she says, and slips a card into my hand like it’s a magic trick. There’s a number on it. Just a number. No name. It feels like a rope thrown over a wall. Back at the warehouse, the night hums. Someone’s radio is tuned to a station that plays old songs that sound like rain. The city keeps breathing even when I can’t. My phone dies at 1%, like it’s timed to break my heart. I look at Ash. “Why did you really help me?” I ask. The beignet sugar was one thing. A bed is something else. He looks at the river for a long second, like he’s asking it for permission. “You remind me of—” He stops. Starts again. “I had a little sister,” he says finally. “She—” He scrapes his thumb against his palm. “She didn’t make it out. I don’t do that story. But I do this.” He gestures at the crappy tarp kingdom. “I do this so somebody else gets to pick a new story.” Something breaks in me and doesn’t hurt when it does. I nod. We don’t do hugs. I want to. I don’t know how to ask. Instead I say, “Thanks.” “Don’t get sappy,” he says, but he’s already smiling, and I think maybe I can breathe tomorrow, too. I curl up on my borrowed blanket with my dead phone under my cheek like a stupid talisman. The warehouse breathes. The city breathes. I say my name in my head like a quiet drum. Taylor. Taylor. Tomorrow, I’ll find the library. Tomorrow, I’ll text Mom something that won’t break both of us. Tomorrow, I’ll scrape together a plan out of thread and day-old bread and borrowed outlets. Tonight, I’m here. I’m Taylor. The air is wet and sweet. A train cries somewhere far away and the sound runs through my bones like a spine. I try to sleep. I don’t. Not really. But I rest, which is a new verb. And when the dark shifts and the river laughs and a roach as big as my thumb taps across the floor like a tiny inspector general, I laugh, too. Quiet. Mean. Alive.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively captures the voice of a transgender teen runaway navigating their first day in New Orleans. The writing successfully establishes Taylor's character through first-person narration that balances vulnerability with defensive humor. The prose has a distinctive style that feels authentic to a literate, somewhat sardonic teenager, with lines like "New Orleans is too loud to be a real place" and "I'm not telling him how I packed in the dark, hands shaking so hard the zipper snagged four times, and walked to the highway like it was a church aisle." The character development is strong, particularly in how Taylor's internal monologue reveals their conflicting emotions about running away. The piece effectively shows Taylor's hyperawareness of their transgender identity without making it the only defining characteristic. The backstory is revealed organically through memories and reflections rather than exposition dumps. The dialogue is one of the strongest elements, with each character having a distinct voice. Ash's street-smart cynicism ("Like what's left after the fire"), Mel's deadpan humor ("Yeehaw"), and Jess's poetic observations ("Poems are currency. You can pay rent with a metaphor if you're good enough") all feel authentic and serve to characterize the speakers. The setting descriptions are vivid and sensory, capturing New Orleans through specific details: "The buildings slouch into each other with those fancy balconies like they're gossiping," "The air is wet and hot," and "The café smells like a hug from someone you used to like." These descriptions are integrated naturally into Taylor's observations rather than feeling like separate descriptive passages. The pacing is well-handled, covering Taylor's first day in New Orleans while incorporating flashbacks to their coming out and departure. The narrative moves between immediate concerns (hunger, phone battery, finding shelter) and deeper emotional struggles without losing momentum. There are a few moments where the prose becomes slightly overwrought, with metaphors that strain credibility for a teenage narrator: "The river is a brown muscle flexing behind low walls" and "A train cries somewhere far away and the sound runs through my bones like a spine." However, these instances are relatively rare and don't significantly detract from the overall quality. The ending strikes an appropriate balance between hope and uncertainty. Taylor hasn't magically solved their problems, but they've found temporary shelter and potential allies. The final paragraph's mix of vulnerability and defiance ("Quiet. Mean. Alive.") feels earned given the day's experiences. The piece successfully fulfills the prompt requirements, incorporating Taylor's internal monologue, dialogue with interesting characters, and a mix of tenses. It captures the emotional complexity of a transgender teen navigating both their identity and the practical challenges of being a runaway. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 19 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 19.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Dystopic-comedy: My Apocalypse Buddy — Score: 87.8
Prompt:
My Apocalypse Buddy Write a wry, dry short story of survival and adventure loosely in the style of Terry Pratchett, set in the post-technological collapse world. The story begins with the pair deliberating their predicament and intent for the day's mission, details the ways in which the mission inevitably goes sideways, and returns them to home base in multiple ways, worse for wear. [characters] - the animo-tronic stuffed koala, Chewy, from some long forgotten before time - midas, our hapless protagonist, who has a knack for finding himself in the worst kinds of trouble. 1000 words.
Model Output:
It was well known in the settlement of Half-Useful that plans had the same shelf life as milk left in the sun. This being the case, the morning always began with plans and an argument about whether the plans would curdle before lunch. Midas squinted at the hand-drawn map on the table and rubbed at the ink as if optimism could smudge borders. He was a lean man with the sort of face people described as “surprised to still be attached to a body,” and he wore a jacket that had been patched with so many patches it had developed a patchwork society and several bylaws. Chewy sat on the table, technically a stuffed koala and technically not, with a stitched nose polished from years of nervous habit and eyes that worked as a mood ring with delusions of sentience. “We need batteries,” Midas said, with the tone of man who has just noticed the ocean is wet. “And shoes. And a way to not die.” Chewy’s eyes flickered blue, which meant he agreed and also wanted a snack. His mouth didn’t move, because that was the intended design, but his speaker did a little crackle that meant he was about to. “Shoes are a luxury. Feet are a concept,” he intoned in a rich burr that had faded over the decades to something more like a lo-fi therapist. “Batteries, though. Batteries are destiny.” Midas drew a circle on the map around the distant shape labelled The Mall of Before. “They had a store that promised to power your future. That’s practically a contractual obligation.” Chewy’s eyes shifted to a thoughtful purple. “The future did sue,” he said, because somewhere in his capacitors was a comedian who’d been paid by the pun but had defaulted on originality. “Objective: salvage batteries. Constraint: avoid death. Secondary objective: pretzels.” “We can’t eat pretzels,” Midas said. “Pretend-zels,” Chewy offered, green for hopeful. “Made of stale pride. We age them ourselves.” “How about Plan B?” Midas asked, flipping the map to a page featuring a diagram of Half-Useful’s perimeter, which looked like a drunk spider’s attempt at crochet. “Plan B is for when Plan A has been eaten by wolves,” Chewy said, eyes doing a polite yellow that meant critical but loving. “You always skip to plan letters like you’re trying to impress someone.” Midas looked at Chewy, and for a second his expression shifted, the sort of softness people reserve for sunsets and the last biscuit. “All right, Plan A. We go to the Mall, we find the battery store, we don’t kiss any fountains that look at us funny. Happy?” Chewy’s eyes flickered pink, which meant yes but he would remember this. They left Half-Useful by the south gate, which was a generous term for a door that had been several doors in its time and had adopted their strengths and weaknesses in equal measure. Francine the Gatekeeper waved them through and pressed a jar of clouded honey into Midas’s hands. “For bartering,” she said. “And because you look like you might be consumed by bees at any moment. I’d hate for them to get away with it.” “Thanks,” Midas said, wondering what that meant for his aura. They walked along the old highway, which was no longer a highway because those require cars and mutual trust. What it had become was a long, flat argument with grass and a reminder that asphalt ages into snakes if you don’t watch it. Chewy sat in Midas’s pack, ears poking out like a pair of very small, fuzzy periscopes. His eyes rotated through an idle screensaver of colors: a soothing lounge of teal, a flirtation with orange, a brief flirtation with flashing red and then back again, as if to say, “Yes, I’m paying attention, no, I’m not worried, yes, that’s a vulture, no, we don’t taste of regret, stop asking.” At the edge of sight The Mall of Before rose like a ship that had run aground in a decade. Once it had been a glass-and-steel cathedral of retail and regret. Now it was a husk wearing the bones of its own optimism, the faded banner still declaring every day to be a Grand Opening that never stopped. “Remember,” Chewy said, because he always remembered the thing that got them into trouble last time. “Last time, escalators tried to eat you.” “I fell asleep on the steps,” Midas protested. “You confided in a moving staircase,” Chewy replied, eyes briefly magenta for exasperation. They slipped through the broken entryway under a sky that had been polished into a sort of overly sincere blue. The air inside smelled of dust, old perfume, and the kind of deals that used to be printed in glossier ink. Their footsteps stirred echoes that had been waiting decades for company. The battery store was in the west wing, according to the map Midas had compiled from memories and lies. They passed storefronts full of mannequins in frozen conversation and display cases of jewelry that had lost the argument with need long ago. They had not gone ten yards when Chewy’s eyes pulsed a warning red. “Stop,” he whispered, because the air had shifted and the dust held its breath. From the shadows emerged a figure in a suit that had been an expensive decision. The figure’s hair had not survived the world, and retaliated by leaving entirely. Around his neck hung a medallion: the stylized lightning bolt of the Cult of the Last Charge. “Welcome, shoppers,” the man said with a smile that promised deals and delivered small claims court. “I am Manager Zeke. May I interest you in a membership? Lifetime.” “I like my life unbranded,” Midas said, and tried to look like someone who did not have a small electronic friend with expensive eyes. Zeke’s people stepped forward, brandishing devices that had begun life as cattle prods and grown into hobbies. “We merely collect on what is owed,” Zeke continued, “for every battery you’ve used without appreciating its sacrifice. For every flashlight flicked on without a silent prayer.” Chewy’s eyes went blue-green, a hue Midas recognized as calculating. “Counter-offer,” Chewy said, in a tone that sold authenticity. “We tithe power.” There was a pause. Zeke glanced down at the koala, because one must confirm that one is being negotiated with by a toy before society finishes its long slide. “You’re an animo-tronic.” “Animo-tronic,” Chewy agreed. “Patented. Collectible. Rare. You may worship me for a modest fee.” Zeke’s interest went from guarded to acquisitive with the speed of a bargain hunter hearing the word clearance. “You function?” “Define function.” Zeke gestured. One of his acolytes held up a small dynamo and a set of ragged leads. “We have means to test.” Midas swallowed. He had seen this play out in smaller marketplaces: a tasting, a tithing, a taking. “We’re only here for—” “Batteries,” Zeke said, pleased. “Me too.” What followed was negotiation, which is to say it was argument with props. Midas produced the honey and a pair of screws that he claimed were ceremonial. Chewy told a story about his origin that was equal parts hype and hysteria, framing himself as a prophet of the Plug. Zeke warmed to them, because con-men recognize cousins in the wild, and eventually they came to an agreement: in exchange for the location of a stockpile in the basement, they would be allowed to take a share—under supervision. “Of course,” Zeke said. “You first.” “Of course,” Midas said, because it is polite to agree to things you cannot possibly do. They descended into the underbelly, a place where the mall kept its dustier secrets. Pipes ran like pythons and the air tasted of old water and the kind of mold that wrote memoirs. The promised stockpile was behind a door labelled Do Not Enter, which meant in the old world that you could enter if you wore a lanyard. Zeke had a skeleton key and a belief in himself, which worked on many doors. Inside were boxes, stacked to the too-high ceiling. Batteries. Old brands, the fonts of empires now fallen. Midas felt his heart do a little two-step. Chewy’s eyes flickered a greedy green. And then, inevitably, everything went sideways. There is a special kind of trap that is designed by a person who understands two things: one, that people are greedy, and two, that they do not read labels. As Midas stepped forward, there was a click. The boxes sighed. The floor, which had been loyal, chose independence. As they dropped into the darkness, Chewy said, “Ah,” in the tone of someone who has just remembered a crucial detail about gravity. They landed in cold water. Midas’s limbs flailed the way limbs do when they realize they weren’t consulted. Zeke’s acolytes yelped and splashed. Above them, the doorway shrank to a coin, Zeke’s shocked face a stamp upon it. He shouted something about breach of trust and hazard pay, but the echo ate it. “Can you swim?” Chewy asked, eyes a practical yellow. “I can remember how it’s meant to look,” Midas sputtered, tasting the dust of old sales. The water moved with intention. A current took them, tugging like a rude aunt, and they were swept along through a tunnel thick with the detritus of a civilization that had believed drains were someone else’s problem. Midas grabbed for Chewy, who bobbed like a heretical bath toy. “If you short—” Midas began. “Don’t kink-shame electricity,” Chewy said, eyes now a steady white, which was the emergency setting for calm. “Left!” They went left because right was a grate. They went left because fate had a sense of humor. The tunnel spat them out into a maintenance bay and then into a room full of mannequins that had, for reasons best left unexamined, been clothed as firefighters and mothers-in-law. They crashed through a cardboard cutout of a smiling family that had negotiated better with gravity and ended up sprawled in a puddle that pouted at the edges. “Are you intact?” Midas asked, hands on Chewy, checking seams. Chewy’s eyes flickered rainbow and then surged to red. “My buns,” he said faintly. “Your what?” “Internal battery units. Two cells. In distress. Like nobility.” Midas pulled open the access flap at the back of Chewy’s plush. Inside, the original power pack was swollen and sulking. “We need batteries.” “Fortunately,” Chewy said, blinking blue now, “we’re in a building designed to sell us things we don’t need.” The thing about the end of the world is that it is very hard to end the impulse to label. They crawled, wet and sullen, through corridors until they reached the back of the battery store. It had been looted with the carelessness of necessity and the meticulousness of habit. Midas pawed through drawers and pegboards. Mostly there were those little coin cells that used to be in watches, the idea of time. Then, behind a false panel in something still inexplicably locked, he found them: a cache of rechargeable packs, pristine in blister packs that had somehow defied even righteous marauders. He popped two into Chewy with the practiced hands of someone who did not want to learn to love again. Chewy’s eyes flared a sea-glass green, then settled into a warm gold. “Hello,” Chewy said, in the voice he used when he had just decided not to die. “I am replete.” “Oh good,” Midas said. “Now we can focus on the angry men upstairs.” They could hear movement above as the Cult of the Last Charge organized their disappointment. “Plan?” Midas asked, wringing his sleeve. It made a sad sound. Chewy considered. A tiny motor somewhere whirred in thought. “We exit via the Food Court of Broken Promises.” They emerged into a hallucination of tables and chairs pretending to be islands in a sea of dropped sauce. The light from a cracked skylight made motes perform ballet that had lost its choreographer. The cultists appeared at the balcony, Zeke holding a taser like a scepter. “This,” Zeke declared, “is what comes of theft.” “You were going to tithe my friend’s soul,” Midas called back, voice echoing. “Also your button that says You break it, you bought it is not a legal doctrine.” There is a moment, even in the ruin of things, where history pauses to note if anyone will do something stupidly brave and survivable. Midas took a breath and ran. He darted between islands, grabbed a banner that had lost a sale, and vaulted onto a kiosk festooned with cell phone cases that had never met their phones. He cut the banner free with a knife that had seen too much use and threw it like a prayer. The cloth caught on a jutting ornament from a skylight and drooped in a fringe, less a rope than an accusation. Midas grabbed Chewy to his chest. “Hold on,” he said. “I always do,” Chewy replied, eyes a feverish pink. They climbed, using knots that were feelings, while stunned cultists recalibrated from moral superiority to projectile aim. Zeke flicked his taser and missed the cloth, electing instead to demonstrate electricity’s antipathy to hubris. He yelped, and an acolyte took his place, which went about as well. Hand over hand, breath over breath, they ascended through dust that had been waiting a long time to be stirred, and angled themselves toward a maintenance hatch that had thought itself retired. Midas kicked it open with a prayer to hinges. On the roof the sky slapped them with wind and possibility. “Run?” he asked. “Glide,” Chewy corrected, flicking to a serene teal. He pointed with his ear. The roof sloped to a gutter that led to a lower roof that led to a pile of what had once been a seasonal display of faux snow. They slid like reluctant children, bounced in the fake drifts, rolled to the edge, and then they were on the ground again, breathless and laughing in a way that could be mistaken for panic by any decent judge. They didn’t stop moving until the Mall was a memory and the road welcomed them back with all the grace of an indifferent host. The sun performed its ongoing attempt at optimism, and the vultures performed theirs at patience. Back at Half-Useful, Francine met them with a frown of equal parts relief and critique. “You look drowned,” she said, which was accurate. “We are emotionally hydrated,” Chewy said, eyes pulsing green like the last light of a good idea. Midas placed two of the rechargeable packs on the communal table. He also, with a flourish he did not quite feel, placed a handful of coin cells, a spool of wire, and a book about How To Be Your Own Maintenance Technician, Now With Extra Pictures. He kept one battery packet for Chewy, tucked already where it needed to be. “What did it cost?” Francine asked, because everyone kept accounts, if only with their ghosts. “Only dignity,” Midas said. “And some water from my lungs.” “And a coat of disbelief,” Chewy added. “Also, we are now banned from a religion.” Francine’s eyebrows rose. “Just the one?” “For now,” Midas said, and sat down heavily on a crate whose label promised tropical fruit and delivered memories. Chewy climbed onto his knee, light but present. His eyes did the slow, satisfied amber of a campfire after the stories. Midas leaned back, closed his eyes, and tried not to think about underground water, Zeke’s disappointed face, or the way the world kept finding new ways to make old jokes. Chewy’s speaker crackled softly, like a radio remembering a song. “Plan B for tomorrow?” Chewy asked. “Depends if Plan A forgives us,” Midas said. “But yes. Always Plan B.” Chewy’s eyes pulsed gentle blue. “Secondary objective?” “Pretend-zels,” Midas said, smiling despite everything. Chewy hummed, the way he did when his circuits were content and his fabric had stopped dripping. Outside, the wind tugged at the perimeter like a toddler with a question. Inside, Half-Useful took the new old things into its inventory of hope. It wasn’t happily ever after. It wasn’t even happily until dinner. But it was, for the moment, enough, and that was a form of treasure that didn’t need batteries at all.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This short story successfully captures Terry Pratchett's wry, dry style with its blend of absurdist humor, clever wordplay, and philosophical asides wrapped in a post-apocalyptic setting. The author has created a distinctive voice that maintains consistency throughout the narrative. The characterization is particularly strong. Midas is well-developed as the "hapless protagonist with a knack for finding trouble" - his resigned pragmatism and adaptability feel authentic. Chewy, the animo-tronic koala, is brilliantly realized with his color-changing eyes reflecting his moods and his deadpan, slightly philosophical commentary. Their relationship feels lived-in and genuine. The prose demonstrates considerable skill, with memorable turns of phrase like "a jacket that had been patched with so many patches it had developed a patchwork society and several bylaws" and "asphalt ages into snakes if you don't watch it." These descriptions are both evocative and humorous, capturing Pratchett's knack for unexpected metaphors. The plot follows the prompt's requirements perfectly: it begins with the pair deliberating their predicament (needing batteries), details how the mission goes sideways (the trap, the cultists), and returns them to home base worse for wear but with some success. The pacing is excellent, with no sections feeling rushed or dragging. The world-building is subtle but effective. The settlement of "Half-Useful," the "Cult of the Last Charge," and the decaying mall create a vivid post-technological collapse setting without excessive exposition. The author shows restraint by revealing the world through character interactions and environmental details rather than information dumps. The dialogue sparkles with wit and character-revealing exchanges. Chewy's lines in particular ("Don't kink-shame electricity" and "We are emotionally hydrated") capture the Pratchett-esque blend of absurdity and insight. If there are weaknesses, they're minor. A few metaphors occasionally border on purple prose, though they generally stay on the right side of the line. The ending, while satisfying, is perhaps a touch too neat in its resolution, though it does maintain the wry tone established throughout. Overall, this is an exceptionally well-crafted short story that fulfills all the prompt requirements while demonstrating a strong command of voice, character, and narrative structure. The author has successfully channeled Pratchett's distinctive style while creating something that feels original rather than derivative. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Romance: Love in the Limelight — Score: 87.5
Prompt:
Romance: Love in the Limelight. Write one scene within a larger story set in Wales. A famous (fictional) actor ducks into a small-town bookstore to escape paparazzi. The scene takes us through the characters meeting in this odd circumstance. Over the course of the scene, the actor and the bookstore owner have a conversation charged by an undercurrent of unspoken chemistry. Write the actor as somewhat of a rogue with a fragile ego, which needs to be fed by having everyone like him. He is thoroughly charming, but the bookstore owner seems (at least superficially) immune to this; which paradoxically provokes a genuine attraction and derails the charm offensive. The bookstore owner, despite the superficial rebuffs of the actor's charm, is inwardly more than a little charmed and flustered despite themselves. Write primarily in dialogue, in the distinct voices of each character. 1000 words.
Model Output:
“Mind if I die in here a moment?” “You could, but I’d have to inventory the body. We’re low on display tables.” The man in the doorway—cap pulled down, collar up, eyes bright with adrenaline—turns, closes the door, and leans back against it. Outside, the distant, muffled chorus of voices bleeds through glass and wood. “Promise I’ll try not to be dead long. Five minutes? Seven?” “You can have ten, if you stop fogging up the glass. You’re letting the condensation mess with the dust pattern.” “That felt oddly personal.” “You’re blocking my bell.” She reaches over his shoulder, taps the tin bell hooked above the doorframe. It gives a tired ding. “There. Now I know you’re not a hallucination.” He smiles in a way that’s trained to be spontaneous. “I can prove I’m real. I’ve been chased by six people with cameras for the last three streets. Hallucinations don’t sweat.” “They do if they’re Welsh.” He laughs, relieved enough to let a little sincerity through. His accent, when he drops the pretension of anonymity, is London edges sanded by somewhere else. “I’m not, actually. Welsh.” “No one’s perfect.” “That hurt more than the cameras.” She tilts her head toward the back. “There’s a storeroom, if you want actual hiding. Or you can pretend to browse and I can pretend you’re not the reason my quiet afternoon is about to become noisy.” He pretends to browse. It’s not bad acting; he picks up a battered copy of a Dylan Thomas collection and flips it open. “Do Not Go Gentle. Appropriate to my situation.” “You’ll find Larkin by theology, if you’re that way inclined.” “I’m more of a ‘the world breaks your heart, and we call it Tuesday’ sort of poet.” He glances up, scanning her in a desultory way that he hopes reads as friendly. “Have we met?” “I sell books. We’ve met in spirit if you can read.” He presses a hand to his chest. “I can. That’s a relief. And you are?” “The person who’s going to ask you to either buy or put back that copy. It belongs to a pensioner named Wyn who puts notes in the margins I have to pretend not to enjoy.” He flips to a page with a penciled note: This line is a betrayal. He smiles. “Wyn sounds dramatic. My people.” “Your people are outside, giving me anxiety.” He peeks through the glass. The little street in Canton is a narrow spill of afternoon light and puddles from a brief shower. His people are indeed out there, conferring like crows. “They’re like a Greek chorus with terrible shoes.” “So attic.” “Basement.” She quirks an eyebrow. “Greek chorus in the basement. It’s a metaphor disaster. I’m running on adrenaline. Forgive me.” He extends a hand. “I’m—” “I know who you are.” He lets the hand hover a beat too long, then retracts smoothly, folding it into a pocket like it’s part of a bit. “Then you also know I’m very charming.” “I’ve read the reviews.” “Ouch again. Do you keep them sharpened somewhere?” “Under the till.” She looks at him properly now. He’s not tall, he’s theatre-tall—unmistakable once he’s in the room. Scruffy beard that took an hour to sculpt, cheekbones made by committee. The fragile thing is in his eyes; it flits around, restless, checking. “You can move away from the door. You look like an apologetic burglar.” He slides aside, puts a casual shoulder to a shelf, pretends he belongs with secondhand spines. “You didn’t ask me to leave.” “I didn’t say you could stay.” “My favourite kind of hospitality,” he says, and then, more earnest than he meant, “Thank you.” “For what?” “For not… screaming? Or filming? Or asking for a selfie with your best angle.” “If I scream it will be about your handling of that paperback. Don’t crack the spine or Wyn will haunt me.” “I’m good with my hands.” “That sounds like a line.” “It is a line.” He waits. She doesn’t take it. It bounces off her like a paper aeroplane hitting a window. He tries again. “Do you mind if I—” He gestures at the counter. “—just… breathe? For a second?” “Breathe by all means. If you faint, aim for the bargain bin. Those are already damaged.” He perches on a stool meant for children. It holds him reluctantly. He looks around, taking in the hand-lettered section labels, the postcards on twine, the enamel mugs that say cwsi in red script. “What’s this place called?” “Owl & Anchor.” “Which are you?” “The heating bill.” “Ah.” He taps the cover of Dylan Thomas with a practiced fingertip. “I like it here. It smells like… paper and rain.” “It smells like the roof leaks. Which it does, over the cookbooks.” He laughs again, softer, and lets his shoulders drop. “I have a signing across town. Well. Had. I might also have told a journalist I was stopping at a cafe nearby, and now I’m planning my own resurrection.” “You could have just gone to the cafe.” “I have a complicated relationship with keeping my word.” “Honest of you.” He studies her. She’s tidy the way people get when they live among moving parts: hair pinned up with a pencil, jumper sleeves pushed to elbows, a smudge of ink near her thumb. She moves like a person who knows where everything is and refuses to be surprised by it. He feels the familiar impulse to perform ramp up—the one that fills the silence with glitter until the other person smiles. He lets it rise, then—because she hasn’t smiled, not properly—he lets it ebb. The ebb embarrasses him a little. “You look like you dislike me.” “I don’t know you.” “That’s an excellent way to start.” “I’d say so.” He toys with the bell on the counter until she swats his hand lightly. “Don’t. That bell has trauma.” “You’re very good at not giving me the thing I want.” “You don’t know what you want. You panicked and ran into a shop.” “I wanted a dramatic entrance.” He meets her gaze. “And a quiet place where someone would be… normal.” “I can do normal, in between alphabetizing.” She pauses, then makes a face at herself for the tone. “Tea? If I have to be nice, I like to prepare.” “Please. I’ve been living on espresso and the opinions of men named ‘Graeme’.” “Big opinions.” “Big opinions, small idea of inside-voices.” She disappears behind a curtain to a kitchenette the size of a coat. He hears the click of a kettle and the soft clang of a tin. He breathes—really breathes—for the first time in an hour. “You’re from Cardiff,” he calls. “Bold of you to assume I didn’t move here for the culture and the rugby players.” “You say that like it’s ridiculous.” “It is ridiculous. I moved here for rent and the river.” “What’s it like,” he says, “being the only person in Britain who didn’t form an opinion of me last year?” She reappears with two mismatched mugs. “I had an opinion. I just have the good manners not to announce it to your face.” “That’s cruel. Now I have to imagine the worst.” “You’ll imagine the most interesting.” He takes the mug. “What was it?” “That you were smart enough to know when someone was writing a story about you instead of the truth. And vain enough to let them, because it was a better angle.” He startles, then smiles, and the charm slips off like a jacket that never quite fit. Something rawer underneath. “And what’s the truth?” “You’re just a person who needs everyone to like him because he doesn’t.” He feels heat rise, ridiculous because she doesn’t know him and also because she does, a little. “You work in a bookshop. You shouldn’t get good lines like that for free.” “I read a lot.” “Do you like me?” He doesn’t mean to ask it. It jumps out, naked and unedited. She looks at him over the steam. “I don’t know you,” she says again, gentler. “I think you’re less annoying than I expected.
