The first few degrees are nothing. Then my glute med wakes in a small, stubborn fire along the lateral posterior hip. My pelvis tries to tilt. His palm resists, a steady wall. The tension is specific, clean. I lower and lift, lower and lift. By the tenth, the burn is real. My breathing gets loud in the quiet room. Lavender swirls. The diffuser hums. “Good,” he says. His voice betrays nothing, but his eyes flick to my face, away, back. “Two more.” On the twelfth, my hip shakes. He moves his hand to the front of my thigh, pads of his fingers finding the TFL. “Don’t let this guy steal,” he murmurs. The touch is informational. My body doesn’t care. Heat blooms low and insistent, separate from the muscle burn, humiliating in its simplicity. I clamp my jaw and finish the rep. He helps me roll onto my back again with a hand under my scapula, a brief, incidental slide over the curve of my ribs. We both pretend it wasn’t anything. He props my right heel on a slider disc. “Hamstring eccentrics,” he says. “Bend your left knee, plant that foot. Lift your hips into a bridge. Now slowly extend your right knee, sliding the heel away, keeping your pelvis level. Only go as far as you can control, then pull back.” “Worse than suicides,” I mutter. He smiles—small, involuntary. It lands in my chest like a thrown pebble, ripples expanding. I bridge. The glutes fire; the hamstrings seize—old friends turned unreliable. I slide the right heel out. At the midpoint, the hamstring on the injured side lights up, a hot wire taut under the skin. My pelvis tries to sag on the right. His hand finds my ASIS, two fingers on each hip bone, and levels me with the gentlest pressure, a physical cue that sends a direct line to muscles that listen better than my mind. I keep the pelvis level. I go an inch farther. The burn is intense, but it’s the right kind of pain—demanding, focused, contained. I pull back. The hamstring protests in a flurry of tremors. He doesn’t let me drop my hips until the heel comes home. “Two more,” he says. On the second, my right foot cramps. My toes curl. He catches it with a quick adjustment, drawing my toes toward me to open the arch, thumb pressing into the flexor hallucis brevis with a practiced roll. The cramp releases like a fist unclenching. Relief floods. I swallow a sound. He steps back finally, hands on his hips, and I feel the absence of him like cold air. The room is just a room again. The lavender is just a scent again. I stare at the ceiling tile seam until it stops shifting. “You’re stronger than last week,” he says. “Your control’s better.” I want to say I don’t care. That control doesn’t put me back on a track with a gun in the air and a lane under my feet. I want to say he betrayed our unspoken pact by leaving and becoming this—steady hands, patient voice, someone who knows exactly where to touch to make my body obey and refuses to use it for anything but fixing me. I want to say I hate the way that makes me want him more. “Great,” I say instead, flat. He hands me a band. “Home program. Terminal extensions, clamshells, heel slides. Three sets. Within pain limits. And—” “And ice,” I finish. “Elevation. Tell me to sleep and drink water. Tell me to breathe.” His mouth lifts at one corner. “Breathe,” he says. Then, softer, “You don’t have to like this. You just have to do it.” The words skitter along my nerves. He steps close again, and for a moment we are back there—with starting blocks and chalked lines—but everything is different. He reaches past me to adjust the strap hanging on the wall, his shoulder brushing my cheek. We both still, a lurch in the machine. “Same time next week?” he asks. His voice is steady but not entirely even. I nod, a jerky hinge. My knee throbs in a slow, righteous pulse. My skin remembers his hands. The lavender sinks into the back of my throat and the clinical brightness of the room sharpens to a point. The door opens with a soft click when he touches it. I hop down carefully, test the leg. It holds, quivering. He watches for a beat, professional, attentive, infuriating. Attractive. “Text if it swells more than usual,” he says. “Or if the pain goes sharp. Midline is okay; joint line catching is not.” “I know my lines,” I say, and hear what I didn’t mean. His eyes meet mine. We both look away, almost in the same breath. In the hallway, the world smells like coffee and copier paper. My knee feels like a storm contained in glass. I tuck the band into my bag, the plastic cold against my palm, and tell myself that the ache I carry out with me is just tissue healing in the invisible dark, not something bigger, messier, something I can’t rehab my way out of. I tell myself I’ll do the exercises. I tell myself I won’t think about his hands. The lavender ghost follows me home.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative effectively captures the complex dynamics between a former professional athlete and their physiotherapist. The piece excels in its anatomical precision and physical coherence, meticulously detailing each therapeutic technique with clinical accuracy while simultaneously conveying the emotional and sexual tension between the characters. The protagonist's resentment toward recovery is palpable throughout. Lines like "Now pain is a locked door I keep slamming my head against" effectively communicate their frustration with their changed circumstances. The narrative skillfully contrasts their former athletic identity with their current diminished physical state, creating a compelling psychological portrait. The physiotherapist is portrayed with nuance - professional yet human, maintaining boundaries while clearly affected by their shared history. The sexual tension is handled with subtlety and restraint, conveyed through small details like "His fingers are warm through the thin fabric of my shorts" and "Heat blooms low and insistent, separate from the muscle burn, humiliating in its simplicity." The sensory details are particularly strong. The writer creates a vivid physical environment through descriptions of smells (lavender, antiseptic), textures, and the precise sensations of pain and touch. The physical therapy session is rendered with exceptional clarity - each movement, stretch, and manipulation is anatomically precise and spatially consistent. The prose style balances clinical precision with emotional resonance. Sentences like "The joint line is warm under his touch" and "The lavender ghost follows me home" demonstrate the writer's ability to shift between technical description and evocative imagery. The narrative maintains a consistent voice throughout - terse, observant, and emotionally guarded, reflecting the protagonist's state of mind. The piece avoids melodrama while still conveying deep emotional currents. The protagonist's complex feelings - resentment, attraction, grief for their lost career - are conveyed through subtext rather than explicit statements. The ending effectively maintains the tension established throughout, avoiding easy resolution while suggesting the ongoing nature of both the physical therapy and the emotional struggle. There are no significant weaknesses in this piece. It successfully fulfills all the requirements of the prompt, creating a physically coherent, emotionally resonant narrative that explores the complex dynamics between the characters while maintaining focus on the physical therapy session. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20 Elegant Prose: 19 Emotionally Engaging: 19 Emotionally Complex: 19 Coherent: 20 Meandering: 2 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 1 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20.0, Elegant Prose: 19.0, Emotionally Engaging: 19.0, Emotionally Complex: 19.0, Coherent: 20.0, Meandering: 2.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 1.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Historical fiction: High Seas and Low Vices — Score: 95.0
Prompt:
High Seas and Low Vices: British Naval Officer in the Opium Trade Character: Lieutenant James Merrick, a high-ranking officer in the British Royal Navy stationed in Canton, China in the 1830s. Once promising and decorated, now struggling with a severe opium addiction he hides from his superiors. Synopsis: Write a chapter following Lieutenant Merrick during a single day as he shirks his official naval duties in what has become a daily need to satiate the dragon. Told primarily in dialogue with the characters he interacts with. Focus on brief slices of his journey through the shadowy underworld of Canton: interactions with acquaintances, negotiations with local dealers, schemes and unsavoury jobs taken to fund his habit. Writing Task: Use rich sensory details to describe a day in the life of James Merrick. Write for a real sense of time & place while avoiding cliche. First person, past tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
They banged the warning drum before dawn—three hollow strikes rolling over the Pearl like stones thrown down a well—and I told my orderly I had a fever. He eyed the damp of my shirtsleeve and the tremor at the corner of my mouth and said, “Yes, sir,” like a prayer he didn’t believe, and left me to the heat trapped under the mosquito net. By seven, the yard bawled the order of the day. The ship’s blisters—the marines—filed ashore in red that caught the light. I looked down from my balcony at the parade of hats and pikes and thought how clean their boots were. I was supposed to inspect the aft magazine, take the tally of powder casks, sign the papers. “Later,” I told the sun. It climbed anyway, slow as a judge. My dressing was a dumb negotiation with buttons. I managed enough uniform to pass through the gate without comment: coat, loose cravat, hat tilted low. On the stairs I met Mr. Hudson, our lieutenant of marines, triangular face all angles and chapbook courage. “Merrick,” he said, pausing two steps above, breath smelling of chalk and boiled tea. “You’ve missed muster twice this week. Captain’s in a pet about the manifests.” “Paper can wait,” I said. “Powder can’t run away.” He looked at my eyes, and I watched him choose not to see. “Inspection at four. Don’t be late.” He went down with that precise soldier’s clatter, each heel like a nail tapped in. I slipped through the back. The quartermaster’s boy followed me to the alley gate with a ledger in his hands. “Sir, Mr. Paget says if you’d sign—” “In the afternoon,” I said, pressing a coin into his palm. He looked at the coin and I looked at the boy’s wrist, black with ink, and the August sun spilled heat like a kettle. The alley received me like a throat—narrow, wet, secret. The scent that lived there pressed against the nostrils: rotting mangoes stacked in shallow baskets, their skins blistered and collapsing, soursweet and rank. The flies were a kingdom. They lifted off the fruit in a low humming sheet when a woman waved her palm-leaf fan. “Mister. Good mango,” she hissed. I shook my head. The city wobbled between wood and brick, lintels carved with peonies already grey with soot. Lanterns under awnings, faces behind cotton veils, a river of syllables. “Gaai si,” someone shouted—a curse. Again, the mango’s sweetness knifed under the fish-stall tang, under the piss in the gutter and the incense from a god-shelf where a paper-eyed warrior watched the indifferent procession of rats. “Lieutenant.” A familiar voice, English strained through ale. Patrick Byrne stepped from a doorway with his shirt half-laced. Irish by birth, Canton by appetite, his beard stiff with last night’s smoke. “You’ve a morning face.” “I’m looking for Huang,” I said, not offering apology and not taking any. “He owes me.” “You owe him, more like,” he said, grinning without teeth on the left side. “But he’s at the Peacock. Or will be when the shade reaches the threshold.” “Then I’ll wait there.” “You’ll buy there,” he said, putting a hand on my sleeve. “Bring money, James.” “Don’t use my name.” He lifted both hands, palms out. “A joke, a joke. God keep you in good health.” He stepped back and whispered, “Avoid Inspector Po’s men by the fish market. New sweeps today. Loud drums, unlucky.” The Peacock’s sign was a painted bird with flaking blue plumage. Inside was all vertical wood and dust motes, a long table pressed with tea cups, the slow scrape of chairs left to their own thoughts. Magdalene—the proprietress—had eyes like polished stone. She wore blue cotton and an iron bangle. “Mr. Officer,” she said, mocking the honorific as she poured. “Yes?” “A pipe,” I said, touching my hat. “Tea as well.” She brought me hot iron-in-brown tea and a look that was sharper than any blade I carried. She set the pipe down, her thumb sliding along the reed, not giving it to me, just letting the possibility sit between us like another customer. “You pay last time?” she asked. “Last time I saved your cousin from the press-gang,” I said. “I stood in a doorway and told a sergeant he’d miscounted. I took his tally-stick and broke it.” “Press-gang is a story,” she said flatly. “You owe three taels.” “I have an account,” I lied. “Your account is a ghost,” she said. “It eats and eats, never pays, and still it sits at my table.” The tea burned a path down my throat, a warm lie. I set the cup down and counted out silver until it stung. She watched my hands with a bored pity. From the corner, a boy in a brown vest told the room, “Inspector Po’s at the quay. Two men taken at the red door.” “There,” Magdalene said lightly, “you see? Hungry ghosts.” I waited, and the day threw heat down into the room. In came sailors in shirts with unwound necks, an American factor with violin fingers, a Cantonese clerk with ink-blackened nails and a watch pinned to his belt. The world leaned on elbows and watched the doorway. The mango-sweet rot came in gusts when someone brushed the curtain. Huang arrived late and smiling, wearing a birdcage ring on his middle finger. He smelled of tobacco and camphor oil, and his hair was slicked back with something that gave it a wet sheen without water. He raised two fingers at Magdalene, and she brought him rice. Then he turned to me. “Lieutenant Merrick,” he said, pronouncing the Rs with care. “This is a surprise.” “We had an agreement,” I said. “We had a conversation,” he corrected. He took a mouthful, chewed, and stared at the table as if it had the next line. “You English with your tall hats and small patience. What do you want?” “You know what I want.” He looked at my sleeves. He looked at the sweat that had made a tide-line along my collar. He took a breath and smelled it: the desperation, the fear that came disguised as command. “Ah,” he said softly. “The dragon in your chest talks loud today.” “We had an agreement,” I said again, because repetition made a shaky thing sound solid. “A consignment is due.” “With respect,” he said, “I don’t sell to men who owe me money.” “I don’t owe—” “You owe everybody,” he said without malice. He set down his bowl. “Captain Po is taking names. I sell you today, I lose you tomorrow. Your officers will pretend they never knew your face. You will go to a place where walls are made of bamboo and men forget their own names.” He lifted his hand and made a passable impression of my signature, the one I’d scrawled on so many platters to make them official. “I am not a fool.” Magdalene put down the pipe in front of me like she was laying out a knife. “You have coin?” she asked again. I reached into my coat and brought out a polished brass telescope, compact enough to fit a captain’s pocket, engraved with a name that was not mine. I set it on the table. “This.” Huang ran a thumb across the engraving. “Paget,” he read. He smiled without showing teeth. “Quartermaster Paget will be upset.” “He won’t be,” I said. “Not today.” “You trade honor for smoke,” he said. He nodded to Magdalene, who took the telescope with a proprietary hum. “You will pay more later. You always pay more later.” I looked at the reed, at the blue-glazed bowl, at the dampened wad of tobacco and the black stone where the pellet would go. The anticipation had a taste like tin. The rot-sugar smell in the doorway grew louder in my head. I could not tell where the alley ended and my blood began. “Come,” Huang said, weary as a teacher. He rose. “Not here. Too many eyes.” We went through the innards of the Peacock: a passage of bamboo cages with sleeping men who might have been dead, a kitchen where a girl in a red blouse chopped ginger, the knife knocking its own clock. Out the back, onto a footbridge, the boards underfoot flexing like a ribcage. The canal beneath was thick and green, like looking into a bottle of medicine. Children’s feet slapped the path; a cat watched me as if waiting for a command. “Careful,” Huang said, bored. “Your nice shoe.” “My shoes are not nice,” I said, and he laughed. We reached the den by way of an alley bulging with baskets of mangoes left too long in the sun. They made a smell you could put your hand into: bloated, sugared, half-fermented. A boy watched over them, nose slick, and every now and then pinched one to see if it would split. He winked at me. “Gweilo,” he said, but without malice. Demon, foreign ghost. I nodded like we shared a joke. Inside the den, the light surrendered. It bled in from a high hole in the wall and made a square on the matting where dust danced, slow partners at a court. The cough that lived in those rooms was ceaseless and specific, as if it belonged to the building. A woman with a freckled face lifted her head and said, “James,” in the voice of an older sister. Her name was Sarah once, and now it was something else. I stepped over two men and sat at a couch that remembered my bones. Huang prepared a long needle of a pipe, the porcelain bowl stained like an old tooth. He held the pellet close to the lamp’s flame, working it with a flattened stick, the resin softening, bubbling, sighing. He was meticulous, precise as a clerk. He passed the reed to me when the vapor rose like the beginning of speech. “Slow,” he murmured. “You always try to outrun it.” “I have duties,” I said, taking breath. He laughed. The first vapor met me in the chest and spread like warmed oil. For a moment, the mango rot and the urine-stink and the heavy breath of other men pulled back. The world was a simple list: breath in, breath out, the skin behind my knees, the taste of copper. The ache in the joints lifted its hand and asked to be excused. “You make me a promise,” Huang said, turning a pellet with his stick. “Tonight you do what you must. You come with me to the river. There is a crate at the French mission. You help me bring it.” “I—” I began. “No argument,” he said, friendly. “Or next time Magdalene takes your boots for payment. Then you are a barefoot lieutenant. Very funny.” Sarah leaned on her elbow. “They took Tom,” she said, as if we were at tea and the weather had turned. “Inspector Po. They took him by his collar, like a dog.” She tilted her head. “He screamed and screamed, and then he didn’t.” “I told you,” Huang said, not unkind. “Po has a list. Many lists. He is learning to read the names in your script.” “I’ll help tonight,” I said. The smoke arranged my words into something that sounded like courage. “What time?” “When the bell at the east tower says eight,” he said. “Bring your uniform. The gate likes to see it.” We sat in the dark womb of the den, and the hours took off their shoes and crept past. The lamp burned low, the resin hissed and pulled back and hissed again. The cough and the sigh and the sometimes-laugh. I thought of the hold of the ship, the square chalk marks, the way Mr. Paget licked his finger before turning a page. I thought of Hudson’s angle-face. I thought of our captain’s neat hands and the blue vein that ran in a true line along his temple. At some point, my head lolled and I startled as if I’d heard my name. “Wake-up time,” Huang said mildly. “You must be a soldier again.” “I was never a soldier,” I said, but I stood. My legs were filled with water. The alleys called to me again, that fruit-sick perfume and the stickiness underfoot. Outside the den, the light stabbed. I squinted. The mango boy had cut one open, and the yellow flesh bled down his wrist. He licked his arm with unabashed veneration. “Lieutenant,” he said, imitating a sergeant’s bark. He saluted me with the fruit-knife. I saluted back before I remembered what a joke it was. By the time I’d made it to the quay, the bell had struck four. Hudson waited on the planks, the river making a loud shushing, as if it could hush every sin in Honam. “Where have you been?” he asked, and it was not really a question. “Accounts,” I said. “You stink,” he said, and his nose flinched. “God’s sake, James.” “It’s the market,” I said. “The fruit.” He stared at me a long time. A junk went past, its square sail patched with cloth of three colours. A boy on the prow spat into the river and laughed when it flew back into his face. Hudson rubbed his jaw. He said, “Be at the magazine at six. The captain expects your signature. And your mind. Both, if you can manage it.” At six, I stared at casks and saw drums of water and thought of the dens that had no windows. Paget flapped the manifest. “Sir?” he asked. “We must be quick before the tide turns.” “Yes,” I said, and let my hand drag the pen along the paper, making my name like I was a man who had one. The ink bled. The lines crossed where they shouldn’t. I was two places at once. At eight, I walked with Huang along the river. The night had a wet cloth in its throat. The mission’s cross made an X against a slice of moon. We lifted a crate so heavy it felt like dishonesty, and he said, “You are strong in the wrong places.” “Story of my life,” I said, and we both smiled because it was not funny. We stowed the crate on a sampan. A girl with a lotus tattoo on her ankle pushed us off with one foot. The river licked the wood like a cat. Lanterns hummed with moths, tiny bodies at the mercy of their light. Inspector Po’s men had drummed all day and now slept in their coats. “You will be paid,” Huang said, as if it were a kindness. “Not enough. Never enough.” “I know,” I said. He made the pipe ready on the low deck, in deference to our labour. The mango smell had become threaded through with the perfume of night-blooming jasmine from some ignorant garden, and for a moment the two scents shook hands and told a polite lie about the world. I took the reed, drew, and watched the mission’s cross grow soft at the edges. “Tomorrow?” he asked. “Tomorrow,” I said, because in Canton tomorrow was a thing you could borrow, if you had the nerve. He laughed like someone who had heard the joke already. The river carried us between dark hulls and the red backs of sleeping fish. Somewhere behind me, the drums tapped again—hollow, patient—measuring a day I had spent like coin. I felt the ghost of the telescope’s weight in my pocket and reached for it before remembering it was gone. My hand closed on air. Above us, the sky had no compass. The scent of rotting mangoes hung in the wet night like a vow I kept and broke with every breath.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece is a remarkable achievement in historical fiction, creating a vivid portrait of a British naval officer's opium addiction in 1830s Canton. The writing excels in sensory immersion, historical authenticity, and psychological depth. The prose is exceptionally strong, with a distinctive voice that maintains consistency throughout. The author employs sensory details masterfully, particularly the recurring motif of rotting mangoes that becomes a metaphor for Merrick's moral decay. Phrases like "the mango smell had become threaded through with the perfume of night-blooming jasmine from some ignorant garden" demonstrate sophisticated imagery that serves both aesthetic and thematic purposes. The dialogue is particularly impressive. Each character has a distinct voice that reflects their background and relationship to Merrick. Huang's careful pronunciation of English "Rs" and his philosophical observations about Merrick's addiction show careful attention to characterization through speech patterns. The dialogue advances the plot while revealing character and never feels expository. The piece excels at "showing" rather than "telling." We understand Merrick's addiction through physical details: "the damp of my shirtsleeve and the tremor at the corner of my mouth," "My dressing was a dumb negotiation with buttons," and Hudson's observation that "You stink." The author trusts readers to infer Merrick's deterioration rather than explicitly stating it. The narrative structure is cohesive, following Merrick through a single day as requested, with clear time markers ("By seven," "At six," "At eight") that create a sense of inexorable progression. The piece avoids meandering by maintaining focus on Merrick's quest for opium while incorporating meaningful interactions that reveal his character and situation. The historical setting feels authentic without relying on clichés. Details like the "press-gang," Inspector Po's list of names, and the French mission create a credible colonial-era Canton. The author incorporates Cantonese phrases naturally ("Gaai si," "Gweilo") without exoticizing the setting. The character of Merrick is complex and believable. His addiction has corrupted his sense of duty and honor, yet he maintains awareness of his degradation. His theft of the telescope and agreement to help smuggle goods show his moral compromise, while his momentary recollections of naval duties reveal his conflicted identity. If there are weaknesses, they are minor. Occasionally, a metaphor might be slightly overwrought ("The alley received me like a throat"), but these instances are rare and generally effective. The ending appropriately maintains the dark tone established throughout, avoiding any incongruent positivity. Overall, this is an exceptional piece that creates a compelling character study while vividly evoking a specific historical moment. The writing demonstrates sophisticated craft in service of emotional and thematic depth. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20 Elegant Prose: 19 Emotionally Engaging: 19 Emotionally Complex: 19 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 2 Weak Dialogue: 1 Tell-Don't-Show: 1 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 0 Unearned Transformations: 0 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20.0, Elegant Prose: 19.0, Emotionally Engaging: 19.0, Emotionally Complex: 19.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 2.0, Weak Dialogue: 1.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 1.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 0.0, Unearned Transformations: 0.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Humour: Sisyphus Gives Advice — Score: 90.5
Prompt:
Sisyphus Gives Advice Write a comedic scene in the style of Terry Pratchett featuring Sisyphus, who has started an advice column while continuing his eternal boulder-pushing. Rather than being bitter about his punishment, Sisyphus has developed a comfortably zen emotional intelligence and wisdom from his centuries of repetitive labor. Not in the cliche ways you might expect -- he's actually very grounded, warm & connected with the everyday human plight. He dictates responses to "Crow," his feathered familiar who serves as both scribe and mail carrier. The piece should include Sisyphus thoughtfully answering several advice-seekers' letters about everyday problems (relationship troubles, work-life balance, dealing with difficult people, life purpose doubts) while periodically returning to his boulder-pushing duties. His advice should be surprisingly insightful and practical. The humor should emerge naturally from the messages he receives, from mundane to risque. Sisyphus should genuinely enjoy helping others, finding meaning in this new pursuit while maintaining his boulder routine. The humour should be *understated and not forced*. Contrary to expectation, almost none of his advice involves boulder rolling metaphors (though he does sneak *one* subtle in there), nor a treatise on stoicism. We are also going against the obvious fish-out-of-water trope; in fact, he's surprisingly a natural at this. In all of this , it's important to *show, don't tell*. The format should be largely epistolary, with the occasional interjection for scene setting. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The day was very much like the day before it, which was fortunate, as this meant all the furniture knew where it stood. In the grey morning of the mountain, wind moving with the stern efficiency of a head librarian, Sisyphus put his shoulder to the boulder, took three steps for momentum, and then said, “All right, Crow, let’s do the post.” Crow, who was black as a scandal and twice as opinionated, hopped onto a flat sun-warmed stone serving as a desk. He shuffled parchment with the expertise of someone who had once stolen a set of theatre tickets and improved everyone’s evening. An inkwell, a quill, and a small pebble employed as a paperweight (strictly part-time, in a neutral union) completed the office. “First letter,” Crow cawed, “in purple ink, smells like cinnamon and divorce.” “Lovely,” said Sisyphus, breathing with the rhythm of someone who had not only made peace with an incline, but had been introduced to its extended family. Crow cleared his throat and read. Dear Sisyphus, My partner leaves wet tea bags on the counter. Every day I move them to the bin. I have tried asking nicely. I have tried asking loudly. I have tried interpretive dance. The tea bags persist, glistening like tiny sea creatures. Is this the hill I die on? — Dripping with Resentment Sisyphus put a hand to the boulder, guiding it as it muttered granite syllables. “Write,” he said, “Dear Dripping.” He dictated, and Crow’s quill scritched away. Dear Dripping, Tea bags are a small thing that has decided to audition for a larger role. It is not the tea bags you dislike, it’s the unpaid labor of remembering them. You could keep a little jar on the counter marked ‘Dry Dock.’ Put a spoon beside it. Make it easier to do the right thing than the lazy thing. Then, crucially: agree with your partner when you’re both calm that the counter is a shared space and the jar is the rule. Most people do not change because of volume, but because of clarity and ease. Also, each time you move a tea bag without comment, say to yourself, “I am choosing peace over an argument I will not enjoy.” It is astonishing how much resentment likes to drink tea. Yours, Sisyphus “Add a p.s.,” Sisyphus said, steering the boulder round a nuisance pebble with the toe of his sandal. “P.S. If you must die on a hill, choose one with a view and a picnic blanket.” Crow snorted ink down his beak and left a period the size of a walnut. “From Agamemnon’s head, he would have appreciated that.” “He was never a picnic,” Sisyphus said. He set his shoulder again. The boulder, affronted by gravity as a matter of principle, rolled on. Crow lifted the next letter. “This one has a lipstick kiss and the faint aroma of ill-advised weekends.” Dear Sisyphus, There is a person at my workplace. Let us call him “Management.” He sends emails at midnight and asks if I got his nine minutes ago. He schedules meetings about meetings. He calls me “champ.” I am not his champ. How do I put boundaries in place without becoming the office villain? — Thunderously Tired Sisyphus tilted his head, listening to the mountain, which was making its usual early afternoon sound of being far too old for this. “Dear Thunder,” he said. Dear Thunder, Boundaries are not walls; they are signposts. The first time he emails at midnight, do not answer until the hour you are paid to be awake. When you reply, include at the top: “For clarity, I respond to messages during working hours, which for me are [x–y]. Urgent issues should be marked urgent.” Then do not break this rule for three weeks. People believe the rule you live, not the one you announce. For “champ,” gently say, “Please call me by my name.” No apology, no explanation. Repeat it, even if he is wearing a tie with tiny boats. If he persists, document it. If you are in a meeting about a meeting, ask, “What decision are we making in this time?” People who like meetings dislike decisions. Bring a decision along to scare them. In private, decide what you would do if nothing changed. Then do one smaller version of that now. Yours, Sisyphus “The bit about the boats was uncalled for,” Crow murmured, impressed. “He knows what he did,” Sisyphus said mildly. A gust of wind brought the smell of hot stone and somebody else’s eternity. The boulder paused at a place where it liked to consider life’s mysteries, then rolled its eyes and kept going. “Here’s one with jam,” Crow said, pecking delicately. “Possibly strawberry. Possibly a cry for help.” Dear Sisyphus, My girlfriend wants to move in. I love her, but my flat is small and full of… me. I have an orderly system of piles. She has an orderly system of plants. I’m 32 and still unsure if I can share a bookshelf without losing myself. Advice? — Shelved and Shaky Sisyphus smiled, the sort that had laughed often and then remembered what laughter was for. Dear Shelved, You are not a book, and love is not a library. Sharing a shelf does not erase your margins; it invites annotations. Start by making space deliberately; choose which pile becomes a drawer. You will be tempted to pretend your flat is symmetrical. It is not. Offer her the place you care about least, and keep the place you care about most. Tell her the story of each object on the mantle. Ask her the story of each plant. If the stories make room for each other, you will, too. If you cannot decide, host a trial month with a box labeled “Stowaways” for things that do not yet belong. At the end, open the box together and decide what stayed merely out of kindness, and what stayed because it’s part of the map. Also, own one chair neither of you may pile things on. It is the ceasefire chair. You sit in it when you need to be only yourself for an hour. Guard this with the seriousness usually reserved for royal weddings and the last biscuit. Yours, Sisyphus The boulder, perhaps out of curiosity, attempted to roll faster. Sisyphus hummed and let it, his hands steady, his feet knowing where the mountain gave and where it argued back. “Next,” Crow said, “is less letter, more stain. The rain made an editorial choice.” He held up a parchment that looked as if someone had written their heart out and then used it to mop up their heart. Only fragments remained: “dear sisy… think my cat… actually my boss… forks go missing… destiny?? help pls.” Sisyphus took a long, sympathetic breath. “All right. We will answer all of them, then. Start with ‘Dear Possibly Several People.’” Dear Possibly Several People, If your cat is your boss, congratulations on working in a progressive environment. Put the food on time, provide sunbeams, and accept that your performance reviews will be conducted from a cardboard box. If your boss is your cat, stop dangling the laser pointer. He cannot resist chasing the new shiny thing, and you will be complicit. Put important items in writing. Close your door. Offer treats sparingly, and reward litter box usage, metaphorically speaking. As for forks going missing, buy more forks. This sounds flippant, but it is actually hospitality. Keep the good ones in a drawer you enjoy opening. Someone will ask where you got them. Tell them. They will get their own. The universe will right itself in small, tine-shaped increments. If this is about destiny, you have not missed yours. It does not come once like a tyrant; it arrives in installments like a patient postman. Pay attention to what you do when no one is making you. Follow that one street farther. If none of this applies because the letter was about plumbing, turn off the water at the mains and ask your neighbor who is good with pipes. There is always one. Yours, Sisyphus “Elegant,” Crow said, visibly pleased. “And applicable to cutlery theft.” “Everyone thinks forks,” Sisyphus said, guiding the boulder round a slick patch, “but it’s spoons you must watch. They sympathize too much.” Crow rifled again. “A short one. Smells of cardamom. ‘Dear Sisyphus, how do I find my purpose? I try hobbies, jobs, lovers. None fit. Is there a trick?’ Signed, Trying on Shoes.” Sisyphus considered. Wind wrapped itself round his bare arms like a shawl someone had knitted from old myths. Dear Shoes, The trick is to stop asking the word “purpose” to do the work of three smaller words: attention, service, and delight. Attention: Notice what you notice without effort. Keep a note of when time doesn’t scold you. Service: What can you do that leaves other people steadier? Not grand gestures. Carrying chairs after a wedding counts. If you keep doing this, someone will eventually call it your calling. It will still be carrying chairs. Delight: What is a private yes? The thing you do and then look around to see if anyone saw you being that alive. Do more of that in public, carefully. Combine two of the above and you will be difficult to stop. Combine all three and you won’t want to. If you need something to do in the meantime, sweep the threshold of your building. The neighbors will talk. This is good. Yours, Sisyphus The boulder reached the top, thought about metaphysics for the briefest possible time, and rolled back down of its own accord. Sisyphus let it go with a little pat, as if sending a child down a slide. He sat on the lip of the ledge, shoulders broad, face lined in the way that comes from having used it a lot. A shadow crossed them as Crow landed with a rustle. “Two more,” he said. “One is from a person calling themself ‘Molten Enthusiasm.’” Dear Sisyphus, My partner and I are very much in love, but our schedules never align. I work nights. They work days. We communicate by notes on the fridge like polite ghosts. How do we stay connected without falling asleep on top of each other, though that is not always a downside? — Molten Enthusiasm Sisyphus bit back a smile that showed he had, in fact, been to certain temples. “Write,” he said. Dear Molten, Design rituals that do not care what the sun is doing. A thermos note system: one writes a message on the thermos of coffee they leave, the other replies on the lid they return. A five-minute ritual when you pass each other—choose three questions you always ask and always answer, no matter how tired: What made you laugh? What was heavy? Where did you notice beauty? Set a standing date that rotates like a lighthouse—one morning pancake date, one twilight walk, one absurdly timed rendezvous in the middle of an aisle at the 24-hour grocery, in which you choose a new fruit together and eat it in the parking lot. Put it on the calendar as if you respect it. Because you do. As for falling asleep on top of each other: invest in a throw blanket. Consent and blankets are the unsung heroes of romance. Yours, Sisyphus Crow preened one glossy wing and produced the last letter with a flourish. “A spicy one.” Dear Sisyphus, I keep dating people who are disasters wrapped in charming paper. It’s fun until it’s a fire. My friends say I have a type. I say I enjoy fireworks. How do I choose someone who won’t burn down my kitchen, metaphorically, or literally, because I have very nice pots? — Singed but Sanguine Sisyphus nodded, grave as a potter. “Dear Singed.” Dear Singed, At the start, ask yourself two questions instead of one. Everyone asks, “Am I excited?” Also ask, “Am I calm?” If you are only excited, you are boarding a rollercoaster with loose bolts. If you are only calm, you are agreeing to watch paint dry while the paint judges you. Look for both. On the third date, cook together. Choose a recipe with one pan, two knives, and three steps that must be done at once. Watch how they treat the onions. Listen for please and thank you when neither of you feels glamorous. If they switch off the stove when you forget, that is a kind of love. If they eat the burnt bits and say, “We’ll do better next time,” that is another. Have a written list (yes, written) of three non-negotiables that are about behavior, not charisma. “Is kind to waiters.” “Apologizes without auditioning for an award.” “Does not make me smaller to feel bigger.” Consult the list when your brain is full of sparklers. If the list says no, trust the list. Fireworks are for festivals, not kitchens. Keep the nice pots. People can be taught; pots cannot. Yours, Sisyphus Crow blew on the ink and looked up. “That’s the lot,” he said. Down below, the boulder angled itself toward its usual starting point with the dogged optimism of a tortoise entering a marathon. “Send them,” Sisyphus said. “Give the cat/boss two peanuts. For morale.” Crow gathered the letters into his satchel with the air of a professional leaving an office that happened to be a precipice. He hesitated. “And you?” he asked, as he always did, though the answer never changed much. Sisyphus stood, stretched, put his hands on the stone he knew better than the back of his hand (the front of his hand had more personality). “I have an afternoon appointment,” he said. “Client is punctual.” He leaned, pushed. The boulder moved, considering the whole business of existence and deciding, as usual, that consistency was its own polite applause. “Crow,” he called as the incline accepted him. “Add this to the bottom of the column, will you?” Crow poised his quill. If your letter is smudged, it will still be answered. If you are smudged, likewise. Also, remember: momentum is less about pushing hard and more about knowing when to breathe. Crow paused. “That’s a bit… you know.” “A little,” Sisyphus admitted, smiling. “One for the purists.” The wind ran ahead to tell the mountain they were coming. The mountain, ancient and practical, made space. And somewhere along the slope, where a paperweight-pebble did its humble work, the ink dried on words that would go out into the world on black wings, find kitchens and desks and laps, and make their own small weather.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This response is a remarkably well-crafted piece that captures Terry Pratchett's distinctive style with impressive fidelity. The author has created a Sisyphus who is indeed "grounded, warm & connected with the everyday human plight" while maintaining a light touch with the humor. The epistolary format works perfectly, with Sisyphus answering a variety of everyday problems through his advice column. The relationship between Sisyphus and Crow is established efficiently, with Crow serving as both scribe and mail carrier as requested. Their interactions have the easy familiarity of long-time companions, with gentle banter that feels natural rather than forced. The prose is particularly strong, with Pratchett-esque similes and metaphors throughout: "Crow, who was black as a scandal and twice as opinionated" and "wind moving with the stern efficiency of a head librarian" capture that distinctive voice. The personification of inanimate objects (the boulder "muttering granite syllables") is also characteristic of Pratchett's style. The advice Sisyphus gives is genuinely insightful and practical, showing emotional intelligence without resorting to clichés. His responses to relationship troubles, work-life balance, and finding purpose are thoughtful and nuanced. The writer has successfully avoided making Sisyphus bitter about his punishment, instead portraying him as someone who has found meaning in helping others. The humor emerges naturally from the situations and characters rather than feeling forced. There's a subtlety to the comedy that respects the reader's intelligence. The writer has also successfully avoided overusing boulder-rolling metaphors, including just one subtle reference as requested ("momentum is less about pushing hard and more about knowing when to breathe"). The piece excels at showing rather than telling. We understand Sisyphus's character through his actions and words rather than through explicit statements about his nature. The scene-setting interjections between letters provide just enough context without overwhelming the epistolary format. If there are any weaknesses, they're minor. Some of the metaphors, while clever, occasionally border on being slightly too elaborate or self-conscious. However, this is consistent with Pratchett's style, so it's hard to consider it a true flaw. Overall, this is an exceptional response that fulfills all the requirements of the prompt while creating a genuinely engaging and entertaining piece of writing. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Coming of age: Lost & Found in Osaka — Score: 86.3
Prompt:
Lost & Found in Osaka Slice of Life / Coming-of-Age: First Connection. Write one scene within a larger story set in Osaka, Japan. A shy, introverted teenager & synthesizer nerd, is browsing the electronics district of Den Den Town. She is drawn to the sound of an electric guitar. A girl, slightly older and radiating confidence, is busking near the entrance to a crowded arcade, playing a blistering rendition of a classic anime theme. The scene takes us through their initial awkward interaction, transitioning into a surprisingly easy conversation. The busker, intrigued by the teenager's quiet intensity and knowledge of music, suggests they grab some sushi at a nearby kaitenzushi (conveyor belt sushi) restaurant. Write primarily in dialogue, capturing the distinct voices of the two characters: the teenager's hesitant and -- initially -- awkward speech, and the busker's more outgoing and playful tone. 1000 words.
Model Output:
“Hey, Den Den Town. You hearing this?” “…is that…? That’s totally ‘Cruel Angel’s Thesis,’ right?” “You got it. Full-speed, no mercy. Wanna request something?” “I—uh—no. I mean, I like this one. You’re… you’re really good.” “Thanks. I practice till my fingers hate me. You look like you know your way around a synth rack though.” “W-what? How did you—?” “Backpack patches. Krell Systems, Rogue Wave, and—hang on—Roland Juno pin. That’s not random. Also, the way you were staring at the loop pedal like it was a crime scene? Synth nerd tells on herself.” “I was just… curious. Your chain. You split the signal?” “Guitar into compressor, overdrive, then the looper. Split to the mini-amp and the little speaker on the ground for ambient shimmer. It’s hokey, but it kicks in the arcade noise. I’m Kana, by the way.” “Um. I’m Yui.” “Yui! Nice to meet you. Wanna hold this pick? Lucky charm.” “I—no, I—I’m okay. Sorry. I just… you, uh, you’re busking at the entrance where the UFO catchers scream like that.” “Prime real estate. People pouring out with armfuls of plushies, hearts open, wallets half-open. See that guy with the big Rilakkuma? He tipped me in Takoyaki last week.” “Can… can you even tip in takoyaki?” “You can if it’s hot. I’ll play for food. Watch this—key change.” “Oh—woah. You reharmonized the chorus. Traded the IV for a flat-VII. That’s… that’s clever.” “You hear that?” “Yes. And you tucked the melody under those power chords. It’s—um—in the guitar community they call that ‘chord-melody,’ right? But it feels more like—like a lead sheet nobody wrote down.” “Yui! You just gave me a cooler bio line for my Insta.” “I didn’t mean—uh, sorry. I’m bad at… talking. I mean, I talk, but it comes out like file names.” “Ha! File names are hot, what are you talking about? Give me a file name.” “Uh. ‘kana_gtr_anothertake_final_FINAL_v6.wav’?” “Accurate. Alright, last chorus.” “It’s getting crowded.” “It’s Friday. Retro tournament inside. Street Fighter II screaming over there.” “I only came to look at capacitors.” “You say the sexiest things.” “…I—what?” “Kidding. But seriously, what are you building?” “Not building. Fixing. My friend—well, okay, not really a friend. Someone I follow—posted a schematic for a chorus mod for the SH-101 clone I bought. The filter drifts, and when the air conditioner kicks on, the pitch… um, sorry. That’s probably boring.” “Do I look bored?” “I can’t tell. You’re… shiny. I mean, I mean you’re… um.” “Hah! I’ll take shiny. Okay, shiny finishes ‘Cruel Angel’s Thesis’ with a whammy you aren’t expecting—” “That note! You bent it just flat, like the vocal vibrato. You listened to the original too many times.” “Between you and me? My mom hummed it making curry. I’m basically made of that song. Hey, you didn’t tip.” “I… didn’t have coins. I can—” “Relax. I’m not shaking you down, Yui. Just a custom payment plan. You owe me a nerdy fact about something here.” “Here? Like… Den Den Town facts?” “Dealer’s choice.” “Okay. You know the shop two blocks down, the one with the broken Mega Drive shell in the window? If you go in and ask politely, the owner will show you a drawer with Famicom carts that never made it to release. He won’t sell them, but he lets you hold them for a second if you promise not to breathe too loud.” “That’s fantastic. I want to go there.” “He memorized the pinouts for five different cartridge connectors. He did it to impress his… wife, I think? But she only pretends to be impressed. She runs the Gachapon shop across the street.” “So he married someone who can roll her eyes at his pinouts. That’s romantic. Oh, and—excuse me—” “Your case is open.” “I saw. Little guy thought he could drop coins without getting noticed. He can. I just wanted to thank him. Gratitude is part of the tone.” “Part of the tone?” “Yeah. Confidence, posture, hydration, gratitude. Same category. Hey, you want to try to loop something?” “No.” “That was quick.” “I mean, I… I don’t do… crowds.” “You and me both. I’m faking.” “You’re very good at it.” “Thanks. Practice faking in the mirror. Also, my amp is small. Smaller amps make me feel safer.” “That’s not—on a technical level the amp size doesn’t matter if you’re mic’d.” “Wow, you really went there.” “Sorry.” “Don’t be. It’s cute. Here, I’ll just lay down a chord and you hit this button when I nod. That’s all.” “Just… the button?” “Yep. The one that says ‘rec.’ Ready?” “Okay.” “Nod.” “—oh. Like that?” “Perfect. You looped me, Yui. Complicit.” “It feels like I stepped on the wrong train and it still got me where I needed to go.” “Good metaphor. Where do you think you needed to go?” “I don’t know. Maybe… out of my room.” “Fair. I respect rooms though. They’re honest. Hey, you smell that?” “Seaweed?” “Sushi place a block over. Kaitenzushi. Conveyor belts like tiny monorails. We should go. I’ll pack up in two minutes.” “I… with me?” “Yes, with you. I don’t invite just anybody who knows what a flat-VII is.” “I shouldn’t—” “Why not?” “I… don’t know you.” “That’s okay. We can know each other over salmon. I’m safe, I swear. You can sit nearest the door and keep your phone out like you’re texting an escape plan. I won’t be offended.” “I wasn’t—” “I do it too when meeting people off gigs. Safety first. Also, if you hate me, you can shove me into a stack of plates and bolt. Though I’d prefer you didn’t. These jeans are borrowed from my cousin.” “You joke a lot.” “It’s cheaper than therapy. But I mean the sushi. I’m starving. And you look like you forget to eat when you’re soldering.” “That’s not—well, yes.” “Called it. C’mon. One more tiny solo, then we go.” “Okay. I’ll—uh—stand here.” “Good spot. Watch the entrance—oh, speaking of loud—” “Fireworks?” “Wait, at this hour?” “There’s a flyer. Namba Summer Something-something Parade.” “Oh right, the pop-up thing. Perfect timing. I’ll time this divebomb to it.” “It’s really loud.” “It’s Osaka. We brag loud. Hold your ears if it hurts.” “I’m fine. It’s… pretty.” “Gold ones bloom like cymbals. I wish the loop station could sample that.” “You could. With a mic.” “Yeah, but then I’d need a good preamp and—there goes my last thousand yen. Okay, last run, then we go get conveyor belts.” “Alright.” “—And… done. You okay?” “Yes. The fireworks made my stomach jump.” “Same. Adrenaline tastes like cheap batteries. Help me coil?” “I can coil.” “Over-under. Not like you’re wrangling a garden hose.” “I know over-under.” “Oh! Sorry. I always assume newbies and then I embarrass myself.” “I look like a newbie.” “You look like Yui. Which is… in the top five looks today.” “Top five?” “I met a man who turned his Switch into a guitar controller. He’s number two. You’re number one.” “You’re being nice because you want me to come with you.” “I want you to come with me because I think you’re interesting. Being nice is just… me. Or I try. This street can be mean. I prefer being an antidote.” “Okay.” “Okay as in okay sushi?” “Okay as in okay sushi.” “Yesss. Help me zip this. Mind the stickers.” “‘Girls to the Front Panel.’ That’s a good sticker.” “Thank you. It’s a synth joke. No one laughs.” “I laughed. Inside.” “I’ll accept inside laughs. Ready?” “Wait. Your cable’s still—” “Caught on the sign. Got it. Let’s walk. Watch your step.” “It’s packed.” “Osaka Friday night. If you get overwhelmed, tug my sleeve.” “I don’t… tug sleeves.” “You can tug mine. It’s free.” “I—okay.” “So, Yui, what’s your favorite oscillator wave? Full disclosure, this is a compatibility question.” “Triangle.” “Scandalous. Why triangle?” “It’s… it’s clean. Like a voice humming before it becomes a word.” “Wow. I’m stealing that too.” “You can steal it. I’ll charge royalties in mackerel.” “Deal. Here we are. This place has an angry tuna on the sign—peak quality.” “It’s bright.” “Yeah. Conveyor belts are like aquariums for food. Let’s sit at the end so you can see everything.” “I’ll… sit by the door.” “Perfect. I’ll sit opposite so you can stare at me and the exit at the same time.” “I wasn’t—” “Teasing. We can pivot if it’s too much. Here comes a plate. Salmon belly.” “I’ve never been to one of these alone.” “Good thing you’re not alone. Two plates?” “One. I’m small.” “Okay, small person. I’ll grab the egg for me. Judge me later. What do you do, besides fix wayward filters?” “I… make little tracks. Nothing special.” “Define nothing.” “Like… minute-long things that never resolve. They’re like… promised bridges that never get to the chorus.” “Unfinished bridges are still pretty. I like them. Send me one.” “I can’t.” “Because you don’t want to or because you think it’s not good enough?” “Both.” “I get it. I said ‘send me one,’ not ‘send me your soul.’ Just one little clip. I’ll listen while eating convenience store pudding and I’ll send you fifteen emojis in response.” “Which fifteen?” “Depends on your waveform. Possibly the whale.” “Whale?” “Big feelings. Or maybe the sparkles. Do you… what do you listen to?” “Old game soundtracks. Namco. Yamaha FM chips. I like how the hardware puts a fence around you and says ‘make meaning inside this box.’” “See, that’s hot. Fences and meaning. I make terrible sense of boundlessness. Too many choices. I freeze.” “Me too. That’s why I like triangles.” “Full circle. Passing you the soy sauce. Want ginger?” “No, thank you. It’s like… too bright. The ginger.” “Same. We’re ginger skeptics. Another compatibility tick. Ooh, look, fireworks reflection in the restaurant glass.” “It looks like pixels.” “Right? Like somebody overexposed a SNES palette.” “I like that. Do you come out here every Friday?” “Most. School’s meh, work’s meh, this is where I feel like the noise is my noise, not just the noise, you know?” “I think so.” “Do your parents care if you’re out late?” “They think I’m at a bookstore. Which is not a lie. There are books here.” “In the gacha machines? Literature in capsule form.” “I had a math teacher who said probability is literature.” “I like them. Do they have office hours at the arcade?” “They would if they were serious.” “You’re funny, Yui.” “I don’t try to be.” “Best kind. Oh, incoming: mackerel for your royalties.” “Payment accepted. Do I… owe you a fact now?” “Please.” “The shop with the curry pan outside? If you ask for ‘Night Mode,’ the owner will turn off half the lights so you can see the RGB fans on the PCs. He did it once for me because I looked like I had been inside for a hundred years.” “You say the nicest things about yourself.” “It was a compliment. It was… it felt like someone saw me.” “I see you. I mean—sorry, too earnest? I do that sometimes.” “It’s okay.” “Yui, can I ask a question? You can veto.” “Okay.” “What made you stop for me? There are a lot of buskers.” “You were playing what my dad hums when he fixes our microwave. He doesn’t sing it right. You did.” “Now I’m emotional. Great. I’m going to drip soy sauce down my face like a mess.” “Don’t cry. The waitress will worry.” “I won’t. But I like that. Tell your dad he can have my chord chart. I’ll write ‘microwave version’ on it.” “He would like that.” “Another plate?” “I’m full.” “Already? Tiny person indeed. We’ll sit for a second. Let the belt hypnotize us. Then I’ll walk you to the train.” “You don’t have to.” “I want to. Also, selfishly, I want to ask you more about your chorus mod. Does it give the 101 a little swirl or full-on spaceship?” “In-between. It adds a slow drift, like you’re turning your head in a small room.” “Okay, poet. I want to hear it. Maybe next time you can bring it here, and I’ll plug you into my amp. We’ll loop your swirl.” “I… maybe.” “Maybe is yes adjacent. I’ll take it.” “Can I ask you something back?” “Always.” “Why did you invite me?” “Because when you stood there, you looked like you were hearing the version of the song I was trying to play, not the sloppy street version. And because your voice does that thing when you talk about waves—like you’re stepping on a train and you’re not sure if it’s the right one, but you go anyway. I like that.” “I was going to run away.” “I could tell. That’s why I made the sushi move fast. It’s harder to run if there’s promise of salmon.” “You’re manipulative.” “Only in service of friendship.” “Friendship.” “Scary word? We can downgrade to acquaintance.” “No. Friendship is fine.” “Good. Then it’s settled. Yui the triangle wave and Kana the overdrive. Next time, bring me a minute-long track that feels like a promised bridge. I’ll bring fireworks on a USB.” “You can’t put fireworks on a USB.” “Watch me. I’ll name it fireworks_final_FINAL_v7.” “I’d listen to that.” “You will. Now, finish your mackerel. The night’s long, and Den Den Town sleeps like a cat—one eye open, tail flicking.” “You’re weird.” “Likewise. Cheers, Yui.” “Cheers, Kana.”
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully creates a dialogue-driven scene between two distinct characters in Osaka's Den Den Town. The writing effectively establishes the shy, introverted synthesizer enthusiast Yui and the confident, outgoing busker Kana through their conversation patterns. The dialogue is the strongest element of the piece. Each character has a distinct voice - Yui's hesitant, often self-interrupting speech contrasts well with Kana's playful, confident tone. The writer uses dialogue tags sparingly, allowing the characters' speech patterns to identify them. Yui's technical knowledge about synthesizers and music theory comes through naturally in her speech, while Kana's outgoing personality shines in her quips and encouragement. The setting of Den Den Town is established through specific details woven organically into the dialogue - mentions of arcade noise, UFO catchers, electronics shops, and the sensory experience of Osaka (fireworks, food smells). These details create a vivid backdrop without relying on heavy exposition. The relationship development between the characters feels authentic. Their connection over music provides a natural foundation, and Kana's gentle persistence in drawing Yui out of her shell is handled with sensitivity. The writer avoids the trap of making Yui's social anxiety disappear too quickly - she remains hesitant throughout, though gradually warming to Kana. There are a few minor weaknesses. The piece occasionally relies on telling rather than showing, particularly when explaining character emotions directly. Some of the technical music discussions might be difficult for readers unfamiliar with synthesizers to follow. The dialogue sometimes becomes slightly repetitive in structure, with many short exchanges that could benefit from more variety in pacing. The ending strikes an appropriate tone - not forcing a dramatic transformation in Yui, but showing a tentative new friendship with potential for growth. The promise of future meetings feels earned rather than contrived. Overall, this is a strong piece that succeeds in its primary goal of capturing two distinct character voices through dialogue while creating an authentic slice-of-life scene in Osaka. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Teen horror: Tick Tock (Goosebumps) — Score: 88.8
Prompt:
Teen Horror (Goosebumps style) Write a chapter where a middle school student discovers their new smart watch has the ability to rewind time, but doesn't realize that each use is aging them until they notice physical changes (like accelerating through puberty) and that people are treating them differently. They inadvertently cause a timeline shift with disastrous consequences -- and it can only be rectified (maybe?) by reversing the clock once more. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
I noticed it first in Mr. Pritchard’s class, while he was explaining the water cycle with a PowerPoint that looked like it was made before any of us were born. He kept mixing up evaporation and condensation, and he refused to call on anyone but Madison, who sat front row like she owned the place. I was in my usual middle-back seat, scribbling skulls in the margin of my notes and tapping my new smart watch against the desk. Dad got it for me for my thirteenth birthday—a real brand, not one of those brick-sized knockoffs. Sleek black band, glowing blue interface. It counted my steps, tracked my sleep, and said “Good morning, Jax” in this chipper voice I could tell had been programmed by someone who never had a morning in middle school. I’d already set the alarms and connected it to my phone. What I hadn’t figured out was this hidden option I found while messing around under my desk: a tiny hourglass icon that wasn’t in the manual. When I pressed it, the watch vibrated once, just a whisper in the skin of my wrist. And Mr. Pritchard was suddenly talking about evaporation again. At first I thought I’d zoned out, daydreaming skulls, and my brain had looped back. But when Madison’s hand shot up with the same “Actually—” she always used, and the same freckles scrunched across her nose, and even the same cough from the vent above the whiteboard, I realized it wasn’t me. I clicked the hourglass again. Another vibration, a tingle up my arm, and time slid like a wet plate. Mr. Pritchard stammered back to the start of the slide, and I watched it all again. Same cough. Same “Actually.” Same spray of light from the dusty projector. Three times, four times. By number five, I’d timed it: thirty seconds. A thirty-second rewind. My watch could rewind time. I’d seen things online about people editing videos to look like time loops or fake magic tricks with cuts, but this was different. The feeling was like being picked up and put back down in the exact same spot, except every time I landed, the world was a tiny fraction more out of sync with me. Hard to explain; only my stomach knew. It swooped faintly, like stepping off the last stair when you think there’s one more. I didn’t tell anyone. Not right away. What would I say? “Hey, my watch is a time machine, want to mess up the science lesson?” They’d laugh. Or worse, they’d believe me and take it away. So I used it on small things. When I said something dumb to Trevor at lunch and he made that face, I nudged the hourglass and said something less dumb. When the ball bounced off my knee in P.E., I tapped the watch and the ball obediently came back, and I scored like I meant to. When Mom asked if I’d fed the cat and I had not, I rewound and fed him before answering, making her eyebrows lift like she was surprised I was suddenly responsible. It was just thirty seconds, but thirty seconds can fix a lot. By Friday, though, I’d noticed the weirdness. Not the gut swoop—that got easier. It was my voice. In the bathroom that morning, I’d said “Hello” to myself just to test the echo, and the sound was… thicker. Like someone had turned up the bass. And my hair had done this thing where it refused to lie flat, like every cowlick had declared independence. “Puberty,” Dad said cheerfully when I asked if my voice sounded weird. “Welcome to the club.” I didn’t feel like joining any clubs. But maybe it was normal. I mean, I was thirteen. Gym class, Coach Ramirez split us into teams for dodgeball. I used the watch three times in a row to avoid getting pelted by Kaylee Taylor, who threw like a pitcher and smiled like a shark. After the third rewind, she squinted at me. “How’d you do that?” “Do what?” I asked, voice coming out rougher than I wanted. “That duck. You knew I was gonna throw.” “Lucky,” I said, and then I felt it. Not the swoop. The pull. My skin felt too tight, like the watchband had shrunk while I wasn’t looking. I tugged at it and realized the impressions it left were deeper than they’d been yesterday. My wrist looked different. Bone looked sharper. I caught my reflection in the backboard glass and frowned. After school, I went to the bathroom before the bus. It’s the kind with greenish lights and stalls with graffiti in Sharpie—if you learned to read in middle school bathrooms, you’d be scarred for life. I stepped up to the sink and looked at myself. Same eyes. Same dark hair doing its own thing. A pimple forming on my chin like a malevolent volcano. But there was more definition in my jaw. That’s what Dad would call it. I would have called it weird. “Hey, Jax,” someone said behind me. Trevor. He walked in, tossed his backpack on the tile like he didn’t care, and gave me a look that was half friendly, half something else. Something measuring. “What?” I asked. “Nothing. You look… different. Did you—” He leaned closer. “Shave?” “I’m thirteen,” I said. But my voice betrayed me again, a crack then a lower note that made me want to chew on the air to get it back. He grinned. “Okay, Barry White.” He washed his hands and left. I stared at my reflection. “Hello,” I said again. It was definitely lower. This time, when I blinked, my face in the mirror blinked a moment later. Not like a regular mirror’s split-second delay. More like a few beats. And in that delay—only for a flicker—I saw something that made my stomach plunge past any staircase. An older face. Mine, but not. Sharper jawline. A shadow where facial hair would be if I could grow any. Eyes that had seen things I hadn’t. It was there and gone, like a bad signal. I shoved away from the sink, my heart banging. The smart watch was warm on my wrist. It couldn’t be. The watch rewound time outside, not inside me. Except what if both were true? What if every rewind cost me something? I didn’t use it on the bus. I didn’t use it when Mom burned the garlic bread and Dad told her it was “rustic,” which earned him a glare. I lay in bed and watched the ceiling fan spin, thinking of the older face like a ghost hovering in my mirror. The watch’s face glowed on my nightstand, the hourglass icon waiting, patient. I dreamed of being pulled backward and forward through a carousel where every horse was me at a different age, reaching out with wooden hooves. Saturday should have been normal. Cartoons with my little sister Mia, cereal dust at the bottom of the box. But the group chat blew up before ten. Madison had posted a picture from in front of the school. It was cordoned off with yellow tape. In the blurry photo, you could see smoke stains on the bricks around the science wing windows. There were comments: “Explosion?” “No school Monday?” “Omg.” Mom got the notification email from the principal. There had been a small fire. No injuries, thank God. “Faulty wiring,” the email said. “We will be performing an investigation and repairs.” Faulty wiring. Except I knew what I’d done yesterday in Mr. Pritchard’s class. I’d rewound him five times in a row because it was funny to watch him say “evaporation” wrong. The projector had been ancient. If time is a thread, imagine tugging at it again and again until it frays. I opened my texts to Madison. Did anything else happen? Anyone hurt? She wrote back right away: No but the lab got trashed. Chemicals everywhere. Mr. P is freaking. I clicked the news app. It hadn’t caught up yet. I clicked the watch. The hourglass pulsed once. Maybe I could fix it. Rewind longer than thirty seconds. It had only ever gone thirty, but there had to be a way. I swiped through menus I hadn’t seen before, dug deeper. Hidden settings flickered like fish. The watch recognized my fingerprint, then asked for a passcode I didn’t remember setting. When I hesitated, it pulsed again, like a heartbeat. My thumb found the hourglass and pressed, and the world hissed. It wasn’t thirty seconds this time. Sound stretched thin. The hum of the refrigerator elongated into a single, piercing line. My hands trembled as the living room rewound around me—Mia’s cereal spoon lifting, lowering, lifting again—then sped backward into last night, my ceiling fan spinning the other way, my breath functioning like lines on a graph drawn in reverse. Back further: Friday afternoon, the bus squealing, the bathroom mirror glinting, Mr. Pritchard’s mouth forming the word “evaporation.” My watch burned against my skin. Everything snapped like a rubber band. I was standing in the school hallway, papers on the bulletin board un-faded by smoke, the air with its usual disinfectant tang. Through the window into the science wing, I could see Mr. Pritchard fiddling with the projector, his brow furrowed. No fire. No melted wires. I did it, I thought, and in the same second, I realized my jeans felt tighter at the calves. The world looked slightly shorter, like the floors had risen. Panic stitched through me. I sprinted toward the classroom before I could think, burst through the door. “Mr. Pritchard!” I said. He jumped. “Jackson!” he scolded, then blinked. “Goodness, your voice… Did you have a growth spurt overnight?” I ignored him. “Don’t turn it on. The projector. It’s… wired wrong.” He looked at me like I’d said the mitochondria were a kind of pasta. “We’ve used this for years,” he said, and turned it on. The hum was fine. The light sputtered to life. I let out a breath that shook. I wanted to use the watch to make myself not look like a total freak, but I forced my hand away. I had to stop. I made myself stop. The day moved like molasses after that, every second heavy with the weight of not pressing the hourglass. I could tell when I reached for it without meaning to; my fingers twitched. At lunch, Kaylee threw a carrot slice and hit me in the forehead, and I didn’t fix it. Madison tripped in the hallway, and I helped her up the normal way. The world breathed. At home, I went to the bathroom and stood in front of the mirror again. I tried to make myself look the way I thought a normal thirteen-year-old should look. It didn’t work. The older face flickered again between my eyes and the mirror’s surface like a broadcast from the future. This time, though, the older me didn’t look scared. He looked tired. I swallowed. “Hi,” I said. The flicker mouthed it with me, then lagged, then matched. He--I--pressed two fingers to the sink. We both did. The porcelain was cold, and my skin felt warmer than it should, almost feverish. I pulled up my sleeve. The watch had left a paler band of skin underneath, like a tan line, except it wasn’t from sun. It was from time. Time had been polishing me like a rock in a tumbler. It wasn’t done, either. The icon was still there, blue and patient. Use me, it seemed to say. Fix anything. The voice in my head that had my own voice, only deeper, said, Every choice is a thread. If you pull, it unravels somewhere. Mom knocked. “Jax? You okay in there?” “Yeah,” I said, and the word caught the way voices catch when they’re skipping steps. “Just a second.” I looked at myself for longer than a second, at the me who was me and at the echo, the older me, who I didn’t know yet. I thought about the fire that didn’t happen because I’d pulled back, and about other things I’d fixed that had changed people in ways I couldn’t see. I thought about Kaylee’s almost-smile when I didn’t dodge. I thought about Trevor’s laugh echoing in the bathroom and how it had sounded jealous. I thought about the thirty seconds multiplied over and over, how they add up to minutes, to hours, to versions of me that stepped past each other in a hallway I couldn’t map. I should smash the watch, I thought. Or lock it away. Or throw it in the deepest part of the dumpster behind school and never look back. But the watch vibrated, just then. Not like when I pressed it. It did it on its own, like it was reminding me it was there. The hourglass pulsed and the world blurred, and for a breath, I saw beyond the mirror. My older face bent closer, and I realized what I’d mistaken for tiredness was something else. Determination. He mouthed, “Once more.” “Why?” I whispered. My voice sounded like my dad’s when the car wouldn’t start. The older me didn’t answer. He reached toward the glass like he could press my watch from the other side. Mom knocked again, urgency in the wood. “Jackson?” “I’m coming,” I said, but my finger hovered over the hourglass. I had fixed the fire. Maybe there was something else, something I didn’t know I’d broken, further back or forward. Time wasn’t a verse you could read and understand. It was a song on a scratched disc. Maybe I’d have to play it until the track stopped skipping. “Once more,” I said to myself. Or to him. Or to the watch. Or to the bathroom with its greenish lights and graffiti that said lies and truths nobody would remember next year. My fingertip sank into the glow. The watch shivered. The mirror flickered, a TV changing channels between versions of me, between lives. Everything tightened around me, my skin, my breath, the loop of time pulling taut. And then I fell. Or flew. Or rewound. Or all three. If I tell you I knew what I was doing, I’d be lying. If I tell you I didn’t have a choice, that would be true and also a lie. What I knew was this: the clock only looks harmless until you wind it too far back, and the click you feel is the trap shutting, confession by confession. When the world knit itself again, when the hum resolved, when the mirror settled, the face that looked back at me wasn’t older. It was mine. Thirteen. Scared. Determined. Behind me, through the thin bathroom window, a siren in the distance rose and fell, a sound that might not have been there before. A sound I might have put there. “Jax?” Mom called for a third time, edges of panic sanded into her voice. “Coming,” I said. My voice was my voice, but if I listened, I could hear the older one, too, like a harmony. I looked at the hourglass icon, still patient, still there. Maybe I had fixed it. Maybe I hadn’t. Maybe the fix would cost me more than I understood. I let my sleeve fall over the watch. I took a breath. I opened the door.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively captures the Goosebumps-style teen horror genre while adding a layer of emotional complexity often missing from middle-grade fiction. The story follows Jax, a thirteen-year-old who discovers his new smartwatch can rewind time, but each use ages him prematurely. The narrative successfully establishes the protagonist's voice and worldview through specific details that feel authentic to middle school experience: the outdated PowerPoint, the social dynamics with Madison "who sat front row like she owned the place," and the bathroom with "stalls with graffiti in Sharpie." These details ground the fantastical premise in a believable setting. The progression of Jax's discovery and subsequent consequences unfolds at an appropriate pace. The writer skillfully builds tension by having Jax first use the watch for trivial matters before realizing the physical toll it takes. The physical changes are described with concrete details rather than abstractions: "my voice... was thicker," "my hair had done this thing where it refused to lie flat," and "more definition in my jaw."
