+ Epistolary: The Lighthouse Keeper — Score: 0
Prompt:
The Lighthouse Keeper Epistolary Narrative: Write a story told entirely through a series of brief correspondences: telegrams or letters or emails between two characters. The correspondence should span several months or years, and reveal a gradually unfolding plot. Use distinct voices for each character, and include details that provide insight into their personalities and motivations. The story should build to an emotional climax, and the final letter should provide a satisfying resolution. The setting is a lighthouse keeper writing to his mother. He is working class and Scottish. He is struggling with the isolation of his posting. Write naturally and without cliches. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Judge Evaluation:
[Skipping – generation error: Text too short after 3 attempts]
+ First-person unique perspective: Hacker Mindset — Score: 88.4
Prompt:
Hacker Mindset Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of a reformed (now) white hat hacker who cannot help but notice exploitable weaknesses in both systems and people they encounter. They habitually look for vulnerabilities and exploit vectors. The narrative takes place during a first date at a restaurant, where they're trying to focus on human connection. It's going surprisingly well due to a discovered shared nerd-fandom (magic the gathering). Things go a little sideways when the date reveals a noticeably insecure phone unlock pattern, which protagonist can't help but comment on. They are then left to negotiate the fallout of this faux pas and attempt to salvage (or perhaps sabotage) the remainder of the date. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
I tell myself, out loud in the car before I get out: don’t audit the date. The waitress is propping the door with her foot, coffee sloshing, and the bell over the frame gives a little glitch of a ring, like it has a race condition with gravity. I clock the router behind the counter on instinct. Older model. Stickers peeled and yellow. The WiFi password is taped right there to the espresso machine with Scotch tape, printed in 16-point Calibri: LatteLove2020!. The exclamation point is doing its best to be entropy. I inhale once, hold, and try to let it go. I’m early. My default. Early is safe; early is recon. I choose a two-top near the back wall with a line of sight past the plants to the bathrooms, to the kitchen door, to the counter where the barista is using the knuckle of her thumb to wipe foam from the steam wand and not sanitizing it. I am here to have dinner, not to file a report. I order water because it buys me the right to exist in a place without making any other commitment. She’s two minutes late, then three, then six, and then there she is, a flash of green scarf and a shiver of bangs that try to behave and don’t, and the precise moment she looks and finds me feels like aligning a puzzle piece you found under the couch. Her smile is not a default. It’s compiled, with care. “Sorry,” she says, sliding into the chair, “I had to argue with a parking meter that thinks time is a construct.” I look at her hands. No ring. Nails bitten, not awful, just lived-in. There’s a tiny blue-black dot on the index finger of her left hand, the tattoo of a leaky pen or an ancient Sharpie. Her phone’s case has a faint scuff pattern around the edges where she fidgets. The edges of her scarf are unraveling into little fiber filaments. Everything about her is a visible history of use. I like that. “It is a construct,” I say, “and also a service with a variable uptime guarantee.” Her laugh lands on me like a warm file download with a progress bar that moves smoothly, no jitter. We talk. About work, about hobbies. She works in a lab doing something with cell lines that I try to not interpret as a metaphor. She asks what I do and I say something about security consulting and education and the word “reformed” is in there, because honesty is both policy and patch. She doesn’t flinch. Her eyebrows do a small arch, the good kind. “So like, ethical hacker?” she says, and I nod, and we share that look where both people are trying to quantify the ethical in front of the hacker, and then the server arrives and takes our orders and I pretend I don’t see the way his tablet has a screen protector bubbling at the corner where anyone could slip under it with a fingernail and pop the whole thing off. No audits, I remind myself, eat your dinner. We discover the fandom by accident. There’s a Planeswalker symbol peeking out of her wallet when she goes to get her ID for the beer she orders. My mouth moves before I can route it through the filter: “Gideon or Jace?” She freezes, then grins. “Liliana, obviously. What are you, a blue control player?” I feel seen and accused and it’s correct. “Look, counterspells are a lifestyle.” She leans in. “I had a mono-red phase in college, but we don’t talk about it.” The restaurant becomes friendlier by degrees. The music is a playlist that can’t commit to a genre and I forgive it because it’s trying. Our food arrives. She steals a fry without negotiating for it and it feels like a handshake protocol we didn’t have to write down. We trade stories of awful combo decks and table flips and the exact tone of disdain reserved for someone who takes a twenty-minute turn and says “just one more thing.” Her laugh does that leap again. I am buoyant. Maybe this is easy. Maybe I can be a person who sits in a restaurant and thinks about the shape of someone’s mouth instead of the shape of someone’s threat model. And then her phone lights up. It vibrates against the wood like a bug trying to flee. She glances down, makes that face people make when their attention splits and then, because she is polite, she picks it up to silence it. Her hand moves in that little unconscious pattern people do when they’re swiping a lock or sketching a line on a grid. The phone is one of those Androids with the nine-dot pattern unlock, and she drags her finger without really looking. I don’t think about it. My eyes are magnets for repetition and low entropy. My brain is a hash table for patterns I’m not supposed to store. It’s an L. Bottom left to top middle, right one, down one. Then a little tail. She does it twice because the first swipe doesn’t register. There are smudges on her screen, old oily evidence of previous unlocks, and I hate that I could unlock her life with a napkin and some sunlight. My mouth, again, traitor, says: “You might want to change that.” Her head snaps up. “What?” I have options. I could cough. I could smile and ask about her siblings like a normal mammal. But the part of me that runs automatic background scanners is already hacking my tongue. “Your unlock pattern,” I say, and I hear the word ‘your’ come out like a prybar. “It’s… easy to shoulder-surf. High probability. L-shapes are like, the most common. With smudge analysis…” I stop, which is to say I run out of buffer. She blinks. There is a microsecond where her face is blank, like a loading spinner. Then the color in her cheeks changes. She sets her phone down with the gentlest possible contempt, like a person placing a glass in the sink instead of throwing it at a wall. “Wow,” she says. I want to roll back the commit. I want to push an emergency patch to myself. “I—sorry. That was—” There is a version of me that says “caring,” another that says “contextual,” a third that says “nonconsensual.” None of them make it to production. “No,” she says, and her voice is small and even. “It’s fine. You’re… that’s what you do, right?” I think about the ten-thousand hours I put into becoming a person who can see the skeleton behind anything. I think about the first time I got a stranger’s email because they used the same password on their social media and their bank, and how the part of me that was addicted wasn’t to the access but to the fact that it was there. I think about how I got caught because I wanted to get caught, and I think about how I got better because someone I hurt decided to believe I could. I hear myself say, “Sometimes I forget that consent applies to advice.” Her eyes soften without her smiling. She is thinking. Her eyebrows make that small bridge they make when she is both annoyed and curious. “It’s just a phone,” she says, but the way she presses the lock button is defensive. “It’s not,” I say. “Not anymore. But that’s mine to manage, not yours.” I invert my hands on the table and show my palms like I’m demonstrating I’m unarmed. It is a silly gesture. It helps. She takes a piece of her burger and holds it for a second like evidence. “Do you do that with people, too? Not just their phones? Like, do you look at someone’s… I don’t know. Walk and decide their secrets?” I could lie. I could say no, that I see people as closed systems until invited. But this night is going well because I didn’t lie. “I notice patterns,” I say. “It took me a long time to learn that not every pattern is a vulnerability. And even if it is, it’s not mine to exploit. Or to name.” She chews. She is composing a response and testing it for defects. I let her. I take a sip of my water and catch the WiFi password out of the corner of my eye again. LatteLove2020!. The network name is CaféGuest. There is a locked one below it called CaféPOS. The POS system’s tablet is logged in as admin. The WiFi is open. If I were the person I used to be, I would have already pivoted. I focus on the condensation ring forming beneath my glass and try to love it like a miracle. “Okay,” she says finally. “You’re not wrong. About the pattern. But, like… can you not tell me in a way that feels like you just watched me leave my diary on the bus?” “Yes,” I say. “No. I mean—yes, I can not do that. I can ask if you want input instead of just… inputting.” She smiles at her own reaction, like she’s watching herself decide something and is a little embarrassed by her own mercy. “Ask then.” “Do you want a suggestion on how to lock your phone in a way that makes me less itchy?” “That,” she says, and exhales, “is so much better. Yes.” “Use a passphrase,” I say. “Like a sentence you can type. Long. Not predictable. Something only you would know. And biometric is okay as long as you can disable it quickly if you’re worried about someone making you unlock it.” She nods. “Cool. I’ll do that. And I will tell my future self that a hacker on a date bullied me into using longer passwords.” “I accept being the villain in a story where your bank account is safe.” “White hat villain,” she says, and it lands with a tiny parachute. We both let it drift. The server appears and asks if we want dessert. She looks at me and I can see that she is running a calculation that has nothing to do with sugar. I nod like a normal mammal. We split a slice of something chocolate and complicated, and she uses her fork to draw a shape in the dusting of powdered sugar on the plate. It’s not an L. It’s a wandering line, looping, almost a spiral. I pretend not to see it. She notices me not noticing and the corner of her mouth lifts. “So,” she says, “what’s the nerdiest thing you’ve done for Magic?” I tell her about the time I wrote a solver to draft terrible decks on purpose because I wanted to see if I could win on suboptimality, and she tells me about a cosplay that involved dangerously sharp foam pauldrons and a glue gun burn she’s oddly proud of. We make a plan to go to FNM like two high schoolers making a plan to jump a fence. The WiFi password leers at me and I ignore it again, and each time I ignore it I feel a small muscle grow. At some point her phone buzzes again. She flips it, looks, and then does not unlock it. She sets it face down. “I’ll change it later,” she says, almost to herself, and then looks at me. “Thank you. For… adapting.” “I’m in beta,” I say. “Lots of updates.” “Do you have a changelog?” she asks, and I laugh and say sure: reduced unsolicited advice by forty percent, improved empathy parsing, patched exploit where I equate intimacy with disclosure. We pay. I tip in cash because I don’t like the tablet asking me to choose a number in front of someone. Outside, the air is cooler and has the metallic taste of a city about to exhale. There is a man smoking by the door under a sign that says No Smoking. The sign is peeling at the corner. Everything peels at the corner if you touch it enough. “Walk you to your car?” I ask, and I brace for no. “Yeah,” she says, and it’s easy. We walk. Our steps try to sync and fail and then succeed, which feels like a metaphor that doesn’t insult either of us. At her car she turns and she is close enough that I can see the smudge of chocolate on her lip, left corner. I do not tell her. I do not wipe it. I put my hands in my pockets and let her be a system with full autonomy. “I’ll text you,” she says, and unlocks her car with a beep that sounds like acceptance. “And I’ll have a passphrase by then.” “Make it long,” I say, and she rolls her eyes in a way that is not a door closing. She leaves. I stand there with the streetlight making the world a grainy photograph. I have the urge to go back in and write the restaurant a pen-test report on a napkin. Instead I get in my car and commit to master: tonight I noticed a vulnerability, and I asked for permission before I patched it. It’s not glamorous. There’s no write-up that will get me a thousand claps. But there’s a quiet between my ribs that feels like a server room with the fans humming at a low, steady pitch. Uptime is good. Latency is human. And the password taped to the counter stays taped, and I leave it there, and that is its own kind of strength check passed.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative successfully captures the perspective of a reformed white hat hacker navigating a first date. The protagonist's internal monologue effectively conveys their habitual security-focused mindset while showing their struggle to connect on a human level. The piece excels in creating a distinctive voice that blends technical terminology with emotional vulnerability. The hacker's perspective is consistently maintained through metaphors and observations that relate to their professional background: "Her laugh lands on me like a warm file download with a progress bar that moves smoothly, no jitter" and "I feel a small muscle grow" when resisting the urge to exploit security weaknesses. The character development is nuanced, showing the protagonist's genuine effort to reform while acknowledging their ingrained habits. The internal conflict is palpable when they notice the date's insecure phone pattern and struggle with whether to mention it. The fallout from this faux pas is handled realistically, with the date's initial offense gradually softening into understanding. The prose is elegant without being overwrought, using technical language in a way that characterizes the narrator without alienating the reader. Descriptions are vivid and specific: "a flash of green scarf and a shiver of bangs that try to behave and don't." The writing maintains a good balance between technical observations and emotional insights. However, there are moments where the narrative becomes slightly meandering, particularly in the middle section where the protagonist reflects on their past. While these reflections provide important character context, they momentarily slow the pace of the date scene. The dialogue, though limited as appropriate for an internal monologue piece, is natural and reveals character. The shared interest in Magic: The Gathering creates an authentic connection between the characters, and their conversation about phone security feels believable rather than contrived. The ending avoids an overly neat resolution while still providing a sense of growth. The protagonist's decision not to exploit the restaurant's security vulnerabilities represents meaningful character development without suggesting complete transformation. The final image of "a server room with the fans humming at a low, steady pitch" effectively ties together the technical and emotional aspects of the character. Overall, this is a strong piece that successfully fulfills the prompt requirements while creating a distinctive voice and emotionally engaging narrative. + First-person unique perspective: Overthinking It — Score: 95.7
Prompt:
Overthinking It Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of an intelligent 8th-grade girl with social anxiety who has developed a crush on a classmate. The narrative takes place during a group science project where they're paired together, as she cycles through rehearsed conversations while second-guessing each potential approach. Her inner thoughts should reveal the gap between her articulate internal voice and her difficulty expressing herself aloud, her fears of coming across as desperate or weird, and the exhausting process of monitoring her every word, expression, and movement for potential embarrassment. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Okay, it's fine. It's fine. It's a group project, not a confession. We're paired together because Ms. Patel did it randomly and not because the universe is trying to make me crumble in front of the human embodiment of a golden retriever in a hoodie. Breathe. Say something like, “We should probably divide the tasks,” like a normal person. Normal people divide tasks. Normal people do not plan their sentences like chess moves. He’s sitting next to me. Why is he so close? Because we’re partners. Right. His elbow is on the table, and his pencil is tapping out an idiotically perfect rhythm like he doesn't even know rhythm exists. He smells like laundry detergent and graphite, and there's that sharp, nasal sting—ammonia. Right. The janitor's mop water. Ms. Patel made a big show of apologizing about it. “Quick cleanup, sorry about the smell,” and then all the windows were cracked open just enough to tease but not enough to save. It's cutting through everything. Brain-singe. Focus. Task division. Talk. “I can—” I start, and the word slides out weirdly thin and brittle, like glass. He glances, a flicker, not even a full look, which is somehow worse. “I can take notes,” I say, and it comes out too fast, like a burst of air from a balloon. He smiles. He has a nice smile. Stop noticing his smile. “Cool,” he says. “I’ll do the measuring stuff? Like, the… what’s it called?” See? This is a door. You know the word. Caliper. Be calm. Say, “We’ll use the digital caliper to measure the mass change—no, that’s not right, calipers don’t measure mass.” You know that. Abort. Okay, just say, “The digital scale,” like a human. “The scale,” I manage, mercifully, and nod, which is fine except it’s too many nods, so I stop nodding and then realize I’ve probably stopped mid-nod and now I look like a broken dashboard bobblehead. I pretend it was a head-tilt. Casual. Very casual. My neck feels like a puppet string someone keeps jerking. He reaches for the small plastic cup and bumps the beaker, and a tiny slosh of clear water shivers to the rim. It’s our project: investigating the rates of dissolution. Salt in water, hot and cold. Simple, controlled, safe. Except my heart is beating like we borrowed the hot plate for it. I visualize my face from across the room, the way people always say to do when you're practicing a speech. An average face. Not weird. Last time I tried this at home the mirror made me cry. Don't think about that. “Do you want the hot water or the cold?” he asks. This is a question anyone can answer. Responses: A) “I can do hot,” because I have better reaction times and we need to be precise. B) “Cold,” because I always was warned about hot plates and my mother’s voice is a lighthouse for caution. C) “Either is fine,” neutral, friendly, flexible. Avoiding the impression of control freak. Choose C. Yes. C is safe. C is Switzerland. C is me. Why is the ammonia smell getting stronger? It’s like it’s crawling up my nostrils and building a little chemical fort. Focus. “Either is fine,” I say, and smile. My lips are dry. The smile feels like it could crack off my face and clatter onto the table like a broken shell. “Cool,” he says again, and grabs the hot plate. “I’ll do hot. You can write stuff down.” Why does he keep saying cool? Is it like a verbal placeholder he uses to be approachable? Do I say cool? No, not anymore, because one time last year I tried to say it and I sounded like I was quoting a brochure about sunglasses. Note: do not mirror his words; you'll sound like a chameleon with a marketing degree. Write the title: "Effects of Temperature on Rate of Dissolution." My handwriting is neat. Too neat? Neat like a teacher's pet? The line of my pen is so straight it's bragging. Make it a little sloppy. No, that seems fake. My hand twitches and makes a tiny wobble in the "R" and I go cold. Now it looks like I'm pretending to be a human. Relax. No one is watching your “R.” He’s measuring out salt with a plastic spoon, tapping it once, twice, then pouring, and the grains sparkle like crushed quartz. Say something interesting. Not weird. Not “I read that in supersaturated solutions crystals can suddenly appear if you introduce a seed.” That is a fun fact but will make you sound like a trivia machine with legs. Say, “Make sure it’s level,” because that’s practical. Yes. “Make sure it’s level,” I say, softer than I meant, so it lands like a suggestion you make to a cat who doesn’t know English. “Right,” he says, and bends down so his eyes are at the level of the measuring line. He actually does it. On the inside I give myself a tiny high five that feels exactly like nothing, like clapping underwater. What if he thinks I'm bossy? What if he thinks I'm trying to be better than him? I want him to think I’m smart, but not in a way that makes his ego feel like a balloon someone’s squeezing. People say guys don't like it when girls are smarter. That is probably a generalized misconception and I should reject it, but also he once made a joke about losing to his little sister at chess and he looked defensive even though he laughed. Examine data before drawing conclusions. You’re doing it again. You’re doing the think-loop. Stop. Just be here. Ammonia again. It’s like the smell pierces a tiny hole in the thought balloon and every sentence deflates. My eyes water for a second. I blink like I mean it. My eyelashes feel heavy. Is there a right number of blinks for seeming normal? Maybe three. Three is a good number. Not too many or you look like you’re sending Morse code. He looks at my notes. “You have good handwriting,” he says, which is like telling a bridge it has nice beams. Compliment acceptance script: A) Say thank you. B) Deflect. Do not deflect with “It’s nothing,” or “Yours is good too,” unless that’s true. Is his handwriting good? He writes like a haunted spider. So, A. Say thank you. Easy. “Thanks,” I say, and clamp my teeth around anything else that wants to come out. My mouth is dry again. Drink water. No, there's the ammonia in the room and I don't want to taste it. Does ammonia have a taste? Stop. He's not thinking about ammonia. Say something back. Ask him about his hoodie, about the basketball game he won, about the formula. Ask him anything. Pick one. Hoodies are safe. “I like your hoodie.” No, that sounds like I'm flirting. You are kind of flirting. No, you're not. You're not allowed to flirt. You're just being nice. But he might think—Okay, what about the game? You saw him score and everyone cheered and he did that little shrug like he couldn't help it. “The game was good.” That sounds vague. “Nice layup last night.” That’s too specific. He’ll think I memorize his layups. “How’s basketball?” That’s like asking a fish how water is. He pours the hot water. Steam curls up and finds the ammonia in the air and they dance, and it hits my throat like a school nurse's office in August. The clock ticks, loud, a metronome for my inner stupid. He’s staring at the dissolving salt, the way it clouds the water, then clears, little crystals disappearing like snowflakes melting on a tongue. “This is kind of cool,” he says. Cool. Again. It is cool. Science is cool. You can say that without irony. “Yeah,” I say, and it comes out a thread. “It’s…” I have a whole paragraph in my head about molecules moving faster in hot water, collisions increasing, the solvent’s kinetic energy overcoming the lattice energy of the solute. In my head it's clean and bright and I'm giving a TED Talk to my crocheted stuffed animals. Out loud it shrinks to a pebble. “Temperature,” I say. “Makes it go faster.” “Right,” he says, not like it’s a revelation or an insult, just a confirmation, and he smiles again, and I think I must be imagining the way my chest feels like someone loosened a knot there. Write down the time. Start the stopwatch. My thumb hovers. Press. The second travels like a grace note around my brain. If I stop looking at my hand I will press the wrong button. I press the right one. The digits begin to climb. It’s ridiculous how proud I am. Say, “Do you want to do the cold trial?” He will say, “Sure,” and then we will switch and I will be the one scooping ice, and my fingers will turn pink and I will wrestle with the scoop like a competent person. My mouth opens. The ammonia swoops in like a bird and I cough. It’s a small cough, but in my head it’s amplified, a foghorn. My nose stings. He glances. Great. Now he thinks I’m sick. Now he’s thinking about me being sick around his perfect hoodie and basketball lungs. Explain it. Say, “Sorry, it’s the ammonia.” That’s a weird sentence. People who say “ammonia” out loud sound like lab techs or complaint emails. Say, “Sorry, the smell.” Yes. That’s human. “Sorry, the…” I start, and then my throat decides to sandpaper itself and somehow the word that comes out is a whistly “smell,” which is the least attractive sound I’ve ever made. It would make babies cry. My ears heat up. “Oh, yeah,” he says, and waves a hand in front of his nose. “It’s strong.” Okay. He did not recoil. He did not die from secondhand embarrassment. He agrees. There is solidarity in this chemical warfare. I am not alone in this classroom; we are two humans in a mild cloud of murder-clean. Breathe. Not too deep. My lungs disagree and take a big drag of ammonia anyway and I swallow and it tastes like a battery. “Do you… want to do the cold one?” I say, and I almost sound normal, except my voice fades at the end like it’s walking away without me. “Sure,” he says. “Switch?” We switch. Our hands brush for a second, and the skin at the base of my thumb registers it like an earthquake: tiny magnitude, epicenter right under my bones. Don’t jerk away. Don’t linger. Perfectly neutral brush. Perfectly fine. My face does not change. It probably changes. I can feel my cheeks. You can see heat. Everyone can see heat. Stop thinking about your cheeks. The ice scoops and crackles into the beaker, clicks like teeth. I pour water, careful but not too careful, measuring it with my eyes because he is already doing the thermometer count on his side and I don’t want to be the slow one, the one who holds up the train with her anxiety baggage. He says, “Do we stir the same number of times? For consistency?” Yes. Yes, marry me. Or, no, don’t say that. Say, “Yeah, thirty seconds clockwise,” which is what Ms. Patel said, and not like you’re thrilled he remembers variables. “Yeah, thirty seconds clockwise,” I say, and our eyes meet for half a second and jump away, like we both glanced at a place we’re not supposed to look. Stir. Thirty seconds. This is quantifiable. This is safety. The spoon swirls and taps glass, and the salt vanishes slower, like it’s thinking about it. Write down the time. Observer bias: calcium in my fingers making them clumsy. That’s not what calcium does. Whatever. Shut up, brain. Write. He leans in a little, looking at the meniscus. He smells like detergent and pencil, like clean laundry and paper fibers. The ammonia tries to bully its way back into the sensory club and I tell it to get bent, and I cough once, tiny. Is cough-tiny a word? No. My brain invents nonsense when people I like are within a radius of my real face. He says, “I saw you at the game,” out of nowhere, and the room tilts. There were hundreds of people. Why would he—No, he’s just being polite. He saw me socially existing on the bleachers with a book in my lap pretending to be normal. My mouth is a small dry desert. “Oh,” I say. There is a long, empty hallway in that word. Fill it. “You were—” Great? Amazing? Fantastic? “Good,” I say, which is a toddler word, but it’s safe, it’s non-committal. He will not think I have a shrine to his layups. He grins. “Thanks.” There’s a place inside me where all the good sentences live. The ones where I say, “I like how you always help Jordan with his math homework and you don’t make him feel dumb,” and “You’re gentle with the lab equipment even when you joke like you don’t care,” and “I get nervous talking but I think you’re kind.” Those sentences sit in a sunlit room and never come down the stairs. I send them messages and they send back thumbs-up emojis. We log the second trial. Our data is clean. Our rates align with our hypothesis. We’re efficient together. I want to say that. “We’re a good team.” Is that flirting or factual? It can be both. I breathe. Ammonia sneaks in and stings me like a reminder to stay real. “We’re a good team,” I say, and it sounds okay. It sounds like something a person would say. “Yeah,” he says. He looks actually happy. Not the performative happy, the kind like sunlight on a tile floor. “We should, uh, do the poster together after school? Library?” After school. Library. My mother will say yes. I will wear the blue sweater that doesn’t make me feel like a question mark. Do not explode. Do not betray your internal fireworks. Smile. Not too big. Not too small. Medium. Goldilocks smile. “Sure,” I say, and my voice is almost steady. “I—” The ammonia darts in like a little assassin and I cough, then laugh at the cough, which is a mistake. Laughing at coughs is the second most awkward thing, right after saluting your teacher by accident like I did in sixth grade. I want to disappear into the grout between the tiles. He laughs too, in a nice way, like we share the joke that the janitor is trying to gas us into becoming better citizens. “Cool,” he says. Cool. Cool. Stop. The stopwatch beeps. We both jump and then both pretend we didn’t, and I write down the final time with precise digits that will make Ms. Patel nod. It’s fine. It’s fine. It’s just a group project. It’s just two people in a room with a little math and a smell trying to sabotage them. I stay in my body. I use my hands. I let sentences be small and still true. I imagine that sunlit room inside me, and I invite one of the big sentences to come down. It hesitates on the landing. “See you after school,” I say, and it’s small, but it’s brave enough. He nods, and I mirror him once, just once, a well-timed yes, and then I look at my paper as if I wrote everything on purpose. The ammonia thins as someone opens a door. The air loosens. My shoulders come down a millimeter, maybe two. I can breathe without measuring how it looks. We clean up. Salt grains cling to the table like constellations that don’t know their names. He’s humming under his breath, and I realize I feel tired, like I ran a race sitting still. It’s okay. Later I’ll lie on my bed and replay everything and edit it and assign scores. For now, I just put the beaker in the bin. For now, I tell myself that being a little weird is not a felony, that the sunlit room has a staircase, that tomorrow I might be brave again on purpose, even if the air stings.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative brilliantly captures the internal monologue of an 8th-grade girl with social anxiety who has developed a crush on her science project partner. The piece excels at portraying the gap between her articulate internal voice and her difficulty expressing herself aloud. The protagonist's thought process is rendered with exceptional authenticity. Her constant second-guessing, rehearsing of potential responses, and overthinking of every interaction creates a vivid portrait of social anxiety. The writer skillfully employs a stream-of-consciousness style that feels genuine to an intelligent but anxious 8th grader, with thoughts that spiral, fragment, and loop back on themselves. The narrative effectively uses the science project setting to create natural moments of interaction while maintaining focus on the protagonist's internal experience. The ammonia smell from the janitor's cleaning becomes a recurring motif that grounds the narrative in physical reality while serving as both an obstacle and occasional relief from her overthinking. The character's voice is consistently maintained throughout. Her intelligence shines through in her scientific knowledge and vocabulary, while her social anxiety manifests in her hyper-awareness of every word, gesture, and facial expression. The contrast between her rich internal life and her stilted external communication is portrayed with remarkable consistency. The prose strikes an excellent balance between the protagonist's sophisticated vocabulary and the authentic voice of an 8th grader. Sentences like "My handwriting is neat. Too neat? Neat like a teacher's pet? The line of my pen is so straight it's bragging" perfectly capture both her intelligence and her adolescent insecurities. The narrative creates genuine emotional engagement through its honest portrayal of social anxiety and young romance. The protagonist's vulnerability and her small victories (successfully saying "We're a good team") are deeply relatable and touching. The piece avoids melodrama while still conveying the genuine emotional intensity of adolescent experience. The ending feels earned and appropriate to the character's journey. There's a small but meaningful shift as she acknowledges her own bravery and considers the possibility of future courage, without an unrealistic transformation that would undermine the authenticity of her character. The writing excels at sensory details that ground the reader in the physical experience—the ammonia smell, the sound of ice crackling, the brief touch of hands—while maintaining focus on the protagonist's internal experience. These details create a vivid, immersive reading experience. Overall, this is an exceptional piece that demonstrates a deep understanding of social anxiety, adolescent experience, and the craft of first-person narrative. The writer has created a character whose internal life is complex and compelling, and whose struggles and small triumphs feel authentic and meaningful. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 20 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 19 Emotionally Engaging: 20 Emotionally Complex: 19 Coherent: 20 Meandering: 2 Weak Dialogue: 1 Tell-Don't-Show: 1 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 20 Overall Impression: 20
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 20.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 19.0, Emotionally Engaging: 20.0, Emotionally Complex: 19.0, Coherent: 20.0, Meandering: 2.0, Weak Dialogue: 1.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 1.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 20.0, Overall Impression: 20.0
+ First-person unique perspective: Rehearsing Rejection — Score: 94.3
Prompt:
Rehearsing Rejection Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of someone with borderline personality disorder who frequently plays out worst-case scenarios of how friends and loved ones might judge them. They construct elaborate internal dialogues, complete with imagined criticisms and their own defensive responses. The narrative takes place as they prepare to meet a close friend & recent lover, who has been somewhat distant lately, triggering their abandonment fears. Their inner monologue should reveal how they cycle between anticipating rejection, mentally rehearsing confrontations, and developing preemptive resentments as protective measures. Incorporate the *actual* events & interactions that are *not* in fact judgemental or involving rejection (in fact, the opposite), and represent how these are interpreted, how the validation & love is desperately felt & needed -- and then immediately questioned. Capture the cognitive dissonance in this struggle. Include moments where they briefly recognize the pattern but struggle to interrupt it, showing limited (and selective) self awareness, competing with the compelling nature of these imagined scenarios. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
I practice it again, the scene where you sigh and say you don’t think we should see each other anymore, like I’m a messy drawer you’d prefer to keep closed. I guess the exact words you’ll use as I pull my shoes on: “You’re amazing, but I can’t do this right now.” My mouth has an answer ready—curated, clipped, cool. That’s fine. I totally get it. I’m good. I’m fine. I master the curve of indifference with my lips while my fingers pick at the loose thread on my sleeve until it almost splits the seam. I run the conversation a second time with a different lighting: you’re disappointed instead of apologetic. “I thought you’d be more… stable.” I say, “That’s unfair,” and I list the twelve things I did to prove I can be human-shaped. I itemize. I reference a spreadsheet in my head. I am convincing, righteous. I hate that I need to be convincing. I lean toward the hallway mirror and see it there, the angled shoulders, the tight chin, an animal stance. I look like I’m bracing for impact before there’s even a car. My reflection looks like it knows something I don’t, like it’s already seen the cliff edge and measured the drop. I adjust my hair, then turn away because if I watch too long I’ll start narrating myself again: the tragic heroine of a soap opera that never ends because the writers are lazy and love cliffhangers. Phone vibrates. Your name on the screen. A bubble: running 10 late, subway delay. A second bubble, almost immediate: sorry sorry. A third: can’t wait to see you. I read them and feel my throat soften and then clamp hard again. Can’t wait to see you. Translation: perform positivity, smooth me, don’t be difficult. I draft two replies and delete both. Finally I send: ok. No exclamation point. Let you come to me. I pretend it’s strategy. I pretend I’m not counting the ten minutes. I sit on the edge of the bed and stage another confrontation—this one where I get there first. I say, “You’ve been distant.” You say, “Work,” or “Stress,” or “Parents.” I don’t accept that answer in this version, because in this version I’m tired of being reasonable. I say, “Just say it if you’re done,” and my voice is knife-clean. You blink slowly, wounded. You say, “I’m not done.” I say, “Then act like it.” Strong. Stronger than I ever am in the moment. I press replay and tweak my tone to sound less desperate. I practice being the person who walks out first, who leaves you mid-sentence, who doesn’t wait around for secondhand crumbs of attention like a dog under a table. The door buzzer goes off inside my chest even though no one has pressed it. I stand up too fast, dizzy. I grab my bag. I check my messages again just in case you’ve reneged in the last 30 seconds. You haven’t. You haven’t and still my body is doing the funeral. On the subway I watch a kid fold a paper crane for his sister. It looks like freedom, all those simple creases that somehow become wings. I imagine telling you about that and then I imagine you smiling, putting your hand on my knee, saying, “That’s sweet,” and the sweetness landing like a small blessing. Then I rewrite it so your smile is strained and your hand is absent. Then I rewrite it again so I say nothing at all because why offer anything when it can be turned down. Why bring anything to the altar when the god might be asleep. At the café, the table in the corner is miraculously empty. I choose it like I need the wall at my back. The waitress puts down water and her hand brushes mine and I almost apologize for existing. I pretend I’m composed, because people say that word around me like it’s a compliment, like I’ve performed something requiring applause. I hold the glass with careful fingers and rehearse new lines: You know, I’ve been thinking. You know, I need to set some boundaries. The performance version of me can do boundaries like she’s putting furniture down in a room and deciding where things go. The real me picks up the couch and then lies underneath it. The door opens and there you are in your too-big coat, the one I once teased you about and you told me it was your ex’s and you didn’t look away from me when you said it, like you were offering truth without seeing if I’d swallow it. You see me and your face does that whole-body smile. My heart lurches toward you with dog-under-table intensity and I mentally yank its leash. “Hey,” you say, and you put your hand on my shoulder when you sit. It’s warm. It’s present. It’s not reluctant at all. It makes my eyes sting because my body keeps receipts of every time you’ve touched me like I might disappear otherwise. “Hi,” I say, and it comes out too soft. I straighten it. “How are you?” You tell me about the subway delay, the guy who serenaded the entire car with a ukulele, how a woman next to you sang along badly and loudly and it made you grin. You ask me if I’ve eaten. You ask me if I’m okay, and your eyes search my face and then you smile like you know I’ll say I am even if I’m not. “I’m fine,” I say, automatic. I want to say I missed you. I want to say where did you go when you were busy. I want to say did I do something. Instead I ask about work and you groan theatrically and roll your eyes, and I feel the relief uncurl and then immediately interrogate it. It’s too easy, right? You’re overcompensating. People perform warmth when they’re hiding something, don’t they? You’re trying to keep me pliant. “I brought you something,” you say, and pull a small paper bag from your coat, grease spots already marking the bottom. “They had those cardamom buns you like.” I’m a terrible actor because the joy surfaces without my consent. I make a sound I hate—too bright, too grateful. I snap it in half with my fingers and put a piece in my mouth and the sugar hits and I think, see, this is love. And right behind it, why now. Did you feel guilty? Are you giving me sweets like a pacifier? “It’s dumb,” you say, laughing. “I saw them and thought of you. That’s all.” I nod. I put a piece on your napkin. You eat it and lick sugar from your thumb and I imagine taking your hand and bringing it to my mouth and then I police myself for imagining too hard. I hear the speech I wrote earlier and it clatters in me, suddenly foolish among napkins and pastry flakes. You reach across and tuck a hair behind my ear in this instinctive way you have that tells me it isn’t a gesture you’re building toward a breakup. It feels like the opposite of leaving. Which is suspicious. “I’m sorry I’ve been… you know,” you say. “I’ve had a lot going on. I should’ve said something.” I nod like it’s nothing. Inside me, fireworks and alarms overlap. I run both scripts simultaneously: the one where I’m understanding and the one where I’m not. “It’s okay,” I say, and I can hear the doubting committee in the back row of my brain whispering don’t let them get away with it. Demand more. Don’t be so easy. They will leave if you don’t make them work. They will leave if you make them work. You are a multiple-choice test where all answers are wrong. “I missed you,” you add, simple as water, like you’re saying the sky is blue. I freeze. I melt. I freeze again. I look at your mouth to see if the words left marks. “I missed you too,” I say, and somewhere a small cynical voice clears its throat: don’t gush. Don’t offer your throat. Protect. I take a sip of water to swallow it all down. I taste sugar and metal. You tell me about your dad’s health scare—the tests, the waiting room coffee that tastes like panic. You didn’t call because you didn’t know what to say. You didn’t call because you were busy holding your own breath. The graph in my head with arrows that point to “not caring” and “getting bored” redraws itself reluctantly. I can feel the pivot, but it grinds. The part of me that built a case is annoyed. It has a closing argument ready. It has charts. “I wish you’d told me,” I say, too quiet, and your face falls and I rush to soften. “Not to fix it. Just to know.” “Yeah,” you say. “I know. I’m learning.” That word hits something tender. Learning implies a future where we keep doing this, where there’s more to learn. It offers continuity, and I want to lie down in that word like a warm patch of sunlight. Immediately, I flip it. Learning also means you might never learn. That you might use it as a pass to keep hurting me. You reach for my hand and I let you. Your thumb draws circles on that paper-thin skin between knuckles. Real. Present. The committee says, don’t get used to it. The committee says, you know what comes next. It shows me the montage of people turning away, the backs of heads, the empty spaces where they sat. It tells me to rehearse goodbyes when hellos run long. “I care about you,” you say, like you’re setting a cup on a table carefully so it doesn’t spill. “I know,” I answer too fast, and you laugh because you know I don’t, not in the simple way. You squeeze my hand. You order coffee for both of us without asking because you remember how I take it. The waitress calls me honey absentmindedly and somehow that hurts, too, because I want to be only yours and then I scold myself for wanting anything that much. I catch my reflection again in the café window, double-exposed over the street. Same shoulders, less angle. I know the pattern, I do. The therapist voice in my head says name it, don’t shame it. My own voice says drown it. There’s a fleeting second where I see the alternate timeline: I say, hey, I spin stories when I get scared. I admit out loud that I’ve spent the last week fighting with a ghost version of you. The second passes. My tongue goes heavy. It feels too dangerous to hand you that power. It feels too dangerous not to. You nudge the bun toward me, the last sugared edge. “Finish it,” you say, and I do because it’s easier than finishing sentences. The sweetness is ridiculous. It settles in me like proof and then like a trick. I watch your face while you talk and annotate it with imagined footnotes: when you glance away, I write disinterest; when you lean in, I write manipulation; when you kiss my cheek as we stand to leave, quick and soft, I write don’t be fooled. My skin burns where your lips were. It’s both blessing and curse. I catalog both. Outside, the air is fragile with cold. You loop your arm through mine without asking and we walk like that, easy. For a few steps the committee is silent, as if even they need air. My body believes, for those steps. It presses closer. It memorizes the exact pressure of your sleeve against my coat. Then someone inside coughs and the noise starts up again, quiet but steady. I love you, they say, and immediately: prove it. You’re here, and immediately: when will you leave. I breathe. I match my stride to yours. I let it all be true for a block, then two, before I start building the courtroom again in my head, just in case.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative brilliantly captures the internal experience of someone with borderline personality disorder (BPD). The piece excels at depicting the protagonist's constant rehearsal of rejection scenarios, their hypervigilance for signs of abandonment, and the cognitive distortions that characterize BPD. The narrative structure is particularly effective, alternating between the protagonist's catastrophizing internal monologues and the actual, much more benign reality of their interaction with their friend/lover. The contrast between what they imagine will happen and what actually occurs creates a powerful tension that drives the piece forward. The writing demonstrates exceptional psychological insight. The protagonist's tendency to "practice" conversations, their hyperanalysis of every word and gesture, and their immediate questioning of positive interactions all ring true to the BPD experience. Lines like "I master the curve of indifference with my lips while my fingers pick at the loose thread on my sleeve until it almost splits the seam" beautifully capture the disconnect between external composure and internal turmoil. The prose is elegant without being overwrought. Metaphors like "I press replay and tweak my tone to sound less desperate" and "The performance version of me can do boundaries like she's putting furniture down in a room and deciding where things go. The real me picks up the couch and then lies underneath it" are vivid and insightful. The writing maintains a consistent voice throughout—introspective, anxious, and self-aware in a way that feels authentic to someone who recognizes their patterns but struggles to break them. The narrative successfully incorporates moments of self-awareness ("I know the pattern, I do. The therapist voice in my head says name it, don't shame it") while showing how compelling and difficult to interrupt these thought patterns are. The ending avoids both unrealistic transformation and complete despair, instead showing a momentary reprieve from the intrusive thoughts before they inevitably return—a realistic portrayal of living with BPD. The piece is emotionally complex, showing the protagonist's desperate need for validation alongside their immediate questioning of it. The cognitive dissonance is palpable in lines like "I freeze. I melt. I freeze again." The narrative also effectively captures the selective self-awareness characteristic of BPD—the protagonist can recognize their patterns intellectually but remains emotionally trapped in them. If there's any weakness, it might be that the piece occasionally relies on metaphors that, while beautiful, slightly distance us from the raw emotional experience. However, this is a minor critique of what is otherwise an exceptionally well-crafted and psychologically accurate portrayal. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 19 Emotionally Engaging: 20 Emotionally Complex: 20 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 20 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 19.0, Emotionally Engaging: 20.0, Emotionally Complex: 20.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 20.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Physical-spatial: Blood Debt — Score: 86.9
Prompt:
"Blood Debt" Write a vivid third-person narrative depicting an unsanctioned underground duel between two talented but hot-headed martial artists. Their schools have been embroiled in a generations-old rivalry, and despite strict prohibitions from their masters, these two younger fighters arrange a secret confrontation fueled by personal pride and simmering animosity. - **One fighter** represents **Jigen-ryū**, a traditional, aggressive style practiced historically by elite samurai clans. Its practitioners emphasize explosive offense, decisive strikes, and overwhelming speed. Known historically for their arrogance and disdain toward outsiders, practitioners consider their art superior and untouchable. - **The opposing fighter** employs a form of historical **Piguaquan**, a Chinese martial art traditionally practiced by commoners, bodyguards, and street fighters. This style emphasizes whipping, circular strikes, rapid footwork, unpredictable angles of attack, and evasive maneuvers. Practitioners often come from lower social classes and view the traditional elite as pretentious and detached from true combat effectiveness. The fight takes place in the crumbling ruins of an abandoned temple, now functioning as a hidden arena for illicit duels. Passionate supporters from both factions surround them, wagering money, pride, and reputation on the outcome. **Essential Instructions:** Maintain absolute physical coherence throughout—clearly track fighters' positions relative to each other and their environment. Precisely depict strikes, counters, momentum shifts, and spatial dynamics, allowing readers to clearly visualize the mechanics and choreography of the fight at every moment. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
They met in the ribcage of the temple: ribs of collapsed beams arched over the cracked flagstones, paper-lantern light shifting in the cold draft. Moss grew between the floor plates. The altar was a broken slab against the eastern wall, and above it, empty eye sockets where statues had once stared. Around the two fighters, a ring of men and women pressed close, their bodies leaning inward while their whispers harried the air. Money changed hands in quick, secret gestures. Red-and-black armbands flashed on both sides, twin colors signifying opposite histories. The Jigen-ryū man stood straight as a lance to the north edge of the ring, bare feet on worn, sunken stone. His hair was clubbed back, the nape cut brutally short, his expression a clean blade. He wore a simple gi, sleeves tied up, and over his right bicep a sharp triangle of cloth—red field, black slash—the mark of his school. In his right hand he held a bokken polished down by relentless practice, wood dense as a promise. He let the tip hover low and forward, the line of the weapon aligned with his centerline, shoulders squared, hips coiled. When he exhaled, the sound was dry and clipped. Across from him to the south, the Piguaquan fighter shifted from foot to foot as if tasting the floor. A lean man with blades of cheekbone and a rope of black hair tied with a strip of threadbare silk. His armband mirrored the Jigen-ryū symbol inverted—black field, red slash—and he wore linen trousers and a sleeveless tunic, the fabric stained by rain and old sweat. He had no weapon but his own reach and the long arc of his arms. When he breathed, it was long and low, rolling through his ribcage and into his stomach as if drawn on a wheel. A gong cobbled from a rusting iron disc clanged once. The crowd hushed, then surged with whispers that chased each other like rats. They closed the distance to five paces. The Jigen-ryū fighter stepped forward half a length—heel touching, then toes sliding—compressing into a forward stance. The bokken dipped a fraction, then snapped up in a straight line toward the Piguaquan man’s brow, a jab more like a spear thrust than a sword cut. The distance was just long enough that the tip would land before the body revealed intent. The Piguaquan fighter shifted right, pivoting on the ball of his left foot. He didn’t retreat; he let the thrust cut past the left side of his face, the bokken skimming the air where his nose had been. As the wooden blade extended, he brought his left forearm up from a low chamber, whipping the back of his wrist against the flat near the tip to redirect. He didn’t try to stop the thrust; he accelerated it off-line with the flick of a catapult. The bokken struck the shoulder of a spectator with a muffled thud that drew a curse, and the Jigen-ryū fighter felt his wrist pulled across his center. He adjusted immediately. There was no pause. His right foot stamped forward and slightly left into the space the Piguaquan man had vacated, hips and shoulders following in a snap. He turned the off-line thrust into a cut, drawing the bokken in a diagonal slash from high left to low right, aiming at the ribs as he stepped across. His left hand came to the hilt for power. The strike drew a clean whoosh and carved a line of air where the Chinese fighter’s torso was already not. The Piguaquan man had ridden the initial pivot into a small counterclockwise circle. As the slash committed past, he sank his weight, right hand whipping outward in a circular backfist toward the Jigen-ryū man’s temple from just outside the arc of the bokken. His left palm shot forward at the same moment toward the elbow of the sword arm. He’d stepped in tight—inside the weapon’s strongest range, just outside the shoulders. The backfist was a scythe; the palm a wedge. The Jigen-ryū man jerked his head back a fraction. The backfist glanced along the hairline, sweat brushed aside. The palm struck the elbow with a pop that shifted the angle of the cut down into harmless air. They were chest-to-chest range now. The Jigen-ryū fighter slammed his left shoulder forward, a battering ram, and drove a knee toward the Piguaquan man’s thigh. The bokken, now trapped between bodies, he used as a bar across the front of the Chinese fighter’s hips. It was inside fighting, inelegant and punishing. The knee landed with a dull thud, and the Piguaquan man’s hip buckled a fraction. He softened into it, flowing down, his joints unlocking like ropes. Rather than resist the pressure across his hips, he spun around the bar, his right foot sweeping back and then forward in a crescent that caught the Jigen-ryū fighter’s left ankle from the outside. He didn’t kick; he scooped and tugged while his left palm slid from elbow to wrist, wrenching down and outward. The Jigen-ryū fighter’s base tilted, but his core held—hips locked forward, back straight, neck in line. He let the tilt become a drop, dropping his center of gravity suddenly like a plummeting stone. The sweep skated under him uselessly as his weight crashed down through both feet. There was a resonant thump, and dust shivered from the beams above. The crowd hissed. The Jigen-ryū fighter drove a short headbutt toward the Piguaquan man’s nose. The Chinese fighter pivoted his head left, the butt glancing along his cheekbone, and in that tight fissure of time he collapsed his torso backward, creating a hand’s breadth of space. His right arm whipped, palm first, from low to high in an arc under the bokken, targeting the Jigen-ryū man’s ribs with the heel of his palm. The strike landed with a thock over the lower right ribs. The Jigen-ryū fighter grunted, not from pain but from the shock. He answered with force: his right hip twisted sharply, and the bokken’s hilt drove like a hammer into the Piguaquan man’s left oblique. There was no room to swing, so he used the butt. They broke apart by mutual necessity. Two quick shoves—one palm on sternum, one forearm across collarbone—and they slid out to a safer measure. The Jigen-ryū fighter reset his guard, bokken angled forward, the tip tracking the other’s chest. He began to advance in a straight line, steps stamping in a rhythm: left-right-left, each landing with a snap of hips and shoulders that promised a strike at any moment. His breath came clipped: kiai held like a drawn arrow. The Piguaquan man circled clockwise, light on the balls of his feet, his steps describing a widening spiral. He stayed just beyond the tip, inviting a lunge. Lantern light painted him in amber and shadow. He cut his arms in wide, deceptive circles, wrists loose, fingers relaxed till the moment of contact. Every few seconds, he feinted a drop of level, shoulders dipping as if to charge, then rolled away. He watched the bokken, not the eyes. The Jigen-ryū fighter snapped forward, a decisive choice. Right foot drove, left followed, bokken thrusting straight as a spear at the solar plexus. The distance closed from two paces to one. As the thrust came, the Piguaquan man stepped not away but in and left, his right foot crossing his left in a tight stepping pattern that carried his torso past the line of the point. His left hand slapped the flat of the bokken near the middle, guiding it off-center to his right as his right forearm swung over the top in a whipping hammerfist toward the Jigen-ryū fighter’s forearm near the wrist. The hammerfist landed; the nerves rang. The bokken slipped a quarter inch in the Jigen-ryū fighter’s grip. He refused the disarm, clamping hard with his left hand, and rolled his right wrist, turning the thrust into an inside cut that sought the Piguaquan man’s left shoulder now that he’d moved in. It was fast, filling the space the other had entered like a closing door. The Piguaquan man dropped his weight under the arcing cut, shoulders folding, the wooden blade skimming the cloth of his tunic. As it passed, he unwound like a cable snapping straight: right palm swung upward across the Jigen-ryū man’s jawline while his left forearm shot under the bokken to strike the inner biceps. Two impacts in one long whip. The jaw strike cracked the mouth open; the biceps strike deadened the arm. Momentum carried both of them half a step. The Jigen-ryū fighter swallowed blood and channeled the pain into speed. He backed off a half-step to create room and unleashed an overhead cut from high to low, the kind that, in earlier centuries, broke helmets. He timed it to catch the Piguaquan man as he rose from his drop. But the Piguaquan fighter never rose straight. He rolled to his left, the cut scything past his right shoulder to explode on the floor with a wooden smack that echoed. The bokken’s tip bit into a joint between stones. For a heartbeat, wood was married to earth. The Piguaquan man capitalized. He slid along the outside of the trapped weapon, his right hand pinning the bokken near the tip with a sudden, downward press, and his left foot stepped deep into the Jigen-ryū fighter’s stance, past the lead foot, to the outside. His left forearm slammed across the Jigen-ryū fighter’s collarbones, a bar that drove him backward while his hips twisted, loading a knee. The Jigen-ryū fighter tried to jerk the weapon free, but the angle and the press stole leverage. The knee came. It rose in a tight arc from the Piguaquan man’s right hip and smashed into the Jigen-ryū fighter’s left flank. Air left the lungs in a rough bark. The bar across the collarbones converted the impact into a stumble. He retreated two short steps, ripping the bokken out with a harsh wrench that drew a splinter from the floor. The crowd erupted—boos and cheers like birds taking off. He had space again, but his ribs throbbed. He decided. Jigen-ryū was not a dance. It was a storm. He set his left foot and surged, the bokken now a blur. First, a feint to the inside—tip toward throat—then a sudden heel-turn and a diagonal cut to the outside thigh. The Piguaquan fighter checked the first with a slap, veered off the second by pivoting his knee inward and lifting his foot—barely—so the wood scythed past shin instead of biting bone. The Jigen-ryū man reversed—hips snapping, arms guiding—bringing the blade up in a rising cut that sought the ribs. The Piguaquan man twisted his torso in a corkscrew, letting the cut graze the edge of his ribs while his hands traced two arcs: right hand high, fingers hooked, brushed across the Jigen-ryū fighter’s eyes; left hand low, palm heel slammed into the side of his lead knee. The eye rake didn’t gouge—it blinded. The knee strike shocked the joint. The Jigen-ryū fighter’s world turned white and red. He did what he’d drilled: step through pain. He stepped, but the knee was a fraction slow. He adjusted by collapsing into a low stance, lowering his center and dedicating everything to the next half-second. He thrust, not at the chest this time, but at the hip, aiming to buckle the Piguaquan man’s base. The bokken drove forward with a short, savage shove. The Piguaquan fighter had kept his circling angle, always traveling clockwise. As the thrust came for his hip, he disappeared from the line by stepping back with his right foot and spinning on his left—a tight half-turn that turned his right shoulder away and opened his left side toward the Jigen-ryū man’s flank. The thrust shot past. In the same motion, he let his right arm unwind from the turn, a long-range whipping strike that started at the ankle and cascaded up through the legs, hips, spine, and shoulder. His forearm struck the back of the Jigen-ryū fighter’s elbow as it extended, not to break but to hyperextend the line. The wooden blade skewed down. His left hand, already up, chopped down on the wrist. The bokken fell. It hit the stone with a clatter that cut the air sharper than any shout. The crowd surged in, then checked itself at the perimeter, the ring of bodies tightening like a noose. The Jigen-ryū fighter didn’t lunge for the weapon. He stepped in. Empty hands now. He struck with a straight punch, hips and shoulders unified, the kind that could break a jaw. The Piguaquan man slid to the outside, the punch passing, and he put his forearm across the striking arm’s triceps to guide it on and down while his right palm hammered the Jigen-ryū fighter’s exposed ribs again, same spot, precise as a debt collector. The breath left louder this time. He chained it: left hand snapped up in a vertical palm to the chin, a rising whip. The Jigen-ryū fighter tucked his chin, took it on the forehead, and answered by hooking his left arm over the Piguaquan man’s right and turning—hip to hip—attempting a shoulder throw. The Piguaquan fighter felt the load, let his feet leave the floor a fraction, then stepped around with his right foot in a tight circle to stay glued to the hip. The throw dissipated into a stumble. He landed light, his arm still threaded under the Jigen-ryū man’s. He twisted, locking the elbow against his chest, and sank, pulling down while stepping behind the Jigen-ryū fighter’s right heel with his left foot. A scissoring motion—upper body down, lower body blocked—sent the Jigen-ryū fighter to one knee. The bokken lay an arm’s length away to his left. He could see it. He reached, but the Piguaquan man’s right hand landed on the back of his neck, a heavy, rooted weight, while his left forearm rode the trapped arm like a lever. The Jigen-ryū fighter drove up with his legs, almost standing, almost shrugging off the hold by raw force. The Piguaquan man allowed the rise, then collapsed his own weight to the right, dragging the arm across and down, redirecting power into emptiness. The Jigen-ryū fighter fell forward onto both hands. The Piguaquan man’s knee pinned the triceps. His right hand lifted and fell, a hammerfist into the back of the shoulder. The impact vibrated through bone. “Enough!” someone shouted from the ring’s edge, a voice older than the rest, frayed by years of shouting secrets. The crowd ignored it. The Jigen-ryū fighter surged again, a last uncompromising shove. He twisted his trapped arm, aligned his thumb with the gap, and ripped free at cost of skin. He twisted, rising into the Piguaquan man’s space with a body-check that slammed both of them into a fallen column. Stone scraped skin. For a heartbeat, they were chest to chest again, both wheezing, both stubborn. Then the Piguaquan man dropped his hips and let his arms become ropes once more. His right forearm slid under the Jigen-ryū man’s jaw, not a choke, just a post. His left hand palmed the sternum, pushed, and in the same instant, his right foot hooked the inside of the Jigen-ryū man’s ankle and drew. The combination broke balance forward. The Jigen-ryū fighter caught himself with his left hand against the column, head turned. The Piguaquan man’s palm cut across the ear, a slapping arc, and the world rang. The follow-up was immediate: a palm heel into the ribs, same bruised target, one more time. The Jigen-ryū fighter sagged, his weight listing. The bokken remained on the floor, quiet. The Piguaquan man stepped back a pace, hands up, chest heaving. He didn’t finish. He didn’t need to. The Jigen-ryū fighter pushed himself upright, one hand against the column, breath rasping. He stared at the man who had refused to meet his strikes head-on and had instead stolen their lines. Pride strangled anger into a thin thread. He straightened as much as his ribs allowed, then bowed an inch—stiff, grudging, intact. Around them, the ring broke into shouts and arguments, money snatched or surrendered. Armbands glowed in the lantern light, red and black flashing on both sides. Someone spat at the floor. Someone else laughed too loudly. From the broken altar’s shadow, two figures in the robes of masters had already turned away, their faces unreadable. The Piguaquan man touched the bruise rising on his cheekbone, then adjusted his armband as if to remind himself who he was. The Jigen-ryū fighter lifted his fallen bokken and slid it under his arm. They stood two paces apart, the ruined temple breathing cold air between them, the debt between their schools uncollected and multiplied, the night’s ledger balanced only in their battered bodies.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This narrative presents a meticulously choreographed martial arts duel between practitioners of Jigen-ryū and Piguaquan styles. The piece excels in its technical precision, tracking the fighters' positions, movements, and techniques with remarkable clarity. The author demonstrates extensive knowledge of martial arts mechanics, creating a fight sequence that remains physically coherent throughout. The setting—a crumbling temple with moss-covered flagstones and paper lanterns—provides an atmospheric backdrop that enhances the clandestine nature of the duel. The author effectively establishes the historical rivalry between the two schools through visual cues like the inverted armbands (red field/black slash versus black field/red slash) and the contrasting fighting philosophies. The prose is highly technical yet fluid, using precise language to convey the mechanics of each strike, counter, and positional shift. Phrases like "He didn't try to stop the thrust; he accelerated it off-line with the flick of a catapult" demonstrate the author's ability to explain complex martial movements in accessible terms. The writing maintains a consistent rhythm that mirrors the ebb and flow of combat, with shorter sentences during intense exchanges and longer, more descriptive passages during moments of tactical assessment. Character development is somewhat limited by the focus on physical action, but the fighters' personalities emerge through their fighting styles. The Jigen-ryū fighter's disciplined, direct approach contrasts effectively with the Piguaquan practitioner's adaptive, circular techniques. Their mutual respect at the conclusion feels earned through the shared experience of combat. The narrative avoids common pitfalls of fight scenes by maintaining spatial awareness throughout. The reader always knows where the fighters are positioned relative to each other and their environment. The author skillfully incorporates environmental elements like the floor joints and fallen columns into the choreography. The ending resolves the immediate conflict while acknowledging that the broader rivalry remains unresolved—"the debt between their schools uncollected and multiplied"—which adds thematic depth to what could have been a purely physical encounter. Some minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the technical descriptions become slightly repetitive, and a few instances where the prose edges toward being overwrought. However, these are minor concerns in an otherwise exceptionally well-executed piece. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 15 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 15.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 15.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Physical-spatial: Breaking Formation — Score: 89.8
Prompt:
**"Breaking Formation"** Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of a street dancer from a rough neighborhood who's won a scholarship to an elite K-pop training academy in Seoul. Desperately out of place culturally and technically, they struggle with a militaristically precise choreography that contradicts everything about their improvisational background. The punishing rehearsal takes place under a famous instructor known for breaking students to remake them, who sees potential in the narrator's raw talent but not their attitude. This scene MUST maintain complete physical coherence—each dance move, position shift, and spatial relationship must be tracked with precision throughout the studio. Paint an exceptionally vivid kinetic picture through descriptions that capture not just movement but the contrast between the narrator's fluid, expressive style and the mechanical precision demanded. Their internal monologue should reveal culture shock, class anxiety, and the threatening realization that success here might mean losing their authentic movement voice. Include technical terminology that highlights the collision of street and commercial styles, moments when muscle memory betrays them, and a crucial decision point about whether to conform or rebel. Physical clarity is essential—readers must be able to visualize exactly how bodies move through space, how rhythms align or clash, and how the protagonist's body struggles against unfamiliar discipline. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Speakers in each corner hiss to life, then slam the track into the room like a steel door. Four walls, four mouths, all blasting the same song half a hair too loud, the bass running under the sprung floor like a subway. The mirrors cut a square of me into four versions I don’t recognize: black tee damp at the sternum, training pants cuffed high to clear the ankle, socks snug in the slippers they make us wear to save the floor. Knees soft. Head forward. Neutral spine, the instructor barked. Neutral, like I’ve never been in my neighborhood. “We set from count one,” he says. Choi-sabeomnim doesn’t raise his voice, but when he breathes, the room inhales. He stands at the front-right quarter of the room, a yardstick in his hand like an extra limb. He’s famous, they said. He breaks you clean, then stacks you back like new. His cap is pulled low, but the eyes in the mirror cut. He taps his yardstick twice against the floor. On his left, assistant No. 1 mirrors him; on his right, No. 2 faces us to demo corrections. They form the point of the triangle. We are the base. I settle into the second row, dead center, so I can track alignment off the assistant’s knees. My right foot is on its mark—a sliver of blue tape crossing the wood, lined exactly between the white lines for center axis. Left foot parallel to right, hip-width apart. Hands at my sides, fingers flat. “Breath,” he says. “You dance late because you breathe late.” I inhale and the speakers jump us to count five, the cut clipping off the vocalist’s breath. The snare hits a sixteenth ahead, a kind of swung-kick pattern that wants to pull my chest into it. My city taught me to ride the drag, to melt into a pocket so slow it feels like breaking the law. Here, the counts sit like nails driven exact. “Five six, seven-and—eight!” The first move is a three-quarter plié, both knees tracking over second toe, then a micro-tilt to the right on “and” as shoulders slice left, palms sharp like blades perpendicular to the floor. We’re supposed to be isometric—one body in conflict with itself. I hit the bend fine, my ankles strong, but my shoulders want to sink, want to roll into it. In the mirror, my right palm lists a degree forward. Choi’s yardstick kisses the back of my hand. Not a slap—just a tap that says, here is a hinge, not a rope. We push off the toes to straight legs on “one,” shift weight to left foot without traveling, then whip the head to the right on “two” like it’s mounted on a gimbal. “Isolate,” he says. “Cervical spine only.” My hood rat neck trick from the block—rolling the head like a slow coin—flares up, and I have to clamp down to make it mechanical, no goo. The track’s synths are laser-clean, no grit, no swing. My sternum tightens against the click track in my head I didn’t know I had: the train brakes, the bottle clinks, the open window arguments. We punch a right-arm diagonal on “three,” wrist flexed at ninety degrees, elbow locked, hand to the four o’clock above the shoulder line. The left arm crosses the body horizontal, palm down. On “and,” both snap to the opposite diagonal. A clean, sharp set. The room ticks. Thirty bodies moving exactly through their pathway, no bleed. My right shoulder squeaks internal, a tendon memory from countless windmills in alleys. I fight the urge to let my elbow soften. “Stronger,” Choi says, and the assistant’s tricep feathers stand like a ridge. I force mine to match, scapula cinching toward the spine like it’s stitched. On “four,” there’s a footwork combo—right foot steps to the diagonal, heel leading, toe out, then left crosses behind in a pas de bourrée modified for sneakers; knees kiss, then separate sharply on the “and,” tracing a tiny diamond with my weight. My body wants to throw a bounce into it, a soft rebound through my Achilles, but we’re not bouncing; we’re clocking counts like timecards. Knees shoot, ankles block, pelvis stays level like a tray. I stare at my pelvis in the mirror. Devant no tilt. My jaw clenches. He stops the track. The silence is so loud after that we all reel. “You bleed,” he says, stepping toward me through the second row like a soldier on inspection. He doesn’t have to look around; people part because they know he will not go around them. He stands at my twelve, inches from the tape line that keeps him out of our box. “You’re dripping style like sweat. Wasteful.” “I thought—” The word jumps out of me like a muscle twitch. “You don’t think here.
