You count.” He pivots in a quarter turn back to the front. “Run it from ‘killing part.’” He picks up the remote, scrubs to the hook. The speakers crush it back at us. A metallic chant. The assistant demonstrates the “killing part” slow: a chest pop timed to a vocal cut, then a cannon ripple through the line from front-left to back-right, each body a precise delay. It’s the kind of visual that made me fall for this place online: a human waveform. But the ripple means suppression. You hold yours until the exact eighth where you’re allowed to release. The air moves like a mouth passing air around a circle. We start. “Seven-and—eight.” I’m at position seventeen. The cannon is going to hit me on the “e-and” of “two.” The girl to my left—Saet-byul—fires on “two.” I have to hold until I feel her elbow up in the corner of my left eye, then I have to catch the residual energy without making it look like it traveled through me from her. It’s an illusion: we’re not connected; we pretend we are. I feel her deltoid twitch; I trap my chest, clamp my ribs like a book closed by a palm. “E-and—” I pulse my sternum forward one centimeter, then snap it back, not with a ripple, but with a recoil. It lands on the “and.” We look like a stadium wave. The instinct to add a micro-linger, a smear of funk, almost kills me. I save it by locking my knees harder than they deserve. My quads lurch under me like someone grabbed them. Pain zaps electric along the IT bands. My mouth tastes like battery. “Good,” Choi says, like a coin tossed, not looking at me. We mark through a floor pathway—the section that has us travel, finally. The room is set in quadrants. My line is the second from back. We’re to slide on counts “one, two” on a diagonal track from front-left to back-right, then half-turn to face back on “three,” continue traveling backward on “four,” then quarter-turn to face left wall on “five,” hit a pop on “six,” then a huddle formation on “seven, eight” in the upstage-right corner. Our boxes are taped out—each person’s square is a grave the exact size of their body if they collapse. We’re not allowed to heel-squeak the floor. Silent feet, loud music. “Glide,” the assistant says, demonstrating a heel-toe, to make it look frictionless. They call it a glide here. I grew up calling it a bullet-walk. Same mechanics, different religion. Heel strikes, weight passes to ball with no vertical bounce, knee stays soft, pelvis stable, shoulders counter to keep the head on one line. My old instinct is to head-tilt into the glide, to let the neck carry the swag. Not here. “Keep your eyeline.” Choi’s voice rides above the crush. We go. My right foot leads. “One, two—” my slide is clean. I keep my torso like a shelf, arms floating in a mid-level S-curve, which is wrong. “Arms down,” Choi snaps. I drop them and immediately feel stripped, anonymous, like somebody shaved my signature. “Three,” I turn over my left shoulder, the right foot crossing behind, pivot on the ball; my axis wobbles. The mirror doubles my sway. On “four,” I travel backward. This is where muscle memory betrays me: I anticipate the backspace too wide, my left foot places an inch outside my taped corner. The boy behind me clicks my heel with his toe. A chain-reaction almost starts, a ripple of imbalance, the bad kind, the real one. “Stop.” The room freezes at something like “five-and.” My breath stops too. Choi walks through the ranks toward me. Everyone else is still as mannequins, chests arrested mid-breath. He crouches, the yardstick parallel to the floor, measures the gap between my left foot’s arch and the blue tape. “Eleven millimeters.” He makes me say it. “Eleven millimeters,” I repeat, heat traveling up my neck. The boy behind me is still like a ghost, eyes forward. We’re all in uniform, and I feel like a stain. “You waste eleven for you; you steal eleven from him,” Choi says, pointing the yardstick over his shoulder to the boy. “You think your neighborhood forgives theft?” I swallow. My neighborhood forgives a lot. It forgives scrapes on knuckles and missed shifts. It forgives you for stealing back breath from a night that choked you. But it doesn’t forgive block parties where one person takes the circle and never gives it back. We reset. Counts roll again. The room is a machine. My lungs fight to match. “Six.” The pop is a muted wave from pelvis to sternum. They call it a hit. You create pressure in your core and release it through the shoulders like a shutter. In my street, a hit is messy, an organism. Here, it’s a switch. I try to place it on the “six” exactly, external obliques contracting like doors slamming. This time, the mirror says I landed it. The girl to my left who nails everything like a forklift glances, then nods half a degree. It feels like a medal. Then comes the freestyle eight. Irony is a god with a mean sense of humor. In the middle of all this industrial precision, they give us eight counts to be “ourselves,” but the square is taped and the camera angle is fixed. Choi calls it “contained freedom.” We are to hit the camera dead-on, stay within our four feet by four feet, and present a motif from the choreography in our own texture. The line moves; each dancer takes their eight and passes the baton. In my block we call it cypher, a circle that expands to fit whoever comes in. Here, it’s a rectangle that doesn’t care about your name. My turn is four people away. Ahead of me, the assistant does a tutting phrase, crisp wrists, ninety-degree elbows, fractal geometry unfolding within the square, a modulus of our larger phrase. Next, Saet-byul interprets the glide motif with a micro-lean, a whisper of waacking in the shoulder blade, but she keeps it chaste, within the brand. The boy behind me does a head-isolation on the “and” that’s so clean I forget to breathe. My palms itch. My body wants to go low, take it to the floor, slip a knee spin on the “three,” arc back up through a wave that travels from ankle to wrist like a fuse. But the floor is sacred; you don’t touch it unless told. The tape squares glare. The camera in the back wall—tiny red light on—watches like an unblinking god. I hear my mother’s voice on a spotty call: Baby, don’t let them make you small. I hear my sponsor’s email in my inbox, all clean lines: Your compliance with program standards ensures opportunity. Two gods arguing in my sternum. “Five, six—” It’s my turn. I step forward exactly one half-foot from my mark so I’m centered in the lens, knees soft. On “seven,” instead of exploding, I inhale. My chest expands against the rib cage and the music like I’m stealing air. On “eight,” I bleed the inhale into a micro-body roll starting at the sternum, traveling outward, but I lock each segment as it goes. It’s my move, but spliced into machine language: sternum one centimeter, then clamp; navel one centimeter, clamp; pelvis tilt two degrees, clamp. My shoulders want to slur the note; I slice them instead. On “one,” I set a tut grid with my hands like fences—my neighborhood, but drafted by an architect. On “two,” I drop my level two inches, heels heavy but silent, chin still level. On “three-and,” I give one eight-note of pure me: a neck tick with a shadow of bounce. It tastes like contraband. On “four,” I pretend it didn’t happen, locking back to the academy silhouette, arms in the set position by my quads. The eight dissolves. The baton passes. The speakers spit the next section. Choi doesn’t say anything. He doesn’t have to. His eyes did a flick on my “three-and,” and I saw it. He saw it. He filed it. We drill transitions until the sun slides off the window and the ceiling fluorescents buzz louder than the track. Sweat turns the floor into a map of salt. Knees track. Toes align. Hips square. My feet blister inside the slippers. In the block, we said pain meant you were alive. Here, pain means you’re not symmetrical. When he finally calls a break, the room exhales like it was told it could. People collapse along the wall in staged exhaustion, legs extended precise, backs flat. I walk my square clean to the bench, toe to heel along the tape like I owe it money. I sit. The speaker in the back-left corner hums the next track in its belly like a warning. Saet-byul drops onto the bench beside me, as careful as if in rehearsal. “Your body fights,” she says, in English for me, though I hear the Korean under it. Her sweat smells like citrus hand soap. “I don’t know how not to.” I rub the arch of my foot with my thumb, feel the blister’s ridge. “Where I’m from, if you don’t fight, you get swallowed.” She looks at the mirror instead of me. “Here, if you fight, you don’t form.” She takes a long drink from her bottle, then caps it exactly. “Form first. Then fight inside it.” She stands when Choi stands, like a tide follows the moon. We line up. The choice is a coin in my mouth. If I conform, I earn the scholarship, the residency, the visa that keeps me away from the noise that knows my name too well. If I rebel, I keep the heat that built my body, the rhythm that saved me. But rebellion here looks like sloppiness to a lens. Authenticity looks like error in HD. He counts us in. “Five, six, seven-and—eight.” I place my feet on the tape until they remember they like it. I lock my elbows with a precision that feels like prayer. And on the “and” of “three”—where no one is looking, where the camera angle has shifted to the front line—I let the smallest pulse of my neighborhood ride from my heel to my hip like a secret, hidden inside the beat, so tight it reads as intensity, not defiance. Choi’s yardstick passes behind me on the “four,” and I hear it whisper a millimeter from my hamstring. It doesn’t touch. He says, “Better.” And the word doesn’t feel like an order. It feels like a bridge. I hit the next mark to the millimeter. And I keep my secret burning inside the counts, bright as a streetlight that refuses to blink.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative successfully captures the experience of a street dancer navigating the rigid world of K-pop training. The piece excels in its physical specificity, tracking movements with precision while maintaining the emotional and cultural tensions at its core. The writing creates a vivid kinetic picture through detailed descriptions of dance movements, positioning, and spatial relationships. The narrator's internal struggle between their improvisational background and the mechanical precision demanded is palpable throughout. Technical terminology effectively highlights the collision between street and commercial styles: "In my block we call it cypher, a circle that expands to fit whoever comes in. Here, it's a rectangle that doesn't care about your name." The physical coherence is maintained exceptionally well. Each movement is tracked with precision—from the "three-quarter plié" to the "chest pop timed to a vocal cut" to the "cannon ripple through the line." The writer creates a clear sense of the studio space, the positioning of dancers, and even the minute details of body mechanics. The protagonist's internal monologue effectively reveals their culture shock and class anxiety. Lines like "Neutral, like I've never been in my neighborhood" and "My neighborhood forgives a lot. It forgives scrapes on knuckles and missed shifts" establish the character's background without being heavy-handed. The threat to their authentic movement voice is conveyed through powerful imagery: "I keep the heat that built my body, the rhythm that saved me. But rebellion here looks like sloppiness to a lens." The prose is elegant and rhythmic, often mirroring the dance itself. Sentences vary in length and structure, creating a cadence that enhances the narrative. The writer employs sensory details effectively, from the "speakers in each corner" that "hiss to life" to the sweat that "turns the floor into a map of salt." The piece builds to a nuanced resolution that avoids simplistic answers. The protagonist finds a way to maintain their identity within the constraints of the system: "I let the smallest pulse of my neighborhood ride from my heel to my hip like a secret, hidden inside the beat." This compromise feels earned and authentic to the character's journey. There are a few moments where the technical terminology might be overwhelming for readers unfamiliar with dance, but these instances don't detract significantly from the overall impact. The piece could perhaps benefit from slightly more development of secondary characters, as Choi-sabeomnim and Saet-byul remain somewhat one-dimensional despite their importance to the narrative. Overall, this is an exceptionally well-crafted piece that fulfills the prompt requirements while delivering an emotionally resonant story. The writing maintains physical coherence while exploring complex themes of identity, authenticity, and adaptation. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Gothic-fantasy-humour: Court of the Dreaming — Score: 89.3
Prompt:
Court of the Dreaming: Territorial Dream Dispute. Write a dark fantasy scene with comedic elements set in the Courts of Dream where a case is being heard to determine ownership of a contested dreamscape. Mora, the Slavic nightmare spirit who sits on sleepers' chests causing paralysis and terror, has recently invaded and subverted a carefully crafted recurring dream of a schoolboy, Max. The dream originally featured the boy lying in a field of wildflowers with his crush, always culminating in a muddled almost-kiss and a pleasant confusion of emotions. This dream was the meticulous work of "First Love" (a rosy-cheeked, slightly bashful entity who crafts formative romantic experiences). However, Mora has recently infiltrated the dreamscape, transforming the scene so that when the girl playfully mounts the boy, she morphs into a terrifying yet somehow still confusingly attractive vision who proceeds to sit on his chest and feed on his breath. Mora's defense largely consists of the practical argument that "a girl's gotta eat too, you know?" Write this scene as it unfolds in the courtroom of the Dreaming, with Dream's demeanour, typically impenetrable, betraying a sense of irritation at having to adjudicate such matters. The comedy should derive from the farcical situation, familiar elements of courtroom drama intersecting with the fantastical world of the Dreaming, and the droll portrayal of the characters and their interactions. The humor should be dark and understated throughout. Dream is tempted to some mischief in the resolution of the case. Use descriptives sparingly when setting scene. Write for readability & engagement. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The Court of the Dreaming convened beneath vaulting rafters carved from old lullabies and unresolved anxieties. Lamps burned with the slow, dim light of bedtime stories retold too often. Every whisper in the gallery had the bounce of a sleep-talking murmur, every cough the dry rustle of turning pages. At the center, an hourglass taller than a watchtower dripped shimmering sand. Each grain whispered as it fell, carrying away bits of someone’s almost-recalled memory: the taste of summer peaches, the desire to turn and look one more time, a half-laughed confession. Time in the Dreaming did not so much pass as make it known, and the hourglass made it very known, each drip precise, a soft ticking at the back of all minds present. Dream sat at the bench. He was dressed like midnight wrapped in etiquette. He had the expression of a cat attending a lecture on obedience. His gaze could have flattened storms. It did not flatten bureaucracy. “Let the record continue,” said the Bailiff, who was constructed entirely of good intentions and brass buttons. He had a head like a cufflink and patience like rain. First Love stood at the petitioner’s table, rosy-cheeked and painfully tidy. Their hair curled around the ears like a promise. They clutched a handkerchief embroidered with forget-me-nots. At the defense table slouched Mora, very pale, very amused, perched in her chair as if it were a ribcage. Her eyes were a little too dark, her smile a little too sharp. If she had a hobby, it would have been exhaling on windows and drawing smudged hearts just to press a thumb through the center. Dream nodded to the Clerk. The Clerk, who was a stack of files with legs, flattened a sheaf of parchment and cleared a throat made of rustling paper. “Case Nox-178B,” the Clerk intoned, “First Love versus Mora, also known as Mara the Hag, the Hag-Rider, the Night-Press, and—” Mora waved. “Just Mora is fine, sweetie.” First Love winced. “It isn’t fine.” Dream made the smallest motion with a finger. It felt like a thunderhead changing its mind. “Speak,” he said, with a voice like the underside of a bell. First Love stepped forward, and several elsewheres turned quietly to listen. “My Lord,” they began, “as guardian and artisan of the soft catastrophe of adolescence, I present for your attention: the recurring nocturne assigned to one Max—surname withheld, because privacy is a kind of mercy we still believe in. It is a pastoral. He lies in wildflowers with his crush of three months, who smells faintly of strawberry lip balm and academic anxiety. The scene culminates in a near-kiss, a little blur, a near-electricity, leaving him confused in a gentle way, and transformed on waking. He is kinder at breakfast. He smiles at bus stops. He googles ‘how to talk to someone without sounding like a robot.’” Murmurs of approval from the gallery. Several shy sprites pressed handkerchiefs to their eyes. A row of adolescent dreams—awkward and brave, all elbows—leaned forward, enthralled. First Love continued. “Recently, this carefully balanced progression has been hijacked. The field remains, the girl remains, the nearly-kiss remains—although let us note the quality of the nearly—when suddenly, during a consensual playful moment of youthful exuberance—” Mora perked up. “She hops on top,” she supplied, helpfully. First Love’s blush deepened to an alarming cherry. “At which point the girl morphs into our defendant, who, and I must be clinical here, sits upon his chest and eats his breath.” “Feeds,” Mora corrected, lightly. “A nibble. He has excellent lungs. Very… buoyant.” First Love turned to the bench. “This is corruptive, my Lord. The dream is no longer formative. It is deformative. The child wakes with a sense of shame and terror braided to desire. He cannot parse his own heart. He has begun to avoid eye contact with his crush, and—this part is new—he googled ‘how to tell if you’re cursed?’” A murmur; some laughter, quickly shushed. The hourglass spilled another sigh. Dream angled his head. “Mora.” Mora crossed one leg over the other and stretched like a cat in a church. “Your Majesty of Blankets. Respectfully: a girl’s gotta eat, too. He’s a healthy boy, full of fresh fright and oxygen and the delicate aroma of deodorant he’s not sure how to use. I did not break the dream; I… seasoned it.” “You invaded,” said First Love. “I relocated a picnic blanket,” Mora said. “You weaponized vulnerability.” Mora shrugged. “We all work with what is present. You pluck the strings of first light. I press where the ribs are harp-like.” A grumble from the gallery, which consisted mostly of retired nightmares, a murder of cupid-wannabes, and a gaggle of sentient report cards. One report card sneered at an F in Algebra, as it always did. Dream’s gaze turned to the hourglass. Sand was falling faster than it had any right to. The Bailiff coughed gently and held a hand over the top bulb to slow time. It did not work, but it looked officious. Dream spoke, not loudly, which somehow was louder than any shout. “We do not feed without permission.” Mora rolled her eyes. “Oh please. Ask the Muse of Insomnia about consent. She parades outside windows humming deadlines.” “Insomnia is duly licensed,” the Clerk murmured, wilting a little as a paper corner drooped. First Love seized their moment. “What we do here matters. He will remember this night in twenty years, my Lord. He will not remember me. He will remember the pressure, the breathless helplessness. As a joke, someone will say, ‘crushed it,’ and he will flinch. He will assume the dizziness of longing is a prelude to suffocation. He deserves a first story that ends in a question mark, not a gasp for air.” Mora leaned forward, resting elbows on the defense table as if it were a ribcage too. “Sweetheart. You want to raise them soft as moonbread. But the world is all teeth. If he learns early that desire bites, he’ll keep his fingers. He’ll recognize the taste of his own fear and call it by its name. Isn’t that also mercy?” The gallery made that noise people make when they don’t want to admit a point has struck them. The hourglass sighed again, letting down a more opalescent ribbon of time. A bead of sand caught the light like a ring no one had worn in years. The Bailiff cleared his throat. “Calling Expert Witness: the Dream Itself.” The floorboards shuffled. A constellation stepped down from the rafters, arranged itself politely at the witness stand, and lit the air with a patient shimmer. It was difficult to see the Dream and not be seen through back. The Dream swore the oath, which was redundant. Dream, the arbiter, and Dream, the witness, regarded each other. The absurdity of it kinked the atmosphere into a pretzel. Even the hourglass hesitated in deference. “Make your statement,” Dream said to themself, which was not as easy as it sounded. The Dream-Witness’s voice was a breeze in tall grass, a chalkboard squeak smoothed by rain. “The boy’s field has been combed by two winds,” it said. “One carries clover and embarrassment. One carries iron and night. Both are truths he will meet. The question is order.” “Order,” Dream repeated, the word landing like a gavel before being a gavel. He pressed two fingers to his temple, as though he could pinch away the ache of moderating this family therapy session held on a battlefield. First Love spoke softly now. “Order matters.” Mora spoke like a lullaby gone wrong. “Hunger matters.” Silence arrived, and it sat. Outside the courthouse, a rain of paper planes fell upward toward a ceiling of black velvet. Somewhere, a dog dreamed of chasing its own tail and caught it, and woke. The feeling settled on everyone present for an instant: that odd triumph and pain. Dream’s impenetrable demeanor cracked by a hair. Irritation leaked like ink. “I am”—he gestured, encompassing forests, gutters, high-rise windows, haylofts, monk cells, cars at red lights—“very busy.” His voice sharpened. “And yet. Here we stand arguing who owns the blush beside the bruise.” Mora smirked. “We could share.” First Love looked stricken. “Share? Overlap is not blend, it’s bruise.” “That’s a line,” someone whispered appreciatively. Dream leaned back. His fingers tapped the bench, the sound of rain late at night when you’ve remembered a name too late to use it. He was tempted—clearly, purely—to mischief. You could see it in the tilt of his mouth, in the way the hourglass suddenly, almost playfully, squeezed its stream thinner, a tease of reprieve. “Let us be practical,” Dream said, adopting the tone of someone who is not. “Mora, you may not take what is not offered. You may, however, suggest.” Mora arched a brow. “Suggest? With… pamphlets?” “Atmosphere,” Dream said. “You may be the chill at the edge of the blanket. The knowledge that there is a deeper night nearby. If he turns his head to you, if he invites, if he reaches, you may taste the breath he offers. No pinning. No press. No ribs for harps unless he says, in his own way, play.” First Love visibly exhaled. “And in the meantime?” “In the meantime, you will acclimate him to the nearness of fear. Not to its rule. You will lace the pastoral with the smallest thorn. A bee that is gentle unless squeezed. A cloud that passes. He must know the sky is a ceiling that can fall, and also that most days it does not.” Mora tilted her head. “So, the girl sits astride him—” First Love squeaked. “—and she remains herself,” Dream continued smoothly. “She laughs. She learns the word no, and the word yes, and both fit her like a jacket. If the boy feels panic, the field will widen; there will be room to breathe. If he feels the thrill and wants the weight—only if he wants the weight—then you may be weight.” The gallery rustled with the sound of a thousand sleepers turning over in their beds. Mora considered. “That’s… less fun.” Dream’s eyes cooled a degree. “Your license to haunt adolescent chests in this jurisdiction is suspended for three cycles of the moon.” Mora opened her mouth, closed it, opened it again. “Is this because I called you Majesty of Blankets?” Dream did not smile. “It did not help.” Mora sat back, then leaned forward, sly. “And if he starts googling ‘how to haunt responsibly’?” “Then he is ours,” Dream said, with something like pride. “He is learning.” First Love pressed a hand to their heart, which ticked as if wrapped in tissue paper. “And the dream?” “The pastoral is restored,” Dream declared. “But not sterilized. The almost-kiss remains almost. The confusion remains pleasant. Once, and only once, the wind will carry the scent of iron. It will pass. He will know it can pass.” Mora slouched with theatrical despair. “Fine. Fine.” She stood, blew a kiss to the hourglass. A few grains reversed direction, then thought better of it and continued down. “You are all no fun at parties.” First Love tidied their cuff and, for a moment, looked at Mora not with anger but with something like curiosity. “You could come to the party,” they said. “Just… don’t sit on anyone.” “No promises,” Mora said, hot coal of a smile. But she nodded, almost imperceptibly, a concession small and real. Dream lifted the gavel. It was heavy with the weight of every decision made in sleep and regretted awake. He paused, tempted again to mischief, to splice in a sidelong joke. Perhaps a future dream: Max at a prom, the punch bowl smoking, the chaperone a wolf with a corsage. Perhaps a postscript that would make the boy wake laughing for once, with no explanation. The temptation tugged like a ribbon around his finger. “Adjourned,” he said, and with a single strike, the sound spread like a ripple across a still lake, threading through beds and bunks and hammocks and passenger seats worldwide. The hourglass resumed its dignified drip. Somewhere, Max turned over, a field of wildflowers unrolling behind his eyes, a girl leaning close with the shy question of the universe on her lips. Somewhere at the field’s edge, a shadow kept a respectful distance, patient as a crow on a fence post. The wind was clover, and then for a heartbeat it was iron, and then it was only wind.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully creates a dark fantasy courtroom drama with comedic elements set in the Courts of Dream. The author has crafted a world that feels both fantastical and grounded in recognizable courtroom proceedings, with Dream as the judge mediating between First Love and Mora over ownership of Max's dreamscape. The writing excels in its atmospheric descriptions and characterization. Dream is portrayed with appropriate gravitas and subtle irritation ("He had the expression of a cat attending a lecture on obedience"). First Love and Mora are well-differentiated, with First Love being proper and concerned while Mora is irreverent and predatory. The descriptions are evocative without becoming excessive - "Mora, very pale, very amused, perched in her chair as if it were a ribcage" gives us a perfect image of the nightmare spirit. The dialogue is particularly strong, revealing character while advancing the plot. Mora's flippant "Just Mora is fine, sweetie" and her defense that "a girl's gotta eat too" capture her irreverent nature, while First Love's earnest concern for Max's emotional development feels genuine. The exchanges between characters maintain the dark humor requested in the prompt. The author skillfully balances the comedic and serious elements. The humor derives naturally from the situation and character interactions rather than forced jokes. The description of the Clerk as "a stack of files with legs" and Dream questioning himself as a witness create moments of absurdity that lighten what could otherwise be a heavy scene. The resolution shows Dream's wisdom and mischievous nature, finding a compromise that respects both entities' roles while prioritizing Max's development. The ending is thoughtful rather than simplistic, suggesting that both fear and desire have their place in human experience. There are a few instances where the prose becomes slightly purple ("He was dressed like midnight wrapped in etiquette"), but these are generally balanced by more straightforward passages. The piece maintains its focus throughout, avoiding meandering, and the pacing feels appropriate for a courtroom scene. The author has successfully created the dark fantasy with comedic elements requested, with the humor deriving from the farcical situation and character interactions as specified. Dream's irritation and temptation toward mischief are well-portrayed, and the descriptives are used sparingly but effectively to set the scene. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Fanfic-crossover: Blood Moon — Score: 92.8
Prompt:
Blood Moon Alucard & Yennefer Write a story where Alucard (Hellsing) encounters Yennefer (The Witcher) in medieval Europe. Yennefer's magical abilities intrigue the vampire, while she's both repulsed and fascinated by his monstrous nature. Their power dynamic shifts constantly as they circle each other, neither willing to show weakness first. **Alucard (Hellsing)** Alucard is an ancient, immensely powerful vampire who works for the Hellsing Organization. He can regenerate from almost any wound and shape-shift at will. He's sadistic, arrogant, and takes pleasure in toying with his enemies before killing them. Despite being a monster, he despises weak vampires who can't accept their nature. He wears a distinctive red coat, wide-brimmed hat, and orange sunglasses. He uses massive handguns loaded with silver bullets. He seeks worthy opponents who can challenge him and potentially end his immortal existence. Famous quote: "The bird of Hermes is my name, eating my wings to make me tame." **Yennefer of Vengerberg (The Witcher)** Yennefer is a powerful sorceress who magically altered her appearance to hide her congenital hunchback. She's ambitious, stubborn, and manipulative when necessary. She has violet eyes and smells of lilac and gooseberries. Despite her cold exterior, she desperately wants to reverse her infertility caused by magical transformation. She's centuries old but appears young. She's politically savvy and refuses to be underestimated. She has a sarcastic sense of humor and little patience for fools. Though she rarely shows it, she's capable of deep love and loyalty. Famous quote: "I'm not sweet and I'm not a maiden in distress in need of saving." Third person, present tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The cart wheel lies like a severed limb by the village gates, its rim split, spokes snapped, half-swallowed by churned mud. The moon is red and swollen, hemorrhaging light into the mist that drifts across fallow fields. There is a smell of trampled earth, clean blood, and something subtler: lilac and gooseberries, like a memory intruding on a nightmare. He arrives first as a shadow that remembers it had once been a man. The hat resolves, then the coat—red, as if dyed with the evening itself—and the smile under the orange-tinted glasses, too many teeth in too wide a mouth. Alucard steps around the abandoned wheel, pauses, lays a gloved fingertip on a cracked spoke. The wood whispers of speed and terror—the hurried departure of peasants with more sense than pride. He inhales the fear and lets it roll across his tongue. “How quaint,” he murmurs to the emptiness. “Such fragile things, wheels. Such fragile things, people.” The night answers with the soft concatenation of leather and steel, the click of heels, the faintest rasp of fabric against fabric. Her presence sharpens at the edge of his senses: pressure, heat, a shape in the world drawing lines around itself through will alone. She steps out of the fog with violet eyes and a mouth that promises cruelty and kindness alike—both earned, neither free. Her hair is raven-dark, pinned like a threat. The scent of lilac and gooseberries cuts cleanly through the iron. She looks the abandoned wheel up and down, then him, and her lips tilt. “Villagers ran,” she says. “Imagine that.” He tips his hat without bowing. “A sensible choice. I have that effect.” “So I’m told,” Yennefer replies, and her voice has steel under silk. “You’re not from here.” “I am from everywhere,” Alucard says. “But only when it amuses me.” “Lucky you,” she says, and does not smile. Her gaze drops to the massive handgun at his side, the stretch of leather across his shoulders, then ascends to his face. She notices the glasses last, as if acknowledging the smallest of his lies. “And are you here to amuse yourself on my account?” He bares his teeth. “Perhaps. If you prove...interesting.” The fog tightens around them; the red moon sinks lower, fattened by distance. A faint susurrus of wings ripples across the fields. Ravens watch from crooked fence posts with glossy eyes. In a hut beyond the gates, a candle sputters and dies. The air hums with the porous edge of the world thinning in places that people avoid naming. Yennefer lifts her chin, tasting the same thinness, the same promise of rupture, and Alucard feels her power unfurl like a banner—scented, sharp, uncompromising. “Tell me,” he says, conversational as a gentleman at a wake. “Do you hide your demons under perfume? Or is that cruelty—” he steps nearer, tasting, “—all yours?” “Both,” she says, and flicks her wrist as if to brush off dust. A circle of indigo fire opens in her palm, then closes, coy as an eyelid. “I’m not sweet and I’m not a maiden in distress in need of saving.” He laughs, a raw low thing that makes the ravens shift. “Good. I would hate to be bored.” “It must be dreadful,” Yennefer says, voice dry. “An eternity of nothing but yourself.” “On the contrary.” His glasses flash with a color that doesn’t belong to the moon. “I am excellent company.” “The lonely often say so.” The broken wheel creaks as if remembering its load. The village gate yawns. The moon licks the thatch with red. He moves first—only a blur, the idea of movement. When he stops, he is behind her, and the smoke of his coat is still catching up to the rest of him. The cold metal of his gun is a whisper at her spine, there and gone. In the same heartbeat, the air around her becomes a lattice of invisible knives. She does not turn. Her chin lifts a fraction more. “Do you want to test me?” she asks. “I want to see you,” he counters, amused. “All these masks. Show me what the world made of you.” Her hand opens again, not a circle this time but a square—a window—through which another sky glows: blue and harsh, bleeding into the red like a bruise. It blinks out. She keeps her back to him as he circles, the two of them orbiting the broken wheel like blades around a whetstone. “Once,” she says, “I broke myself to become what I wanted. It cost me, and it was worth it.” “Ah,” he says, delighted. “I do so adore the butchery of becoming. The bird of Hermes is my name, eating my wings to make me tame.” “Tame?” she says. “You?” “Of a sort.” He spreads his arms as if to offer himself to the moon. “We all find our leashes where we can.” “And what’s yours?” she asks. “Orders? Duty? A pretty red coat?” “Hope,” he says lightly. “For a good death.” She laughs then, a genuine sound that shows the edge of her teeth. “You’re not going to find that here.” “You might be surprised.” He slides closer, and his shadow slides with him, wrong in the ways shadows should be. “You smell like wanting. It’s charming.” “Careful,” she says, and the air thunders. The mist collapses and then expands, a lung inhaling. A circle of sigils lights at her boots, geometric and merciless. “I did not ask for company.” “Neither did I,” he says, and his teeth lengthen. “And yet.” They arrive at an agreement without naming it. They test. He fires first, silver hissing through the night like lines drawn on a map. She twists her fingers and the bullets die mid-flight, falling like dull stars, hissing into the mud. He watches the deflection—the angle, the flare—and grins. She flickers, vanishes, appears a pace to the left. His shadow lunges at where she had been and finds only heat, only perfume. Yennefer lifts her palm. A whip of blue-white lightning unfurls and cracks him across the chest, a strip of scorched coat and charred flesh. He laughs through the burn, delighted, and splits into a flock of black-eyed dogs with dripping jaws. They fan out, a semicircle of hunger. She curls two fingers, and the earth rises in a ridge, throwing the nearest dogs away as if they were pebbles. One lunges—she looks into its eyes and unthreads it with a word. It unwinds into smoke, then becomes him again, whole and grinning, the scorch mark closing like a thought dismissed. “Regeneration,” she says, bored, but a sheen of sweat collects at her brow. “How novel.” “For your part,” he says, ducking a shard of ice that would have pinned him to the gate like a specimen, “your discipline pleases me. So many of your ilk wave their hands and pray. You cut.” “My magic is not a prayer,” she snaps, and the air around him hardens, pressure blooming in his bones. For a second he is a pinned insect. He smiles with his eyes and sheds himself, steps sideways out of his skin like a snake. The husk collapses, grinning and empty. She huffs; the line of her mouth softens despite herself. They circle. The wheel watches, a broken omen, and the ravens provide commentary in throaty croaks. On the second pass, he tests her with speed; on the third, with fear—throwing illusions of fire, of a crib burning, of a child with black eyes screaming. She draws breath as if struck. Her hands tremble once. Then her expression shuts like a door. “You do not get to use that,” she says, contempt gentling into something he does not recognize in time to name. She takes the image from the air and breaks it, her fingers closing on its throat until it is only smoke. He tilts his head, curious now, the sadism slipping. “Who broke you?” he asks, sincere as a knife. “I did,” she says. “And I made myself again.” He nods, respectful. The next time she moves, he is not quick enough to avoid the net she drops—a lattice of force as elegant as lace and as merciless as a trap. It cinches around his ribs, his throat. He feels it and remembers constraint; he licks his teeth like a man tasting salt. He could become mist; he could become vermin; he could simply let the guns speak, silver humming a hymn. Instead he leans into it, into her. He lets her think she has him. The net tightens. She steps close, one hand on her hip, the other at her side. Not gloating. Assessing. Her violet eyes are critical, and something like hunger lives there, honest as the moon. “You’re old,” she says. “Older than any I’ve met. Older than sense. What world spat you out?” “All of them,” he says, smiling against a throat that does not need to breathe. “I crawled out of the bottom of history and decided to stay.” “Why?” she asks. “To watch.” “Vain answer.” She looks at his mouth, then his eyes. “Cowardly, too.” He laughs, glad. “Say that again.” “Coward,” she repeats, and her fingers flex. The net bites, a kiss that bruises. He becomes dust then, impatient. The net sinks into powder. Yennefer flinches, surprised, and throws a ward instinctively. He reassembles behind her, mouth at her ear. The gun is nowhere; his hands are pockets, casual as night. “You are right,” he murmurs, and the admission tastes like copper. “I am waiting for someone to be brave enough to end me.” “And you think that’s me?” she asks, still as glass, aware of him like an ache. “I think,” he says, “you might be brave enough to try.” “Not tonight.” She steps forward, and he lets her, the space between them bending and then snapping like a bowstring. She turns to face him. The wheel creaks again, a useless sermon. “I didn’t come here for you.” “Then for whom?” he asks, because curiosity is a leash, too. “Someone who doesn’t matter anymore.” She glances toward the houses, now quiet, now emptied by feet that fled toward thicker forests. “He ran with the rest.” “So disappointing.” Alucard sighs and tilts his head, mock regretful. “I had hoped for a mob.” “They have children,” she says, and he shrugs one shoulder as if absolved. He studies her again, the cut of her, the effort it cost. He likes that she does not hide it from herself. “Will you walk?” he asks. “I don’t stroll under blood moons with monsters for company,” she says, and then, after a beat, with a curve to her mouth, “Not without a purpose.” “Purpose then,” he says. “We could hunt.” “I’m not your hound.” “Nor I yours.” He adjusts his hat. “Perhaps we will meet again when we can agree on a prey.” She considers, measuring him against the hazard he offers. “Perhaps,” she says, and the word is smoke. He bows—an actual bend, spine forming a shape that hints at a court long dead. “Yennefer of Vengerberg,” he says, savoring it. She does not start. “And you call yourself?” “Alucard,” he says. “Of a house that eats itself.” “Fitting.” She draws a line in the air with her index finger. It opens into a slit, a dark corridor smelling of stone and thunderheads. She steps toward it and then pauses, half-turned, violet eyes catching the red of the moon and making something new out of it. “If you try to follow me,” she says, “I will hurt you.” “I encourage it,” he replies, delighted. “Hurt me beautifully.” She snorts, inelegant and perfect. “Find a poet,” she says, and is gone. The slit closes. The night rattles its bones. Ravens shuffle, disappointed. Far off, a wolf howls like a door hinge. Alucard stands by the abandoned wheel and considers the empty village, the fields, the moon unashamed. Then he laughs, a long sound that fills the road and makes the wheel vibrate. “Interesting,” he tells no one, and the word returns to him from the fog, pleased with itself. He tips his hat to the place where she had been and melts into a darkness that is less absence than appetite. Behind him, the broken wheel leans and waits, patient as all ruins, for the next hurried departure. The moon stains everything red, and the gates stand open, as if the night itself is an invitation neither of them has yet decided to refuse.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece is a remarkably well-crafted encounter between Alucard from Hellsing and Yennefer from The Witcher. The author has created a tense, atmospheric dance between two powerful characters who are both intrigued and wary of each other. The prose is exceptionally strong, with vivid imagery that establishes the gothic, foreboding atmosphere from the very first paragraph. The broken cart wheel serves as both a physical object and a symbolic motif throughout the piece, representing the broken boundary between the normal world and these supernatural beings. The blood moon casts its red light over everything, enhancing the sense of danger and otherworldliness. Character portrayal is excellent. Both Alucard and Yennefer are depicted true to their source material while being seamlessly integrated into this shared universe. Alucard's sadistic playfulness, his boredom with immortality, and his desire for a worthy opponent are all present. Yennefer's stubborn pride, magical prowess, and hints at her painful past (particularly the references to infertility with the illusion of a burning crib) are handled with subtlety and respect for the character. The dialogue is particularly strong, capturing each character's distinctive voice. Alucard's formal, almost archaic speech patterns contrast with Yennefer's more direct, cutting remarks. Their verbal sparring reveals character while advancing the tension between them. The power dynamic shifts constantly as requested, with neither character willing to show weakness first. Their magical duel is well-choreographed, showing rather than telling about their respective abilities. The author balances their powers effectively, making neither seem overwhelmingly stronger than the other. The prose occasionally verges on purple but generally stays on the right side of poetic without becoming overwrought. Sentences like "The moon is red and swollen, hemorrhaging light into the mist that drifts across fallow fields" create vivid imagery without becoming excessive. The ending is particularly strong, leaving the encounter unresolved but suggesting future meetings, which feels appropriate for these two immortal beings. Neither has fully revealed themselves to the other, maintaining the mystery and tension. If there are weaknesses, they are minor. A few metaphors might be slightly overextended, and there are moments where the prose becomes a touch too self-conscious in its poeticism. However, these are minimal concerns in what is otherwise an exceptional piece of character-driven fiction. The author has successfully created a compelling encounter between two complex characters from different fictional universes, maintaining their essential natures while creating something new in their interaction. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 19 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 1 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 19.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 1.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Fanfic-crossover: Prison Strings — Score: 90.7
Prompt:
Prison Strings Jolyne Cujoh & Makima Write a story where Jolyne Cujoh (JoJo's Bizarre Adventure) and Makima (Chainsaw Man) cross paths at a supernatural prison facility. Jolyne is immediately suspicious of Makima's falsely sweet demeanor, while Makima is intrigued by Jolyne's Stand ability. Their battle of wits escalates dangerously as Jolyne realizes how manipulative Makima truly is. **Jolyne Cujoh (JoJo's Bizarre Adventure)** Jolyne is the daughter of Jotaro Kujo and the first female JoJo protagonist. Her Stand, Stone Free, allows her to unravel her body into string that she can control. She's hot-headed, foul-mouthed, and doesn't take disrespect from anyone. She was framed for murder and sent to prison. She has a distinctive butterfly tattoo on her arm and wears her hair in two buns. Despite her tough exterior, she's deeply loyal to her friends and family. She can be impulsive but is highly adaptable in battle. She inherited her father's ability to stay cool under pressure but is more emotionally expressive. Famous quote: "If there's no Mickey, this shit ain't Disney!" **Makima (Chainsaw Man)** Makima appears as a young woman with auburn hair and ringed yellow eyes. She's the Control Devil who can dominate anyone she considers beneath her (nearly everyone). She maintains a pleasant, soft-spoken demeanor that masks her manipulative, cold nature. She can create contracts with humans and devils, often exploiting their desires. She's obsessed with Chainsaw Man and wants to control him. She keeps numerous people and devils as pets on leashes. She's practically immortal due to a contract with the Prime Minister. She views humans as lesser beings but mimics human emotions perfectly. Famous quote: "It's okay. Dogs are supposed to die for their owners." Third person, present tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The yard hums with whispers, steel on steel. Chain-link fences within the yard rattle whenever an inmate passes by, a metal chorus to the warden’s bell. Overhead, the sky is a dull bruise, heavy with weather that never breaks. The prison’s new wing is different from Green Dolphin Street—taller fences, smoother cameras, angles that deny blind spots. Jolyne Cujoh stands with her back against concrete that sweats, rolling her neck until the tendons pop. Even in a place like this, she’s a bright streak of defiance: black hair in twin buns, a butterfly tattoo glinting at her arm, eyes that look like they’ve got teeth. She can feel the strings under her skin twitch. Stone Free hums at her touch, a chorus she can mute or sing with. She wants to sing. She wants to punch. “Jolyne Cujoh.” The voice is soft, almost swallowed by the yard, polite as tea. It slips through the fence hum, touches the back of Jolyne’s skull. She turns, already annoyed, already braced for someone who thinks they can order her like a lunch special. The woman in front of her is dressed like she doesn’t belong anywhere near prison: long coat, auburn hair neatly tied back, ringed yellow eyes that look like they cut. She doesn’t wear a prison uniform. She doesn’t wear fear either. Her smile is unassuming, almost warm, like a neighbor holding a plate of cookies. Jolyne doesn’t buy it for a second. “And you are?” Jolyne says. Her thumbs hook under her waistband, posture casual, stance ready. The fence behind the woman rattles as a group of inmates thread past, gossiping, laughing too loud for a place like this. A guard posts himself like a lamppost and pretends not to listen. “Makima,” the woman says. “I’ve been told very interesting things about you.” “Great. You a fan? If there’s no Mickey, this shit ain’t Disney.” Jolyne tilts her head, smiles without humor. “I don’t give out autographs.” Makima’s eyes flicker to the butterfly at Jolyne’s arm and back to her face. “You’re cautious,” she says, approving as if she’s grading a paper. “That’s good.” Jolyne snorts and pushes off the wall. The yard stretches out—concrete, exercise bars, a track painted so faint it could be imaginary. The new wing has a view of the old, and the two prisons eye each other like rival dogs. Something about this place isn’t Green Dolphin, though. There’s a smell like pennies. There’s a quiet behind the noise. “You’re not staff,” Jolyne says, circling a little, measuring distance. “And you’re not an inmate. So what are you?” Makima meets her eyes. It should feel like staring into a pond. It feels like staring into a well that goes all the way down. “I’m here to help you,” she says. “You’ve been framed. That must be very difficult. You want to go home. You want to protect your father.” Jolyne’s smile cracks, becomes teeth. “You know a lot for someone I’ve never met.” “It’s my job to know.” Makima clasps her hands behind her back. On her finger, a neat ring—innocuous. The guards around the yard have gone quiet in that way people do when they’re waiting for something. A breeze strums the fence like a harp. “I would like to see your ability.” Jolyne laughs, short and sharp. “You wanna see my panties, too? There’s dinner for that.” “Stone Free,” Makima says, saying it like prayer, like it’s already hers. The humming under Jolyne’s skin spikes. Heat crawls up her neck; her fingers flex. She takes a step, half-curious, half-itch to swing. “Awfully confident, lady.” “As confident as a person is when they hold a leash,” Makima says. She smiles again. “Show me. I don’t mind if you try to hurt me.” The yard seems to lean in. Jolyne rolls her shoulders. Fine. If this is a trap, she’ll find the teeth and break them. She reaches up and unravels herself—takes the flesh of her forearm and draws it out into shining cords, blue and bright like wire catching sun. The sensation is familiar and wrong in the way a favorite scar is. Stone Free spills, a spool unspooling, threads weaving patterns in the air. The nearest inmates gasp; one crosses himself. Makima’s eyes dilate. Her breath doesn’t hitch; her posture doesn’t change. But her pupils narrow, and it feels like she’s smelling rain. “Beautiful,” she says. “You’re very adaptable.” “That’s a nice way to say you don’t know what I can do.” Jolyne flicks a line and it whips around a yard pole, snaring it with a metallic twang. “That makes two of us. But here’s the difference. I don’t pretend to be your friend.” “I am your friend,” Makima says, and the words drop, heavy, oiled, sliding into the spaces between Jolyne’s ribs. Jolyne feels a tug under the sternum, like a bad dentist is working on her soul. She swallows. Her threads tremble. Stone Free hates the pull and sings louder. “Stand down,” Makima says. The softness of the voice doesn’t match the command. It’s pretty the way poison can be. Jolyne hears the words, and for a heartbeat, she understands why people kneel. It’s the pull of gravity, the urge to put your head in someone’s lap and not worry anymore. She grits her teeth. Jotaro’s stare flickers through her memory like a blade flashing. You don’t bow. You measure. You punch a hole where the light wants to get out. Her strings twist and loop, wrapping around her torso, around her waist, bracing her like a corset of her own making. She ties her own ribs to her spine, an anchor and a promise. “No,” she says. The word is small and solid. She smiles, and it is feral. “I’m not your dog.” Makima tilts her head a fraction. “It’s okay,” she says, gentle. “Dogs are supposed to die for their owners.” “Good news,” Jolyne says. “I’m not housebroken.” The first thread flicks at Makima’s ankle, a tripline that should have toppled anyone else. Makima steps over it like she saw it yesterday. Two guards on the perimeter lay hands on their batons and then freeze, eyes going wide and blank. Makima doesn’t look at them; they’re not worth looking at. She looks at Jolyne. “You’re resisting,” she says, curious. “Interesting.” Stone Free splits, strings radiating like spider silk, a web spinning itself in three dimensions. Jolyne throws it wide, looping high above them, snagging the crossbars of the floodlights and the camera housings, finding traction where there isn’t any. She doesn’t attack head-on. She pulls lines taut to change the way sound travels, sending her voice bouncing, her footfalls elsewhere. She changes the yard. Makima steps into the web and never snags. She doesn’t not-see it. She sees it and makes it irrelevant. Her gaze follows the patterns, calculating. She doesn’t hurry. Jolyne’s stomach flips, cold and thrilled. She loves fights that feel like dancing with knives. “You’re after someone else,” Jolyne says, a line slipping past Makima’s ear, whispering. “You don’t actually give a damn about my case.” Makima’s smile shows the barest suggestion of teeth. “You’re sharp,” she says. “I thought so.” “You keep pets,” Jolyne says. “I keep friends.” “How sentimental.” Makima’s yellow irises ring in the gray light. “Tell me about your father.” “Tell me about yours,” Jolyne snaps back, and throws three lines like fists. Makima doesn’t dodge. She steps forward and the world shivers; the closest guard opens his mouth and bleeds from his eyes without a sound. The three lines hit something that isn’t there, slacken mid-air, like they were cut with a thought. Jolyne feels the sever like a paper cut at the pad of each finger. She hisses. “Who did you make a deal with?” Jolyne asks, binding her right hand into a hard, knuckled weave. “I’ve met devils. I’ve broken devils.” Makima’s smile doesn’t change. “So have I.” Jolyne lunges, low and mean, fists wrapped in her own unraveled sinew. The yard explodes into motion: inmates scatter and then halt as if someone put pause on their spines. The chain-link fence rattles and then goes perfectly still. Jolyne hits the air like there’s resistance there, like the sky is a body pushing back. She takes a breath, and it tastes like copper. Stone Free grips the ground, threads burrowing into concrete, and Jolyne uses herself as pulley and anchor, slingshotting sideways, punching from an angle that wasn’t possible a heartbeat ago. Makima doesn’t even blink. The punch stops a finger’s width from her cheek, and that’s when Jolyne understands that Makima didn’t block her. Someone else did. Every guard and inmate near them is on their knees, eyes wide, arms straining against an invisible weight as if they’re all holding the air shut with their hands. “Bad dog,” Makima says softly, not to Jolyne but to the world. The weight increases. Jolyne’s web groans, threads singing high and tense. Jolyne adjusts. She splits herself thinner, threads like hair, like breath, sliding through the gaps of whatever pressure Makima’s conjured. She throws a line around her own throat and pulls, keeping her head up, reminding her body which way is up. She lets Stone Free pick locks with sound—she hums, a little off-key, vibration traveling down strings to floodlight to camera to the armory door. “I can help you,” Makima says, close now. When did she move? “Your impulsivity endangers your goals. You’re adaptable, but you’re too attached. You would do better under guidance.” “From you?” Jolyne grins, and it isn’t pleasant. “You don’t even know what to do with me. You want me to heel. I bite.” Makima leans in, and there’s the smell of clean paper and the metallic air of the yard. “Heel,” she says, and pushes with something that isn’t air or weight or sound; it’s attention, and it’s a command. Jolyne thinks of her father’s hat and shadow, of Hermes’ laugh, of F.F.’s smile like a little cracked cup. She thinks of the way the sun felt through glass when she wasn’t looking. She thinks of all the times people told her to be quiet. She wraps a thread around every thought and ties them into her sternum, cinches herself closed. “No,” she says again, sweeter this time. Stone Free flushes through her like adrenaline. The lock on the armory clicks. The light stutters. The yard breathes. Makima’s eyes cut sideways to the sound. It’s the smallest thing. It’s enough. Jolyne uses the fraction of nothing like a lever, rolling under the pressure, grabbing Makima’s coat with three cords, not to yank but to map. She doesn’t need to break her. She needs to learn her edges. “Interesting,” Makima murmurs. “You’re learning.” “Fast,” Jolyne says. “Hope you can keep up.” “There’s no need to run,” Makima says, serene. “There’s nowhere to go I can’t go.” “I’m not running.” Jolyne’s grin is sharp. “I’m making noise.” She yanks three floodlights down simultaneously. They hit concrete, burst into sparks that skitter like fireflies. Alarm bells bray. Inmates jerk like puppet strings cut and then reattached; someone starts laughing hysterically. The chain-link fences rattle back to life, trembling in their poles, singing the song of metal freed from attention. Makima does not look annoyed. She looks… engaged. “You fascinate me,” she says. “Gross,” Jolyne says, and then tosses a line high, catches the lip of the roof, and goes, Stone Free hauling her like she’s a bullet on a string. She doesn’t leave her web behind. She takes it with her, reeling in, reweaving, making herself scarce and everywhere at once. She doesn’t forget the way Makima’s voice tugged the marrow from her bones. She files it away. She hates it. She will never forgive it. Makima watches her angle onto the roof, the breeze tugging at her hair, the alarm painting everything red and loud. Guards shout and aim and then lower their guns, their hands shaking. Makima doesn’t raise hers. She touches her ring, almost idly. “We’ll talk soon,” she says, to no one and everyone. “Bring dinner,” Jolyne’s voice drifts back, echoing through the thread-microphones she’s left. “And a leash for yourself.” Makima smiles, a little real now, something like delight in it. “As you wish.” Up on the roof, Jolyne crouches behind an HVAC unit that thrums like a lazy heart. The yard below is in motion, like a brain waking out of anesthesia. Her own pulse is high and hot. Her strings tremble, wanting, pleased. She sits there, breathing hard, and lets the web she’s woven feed her the yard’s conversations: orders, panic, prayers. Somewhere, a woman with ringed yellow eyes steps lightly through it as if it were silk curtains, not a trap. Jolyne presses the pad of her thumb to the butterfly at her arm, not gently. “I’m not your dog,” she whispers, to the sky, to the fences, to herself. Stone Free hums. The hum sounds like promise. It sounds like fight. It sounds like the rattle of chain-link settling back into silence, waiting for the next time someone walks by.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively captures a tense confrontation between Jolyne Cujoh and Makima, staying true to both characters' established personalities and abilities. The author demonstrates a strong understanding of both source materials, weaving together Jolyne's string-based Stand abilities with Makima's manipulative control powers in a believable prison setting. The prose is particularly strong in its imagery and sensory details. Descriptions like "the sky is a dull bruise, heavy with weather that never breaks" and "eyes that look like they've got teeth" create a vivid atmosphere. The author skillfully uses metaphor and simile throughout, such as comparing Makima's gaze to "staring into a well that goes all the way down." Character voices are distinct and authentic. Jolyne's defiant, foul-mouthed nature comes through clearly ("You wanna see my panties, too? There's dinner for that"), while Makima maintains her falsely sweet demeanor that masks her cold manipulation ("It's okay. Dogs are supposed to die for their owners"). The dialogue exchanges are sharp and reveal character through conflict rather than exposition. The action sequences are dynamic and creative, particularly in how Jolyne uses her Stone Free ability to manipulate the environment. The author doesn't just describe the powers but shows how they interact with the setting and each other. The battle of wits escalates naturally, with Jolyne recognizing Makima's manipulative nature and actively resisting it. The pacing is excellent, with tension building throughout the confrontation. The story maintains focus on the central conflict without meandering, and the ending leaves room for continuation while still providing a satisfying conclusion to this encounter. There are a few instances where the prose becomes slightly purple, with metaphors occasionally stacking too densely. However, these moments are rare and don't detract significantly from the overall quality. The piece demonstrates emotional complexity through Jolyne's internal struggle against Makima's control: "She hears the words, and for a heartbeat, she understands why people kneel." This psychological dimension adds depth to what could have been a purely physical confrontation. Overall, this is an exceptionally well-crafted piece that captures the essence of both characters while creating a compelling, original scenario for their interaction. The writing is confident, stylistically consistent, and emotionally engaging. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Scp: Notes from the Future — Score: 91.2
Prompt:
Write an SCP report about a researcher who begins finding handwritten notes from their future self, warning about a containment breach that hasn't happened yet. The notes become increasingly desperate and incoherent, sometimes containing information that contradicts known reality. Include the Foundation's attempts to determine if this is an actual temporal anomaly or psychological manipulation by a contained entity, and the researcher's struggle to trust their own perception. First person (researcher's perspective with interspersed notes), past tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
Item #: SCP-5███ Object Class: Euclid (Pending) Special Containment Procedures: Researcher Dr. H. L. Mora has been placed under observation in a standard psychological monitoring suite at Site-41 with continuous audiovisual recording. All materials utilized by Dr. Mora are to be pre-catalogued, numbered, and stored under lock when not in use. Writing instruments within the suite are supplied by Procurement and Logistics Section-07 (P&L-07), catalogued, and swept daily; their ink chemistry is recorded and archived. Any handwritten notes not matching known inventories and not recorded by cameras during normal use are to be placed in a sealed evidence folder with nitrile gloves, scanned, sent to Ink Forensics (IF-3), and then stored in Secure Evidence Locker 7C. No contained entity is to be allowed physical or audiovisual contact with Dr. Mora without O5/RAISA approval. Temporal Anomalies Department (TAD) has designated the area around Dr. Mora’s suite as a low-probability chronospatial irregularity zone; standard Type-3 temporal anchors have been installed in the corridor outside. Anchor calibration logs are taken twice daily. Memetics Division has initiated Class-III suggestibility testing on audiovisual feeds with no positive hits to date. Description: SCP-5███ refers to a series of handwritten notes that began appearing in proximity to Researcher Dr. Mora beginning ██/██/20██. The notes claim to be written by Dr. Mora at a future date and warn of an impending containment breach involving a currently non-critical entity contained at Site-41 (Entity Designation redacted; see Addendum 5███-E). The notes escalate in urgency and exhibit increasing degrees of informational inconsistency. Ink analysis: IF-3 has found trace elements in the ink inconsistent with any office pens currently in circulation at Site-41 or broader Foundation supply lines. Specifically, the ink contains a detectable signature of organometallic ruthenium complexes and a chlorine isotope distribution that suggests synthesis under non-standard atmospheric conditions (IF-3 Report, Ref. IF-3/41/5███). P&L-07 denies procurement of any such ink. Internal audit yielded no matches to consumer inks. The following is the personal report of Dr. Mora (Researcher-involved testimony authorized by RAISA and Ethics Committee due to ongoing evaluation of potential cognitohazard and/or psychogenic factors). Redactions pertain to active operations. Begin Transcript: Personal Report of Dr. H. L. Mora I signed the form attesting that I would report any anomaly affecting my cognition or senses. I am doing that now. The first note was simple. I found it beneath my keyboard on ██/██/20██ at 08:12 during shift start. The paper was from a Site-41 memo pad, but slightly smoother, as if it had been pressed between glass and allowed to rest too long. The words were in my handwriting but neater, the neatness I aim for when entering data that lives forever in other people’s eyes. “Don’t go into Hallway C at 11:43. Tell Jian to check the vent seals. Bring coffee.” I laughed. Jian (Dr. Li) always complained about the coffee, and vent seals are eternally suspect. I carried the note to Security. We checked the feeds. No one entered my office. The camera scan had one of those empty seconds that we got after the last firmware update. I told myself a tech had mis-synced the timestamp and someone played a prank. At 11:41, I stood up. I was thinking, if this is me, I should follow my own advice. I texted Jian about the vent seals. I held a coffee. At 11:43, a pallet jack loaded with Class-C disinfectant containers rolled briskly down Hallway C. The driver nudged the brake too late and the right front wheel slipped into a crack where a tile had bowed. The pallet lurched; the top container crushed against the doorframe and vented a mist. We had been planning to replace that tile. Two seconds of bleach came like rain. No harm, except to pride and polymer flooring. I watched on the feed next day. If I had been there, the mist would have kissed my face. It would have stung. I wanted to feel grateful. I filed the report anyway with Site Director Yates. Ink forensics took the note. The lab came back with talk of ruthenium. I pretended to understand, and then I pretended not to be impressed. The second note appeared while I was showering in the gym locker room, folded into the cuff of my clean shirt. Three words: “Check containment seals.” The ‘s’ in seals hooked exactly like mine when I’m late. I walked to the lab. Containment (SCP-3114-Sub) hummed in its cube like a frozen lung. Jian called me to look at a pressure readout: a fractional drop across the tertiary gasket. It wasn’t a breach; it didn’t even qualify as an incident, but we filed the maintenance ticket. I drank my coffee and waited for the third note. Security installed additional cameras in my office, in my locker, in the hallway. My coworkers joked about paparazzi. Nothing showed. Then came the third note: “Park on the east lot. Avoid the visitor entrance. There’ll be a man in a red cap. Don’t stop.” There is no visitor entrance at Site-41. We haven’t had external visitors since 20██. But the east lot exists. I parked there and saw no red cap, only the usual low gray of morning and the chain-link fence doing its quiet metal duty. The note sat heavy in my pocket all day like a dare. I imagined the man anyway, standing at a gate that never opens, the cap the kind you buy when you don’t want to think about hats. Security told me to stop complying with the notes. This is how the Foundation keeps us from letting our own pattern-hunger pull us apart. I nodded. Then I read note four in the stairwell between B and C, taped under the handrail where my left hand touched it by accident. “I’m sorry. I thought it would help. It does, but not enough. Please, if you remember, left pocket Wednesday. You’ll understand.” In the pocket was a clip-on pen I didn’t own. The barrel read a brand that doesn’t exist. When IF-3 analyzed it, they found the same ruthenium, the same impossible chlorine. The pen didn’t write. By the sixth note, contradictions began. “Don’t trust Jian” sat on my desk, printed with that neatness my hand only finds when I pretend to be someone else. Later that day, Jian brought me an almond pastry, the sticky kind that leaves a sheen on your fingers and forces you to lick sugar from your polestar lines. Jian has saved my life twice on paper, and once physically, dragging me out from under a shelf when the 9.3 micro tremor knocked Storage G to ruin. The note went into an envelope. I told Security. They told me to accept that an entity could access me. I asked which entity. We had three candidates: SCP-3114-Sub (capable of limited memetic suggestion but blocked by the containment’s opaque mesh), SCP-2120 (a retrocausal echo contained in a Faraday shell two floors down), and SCP-████ (redacted). We also had my own fear, which is not catalogued but leaks through everything. I began recording myself sleeping. I woke to my own voice reading my own notes into a phone I had turned off. When I checked, the phone had no recording and the time on its lockscreen was 03:09, even though it was 06:20. The clocks in my office were three minutes fast for the rest of the morning. The anchor outside my door hiccuped once, a micro-fluctuation TAD called “within tolerance” and that I called “hope.” I met with the Site Psych. She asked me if anyone in my family had a history of writing to themselves. I told her about my father, who wrote shopping lists on the inside of paper bags and then forgot the bag in the car. She asked if I feared the breach more because I imagined I could prevent it. I said yes. Then she asked if I wanted to be the kind of person who listened to herself. I said I did, but not like this. Note eight was smudged. “Don’t look at the camera at 02:16.” It felt childish, the way kids dare each other not to blink. At 02:16, I stared at the ceiling. In the morning, we reviewed the footage. The tape had a pulse, a single black frame, then me looking down, not up, then back to up. TAD said the anchor had logged a nanosecond slip in local phase alignment. I wanted to shout that a nanosecond is a life in certain systems, that the universe is a great unkindness that pretends continuity is the same as mercy. Note nine contradicted physics. It told me my mother was alive. She died in 20██. The note said, “She’ll call at 7:44. Answer. Ask about the rain.” I sat with my phone on the desk and my hands not touching it. At 7:44, the phone rang. Unknown number, area code from the county where my mother never lived. I let it go to voicemail. The message was static punctuated by the sound of wet streets after cars pass, the distinct hiss that is not quite white noise. I listened to it twice. I cried in the stairwell and pretended to have something in my eye when Jian asked. The tenth note told me about the breach. It named the object and the time and the condition: “3114-Sub will slip when the tertiary gasket is replaced. 15:09. The new sealant interacts with the mesh at a molecular level; it’s not inert. It’s hungry. You’ll see the shimmer. You’ll hear the pressure equalize like breath. Tell them to delay by two days. Move the pallet schedule.” I took the note to Yates. We halted maintenance. Procurement checked the sealant. Nothing anomalous. The brand had a new anti-corrosion additive released six months prior; its MSDS said nothing about hunger. We rescheduled anyway. The anchor hummed. The day passed without shimmer. We logged a near miss. Memetics Division brought me in to sit in a dark room and stare at shapes. They showed me ladders and faces and a field of sheep disguised as static. I saw all of them, which is to say I am average, which is to say I am not safe from ambiguity. They asked me what I believed. I said: It feels like me. It looks like me. It writes like me, except when it doesn’t. The contradictions could be noise, or they could be a lure. A lure has hooks even if you throw it back. Note twelve apologized again. The handwriting shook as if the writer had been cold or under sedation. “I thought I could thread it, but threads knot. Please stop reading here. Burn the rest. Trust Jian. Don’t trust me. The breach is not in 3114. It’s in the paper.” I carried that one in my pocket and then did not burn the rest. We conducted an experiment. Security emptied my office, my locker, my desk. I was assigned a blank room with a metal table and a bed and a toilet in a corner with a curtain that felt like a suggestion of privacy. P&L-07 issued me a single pen. It was sealed in a bag with a grin of blue ink barely visible. IF-3 catalogued it like a saint’s fingerbone. I wrote my name. I imagined how, if I were future me, I would get a note into this room. I thought about ventilation shafts, about crawlspace access, about the way the cameras blink when the power tests cycle on Thursdays at noon. At 12:03, the room smelled like ozone. At 12:04, a note lay under my left elbow. I had not felt it placed. The cameras did not see it placed. The anchor log recorded nothing. The note said: “Don’t let them make this a case study. Don’t let yourself be data. I’m sorry. I need you to be a person for this to work.” We tore into the paper with swabs and arrays and gas chromatographs. The ink sang the same song: ruthenium and wrong chlorine. IF-3 said the polymer in the paper held microbubbles that did not release like normal. As if time itself had been a solvent and the page had been rinsed in it. Note fourteen was terror. It used my words but as if someone had scraped them from my mouth. It warned of blood on the ceiling, of alarms that did not sound, of a hole in the wall where there had only been wall. It told me I would wake with my left arm numb and hear the sound of my own voice from behind the closet door. My left arm went numb at 03:17 because I sleep with my neck at bad angles. There was no closet in the room. I began to distrust myself. I began to watch my hand when it wrote, certain that in the flourishes of the letters I would find a traitor.
